text:
Leo Abaya (Leo Antonio Calceta Abaya) is a film production designer, design consultant, and film director. He was born in Sampaloc, Manila on Dec 1960. He is the son of Dr Servando Abaya and Beatriz Calceta. He grew up in Tagbilaran City, Bohol, with five siblings. In 1981, he graduated from Holy Name University with a bachelor’s degree in economics. Fourteen years later, he graduated from the University of the Philippines Diliman with a bachelor’s degree in fine arts (painting), magna cum laude. He received his master’s degree in fine arts (painting) in 2005 at Winchester School of Art, University of Southampton, United Kingdom.

In 1986, a month after the EDSA Revolt, Abaya was recruited by then production designer Brillante Mendoza to work as the art director for Diary of Vietnam Rose, an unfinished film. Other early works as production designer or art director include Di Maghilom ang Sugat (The Wound Never Heals), 1986; Salamangkero (Magician), 1986; Lihim ng Kalapati (Dove’s Secret), 1987; and Estudyante Blues (Student Blues), 1989.

In 1988, he received nominations as a production designer from the PMPC Star Awards for Movies and Gawad Urian for Misis Mo, Misis Ko (Your Wife, My Wife) and Itanong Mo sa Buwan (Ask the Moon). In 1990, he won the PMPC Star Awards and the Young Critics Circle trophies in production design for Bakit Kay Tagal ng Sandali? (Why Is a Moment So Long?). In 1998, Abaya won awards in the Metro Manila Film Festival, the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), and the Gawad Urian for the production design of Jose Rizal. Other critically acclaimed works of Abaya as production designer are Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 1999; Kubrador (The Bet Collector), 2006; and Dukit (Carving), 2013.

Abaya worked as a production design consultant for some movies including Jay, 2008, and five films in 2010: Paano na Kaya? (What If?), Miss You Like Crazy, Babe, I Love You, Bulong (Whisper), and In the Name of Love. In 2013, he directed Instant Mommy, an entry in the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival.  Written by Gregory del Carmen

Manolo Abaya (Manolo Roxas Abaya) is a cinematographer and film editor. He was born in Manila on 5 Feb 1954 to parents Cesar C. Abaya and Catalina Roxas. He studied at De La Salle College from grade school to high school. After graduation, he took up a diploma course in filmmaking at the London International Film School in England. He married movie director Marilou Diaz-Abaya, with whom he has two sons: Marc, an actor/singer, and David, a cinematographer.

After learning all that he could about film in London, Abaya returned to the Philippines to set up the family’s own movie production outfit, Cine Filipinas Inc. His partners in this venture were his wife and two high school buddies, film assistant director Gregg de Guzman and sound director Amang Sanchez. Their first movie production was Tanikala (Chains), 1980, a period film. When not producing movies, they rent out their equipment to other filmmakers and conduct seminars and workshops for aspiring talents.

Abaya received two Gawad Urian trophies for Best Cinematography, one for Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983, which he did solo, and the other for Pahiram ng Isang Umaga (Lend Me One Morning), 1989, where he collaborated with Eduardo Jacinto and Nonong Rasca. He also won Best Cinematography in the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) for Karnal. He was nominated by the Gawad Urian for Best Cinematography for Alyas Baby Tsina (Alias Baby Tsina), 1984, and Misis Mo, Misis Ko (Your Wife, My Wife), 1988, and also for Best Editing, jointly with Mark Tarnate, for Brutal, 1980.  Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja

Richard Abelardo (Richard Velayo Abelardo) was a film director and visual effects artist. He was born in San Miguel, Bulacan on 29 Sep 1900. He died in Quezon City on 27 Aug 1993. He was the son of Juan Abelardo, a scenic painter, and Cecilia Velayo, a designer of women’s costumes. He was educated at San Miguel Elementary School in Bulacan and Manila High School. He studied at the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts. He was a cousin of the famous composer Nicanor Abelardo, brother to cinematographer Bayani Abelardo, and uncle to Ben Resella, art director of Sampaguita Pictures who later became a scenic artist in Hollywood. He married Maria Saret who is also a movie director.

Abelardo went to the United States to train as scenic artist in early Hollywood films, such as Footlight Parade, 1933, and Charlie Chaplin’s Modern Times, 1936. In local movies, he pioneered the art of cinematographic wizardry. To him have been attributed such awesome and wondrous cinematic effects as human princes turning into figures of stone and vice versa in Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941; the fantastic floating castle in Prinsesang Basahan (Princess in Rags), 1949; the biblical Red Sea parting at the stroke of a cane in Tungkod ni Moises (Moses’s Cane), 1952; handsome Jaime de la Rosa transformed into a horrifying bat creature in Taong Paniki (Bat Man), 1952; Bayani Casimiro dancing upside down from ceiling-to-wall-to-floor in Big Shot, 1956; and the terrifying giant reptile monster sowing havoc in Tuko sa Madre Kakaw (Gecko at Madre Cacao), 1959. Abelardo collaborated with Carlos V. Francisco aka Botong for the production design of some films that he directed, among them Haring Kobra (King Cobra), 1951, where a mythical Balinese country near the Philippines was created; and Higit sa Korona (Above the Crown), 1956, where the illusion of ancient Egypt provided the backdrop for the longest sword fight in local movie history.

The other films Abelardo directed include Malikmata (Illusion) and Engkantada (Enchantress), 1948; El Diablo (The Devil), 1949; Mutya ng Pasig (Muse of Pasig), Nuno sa Punso (Old Man of the Anthill), and Doctor X, 1950; Shalimar, 1951; Krus na Bakal (Iron Cross), 1954; Zarex, 1958; Miranda and Lastik Man (Plastic Man), 1966.

Abelardo was conferred the Lifetime Achievement Award by the Film Academy of the Philippines in 1985 for his outstanding contributions to the movie industry. He received the Natatanging Gawad Urian from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino in 1990 for his outstanding achievements in film.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

Tommy Abuel (Tomas Rosales Abuel Jr) is a theater, television, and film actor. He was born in Naga City on 16 Sep 1942. His parents are Tomas Abuel, a school principal, and Angelina Rosales. He finished elementary and high school at Lucban Elementary School and Lucban Academy, and earned a bachelor’s degree in political science at the Ateneo de Manila University. He graduated from the Ateneo de Manila Law School and practiced law for seven years. He represented the Philippines at the ASEAN Film Festival in Bangkok in 1976. In 1982, he traveled with Bulwagang Gantimpala to represent the country at the Taiwan Theater Festival and the Philippine Independence Day celebration in Moscow.

While at Ateneo in the late 1960s, Abuel acted in productions directed by Fr James B. Reuter, who cast him in such musicals as Brigadoon, West Side Story, and Carousel. He also acted in Rolando Tinio’s translation of Little Foxes titled Mga Ibong Mandaragit (Birds of Prey), 1968; Tony Perez’s Anak ng Araw (Child of the Sun), 1970; and the Philippine Educational Theater Association’s (PETA) Ang Tao, 1970, a translation of Everyman. He appeared regularly for five years in Teatro Pilipino productions: as the priest in Santa Juana (Saint Joan), 1975; Leonidik in Kawawang Marat ( The Promise ) and Orosman in Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira), 1977; and Romeo in Romeo at Julieta (Romeo and Juliet), 1978. He played major roles in Bulwagang Gantimpala productions: as Andres Bonifacio in Katipunan: Mga Anak ng Bayan (Katipunan: Children of the People), 1978; Crisostomo Ibarra in Kanser (Cancer), 1979; Corporal Bombita in Bombita, 1981; the lead roles in Gregorio Aglipay, 1981, and Tolentino, 1983; Florante in Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1988; Simoun in El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1988; and the Pilot in Munting Prinsipe (The Little Prince), 1991. Abuel also acted for other theater companies: Repertory Philippines’s Suddenly Last Summer, 1968, and Glass Menagerie, 1977; PETA’s The Chinese Wall, 1971; UP Repertory Company’s Ang Panahon ni Cristy (The Times of Cristy), 1979; and Tanghalang Pilipino’s Ang Balkonahe (The Balcony), 1991 and Mga Gerilya sa Powell Street (The Guerrillas of Powell Street), 2008 and 2009, an adaptation of Benjamin Pimentel’s novel of the same title. He was featured in Enchanted Kingdom’s Reader’s Theater during its fifth anniversary celebration in 2000. At St. Paul University Manila College of Music and Performing Arts’ celebration of its 65th year in 2006 titled Balik Tugtugan III (Return to Jamming III), he was the narrator in Tom Scott’s Creation, conducted by Oscar C. Yatco. He was one of the participants in Pepe Goes to Market, 2008, in celebration of Jose Rizal’s 147th birthday by the Artists Welfare Project. He was also one of the narrators in the concert titled One with You Forever: A Tribu te to Fr. James B. Reuter, 2009.

As a stage actor, he also performed in Mapaghimalang Birheng Caysasay / The Miraculous Virgin of Caysasay, 2005, 2006, and 2008; Martir sa Golgota (Martyr in Golgotha), 2006; Into the Woods, 2007; Cory: The Musical , 2008, 2009, and 2011; The Male Voice and A Song for Two Tribes, 2009; and Totong Hilot (Toto the Healer), 2012.

As a film actor, he appeared in Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), Pira-pirasong Langit (Pieces of Heaven), and Diligin Mo ng Hamog ang Uhaw na Lupa (Water the Parched Earth with Dew), 1975; Itim (The Rites of May), Bata Pa si Sabel (Sabel Is Still a Child), and Putik Ka Man … Sa Alabok Magbalik (Even If You Are Mud … To Dust You Return), 1976; Gomburza and Mga Basag na Kristal (Crystal Fragments), 1977; Hermano Pule (Brother Pule), 1979; Karma, 1981; T-Bird at Ako (Lesbian Love ), 1982; Working Girls and Bukas … May Pangarap (Tomorrow … There’s Hope), 1984; Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), Moises Padilla Story: The Missing Chapter, and Bakit Manipis ang Ulap? (Why’s the Cloud So Thin?), 1985; Sa Kuko ng Agila (In the Claws of an Eagle), 1989; Moro, 1991; Akin ang Pangarap Mo (Your Dream Is Mine), 1992; Sana Maulit Muli (Second Chances), 1995; Mulanay: Sa Pusod ng Paraiso (Mulanay: Deep in Paradise), 1996; Tirad Pass: The Story of Gen. Gregorio del Pilar, 1997; Esperanza: The Movie and Mahal Na Kung Mahal (Okay, Fine, I Love You), 1999; Senswal (Sensual), 2000; Don’t Give Up on Us, 2006; Lovebirds, 2008; Fausta and Last Viewing, 2009; and Ang Babae sa Sementeryo (The Lady in the Cemetery), 2010.

Since the 1960s, he has essayed roles in television drama anthologies, such as Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), Coney Reyes on Camera, Lovingly Yours, Helen, Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), Hilda, Vilma, and Nora; and drama series like Esperanza, 1997, Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001, Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), 2007, Katorse (Fourteen), 2009, Sabel, 2010-11, and Marimar, 2015.

Abuel won Best Supporting Actor awards: twice from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag in 1976 and Karma in 1982, and another from the Metro Manila Film Festival for his role in Moises Padilla Story: The Missing Chapter in 1985. He received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Aliw Awards in 2010.   Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Trixie Dauz

Mike Accion (Miguel Bautista Accion) was a cinematographer and a film actor and director. He was born in Catanduanes on 10 Jan 1919. He died in Manila on 15 Jan 1992. His parents are Rafael Accion and Filomena Bautista. He finished high school at the University of Manila. He was married to Josette Collin Macalalag, sister of actor Mario Montenegro, with whom he had six children.

In 1939 he was recruited to work in Sampaguita Pictures by Representative Pedro Vera, a provincemate who was one of the founders of the studio. He started as a clapper boy in the films of director Carlos Vander Tolosa. Through self-study, he learned how to operate a camera. When Tolosa transferred to LVN, Accion was made assistant cameraman to cinematographers Remigio Young and Rafael Salumbides. His first film was Malaya: Mutya ng Gubat (Malaya: The Forest Nymph), 1948, starring Mila del Sol and Teody Belarmino. He was assistant cameraman to Ray Lacap in Hantik (Black Ant), 1950, which won the Maria Clara Best Supporting Actor award for Tony Santos Sr. He became a full-fledged cinematographer in Kandelerong Pilak (Silver Candlesticks), 1954, which won for Lilia Dizon the Best Actress award in the Cambodian Film Festival. He was also the cinematographer of Malvarosa, 1958, which won for Rebecca del Rio the Best Supporting Actress award in the 5th Asian Film Festival held in Manila.

Within the span of 55 years that he worked in Philippine movies, Accion was cinematographer to the best film directors in the industry, including Gregorio Fernandez, Eddie Romero, Lamberto V. Avellana, and Gerardo de Leon. He worked on such films as No Place to Hide, 1955; Kundiman ng Lahi (Love Song of the Race) and Surrender–Hell!, 1959; Blackburn’s Guerrillas and Cry Freedom, 1960; Tagumpay ng Mahirap (Triumph of the Poor), 1965; Ibulong Mo sa Hangin (Whisper to the Wind), 1967; Mariposang Dagat (Sea Butterfly), 1977; Sino’ng Pipigil sa Pagpatak ng Ulan? (Who Will Stop the Rain from Falling?), 1978; and Kasal o Asawa? (Marriage or Spouse?), 1983. He also photographed the prizewinning Avellana documentary El Legado (The Legacy), 1959.

As actor, Accion appeared in films like Ang Lalaki (The Male), 1947; Sierra Madre, 1948; Tambol Mayor (Big Drum) and Kandidato (Candidate), 1949; In Despair , 1950; and Donato, 1954. In his later years, he turned to movie directing and made Kung Kaya Mo, Kaya Ko Rin (If You Can Do It, So Can I), 1978, with Christopher de Leon, and Coed, 1979, with Vilma Santos and Jay Ilagan.

Accion received Best Cinematography awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1957; El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1962; and Ang Daigdig ng mga Api (The World of the Oppressed), 1965. From the Asian Film Festival, he received two awards for his cinematography: the first time for Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956 when it won the Best Picture award and swept all categories, and the second time for Badjao, 1957, when his work was singled out as Best Photography in Black and White. The Citizens Council for Mass Media gave him a Best Cinematography award for A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965. He received the Natatanging Gawad Urian from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino in 1983 for his outstanding contributions to Philippine cinema, and the Film Academy of the Philippines Lifetime Achievement Award in 1992.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

Actors Workshop Foundation (AWF) is a nonstock, nonprofit foundation that aims to provide training to actors through workshops. Organized as the Actors Workshop in 1983, it originally functioned as the education committee of the Katipunan ng mga Artista ng Pelikulang Pilipino (KAPP) aka Filipino Screen Actors Guild, conducting regular workshops for KAPP’s member-actors, professional extras, and bit players. In May 1985, the Actors Workshop became a private foundation and opened its doors also to nonprofessional actors and other acting enthusiasts. Its founders were noted actors and directors from the film industry, including Johnny Delgado, Laurice Guillen, Peque Gallaga, Leo Martinez, Ishmael Bernal, Rudy Fernandez, Amy Austria, Vivian Velez, Rowell Santiago, Mario Taguiwalo, and Ricardo Puno Jr. The AWF membership as well as its teaching staff is composed largely of practicing actors involved actively in film, television, and theater.

The AWF specializes and offers courses in improvisation and the Eric Morris system of work. It also conducts special craft workshops for specific movie productions, and one-on-one tutorials for lead and support actors. Its centerpiece project is its AWF Scholarship Program for Young Actors which provides selected talents a year-long curriculum and training in acting.

At one time, AWF produced a 30-minute daily TV drama called Wakasan (Endings) which served as a practicum for workshop participants. In March 1988, it set up a theater company which produced a play, Manly-linlang (Filipino adaptation of Norman, Is That You?) at the Manila Film Center.

The AWF is recognized by the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) as an educational entity for its actors and is a member of the FAP Board of Governors.  Written by Mauro F. Tumbocon Jr

Art Acuña (Arthur Topacio Acuña) is a theater, television, and film actor. He was born in Manila on 11 Dec 1961. He is the son of Rafael Diaz Acuña and Maria Cecilia Topacio. He finished high school at Don Bosco Technical Institute in Makati City and took up political science at De La Salle University.

Acuña was part of the Ma-Yi Theater Company group of Asian-American actors who received the prestigious 2003 Obie Award for the play The Romance of Magno Rubio, 2002, which held its premiere in New York City. In 2008, he received a Best Actor nomination from the Philstage Awards for the Performing Arts for his performance in the Manila run of Golden Child, 2008. Acuña was also a cast member of the comedy play God of Carnage, 2012, together with Lea Salonga, Adrian Pang, and Menchu Lauchengco-Yulo. Acuña further gained popularity after being nominated at the International Emmy Awards for Best Performance by an Actor for his role as Shaw in The Kitchen Musical, 2011. He was nominated for the same role at the 2012 Monte Carlo TV Festival. Before the hit television show, Acuña also appeared in Third Watch, 2001, and Law & Order: Criminal Intent, 2005, crime drama series produced by the US-based National Broadcasting Corporation; in Curse of the Crimson Mask, 2013, produced by ESP Films; and in local shows produced by ABS-CBN, such as Maria la del Barrio, 2011-12, Princess and I, 2012-13, and FPJ’s Ang Probinsyano (FPJ’s The Country Boy), 2016.

He appeared in international films like Amigo (Friend), 2010, and The Bourne Legacy, 2012. Together with Joel Torre, Yul Servo, and Ruben Tizon, he received the Best Actor award at the Cinemanila International Film Festival for Lav Diaz’s Batang West Side (West Side A venue), 2001. He was also awarded Best Supporting Actor in the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival and the Gawad Urian for the films Niño (Boy), 2011, and Posas (Shackled), 2012. He also starred in independent movies Woman of the Ruins, Diplomat Hotel, Bingoleras (Bingo Players), and David F, 2013, and Bang Bang Alley, 2014. He was in the cast of Jerrold Tarog's Heneral Luna, 2015, where he played Col Manuel Bernal, Gen Antonio Luna's trusted aide.  Written by Kathrina Alvarez

Irma Adlawan (Irma Santonil Adlawan-Marasigan) is a theater, television, and film actor. She was born in Tondo, Manila on 7 Mar 1962 to parents Pedro C. Adlawan, a retired colonel of the Philippine Air Force, and Conrada Santonil. She is married to lighting designer, technical director, and stage director Dennis Marasigan. They have four children, one of whom, Mara Paulina, is also an actor. Adlawan had her early schooling at St. Mary Magdalene School in Kawit, Cavite. In 1979, she entered Maryknoll College, and then transferred to the University of the Philippines (UP) Manila a year later. In 1982, she shifted to speech and drama at UP Diliman, completing the entire course in 1987, save for her thesis. She was information coordinator for the First ASEAN Theater Festival in 1988, and handled drama workshops for children. She was newswriter/newscaster for DZRJ-AM Broadcasting Company in 1987.

Adlawan’s stage work began with Dulaang UP in 1983 when she acted as Helena in William Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream, under the direction of Tony Mabesa. Among her best works for the different theater groups in UP are Anton Chekhov’s Three Sisters as Irina, 1984; the translation of Ugo Betti’s The Queen and the Rebels as Argia, 1985; the translation of Faye Michael Kanin’s Rashomon as Kinume, 1985; and Moliere’s Misanthrope as Celimene, 1987. She started acting for Tanghalang Pilipino (TP) in 1991, and in the same year became a resident actor in its Actors Company. For TP, she is best known for her performances in Jose Y. Dalisay Jr’s Mac Malicsi, TNT as Sally Sumulong, 1991; Dennis Marasigan’s Ang Buhay ay Pelikula (Life is a Movie) as the Chinese producer, 1992; Chekhov’s Seagull as Nina; Carlo Goldoni’s Sigalot sa Venetia (Brawling in Chioggia) as Checca, 1992; Tony Perez’s Oktubre, Noong Tayo’y Nagmamahalan Pa (October, When We Were Still in Love) as the Woman, 1993, Sa North Diversion Road (On the North Diversion Road) as the Woman, and Nobyembre, Noong Akala Ko’y Mahal Kita (November, When I Thought I Love You) as Woman 1, 1994; Francisco Baltazar’s Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira) as Zafira, 1993; and Rene Villanueva’s Teodora as Teodora, 1993. Other roles for TP productions include Cely in Anatomiya ng Korupsyon (Anatomy of Corruption), 1992, 1998, 2002; Zafira in Orosman at Zafira, 1993; Mary Helen in One Hundred Songs of Mary Helen Fee, 2001; the prostitute Brontsatski in Ang Pokpok ng Ohio (The Whore from Ohio), 2005; Siu Wong in The Golden Child, 2008; and Leda Santos in Mga Buhay na Apoy (A Breath of Fire), 2015. She also acted in Repertory Philippines’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino as Candida, 2009, and Medea as Medea, 2010; and Dulaang UP’s The Forsaken House as Doña Encarna, 2012. She also performed as Desdemona in Tanghalang Ateneo’s Otelo: Ang Moro ng Venecia (Othello), 2008.

She has also appeared on television in drama shows such as Cecile Guidote-Alvarez’s Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), Behn Cervantes’s Angkan (Clan), and Mario O’Hara’s Mama, as well as in several TV commercials. She was part of the TV series Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001; Kay Tagal Kang Hinintay (So Long Have I Waited for You), 2002; Encantadia (Fairyland), 2005; Komiks (Comics) and Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), 2006; Marimar, 2007; Lobo (Wolf), 2008; Parekoy (My Comrade), Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), The Wedding, Nagsimula sa Puso (It Began from the Heart), and Only You, 2009; My Cheating Heart, 2009-10; Amaya, 2011; Alice Bungisngis and Her Wonder Walis (Giggly Alice and Her Wonder Broom), Magdalena: Anghel sa Putikan (Magdalena: Angel in the Mud), Angelito: Batang Ama (Angelito: Young Father), and Sana Ay Ikaw na Nga (I Hope You’re the One), 2012; and Titser (Teacher) and Got to Believe, 2013. She also played roles in episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2011, 2012, 2013; and Magpakailanman (Forever), 2013.

In movies, her works as an actor include Tuhog (Larger Than Life), 2000; Mga Munting Tinig (Small Voices), 2002; Naglalayag (Silent Passage), 2004; ICU Bed, Sa North Diversion Road, Nasaan Ka Man (Wherever You Are), and Mga Pusang Gala (Stray Cats), 2005; Tukso (Temptation), Signos (Signs), and Ataul for Rent (Coffin for Rent), 2007; Hubad (Naked), A Very Special Love, Dose (Twelve), Puting Ilaw (White Light), and Huling Pasada (Last Trip), 2008; Mangatyanan (Blood Trail), Kamoteng Kahoy (Cassava), Ang Panggagahasa kay Fe (The Rapture of Fe), and Heavenly Touch, 2009; Vox Populi and Amigo (Friend), 2010; Wedding Tayo, Wedding Hindi (We Can or Not Wed), 2011; Sta. Niña (Saintly Girl), 2012; and Island Dreams, Bamboo Flowers, and Transit, 2013. She directed the “Walang Ilaw” (No Lights) episode of the tribute show Daisies, 2007, in celebration of Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana’s 90th birthday.

She was awarded first prize at the 1986 Intercollegiate Shakespeare Contest sponsored by the British Council; Excellent Performer at the 1992 Toyama International Amateur Theater Festival in Toyama, Japan; and Best Actress of the Year by the Young Critics Circle in 1992 for her performance in Ang Buhay ay Pelikula. She won Best Stage Actress in the Aliw Awards for One Hundred Songs of Mary Helen Fee in 2002, for Speaking in Tongues in 2005, and for Ang Pokpok ng Ohio in 2006. In 2008, she was inducted into the Aliw Awards Hall of Fame.

She won Best Actress for Mga Pusang Gala in the Film Academy of the Philippines Luna Awards in 2006, Best Supporting Actress for Ataul for Rent in the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards in 2008, and Best Actress for Transit in the 2013 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival.  Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido and Vladimeir B. Gonzales
