Tessie Agana (Maria Teresa Rigotti Agana-Ja) is a film actor. She was born in Manila on 16 May 1943. Her parents are actor Linda Estrella and Dr Adriano Agana. She studied at St Paul College, Quezon City, and the Philippine Women’s University. She is married to Dr Rudy Jao, and their nine children reside with them in Gary, Indiana, USA.

Agana was discovered by Dr Jose R. Perez of Sampaguita Pictures, who gave her a bit part as a solo ballet dancer in Milagro ng Birhen ng mga Rosas (Miracle of the Virgin of the Roses), 1949. This was followed by Campo O’Donnell (Camp O’Donnell), 1950, a war film, where she portrayed the daughter of Pancho Magalona and Linda Estrella. Her biggest break came when she portrayed the role of a maltreated waif in Roberta, 1951. The film broke box-office records and helped Sampaguita Pictures rise again after a big fire gutted its studio. She became the most popular child star of the 1950s, sharing top billing with major stars, such as Pancho Magalona and Lillian Leonardo in Anghel ng Pag-ibig (Angel of Love), 1951; Gloria Romero in Rebecca, 1952; Ramon Revilla and Sylvia La Torre in Ulila ng Bataan (Bataan Orphans), 1952; Katy de la Cruz and Norma Vales in Cumbanchera, 1953; and Fred Montilla in Nagkita si Kerubin at si Tulisang Pugot (Cherubim Meets the Headless Bandit), 1954. She was under exclusive contract with Sampaguita and did not work for any other movie company except Alta Productions, the Agana firm that produced Kung Ako’y Maging Dalaga (When I Grow Up to Be a Lady), 1955. When she was 14, her family migrated to the United States but she returned briefly to do some teen movies with Jose Mari, Love at First Sight, 1960, and Amy, Susie, Tessie, 1960, and again with Gloria Romero and Luis Gonzales in For You Mama , 1970, before she married and settled there for good.

Agana received the Maria Clara Award as Best Child Actress for her dual-role performance in Eddie Romero’s Prinsesa at Pulubi (The Princess and the Pauper), 1951, an adaptation of the classic The Prince and the Pauper.  Written by Joy Galvez and Lena S. Pareja

T. D. Agcaoili (Teofilo Dumlao Agcaoili), also known as Ernesto Ventura, Albino S. Rey, Cornelio Mauricio, Jaime D. Lagasca, Juan O’Brien, Manuel Dumlao, Vicente P. Candido, Constancio Bermudez, and Primero, was a fictionist, screenwriter, film director, and poet. He was born in Laoag, Ilocos Norte on 5 Mar 1915. He died in Quezon City on 1 Jun 1987. He was the son of Adriano Agcaoli, a goldsmith, and Juana Dumlao. At 19, he married Emma Knowlton. Actor Adriana Agcaoili is his daughter. He studied in public schools in his native Ilocos and obtained his bachelor of philosophy degree at the University of the Philippines (UP). While in college, he became president of the liberal arts student council, literary editor of the Philippine Collegian, and member of the UP Writers’ Club.

In the mid-1930s, he was active as a member of the Veronicans. In 1934, he became news editor of Graphic. Later he became publicity manager of FilippineFilms and editor of Philippine Cinema and Radio. During World War II, he served as a major in the anti-Japanese resistance, was imprisoned in FortSantiago, and took to the mountains upon his release. After the war, Agcaoili worked as literary editor of This Week, the Sunday magazine of the Manila Chronicle. He organized Palaris Films with Fernando Poe Sr, and wrote the script for its first film, Dugo ng Bayan (I Remember Bataan). He became a movie columnist of Sunday Times Magazine. He filmed the war in Korea in 1952. He also joined Royal Productions (the old Palaris Films) as production manager. For Royal, he wrote and directed Ulilang Anghel (Orphaned Angel). His other screenwriting credits include: Awit ni Palaris (Song of Palaris), 1946, based on his own short story of the same title; Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), 1958; and Halik na Lumalatay (Welting Kiss), 1977, which he also directed.He was also credited as a story consultant of Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956, Badjao, 1957, and Kundiman ng Lahi (Love Song of the Race), 1959.

He was known for his radical writings: at a time when pro-Americanism was prevalent, he was considered anti-imperialist. Among his short stories are “Dugo ng Bayan” (Blood of the Nation), “Intramuros,” “Palaboy ng Tadhana” (Vagabond of Fate), “Awit ni Palaris,”, “The Filipino Boy,” and “We Who Rove.” Some of his stories, such as “Dugo ng Bayan” and “Palaboy ng Tadhana,” have been adapted for the screen. He also wrote erotic poetry. Some of his poems are “I Remember the Way You Cross a Room,” “Golden Music,” “Great Dawn,” “Mysterious Way,” and “Lamentations.” His works were published in major magazines and anthologized in Manuel Viray’s Heart of the Island, 1949, and Philippine Poetry Annual: 1947-1949, 1950. He edited an anthology of contemporary Philippine literature, Philippine Writing: An Anthology, 1953.

Agcaoili’s “The Filipino Boy,” 1937, and “We Who Love,” 1939, are on Jose Garcia Villa’s roll of honor of short stories. His short stories were posthumously collected in two volumes titled T. D. Agcaoili Collected Stories, 1992-94.  Written by Rosalie Matilac and F. Cao

Ditoy Aguila (Edilberto Aguila) is a sound designer. He was born in Quezon City on 13 Nov 1971 to parents Eddie and Connie Aguila. He studied at Ateneo de Manila University where he finished a bachelor’s degree in business management in 1983. He is married to Isabel Yotoko. They have two children.

Aguila is the president of Sound Crew, a Filipino company doing original music and jingles for corporate audio-video productions, TV commercials, and movies. Among their works are themes from popular TV shows such as Saksi (Witness), Reporter’s Notebook, and Emergency, aired on GMA Network. He is also the head of the audio-post department at Ignite Media, a complete postproduction outfit with film and video editing and visual effects services.

Between 2003 and 2005, Aguila also worked as the head of sales and a specialist for Digital Media, the distributor of Pro Tools in the Philippines. He assisted in the design and setup of various facilities and studios in Manila, from schools to television networks like GMA and ABS-CBN. Part of his job was also to train engineers in these facilities.

Aguila won recognition from various award-giving bodies. From the Metro Manila Film Festival, he won Best Sound awards for the following films: Exodus: Tales from the Enchanted Kingdom, 2005, Mano Po 5: Gua Ai Di (I Kiss Your Hand 5: I Love You), 2006, Resiklo (Recycle), 2007, and Super Inday and the Golden Bibe (Super Inday and the Golden Duckling), 2010. From the Gawad Urian, he won Best Sound for Tirador (Slingshot) in 2008. From the Film Academy of the Philippines, he received Best Sound awards for Ouija in 2008 and Baler in 2009, both of which also won the same award for him in the PMPC Star Awards for Movies. From the Star Awards, he also won Best Sound for Ang Panday (The Blacksmith) in 2010, Patikul in 2012, and Tiktik: The Aswang Chronicles in 2013. From the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, he received Best Sound awards for Baler in 2009, Ang Panday (The Blacksmith) in 2010, and Ang Panday 2 (The Blacksmith 2) in 2012. From the Young Critics Circle Film Desk, he won Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration for Adela in 2009, Biyaheng Lupa (Soliloquy) in 2010, and Kalayaan (Wildlife) in 2013. From the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, he received the Balanghai trophy for Best Sound for Astig (Squalor) in 2009.  Written by Christian Co

Tikoy Aguiluz (Amable Emiliano R. Aguiluz VI) is a film director, producer, screenwriter, and cinematographer. He was born in Manila on 1 Jan 1952. He graduated from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman with a degree in comparative literature and fine arts. In 1976, he co-founded the UP Film Center (now the UP Film Institute Film Center) where he served as assistant director until 1990.

Aguiluz’s first film was a 15-minute documentary titled Mt. Banahaw, Holy Mountain, 1976. The film won the Silver Trophy at the Young Filmmakers of Asia Festival inIran. In 1984, Aguiluz made his first feature film, Boatman. Starring Sarsi Emmanuelle, one of the hottest bold stars at the time, Boatman was both a commercial and critical success. Its bleak yet realistic depiction of poverty and the lives of live sex performers set the film apart from the soft-porn films being made at the time. Aguiluz’s next project was co-directing Viva Films’s Balweg: The Rebel Priest, 1986, the true-to-life story of Fr Conrado Balweg, the Catholic priest-turned-revolutionary leader who founded the Cordillera People’s Liberation Army.

It took almost a decade before Aguiluz made his next film, the docudrama Bagong Bayani (Unsung Heroine), 1995. Bagong Bayani explores the real events surrounding the execution of Flor Contemplacion, the Filipino domestic worker in Singapore who was sentenced to death for killing her fellow domestic worker, Delia Maga, and the four-year-old son of Maga’s employer. Helen Gamboa as Contemplacion was awarded the Gawad Urian for Best Actress. Aguiluz’s next film, Segurista (Dead Sure), 1996, is about a beautiful young insurance agent Karen (Michelle Aldana) who is forced to work at an escort club at night so she can provide a better life for her family living in lahar-stricken Pampanga. The film won the Best Director award for Aguiluz in the 1997Gawad Urian, as well as Best Picture, Best Screenplay, Best Editing, Best Production Design, and Best Supporting Actor (Albert Martinez). The following year, Aguiluz made Rizal sa Dapitan (Rizal in Dapitan), 1997. Produced on a shoestring budget, the film tells the story of Jose Rizal’s life while in exile in Dapitan. Rizal sa Dapitan swept the major awards at the 1997 Metro Manila Film Festival, 1998 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards, and 1998 Star Awards for Movies. When it competed in the Festival International du Film Independent in Brussels, it won the Grand Jury Prize in addition to the Best Actor award for lead star Albert Martinez who played Rizal.

Between 1998 and 2003, Aguiluz made four feature films: Tatsulok (Triangle), 1998, Biyaheng Langit (Paradise Express), 2000, Tatarin (St John’s Day Ritual), 2001, and www.XXX.com, 2003. In 2011, he made the Metro Manila Film Festival entry Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story. Aguiluz later claimed that the producers shot additional scenes and re-edited the film without his knowledge, prompting him to ask lead star and producer Jeorge “ER” Ejercito to remove his name in the film’s credits. In 2015, he made Tragic Theater, an adaptation of GM Coronel’s book about the ghost haunting the abandoned Manila Film Center. In 1999, Aguiluz founded the annual Cinemanila International Film Festival. The festival showcases weeklong screenings of films from different parts of the world together with film-related seminars and workshops.

In 2003, the French government awarded Aguiluz the Chevalier dans l’Ordre des Arts et Lettres (Knight in the Order of Arts and Letters) for his contributions to Philippine cinema.  Written by Elvin Valerio

Rosa Aguirre was a film actor. She was born in Laguna on 25 Jan 1908. She died on 9 Oct 1981. She married actor Miguel Anzures and together they appeared in several movies before the war. Actor Narding Anzures was their son. Another actor, Lito Anzures, was a nephew.

Aguirre made her screen debut in Sampaguita Pictures’s Himagsikan ng mga Puso (Revolt of the Hearts), 1938, which was based on the novel by Julian Cruz Balmaseda, Tala ng Bodabil (Star of Vaudeville). Her other prewar movies are Mapait na Lihim (Bitter Secret), 1938, with Rosario Moreno; Pasang Krus (Cross on the Shoulder), 1939, with Corazon Noble and Rogelio de la Rosa; Gabay ng Magulang (Parent’s Guidance), 1939, with Yolanda Marquez; Walang Tahanan (Homeless), 1939, with Carlos Padilla Sr; and Takip-silim (Twilight), 1939, the picture that launched the famous love team of Carmen Rosales and Rogelio de la Rosa.

Aguirre was famous for her mother roles. After the war, she appeared in Lamberto V. Avellana’s Death March, 1946; Luis F. Nolasco’s Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows) and Mga Busabos ng Palad (Slaves of Destiny), 1948; Eddie Infante’s Ina (Mother), 1948; and Tony Arnaldo’s Anak ng Pulubi (A Beggar’s Child), 1951. During the 1950s, she was an exclusive contract star of LVN Pictures for mother roles in films like Pag-asa (Hope), 1951; Tia Loleng (Aunt Loleng), Tenyente Carlos Blanco (Lt Carlos Blanco), and Matador (Bullfighter), 1952; Tumbalik na Daigdig (Topsy-Turvy World), 1953; and Sa Paanan ng Bundok (At the Foot of the Mountain), 1953. She was also in the cast of Lino Brocka's Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (You Were Weighed But Found Wanting), 1974, and Tahan na Empoy, Tahan (Stop Crying Now, Empoy), 1977. 

She was part of the cast of Sebya, Mahal Kita (Sebya, I Love You), which started as a radio show over DZXL and was later made into a movie by LVN in 1957. On television, she appeared as a mainstay in the sitcom Si Tatang Kasi (Blame It on Father), 1970.

Aguirre won the Citizens’ Award for Television as Best Supporting Actress for Si Tatang Kasi in 1970. She was nominated by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences as Best Supporting Actress twice: for Kundiman ng Lahi (Love Song of the Race), 1959, and Mahal Kita, Inay (I Love You, Mother), 1962.  Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja

Marvin Agustin (Marvin Jay Marquez Cuyugan) is a film and television actor. He was born in Paco, Manila on 29 Jan 1979. He is the youngest son of Ma. Teresa Aquino Marquez and Danilo Punongbayan Cuyugan. He went to St. Rita College for high school. In 2001, while being active in the show business industry, he took up management of the arts in the Asian Institute of Management. In 2004, he took fundamentals of culinary arts in the International School of Culinary Arts and Hotel Management. He now runs a chain of restaurants and a concert and events production company.

Agustin was first launched in ABS-CBN Star Magic’s Star Circle Batch 2 in 1996 along with Jolina Magdangal, Carlo Aquino, Diether Ocampo, and Mylene Dizon. He appeared in a number of movies but is best known for his team-up with Jolina Magdangal. Together, they appeared in Flames: The Movie, 1997; Labs Kita, Okey Ka Lang? (I Love You, Okay with You?), 1998; Hey, Babe, 1999; and Gimik: The Reunion (Hang Out: The Reunion), 1999. Agustin proved his versatility by appearing in films of different genres, like the family comedy-drama movie Ang Tanging Ina (The One and Only Mom), 2003; the award-winning dramatic movie Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000; and the film adaptation of Lualhati Bautista’s acclaimed novel Dekada ’70 (The 1970s), 2002, where he played the young political writer Emmanuel “Em” Bartolome.

Among his first TV appearances was in the youth-oriented TV series Gimik (Hang Out), 1996-99. While filming movies, he was also doing Esperanza, 1997-99, for ABS-CBN where he played the younger brother. Shortly after Esperanza, Agustin starred in Sa Sandaling Kailangan Mo Ako (The Moment You Need Me), 1998-99, directed by Olivia Lamasan. He went back to teaming up with Magdangal in the TV comedy series Labs Ko si Babe (I Love Babe), 1999-2000. From 2001-2004, Agustin joined Dominic Ochoa and Rico Yan in the sitcom Whattamen. In 2004, he left ABS-CBN and transferred to rival network GMA Network where he appeared in a number of TV series, such as I Luv NY (I Love NY), 2006; Mga Mata ni Anghelita (Anghelita’s Eyes), 2007; Babangon Ako’t Dudurugin Kita (Sweet Revenge), 2008; Lalola, 2008-9; and Panday Kids (Blacksmith Kids), 2010, as the villain Lizardo. He also hosted GMA’s weekly drama anthology Dear Friend, 2008; the variety show Party Pilipinas (Party Philippines), 2010; and the cooking game show Kitchen Superstars, 2011. He transferred to TV5 where he hosted Artista Academy (Artist Academy), 2012, and produced and hosted the cooking show Karinderya Wars (Food Stall Wars), 2013. Agustin returned to his home network ABS-CBN in 2014 and was reunited with former love-team partner Magdangal in the remake of Flordeliza, 2015.

Agustin received awards like Best New Movie Actor from the 1998 PMPC Star Awards for Movies for Flames: The Movie, and Best Actor from the 2005 Metro Manila Film Festival and 2006 Film Academy of the Philippines for his performance in the horror film Kutob (Hunch), 2005.  Written by Lorelie Legisniana

Gina Alajar (Regina Liguid Alatiit) is a film, television, and theater actor, and television director. She was born in Manila 28 Jun 1959. She is the eldest child of Bernardino Alatiit of Roxas City and Angelica Liguid of Cavite. She was married to actor Michael de Mesa, with whom she has three children—two of whom, Ryan Eigenmann and Geoff Eigenmann, are actors. Their marriage was annulled in 2006. She attended grade school at P. Burgos Elementary School. After high school, she took a one-year course in tourism and travel at Centro Escolar University. She was a member of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines (CAP), which was headed by her mentor and friend, the late Lino Brocka.

Alajar was only eight years old when she auditioned for Lea Productions’s Kaibigan Ko’ng Sto. Niño (The Holy Infant Is My Friend), 1967. She stood out among the almost 300 aspirants and played the title role opposite Roderick Paulate. Later, she appeared in several films produced by Sampaguita Pictures. One of her early movies is Donata, 1968, where she plays the role of the girl who grows up to be Gina Pareño. She is the young Irene Marcos in Pinagbuklod ng Langit (Joined by Heaven), 1969, and is one of the children in Lino Brocka’s Wanted: Perfect Mother, 1970. By the time she appeared in the remake of Cofradia, 1973, in the role popularized by Gloria Romero in 1953, Alajar was already a Sampaguita contract star.

Her other films include Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels without Heaven), 1970; Robina, 1971; Mga Basag na Kristal (Crystal Fragments), 1977; Modelong Tanso (Fake Model), 1979; Diborsiyada (Divorcee) and City After Dark, 1980; Kontrobersyal (Controversial) and Playgirl, 1981; Moral, 1982; Dalmacio Armas, 1983; Orapronobis (Fight for Us), 1989; “Ate” (Elder Sister) episode of Shake, Rattle & Roll 3, 1991; Jose Rizal, 1998; Bahay ni Lola (Grandma’s House), 2001; Singsing ni Lola (Grandma’s Ring) and Mano Po (I Kiss Your Hand), 2002; Mano Po 5: Gua Ai Di (I Love You), 2006; and Mater Dolorosa and The Reunion, 2012.

As a director, she worked with GMA Network in such television series as Rio del Mar and Kirara: Ano ang Kulay ng Pag-ibig? (Kirara: What is the Color of Love?), 1999; Narito ang Puso Ko (Here's My Heart), 2003; Asian Treasures, 2007; Tween Hearts, 2010; Temptation of Wife, 2012; Unforgettable, Anna Karenina, and Villa Quintana, 2013; Yagit (Pushcart of Dreams), 2014; and Let the Love Begin, The Half Sisters, and Destiny Rose, 2015.

On stage, she performed in Dulaang UP’s Misteryo ng Pumpon ng Rosas (Mystery of the Rose Bouquet), 1992, a translation of Manuel Puig’s play of the same title, and Larawan (A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino), 1993, where she played Paula opposite Malou de Guzman who played Candida. 

Alajar won awards for child actor for Kaibigan Ko’ng Sto. Niño from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 1968 and for Wanted: Perfect Mother from the Citizens’ Council for Mass Media in 1971. Later, she received Best Supporting Actress awards for Brutal, 1980, from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF); for Kaya Kong Abutin ang Langit (I Can Reach the Sky), 1984, from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP); for Andrea, Paano Ba ang Maging Isang Ina? (Andrea, How Does One Become a Mother?), 1990, from the MMFF and the FAP; for Biktima, 1990, from the FAMAS, the Gawad Urian, and the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA); and for Mulanay: Sa Pusod ng Paraiso (Mulanay: Deep in Paradise), 1996, from the Gawad Urian. She won Best Actress awards in the Gawad Urian for Brutal in 1981, for Salome in 1982, and for Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim (My Country: Gripping the Knife’s Edge) in 1986. At the 1991 CMMA, she also won Best Actress for Andrea, Paano Ba ang Maging Isang Ina?   Written by Galileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

Panchito Alba (Alfonso Discher Tagle Sr), also known as Panchito, was a film, theater, and television actor. He was born in Paco, Manila on 25 Feb 1925. He died in Manila on 18 Dec 1995. His parents were actor Etang Discher and businessman Igmedio Tagle. He finished secondary education at E. Rodriguez High School in Quezon City. He was married to singer Annie Mendoza Martin. His son Panchito Jr was also in show business.

In 1942, Alba joined the Travel Stage Show. He performed at the Orient Theater together with Dolphy, among others, in 1945. Goaded by Bayani Casimiro, he joined the movies and first appeared in Sa Isang Sulyap Mo, Tita (With One Glance from You, Tita), 1949. Since then, he appeared in many films and came to be known as Dolphy’s sparring partner. Some of his memorable movies are Kala bog en Bosyo (Kalabog and Bosyo), 1950; Eca Babagot (Don’t You Dare), 1961; Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life) and Dakilang Tanga (The Great Idiot), 1968; and Ang Mahiwagang Daigdig ni Pedro Penduko (The Mysterious World of Pedro Penduko), 1973. He portrayed a variety of roles: a Western gunfighter who challenges Dolphy to a duel in Barilan sa Baboy-Kural (Gunfight at the Pig Corral), 1962; a wacky private sleuth in Detektib Kalog (Detective Kalog), 1963; a fierce tribal chieftain in Tansan vs Tarsan, 1963; a hippie in Beatnik, 1960; and the devil himself, Lucifer, in Si Lucio at si Miguel (Lucio and Miguel), 1962. He also played supporting roles in several blockbuster comedies starring Vic Sotto, such as Crocodile Jones: The Son of Indiana Dundee, 1990; Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), 1991; and Boy Anghel: Utak Pulburon (Boy Anghel: Harebrained), 1992. Panchito also appeared on television as a regular co-host of Dolphy in the long-running Buhay Artista in the 1960s and as guest actor in many other shows.

Alba won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Supporting Actor award not for playing a comedian but for portraying the tragic character of Kabesang Tales in Lupang Kayumanggi (Brown Land), 1955. He was also nominated Best Supporting Actor by the FAMAS for his comedic performances in Kung Ano ang Puno, Siya ang Bunga (Whatever Is the Tree, That Is the Fruit), 1967; Dakilang Tanga (Great Stupid), 1968; and in Ang Mahiwagang Daigdig ni Pedro Penduko, 1973.  Written by Romulo P. Baquiran Jr and Anne Frances Sangil

Mike and Johnny Alcazaren are film animators. Mike (Miguel Gonzalez Alcazaren) was born on 3 Jun 1954. Johnny (Juan Gonzalez Alcazaren III) was born on 24 Oct 1960. Their parents are Juan Alcazaren Jr and Rolinda Gonzalez. Architect Paulo Alcazaren is their brother. Filmmaker Whammy Alcazaren is their nephew. Johnny is also a sculptor. Mike and Johnny finished elementary and high school at Don Bosco Technical College. Miguel obtained his bachelor of arts degree in communication arts from Ateneo de Manila University, while Juan earned his bachelor of science in landscape architecture at the University of the Philippines. They received no formal training in animation, but learned it on their own through readings and practice. In the clay animation company they set up, Miguel and Juan serve as director and design engineer, respectively. Their siblings, Gabriel and Marita, work as model makers.

The Alcazaren brothers have made eight animated films using clay: Hari (King), 1982; Headset, 1983; Huling Trip (Last Trip), 1983; Juan de la Cruz, 1984; Pagpula (Becoming Red), 1984; Ang Klon (The Clone), 1985; and C.O.D., 1989. All, except Ang Klon, won awards in short film festivals of the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines and the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). In 1992, Johnnyexhibited his metal sculptures at the CCP Small Gallery.  Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

Adolfo Alix Jr (Adolfo Borinaga delos Ama Alix Jr), also known as Adolf Alix, is a film and television director, screenwriter, and producer. He was born in Makati City on 17 Oct 1978. His parents are Adolfo E. Alix Sr and Adelaida delos Ama. He graduated magna cum laude with a bachelor of arts degree in mass communication at Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila.

In 1997, Alix attended the scriptwriting workshop of the Film Development Foundation of the Philippines Inc (FDFPI) conducted by Nestor U. Torre, for which he wrote Ada. This work later won first prize in the nationwide FDFPI Scriptwriting Contest. Director Carlos Siguion Reyna bought the rights and adapted it into Kahapon May Dalawang Bata (Yesterday Children), 1999.

In 2006, Alix made his debut as director in the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival with Donsol, which later won Special Jury Prizes at the 2006 Fort Lauderdale International Film and the 2006 Asian Marine Film Festival. He has become one of the prolific directors of his generation with more than 20 feature-length films in a span of 10 years. His notable films are Kadin (The Goat), 2006; Nars (Nurse), Tambolista (Drumbeat), and Batanes, 2007; Daybreak, Adela, and Imoral (Immoral), 2008; Manila, Aurora, Karera (Ante), and Muli (The Affair), 2009; Chassis and Presa (Female Prisoner), 2010; Haruo (Springtime Man), Isda (Fable of the Fish), and Liberacion (Freedom), 2011; Kalayaan (Wildlife) and Mater Dolorosa (Sorrowful Mother), 2012; Death March, Porno, and Ang Alamat ng China Doll (The Legend of China Doll), 2013; Padre de Familia (Head of the Family) and Kinabukasan (The Day After), 2014; and Whistleblower, 2015. He wrote the screenplays for Gil Portes’s Mga Munting Tinig (Small Voices), 2002, which won Best Screenplay at the 2003 Palm Beach International Film Festival, and Homecoming, 2003; and Joyce Bernal’s D’Anothers, 2005.

Alix directed GMA News TV’s six-part series Bayan Ko (My Country aka The Politician), 2013, about the idealism and exploits of a young mayor. It won Best Drama Series at the Catholic Mass Media Awards and Best Inspirational Drama in the 2014 Asian Rainbow TV Awards. He directs a weekly drama anthology, GMA News TV’s Wagas (Sincere), which won gold honors in the 2014 US International Film and Video Festival.

Presa won Best Picture in the Independent Section of the 2010 Metro Manila Film Festival. Liberacion was chosen Best Narrative Film at the 2011 International Film Festival Manhattan (IFFM). Haruo won Best Film in the 2012 Young Critics Circle (YCC) Film Desk Citations and the Independent Feature Award in the 2012 IFFM. Kalayaan won the NETPAC (Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema) Award for Best Asian Film at the 30th Warsaw International Film Festival and Best Production Design for Alix at the Directors Showcase section of the 2012 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. Mater Dolorosa won Best Director at the 2013 Gawad Urian. Porno was voted Best Film by the Young Critics Circle Film Desk for 2013 and won Alix the Gawad Urian for Best Production Design. Kinabukasan won Best Short Film in the 2015 Gawad Urian.  Written by Rica Arevalo

Josabeth Alonso, also known as Atty. Joji Alonso, is a film producer. Her son Nico Antonio is a film and television actor. A lawyer by profession, Alonso has been very visible in the independent filmmaking scene as a producer since 2004. Many of the films she produced were awarded in the Philippines; some traveled all over the world and reaped awards in film festivals abroad. A few of the films she produced became commercial hits.

Under MLR Films, she was executive producer of Minsan Pa (One Moment More), 2004, with John Alonte, Percie Managuelod, Dot Ramos-Gancayco, and Rogelio Rayala; Kubrador (The Bet Collector), 2006, with Rogelio Rayala; and Biyaheng Lupa (Soliloquy), 2009, with Josephine Bautista-Tence and Armando Lao. She was also executive producer of Mga Pusang Gala (Stray Cats), 2005, with Martin Marfil and Rogelio Rayala in a co-production of MLR Films with Erasto Films Inc.

Under her own Quantum Films,she was executive producer of Bisperas (Trespassers), 2011, Ad Ignorantiam, 2012, and The Diplomat Hotel, 2014. She was also executive producer of Magkakapatid (Blood Ties), 2010, with John Victor Tence in a co-production of Quantum Films with the Film Development Council of the Philippines and Crimson Light Productions; Ang Babae sa Septic Tank (The Woman in the Septic Tank), 2011, with Chris Martinez, Marlon Rivera, and John VictorTence in a co-production with Martinez Rivera Films and Straightshooters Media; Posas (Shackled), 2012—where she was concurrently creative consultant—with Armando Lao and John Victor Tence; and Babagwa (Spider’s Lair), 2013, with Kamaru Productions. Save for Ad Ignorantiam, all six films were produced in cooperation with the Cinemalaya Foundation.

She was the executive producer and producer of Here Comes the Bride, 2010, with Orly Ilacad of OctoArts Films, and Malou Santos and Charo Santos-Concio of Star Cinema; executive producer and creative producer of The Strangers, 2012 , a co-production with MJM Productions with Edgar Mangahas and John VictorTence. She was also executive producer of Ekstra (The Bit Player), in a co-production with John VictorTence, Jeffrey Jeturian, and Vilma Santos-Recto; Gaydar (Gay Radar), 2013, with Alemberg Ang and Alvin Yapan, in collaboration with Vim Yapan/Alem Chua Productions and the Quezon City Film Development Commission; Beauty in a Bottle with Enrico Santos, Malou Santos, and Charo Santos-Concio in collaboration with Skylight Films; English Only, Please, 2014, in collaboration with Buchi Boy Films, with Edgar Mangahas, Fernando Ortigas, and Eduardo Rocha; and Tandem, 2015, with Alemberg Ang and Ferdinand Lapuz, in collaboration with Tuko Films and Buchi Boy Films.

She was the producer of Sampaguita, National Flower, 2010, with Pasion Para Pelicula Productions and Voyage Studios; and Instant Mommy, 2013, with Kris Aquino, Chris Martinez, John VictorTence, Joey Abacan, and Leo Abaya with K Films; both films were done in cooperation with the Cinemalaya Foundation.

Alonso was the postproduction executive of Quantum Post for The Trial, Beauty in a Bottle, and That Thing Called Tadhana (That Thing Called Fate), 2014; and Halik sa Hangin (Kiss in the Wind) and Etiquette for Mistresses, 2015.  Written by Susan Claire Agbayani

Alicia Alonzo (Germelina Viana Hernandez) is a film and television actor. She was born in Manila on 1 Jun 1946. Her parents are Alfredo Hernandez and Lourdes Anderson Viana. Brother Anthony Alonzo was an actor. She is married to actor Ross Rival, eldest brother of actor Phillip Salvador. Actor son Jon Hernandez died in a car accident in 1993. Alonzo was briefly enrolled at the Mapua Institute of Technology (MIT) and, at one time, was a Philippine Airlines flight attendant.

Introduced in Kwatang, 1967, Lea Productions soon signed her up as a contract actor. She played her first lead role in Jingy, 1968, opposite Fernando Poe Jr. Among her later notable performances was in the film directed by Behn Cervantes, Sakada (Seasonal Cane Workers), 1976, and in Lino Brocka's Tahan na Empoy, Tahan (Stop Crying Now, Empoy ), 1977. Her other films include Marahas ang Daigdig (Cruel World), 1970; Signos Trece (The 13th Sign) and Tapang Brothers, 1971; Bandila ng Magigiting (Flag of the Brave), 1973; Kamay na Gumagapang (Crawling Hand), 1974; Hermano Pule (Brother Pule), 1978; Waikiki, 1980; Condemned, 1984; Nasaan Ka Inay? (Where Are You Mother?), 1988; Days of Being Wild, 1990; Sinungaling Mong Puso (Your Lying Heart), 1992; Alfredo Lim: Batas ng Maynila (Alfredo Lim: The Law of Manila), 1995; Soltera (The Spinster), 1999; Abakada … Ina (ABC … Mother), 2001; Kapalit (Substitute), 2002; Birhen ng Manaoag (Our Lady of Manaoag), 2005; and Mga Batang Bangketa (Street Children), 2006.

On television, Alonzo was in the cast of the long-running TV soap opera Anna Liza, which aired from 1980 to 1986. She also appeared in GMA Network’s Munting Anghel (Little Angel), 2000, Ikaw Lang ang Mama halin (I’ll Always Love You), 2001, Ikaw sa Puso Ko (You in My Heart) and Mulawin, 2004, Lupin, 2007, Ikaw Sana (Hope It’s You), 2009, and Sana Ay Ikaw na Nga (I Hope You’re the One), 2012; ABS-CBN’s Dahil May Isang Ikaw (Because There Is You), 2009, Momay, 2010, Mula sa Puso (From the Heart), 2011, Nathaniel and Inday Bote (Inday the Bottle Trader), 2015; and TV5’s Rod Santiago’s The Sisters, 2011.

Alonzo received Best Supporting Actress award in the 1972 Manila Film Festival for her role in Villa Miranda, and in the 1983 Metro Manila Film Festival for Bago Kumalat ang Kamandag (Before the Venom Spreads).   Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

Anthony Alonzo (Antonio Viana Hernandez) was a film actor. He was born in Manila on 2 Apr 1948. He died in Quezon City on 9 Oct 1998. His parents are Alfredo Hernandez and Lourdes Viana. He received his elementary and secondary education at Marulas Elementary School and Espiritu Santo High School, respectively. He took up commerce at the Mapua Institute of Technology. Sister Alicia Alonzo is an actor.

Alonzo was known for his action movies, among them Muntinlupa 1950, 1974; Dakpin si Junior Bomba y (Arrest Junior Bombay), 1979; Diablong Sagrado (Sacred Devil), 1980; Dakpin si Pusa (Arrest Pusa), Intrusion: Cambodia, Totoy Scarface, and Warren Balane, 1981; Manila Gangwar and Clash of the Warlords, 1985; Jailbreak 1958, 1987; Jabidah Massacre, 1990; Angel on Fire and Markang Bungo 2: Iligpit si Bobby Ortega (Skull Mark: Execute Bobby Ortega), 1995; Ang Mama tay nang Dahil sa ’Yo (To Die for You), 1996; and Masdan Mo ang mga Bata (Look at the Children), 1997.

Alonzo won Best Actor awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Bambang, 1982, and from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Bago Kumalat ang Kamandag (Before the Venom Spreads), 1983, Moises Padilla Story, The Missing Chapter, 1985, and Anak Badjao (Son of a Badjao), 1987.

In 1992, Alonzo began his involvement in local politics and was elected as Quezon City councilor.  Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Erika Carreon

Max Alvarado (Gavino Maximo Teodosio) was a film actor. He was born in Manila on 19 Feb 1929. He died in Manila on 6 Apr 1997. His parents are Gonzalo Teodosio and Maria Maximo. He was married to Ester Hugo with whom he had seven children.

Alvarado played his first bit role in Halik sa Bandila (A Kiss to the Flag), 1948, and his first starring role in Alyas Chain Gang (Alias Chain Gang), 1967. Alvarado typified a kontrabida (villain) image and character in the local cinema peculiar to his seriocomic countenance. He played such roles in movies like Totoy Guwapo (Handsome Totoy), James Bondat (Potbellied James), Deadly Fighter, 1970; Liezl at ang Seven Hoods (Liezl and the Seven Hoods) and Sebastian Gustavo, 1971; Jailbreak, El Vibora (The Viper), and Nardong Putik, 1972; and Mahiwagang Kris (Mysterious Dagger), 1976. Alvarado also gave life to the comic character Lizardo, the archenemy of the hero Flavio as played by Fernando Poe Jr in Ang Panday (The Blacksmith), 1980, Pagbabalik ng Panday (Return of the Blacksmith), 1981, and Ang Panday … Ikatlong Yugto (The Blacksmith … Third Chapter), 1982, and by Ramon “Bong” Revilla Jr in Ang Dugo ng Panday (The Blacksmith’s Blood), 1993.

Alvarado won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Supporting Actor award for his performance in Ang Kampana sa Santa Quiteria (The Bell in Santa Quiteria), 1971. In the same year, he received a Best Supporting Actor trophy in the 2nd Quezon City Film Festival for Alyas Bagsik (Alias Terror), 1971. He was also nominated by the FAMAS as Best Supporting Actor for Pitong Makasalanan (Seven Sinners), 1962, and Tiger Unit, 1963.  Written by Romulo P. Baquiran Jr and Anne Frances Sangil

Cesar Amigo (Cesar Jalandoni Amigo) was a film director and screenwriter. He was born in Dumaguete City on Sep 1924. He died in Manila on 5 Jun 1987. He was the son of Marcelino Amigo, a former provincial sheriff of Negros Oriental, and Belen Jalandoni. He married Ursula Mostajo, with whom he had six children. He obtained his bachelor’s degree in political science at Silliman University (SU), Dumaguete City.

Amigo first tried his hand at fiction writing before he began to write movie scripts. With director Eddie Romero, who also came from SU in Dumaguete, he worked as scriptwriter for films like Prinsesa at Pulubi (The Princess and the Pauper), 1951; Buhay Alamang (Easy Come, Easy Go), 1952; Sweethearts, 1958; and Day of the Trumpet, 1958.

For director Gerardo de Leon, Amigo wrote the screenplays of movies like Saigon, 1956; Kamay ni Cain (Hand of Cain), 1957; Barilan sa Pugad-Lawin (Gunfight at Pugad-Lawin), 1963; Kulay Dugo ang Gabi (Blood Is the Color of Night), 1964; Magandang Bituin (Lovely Star), 1965; Tagumpay ng Mahirap (Triumph of the Poor), 1965; and The Gold Bikini, 1968.

In the 1970s, Amigo turned to movie directing in films like Babae sa Likod ng Salam in (Woman Behind the Mirror), 1976, a candid look at feminism; and Sa Dulo ng Kris (At Dagger’s End), 1977, which views Filipino Christian-Muslim relations more positively.

Amigo won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) award for Best Screenplay four times, making him one award short of the FAMAS Hall of Fame. He received his trophies for Buhay Alamang, which he co-wrote with Eddie Romero; Hanggang sa Dulo ng Daigdig (To the Ends of the Earth), 1958, which was based on the real-life story of Nardong Putik; Kadenang Putik (Chain of Mud), 1960, a film that dealt with marital infidelity; and The Moises Padilla Story, 1961, one of the most significant movies of the 1960s. As movie director, he earned a FAMAS nomination for Sa Atin ang Daigdig (The World Is Ours), 1963.  Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja

Julio Esteban Anguita (Julio Anguita Esteban) was a pianist, piano teacher, composer, and film scorer. Of Spanish parentage, he was born in Shanghai, China on 18 Mar 1906, but was raised in Spain. He died in Palma de Mallorca, Spain on 3 Dec 1987. Although he was known as Mr. Anguita, his real surname was Esteban, Anguita being his mother’s surname.

Anguita started playing the piano at age seven and studied music in Barcelona, Spain. By the time he was 18, he graduated with honors at the Circulo Filarmonico de Barcelona. In a year’s time, at age 19, he was hailed in Barcelona as well as other key cities and suburbs in Spain as a concert artist and soloist.

He arrived in Manila on 14 Jan 1925 and became a staff pianist at the radio station KZRH, now DZRH. Later he became a piano instructor in the music department of the Colegio de San Juan de Letran. He pursued further education in music and obtained a bachelor of music degree from the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music in 1933, after which he went back to Barcelona to finish his masteral degree in music at Escuela Municipal de Musica.

He taught music at the UP Conservatory of Music for more than two decades. In between his teaching career, Anguita teamed up with violin virtuoso ErnestoVallejo to perform in concert tours in the Visayas and southern China. Around this time, he began to compose music for the movies, like Parlatone Hispano-Filipino’s Bahay Kubo (Nipa Hut), 1938. In addition, from 1928 to 1952, he appeared intermittently as piano soloist in concerts by the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) and, in 1949 and 1952, guest conducted the same orchestra.

During the Japanese Occupation, he transferred to the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) Conservatory of Music to head its piano department. With the resurgence of theater activities during World War II, Anguita and Vallejo again teamed up in a series of musical performances at the Times Theater.

After World War II, he resumed his position in the UP Conservatory of Music. Later he transferred to the University of Santo Tomas (UST) as the second director of its conservatory from 1947 to 1957.

Concomitantly, he was also a musical consultant for Lebran Productions where he did over 50 musical scores of local films like He Promised to Return, 1949; The Spell, His Darkest Hour,and The Pirates Go to Town, all in 1950; Romeo at Julieta (Romeo and Juliet), Babae, Babae at Babae pa! (Women, Women, and More Women!), Sigfredo, and Tatlong Patak ng Luha (Three Teardrops), all in 1951; Kalbaryo ni Hesus (The Calvary of Jesus), 1952; and Malapit sa Diyos (Close to God), 1953.

He conducted operas and ballets in Europe, Asia, and the United States, and composed the United Nations Hymn in the Philippines and the UST Hymn. As chair of the curriculum committee of the then Bureau of Education of the Philippines, he introduced the bachelor and master degrees in music in private schools based on the standards of American conservatories.

He later settled in the United States where he taught piano pedagogy, piano, and piano literature at the Peabody Conservatory of Music in Baltimore, Maryland.

He published two books, namely The Technical Exercises with Liszt and Chopin Etudes, Op. 18, and wrote numerous articles for professional publications.

Anguita won the 1950 Maria Clara Awards for best musical direction for his work in The Spell. The same award was bestowed on him by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for his work in Kalbaryo ni Hesus in 1952.  Written by M. Globio and M. Ojeda, updated by Josephine Baradas

article_title: Animation Council of the Philippines Inc
text:
Animation Council of the Philippines, Inc. (ACPI) is a nonstock, nonprofit organization founded in 2000. ACPI holds the four core values of excellence, innovation, entrepreneurship, and integrity. As of 2014, Rowena Bagadion of Media Farm Inc represents the council as its president. Other officers are Nestor Palabrica of TOIE Animation Philippines Inc as vice president and Ricky Orellana of Mowelfund Film Institute as secretary. With its partnership with several animation stakeholder industries—for example, Tuldok (Dot), Cadweb, Unang Kompanya (First Company)—and learning institutions such as De La Salle-College of Saint Benilde, ACPI visualizes the progress of animation in the country through business and education. It aims to nurture potential animators, both in 2D and 3D platforms, and the Filipino passion for animation as well.

ACPI promotes a globally competitive animation industry in the Philippines. It aims to carve more Filipino talents in creative and technological animation, in both the local and the international animation scenes. With several projects in line, it aims to bring the Philippines to the list of countries as prime providers of animation and content creation services. Other services of ACPI are preproduction (including, but not limited to, storyboard, sound editing, and concept art), production (including, but not limited to, cleanup/in-betweening, line stating, digital animation services, architectural visualization, and audiovisual presentations), and postproduction (including, but not limited to, musical scoring, sound effects and design, and special effects) services in Philippine 2D/3D animation, deployment of instructors or experts to animation workshops, and web/graphic/art designs for different platforms such as mobile applications, interactive games, and e-Learning modules. It provides training programs across the country, catering to beginners interested in animation as well as to advanced trainers and professional animators. Some of the training programs are curriculum development and consultancy for 2D/3D animation, technical advising for software and hardware requirements, and project/production management in 2D/3D/Flash animation.

Animahenasyon (a combination of Filipino terms for animation and imagination), ACPI’s flagship project, is an annual Filipino animation festival and competition. It serves a place for the diverse sets of participants (aspiring and professional animators) to show their potentials, ideas, and original works. Animahenasyon also includes seminars, workshops, congresses, classes, and exhibits featuring works of seasoned animators and lifetime achievement awardees. Moreover, it is a venue for the aspiring and amateur animators to meet the experts and renowned names in the industry. Two of the most notable Animahenasyon films are Dayo: Sa Mundo ng Elementalia (The Wanderer in the Land of Elementalia), 2008, the first Filipino full-length digital animation; and RPG Metanoia, 2010, the first Filipino full-length 3D animation. In 2011, Geirry Garcia received the Animahenasyon Lifetime Achievement Award while Jose Ramon Vicente del Prado was awarded the Outstanding Emerging Artist in Animation. Recent Animahenasyon grand prize winners include Nelson Caliguia’s Doodle of Doom, 2006, Inday Wanda, 2007, and Mutya (Muse), 2009; Niko Salazar’s Marianing, 2012; and Ellen Ramos’s Buhay Kubo (Nipa Hut Life), 2013.  Written by Gregory del Carmen

Boots Anson (Maria Elisa Cristobal Anson), also known as Boots Anson-Roa and later, Boots Anson-Rodrigo, is a film and television actor and host. She was born in Manila on 30 Jan 1945. She is the daughter of Oscar Moreno, a popular postwar actor, and Belen Cristobal. She was previously married to Pete Roa and they have four children. Her daughter Chiqui Roa is a television host; her brother Alvin is an actor. After being a widow for many years, she married Francisco Rodrigo Jr, a lawyer, in 2014. She studied speech and drama at University of the Philippines (UP) and took up courses in journalism and media relations at Georgetown University in the United States

She now serves as trustee and executive director of the Movie Workers Welfare Foundation Inc. At one time or another, she was chair of the Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation (IBC 13), a board member at the Balikatan sa Kaunlaran, vice chairman for television for the Metro Manila chapter of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas, chairman for the Friends of the Philippine High School for the Arts, vice chairman for the Film Committee of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, and director of the UP College of Arts and Letters Alumni Foundation. She also served as governor of the Philippine National Red Cross; director for the UP-Philippine General Hospital Medical Foundation, National Commission on the Rehabilitation of the Disabled, and the Philippine Mental Health Association; and adviser for DARE, an anti-drug foundation, and the Philippine Association for the Deaf. Her writings were published in the Manila-U.S. Mail, Isyu, and the Philippine Daily Inquirer. She was also editor-in-chief for the Balikatan Herald in 1994.

Anson started as an actor in 1968 under Sampaguita Pictures and was paired with some of the most sought-after matinee idols of the time, such as Fernando Poe Jr, Ramon Revilla, Joseph Estrada, and others. Among Anson’s most memorable films are Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), 1968; Adriana and Si Darna at ang Planetman (Darna and the Planetman), 1969; Wanted: Perfect Mother, 1970; I Love Mama, I Love Papa, The Wonderful World of Music, Living Doll, and Ang Kampana sa Santa Quiteria (The Bell in Santa Quiteria), 1971; Tatay Na si Erap (Erap Is Now a Father), and Santo Domingo (Saint Dominic), 1972; Ang Agila at ang Araw (The Eagle and the Sun), Tanikalang Dugo (Chain of Blood), James Wong, and Paru-parong Itim (Black Butterfly), 1973; May Isang Tsuper ng Taksi (There Was a Taxi Driver), Bawal: Asawa Mo, Asawa Ko (Forbidden: Your Spouse, My Spouse), and Sumigaw Ka Hanggang Ibig Mo (Scream All You Want), 1974; Pagsapit ng Dilim (Nightfall), Anak ng Araw (Child of the Sun), Ani no ng Araw (Shadow of the Sun), Mga Uhaw na Bulaklak (Thirsty Flowers), Isang Gabi, Tatlong Babae (One Night, Three Women), Isinumpa (Cursed), and Postcards from China, 1975; Tatlong Kasalanan (Three Sins) and Daigdig ng Lagim (World of Terror), 1976; Hubad na Bayani (A Hero Stripped), 1977; Mga Mata ni Angelita (Angelita’s Eyes), and Camerino, 1978; Hiwaga (Mystery) and Tembong, 1980; P.S. I Love You, 1981; Kadenang Bulaklak (Chain of Flowers) and May Minamahal (Loving Someone), 1993; The Maggie de la Riva Story: God … Why Me?, 1994; The Lilian Velez Story: Till Death Do Us Part, 1995; Ama, Ina, Anak (Father, Mother, Child), 1996; May Isang Pamilya (There Was a Family), Hinahanap-Hanap Kita (I Keep Looking for You), and Ganito Ako Magmahal (This Is How I Love), 1999; Mano Po (I Kiss Your Hand), 2002; Bridal Shower and Mano Po 3: My Love, 2004; Ilusyon (Illusion), Ang Anak ni Brocka (The Child of Brocka), and Blue Moon, 2005; White Lady and Mano Po V: Gua Ai Di (I Love You), 2006; Angels, 2007; When Love Begins, Caregiver, One True Love, and Lovebirds, 2008; Mano Po VI: A Mother’s Love, 2009; Ganap na Babae (Garden of Eve), 2010; Third Eye and Unfriend, 2014.

Anson has also been a very active TV host and actor. She hosted the show Dance-O-Rama, 1964, where she met her first husband, Pete Roa, her co-host. She was a frequent character actor in many populartelenovelas of recent years,including Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001; Ang Iibigin Ay Ikaw (You Are the One to Love), 2002; Kokey, 2007; Pangarap na Bituin (Dream Star), 2007; May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), 2009; Minsan Lang Kita Iibigin (I Will Love You Only Once) and Munting Heredera (Little Heiress), 2011; My Beloved and Luna Blanca, 2012; Rhodora X, 2014; and Princess in the Palace, 2015. She also played Lola B, a modern reincarnation of the well-loved storyteller, Lola Basyang, in TV5's fantasy anthology LolaBasyang.com, 2015-16.

Anson won Best Actress in the 1973 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Awards for Tatay Na si Erap. From the FAMAS, she also received the following: Dr Jose Perez Memorial Award in 1980, Lifetime Achievement Award in 2003, and Presidential Award in 2008. In 2006, she won Best Supporting Actress at the Golden Screen Awards for Blue Moon. She also received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the PMPC Star Awards for Movies in 2001, and from the Film Academy of the Philippines in 2008.  Written by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

Lito Anzures (Angelito Castro Anzures) was a film actor. He was born in Santa Ines, Bulacan on 22 Feb 1927. He died in 1995. His parents are Juliana Castro and Felix Anzures. He was the nephew of actors Miguel Anzures and Rosa Aguirre, and a cousin of actor Narding Anzures. He married Norma Ledesma with whom he had eight children. He studied at Marcelo H. del Pilar Elementary School and finished high school at Bulacan Academy.

Anzures first appeared in Halik sa Bandila (A Kiss to the Flag), 1948. He also appeared in Zamboanga , 1966; Romantika (Romantic) and Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels without Heaven), 1970; Ang Kampana sa Santa Quiteria (The Bell in Santa Quiteria), 1971; Ang Pinakamagandang Hayop sa Balat ng Lupa (The Most Beautiful Animal on the Face of the Earth), 1974; Ang Madugong Daigdig ni Salvacion (The Bloody World of Salvacion), 1975; Daluyong at Habagat (Tidal Wave and North Wind), 1976; Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Heron Turns Black), 1978; Ang Alamat ni Julian Makabayan (The Legend of Julian Makabayan), 1979; Ang Panday (The Blacksmith), 1980; Pagbabalik ng Panday (Return of the Blacksmith), 1981; Ang Panday … Ikatlong Yugto (The Blacksmith … Third Chapter), 1982; and Misteryo sa Tuwa (Joyful Mystery), 1984.

He received the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences award for Best Supporting Actor for Sigaw ng Digmaan (War Cry), 1963, where interestingly he played his first starring—not supporting—role. For his performance in Paradise Inn, 1985, he won both the Gawad Urian and the PMPC Star Award trophies for Best Supporting Actor.  Written by Glecy Atienza, updated by Erika Carreon

Apeng Daldal (Serafin Maniego Gabriel) was a stage, film and television actor, comedian, singer, dancer, and scriptwriter. He was born in San Luis, Pampanga on 12 Oct 1928. He died on 9 Feb 1992. He was the son of Moises Gabriel and Mauricia Maniego. He was married to Elma Modesto with whom he had eight children. It is believed that his moniker was based on his set of big teeth (apen in his native Kapampangan) and his being a fast talker (daldal), although the nickname Apeng is also a diminutive of the first name Serafin.

Apeng Daldal began his career dancing in bodabil in his Tondo, Manila neighborhood, where he was a favorite dancing partner of cross-dressers. In the late 1940s to 1950s, his performances in comedy skits at the Manila Opera House with Mar Lopez and Bebing Santos, who formed the trio Top Three, were a crowd drawer.

In the 1960s, actor Johnny Wilson discovered him for television and put him in The Big Show with Cris de Vera, later becoming a mainstay in the sitcoms Tindahan sa Nayon (Village Store) and Trio los Bobos (The Three Idiots) in the 1970s and Cafeteria Aroma and Super Laff-In in the 1980s. At the same time, Apeng Daldal began to make movies, mostly in supporting roles. In 1964, he appeared with Susan Roces in Libis ng Baryo (Barrio Edge). His major movie roles were in Magic Bilao (Magic Winnowing Basket) and Walis ni Tenteng (Tenteng’s Broom), both in 1965. His first starring role was in Maskulado (Muscular), also in 1965.

Apeng wrote scripts for several TV shows in the 1970s, including Ayos Lang, Pare Ko (It’s Okay, My Friend) and The Nida-Lita Show on Channel 9, and Barok-an Subdivision on Channel 13. He was also on radio in the afternoon and evening timeslots. He wrote several songs, the most well-known of which were Hoy, Mama ng Kaminero (Hey, Mr Street Sweeper) and Pandanggo ng Aswang (Fandango of the Viscera Sucker), both released in 1968.

Though lacking in recognition from award-giving bodies, Apeng Daldal won praise from critics for his dramatic role in an episode of the TV drama series Eliza, 1970-72, ABS-CBN (Channel 9), deviating from his comic stereotype.

Most of the movies Apeng Daldal appeared in were from Sampaguita Pictures, including Alias Golden Boy, 1963; Babaing Kidlat (Lightning Woman), Mga Daliring Ginto (Golden Fingers), Show Business, Bandong Pugante (Bando the Escapee), and Simbangis ng Tigre (Ferocious as a Tiger), 1964; Tatlong Mabilis (The Three Fast Ones), Magic Bilao (Magic Winnowing Basket), Maskulado (Muscular), Tatlong Mabilis sa Hong Kong (The Three Fast Ones in Hong Kong), and Walis ni Tenteng (Tenteng’s Broom), 1965; Mistico Meets Mamaw and Pitong James Bonds (Seven James Bonds), 1966; The Son of Dyango Meets Dorango Kid, Langit Pa Rin Kita (You’re Still My Heaven), and The Pogi Dozen (The Handsome Dozen), 1967; Yolindina, Concentration Camp No. 5, and Ang Inyong Lingkod, Matutina (At Your Service, Matutina), 1975; Habang Pinipigil, Lalong Nanggigigil (The More You Try to Control, the More the Desire Gets Stronger), and Wow, Sikat! Pare, Bigat! (Wow, Famous! Dude, Heavy!), 1977; Dobol Dribol (Double Dribble), for which he created the story and wrote the screenplay, 1979; and Kamakalawa (Day before Yesterday), 1981.  Written by Rolando O. Santos

 

Sources

Francisco, Butch. 2003. “Remembering Departed Stars.” Philstar.com, 1 Nov. http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/226255/ remembering-departed-stars.

———. 2006a. “Apeng Daldal.” Starbytes. The Philippine Star, 17 Aug. Posted in Movie Celebrities Then and Now (blog), 1 Aug 2010. http://movie-industry.blogspot.com/2010/08/apeng-daldal-sln.html.

———. 2006b. “The Greatest Comedians of All Time.” Philstar.com, 17 Aug.

Theiapolis. 2013. “Apeng Daldal.” Accessed 23 Aug. http://people.theiapolis.com/actor-1OBU/apeng-daldal.

Wikipedia. 2013. “Apeng Daldal.” Accessed 15 Oct. https://tl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apeng_Daldal.

———. 2013a. “Super Laff-In.” Accessed 15 Oct. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Laff-.

Angel Aquino (Angelita Velasquez Aquino) is a film, television, and theater actor, and a television host. She was born in Dumaguete City on 7 Feb 1973. Aquino is a graduate of bachelor of arts in journalism from the University of the Philippines Baguio. She has two daughters, Iana, a film actor and producer, and Thea.

Aquino started her career as a fashion model. Her first film is Mumbaki (Shaman), 1996. Her succeeding films include Goodbye, America, 1997; Bata, Bata … Paano Ka Ginawa? (Lea’s Story), Sana Pag-ibig Na (Enter Love), and Serafin Geronimo: Ang Kriminal ng Baryo Concepcion (The Criminal of Barrio Concepcion), 1998. Her acting career continued to flourish with her performances in Laro sa Baga (Playing with Fire), 2000, Batang West Side (West Side Avenue), 2001, Crying Ladies, 2003, Beautiful Life, 2004, and Ebolusyon ng Isang Pamilyang Pilipino (Evolution of a Filipino Family), 2004. She has appeared in more independent films, like ICU Bed #7 during the first Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival in 2005, and other notable works like Nasaan si Francis? (Where Is Francis?), Donsol and Kaleldo (Summer Heat), 2006; Siquijor: Mystic Island, 2007; I Love You, Goodbye, 2009; Amorosa (The Revenge), 2012; Captive, On the Job, Porno, and Ang Huling Cha-Cha ni Ani ta (Anita’s Last Cha-Cha), 2013; and Lorna, 2014.

On television, Aquino was host of lifestyle shows like F! and Us Girls. She also appeared in numerous drama series of GMA Network and ABS-CBN, like Recuerdo de Amor (Memory of Love), 2001; Encantadia: Pag-ibig Hanggang Wakas (Enchanted: Love till the End), 2006; Darna , 2009; Magkaribal (Rivals), 2010; Maria la del Barrio, 2011; Apoy sa Dagat (Raging Love) and Honesto, 2013; and Bagito (Young Man), 2014. She was also a cast member of the comedy series Camera Cafe , 2007, andhas also done numerous guest appearances in the drama anthologies Maaalala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) and Magpakailanman (Eternity), and the fantasy anthology Wansapanataym (Once Upon a Time).

Aquino received a Balanghai trophy for Best Actress from the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival for her performance in Donsol, 2006. For Ang Huling Cha-Cha ni Anita, she won four Best Supporting Actress awards: at the 2013 Cine Filipino Film Festival and the 2014 PMPC Star Awards for Movies, Golden Screen Awards, and Gawad Urian. In 2014, she also won Best Supporting Actress in the Golden Screen Awards for Television for her performance in Apoy sa Dagat.  Written by Mario Mendez Jr

Carlo Aquino (Carlo Lopez Aquino) is a television and film actor. He was born in Quezon City on 3 Sep 1985. He is the son of Jose Aquino and Amelia Lopez. Aside from acting, Aquino is also a singer for the band Kollide, and was one-third of the JCS group with John Prats and Stefano Mori. The trio was also part of ABS-CBN’s youth-oriented show G-Mik, 1999.

Aquino first appeared in Cedie: Ang Munting Prinsipe (Cedie: The Little Prince), 1996. After various films and television shows, he won his first major acting award for Bata, Bata … Paano Ka Ginawa? (Lea’s Story), 1998. Aquino played the role of Ojie, son to veteran actor Vilma Santos’s character, Lea Bustamante. He was recognized as the Child Performer of the Year by the PMPC Star Awards for Movies, Best Child Actor by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, and Best Supporting Actor by the Film Academy of the Philippines. He was 13 years old then. Aquino also won awards for independent films Mater Dolorosa (Sorrowful Mother), 2012, from the PMPC Star Awards for Movies, and Porno, 2013, from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk. He was also chosen as Best Actor in a lead role for Sa Aking Pagkakagising mula sa Kamulatan (My Awakening from Consciousness), 2005, in the Golden Screen Awards. Aquino’s other noteworthy films are Kahapon May Dalawang Bata (Yesterday Children), 1999, and Minsan May Isang Puso (Once There Was a Heart), 2001.

On television, Aquino appeared in various programs, from dramatic series like Sa Puso Ko, Iingatan Ka (In My Heart, I’ll Take Care of You), 2001-02, Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), 2006, and Annaliza, 2013-14, to fantasy adventure like Panday Kids (Blacksmith Kids), 2010, and action series like Ang Utol Kong Hoodlum (My Hoodlum Brother), 2011. In 2006, Aquino won the Best Single Performance by an Actor from the PMPC Star Awards for TV for “Scapular,” an episode in Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember).  Written by Kathrina Alvarez

Lupita Aquino-Kashiwahara (Guadalupe Lampa Aquino-Kashiwahara), also known as Lupita Aquino-Concio, is a television and film director. She was born in Concepcion, Tarlac on 28 May 1934. She is one of the children of Aurora Lampa and Benigno Quiambao Aquino Sr, a former congressman, 1919-25, senator, 1928, secretary of agriculture under Commonwealth president Manuel L. Quezon, 1937, and Speaker of the National Assembly of the Second Philippine Republic, 1943-45. Her siblings are Maria Aurora Aquino-Lichauco, former senator Benigno Simeon Jr aka Ninoy, Maria Gerarda, Paul, former senator Agapito aka Butz, and former senator Maria Teresa Aquino-Oreta aka Tessie. Her brother Butz was a film and television actor. She is the aunt of TV host Kris Aquino and former president Benigno “Noynoy” Aquino III. She married her first husband Cesar Rafael Concio Jr in 1961, with whom she has six children, one of whom is Mia Concio, a screenwriter and former chair of the government station National Broadcasting Network Channel 4, formerly People’s Television. Concio Jr was a recipient of the Ten Outstanding Young Men in the field of technology in 1966. After their separation and divorce, she married Emmy Award-winning Japanese journalist Ken Kashiwahara, who was then working as ABC’s San Francisco bureau chief, in the early 1980s. She took up liberal arts, major in social studies and minor in journalism, at Maryknoll College (now Miriam College). She obtained a master of arts in communication, major in television, from the American University in Washington, DC, in the late 1950s.

When she returned to the Philippines, she directed TV programs on ABS-CBN, beginning in the early 1960s, such as the children’s program Magnolia Sunday Party; the instructional show Education on TV; the live 30-minute drama program Family Theater by Fr James Reuter, SJ, which usually featured adaptations of American plays; and Northern Motors’ Filipinesques, a music program that featured a 24-piece orchestra playing Filipino compositions. From 1963 to 1967, she worked with the Educational TV Project of Ateneo de Manila University under the leadership of Fr Leo Larkin. When she returned to television, she directed the pre-martial law drama anthologies on ABC 5: Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), 1967-72, and Malikmata (Illusion), 1972, the first TV horror-suspense-psychological drama in the Philippines.

Her decision to go to filmmaking moved one critic to say that “TV’s loss was moviedom’s gain” (Nograles 1976, 7). She directed only a few films, but they are all memorable productions. Her first film directorial work was Premiere Productions’s Alkitrang Dugo (Blood Tar), 1975, for Nora Aunor’s NV Productions. The movie was inspired by the English novel Lord of the Flies by William Golding. This was followed by Premiere Productions’s Magandang Gabi sa Inyong Lahat (Good Evening Everyone), 1976, starring Aunor and Tirso Cruz III, and Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth), also in 1976, starring Aunor, a film critical of the Philippine-American relations, specifically the maintenance of US bases in the country. She also made Filmmaster’s Ibalik Mo ang Araw sa Mundong Makasalanan (Bring Back the Sun to a Sinful World), 1978, which is based on a true occurrence: the theft of the image of the Santo Niño to which religious folk attributed several calamities that befell them in Tondo. For Viva Films, she directed Hati Tayo sa Magdamag (Let’s Split the Night between Us), 1988, starring Edu Manzano, Jaclyn Jose, and Tetchie Agbayani, and co-directed Dear Diary, 1989, starring Lea Salonga; and for Premiere, she made Babae (Woman), 1997, starring Aunor and Judy Ann Santos.

While doing films, she continued directing the long-running TV music program Superstar, 1971-89, and Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora), 1970s-1980s, both on RPN 9. On top of these two shows, there was a time in the 1970s that she directed several shows a week—namely, Sulyap sa Kalinangan (A Look at Culture) with Joy Virata on Fridays; From the Mouths of Babes and Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora, both on Saturdays; and Musika ng Lahi (Music of the Race) and Premyo sa Palaro (Prize in Games), both on Sundays. She also directed the interview program Celebrity Hour, with Leila Benitez as host.

After the fall of the Marcos administration, she continued directing TV programs, such as the drama series Bisperas ng Kasaysayan (Eve of History), 1994, RPN 9; the single-airing drama Evelio, 1986, PTV 4, starring Gina Alajar and Joel Torre; other dramas like Higpitan Mo ang Yakap Mo (Embrace Tight) and Umaandap na Ningas (Flickering Light); and the documentaries Kataksilan sa Bayan (Betrayal to the Nation) and Sabwatan sa Kataksilan (Conspiracy to Treachery), both in 2006, of RTV Malacañang, which tackled the failed coup attempts against the Arroyo administration on 24 Feb 2006. She worked as a project consultant for the musical film Emir, 2010, directed by Chito Roño.

In 2004, Aquino-Kashiwahara worked for the presidential election campaign of PresGloria Macapagal Arroyo and came to be known as the president’s “personal director.” She personally oversaw the technical and production aspects of the president’s activities, media appearances, photo opportunities, speeches, and press releases. Aquino-Kashiwahara works as a consultant with Digna Santiago in the Philippine Film Export Services Office of the Film Development Council of the Philippines.

She received the Patnubay ng Kalinangan Award from the city government of Manila, 1970, in connection with the Araw ng Maynila celebrations for “her contribution to the development of Filipino drama on TV and helping to focus public interest in Philippine culture” (Nograles 1976, 6). She and the programs and the artists she had directed won the Citizens’ Award for Television several times: Outstanding TV Director for Balintataw, 1967; Best Educational TV Program for Education on TV, 1966; Best News Interview Program for J. V. Cruz Interviews, 1966 and 1967; Best Special Events for Election ’67, 1967; Best Anthology Series for Balintataw, 1967, 1968, 1969, 1970, and 1971; and the Hall of Fame award for Balintataw, 1972. From 1975 to 1978, her shows Superstar and Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora won for her, Nora Aunor, and the show the awards for Best Director, Best Actress, Best Musical Program, and Best Drama Program, respectively, from the Philippine Academy of Television Arts and Sciences or PATAS. She won Best Director for the film Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo at the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards in 1977, which also won Best Picture, Best Story and Best Screenplay for Marina Feleo-Gonzales, and Best Editing for Edgardo Vinarao. The film also won Best Story and Best Editing in the 1976 Metro Manila Film Festival. Bisperas ng Kasaysayan won the Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon in 1994. She also received the Gawad para sa Natatanging Kontribusyon at the 1994 Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon.   Written by Lena S. Pareja and Eulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Mae U. Caralde
