Jorge O. Arago was a screenwriter and journalist. He was born on 12 Jan 1943. He died on 27 Dec 2011. He earned his degrees in journalism, comparative literature, and geology at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. Having a civil service license as an information writer and as a cultural attaché, he used this as a qualification to write and direct a film documentary on People’s Republic of China and to cover presidential state visits to Russia and Cuba.

Arago was a freshman in UP when he met Ishmael Bernal. Eventually, he wrote the screenplays for Bernal’s Nunal sa Tubig (Speck in the Water), 1976, and Sugat sa Ugat (Wound in the Roots), 1983. He also served as a script consultant for Bernal’s City after Dark (or Manila by Night), 1980. In 2005, Arago was a co-writer to director Briccio Santos for the independent film A la Verde, A la Pobre (Green, Poor), 2005. Two years later, they co-wrote another independent film titled A la Suerte, A la Muerte (Luck, Death), 2007.

Arago was nominated in the 1977 Gawad Urian for his screenplay for Nunal sa Tubig. In 2005, he won with Santos the Gawad Urian Best Screenplay for A la Verde, A la Pobre.

Arago’s last known project was supposed to have been a biopic on Bernal’s life, which would have included a 60-minute video portrait, an anthology of film reviews, the full text of his six screenplays, annotated working scripts, and interviews with Bernal’s former co-workers and associates. Unfortunately, such project was never finished. Written by Gregory del Carmen

John Arcilla (Romeo John Gonzales Arcilla) is a theater, television, and film actor, and teacher. He was born in Quezon City on 24 Jun 1966. He is the son of Dominador Gil Alemania Arcilla and Eustacia Gonzales. He spent his childhood in Baler, Aurora where he became active in school- and community-based productions, some of which were under the guidance of the Philippine Educational Theater Association’s Metropolitan Manila Teen Theater League (PETA–MTTL). After finishing his secondary studies at Mount Carmel College of Baler, he relocated to Manila and became a scholar at St. Joseph’s College where he graduated with a degree in mass communications. He continued to hone his craft as an acting scholar of the Actors Workshop Foundation from 1987-90 under the tutelage of Laurice Guillen and Leo Martinez.

 

Arcilla is best known as a musical theater artist having starred in many productions in this genre. His association with Tanghalang Pilipino, both as a member of the Actors Company and as performing artist, spanned several years from the company’s sixth to its twelfth season. Among the productions he has starred in are: Francisco Maniago, 1988; Cyrano ng Bergerac (Cyrano de Bergerac), 1989; Ang Ginintuang Bayan (The Golden Country), Aninag, Anino (Glimmer, Shadow), Lusak (The Lower Depths), and Tatlong Kuwento ni Tonyo, Pepe, at Pule (Three Stories of Tonio, Pepe, and Pule), 1990; El Filibusterismo (Subversion), Mac Malicsi, TNT, Walang Sugat (No Wounds), and Julio Cesar (Julius Caesar), 1991; Larawan (A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino), Ang Buhay ay Pelikula (Life is a Movie), Sigalot sa Venetia ( Brawling in Chioggia ), and Ibon ng Lawa (The Seagull), 1992; Pilipinas Circa 1907 (Philippines Circa 1907), Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira), Layas (Away), and Oktubre Noong Tayo’y Nagmamahalan Pa (October, When We Were Still In Love), 1993; Prinsipe ng Buwan (Prince of the Moon), Santa Juana (Saint Joan), and Sa North Diversion Road (On the North Diversion Road), 1994; Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) and Ang Memorandum (The Memorandum), 1995; Ilustrado: Ang Buhay ni Rizal (The Enlightened: The Life of Rizal), 1996; and Banaag at Sikat (Glimmer and Light), 2010.

 

He has worked with many other Philippine theater companies and was part of Repertory Philippines’s Kiss of the Spider Woman, Sari Kultur’s Lakshmana, Emmaus Tri-Media and Tanghalang Andres Bonifacio’s Andres Bonifacio, Dulaang UP’s Ang Alkalde ng Zalamea (The Mayor of Zalamea), Philippine Theater Visions’s Huling Gabi sa Maragondon (Last Night in Maragondon) and Mga Santong Tao (People Saints), and Theater Arts Philippines’s Ambon sa Madaling Araw (Drizzle in Early Morning). He has also conducted numerous workshops on acting for film and theater in Metro Manila and various provinces.

 

Arcilla’s popular one-liner “Coffee na lang, dear” in a TV commercial for Purefoods Honeycured Bacon somewhat became his ticket to a career in film and television. He has appeared in numerous episodes of ABS-CBN's Maalala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) and Wansapanataym (Once Upon a Time) and GMA Network’s Magpakailanman (Eternity). He has also played character roles in various drama series of ABS-CBN including Basta’t Kasama Kita (As Long as I Am With You), Pangarap na Bituin (Dream Star), May Minamahal (Loving Someone), May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), Magkaribal (Rivals), Habang May Buhay (While There is Life), Mula sa Puso (From the Heart), Hiyas (Treasure), Be Careful With My Heart , Apoy sa Dagat (Fire in the Sea), Pure Love , Oh My G!, and Ang Probinsyano (The Country Boy). For GMA Network, he has appeared in Sugo (Savior), Gagambino, Machete, My Beloved, Genesis, and Encantadia.

 

As a film actor, Arcilla was first seen in Lino Brocka’s Orapronobis (Fight For Us), 1989. He was also in the cast of Raymond Red’s Bayani (Hero), 1992, and Sakay, 1993. He played Rosanna Roces’s naïve boyfriend in Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin ( They Call Me Joy ), 1997. He and Irma Adlawan played multiple characters in Sa North Diversion Road, 2005, Dennis Marasigan’s film adaptation of Tony Perez’s play about marital infidelity, which Arcilla and Adlawan first performed on stage as company members of Tanghalang Pilipino. Arcilla’s other film credits include: Mulanay: Sa Pusod ng Paraiso (Mulanay: Deep in Paradise ), 1996; Compound, 2006; A Love Story, 2007; Manila Skies, 2009; Halaw (Ways of the Sea), 2010; Thelma, 2011; El Presidente, 2012; and Birdshot, 2016. Arcilla was also in the cast of four international movies shot in the Philippines: Amigo, 2010; The Bourne Legacy and Lilet Never Happened, 2012; and Metro Manila, 2013, where he played the lead role.

 

But many regard Arcilla’s portrayal of the titular character in Jerrold Tarog’s Heneral Luna (General Luna), 2015, as his most memorable performance on screen—and his most awarded as well, with him winning the Best Actor trophy from the Film Academy of the Philippines, Gawad Tanglaw Awards, Platinum Stallion Media Awards, The COMMEXCEL Students' Choice Awards of Colegio de San Juan de Lateran, and Pangasinan Government’s Urduja Film Festival. His other acting awards include: Best Actor, Mulanay, Metro Manila Film Festival, 1996; Best Supporting Actor, Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin, Gawad Urian, 1997; and Halaw, Best Actor (New Breed Category), Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, 2010.

 

Anino (Shadow), Raymond Red’s short film where Arcilla played the lead role, won the Cannes Film Festival’s Palme d’Or in 2000. Metro Manila won the Audience Award in the 2013 Sundance Film Festival and earned Arcilla a Best Supporting Actor nomination at the 2013 British Independent Film Festival. Metro Manila was also the official entry of the United Kingdom in the Best Foreign Language Picture category of the Oscars in 2014.

 

For his achievements as an actor, Arcilla received honors and recognitions from the Aurora Government (Dangal ng Aurora in 2005 and Outstanding Citizen of San Luis, Aurora in 2009); Marikina City Government and Parañaque City Government (meritorious contribution in the field of performing arts), both in 2012; and University of Makati AGHAM Theater Company (Gawad Malayang Pilipino), Youth for Leadership Summit (Award for Excellence in Culture), Manila City Government (Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan), PEOPLE ASIA (People of the Year Award), Gawad Amerika Awards (Most Outstanding Performance for Theater, TV, and Film), The PEP Awards (Breakout Star of the Year), and Indieng-Indie Golden Choice Award (Pinakadalubhasang Artista), all in 2016.

 

Arcilla is also an active advocate for the environment. He was the Vice Chairman of the Executive Committee of Kalikasan Partylist and founder of CAPABLE Foundation Inc., a nonprofit organization that promotes environmental volunteerism and community development in the provinces.  Written by Dominique Garde-Torres and Elmer L. Gatchalian

Rica Arevalo (Rica Leticia Ilagan Arevalo) is a film director, producer, and screenwriter. She was born in Manila 28 Feb 1974. Her parents are Ricardo Arevalo and Socorro Ilagan. She has a communication arts degree from De La Salle University and a master of arts in communication management from Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila. She teaches at De La Salle University and College of Saint Benilde.

Among her documentaries are Nag-aalinlangang Ina (Reluctant Mothers), 1995, and The Privileged Migrants, 2013. Her short films include the animated Ani nag sa Dapit hapon (Visions at Dusk), 1996; Batang Maynila (Children of the Streets), 2001; and Gusto Kita Too (I Like You Too), 2008. Her other films include ICU Bed # 7, 2005, and Ganap na Babae (Garden of Eve), 2010, the latter co-directed with Ellen Ramos and Sarah Roxas. She also directed for television, such as the TV5 series Ako Mismo (I Myself), 2011, and GMA Network’s Case Unclosed, 2008.

Her thesis film Nag-aalinlangang Ina won the Best Documentary award at the 9th Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video in 1995. In 2005, she won Best Director at the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival for ICU Bed # 7. The feature film Ganap na Babae is multi-awarded. It won the Mient’s Pick Excellence in Cinematography at the 2011 Soho International Film Festival in New York City; the Ani ng Dangal award from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2012; and the Mount Hope Project Award at the 2012 International Film Festival in Manhattan City.

Arevalo also won literary awards for her screenplays. Mana (Inheritance), 1998, and Pamilya (Family), 2000, won first place and third place, respectively, at the Film Development Council of the Philippines scriptwriting contest. ICU Bed #7 won second place for the screenplay category of the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 2003.  Written by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

Robert Arevalo (Roberto Francisco Ylagan), also known as Robert Ylagan, is a film, television, and theater actor, screenwriter, and film director. He was born in Manila on 6 May 1938. He is the eldest of three children of Guadalupe Francisco and Eustacio Ylagan aka Tito Arevalo, composer, musical director, and film actor. Arevalo is a grandson of sarsuwelista Hermogenes Ilagan; nephew of National Artist for film Gerardo de Leon, director Conrado Conde, and actor Angel Esmeralda; cousin of actors Liberty Ilagan and Jay Ilagan; and uncle of Janno Gibbs. He is married to actor Barbara Perez with whom he has two children, Anna and Georgina. He was educated at Legarda Elementary School, National University, and San Beda College. He finished high school and received his bachelor’s degree in business administration at Ateneo de Manila University. A stalwart of the movie industry, he was the first president of the Katipunan ng mga Artista ng Pelikulang Pilipino, aka the Actors’ Guild, from 1981 to 1983. He also served as a board member of the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board from 1998 to 2001.

Arevalo distinguished himself as a mature and respected actor, appearing in films such as Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1961; El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1962; Sa Atin ang Daigdig (The World Is Ours), 1963; Sakada (Seasonal Cane Workers) and Divorce, Pilipino Style, 1976; Hubad na Bayani (A Hero Stripped) and Gomburza , 1977; Ang Boyfriend Kong Kano (My American Boyfriend), 1983; Miguelito: Batang Rebelde (Miguelito: Young Rebel), 1985; Nude City, 1986; Stolen Moments, 1987; Babayaran Mo ng Dugo (Your Blood Will Be Shed), 1989; Ako ang Batas: General Karingal (I Am the Law: General Karingal), 1990; Takas sa Impiyerno (Fugitive from Hell), 1991; Alyas Boy Kano (Alias American Boy), 1992; The Vizconde Massacre Story: God Help Us!, 1993; The Maggie de la Riva Story: God … Why Me?, 1994; Inagaw Mo ang Lahat sa Akin (Harvest Home), 1995; Mulanay: Sa Pusod ng Paraiso (Mulanay: Deep in Paradise), 1996; Tirad Pass: The Story of Gen. Gregorio del Pilar, 1997; Birador (Hitman), 1998; Madam X, 2000; Kaaway Hanggang Hukay (Enemy until Death), 2001; Batas ng Lansangan (Law of the Streets), 2002; The Cory Quirino Kidnap: NBI Files, 2003; Barcelona and Wrinkles, 2006; Gulong (Wheel) and Paraiso: Tatlong Kwento ng Pag-asa (Paradise: Three Stories of Hope), 2007; Sagrada Familia (Holy Family), Dukot (Desaparecidos), Sabungero (The Cockfighter), and Fuchsia, 2009; The Healing, 2012; and Hari ng Tondo (Where I Am King), 2014.

Arevalo directed four films: Akin ang Huling Awit (The Last Song Is Mine), 1971; Hiwaga sa Pulong Pasig (Mystery in Pasig Isle), 1973; Hubad na Bayani, which won the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, 1979; and Sino’ng Pipigil sa Pagpatak ng Ulan? (Who Will Stop the Rain from Falling?), also in 1979.

He received the Best Actor award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Ang Daigdig ng mga Api (The World of the Oppressed), 1965. He also received the Rajah Soliman Grand Award from the first Manila Film Festival for his performance in the same picture. He also won Best Supporting Actor from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Ama … Bakit Mo Ako Pinabayaan? (Father … Why Have You Forsaken Me?), 1990. As scriptwriter, Arevalo got a Gawad Urian trophy for his work in Hubad na Bayani.

For his work on television, Arevalo was cited by the Citizens Awards for Television (CAT) in 1970 for Outstanding Performance in a Lead Role in the TV drama series, Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye). He also appeared in recent drama series, such as ABS-CBN’s May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), and Lobo (Wolves), 2009, and GMA Network’s Genesis and Indio (Christianized Native), 2013, and Ang Dalawang Mrs. Real (The Two Mrs Real), 2014.  Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

Tito Arevalo (Eustacio Ylagan) was a film actor and musical director. He was born in Manila 29 Mar 1911. He died on 4 Dec 2000. He was the son of famous sarsuwelista writer, director, and producer Hermogenes Ilagan and brother of National Artist for film Gerardo de Leon, actor Angel Esmeralda, director Conrado Conde, and comedians Edo Nagali and Laling Talti. He was married to Guadalupe Francisco, by whom he had three children, including actor Robert Arevalo. He is the uncle of actors Liberty Ilagan, Eddie Ilagan, and Jay Ilagan. He had a law degree from the University of Manila and passed the bar in 1938. He had a stint with the special service branch of the United States Army after World War II.

Arevalo was tutored early in music. He started out professionally as a pianist and conductor for silent pictures and later became musical director for various production outfits. Among the films that he scored are the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) first Best Picture, Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo (Python in the Old Dome), 1952; the original Dyesebel, 1953; the Philippine-Hong Kong co-production Sanda Wong, 1955; the Pancho Magalona–Tita Duran musical, Mr. and Mrs., 1956; and the two Jose Rizal novels adapted to the screen by Gerardo de Leon, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1962.

Arevalo acted in movies like Nasaan Ka Irog (Where Are You, Beloved), 1937; Ama at Anak (Father and Son), 1939; Princesa ng Kumintang (Princess of Kumintang), 1940; and Ang Tiktik (The Detective), 1941, where he played the title role.

In 1952, Arevalo received a Maria Clara award as musical scorer of Diego Silang, 1951. His other awards include the FAMAS for Best Musical Score for Huwag Mo Akong Limutin (Never Forget Me), 1960; El Filibusterismo, 1962; Igorota (Mountain Maiden), 1968; and Lilet, 1971. In 1985, he received the Natatanging Gawad Urian from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino for his outstanding contribution to Philippine cinema. His performance in Peque Gallaga's Isang Araw Walang Diyos (One Day without God), 1989, earned him a Best Supporting Actor trophy from the Film Academy of the Philippines.  Written by Ramon Jocson and Ellen Bomasang, updated by Erika Carreon

Jun Aristorenas (Juanito Aristorenas) was a film actor, director, and producer, and a dancer. He was born in Manila on 7 May 1933. He died in 2003. He was married to action star Virginia Gaerlan. His son Robin Aristorenas was a child actor. Before going into the movies, Aristorenas used to do sing-and-dance routines onstage. In 1960 he toured the Asia-Pacific and Las Vegas as a bodabil troupe member.

Aristorenas worked as an “extra” for Sampaguita Pictures in Lupang Kayumanggi (Brown Land), 1955, and moved up as a bit player in Kulang sa Pito, Sobra sa Walo (Less than Seven, More than Eight), 1956. Having been formally introduced in Kardong Kidlat (Lightning Kardo), 1965, he played the lead role in Dugong Tigre (Tiger Blooded), 1965. As director-producer of Junar Productions, his first venture was Dugong Kayumanggi (Blood of the Brown Race), 1967. His other films are Soliman, 1970; Guadalupe, Ang Mababangis (The Fierce Ones), Pulang Lupa (Red Earth), and San Cristobal, 1971; Kampilan (Cutlass), Apat na Bagwis (Four Wings), and Buhay Maynila (Life in Manila), 1972; Dimas Guererro and Santa Fe, 1973; Hit and Run, 1975; Isang Kumot, Tatlong Unan (One Blanket, Three Pillows), 1986; Masahol Pa sa Hayop (Worse Than an Animal) and Markadong Hudas (Marked Judas), 1993; Marami Ka Pang Kakaining Bigas (You Still Have More Grains to Eat), 1994; Isa, Dalawa, Takbo! (One, Two, Run!), 1996; and Pag Oras Mo, Oras Mo Na (When It’s Your Time, It’s Your Time), 2000.

Aristorenas received the Rajah Soliman award from the 1970 Manila Film Festival as Best Director for Dimasalang, a Junar Production.  Written by Glecy Atienza, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

Dely Atay-Atayan (Adelaida Marquez Fernando-Cruz) was a radio, television, and stage actor, and a singer. She was born in Tayabas, Tondo, Manila on 17 Mar 1914. She died in Parañaque on 30 Aug 2004. She studied at Rizal Elementary School, Torres High School, and Philippine Normal School up to the second year. Her father Amado Fernando was a painter and composer, mother Carmen Marquez, a singer, and brother Fernando aka Ading Fernando was an actor, scriptwriter, and director. When first spouse Alejandro Villegas, aka Andoy Balunbalunan, died, she married Catalino Cruz, aka Jockey Tenoy. Her only child with Villegas, Alfonso, is a dancer, while Alfonso’s three daughters, Ann, Armi, and Aida, are actors. Her great-grandson, Manuel Villegas Quizon II, also the grandson of Dolphy, is an actor and singer.

Atay-atayan was 15 when she first joined amateur singing contests in Binondo, where her family lived. She then landed a stint as a kundiman singer at the Palace Theater, touring the country as a member of a bodabil troupe from 1930 to 1934. It was also during this period when she began to sing on KZIB with her brother Ading. She also performed at the Clover Theater with comedians Dolphy, Aruray, the duo Pugo and Togo, Casmot, Balot, Panchito, and Chiquito. When she married Villegas in 1934, they became partners in Radio Variety Revue Company performing on stage and on the air. Radio programming manager G. S. Fernandez gave her the moniker Dely Atay-atayan while Matty Torres gave her husband the nickname Andoy Balunbalunan. Their nicknames (atay is Tagalog for liver while balunbalunan is chicken gizzard) led to their theme song “Awit ng Manok” (Song of the Chicken). Producing the most popular blocktime programs, the couple was the biggest earner among prewar radio blocktimers, making over one thousand pesos a month, a fabulous sum when top-level government employees earned 30 to 35 pesos a month. Some of their songs, interspersed with comic routines, were critical of the colonial condition at the time, such as “Alila” (Slave). Moreover, the husband-and-wife team sang radio commercials, the most popular being Kiko Baterya (Kiko Battery) and Alviz Tailoring.

She was tagged as “queen of laughs,” “sweetheart of the airlanes,” and Gracie Allen of the Philippines (referencing the American comedienne, half of the George Burns and Gracie Allen Show). She was outstanding in such radio shows as Tang-tarang-tang (Daddy-O), Gabi ng Shell (Night of Shell Company), and Ay, Neneng (Oh, Neneng). She formed a quartet called the Ancient Fox with Pugak, Lopito, and Doro de los Ojos. Even during the war, she continued performing comedy at the Life Theater and at the Manila Grand Opera House under the direction of Lou Salvador Sr.

Her first movie was Lakambini (Muse), 1940, opposite Balunbalunan. She made some five dozen films, including the popular movies of Premiere Productions, like Bulaklak at Paru-Paro (Flower and Butterfly) and Kumander Sundang (Commander Dagger), 1948; Padre Burgos (Father Burgos), 1949; Kenkoy (Comic), 1950; Mr. and Mrs., 1956; Pitong Gatang (Seven Gantas), 1959; Nobody’s Child, 1970; Mahiwagang Kris (The Fantastic Kris), 1975; and Buhay Misis (Life of a Housewife), 1983. Her other films include I Won, I Won: Ang Swerte Nga Naman (I Won, I Won: How Lucky of Me), 1985; Si Baleleng at ang Gintong Sirena (Baleleng and the Golden Mermaid), 1988; Everlasting Love, 1989; and Chickboys, 1994.

From the 1970s to the 1980s, she concentrated on TV, appearing as the moralizing mother-in-law in the long-running comedy series John en Marsha (John and Marsha), 1973-1990, with Dolphy and Nida Blanca. Written and directed by her brother Ading, John en Marsha, one of the longest running television sitcoms, was the program for which she is best remembered. She reprised her TV role in several movie spinoffs of the series from 1974 to 1991. Atay-Atayan also appeared in another popular television show, Iskul Bukol (Truants), from 1977 to 1990, starring the comedy trio of Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, and Joey de Leon. Like John en Marsha, this series also spawned movie adaptations and remakes.

Atay-Atayan received the Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining (PATAS) Award as Outstanding Actor, 1977, and Best Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series, 1978. She also received the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) at the age of 81 during ceremonies held at the Philippine International Convention Center in 1993. In 2001, the Film Academy of the Philippines honored Atay-atayan with another Lifetime Achievement Award.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis and Lena S. Pareja, updated by E. Carreon and Yna Marei Aguilar

Nora Aunor (Nora Cabaltera Villamayor), also known as Guy, is a film, television, and theater actor, a singer, and a film producer. She was born in Iriga, Camarines Sur on 21 May 1953. Her parents are Antonia Cabaltera and Eustaquio Villamayor. She was married to actor Christopher de Leon, with whom she has one child, actor Ian de Leon, and two adopted daughters, actors Lotlot de Leon and Matet de Leon. Lotlot was married to actor Ramon Christopher, son of actors Eddie Gutierrez and Pilita Corrales. Actor Eddie Villamayor is her brother. Aunor has two other adopted children, Kiko and Kenneth.

Aunor began her career doing the rounds of amateur singing contests. Under the tutelage of her aunt Belen and uncle Saturnino Aunor, who took her under their custody and from whom she got her screen name, she emerged champion in the nationwide TV show Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage) in 1967. Her successful stint in Tawag, as well as in Darigold Jamboree, led to her phenomenal rise as a major star of the Philippine movie industry, which accorded her the title “Superstar.” Dr Jose R. Perez of Sampaguita Pictures signed her up for a contract and initially cast her in bit roles in films like All Over the World and Cinderella A-Go-Go, 1967; Dobol Wedding (Double Wedding), 1968; YeYe Generation! and 9 Teeners, 1969. Two other companies launched Aunor as a lead star in movies released simultaneously in Sep 1969: Tower Productions’ D’ Musical Teenage Idols and JBC Productions’ Fiesta Extravaganza. Her subsequent appearances in the films of Tower, like Teenage Escapades, 1969, and Teenage Jamboree, 1970, led to a lawsuit filed by Sampaguita Pictures Inc (SPI) and its sister company, VP Pictures (VP), for breach of contract. The case dragged on for years while Aunor made films with the two litigants, transferring from Tower to SPI-VP long before the lawsuit was resolved. Among her films for Tower are Tell Nora I Love Her, Three for the Road, Darling, Nora in Wonderland, Tomboy Nora, and Around Asia with Nora, all in 1970, while for SPI-VP she made Young Love and Nasaan Ka, Inay? (Where Are You, Mother?), 1970; Guy and Pip and My Blue Hawaii, 1971; A Gift of Love and Winter Holiday, 1972, among others. The case was finally decided in favor of SPI-VP in 1974. Meanwhile, Aunor had turned movie producer, naming her company NV (Nora Villamayor) Productions.

With the help of Dr Perez, who loaned her his studio and film equipment, NV released its initial film in 1973, Carmela, a horror movie. Aunor produced films with commercial appeal—like Super Gee, 1973, Nestor U. Torre’s As Long as There’s Music, 1974, Batu-Bato sa Langit (Bird in the Sky), 1975, and Annie Batungbakal, 1979—as well as “prestige” projects, including Paru-parong Itim (Black Butterfly), 1973; Banaue, 1975, directed by Gerardo de Leon; Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos (Three Godless Years), 1976; Bona, 1980; and Condemned, 1984. NV also produced films for other stars, like Ander di Saya si Erap (Erap Is Henpecked), 1973, starring Joseph Estrada and Boots Anson-Roa; Ishmael Bernal’s Tisoy (Mestizo), 1976, starring Christopher de Leon and Charo Santos; and Lupita Concio’s Alkitrang Dugo (Blood Tar), 1976, with young stars Eddie Villamayor and Roderick Paulate.

Aunor continued to star in numerous films for other companies, such as Erap Is My Guy, 1973; Dalawang Mukha ng Tagumpay (Two Faces of Victory), 1973, which won for Jun Raquiza the Best Director award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) ; Fe, Esperanza, Caridad, 1974, an anthology of three short features directed by Cirio Santiago, Lamberto V. Avellana, and Gerardo de Leon; Lollipops & Roses at Burong Talangka (Lollipops & Roses and Fermented Crablets), 1975; and the “Goodbye” segment of Romy Suzara’s Hello, Goodnight, Goodbye, 1975, with Rita Gomez. Between 1976 and 1985, her films include Magandang Gabi sa Inyong Lahat (Good Evening Everyone) and Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth),1976; Little Christmas Tree, 1977, with Fernando Poe Jr; Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), 1977, with Joseph Estrada; Ikaw Ay Akin (You Are Mine), 1978; Jack n’ Jill of the Third Kind, 1978, with Dolphy; Bakit May Pag-ibig Pa (Wherefore Love), 1979, in the episode directed by Bernal; Nakaw na Pag-ibig (Stolen Love), Kung Ako’y Iiwan Mo (Should You Abandon Me), and Kastilyong Buhangin (Sand Castle), 1980; Bakit Bughaw ang Langit? (Why Is the Sky Blue?), 1981; Mga Uod at Rosas (Worms and Roses) and T-Bird at Ako (Lesbian Love), 1982; Minsan, May Isang Ina (Once There Was a Mother), 1983; Beloved, Tinik sa Dibdib (Thorn in the Heart), and Till We Meet Again, 1985. In the post-EDSA period to the 1990s, she starrred in Tatlong Ina, Isang Anak (Three Mothers, One Child), 1987; Babae (Woman), 1997; and Sidhi (The Story of Ah), 1999, among others. After appearing in the film Naglalayag (Silent Passage) in 2004, Aunor took semiretirement in the United States. She made a comeback in 2011 and starred in a series of independent films, such as Thy Womb, 2012; Ang Kuwento ni Mabuti (The Story of Mabuti), 2013; Hustisya (Justice), 2014; Dementia, 2014; Kinabukasan (The Day After), 2014, a short film with Alden Richards; and Taklub (Trap), 2015, screened in the Un Certain Regard section of the 68th Cannes Film Festival.

As singer and recording star, Aunor recorded over 200 singles and more than 50 albums, among them The Golden Voice and The Phenomenal Nora Aunor, 1970; The Song of My Life, 1971; Mga Awiting Pilipino (Filipino Songs), 1972; Handog (Gift), 1979; Handog ni Guy: Live (Guy’s Gift: Live), a recording of her first solo concert in Araneta Coliseum, 1991; and Habang Panahon (Forever), 2009.

Her TV musical variety show ran for more than two decades, starting as the Nora-Eddie Show, 1967, with Eddie Peregrina, becoming The Nora Aunor Show in 1968, and Superstar from 1971 to 1989. She also starred in weekly drama anthologies: from Nora Cinderella, 1971-73, to Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora), 1974-79, which received the Sinag award for Outstanding Drama Series from the Philippine Academy for Television Arts and Sciences in 1978. She returned to television in 1993 with a new weekly drama series simply titled Nora. She also had daily drama series on primetime: ABS-CBN’s Bituin (Star), 2002, and TV5’s Sa Ngalan ng Ina (In the Name of the Mother), 2011, where she was reunited with her Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos director Mario O'Hara and costars, Christopher de Leon and Bembol Roco, and Never Say Goodbye, 2013, among others.

On stage, she performed in two major Philippine Educational Theater Association productions: Minsa’y Isang Gamu-Gamo, 1991, and DH (Domestic Helper), 1992. She also played the role of Cassandra in Muslim-a-Babai, 1994, a Filipino adaptation of Euripedes’s The Trojan Women, presented by the Philippine-Cyprus International Theater Institute.

Aunor was nominated 17 times for Best Actress by the FAMAS, winning for Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos; Ina Ka ng Anak Mo (You Are the Mother of Your Daughter), 1979; Bulaklak sa City Jail (Flowers of the City Jail), 1984; Bilangin ang Bituin sa Langit (Count the Stars in the Sky), 1989; and Andrea, Paano Ba ang Maging Isang Ina? (Andrea, How Does One Become a Mother?), 1990. She was elevated to the FAMAS Hall of Fame in 1992. She scored 20 Gawad Urian Best Actress nominations between 1976 and 2015, winning for Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos; Bona; Bilangin ang Bituin sa Langit; Andrea; The Flor Contemplacion Story, 1995; Bakit May Kahapon Pa? (Why Is There a Yesterday?), 1996; and Thy Womb. She was Gawad Urian’s Best Actress of the Decades 1980-89 and 1990-99. She was nominated 17 times by the PMPC Star Awards for Movies between 1984 and 2015; she won for ’Merika (America), 1984; Andrea; Ang Totoong Buhay ni Pacita M. (The Real Life of Pacita M.), 1991; Flor Contemplacion; and Dementia. She got 11 Best Performance nominations from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk between 1990 and 2015, winning for Andrea; Pacita M.; Inay (Mother), 1993; Flor Contemplacion; and Thy Womb. She was nominated 15 times in the Metro Manila Film Festival as lead actor, winning Best Performer for Atsay (Housemaid), 1978, and seven Best Actress awards for Ina Ka ng Anak Mo; Himala (Miracle), 1982; Bulaklak sa City Jail; Andrea; Pacita M.; Muling Umawit ang Puso (The Heart Sings Again), 1995; and Thy Womb. She earned 13 Best Actress nominations from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), winning for Bilangin ang Bituin sa Langit, Andrea, Pacita M., and Flor Contemplacion. From the Catholic Mass Media Awards, she received Best Actress trophies for Bakit Bughaw ang Langit?, Bulaklak sa City Jail, and Andrea (runner-up). For Hustisya, she won a Balanghai trophy for Best Actress (Directors Showcase) in the 2014 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival.

Aunor first gained international acclaim as an actor through Lino Brocka’s Bona (Directors’ Fortnight, 1981 Cannes Film Festival) and Ishmael Bernal’s Himala (main competition, 1983 Berlin Film Festival). She won Best Actress awards at the 1995 Cairo International Film Festival for The Flor Contemplacion Story; the 1997 East Asia Film and Television Festival in Penang, Malaysia for Bakit May Kahapon Pa?; the 2004 Brussels International Independent Film Festival for Naglalayag; and the 2015 St. Tropez International Film Festival for Dementia. Brillante Mendoza’s Thy Womb competed in the 2012 Venice Film Festival, where Aunor received a Bisato d’Oro (Golden Eel) as “Best Actress of the Festival” from the European critics group that gives Premio della Critica Indipendente (Independent Critics’ Prize). For her performance in the same film, Aunor won Best Actress in the 2013 Sakhalin International Film Festival in Russia, as well as in the two Asian region awards: the Asia Pacific Screen Awards (APSA), 2012, held in Brisbane, Australia; and the Asian Film Awards, 2013, held in Hong Kong. In 2014, Aunor was again nominated by the APSA for Best Performance by an Actress for Hustisya. She was conferred a Lifetime Achievement Award at the 2015 ASEAN International Film Festival and Awards in Kuching, Sarawak, Malaysia.

Aunor was chosen one of the Ten Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service in 1983. The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) awarded her the Centennial Honors for the Arts in 1999. She received Lifetime Achievement Awards from the FAP in 1994, Philippine Movie Press Club in 1997, Awit Awards in 1998, Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival in 2011, Golden Screen Awards in 2012, Cinemanila International Film Festival as World Cinema artist in 2012, Aliw Awards in 2013, and Gawad Urian in 2015. She won the Gawad Plaridel as outstanding transmedia practitioner from the University of the Philippines College of Mass Communication in 2014. In 2015, she received the Gawad CCP para sa Sining for film and broadcast arts; the Diwa ng Lahi for cinema from the City of Manila; Bulawan na Bikolnon (Golden Bikolnon), the highest honor bestowed by Ateneo de Naga to outstanding Bicolano artists; and the Gusi Peace Prize for international excellence in performing arts.  Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

Amy Austria (Esmeralda Dizon Tuazon) is a film and television actor. She was born in Tondo, Manila on 13 Dec 1961. The second eldest among six children born to a poor couple, she helped support the family by selling chewing gum. She studied at Rajah Soliman High School. She and the late actor Jay Ilagan have an adopted daughter, Alexandra.

Austria was introduced to producer Baby Martinez of MBM Productions by a kin of her friend, actor Ruby Anna. She was cast in Bitayin si Baby Ama (Execute Baby Ama), 1976, the movie that made Rudy Fernandez an action star. After doing her second picture, Alas (Ace), 1976, with Jun Aristorenas, she was given minor parts in a number of movies, then dropped out of the scene for almost a year. When she came back in mid-1977, she was a contract star of Jesse Ejercito’s Seven Star Productions. She became one of the busiest actors in the late 1970s, appearing in such films as Dabiana, 1977; Miss Dulce Amor, Ina (Miss Dulce Amor, Mother) and Atsay (Housemaid), 1978; Menor de Edad (Underage), Gabun, Ama Mo, Ama Ko (Gabun, Your Father, My Father), Bedspacers, and Swing It, Baby, 1979. Two of her most important films in 1979 are Ishmael Bernal’s Aliw (Pleasure) and Lino Brocka’s Jaguar (Guard), which was chosen by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) and the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino as the best picture of the year. She was promoted to full stardom in Nang Bumuka ang Sampaguita (When the Sampaguita Blossomed), 1980. This was followed by Langis at Tubig (Oil and Water), Sugat sa Ugat (Wound in the Roots), and Goriong Butete, all in 1980; Tondo Girl, 1981; Pusong Uhaw (Thirsty Heart) and Waywaya, 1982. She played supporting roles in Hinugot sa Langit (Wrenched from Heaven), 1985, The Flor Contemplacion Story, 1995, Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 1999, and Bagong Buwan (New Moon) and Pagdating ng Panahon (When the Time Comes), 2001.

As a television actor, Austria has appeared in many drama series, including GMA Network’s Kirara, Ano ang Kulay ng Pag-ibig? (Kirara, What is the Color of Love), 1999, Mulawin , 2004, Sugo (Savior), 2005, andTanikala: Ang Ikaapat na Yugto – Unos (Chains: The Fourth Act – Tempest), 2012,and ABS-CBN’s Pangako Sa 'Yo (The Promise), 2000, Bituing Walang Ningning (Star Without Sparkle), 2006, Minsan Lang Kita Iibigin (I Will Love You Only Once), 2011, Ikaw Lamang (No Greater Love), 2014, and the 2015 remake of Pangako sa ’Yo. She also appeared in numerous episodes of ABS-CBN's drama anthology, Maalala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember).

Austria has five Best Actress awards: two for Brutal, 1980, from FAMAS and the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF); and three for Celestina Sanchez, Alyas Bubbles, 1988, from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA), and the MMFF. She has three Best Supporting Actress awards: for Jaguar from the Gawad Urian and for Narito ang Puso Ko (Here Is My Heart), 1992, from the Gawad Urian and the FAP. She and Phillip Salvador, together with the late director Lino Brocka, represented the Philippines at Cannes Film Festival in 1980, where Jaguar was showcased in the main competition.  Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

Ariston Avelino (Ariston Tejoro Avelino), also known as Aris, was a composer, film scorer, conductor, and pianist. He was bornin Tondo, Manila on 7 Sep 1911. He died in Tagaytay City on 18 Feb 1980. His father, Juan Avelino, was a music teacher; his mother, Nicolasa Tejoro, sang in school choruses; his sister Dolores played the piano. He married movie actor Lirio Lakindanum. He played the piano by ear, and later learned to read notes. He taught himself to play the clarinet and saxophone. During his high school days at the Manila East (now Mapa High) School, he played in the school orchestra as pianist. After graduating from high school in 1929, Avelino could not afford to go on to college, so he worked and joined Serafin Payawal’s Orchestra, which played dance music at the Bayview Hotel.

 

He was also the pianist of the Modern Theater in Sampaloc and of the Starr Phonograph Company which released top hit records of the day. Later he joined the KZRM Orchestra as pianist under Johnny Harris. After Harris’ resignation, he became its conductor and subsequently program director.

 

During the Japanese Occupation, he played for community programs and stage shows. After World War II, he returned to radio work and at the same time organized an orchestra. He also had a stint as conductor of the Manila Polo Club Orchestra. In 1949 he resigned from radio but continued conducting the orchestra for the Camay Theatre of the Air for two more years. Avelino’s talent in composing music was enhanced when he attended Miklos Rosza’s lectures on motion picture scoring at the University of California during his trip to the United States in 1951-52.

 

It was while Avelino was at KZRM that he first composed for motion pictures. His first assignment, Dalaga, Isang Ngiti Mo Lamang (Lady, Just a Smile From You), 1940, was followed by many others, including the scores for Padre Burgos (Father Burgos), 1949; Sisa, 1951; Hanggang sa Dulo ng Daigdig (To the Ends of the Earth), 1958; and Habang Buhay (While There is Life), 1953.

 

In 1953, he won an award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for musical direction for his work on the movie Habang Buhay. His scores for Desperado (Desperate), 1956, and Condenado (Condemned), 1958, were nominated for Best Musical Score in 1957 and 1959 respectively. From 1955 to 1972, he composed 89 movie songs, with years 1965 and 1966 being his most productive period. Aside from film scoring, Avelino composed jazzy popular tunes, lyrical ballads, and kundiman. He received a special citation from the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP) for his achievements.  Written by J. Dalisay, updated by Josephine Baradas

Angel Avellana (Angel Perez Avellana) was a film sound director. He was born in Tondo, Manila on 2 Mar 1926. He died in Manila on 1 Feb 1983. The son of Francisco Avellana and Milagros Perez, he studied at San Beda College and Mapua Institute of Technology where he earned a degree in electrical engineering. He also studied radio engineering on his own. He was married to Rosario Evangelista, by whom he had six children. At the time of his death he was a member of the Society of Motion Pictures and Television Engineers.

Consulted by cousin Lamberto V. Avellana regarding film sound, he soon found himself working in the film industry as sound technician for the Philippine Artists League, 1943; as recordist for Movie Technical Services Inc aka Movietec, a film facilities leasing outfit; as sound engineer for Phil-Am Films Inc; and as sound consultant of Sampaguita Pictures.

Avellana received Best Sound Recording awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for his work in the films Pinagbuklod ng Langit (Joined by Heaven), 1969; Asedillo, 1971; Kill the Pushers, 1972; and Hanggang sa Kabila ng Daigdig (Till the Other Side of the World), 1973. He received a Gawad Urian nomination for Laruang Apoy (Playing with Fire), 1977. He is acknowledged to have contributed significantly to innovations in sound engineering in spite of inferior equipment, and to the training of Filipino sound technicians. Avellana was posthumously elevated to the FAMAS Hall of Fame in 1983.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

Jose Mari Avellana (Jose Ma. Antonio Hontiveros Avellana) was a film and theater actor, film and theater director, producer, screenwriter, cinematographer, and production designer. He was born in Manila on 6 May 1941. He died in Manila on 26 Jun 2011. He was the son of film and stage director Lamberto V. Avellana and stage actor Lourdes Genoveva Dolores Pardo Hontiveros aka Daisy Hontiveros, both National Artists. His sister Ivi Avellana-Cosio is a visual artist and actor. His brother Lamberto Jr is a documentary filmmaker. He was married to Corazon Sarmiento with whom he had four children. He received his early education at Ateneo de Manila, high school at Far Eastern University, and his bachelor of arts degree in English at San Beda College, 1964. He was a member of the Kapisanan ng mga Direktor ng Pelikulang Pilipino, vice president for internal affairs of the Screenwriters Guild of the Philippines, and member of the Organization of Specialized Filipino Filmmakers.

He made his theatrical debut in high school at Far Eastern University under the direction of Sarah K. Joaquin. He played Tajomaru in Rashomon and went on to essay such roles as King Creon in Oedipus, Mercutio in Romeo and Juliet , Marc Anthony in Anthony and Cleopatra, Shylock in The Merchant of Venice, and Hamlet in Hamlet. In the 1960s, while still in college, he began his career as a radio announcer with DZFM radio. He shifted to theater and movies as an actor and director in the 1970s. He joined the roster of actors in the Barangay Theater Guild, which his parents founded. From 1975 to 1991, he took roles such as Tony Javier in A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, Tom Wingfield in The Glass Menagerie, Biff in Death of a Salesmen, Lophakin in The Cherry Orchard, Jamie Tyrone in Long Day’s Journey into Night, Simon in Sign of the Seagulls, Elias in Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), and Hamlet in Hamlet. He acted in Repertory Philippines’s (Rep) Rosencrantz and Guildernstein Are Dead, 1969, as Rosencrantz; Belcher’s Luck as Harry Belcher and Rashomon as Tajomaru, both in 1970; Equus, 1975, as Dr Dysart; The Diary of Anne Frank, 1976, as Otto Frank; Loot, 1977, as Truscott; Woman in Black, 1993, as Arthur Kipps; and Tuesdays with Morrie, 2008, as Morrie; Teatro Pilipino’s Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira), 1977, as Abdalap, and Haring Edipo (Oedipus Rex), 1978, as Edipo; Tanghalang Pilipino’s Cyrano de Bergerac, 1980, as Cyrano; and the Artist’s Theatre Company’s A Life in the Theater, 1982, as Robert. For Rep’s Tuesdays with Morrie, he won Best Actor in a Play at the 2008 Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group Gawad Buhay!

In the 1970s, he directed Barangay Theater Guild’s Turn Red the Sea at the CCP and the staged reading of Memoir at the Heritage Art Center in 1991. He directed Rep’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 2009, which won him the Best Direction of a Play award at the Aliw Awards of the same year. In 1962, he became the first TV director for PBS Channel 4. In the 1970s, he directed and wrote several soap operas, drama specials, action thrillers, and musicals for TV station ABS-CBN. Afterward, he moved to KBS where he directed Oh, Rosemarie and shared directorial tasks with George Rowe in the production of Sinekulay, the first-ever series of movies filmed for local television. In the 1980s, he joined his father in the family business as producer-director for Documentary Incorporated. While working for his father, Avellana produced cultural, advocacy, and tourism-oriented films, as well as technical and informational audiovisual presentations for the National Media Production Center and other government agencies.

During the 1980s, he was hired by Cirio H. Santiago of Premiere Productions to appear in a co-production venture with Roger Corman’s company. Santiago exposed him to the world of low-budget films as director, writer, actor, director of photography, and production designer. He directed Killer Instinct, 1987; Bloodfist, 1989; Fist of Glory and Moro, 1991; Kung Mawawala Ka Pa (If I Lose You), 1993; Damong Ligaw (Wild Grass), 1997, based on Ceres Alabado's young adult novel, Kangkong 1986; Emilio Aguinaldo, 2000; Operation Balikatan, 2003; Colorum, 2009; and Vox Populi, 2010. He wrote the scripts of Fast Gun, 1988, Fist of Glory, 1991, Damong Ligaw, and Anak ng Bulkan (Son of the Volcano), 1997. He acted in Boys of Company C, 1978; Wheels of Fire, 1985; Saigon Commandoes, 1988; Bloodfist, Operation Balikatan, and When Eagles Strike, 2003; Bloodfist 2004, 2004; and The Hunt for Eagle One: Crash Point, 2006. He was director of photography in Final Mission, 1984; Wheels of Fire; Fast Gun; and Bloodfist. He worked as production designer and co-director in When Eagles Strike, Bloodfist 2004, and The Hunt for Eagle One: Crash Point.

Avellana won the Best Supporting Actor award in the 2003 Manila Film Festival for his role in Operation Balikatan. His directorial works have received critical acclaim. Geothermal Energy NMO won the Golden Globe for Best Specialized Film, 1977. The Lenny Villa Story won the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon and Best Foreign Docu-Drama at the Emmy Awards for Daytime Programming, USA, 1992. Salisalising Buhay (Criscrossed Lives) won the Best Drama Mini-Series from PMPC Star Awards, Oscar Special Award for Foreign Soap Operas, and recognitions from the New York Soap Opera Digest and Population Communications International, 1993. Kung Mawawala Ka Pa won Best Picture in the 1993 Metro Manila Film Festival. Taghoy ng Dagat (Lament of the Sea) won Best Movie for Television in the 1993 Star Awards. Damong Ligaw won Best Story Adaptation in the 1998 Film Academy of the Philippines Awards.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis, updated by Walter Ang

Lamberto V. Avellana (Lamberto Vera Avellana), also known as Donato Valentin, was a theater and film director and producer. He is a National Artist for film and theater. He was born in Bontoc, Mountain Province on 12 Feb 1915. He died in Manila on 25 Apr 1991. He was the son of Dr Jose Avellana and Rita Vera. He married actor Lourdes Genoveva Dolores Pardo Hontiveros aka Daisy Hontiveros. She is also a National Artist for theater. Their children are Jose Mari, actor and director; Marivi aka Ivi, visual artist and actor; and Lamberto Jr, documentary filmmaker. He studied at Ateneo de Manila from grade school to college. An outstanding student and campus leader, he obtained a bachelor of arts degree from Ateneo de Manila in 1937. Receiving his first theater training from Jesuit Fr Henry Lee Irwin, he became the lead actor and director of major stage productions in school.

Together with his wife and some 50 young theater artists and enthusiasts, Avellana formed the Barangay Theater Guild (BTG) in 1939 and became its artistic director. Carlos P. Romulo, seeing one of his plays, offered him a directorial job at Filippine Films. Avellana’s first movie for the company was Sakay, 1939. While continuing to work with BTG and other theater groups, he made Alitaptap (Firefly) and Inday, 1940; Lihim (Secret), Ikaw Pala (It’s You), and Rosalinda, 1941; and Tia Juana (Aunt Juana), 1943. When World War II broke out and the Japanese war regime allowed stage shows, Avellana worked with producer Sammy Rodriguez of the Philippine Artists League in staging bodabil shows at the Avenue Theater in Manila. Their initial production, also the first during the war, was Tropicana, 1942, an extravaganza featuring Leopoldo Salcedo. Avellana also worked with Lou Salvador Sr in presenting shows at the Apollo theater, the first being Cuban Serenade, 1943, a musical comedy featuring Bimbo Danao.

After the war, Avellana resumed movie work with most of his films done at LVN Studio. He directed Hantik (Black Ant), 1950, which won for Tony Santos the Maria Clara Best Supporting Actor award; Korea, 1952, which won for Gil de Leon and Nida Blanca the Best Supporting Actor and Best Supporting Actress trophies at the first Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) awards rites; Kandelerong Pilak (Silver Candlesticks), 1954, which won for Lilia Dizon the Best Actress award at the Cambodian Film Festival; Kundiman ng Lahi (Love Song of the Race), 1959, which won for Charito Solis her first FAMAS award; and A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965, which won the Manila Film Festival award for best technically produced film. He directed a popular radio serial, Clodualdo del Mundo Sr’s Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), 1950, and its sequel Prinsipe Amante sa Rubitanya (Prince Amante in Rubitanya), 1951, both starring Rogelio de la Rosa; In Despair and Ang Bombero (The Firefighter), 1950; Pag-asa (Hope), Satur, and Amor Mio (My Love), 1951; Sa Paanan ng Nazareno (At the Foot of the Nazarene), Aklat ng Buhay (Book of Life), and Haring Solomon at Reyna Sheba (King Solomon and Queen Sheba), 1952; Loida and Hiyasmin, 1953; Damong Ligaw (Wild Grass), 1954; Lapu-Lapu and Saydwok Bendor (Sidewalk Vendor), 1955; the “Welga” (Strike) episode of Medalyong Perlas (Pearl Medallion), No Money, No Honey, and Kumander 13 (Commander 13), 1956; Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1957, starring Charito Solis and Mario Montenegro, and the remake of his pre-World War II film Rosa Linda, retitled Rosalina, starring Mila del Sol and Nida Blanca. In 1958, he did Faithful starring Rosa Rosal. He also directed films for other studios, like Tandang Sora (Old Woman Sora), 1947; Scout Rangers, 1964; and Kumander Dimas (Commander Dimas), 1968, which was chosen Best Picture by the Citizens’ Council for Mass Media. In 1967 he was invited by Hong Kong magnate Run Run Shaw to direct the film Sergeant Hassan, 1967, for worldwide release. His other internationally released films are Destination Vietnam, 1969, and The Evil Within, 1970.

For the theater, he directed the first production of Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1955, made into film a decade later. Other memorable stage productions from 1954 to 1964 are Leonor Orosa-Goquingco’s My Son, Jose; Antonio Bayot’s Rejection; Conrado Pedroche’s A Little Comer of the City; Wifrido Ma. Guerrero’s Forever; Marcelino Agana’s New Yorker in Tondo; and Claro M. Recto’s Shadow and Solitude, Nick Joaquin’s English translation of the play in Spanish.

Avellana won the FAMAS award for Best Director for Huk sa Bagong Pamumuhay (Huk in a New Life), 1953. He received the FAMAS International Prestige Award four times: for Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956, and Badjao, 1957, both starring Rosa Rosal and Tony Santos; El Legado (The Legacy), 1960; and La Campana de Baler (The Church Bell of Baler), 1961. Anak Dalita won the Grand Prix as Best Picture at the Asian Film Festival in Hong Kong; Badjao won for him the Best Director award and three other major awards at the Asian Film Festival in Tokyo; El Legado won the Conde de Foxa award in Bilbao, Spain; La Campana repeated the feat a year later at the same international film festival when it won the Conde de Foxa silver medal “for the best film exaltation of Spanish valours.” In 1969 he received the Best Documentary award at the Cambodian Film Festival for his film The Survivor. He was given the Presidential Citation for Excellence in Film Direction by Presidents Elpidio Quirino, Ramon Magsaysay, Carlos Garcia, Diosdado Macapagal, and Ferdinand Marcos. He received the 1981 Natatanging Gawad Urian (Lifetime Achievement Award) from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino, and in 1991, a posthumous Lifetime Achievement Award from the Film Academy of the Philippines.

On 27 Mar 1976, Avellana was conferred the National Artist Award, for film and theater, by the president of the Republic of the Philippines. In 2015, Avellana’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino was restored through the funding of the Film Development Council of the Philippines and the National Film Archive of the Philippines. In the same year, Ateneo de Manila University gave Avellana a monthlong tribute, titled “Lamberto V. Avellana @ 100: Portrait of the Artist as an Atenean,” that showcased and commemorated his contributions to Philippine film.  Written by Malou M. Maniquis and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

Raymond Bagatsing (Ramon San Diego Bagatsing III) is a film, television, and theater actor. He was born on 15 Sep 1969. He is the eldest child of Ramon Bagatsing Jr and Emerlinda San Diego, whose marriage begot 10 children. Younger siblings Monina and RK share Raymond’s passion for acting. He studied political science and legal studies in Melbourne, Australia.

Bagatsing was a college student when he entered the movie industry in the late 1990s as an action star, often taking the role of the kontrabida (villain), before he forayed into doing dramatic roles. His most memorable films include Dugo sa Pakpak ng Anghel (Blood on the Wings of an Angel), 1980; Tondo: Libingan ng mga Siga (Tondo: Grave of the Courageous), 1992; Tagos sa Laman (Down to the Flesh) and Nena, 1995; Bastardo (Bastard), 1997; Bata, Bata … Paano Ka Ginawa? (Lea’s Story), 1998; Burlesk King (King of Stripteasers), Soltera (The Spinster), and Suspek (Suspect), 1999; Marital Rape and Tatarin (St John’s Day Ritual), 2001; Sanib (Possession), Alab ng Lahi (Fire of the Race), and Filipinas, 2003; What a Wonderful Place, 2005; and Brown Soup Thing, 2008. After taking a break from showbiz to live in California from 2006 to 2010, he made his comeback in 2011. He has since thenappeared in a number of local movies including Boundary, 2011; Captive, 2012;The Guerilla is a Poet, 2013; Mumbai Love and The Janitor, 2014; and Felix Manalo, 2015. He was also in Sari Dalena's docudrama Dahling Nick, 2015, where he portrayed National Artist for literature Nick Joaquin.

On television, Bagatsing has played character roles in various drama series of GMA Network like Encantadia, 2005; Time of My Life and Amaya , 2011; One True Love, The Good Daughter, and Temptation of Wife, 2012; Genesis, 2013; and Strawberry Lane, 2014. He also appeared in a number of episodes of GMA's Magpakailanman (Eternity) and ABS-CBN's Ipaglaban Mo (Fight For It).

Bagatsing is also a musician as well as a theater actor. In 2003-06, he lay low from showbiz to become lead vocalist and composer for his rock band Raymond Bagatsing & The Bandidoz. He took part in various stage plays, including Dramatis Personae’s The Man Outside, Anton Juan’s A Streetcar Named Desire, Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company's KKK, Ballet Philippines’s La Revolucion Filipina (The Filipina Revolution), World Theater’s A Portrait of an Artist as Filipino, and the musical Lalawigan (Province) in San Francisco, California.

It was for his offbeat roles in films and on television that his sensitive portrayals gained critical attention, locally and internationally, winning for him several major acting awards. Bagatsing was named Best Actor twice by the Gawad Urian: for Milagros, 1998, and for Serafin Geronimo: Kriminal ng Barrio Concepcion (The Criminal of Barrio Concepcion), 1999. He was likewise named Best Supporting Actor by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences and the Film Academy of the Philippines for Soltera. He received another Best Supporting Actor award, this time from the Gawad Urian for Burlesk King.

For his work on television, Bagatsing received a Best Actor award from the Singapore Asian Television Awards for “Wedding Ring,” an episode in Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2001. He also received a Best Actor award from the Golden Screen Awards for Television for Narito ang Puso Ko (Here Is My Heart), 2003.  Written by Camilo Villanueva Jr, with notes from Clodualdo del Mundo Jr

Conrado Baltazar (Conrado Casaje Baltazar), also known as Dengcar, was a cinematographer. He was born in Quezon City on 21 Feb 1929. He died in Manila on 11 Aug 1988. His parents are Clemente Baltazar, a set designer, and Perfecta Casaje. He studied at Far Eastern University from elementary to college. He was married to Emiliana Gallardo and they had four children, one of whom, Jim, runs the family-owned CMB Film Services, a film equipment company that Baltazar established more than 30 years ago.

Baltazar was the favorite cinematographer and frequent collaborator of the late director Lino Brocka. They worked together in such films as Santiago, 1970; Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (You Were Weighed and Found Wanting), 1974; Insiang, 1976; Rubia Servios, 1978; Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Mother, Sister, Daughter) and Ina Ka ng Anak Mo (You Are the Mother of Your Daughter), 1979; Bona and Nakaw na Pag-ibig (Stolen Love), 1980; Cain at Abel (Cain and Abel), 1982; Hot Property, 1983; and Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim (My Country: Gripping the Knife’s Edge), 1985. His other memorable works include Kaibigan Ko’ng Sto. Niño (The Holy Infant Is My Friend), 1967; Alipin ng Busabos (Slave of the Destitute), 1968; Haydee, 1970; Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos (Three Godless Years), 1976; Mortal, 1976; Dapat Ka Bang Mahalin? (Should You Be Loved?) and Hotshots, 1984; Virgin Forest and Bomba Arienda, 1985; Yesterday, Today & Tomorrow, Sensual, and Nasaan Ka Nang Kailangan Kita? (Where Were You When I Needed You?), 1986.

He received the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Cinematography award for his work in Salambao (Fishnet), 1964. Baltazar also won in the 1976 Metro Manila Film Festival for Insiang. He was a three-time Gawad Urian awardee for Best Cinematography for Gumising Ka … Maruja (Wake Up … Maruja), 1978; Jaguar (Guard), 1979; and Angela Markado (Angela the Marked One), 1980. Two of the films that Baltazar and Brocka have collaborated on were presented at the Cannes Film Festival: Jaguar in 1980 and Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim in 1984. Baltazar was a posthumous recipient of the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Cinemanila International Film Festival in 2013.  Written by Rosalinda Galang and Anne Frances Sangil

Gaudencio Barredo (Gaudencio Leonardo Barredo) is a film sound director. He was born in Manila on 30 Aug 1936. His parents are Victor Barredo and Consorcia Leonardo. He is married to Natividad de la Cruz with whom he has three children. He attended Arellano High School and took an electronics course at FEATI Institute of Technology. He apprenticed for two years under Angel Avellana, a sound technician at Lebran Productions, and worked with Sampaguita Pictures for many years.

Some of the films he worked on are Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven), 1991, Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal (You’re the Only One I’ve Loved), 1992, and Lumayo Ka Man sa Akin (Though You Stray from Me), 1991.

Barredo received Best Sound awards for Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Heron Turns Black) from the Gawad Urian in 1979; for Rubia Servios from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) in 1978; for Kadete (Cadet) from the MMFF in 1979; for Hihintayin Kita sa Langit from Gawad Urian and the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) in 1992; and for Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 1993. He received nominations for Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos (Three Godless Years) from FAMAS in 1977; for Nagbabagang Luha (Smoldering Tears) from the FAP in 1989; for Boy Life from the FAP in 1990; and for Takbo, Talon, Tili (Run, Jump, Shout) from the MMFF in 1992.  Written by Raquel Hernandez

Claudine Barretto (Claudine Margaret Castelo Barretto) is a television and film actor. She was born in Manila on 20 Jul 1979. She is the youngest among four daughters of Miguel Alvir Barretto and Estrella Castelo. Her sisters Gretchen Barretto and Marjorie Barretto are also in the entertainment industry. Actor Julia Barretto, daughter of Marjorie and actor Dennis Padilla, is her niece. Barretto is now legally separated from actor Raymart Santiago, with whom she has a son named Santino. Barretto also takes care of her adopted daughter, Sabina.

Child star Claudine Barretto started her career in ABS-CBN’s Ang TV (The TV), 1992, and Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad), 1992-2003. She then appeared in the films Taong Gubat (Man from the Forest) and Muntik na Kitang Minahal (I Almost Loved You), 1994; Pare Ko (Hey Dude), 1995; and Radio Romance, 1996. She was also a cast member of the film Oki Doki Doc: The Movie, 1995; May Nagmamahal sa Iyo (Madonna and Child), Mangarap Ka (Dream On), and Madrasta (Stepmother), 1996; Calvento Files: The Movie and Flames: The Movie, 1997; Dahil Mahal na Mahal Kita (Because I Love You So Much), 1998; Soltera (The Spinster), 1999; Anak (The Child), 2000; Kailangan Kita (I Need You) and Got 2 Believe, 2002; Milan, 2004; Nasaan Ka Man (Wherever You Are) and Dubai, 2005; Sukob (The Wedding Curse), 2006; In Your Eyes, 2010; and Etiquette for Mistresses, 2015.

Barretto is also a prominent face on television. She was part of the comedy series Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Wait for the Next Chapter), 1994-96, and the teen-oriented drama series Gimik (Hang Out), 1996. She played the lead role in some of ABS-CBN's toprating drama series on primetime: Mula sa Puso (From the Heart), 1997-99; Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1999; Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001; Marina, 2004; Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin (You Are Everything to Me), 2005; Walang Kapalit (Nobody Else), 2007; and Iisa Pa Lamang (Just One), 2008. She has also appeared in several episodes of Maalala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember).

In 1997, Barretto won Best TV Personality in the Star Awards for Television for her role in Star Drama Presents: Kasunduan (Star Drama Presents: The Deal). She received the German Moreno Youth Achievement Award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 2002. She also received Best Actress awards for Milan from the Film Academy of the Philippines and the FAMAS in 2005 and for Nasaan Ka Man from the PMPC Star Awards for Movies and the FAMAS in 2006.  Written by Christian Co, with notes from Mario Mendez Jr and Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

Teresa Barrozo (Maria Teresa Lopez Barrozo) is a music composer, film scorer, and sound designer for film and theater. She was born in Quezon City on 7 Aug 1982. The daughter of Raul Sta. Maria Barrozo and Guillermina Dimacali Lopez, she took undergraduate courses in composition at the University of the Philippines College of Music. She trained in film scoring at the Asia Pacific Film Institute in 2005 and in musical theater at the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) in 2007. In 2014, she received the Asian Cultural Council grant to explore the sound art scene in the United States.

Barrozo’s key works are characterized by experimentation, the use of sound design as music, and minimalism. For instance, her work on Brillante Mendoza’s Kinatay (The Execution of P.), 2009, and Captive, 2011, and as well as on Adolfo Alix’s Kalayaan (Wildlife) and Vincent Sandoval’s Aparisyon (Apparition), both in 2012, are reliant on unobtrusive and yet haunting ambient sounds. For Mendoza’s Tirador (Slingshot), 2007, and Ralston Jover’s Bakal Boys (Children Metal Divers), 2009, she utilized tin cans, wood, and metal for her compositions to match the film’s gritty imagery. And for Sari Dalena’s Ka Oryang (Comrade Oryang), 2011, she used bells and ringing sounds to recast the lullaby.

Barrozo collaborated with certain directors. With Mendoza, she also worked on Lola (Grandmother), 2009, and Thy Womb, 2012. With Alix, she did Karera (Ante), 2009, and Presa (Female Prisoner) and Romeo at Juliet (Romeo and Juliet ), both in 2010. With Jade Castro, she worked on Zombadings: Patayin sa Shokot si Remington (Remington and the Curse of the Zombadings), 2011, and Juana C. The Movie, 2013. With Keith Sicat, she did Room 213, 2008, and Woman of the Ruins, 2013. Her other notable works include: in 2008, Raya Martin’s Possible Lovers; in 2010, John Torres’s Ang Ninanais (Refrains Happen Like Revolutions in a Song); in 2012, Rory Quintos’s Suddenly It’s Magic and Sherad Anthony Sanchez’s Jungle Love; and in 2013, Eduardo Roy’s Quick Change and Alvin Yapan’s Debosyon (Devotion).

Barrozo won Best Music for her work on Joyce Bernal’s 10,000 Hours, 2013, at the 39th Metro Manila Film Festival; Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration for Adolfo Alix’s Kalayaan at the Young Critics Circle Film Desk annual citations; Best Music Score for Sari Dalena’s Ka Oryang at the 2011 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival; and Best Original Soundtrack for Brillante Mendoza’s Kinatay at the 42nd Sitges International Film Festival in Spain. She also received the Ani ng Dangal Award at the Philippine International Arts Festival of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, 2010.

Aside from film work, Barrozo did the score for GMA News TV's miniseries Titser (Teacher), 2013. She also did compositions and sound design for the Sipat Lawin Ensemble, Tanghalang Ateneo, Ateneo ENTABLADO, Dulaang UP, Ballet Philippines, PETA, and collaborated with dancer-choreographer Myra Beltran.  Written by Patrick Campos

Jose Batac Jr, also known as Joe Batac Jr, is a cinematographer. He was born in Manila on 22 Sep 1932. He is the son of Jose and Eulogia Batac. He studied at Manila Central University. Producer-director Cirio H. Santiago helped him get a break in the movie industry. He worked his way up to the top ranks of his profession, and was former president of the Filipino Society of Cinematographers.

Batac worked for the major local movie production companies, such as Viva Films, Regal Films, Star Cinema, and Premiere Films International. He also worked with international movie production companies—such as Concorde-New Horizons, New Horizons Pictures–USA, and Peer Oppenheimer Production Inc—that produced films in the Philippines as well as in the USA.

His notable films include Mga Batong Buhay (Living Stones), 1970; Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (You Were Weighed and Found Wanting), 1974; Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth), 1976; Mananayaw (Dancer), 1978; Saan Darating ang Umaga? (Where Will the Morning Come?), 1983; Apoy sa Iyong Kandungan (Fire in Your Cradle), 1984; Tinik sa Dibdib (Thorn in the Heart), 1985; Kumander Dante (Commander Dante), 1988; Imortal (Immortal), 1989; Hanggang Kailan Kita Mama halin? (Until When Will I Love You?), 1997; and Anak (The Child), 2001. In addition, he was also second unit cameraman for both Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000, and Kailangan Kita (I Need You), 2002.

Batac also did the cinematography for several American productions filmed in the Philippines—for example, Whiteforce and Braddock: Missing in Action III, 1988; Dune Warriors, 1991; Raiders of the Sun, 1992; Angelfist, 1993; Caged Heat II: Stripped of Freedom and Angel of Destruction, 1994.

He was also the director of photography for several episodes of ABS-CBN’s TV series Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2005-06. He was also lighting director for several episodes of ABS-CBN’s Nagsimula sa Puso (It Began from the Heart) and Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009.

In 1987, Batac won the Best Cinematography award from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) for Nasaan Ka Nang Kailangan Kita? (Where Were You When I Needed You?). He also received the Lamberto Avellana Award from the FAP in 2012.  Written by Raquel Hernandez, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

Dez Bautista (Benjamin Basilidez Garong Bautista) is a film production designer, screenwriter, and cultural historian. He was born in Malolos, Bulacan on 12 Jun 1948. His parents are Jose Bautista and Norma Garong. He finished his elementary at Immaculata Academy of Malolos and his high school at San Jose Seminary. He worked for a bachelor’s degree in humanities and philosophy at Ateneo de Manila University.

Bautista began his career writing scripts, designing sets and costumes, and directing for the theater productions of Babaylan. He became involved in the movies in 1977 when he did the production design of Hubad na Bayani (A Hero Stripped), directed by Robert Ylagan. Then, he worked in such films as Sa Piling ng mga Sugapa (In the Company of Addicts), 1977; Mahal Mo, Mahal Ko (Your Love, My Love), 1978; Magkaribal (Rivals), Iskandalo (Scandal), Disgrasyada (Fallen Woman), Stepsisters, and Bedspacers, 1979; Nympha, Tanikala (Chains), and Katorse (Fourteen), 1980; Diosa (Goddess) and Diary of Kristina Gaston, 1982; and Yesterday, Today & Tomorrow, 1986. In 2001, he wrote a screen adaptation of Nick Joaquin’s play Tatarin and did the art direction for the movie. He also handled production design and direction for TV commercials, TV series, and documentaries for both local and foreign films.

Even while active in the movies, Bautista continued with his stage work, doing sets and costume designs for productions like Godspell, directed by Behn Cervantes; Hello, Dolly by Zeneida Amador; and Flores para los Muertos (Flowers for the Dead), Orlando Nadres's Filipino translation of Tennessee Williams's A Streetcar Named Desire, directed by Lino Brocka. He also conducted drama workshops and gave lectures in schools and cultural venues. In 1981, he founded, together with his colleagues in the industry, the Production Designers Guild of the Philippines under the Film Academy of the Philippines.

In 1978, Bautista won the Gawad Urian for Best Production Design for Hubad na Bayani. Fiesta, for which he did the script, design, and direction, received an award as Best Cultural-Tourism Documentary at the 1987 Tashkent Film Festival in Russia and was the Philippine entry in the 1988 ASEAN Film Festival in Malaysia.  Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

Lualhati Bautista (Lualhati Torres Bautista) is a fictionist and screenwriter. She was born in Tondo, Manila on 2 Dec 1945. She is one of the six children born to Esteban Bautista, a composer, singer, and poet, and Gloria Torres. She has three children. She graduated from the Emilio Jacinto Elementary School, 1958, and Gregorio Perfecto High School, 1962. She enrolled at the Lyceum of the Philippines, 1964, but dropped out of her journalism course in less than a year. She began writing professionally after high school. She was at one time vice president of the Screenwriters Guild of the Philippines, and is a member of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines, founding member of the Women Involved in Creating Culture Alternatives, and chair of Kapisanan ng mga Manunulat ng Nobelang Popular. She was editor of Rosas, a series of alternative popular literature published by Anvil Publishing. In 1986, she toured the United States under a grant from the US International Visitors Program for Film. She was a delegate to the Third ASEAN Writers’ Conference held in Singapore, and to Asian Women and Media Conference held in Manila, both in 1987.

Bautista’s 'Gapo (Olangapo), 1988, Dekada’70 (The 1970s), 1984, and Bata, Bata … Pa’no Ka Ginawa? (Child, Child … How Were You Made?), 1983, won the Palanca grand prize for the novel in 1980, 1983, and 1984, respectively. Dekada ’70 exposes the atrocities of the Marcos dictatorship and even mentions the names of the perpetrators of the crimes. It was translated into Japanese by Satoshi Masutoni in 1993. Bata, Bata is considered to be one of the first Filipino novels to explore women’s liberation; it tells of ordinary lives and ordinary dreams, written from a feminist point of view. Her short stories were collected in Buwan, Buwan, Hulugan Mo Ako ng Sundang: Dalawang Dekada ng Maikling Kuwento (Moon, Moon, Drop Me a Dagger: Two Decades of Short Fiction), 1991. She also wrote over a dozen romance novels like Pag-ibig Ko, Karapatan Ko (My Love, My Right), 1985, and Pahingi ng Konting Pagtingin (Give Me Some Attention), 1989, and translated Asian fiction into Filipino: Rashomon at Iba Pang Kuwento (Rashomon and Other Stories), 1989, and Si Taw at Iba Pang Kuwentong Thai (Taw and Other Thai Stories), 1988. In 1986, she was a national fellow for fiction of the University of the Philippines Creative Writing Center. She received a Recognition Award from the Surian ng Wikang Pambansa in 1987. Two of her short stories also won Palanca Awards: “Tatlong Kuwento ng Buhay ni Juan Candelabra” (Three Stories on Life of Juan Candelabra), first prize, 1982; and “Buwan, Buwan, Hulugan Mo Ako ng Sundang,” third prize, 1983. In 1999, she was conferred the Gawad Pambansang Alagad ni Balagtas for fiction in Filipino by the Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas. She was included in a book that features international women writers, such as Isabel Allende, Isaak Dinesen, Alice Walker, and Margaret Atwood, published in Japan, 1991.

Bautista is also known as a screenwriter. Her first screenplay was for the movie Sakada (Seasonal Cane Workers), 1976, co-written with Oscar Miranda, which exposed the plight of Filipino peasants. The military confiscated the film after only a few days of its showing. Her other screenplays are for Kung Mahawi Man ang Ulap (Should the Skies Clear), 1984, and Bulaklak sa City Jail (Flowers of the City Jail), 1984. Bautista adapted Bata, Bata ... (Lea's Story) and Dekada ’70 for film in 1998 and 2002, respectively. Her screenplays for all those movies received awards from local film award-giving bodies. Dekada ’70 was also chosen as the country’s entry in the Best Foreign Language Film category at the 76th Academy Awards. In 1994, she won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences award for Best Screenplay for Kadena ng Bulaklak (Flower Chain). In 1985, PMPC Star Awards cited her work for Sex Object, based on her short story “Iiyak Ka Pa Ba?” (Will You Still Cry?), which delved into the attitudes of a patriarchal society toward a rape victim. First adapted into a teleplay directed by Lino Brocka, Sex Object was banned because it exposed the miscarriage of justice in courts. In 1993, she wrote the screenplay for the Maricris Sioson Story based on the life of a Filipina entertainer allegedly murdered in Japan.

Bautista also wrote stage plays, including the monologue Lorena, 1980s, performed by Joi Barrios and produced by the Women’s Desk of the Cultural Center of the Philippines as a tribute to rebel poet Lorena Barros, and Buhay Namin (Our Life), 2005, a play about women’s reproductive health issues produced by the Linangan ng Kababaihan.

Bautista has also written for television. Her first drama script for television, Daga sa Timba ng Tubig (Rat in a Bucket of Water), 1970s, directed by Lino Brocka, was banned by the Board of Censors because of its theme about the miscarriage of justice. Her teleplay for “Isang Kabanata sa Buhay ni Leilani Cruzaldo” (A Chapter in Leilani Cruzaldo’s Life) was the pilot episode of the drama anthology Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), revived in 1987, and won for the series the Best Drama Anthology award at the Catholic Mass Media Awards that same year. Other drama scripts she wrote include Desaparesido, GMA Network, 1998, about missing persons. She has also written for the drama series Dear Teacher, 1991, and Mama, 1992. In 1994, she won the first Bahaghari Award for television for her teleplay on domestic violence. In the same year, she wrote the script of Taghoy sa Dilim (Cryin the Dark), which won Best Teleplay in the 1st GMA Rainbow Awards.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis and Elmer L. Gatchalian, updated by Rolando O. Santos and Om Narayan Velasco

Perla Bautista (Perla Marcial Bautista) is a film and television actor. She was born in Manila on 18 Feb 1940. She is the fifth of eight children of Carmen Marcial and Vicente Bautista. She finished secondary education at Torres High School and enrolled in commerce at the Lyceum of the Philippines until the second year. She has one son, Jude Bautista.

At 17, Bautista took on bit roles until she was introduced in Eddie Junior Detective, 1958. This was followed by Malvarosa, Anak ni Waray (Waray’s Child), Ana Maria, Hiwaga ng Pag-ibig (Mystery of Love), and Venganza (Revenge), 1958; Barrio Fiesta and Mr. Announcer, 1959; Black Beauty and Kung Ako’y Iiwan Mo (Should You Abandon Me), 1960. She earned a starring role in Kilabot sa Barilan (Gunfight Terror), 1961. Her other films include Crush Ko si Sir (I Have a Crush on Sir), 1971; Tatlo, Dalawa, Isa (Three, Two, One), 1974; Sa Kagubatan ng Lunsod (In the Jungle of the City), 1975; Minsa'y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth), 1976;Bawal na Pag-ibig (Forbidden Love), 1977; Laruan (Toy), 1983; Bulaklak sa City Jail (Flowers of the City Jail), 1984; Cop Brutus Logan: The Crime Buster and Bilang Na ang Oras Mo (Your Time Is Running Out), 1985; Sa Bawat Hakbang, Babaha ng Dugo (Every Step, Blood Will Shed) and The Jun Labo Story, 1986; Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig? (Where Does Love Hide?), 1987; Alega Gang: Public Enemy No. 1 of Cebu and Sa Akin Pa Rin ang Bukas (Tomorrow Still Belongs to Me), 1988; Bilangin ang Bituin sa Langit (Count the Stars in the Sky), 1989; Dyesebel and Walang Piring ang Katarungan (Justice Isn’t Blind), 1990; Sagad Hanggang Buto (Cut to the Bone), 1991; Ako ang Katarungan: Lt. Napoleon M. Guevarra (I Am Justice: Lt Napoleon M. Guevarra) and Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1992, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines; The Fatima Buen Story and Relax Ka Lang, Sagot Kita (Relax, I Got You), 1994; The Lilian Velez Story: Till Death Do Us Part, 1995; Flames: The Movie, 1997; ’Di Ko Kayang Tanggapin (I Can’t Take It), 2000; Jologs, 2002; Txt, 2006; Ouija, 2007; Ded Na si Lolo (Grandpa Is Dead), 2009, the country’s official entry in the foreign language category of the 82nd Academy Awards; Fausta, 2009; Shake, Rattle & Roll 13 and Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story, 2011; Ang Maestra (The Teacher), 2013; and Bigkis (Intertwined), 2014.

Bautista appeared in several local telenovelas, such as ABS-CBN’s Pangako Sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000-2002, Maria la del Barrio (Maria of the Barrio), 2011-12, and Apoy sa Dagat (Fire at Sea), 2013; GMA Network’s Walang Hanggan (Forever), 2003-4, Darna , 2009-10, and Amaya, 2011-12; and TV5’s “Putik” (Mud) from 5 Star Specials, 2010, and Rod Santiago’s The Sisters, 2011. She also starred in several episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 1998-2014, Wansapanataym (Once upon a Time), 2011-15, and Magpakailanman (Forever), 2013-15.
