She won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Actress award for Markang Rehas (Mark of the Prison Bars), 1962, opposite Joseph Estrada, who also won the Best Actor award. Her other achievements include three FAMAS Best Supporting Actress awards for Ang Alamat ni Julian Makabayan (The Legend of Julian Makabayan), 1979; Nang Bumuka ang Sampaguita (When the Sampaguita Blossomed), 1980; and Bulaklak sa City Jail, 1984. She was also the Gawad Urian Best Supporting Actress for Anak ng Cabron (Son of a Thief), 1988. In 2000, she received the Ulirang Artista Lifetime Achievement Award from the Philippine Movie Press Club.  Written by Galileo Zafra, updated by Erika Carreon

Angeli Bayani (Angeli Ablog Bayani) is a theater, film, and television actor. She was born in 13 Nov 1977. Her father, Nilo Bayani, was an actor in Rolando Tinio’s theater group Teatro Pilipino in the 1970s; her mother, Fresnaida Diego Ablog, was a preschool teacher. She has one child, Rowan Marek.

Bayani started her career as a theater actor at Dulaang UP at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, where she was initially a biology major, until she shifted to music, then finally to theater arts. She was with Tanghalang Pilipino, the resident theater group of the Cultural Center of the Philippines, from 2002 to 2006. She had also been part of the productions of UP Repertory Company, Gantimpala Theater Foundation, and the Philippine Educational Theater Association. She eventually ventured into acting for TV and cinema.

Her first role in cinema was as a guest relations officer in Ang Huling Birhen sa Lupa (The Last Virgin), 2003. She appeared in Lav Diaz’s Kagadanan sa Banwaan ning mga Engkanto (Death in the Land of Encantos), 2007, and Melancholia, 2008. Her other notable films include Raya Martin’s Independencia (Independence), Adolfo Alix Jr’s Chassis and Adela, and GB Sampedro’s Astig (Squalor), 2009. She was also in Eduardo Roy Jr’s Bahay Bata (Baby Factory) and Sari Dalena’s Ka Oryang (Comrade Oryang), 2011; Adolfo Alix Jr’s Kalayaan (Wildlife), Ron Morales’s Graceland, and Jacco Groen’s Lilet Never Happened, 2012; Carlo Obispo’s Purok 7 (Seventh District), Mel Chionglo’s Lauriana, and Sari and Kiri Dalena’s The Guerilla Is a Poet, 2013. She played a pivotal role in Diaz’s Norte, Hangganan ng Kasaysayan (Norte, The End of History) and as the Filipino nanny in Singaporean Anthony Chen’s Ilo-Ilo, 2013, which won the Camera d’Or (Golden Camera or Best First Feature Film) at the 66th Cannes Film Festival. She also played a major role in Francis Xavier Pasion’s Bwaya (Crocodile), 2014.

Bayani’s television work includes the French TV movie Esclaves des Mers (Slaves of the Sea), 2009; the TV series Nagsimula sa Puso (It Began from the Heart), 2009, Beautiful Girl, 2010, Angelito: Batang Ama (Angelito: Young Father), 2011, Never Say Goodbye, 2013, and Wansapanataym (Once upon a Time), 2014; and episodes of the drama anthologies Wagas (Sincere), 2014, and Magpakailanman (Forever), 2015. She also played a part in the TV miniseries Bayan Ko (My Nation), 2013, and Wattpad Presents, 2014.

Bayani won the Vic Silayan Award for Best Actress, international category, at the 2008 Cinemanila International Film Festival for her performance in Melancholia, and Best Actress for her performance in Norte at the Gawad Urian in 2014.  Written by Susan Claire Agbayani

Rolf Bayer was a screenwriter and film director. He was born in 1926. Bayer wrote for director Lamberto V. Avellana and collaborated in the making of local movie classics like Scout Rangers, 1964; Destination Vietnam, 1968; and Cry Freedom, 1959. In 1956, Bayer co-directed with Ho Chapman Treasure of General Yamashita for Manuel Vistan-Ho Chapman Productions. He directed Kahariang Bato (Stone Kingdom), 1957, the first trilingual film (English, Tagalog, and Chinese) in the local cinema; Tatak ni Solomon (Mark of Solomon), 1958; Flight of the Sparrow, 1960, together with Ronald Remy and Conrad Parham; Tagani, 1965; and The Kill, 1975.

He wrote the screenplay of Huk sa Bagong Pamumuhay (Huk in a New Life), 1953, the LVN film directed by Lamberto V. Avellana which copped the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Picture award; Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956, which garnered the Asian Film Festival Best Picture award; and Badjao, 1957, which also won the Asian Film Festival award for Best Screenplay. Another work, Scout Rangers, won the FAMAS for Best Screenplay in 1965.  Written by Rosalie Matilac, updated by Pamela Mathiel Lopez

Bentot (Arturo Vergara Medina), also known as Ben Cosca, was a film, stage, and television actor. He was born in Tondo, Manila on 13 Jul 1920. He died in Manila on 19 Jun 1986. He was the son of Claro Medina, a laborer, and Leoncia Vergara. He stopped schooling after his studies at La Loma Elementary School. He married Rosario Garcia, with whom he had four children, one of whom, Bentot Jr, also joined the movies as a child actor.

As a comedian, Bentot became popular for his portrayal of the overgrown child forever, getting his father, played by the famous comedian Pugo, and other adults into trouble, in the famous radio program Sebya, Mahal Kita (Sebya, I Love You), which was made into a movie in 1957 starring the love team Nida Blanca and Nestor de Villa. Pugo and Bentot were later reunited with their original radio co-stars—singer-comedian Sylvia La Torre, Eddie San Jose, and Rosa Aguirre—in films like My Little Kuwan (My Little Something), 1958; Puro Utos, Puro Utos (All I Get Are Orders), 1959; Yantok Mindoro (Mindoro Rattan), 1960; Nukso nang Nukso (You Keep Teasing Me), 1960; and O Sendang, 1961. With the emergence of television, it was inevitable that the same characters would appear in the top-rating television comedy show Tangtarangtang (Daddy-O), later made into a movie in 1963. Bentot also appeared in Triplets, 1960, with him playing the three roles.

Bentot was nominated in the Citizens’ Award for Television (CAT) in 1963 for Tangtarangtang.  Written by Rosalinda Galang

Ishmael Bernal, also known as Ishma, was a film director, screenwriter, and theater actor. He is a National Artist for film. He was born in Manila on 30 Sep 1938. He died in Quezon City on 2 Jun 1996. He is the son of Elena Bernal and Pacifico Ledesma. He studied at Burgos Elementary School, Mapa High School, and the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. In college, he was active in the UP Dramatic Club. After graduating from UP with a bachelor of arts degree in literature, he proceeded to France where he obtained a licentiate in French literature and philosophy from the University of Aix-en-Provence. He also studied film directing as a Colombo Plan scholar at the Film Institute of India in Poona. He was a board member of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines and an active participant in the struggle for artists’ rights and welfare.

His first directorial and screenwriting job, Pagdating sa Dulo (At the Top), 1971, established Bernal as an intelligent and innovative filmmaker who would not be content with the conventional formulas of local filmmaking. He had a broad range of films covering different genres and themes, like Daluyong (Tidal Wave), 1971; Inspiration, Till Death Do Us Part, and El Vibora (The Viper), 1972; Sleeping Dragon and Pito ang Asawa Ko (I Have Seven Wives), 1974; Lumapit … Lumayo ang Umaga (Morning Comes and Goes), 1975; Nunal sa Tubig (Speck in the Water), the Bonifacio episode in the unreleased Lahing Pilipino (The Filipino Race), Ligaw na Bulaklak (Wildflower), and Babaing Hiwalay sa Asawa (Estranged Wife), 1976; Tisoy (Mestizo), 1977; Lagi na Lamang Ba Akong Babae? (Must I Always Be Woman?), Isang Gabi sa Iyo, Isang Gabi sa Akin (One Night with You, One Night with Me), Menor de Edad (Underage), Mister Mo, Lover Boy Ko (Your Husband, My Lover), and Ikaw Ay Akin (You Are Mine), 1978; Aliw (Pleasure), 1979; Bilibid Boys and Pabling, 1981; Himala (Miracle) and Relasyon (An Affair), 1982; Broken Marriage, 1983; Working Girls, 1984; Hinugot sa Langit (Wrenched from Heaven), 1985; The Graduates, 1986; Working Girls II, 1987; Nagbabagang Luha (Smoldering Tears), 1988; Pahiram ng Isang Umaga (Lend Me One Morning), 1989; Mahal Kita Walang Iba (I Love You There Is No One Else), 1992; and Wating (Street-smart), 1994. In his more than 50 movies, Bernal explored new styles and approaches as well as new themes in filmmaking, both enriching and deepening the stereotype characters and plots of commercial formulas.

Bernal also directed television shows, like Metro Magazine, Isip Pinoy, and Dear Teacher as well as episodes for PETABISYON, Ang Makulay ang Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora), Lorna, and other TV shows. He played lead roles for stage plays like Kamatayan sa Anyo ng Isang Rosas (Death in the Form of a Rose), 1991, and Bacchae, 1992. He also handled theater workshops and directed plays for SINING, a federation of community-based youth theater groups. He worked with theater artists from different regions in the country through BUGKOS, the national coordinating center for people’s art and literature.

In the Gawad Urian, he won Best Director four times—for Dalawang Pugad, Isang Ibon (Two Nests, One Bird), 1977; Broken Marriage, 1983; Hinugot sa Langit; and Pahiram ng Isang Umaga—and Best Screenplay for City after Dark, 1980. His film Pagdating Sa Dulo won for him theBest Screenplay award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences. His Nunal sa Tubig was named Best Picture in the 1977 Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA). Himala garnered nine major awards in the Metro Manila Film Festival, including Best Picture, Best Director, Best Story, and Best Actress. It was personally selected as the Philippine competition entry by the director of the 1983 Berlin International Film Festival. It won the Bronze Hugo award in the 1983 Chicago International Film Festival. More than two decades later, Himala won the 2008 CNN Asia Pacific Screen Awards Viewers’ Choice Award for the Best Asia-Pacific Film of All Time. Bernal also won Movie Director of the Year in the Star Awards for Pahiram ng Isang Umaga. Bernal was named Director of the Decade 1970s by the CMMA. The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino voted five of his films—namely, Pagdating sa Dulo, Nunal sa Tubig, Manila by Night, Himala, and Hinugot sa Langit—as among the 10 best films of the 1970s and 1980s. In February 1990, Bernal received the Gawad CCP sa Sining in film for “rising above the commercial orientation of local filmmakers and creating a body of well-crafted films—some of which have been hailed as cinematic masterpieces of our time—and for exploring new directions in the form and content of Philippine cinema.” In 1993, he received the ASEAN Cultural Award in communication arts. Bernal was posthumously conferred the title National Artist for film in 2001.   Written by Mario Hernando, Nicanor G. Tiongson, and Carolina Malay, updated by Ronald Baytan

Bernardo Bernardo (Bernardo Coniconde Bernardo) was a theater, television, and film actor, theater director, and educator. He was born in Santa Ana, Manila on 28 Jan 1945. He died in Manila on 8 Mar 2018. He was the son of Meliton Bernardo and Leoncia Coniconde. He attended the Epifanio de los Santos Elementary School and the Manila High School. He finished bachelor of literature in journalism at the University of Santo Tomas (UST), 1967; master of arts in theater at the University of California, Santa Barbara, USA, 1970; and another master of arts in education, curriculum and instruction, at the University of Phoenix, Arizona, USA, 2009.

He received theater training in acting from the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco, 1969; Inner City Cultural Center Institute in Los Angeles, 1970-71; Pacific Conservatory Theater in California, 1971; and the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art, under a British Council grant, 1976-77. He attended several acting workshops in the Philippines. He took special training in jazz, tap, modern, afro, and folk dancing as well as voice/musical training from Aurelio Estanislao and Dalisay Aldaba. He also went through production training for television under the Children’s Television Workshop and Sesame Street in New York for the Philippine Sesame Street Project. He is a member of the Actors Workshop Foundation, Kapisanan ng mga Artista ng Pelikulang Pilipino, and Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit, and served as chair in charge of pop music of the Presidential Commission on Culture and Arts in 1989.

In the United States, he taught at the Department of Philippine Studies, University of San Francisco, San Francisco, 2007; Foreign Service Institute, School of Language Studies, US Department of State, Arlington, Virginia, 2008; Department of Comparative Literature and Foreign Languages, University of California, Riverside, California, 2010-11. He taught at the college level in a multicultural environment using creative drama techniques in language learning. His extensive experience includes teaching acting, acting for singers, musical theater, voice production, movement, improvisation, and scene study; planning and implementing study programs; and assessing creative accomplishments of students. In 2014, he became the artistic director of Studio Connections International and artistic director of musical theater of the Julie Borromeo Performing Arts Foundation (JBPAF).

A multitalented and versatile actor, Bernardo has played major roles on stage. He has been involved in productions with the UST-based Aquinas Dramatic Guild, 1964-65; the University of California theater group, 1967-68; Youth Theater of Santa Barbara, 1969; and Hollywood Center’s Sayar’s Players, 1970.

In the 1970s and 1980s, he was known for his performance in the University of the Philippines Anak Tibawan’s Alipato (Spark), as Bino, 1976; the Cultural Center of the Philippines’s Tatarin (an adaptation of Nick Joaquin’s short story, “Summer Solstice”), 1978; and Dulaang Babaylan’s Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow), at about the same time; as well as in dinner shows like The Boys in the Band as Bernie, 1977, and Rocky Horror Show as Frank N. Furter, 1983. He later performed in Philippine Educational Theater Association's Haring Lear (King Lear), 2012, at the Taipei National University of the Arts’s Kuandu Arts Festival, Taiwan, 2014; Virgin Labfest’s Imbisibol (Invisible), 2014; and JBPAF’s The Wiz of Oz, 2014. He also acted in the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival entry Ronda (Rounds), 2014; Quento Media/Deus Lux Mea’s Whistleblower, 2014; and Sinag Maynila Film Festival’s Imbisibol, 2015, the film adaptation of the stage play with the same title. On television, he is best remembered as Steve Carpio, the flamboyant nemesis of Dolphy in the popular ABS-CBN sitcom, Home Along da Riles (Home Along the Railroad), 1992-2003.

His numerous awards include the Gawad Urian Best Actor for his performance as Manay in Manila by Night, 1980; Best Male Performer in Hotel and Nightclubs, 1986; Outstanding Alumnus in Theater, Centennial Celebration of Philets-AB, 1996; and the Most Outstanding Alumnus for Theater by the Faculty of Arts and Letters Centennial Celebration by the UST, 2012. While in the United States, he was conferred the Via Times Hall of Fame Award for Entertainment, Chicago, 2004; Gawad Parangal Stand Up Comedian of the Year, Chicago, 2005; Filipinas Magazine Achievement Award for Entertainment in San Francisco, 2005; Thomasians USA Nobility Award for Drama and Entertainment in San Francisco, 2006; Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle Award for Best Director for the The Romance of Magno Rubio / Ang Romansa ni Magno Rubio in Los Angeles, 2012; Heritage Award in Entertainment in Los Angeles, 2012; and Image Award for Lifetime Achievement in Theater, Los Angeles, 2013. For his role in Imbisibol, he received a Best Supporting Actor nomination from the Film Academy of the Philippines and won the Best Supporting Actor award from the Gawad Urian in 2016. He was last seen in the films Ang Larawan (The Portrait), 2017, and The Significant Other, 2018.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis, updated by Ruby Gamboa-Alcantara

Naty Bernardo (Natividad Bernardo) was a film actor. She was born in Manila on 25 Apr 1911. She died in Pasig on 4 Jan 1987. Her granddaughter is singer Joanne Lorenzana. At 14, Bernardo started her career as a substitute singer of the Sarswela Gabriel in Manila. Over the years, she became a soloist at the Lotus Theater. She appeared in bit parts for Malayan Movies and Filippine Films until she played second lead to Carlos Padilla and Ana del Rosario in Sa Tawag ng Diyos (At God’s Call), 1934. She also appearedin Mayroon Nga Bang Dios? (Is There Really a God?), 1939, with Leopoldo Salcedo. She was given the lead role in Ina (Mother), 1935, with Gregorio Ticman, child actor Berting Labra, and Perla Garcia.

Bernardo portrayed martyr roles in her earlier films and later shifted to character roles, for which she was better remembered by the public. Her other prewar films include Ang Birheng Walang Dambana (The Virgin without a Shrine), 1937, Siya’y Aking Anak (That Child Is Mine), 1939, and Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), 1939, with Rosario Moreno.

She performed in stage shows during the Japanese Occupation. After World War II, she appeared in more than 40 films of LVN Pictures, like Tagumpay (Victory), Garrison 13, Angelus, and Aladin, all in 1946; Manugang at Biyenan (The In-Laws) and Puting Bantayog (White Monument), 1948; El Diablo (The Devil), 1949; Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), 1950, and its sequel Prinsipe Amante sa Rubitanya (Prince Amante in Rubitanya), 1951, both directed by Lamberto V. Avellana; Gregorio Fernandez’s Rodrigo de Villa and Bohemyo (Playboy), 1952; and the Nida Blanca–Nestor de Villa starrers, like Hijo de Familia (Family Heir), 1953, Waray-Waray (Visayan Lass), 1954, Ikaw Kasi (You Are to Blame), 1955, Tingnan Natin (Let’s See), 1957, and Everybody, Dance, 1964; Higit sa Korona (Above the Crown), 1956; and Lelong Mong Panot (Your Bald Grandpa), 1957, with Pugo, Manding Claro, and Nenita Vidal.  Written by Cesar Hernando and Danny Villanueva

Nida Blanca (Dorothy Acueza Jones) was a dancer and a film and television actor. She was born in Gapan, Nueva Ecija on 6 Jan 1936. She died in San Juan City on 7 Nov 2001. She was the only child of Inocencia Acueza and American John William Jones II. She finished high school at Adamson University and took up prelaw at the University of Santo Tomas. She had a daughter by estranged husband Victorino Torres; her second husband, Rod Lauren, was a singer.

Blanca was 13 when she joined an amateur singing contest in Manila. Actor Delia Razon brought her to LVN matriarch Doña Sisang, who gave her a chance to appear in Reyna Elena (Queen Helen), 1951. This was followed by Amor Mio (My Love), 1951, where she appeared with Nestor de Villa for the first time. She made more movies, mostly with de Villa as a romantic and dancing partner in such films as Tumbalik na Daigdig (Topsy-Turvy World) and Hijo de Familia (Family Heir), 1953; Waray-Waray (Visayan Lass), 1954; Ikaw Kasi (You Are to Blame) and Darling Ko (My Darling), 1955; Ganyan Ka Pala (So That’s the Way You Are), Handang Matodas (Ready to Die), and Bahala Na (Come What May), 1956; Turista (Tourist) and Tingnan Natin (Let’s See), 1957. The image of a tomboyish but lovable screwball became her signature when she made Galawgaw (Wacky), 1956, with Jaime de la Rosa, who was also leading man to her knife-wielding Batangueña (Batangas Girl) character in the 1953 movie. Early in her career, Blanca proved that she could switch just as easily from comedy to drama in such films as Babaing Hampas-Lupa (Female Tramp), 1952, Rosalina, 1957, and Limang Dalangin (Five Prayers), 1958.

When LVN stopped producing, she freelanced, proving her mettle in a variety of films, such as Shake, Baby, Shake, 1966, Pag-ibig, Masdan ang Ginawa Mo (Love, Look at What You’ve Done), 1969, Forgive and Forget, 1982, My Heart Belongs to Daddy, 1982, and many others.

On television, Blanca’s shows were consistently top-rated. The Nida-Nestor Show showcased her dancing prowess, while John en Marsha (John and Marsha) proved her knack for comedy and firmly established her iconic pairing with Dolphy. John en Marsha also became one of local television's longest-running comedy series. In her sitcom Fifty Carats, O Di Ba? (Fifty Carats, Isn’t It So?), she shared top billing with Gloria Romero and Charito Solis. She was also a mainstay in Mana (Inheritance).

Blanca won the first Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) award for Best Supporting Actress for her role as a Korean woman, Lee Ming, who falls in love with Filipino soldier Boni Serrano in Korea, 1952. The film was based on then Manila Times correspondent Benigno (Ninoy) Aquino Jr’s chronicles about the Philippine Expeditionary Force to Korea in the 1950s. Her other awards include Best Supporting Actress in the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) for Batu-Bato sa Langit (Bird in the Sky), 1975; Best Actress in the Gawad Urian, Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA), and Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) for Miguelito: Batang Rebelde (Miguelito: Young Rebel), 1985; Best Supporting Actress in the FAMAS and FAP for Magdusa Ka (Suffer), 1986; Best Supporting Actress in the FAMAS, FAP, and CMMA for Kid, Huwag Kang Susuko (Kid, Do Not Give Up), 1987; Best Supporting Actress in the FAP and MMFF for Babae (Woman), 1997; Best Actress in the FAMAS for Sana Pag-ibig Na (Enter Love), 1998; and Lifetime Achievement Awards from the Gawad Urian and the FAP in 2000 and 2002, respectively.

For her work on television, Blanca won two awards from the Citizens’ Awards for Television as Best Female TV Performer for the Nida-Nestor Show, and three awards from the Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining in 1975, 1976, and 1978 as Most Outstanding Actress in a Comedy Series for John en Marsha.

In 2001, Blanca was found dead in her car. The case remained unsolved as of 2018.  Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

Norma Blancaflor (Lydia Jurado Velasco) was a film actor. She was born in Tondo, Manila on 27 Oct 1919. She died in Manila on 12 Oct 2004. The eldest of nine children of Gregorio Velasco and Maria Jurado, she married John Robert Price, an American. She finished high school at Mapua Institute of Technology, and obtained a pharmacy degree from Manila College of Pharmacy and Dentistry. After the war, in a test conducted by Ansco Technicians for LVN Pictures, Blancaflor, who was known for having “one of the most beautiful faces in local filmdom,” got a perfect score for complexion compatibility in color films.

It was actor Lilia Vizconde who brought her to Filippine Films studio where she was discovered by Luis F. Nolasco. Director Carlos Vander Tolosa was so impressed by her beauty that he wrote the script of Dalaga, Isang Ngiti Mo Lamang (Lady, Just One Smile from You), 1940, expressly for her. Blancaflor played second lead in Sa Dating Pugad (In the Old Nest), 1940. Her first lead role came in Hatinggabi (Midnight), 1940. Her other prewar movies include Bawal na Pag-ibig (Forbidden Love), 1940, where she played the daughter of Angel Esmeralda and Maria Clara Ruiz; Binibini ng Palengke (Muse of the Market), 1941; and Binibiro Lamang Kita (I Was Only Joking), 1941.

During the Japanese Occupation, she appeared in stage shows at Life, Lyric, and Avenue theaters with Rogelio de la Rosa. After the war, she signed an exclusive contract with LVN, and played leading lady roles in such films as Aladin, Honeymoon, Victory Joe, and The Voice of Freedom , 1946; Bagong Manunubos (New Messiah) and Miss Philippines, 1947; Huling Dalangin (Last Prayer), P1,000 Kagandahan (1,000-Peso-Beauty), Manugang at Biyenan (The In-Laws), Sumpaan (Pledge), and Puting Bantayog (White Monument), 1948; and Parola (Lighthouse), 1949. Blancaflor’s later films include When Good Girls Go Wrong and Plaza Miranda, 1971, The Sisters, 1972, Sinasamba Kita (I Worship You), 1982, and Ayaw Kong Maging Querida (I Don’t Want to Be a Mistress), 1983.

Blancaflor was declared Best Actress of 1940 at the awards rites sponsored by the Bureau of Commerce, which was held at the Metropolitan Theater. She won it alongside Ely Ramos, Best Actor, for Dalaga, which was also declared Best Picture. She was a recipient of the Walang Kupas award in 1982.  Written by Danny Villanueva and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Erika Carreon

Dina Bonnevie (Geraldine Schaer Bonnevie) is a film and television actor. She was born in Quezon City on 27 Jan 1961. Her parents are Honesto Bonnevie and Jeannette Schaer. Her grandmother is pre-World War II actor Rosita Rivera. She has two children by actor Vic Sotto: Vittorio Mari (Oyo) and Danica Sotto, who are both movie and television actors. She is currently married to Deogracias Victor Savellano, vice-governor of Ilocos Sur. She began her schooling at St. Theresa’s College, Manila, but finished her elementary and secondary education at St. Agnes Academy in Legaspi City, where she was active in drama guilds. In 1980, she enrolled in communication arts at Ateneo de Manila University and, later, at the University of the Philippines Diliman.

Introduced by actor Alfie Anido to director Joey Gosiengfiao, she first appeared in Temptation Island, 1980, but her launching movie is Katorse (Fourteen), 1980, which established her as one of the “Regal Babies.” She then appeared in a number of films catering to the teenage audience, like Underage, 1980, and Bakit Ba Ganyan? (Why Is It So?), 1981, in which she herself sang the theme song. In 1985 she started doing dramatic roles in films like Hindi Nahahati ang Langit (An Indivisible Heaven) and Tinik sa Dibdib (Thorn in the Heart). Her other notable films are Palimos ng Pag-ibig (Begging for Love) and Magdusa Ka (Suffer), 1986; A Dangerous Life, 1988; Orapronobis (Fight for Us), 1989; Pangarap na Ginto (Golden Dreams) and Gumapang Ka sa Lusak (Dirty Affair), 1990; Huwag Mong Salingin ang Sugat Ko (Touch Not My Wound) and Sa Kabila ng Lahat (Despite Everything), 1991; Akin ang Pangarap Mo (Your Dream Is Mine), 1992; and Eskapo (Fugitive), 1995. Bonnevie played important roles in Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000; Tatarin (St John’s Day Ritual), 2001, a movie adaptation of Nick Joaquin’s play Tatarin: A Witch’s Sabbath in Three Acts; American Adobo, 2002; Bridal Shower, 2004; and When the Love is Gone, 2013.

Her work in television includes ABS-CBN’s Hiram (Stolen Moments), 2004-05, May Bukas Pa (There's Still Tomorrow), 2009-10, and Two Wives, 2015; GMA Network’s Ikaw Lang ang Mamahalin (I’ll Always Love You), 2001, Babangon Ako’t Dudurugin Kita (Sweet Revenge), 2008, and Beautiful Strangers, 2015; and TV5’s My Driver Sweet Lover, 2010-11, and P.S. I Love You, 2011-12. She also appeared in several episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) from 1993 to 2015.

Her performance was noticed in the film Tinik sa Dibdib, for which she received Best Supporting Actress awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) and the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) in 1986. She was awarded Best Actress by the FAMAS, FAP, and the Catholic Mass Media Awards for her performance in Magdusa Ka in 1987.  Written by Galileo Zafra, updated by Erika Carreon

Emmanuel H. Borlaza (Emmanuel Hombrebueno Borlaza), also known as Maning Borlaza or Manolo Hombrebueno, was a film director and screenwriter. He was born in Liliw, Laguna on 5 Nov 1939. He died in Manila on 12 Oct 2017. He was the son of Severina Hombrebueno, a schoolteacher, and Gregorio Borlaza, former president of the Philippine Normal College (PNC, now University). He studied at Manuel Luis Quezon University and PNC. He obtained a bachelor of arts degree in English, cum laude, from Northwestern Educational Institution, Dagupan City, in 1956. He was first appointed a board member of the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board during the chairmanship of Armida Siguion-Reyna in 1998 and became vice-chair in 2010 under Chair Grace Poe-Llamanzares and continued as such under Chair Eugenio Villareal Jr.

Borlaza was a stage actor with Severino Montano’s Arena Theater in the 1950s. He applied as a scriptwriter at Sampaguita Pictures after graduation and also worked as a movie extra. His first screenplay was Mga Ligaw na Bulaklak (Wildflowers), 1957. Borlaza wrote over 200 stories and screenplays. Among his screenplays are Tatlong Magdalena (Three Magdalenes), 1960; Dalawang Kalbaryo ni Dr. Mendez (The Two Calvaries of Dr Mendez) and Halik sa Lupa (Kiss the Earth), 1961; Kapatid Ko ang Aking Ina (My Mother Is My Sister), 1968; and Paano Tatakasan ang Bukas? (How Does One Escape from Tomorrow?), 1988. His later screenplays include Kapag Langit ang Humatol (Heaven’s Judgment), 1990, Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), 1991, Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang ? (Why Only Now?), 1994, Dyesebel, 1996, and Tinik (Thorn), 2013.

Borlaza directed more than 100 films. Among these are Dyesebel , Lipad, Darna, Lipad (Fly, Darna, Fly), and Darna and the Giants , 1973; Bakit Kailangan Kita? (Why Do I Need You?) and the Jay Ilagan-starrer Hatulan si Dodong Diamond (Sentence Dodong Diamond), 1978; Shake, Rattle & Roll, 1984; Yesterday, Today & Tomorrow, 1986; Blusang Itim (Black Blouse),1986; Rosa Mistica and The Sisters, 1987; Bihagin ang Dalagang Ito (Capture This Maiden), 1989; and To Saudi with Love, 1997; and Mapagbigay (Generous), 2000. He directed many of Sharon Cuneta's box-office hits including Dapat Ka Bang Mahalin? (Should You Be Loved?) and Bukas Luluhod ang mga Tala (Tomorrow the Stars Will Kneel), 1984, and Bituing Walang Ningning (Star Without Sparkle), 1985. He also directed episodes of ABS-CBN’s Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) in 1991-92.

Borlaza received Best Screenplay awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Psycho Maniac in 1969 and Pinagbuklod ng Langit (Joined by Heaven) in 1970. At the Film Academy of the Philippines Awards, he won Best Director for Paano Tatakasan ang Bukas? in 1989 and Best Adapted Screenplay for Kapag Langit ang Humatol in 1991, which he shared with Armando Royales. He also received the runner-up award for directing from the Catholic Mass Media Awards for Oras-Oras, Araw-Araw (Every Hour, Every Day) in 1990. From the Young Critics Circle Film Desk, he received the Best Screenplay award for Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang? in 1995, which he shared with Jose Y. Dalisay Jr.  Written by Rosalie Matilac and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

Lee Briones (Videlle Briones), also known as Lee Meily or Lee Briones-Meily, is a cinematographer. She was born in Manila on 27 Sep 1962. Her parents are Abner and Yolanda Briones. She married film director Mark Meily. Son Kiko is a director; brother-in-law Ruel Yan is a postproduction producer; and aunt Florence Edwards is a producer. She finished high school at Santa Isabel College and earned her bachelor’s degree in communication arts at De La Salle University. She lectures at the Mowelfund Film Institute and at the Asia Pacific Film Institute. She also established her own production company, Simple Truth, which is engaged in noncommercial projects.

Briones started her career as a photographer and became a TV commercial producer for Image Films and Unitel Productions and a full-fledged cinematographer in 1996. She did the photography for Jeffrey Jeturian’s first film Sana Pag-ibig Na (Enter Love), 1998. Since then she worked as director of photography for films of Mark Meily, Laurice Guillen, Chito Roño, John Sayles, and independent filmmakers like Kidlat Tahimik, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, and Ida Anita del Mundo.

Briones received the Best Cinematography award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000, from the Gawad Urian for Crying Ladies, 2003, and the PMPC Star Awards and Golden Screen Awards for Santa Santita (Magdalena), 2004. She won the Best Cinematography award from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF), the PMPC Star Awards, and the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) for the film Baler, 2008. She also did the cinematography for I Love You, Goodbye, 2009, which earned her another Best Cinematography award in the 35th MMFF. She also directed the cinematography of Sa ’Yo Lamang (Only Yours), 2010, which was produced and released by Star Cinema in celebration of the movie company’s 17th anniversary. In 2011, she did the photography for Emir, which won for her the FAP award for Best Cinematography. She also did the cinematography for award-winning films like Amigo (Friend), 2010, American Adobo, 2005, and La Visa Loca (Crazy Visa), 2005.

An avid supporter of independent filmmaking, she did the photography for indie films, including Paglipad ng Anghel (Flight of an Angel), 2011; K’na the Dreamweaver, Mana (Inheritance), and Kamkam (Greed), 2014; Balikbayan #1 Memories of Overdevelopment Redux III, 2015; and Ignacio de Loyola (Ignatius of Loyola), 2016.  Written by Christian Co, with notes from Mario Mendez Jr

Lino Brocka (Catalino Ortiz Brocka) was a theater, film, and television director, theater actor, screenwriter, and producer. He is a National Artist for film. He was born in Pilar, Sorsogon on 7 Apr 1939. He died in Quezon City on 22 May 1991. He was the son of Regino Brocka of Sorsogon and Pilar Ortiz of San Jose, Nueva Ecija. When his father died, Brocka’s family moved to his mother’s birthplace. He studied at Nueva Ecija North High School. He would hold poetry sessions in the evening with the dining table as his stage. He was the best student orator in the province. He organized and headed a community theater group, which gave performances and workshops in the barrios. During his college days at the University of the Philippines (UP) in Diliman, while pursuing a bachelor of arts degree in English literature, he was active with the UP Dramatic Club. He could not get any roles because of his provincial accent and lack of height, so he volunteered to do stage management and lighting design to stay in theater. After UP, he became a Mormon missionary for two years and spent some time in Molokai, the Hawaii leper colony.

Upon his return to the Philippines, he joined the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA). He played minor roles in PETA plays and did odd jobs, writing press releases, working as a stage hand, assistant director, and later as director. He directed such plays as Tatlo (Three), 1973; Mga Ama, Mga Anak (Fathers and Sons), 1977; Larawan (A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino), 1969 and 1979; and Pusa sa Yerong Bubong (Cat on a Hot Tin Roof), 1980. He also appeared as lead actor in Orlando Nadres’s play Hanggang Dito na Lamang at Maraming Salamat (This Is as Far as We Go, and Many Thanks), 1975. He became executive director of PETA in 1974.

In television, he scripted and directed episodes of Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) starring veteran actors. His other TV shows include Lino Brocka Presents, Hilda, Tanghalan (Stage), and Biktima ng Ligaw na Sandali (Victim of the Wild Moment). He also directed episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember).

The first movie he directed was Wanted: Perfect Mother, Lea Productions’s entry in the 1970 Manila Film Festival. The film was both an artistic and commercial success. It was followed immediately by Santiago, 1970, which gave Hilda Koronel her first acting award, and Tubog sa Ginto (Dipped in Gold), 1970, where Eddie Garcia veered from macho villain roles to portray a homosexual. For the next two years, Brocka directed other films for Lea: in 1971, Stardoom, Lumuha Pati mga Anghel (Even the Angels Wept), Cadena de Amor (Chain of Love), and Now; and in 1972, Villa Miranda and Cherry Blossoms.

In 1974 he put up his own movie company, CineManila Corporation, with some of his friends as stockholders and financiers. He produced and directed the critically acclaimed Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (You Were Weighed and Found Wanting), 1974, and Tatlo, Dalawa, Isa (Three, Two, One), 1974. Producing did not turn out to be so viable, so he continued directing films for other movie companies, among them Inay (Mother), 1977; Hayop sa Hayop (Beast to Beast), Init (Heat), Rubia Servios, and Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Mother, Sister, Daughter), 1979; Nakaw na Pag-ibig (Stolen Love), 1980; Kontrobersyal (Controversial), Hello, Young Lovers, and Caught in the Act, 1981; PX, In This Corner, Mother Dear, and Cain at Abel (Cain and Abel), 1982.

In 1978 he was invited to present his film Insiang, 1976, in the Directors’ Fortnight at Cannes Film Festival in France. This was followed by Jaguar (Guard), 1979, selected for the main competition of Cannes Film Festival in 1980, and by Bona, 1980, which was exhibited at the Directors’ Fortnight in 1981. Angela Markado (Angela the Marked One) won Best Picture at the 1983 Nantes Festival of Three Continents. In 1984, Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim (My Country: Gripping the Knife’s Edge) competed at Cannes Film Festival, and it was hailed as the Best Film of the Year by the British Film Institute. Another Brocka film of international repute is Orapronobis (Fight for Us), 1989, a searing indictment of military and vigilante abuses in post-EDSA Philippines. He was jury member at the 1985 New Delhi Film Festival and at the 1986 Cannes Film Festival. Brocka was chosen one of the 10 best filmmakers of the 1980s at the 1986 Toronto Film Festival.

His fight against censorship and all forms of repression took him to the streets and made him adopt a more active stance in the Free the Artist Movement, which later became the Concerned Artists of the Philippines. He was a fearless and outspoken critic of the Marcos administration. In 1985 he was arrested with director Behn Cervantes for participating in a jeepney strike. Although he was appointed by President Corazon Aquino as a member of the 1986 Constitutional Convention, he walked out in protest of the convention’s decision on the land reform issue.

Brocka was elevated to the Hall of Fame of the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 1992 after Gumapang Ka sa Lusak (Dirty Affair) gave him his fifth FAMAS Best Director award in 1991. He won four other FAMAS trophies for Tubog sa Ginto, Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang, Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), and Jaguar. At the 1980 Gawad Urian, he won Best Director for Jaguar. He received two trophies as Best Director from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP): for Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim and Gumapang Ka sa Lusak. The Catholic Mass Media Awards chose him Best Director for Miguelito: Batang Rebelde (Miguelito: Young Rebel), 1985. He won Movie Director of the Year in the 1991 PMPC Star Awards for Gumapang Ka sa Lusak. Brocka also won two Best Director awards at the Metro Manila Film Festival for Ina Ka ng Anak Mo (You Are the Mother of Your Daughter), 1979, and Ano ang Kulay ng Mukha ng Diyos? (What Is the Color of God’s Face?), 1985.

Brocka was in preproduction of Huwag Mong Salingin ang Sugat Ko (Touch Not My Wound), a contemporary adaptation of Jose Rizal's Noli Me Tangere, when he died in a car accident in 1991. The film was later directed by actor Christopher de Leon and released by Viva Films that same year. Before his untimely demise, he also directed three movies: Sa Kabila ng Lahat (Despite Everything), Kislap sa Dilim (Spark in the Dark), and Makiusap Ka sa Diyos (A Plea to God), all released in 1991. Another project, How Are the Kids?, an omnibus film made with French director Jean-Luc Godard, among others, was released in 1992. Brocka received the Ramon Magsaysay Award for Journalism, Literature, and Creative Communication Arts in 1985; the Gawad CCP para sa Sining for film in 1989; the Lamberto Avellana Memorial Award in 1990; and the FAP Lifetime Achievement Award (posthumously in 1992) for his outstanding achievements in Philippine cinema. Brocka was posthumously conferred the title National Artist for film in 1997.  Written by Lena S. Pareja and Herminio S. Beltran Jr

Augusto Buenaventura (Augusto Marcelo Buenaventura), also known as Totoy Buenaventura, was a film director and screenwriter. He was born in Tondo, Manila on 2 Feb 1933. He died on 2 Jun 2006. He was the son of Marcosa Marcelo and Carlos Buenaventura who were both government employees. He studied at Magat Elementary School, finished high school at Torres High School, and took up courses for a bachelor of arts degree at Far Eastern University.

Buenaventura wrote scripts for the films of director Cesar Gallardo, like Kalibre .45 (Caliber .45), 1957; Ang Maton (The Bully), 1959; Bati ngaw (Church Bell), 1960; The Flash Elorde Story and Baby Damulag (Man-Child), 1961; Kapag Buhay ang Inutang (When Life Is Taken), 1962; Dapit-hapon: Oras ng Pagtutuos (Dusk: Hour of Reckoning), 1963; Geron Busabos: Ang Batang Quiapo (Geron the Vagabond), 1964; and Joe Nazareno: Ang Taxi Driver (Joe Nazareno: The Taxi Driver), 1965.

His first directorial job was Valentin Galit (Angry Valentin), 1965. Among his early works are Alex Big Shot, 1967; Cuadro de Jack (Big Four) and Valiente Brothers, 1968; Sebastian, Simon Bastardo (Simon the Bastard), and Areglado, Boss (Okay, Boss), 1970; and Pulot-Gata (Honeymoon), 1971. Other films he directed are Kill the Pushers, 1972; Tanikalang Dugo (Chain of Blood), 1973; Big J, 1975; Alas 5:00 ng Hapon, Gising Na ang mga Anghel (Five in the Afternoon, The Angels Are Awake), 1976; Huwag Mong Dungisan ang Pisngi ng Langit (Do Not Stain Heaven’s Cheek), 1977; Batang City Jail (Young Man from City Jail) and Magkaaway (Enemies), 1978; Hoy, Tukso Layuan Mo Ako! (Hey, Temptation, Stay Away from Me!) and Taga sa Panahon (Ripe with Experience), 1980; Kumander Alibasbas (Commander Alibasbas), 1981; Pedring Taruc, 1982; Macho-nurin (Submissive Macho), 1983; Apoy sa Iyong Kandungan (Fire in Your Cradle), 1984; Order to Kill, 1985; Bagets Gang (Teenage Gang), 1986; Cabarlo and Barbaro Santo (Brutal Saint), 1987; Sa Kuko ng Agila (In the Claws of the Eagle) and Irosin: Pagputok ng Araw … Babaha ng Dugo! (Irosin: As the Sun Rises … There Will Be Bloodshed!), 1989; and Tapatan ng Tapang (Match of Courage), 1997.

Buenaventura is in the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Hall of Fame for having won writing awards for the following pictures: as story writer of Geron Busabos and Ito ang Pilipino (Behold the Filipino), 1966; and as scriptwriter of Kalibre .45 (Caliber .45), Psycho Sex Killer, 1970, Erap Is My Guy, 1973, and Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), 1977. As a movie director, he won three awards from the FAMAS for Kill the Pushers, 1972, Bakya Mo, Neneng, and Kumander Alibasbas (Commander Alibasbas), 1981, all of which were chosen Best Picture of their respective years. He also won three Best Director awards from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) for Ang Huwaran (The Model), 1971, Tanikalang Dugo (Chain of Blood), 1973, and Diligin Mo ng Hamog ang Uhaw na Lupa (Water the Parched Earth with Dew), 1975.  Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Pamela Mathiel Lopez

Nonie Buencamino (Anthony Jose Martin Cristobal Buencamino) is a theater, television, and film actor. He was born in Manila on 28 Nov 1966. He is the son of Dionisio Buencamino and Aida Cristobal, and is a sibling of music composer Nonong Buencamino. He married actor Shamaine Centenera with whom he has four children. Daughters Delphine and the late Julia are both actors, while the youngest, Jose, is a music student. Music composers Lorrie Ilustre and Willy Cruz and pianist Cecile Licad are his cousins. Buencamino studied at the PAREF Southridge High School in Alabang and at the Ateneo de Manila University (ADMU). While earning his bachelor’s degree in interdisciplinary studies at ADMU, he acted for Tanghalang Ateneo, as well as for Repertory Philippines. He was among the first members of Tanghalang Pilipino (TP) Actors Company. Besides TP, Buencamino also joined productions of many other theater companies, including Bulwagang Gantimpala, SK Entertainment, Repertory Philippines, Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), Tanghalang Ateneo, Atlantis Productions, Marie Eugenie Theater of the Assumption, Ultimate Entertainment, Red Turnip Theater, Ballet Philippines, and Dulaang UP.

Buencamino starred in numerous plays, including Taga sa Panahon (A Man for All Seasons), 1987; El Camino Real (The King’s Highway) and Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1988; Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), Kasalan sa Likod ng Simbahan (Wedding Behind the Church), and Cyrano de Bergerac, 1989; Ang Ginintuang Bayan (The Golden Country) and Ang Memorandum (The Memorandum), 1990; Kenkoy at Rosing (Kenkoy and Rosing), Kanser (Cancer), and Ang Pagbabalik ng Madam (The Visit), 1991; Into the Woods and Pilipinas Circa 1907 (Philippines circa 1907), 1992; La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution), 1996 and 1998; A Chorus Line, 1997; Rama at Sita (Rama and Sita), 1998; Once on This Island, 1999; Antonio Luna and Middle of Silence, 2004; Othello, 2008; Three Sisters and A Little Night Music, 2010; Twelfth Night, 2011; Stageshow, 2012; The King and I, 2013; and Time Stands Still, 2015.

Buencamino has also been active in television. He guested on Batibot (Small but Strong), Maricel Drama Special, Lovingly Yours, Helen, Sta. Zita and Mary Rose, and Handog ng PETA (An Offering of PETA). He was also a regular cast member of several television shows produced by ABS-CBN, including Tanging Yaman (Only Treasure) and Noah, 2011; Walang Hanggan (My Eternal), 2012; Honesto, 2013; and Ikaw Lamang (No Greater Love), 2014. He also appeared in several television commercials and in the Cultural Center of the Philippines television movie Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1993. He was also a featured guest in several episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), Wansapanataym (Once Upon a Time), and Magpakailanman (Forever).

On film, he worked with directors such as Mel Chionglo, Marilou Diaz-Abaya, Lawrence Fajardo, Jerrold Tarog, and Jun Robles Lana. He was a cast member of acclaimed Filipino movies, including Milagros, 1997; Jose Rizal, 1998; Bagong Buwan (New Moon), 2000; Noon at Ngayon (Then and Now), 2002; Hubad (Naked), 2008; Ikaw ang Pag-ibig (You Are Love), Amok, and A Mother’s Story, 2011; Mga Kuwentong Barbero (Barber's Tales ), 2013; K’na the Dreamweaver and Dagitab (Sparks ), 2014; and Heneral Luna (General Luna), 2015.

Buencamino placed first in the 1982 British Council’s Shakespeare competition in the solo category, and snatched second place in the pair category. From PMPC Star Awards he won a Best Supporting Actor trophy for his outstanding performance in the films Sibak (Midnight Dancers), 1994, and Milagros, 1997, and bagged the Best Single Performance by an Actor plaque in 2012 for an episode of Maalaala Mo Kaya. Aliw Awards named him Best Actor in a Musical in 2006 for Palasyo ni Valentin (Valentin’s Palace), while the Golden Screen Awards recognized him as Best Supporting Actor in 2007 for Batad, Sa Paang Palay (Before the Harvest). Asian Television Awards conferred on him the Best Performance in a Drama award in 2006 for a Magpakailanman episode. With Eula Valdez, Buencamino won the Best Performance award from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk in 2014 for Dagitab.  Written by Malou L. Maniquis, updated by Josem Arie Roxas Pabion

Nonong Buencamino (Dionisio Jose Cristobal Buencamino Jr) is a music composer and film scorer. He was born in Manila on 1 Apr 1956 to parents Dionisio Buencamino Sr and Aida Cristobal. Theater, television, and film actor Nonie Buencamino is his brother, while music composers Lorrie Ilustre and Willy Cruz and pianist Cecile Licad are his cousins. After two years of majoring in economics, Buencamino decided to pursue music studies, majoring in composition, at the University of the Philippines College of Music from 1975 to 1981.

Buencamino started his career as a film composer in 1976, working as assistant music director and contributing composer/arranger for the full-length feature film Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (When You Dream and Wake Up), 1977, directed by Mike de Leon. From then on, he produced scores for more feature films. He had worked on more than 200 full-length feature films and won numerous awards from all the major award-giving bodies for film. He also wrote music for numerous short films, television drama series, stage musicals, live concerts, religious music compilations, documentaries for History Channel and NHK, and commercial advertisements.

Among the films for which he worked as a composer are Kapitan Kidlat (Captain Lightning), 1981; Kid, Huwag Kang Susuko (Kid, Do Not Give Up), 1987; Hot Summer, 1989; Kapag Langit ang Humatol (Heaven’s Judgement), 1990; Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin (You Are Everything to Me), Alyas Boy Kano (Alias American Boy), and Apoy sa Puso (Fire in the Heart), 1992; Kapag Iginuhit ang Hatol ng Puso (When the Heart’s Judgement Is Fated), Paniwalaan Mo (Believe It), and May Minamahal (Loving Someone), 1993; Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang ? (Why Only Now?), Nag-iisang Bituin (Lone Star), and Separada (Separated Woman), 1994; Urban Rangers, Hanggang sa Huling Bala (Till the Last Bullet), and Basta’t Kasama Kita (As Long as I’m with You), 1995; Dyesebel, Ang Titser Kong Pogi (My Handsome Teacher), Nasaan Ka Nang Kailangan Kita? (Where Were You When I Needed You?), and Sa Aking mga Kamay (In My Hands), 1996; Ama, Ina, Anak (Father, Mother, Child) and Milagros, 1997; Sa Pusod ng Dagat (In the Navel of the Sea) and Jose Rizal, 1998; Sidhi (The Story of Ah) and Ganito Ako Magmahal (This Is How I Love), 1999; Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000; Bagong Buwan (New Moon), 2001; Dekada ’70 (The 1970s), 2002; Panaghoy sa Suba (The Call of the River), 2004; Inang Yaya (Mother Nanny), 2006; In My Life, 2009; Lauriana, 2013; and Old Skool (Old School), 2015.

Buencamino received Best Musical Score awards for Biktima (Victim) from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) in 1991; for Bakit Labis Kitang Mahal? (Why Do I Love You So Much?) from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) in 1992; and for Dahil Mahal Kita: The Dolzura Cortez Story (Because I Love You) from the FAP and the Gawad Urian in 1994. Many of the films that he scored and won awards were directed by Marilou Diaz-Abaya—notably, Milagros, 1997, Gawad Urian and Young Critics Circle (YCC); Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 1999, Star Awards for Movies; Jose Rizal, 1999, Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), Gawad Urian, MMFF, and PMPC Star Awards for Movies; and Bagong Buwan, FAMAS. He also did the music score for Tanging Yaman, which won the 2001 FAMAS award, and Dekada ’70, which earned him another Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration from the YCC in 2003. His music score for Panaghoy sa Suba won in the 2004 MMFF, and the 2005 FAP Awards and Gawad Urian. In 2007, his music score for Inang Yaya won Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration from the YCC.  Written by Christian Co

Cachupoy (Salvador Garcia Tampac) was a film, stage, and television actor, comedian, and singer. He was born in Sampaloc, Manila on 12 Jul 1932. He died in Manila on 7 Dec 1993. He was the son of Segundina Garcia and Meliton Tampac. He had five children. He studied at Juan Luna Elementary School, Roxas High School, and the University of Santo Tomas, where he finished two years of fine arts. He worked with a construction firm before going into show business.

The late veteran showman Lou Salvador Sr, who was also known as Chipopoy, gave him the name Cachupoy when they appeared together at Manila Grand Opera House stage shows. Cachupoy became a comedian by accident. He was a guitarist and singer under Dalton de Castro when he was forced to take the place of an absent comedian. Reluctant to do so, he was pushed to the center of the stage and stumbled, provoking laughter from the audience who thought it was part of the act. Soon, he became a regular at the Manila Grand Opera House and was sought after by other entertainment groups. He also sang as a member of “The Millionaires,” with Manok and Miniong Villegas.

In 1972, he appeared opposite Djohanna Garcia in Luis Nepomuceno Productions’s Ang Larawan ni Melissa (Melissa’s Portrait). He also appeared in the movies Igorota (Mountain Maiden), 1968; Mong, 1979; Andres de Saya (Andres the Henpecked Husband), 1980; Boni en Klayd (Boni and Klayd), 1981; Sinisinta Kita (You Are My Love), 1981; Tsaplin en da 3 Istudyes (Chaplin and the 3 Stooges), 1982; and Wrong Ranger, 1984. In most of his films, he portrays the Sad Sack; his long, forlorn face, with hair parted in the middle and falling down straight, is what distinguishes him from other comedians. He worked with actors such as Apeng Daldal, Bentot, Eddie Mesa, Daisy Romualdez, Ruby Regala, Mario Montenegro, and Lucita Soriano. His colleagues aver that Cachupoy is a small man with a big heart who goes around giving free charity shows in hospitals, orphanages, prisons, and military camps. In 1990, the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences honored Cachupoy with the Lou Salvador Memorial Award for his achievements in show business.   Written by Danny Villanueva

Joven Calub (Joven Vinluan Calub) is a film editor. He was born in Manila on 30 Oct 1935. His parents are Victoriano “Vic” Calub, a pioneering film editor, and Adoration Vinluan. He is married to Angelita Ilagan (deceased). He graduated with a degree of bachelor of science in accounting at the University of Santo Tomas in 1956. In 1962, he got a scholarship to study at Carl Duisberg Gesellschaft in Germany.

Larry Santiago Productions gave Calub the break to be an editor. His works include Ramon Estella’s Buhay at Pag-ibig ni Dr. Jose Rizal (Life and Loves of Dr Jose Rizal), 1956; Pablo Santiago’s Los Lacuacheros (The Truants), 1957; Efren Reyes’s Sa Ngalan ng Espada (In the Name of the Sword), Pablo Santiago’s Ang Lo’ Waist Gang at si Og sa Mindoro (The Lo’ Waist Gang and Og in Mindoro), and Larry Santiago’s Yaya Maria (Nanny Maria), 1958; Pablo Santiago’s Sumpa at Pangako (Vow and Promise), 1959; Gerardo de Leon’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1961; Eddie Romero’s Lost Battalion, 1962; Monte Hellman’s Flight to Fury, produced by Eddie Romero starring Jack Nicholson and Joseph “Erap” Estrada; Eddie Romero’s Moro Witch Doctor, and Gerardo de Leon and Eddie Romero’s Intramuros (The Walls of Hell), 1964; and Eddie Romero’s The Ravagers, 1965.

Calub worked in MGM and was the first Filipino member of the Film Editors Guild of Hollywood. Before his retirement, he worked at PRO-TEK, a subsidiary of Eastman Kodak that deals in film restoration and preservation of films. He is based in Los Angeles, USA.  Written by Rica Arevalo

Iza Calzado (Maria Izadora Ussher Calzado) is a film and television actor, television host, and model. She was born in Quezon City on 12 Aug 1982. She is the daughter of the late choreographer Lito Calzado and Mary Ann Ussher. She finished high school at Miriam College and earned her degree in fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas.

Calzado started with GMA Network and after years signed an exclusive contract with ABS-CBN. Before becoming an actor, she was a dubber for a Mexican telenovela. She started her acting career as a guest teen star in the television show Click. At age 19, she played the villain in a drama series, Kung Mawawala Ka (A World Without You), 2002-03, and starred in her first soap opera Te Amo: Maging Sino Ka Man (Speaking the Language of Love), 2004, at age 22, with Argentinean actor Segundo Cernadas. In 2005, Calzado played Reyna Amihan (Queen Amihan) in the television series Encantadia. She was part of the TV series Beauty Queen, 2010, and was also in a GMA Network sitcom called Andres de Saya (Andres the Henpecked Husband) with Cesar Montano, 2011. On 28 Feb 2012, she signed her contract with ABS-CBN and starred in the drama series Kahit Puso’y Masugatan (Hearts on Fire), 2012-13. In 2014, she appeared in the drama series Hawak Kamay (Holding Hands). The following year, she had a recurring role in the primetime drama series Ang Probinsyano (The Country Boy).

In 2004, she starred in her first movie, Milan, for Star Cinema. In the same year, she also appeared in Annie B., Sabel, and Sigaw (The Echo). She starred in Moments of Love, 2006; Batanes: Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (Batanes: The End of Infinity), 2006, with Taiwanese actor Ken Zhu; and in Star Cinema’s Starting Over Again and Maria Leonora Teresa, 2014, and Etiquette for Mistresses, 2015. She played the suffering wife of a corrupt mayor in Jun Robles Lana's Mga Kuwentong Barbero (Barber's Tales), 2013, and the ambitious broadcast journalist in Jose Javier Reyes's Somebody to Love, 2014.

Calzado also hosted the Binibining Pilipinas (Miss Philippines) pageant, 2009. The following year, she began appearing in Healthy Cravings on QTV and Party Pilipinas (Party Philippines). Calzado was also a co-host of Lucy Torres on The Sweet Life, a lifestyle TV program for women on QTV. In 2011, she started hosting Showbiz Exclusives on GMA News TV. She was also the host in the second season of The Biggest Loser: Doubles. Calzado was also seen on the Sunday variety show ASAP.

Calzado won Best Supporting Actress awards in the 2004 Gawad Urian for Sigaw and the 2008 Film Academy of the Philippines for One True Love. She received the Best Actress award in the New Wave section of the 2011 Metro Manila Film Festival for HIV: Si Heidi, si Ivy at si V and the Balanghai trophy from the 2012 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival for Best Ensemble (Directors Showcase) for Mga Mumunting Lihim (Those Little Secrets), shared with Judy Ann Santos, Janice de Belen, and Agot Isidro.  Written by Christian Co

George Canseco (George Masangkay Canseco) was a music composer and film scorer. He was born in Manila on 23 Apr 1934. He died on 19 Nov 2004. Born to Jose Canseco, a doctor, and Seferina Masangkay, he studied at the Naic Elementary School and Jose Abad Santos High School. He took liberal arts at the University of the East, but did not finish his course. A journalist by profession, he was at one time or another part-time scriptwriter for the Manila Broadcasting Co, news director at Eagle Broadcasting, senior desk editor of the Associated Press, and desk editor of Philippine Herald. When martial law was declared in 1972, he turned to music writing. He had been president of the Filipino Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers or FILSCAP since 1973.

Canseco’s first composition was “I Will Never Be Yours” followed by “You’re All I Love.” He translated the latter into Tagalog in 1970, when Eddie Rodriguez asked him to write a theme song for the movie Kapantay ay Langit (As High as the Sky). It became a big hit, bringing Canseco instant popularity. Since then, he has composed one hit after another. Among them are “Rain,” “Kailangan Kita” (I Need You), “Ngayon at Kailanman” (Now and Forever), “Kung Ako’y liwan Mo” (If You Leave Me), “Kastilyong Buhangin” (Sand Castle), “Ako ang Nagwagi, Ako ang Nasawi” (I Was the One Who Won, I Was the One Who Lost), “Dito Ba?” (Is it Here?), and “Langis at Tubig” (Oil and Water), interpreted by popular singers like Pilita Corrales, Basil Valdez, Dulce, Leah Navarro, Kuh Ledesma, and Sharon Cuneta. Apart from composing movie theme songs, he had also been musical director for many films, such as Burlesk Queen, Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Heron Turns Black), Atsay (Maid), and Miss X.

Since 1969, Canseco had won numerous awards for best composer, best theme song, song of the year, best musical director, and best musical scoring from several award-giving bodies. He won the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) Best Theme Song award for “Kapantay ay Langit,” 1971, and “Imortal” (Immortal), 1989. He also won the Best Theme Song award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for the following songs: “Huwag, Bayaw” (No, Brother-in-law), 1979; “Langis at Tubig,” 1980; “Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan” (How Often is Once), 1982; “Paano Ba ang Mangarap” (How is it to Dream), 1983; “Dapat Ka Bang Mahalin?” (Are You Worthy to be Loved?), 1984; and “Hihintayin Kita sa Langit” (I Will Wait For You in Heaven), 1991. He was elevated to the FAMAS Hall of Fame in 1989. “Hiram” (Borrowed), used as the theme song of the movie Palimos ng Pag-ibig (Begging For Love), won the PMPC Star Awards for Movie Theme Song of the Year in 1987, while the following songs received the Best Original Song award from the Film Academy of the Philippines: “Sinasamba Kita” (I Adore You), 1982; “Misis Mo, Misis Ko” (Your Wife, My Wife), 1988; “Paano Tatakasan ang Bukas” (How Can You Escape Tomorrow), 1988; “Hihintayin Kita sa Langit,” 1991; and “Paano ang Ngayon Kung Wala ang Kahapon” (How Will Today Be Without Yesterday), 1995.

He was chosen best musical director by the MMFF for Bato-Bato sa Langit (Throwing Stones to the Air), 1975; Burlesk Queen, 1977; Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak, 1978; Atsay, 1979; and Imortal, 1989; by the FAMAS for Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak, 1978, Huwag, Bayaw, 1979, Miss X, 1980, Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan, 1982, and Palimos ng Pag-ibig, 1988; by the FAP Awards for Paano Tatakasan ang Bukas (How to Escape the Past), 1988; and by the PMPC Star Awards for Magdusa Ka! (Suffer!), 1987. Among his award-winning songs are “Sinasamba Kita,” 1982, and “Langis at Tubig,” 1983, both chosen by the Cecil Awards as best song written for motion picture, TV or radio; “Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan,” Cecil Awards’ Song of the Year, 1984; and “True Love Came Too Late,” Awit Awards Song of the Year, 1970. Dulce’s rendition of his composition, “Ako ang Nasawi, Ako ang Nagwagi,” won the grand prize for the Philippines at the World Song Festival in Hong Kong in 1979; the same year, “Ngayon” (Now) sung by Basil Valdez, received the Artistic Achievement Award at the Pacific Song Contests in Sydney, Australia and the grand prize in the Likha Awit Pambata Songwriting Contest. Ogie Alcasid’s album in 2010 was in his honor, Ngayon at Kailanman: A Tribute to George Canseco, Universal Records. It includes pop classics composed by Canseco such as “Hanggang sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan” (To the End of Eternity), “Yakap” (Embrace), “Paano Kita Pasasalamatan” (How Can I Thank You), “Kung Ako’y Iiwan Mo” (If You Leave me), “Kaibigan” (Friend), “Kapantay ay Langit,” and “Kastilyong Buhangin.”   Written by T. Galvez, updated by Connie Ladrido

Canuplin (Canuto Francia) was a stage and film actor and comedian. He was born in Tondo, Manila on 28 Jan 1904. He died on 4 Sep 1979. He and his wife Isabel raised their children in the Tondo area. One son, Canuplin Jr, helped him in his magic routines. He grew up in Divisoria, Manila, where his mother owned a sari-sari (variety) store, a livelihood that could hardly send all her eight children to school. The young Canuto stopped schooling at grade 4 to work as a houseboy. Sneaking out to watch Charlie Chaplin movies and playing in a neighborhood band were his favorite pastimes. His mother died when he was 10, and he had to work as shoeshine boy, earning 20 centavos a day.

At the age of 11, his fortunes turned. During the town parade, Canuto, dressed in a Chaplin costume, won first prize, and with it the chance to become a barker in the circus. From carnival crier he progressed to magician’s assistant, and attracted the attention of one of the pioneers of bodabil in Manila, Lou Borromeo. The bodabil impresario invited him to do a Chaplin act, and from then on he was known as Canuplin, a coinage from his name and that of Chaplin, his screen idol. Billed as the “Charlie Chaplin of the Philippines” at a time when many actors and singers strove to be Philippine versions of American performers, Canuplin began attracting crowds, playing in packed theaters. His act was that of a pathetic clown, a magician whose tricks frequently failed or were revealed to the audience. Between 1930 to 1934, he appeared with such local bodabil players as Patsy and Bayani Casimiro. The war years found Canuplin at his peak in show business, performing in major theaters like the Avenue, Lyric, Capitol, and Life. In the post-World War II years, he helped mold budding stage performers.

He also entered the movies, then at an experimental stage. Movie director Jose Nepomuceno signed Canuplin up for various silent pictures, in which he played Chaplin. Later, he appeared in other pictures, including Morir Antes Pagar (Die Before Paying). He also appeared in such LVN pictures as Aladin, 1946; Waling-waling, 1948; Si Eva at Si Adan (Eve and Adam), 1954; Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1955; and Diyes Isang Kanta (Ten Centavos for a Song), 1961. His last film appearance was in Celso Ad. Castillo’s Burlesk Queen, 1977, where he portrayed the role of an aging comedian front-acting in a burlesque show. His life became the subject of Manuel Pambid’s full-length play Canuplin: Isang Improbisasyon sa Buhay at mga Palabas ng Isang Komedyanteng Pilipino (Canuplin: An Improvisation on the Life and Shows of a Filipino Comedian), produced by the Philippine Educational Theater Association in 1980.   Written by Malou L. Maniquis

Carlo J. Caparas (Magno Jose Caparas), also known as Carlo J., is a film director, screenwriter, and komiks writer. He was born in Pampanga on 15 Dec 1958. He married film actor turned producer Donna Villa. He studied at Rizal High School in Pasig. He worked as a factory worker and security guard before becoming associate editor of Continental Komiks of Pablo S. Gomez Publications (PSG). His first short story, “Akong Nagmamahal sa Iyo” (I Who Love You), was published by PSG in 1967 and was followed by the komiks series Citadel, Till Death Do Us Part, and Kiss My Feet. His komiks stories range from popular drama to comedy, action, and fantasy.

A number of his works were adapted for film, including Bakekang, 1978, which starred Nora Aunor; Ang Huling Lalaki ng Baluarte (The Last Man of Baluarte), 1978; Angela Markado (Angela the Marked One), 1980, which won acclaim at the Festival of the Three Continents in Nantes, France; Totoy Bato (Totoy the Rock), 1977, and its sequel, Durugin si Totoy Bato (Crush Totoy the Rock), 1979, both starring Fernando Poe Jr; Alyas Palos II (Alias Palos II), 1983; and the multi-awarded Panday series beginning with Ang Panday (The Blacksmith), 1980, Pagbabalik ng Panday (Return of the Blacksmith), 1981, Ang Panday … Ikatlong Yugto (The Blacksmith … Third Chapter), 1982, and Ang Panday IV: Ika-Apat na Aklat (The Blacksmith: Fourth Book), 1984. Ramon "Bong" Revilla Jr. later starred in Ang Panday 2 (The Blacksmith 2), 2011, produced by GMA Films and Imus Productions, Inc. Other films based on Caparas's komiks stories are Agatona and Andres de Saya (Andres the Henpecked Husband), 1980; Somewhere and Sampung Ahas ni Eva (Ten Snakes of Eve), 1984; God Save Me!, 1985; Lumuhod Ka sa Lupa (Kneel on the Ground), 1986; and Limang Daliri ng Diyos (God's Five Fingers) and Rosenda, 1989. 

Caparas directed some of the films made from his own story and screenplay. He co-directed Mong, 1979, with Artemio Marquez, whose daughter, Melanie Marquez, starred in the film. Other movies he directed from his own story and screenplay are Dalmacio Armas,  Utol (Brother),  Pieta, and Dugong Buhay, all in 1983; Tuklaw (Snakebite), 1986; Ang Mahiwagang Daigdig ni Elias Paniki (Elias Paniki's Mysterious World), 1989; and Tasya Fantasya, 1994. 

Perhaps, Caparas will be most remembered by Filipino moviegoers for his massacre and bio movies, such as Humanda Ka Mayor!: Bahala Na ang Diyos (Watch Out Mayor!: God Will Take Care), 1993; The Vizconde Massacre Story: God Help Us!, 1993; The Maggie de la Riva Story: God … Why Me?, 1994; Lipa “Arandia” Massacre: Lord, Deliver Us from Evil, 1994; The Lilian Velez Story: Till Death Do Us Part, 1995; The Marita Gonzaga Rape-Slay: In God We Trust!, 1995; and The Cory Quirino Kidnap: NBI Files, 2003.

Some of Caparas's popular komiks novels were also turned into primetime drama series on television and used as vehicles to boost the careers of the major networks' contract stars. ABS-CBN produced Ang Panday, 2005-06, starring Jericho Rosales, and Pieta, 2008-09, starring Ryan Agoncillo. GMA Network produced Bakekang, 2006-07, starring Sunshine Dizon; Gagambino, 2008, starring Dennis Trillo; Kamandag (Venom), 2007-08, starring Richard Gutierrez; Joaquin Bordado, 2008, and Totoy Bato, 2009, both starring Robin Padilla; and Ang Babaeng Hinugot sa Aking Tadyang (The Woman Who Came From My Rib), 2009, starring Dingdong Dantes and Marian Rivera. TV5 produced Bangis (Deadly), 2011, starring Oyo Sotto, and its own version of Ang Panday, 2016, starring Richard Gutierrez. Tasya Fantasya was adapted into a weekly fantasy series by both GMA Network and TV5 in 2008 and 2016, respectively. 

Caparas won the Best Story award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) three times, for Durugin si Totoy Bato; Somewhere, 1984; and Sandakot na Bala (A Handful of Bullets), 1988. He also received Best Story award from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) for Celestina Sanchez aka Bubbles, 1988. As scriptwriter, he has two Best Screenplay awards from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) for Celestina Sanchez and Pieta. He also received Best Director award from the FAP for Pieta.

In 2009, Caparas was named National Artist for a new category, visual arts and film, by Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. However, the Supreme Court ruled the proclamation of Caparas and three others as National Artists null in Jul 2013.  Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

Ana Capri is a film and television actor. She was born in 1977. Her first film is Celso Ad. Castillo’s Virgin People II, 1996. This was followed by Serafin Geronimo: Ang Kriminal ng Baryo Concepcion (The Criminal of Barrio Concepcion), 1998; Batang Pro (Professional Kid), Pila Balde (Fetch a Pail of Water), and Sa Paraiso ni Efren (In Efren’s Paradise), 1999; Live Show, 2001; Dekada ’70 (The 1970s), 2002; Hiram (Borrowed), 2003; Pa-Siyam (Nine-Day Novena), 2004; A la Verde, A la Pobre (Green, Poor), Kutob (Hunch), and Dubai, 2005; Twilight Dancers and the “Kama” (Bed) segment of Matakot Ka sa Karma (Be Afraid of Karma), 2006; A la Suerte, A la Muerte (Luck, Death), 2007; Tarot and Nandito Ako … Nagmamahal sa ’Yo (Here I Am … Loving You), 2009; and The Healing, 2012.

Capri has also been very visible on television. Her television drama series include Esperanza (Hope), 1997; Ikaw Lang ang Mamahalin (I’ll Always Love You), 2001-02; Hanggang Kailan (Circle of Hearts), 2004; Daisy Siete (Daisy Seventeen), 2005; Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels without Heaven), 2005-6; Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), 2007; Magdusa Ka (Suffer), 2008; Rosalinda and May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), 2009-10; Pepeng Agimat (Pepe the Amulet), 2010; Noah, 2010-11; Wansapanataym (Once upon a Time), 2010-12; Amaya, 2011-12; Nandito Ako (Here I Am), 2012; Magkano Ba ang Pag-ibig? (How Much Does Love Cost?), 2013-14; Ipaglaban Mo (Fight for It) and Rhodora X, 2014; Forevermore, 2015; and various episodes in Magpakailanman (Forever), 2013-15, and Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2006-15.

Capri received her first Best Actress award from the 1999 Cinemanila International Film Festival (CIFF) for her work in Pila Balde. Later, she received two more Best Actress awards for Briccio Santos’s A la Verde, A la Pobre in 2005 and A la Suerte, A la Muerte in 2007, both from the CIFF. She also received a Best Actress award from the Golden Screen awards for her role in A la Verde, A la Pobre.  Written by Susan Claire Agbayani

Nemesio E. Caravana was a fictionist, screenwriter, and film director. He was born in 1901. He died in 1968. He was one of the most popular novelists of the vernacular magazines, known for his dramatic, colorful, stirring, and entertaining style. He used traditional themes and techniques in his novels. His sources of inspiration were old folk stories, epics, apocryphal stories in the Bible, and myths. The strong influence of the tradition of the awit and korido (metrical romances) can be clearly seen in his plots, in his use of rhetorical language, and even in his worldview. As a novelist, he sought to entertain his readers, transporting them into a world far from social realities.

Most of Caravana’s works, covering a period of 25 years, were published in Liwayway, Aliwan, Tagumpay, and Ilang-Ilang. Ilocano translations of his works also appeared in Silaw and Bannawag. He wrote such novels as Katas ng Kamatayan (Juice of Death), 1943, a humorous story about a man who falls in love with a hostess and who mends his ways after a bad dream; Bagong Manunubos (New Savior), 1946, about two people who get married, not knowing that in their early youth, they had been sweethearts forced apart by their warring families; Sanlibong Pisong Kagandahan (One-Thousand-Peso Beauty), 1946, about two people separated while they were still infants and whose lives come together again by fortuitous circumstances; Kasintahan ng Maynila (Sweetheart of Manila), 1947, whose plot also involves the reunion of two lovers after a long period of separation; and Palasyo sa Ulap (Palace in the Clouds), 1967, about the adventures of Principe Radamallin in his search for the only person who can cure his father’s illness, Princess Fatima.

Among his other novels are Banga ni Zimadar (Zimadar’s Jar), Ang Kambal sa Sinukuan (Twins of Sinukuan), and Mutya sa Taal (Fair Maiden of Taal), 1946; Paraluman sa Apo (Lovely Lady of Apo), 1949; Talisman, 1950; Durandal, 1952; Prinsesa Naranja (Princess Naranja) and Sarhento Salcedo (Sergeant Salcedo), 1960; Milagrosang Kamay (Miraculous Hands), Sandalyas ni Zafira (Zafira’s Sandals), and Ika-IX na Utos (The Ninth Commandment), 1961; Prinsesang Kalapati (Pigeon Princess), Pitong Puso (Seven Hearts), and Sampung Anak (Ten Children), 1962; Pitong Bulaklak ng El Dorado (Seven Flowers of El Dorado), 1964; Pitong Espada ng Castilla (Seven Words of Spain) and Ang Mahiko (The Magician), 1965; Mahiwagang Trumpeta (The Magic Trumpet) and Doctor Sy Kaw Tong, 1967; and INRI, 1968.

A number of Caravana’s novels were adapted into full-length films. He also wrote stories for film, such as Higit sa Korona (Above the Crown), 1956. Among the movies he directed for Premiere Productions were Libre Comida (Free Food), Espadang Umaangil (Roaring Sword), and Prinsipe Alejandre at Don Luis (Prince Alejandre and Don Luis), all in 1957; May Pasikat Ba sa Kano? (Are There American Show-Offs?) and Ramadal, 1958; Duke de Borgonia (Duke of Borgornia) and Pilyong Kubrador (The Naughty Collector), 1959; and Princesa Naranja, Party Line, and Sarhento Salcedo, 1960.   Written by Rosalinda Galang

Nena Cardenas was a film actor. She was born in San Fernando, La Union ca 1933. She finished secondary education at Arellano High School. She married Arturo Lerma.

Placing sixth in the Miss Philippines contest, Cardenas, then 16, was signed up as a contract actor by Premiere Productions and was given a lead role in Kidlat sa Silangan (Lightning in the East), 1949, with Rogelio de la Rosa. She also played the lead in Munting Anghel (Little Angel), 1951.

In 1953 she was loaned out by Premiere to Sampaguita Pictures to portray the role of a Spanish lady opposite Cesar Ramirez in El Indio (The Native), a film directed by Eddie Romero. Her other notable performances were in Hindi Ako Susuko (I Will Not Surrender), 1949; Kamay ni Satanas (Hand of Satan), 1950; Taga-Ilog (River Dwellers), 1951; Malolos, 1951; 48 Oras (48 Hours), 1950; Habang Buhay (For a Lifetime), 1953; Takas (Fugitive), 1954; and Laging May Umaga (There’s Always Tomorrow), 1954.

She won the first Maria Clara award for Best Actress for her performance in Gerardo de Leon’s Doble Cara (Two Faces), 1950.  Written by Danny Villanueva

Luciano B. Carlos (Luciano Balares Carlos), also known as Chaning Carlos, was a screenwriter and film director. He was born in Manila on 23 May 1928. He died in Las Vegas, USA on Nov 2002. He was the son of Cipriano Agulto Carlos and Juliana Laxamana Balares. He studied chemistry at the University of the Philippines Diliman, but reached up to second year only. He was married to Aurora Rodriguez with whom he had seven children. His nephew, Rahyan Carlos, is also a filmmaker.

Carlos first wrote some speaking lines for the comedy team Chichay and Tolindoy in the movie Baguio Cadets, 1950. Dr Jose Perez, satisfied with his work, assigned him a full script for Tres Muskiteros (Three Musketeers), 1951, a comedy adaptation of Alexander Dumas’s classic. It was a hit, and led to a sequel, Tres Muskiteras (Three Lady Musketeers), 1954.

Writing and/or directing exclusively for Sampaguita Pictures, he made some of the company’s most entertaining films, such as Jack and Jill, 1954; Dalagang Ilocana (Ilocano Maiden), 1954; Kuripot (Miser), 1955; Mga Reyna ng Vicks (Queens of Vicks), 1958; Silveria, 1958; and The Big Broadcast, 1962. Later on, he directed movies for other companies like Regal Films where he made a string of box-office hits including Inday Bote (Inday the Bottle Woman),1985; Inday, Inday sa Balitaw (Inday, Inday of Balitaw),1986; Jack en Poy (Jack and Poy), Maria Went to Town , and Bunsong Kerubin (Youngest Cherub), 1987; Super Inday and the Golden Bibe (Super Inday and the Golden Duck) and Petrang Kabayo at ang Pilyang Kuting (Petra the Horse and the Naughty Kitten), 1988; and Petrang Kabayo 2: Anong Ganda Mo! Mukha Kang Kabayo! (Petra the Horse 2: How Pretty You Are! You Look Like a Horse!), 1990. Known for his movies that mix broad comedy with songs and dances, Carlos's style would later influence the work of younger filmmakers like Wenn Deramas whose 2010 remake of Petrang Kabayo starring comedian Vice Ganda became a blockbuster hit. 

Carlos became the first Filipino to win an Asian Film Festival award, the Best Screenplay trophy for Ang Asawa Kong Amerikana (My American Wife), 1953. In 1975, he won the Metropolitan Film Festival Best Screenplay award for Batu-Bato sa Langit (Bird in the Sky).  Written by Lena S. Pareja

Ditsi Carolino (Edita Mariveles Carolino) is a documentary filmmaker and producer. She was born on 21 Jan. Her parents are Edillo Calza Carolino and Teresita Mariveles. She is married to human rights lawyer Aison Alejandro Garcia. She earned her bachelor of arts in sociology from the University of the Philippines Diliman in 1982 and studied at the Advance Program of the National Film and Television School in the United Kingdom (UK). In 2005, she got a grant from the Asian Cultural Council/Rockefeller Brothers Fund to explore documentary filmmaking in New York City, USA.

Minsan Lang Sila Bata (Children Only Once), 1996, a film about the country’s child labor, won first prize and Best Work on Children, Documentary Video, at the Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video in 1996; Best Documentary Film, Film Academy of the Philippines in 1997; Grand Prix Toutes Categories, Festival International du Film Independent in Brussels in 1998; Silver Medal, UNESCO Prize at the New York Festival for TV Programming in 1999; Gold Medal (Current Affairs and Social Issues) and the Grand Award at the New York Festival for TV Programming in 1999.

Riles (Life on the Tracks), 2002, produced for the National Film and Television School in the UK is an observational documentary about a Filipino couple, Eddie and Pen, who live along the railroad tracks in the slums of Manila.
