It won Best Documentary Film at the 2003 Cinemanila International Film Festival; one of the Top 10 Audience Awards at the 2002 International Documentary Film Festival Amsterdam (IDFA); and the 2003 Royal Television Society Award, Best Factual Film (Student), in London. It was acquired for broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation in 2005.

Bunso (The Youngest), 2004, follows the lives of three minor boys detained in a Cebu jail among adult criminals. It won the Best Director award at One World Human Rights International Film Festival in Prague, Czech Republic in 2005; the Grand Prize at EBS International Documentary Film Festival (EIDF), Seoul, Korea in 2005; the Youth Jury Prize at Perspektiv: Nuremberg International Human Rights Film Festival in 2006; and the Gawad Urian Best Short Film in 2005.

Lupang Hinarang (Hindered Land), 2011, is a feature-length film about the raging battle between landowners and farmers in the Philippines in the latter’s quest for agrarian reform.

March to Progress in the Philippines, 2014, is about an indigenous Dumagat man who opposes the government land development project in Aurora Province of a powerful political clan. It was produced by Al Jazeera Viewfinder Asia.  Written by Rica Arevalo

Rustica Carpio (Rustica Cruz Carpio) is a theater, film, and television actor, theater director, author, and teacher. She was born in Paombong, Bulacan on 9 Aug 1930 to parents Leon Jose Carpio and Maria Sol Cruz. She studied at Paombong Catholic School and Arellano High School. Carpio is an honor graduate of the Polytechnic University of the Philippines (PUP) and holds a bachelor’s degree in English, magna cum laude, 1953, from Manuel L. Quezon University (MLQU). With a Fulbright grant and International House scholarship, she got her master of arts in speech education, 1956, at New York University, USA. She holds a doctorate in literature, meritissimus, 1979, from the University of Santo Tomas. She taught at the Philippine College of Commerce (now PUP), 1953-54 and 1956-57; Teachers Seminary of America in New York, 1956; MLQU, 1958; Far Eastern University (FEU), 1957-67; Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM), 1967-84; and PUP since 1984. She was dean of student affairs at PLM, 1978-83, where she founded the bachelor’s program in mass communication in 1968. At PUP, she was the first dean of the College of Languages and Mass Communications, and served as dean of its graduate school.

She has appeared in various roles on stage: in Macbeth as Lady Macbeth, 1958; The Love of Leonor Rivera as Leonor Rivera, 1959; Shadow and Solitude as Gabriela, Rigodon as Tita, and Reunion as Maya, all in 1960; New Yorker in Tondo as Kikay, 1962; and Go Rider as Annie, 1974. She acted for Barangay Theater Guild in Rejection, 1960-61, and The Blue Tie and A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, both in 1960. In the mid-1970s, she was seen in Teatro Pilipino’s Bayan-bayanan (Little Country), 1975; and Tiyo Vanya (Uncle Vanya), Paano Man ang Ibig (As You Like It), and Ang Abaniko (The Fan), 1976. She first gained international notice when as a college student she became the youngest member and singer of the First Filipino Entertainment Troupe sent by the Philippine government to Korea in 1951 where they performed for the Philippine Expeditionary Forces to Korea and other United Nations armies. For this, the battleground “Rustie Hill” was named in her honor and had been adopted in the war maps of Korea. In 1983, she was leader, director, and principal actor of Sining Silanganan’s performance tour of the People’s Republic of China.

She has appeared in such television programs as Si Tatang Kasi (Blame It on Father), and Mrs. Milyonarya (Mrs Millionaire), both in 1971; My Family 3, 1972; Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora), 1979; Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday), 1980; Flor de Luna and Panagimpan (Reverie), both in 1981; Dear Teacher, 1992; Momay, 2010; Amaya and 100 Days to Heaven, both in 2011; Wako Wako, 2012; Aryana, 2013; and Magpakailanman (Forever), 2015. She appeared in the made-for-TV movie Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1993, produced by the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Carpio’s appearances in movies include Nunal sa Tubig (Speck in the Water), 1976; Bawal na Pag-ibig (Forbidden Love), 1977; Promo Girl, 1978; Menor de Edad (Underage) and Aliw (Pleasure), 1979; Nang Bumuka ang Sampaguita (When the Sampaguita Blossomed) and Bona, 1980; Tondo Girl, 1981; Waywaya, Don’t Cry for Me Papa, Moral, and T-Bird at Ako (Lesbian Love), all in 1982; Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983; Where Love Has Gone, 1984; Ma’am May We Go Out?, 1985; Shake, Rattle & Roll V, 1994; The Marita Gonzaga Rape-Slay: In God We Trust!, 1995; Totoy Mola (Big Boy), Damong Ligaw (Wild Grass), and Rizal sa Dapitan (Rizal in Dapitan), all in 1997; Campus Scandal, 1998; Kesong Puti (White Cheese), 1999; Arayyy! (Ouch), 2000; Body Parts, 2001; Kiskisan (Rice Mill), 2003; Astig (Tough) and Lola (Grandmother), 2009; Tarima (Bunks), Chassis, and Ika-Sampu (The Tenth), all in 2010; Ang Panday 2 (The Blacksmith 2), 2011; Captive and Aparisyon (Apparition), and Vesuvius, all in 2012; Ano ang Kulay ng mga Nakalimutang Pangarap? (What Is the Color of Forgotten Dreams?), 2013; Halik sa Hangin (Kiss in the Wind) and Bahay Ampunan (Orphanage), both in 2015.

Carpio has directed plays for MLQU, FEU, PLM, and Angeles University, and for private organizations. She has written several books such as Hermogenes Ilagan, 2000; Readings in Literature, 2001; Literature Is Life and Tilamsik ng Plastik (Spark of Plastic), both in 2003; The Shanghai of My Past and Other Essays, 2005; Crisscrossing through Afro-Asian Literature, 2006; and Shuttling from Stage to Screen, 2008.

She won Best Actress (shared with co-star Anita Linda) for Lola at the Gawad Urian and Las Palmas Film Festival in 2010, and at the Fajr Film Festival in Iran in 2011. She also won Best Actress for Ano ang Kulay ng mga Nakalimutang Pangarap? (tie with Vilma Santos) in the 2014 Golden Screen Awards. She was conferred the FAMAS Lifetime Achievement Award in 2010 and the PMPC Star Awards for Movies Lifetime Achievement Award in 2014. She was chosen as one of the Ten Outstanding Women of the Philippines in the performing arts, 1968-69, by the Federacion Internacional de Abogadas; and one of the Twelve Outstanding Bulaqueños, 1991, for her achievements as teacher and performing artist. She was UNESCO fellow in Dramatic Arts at the National School of Drama and Asian Theatre Institute in India, 1961. She was also cited in The World Who’s Who of Women, volume 6, 1982, published in England by International Biographical Centre.

Other awards Carpio received include a Green and Gold Artist Award of FEU on its 70th founding anniversary in 1998 for outstanding achievements in performing arts; the Gawad Parangal sa Natatanging Guro ng Pangmadlang Komunikasyon in 1999 from Pampelikulang Samahan ng mga Dalubguro or PASADO; Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan in the field of theater, given by the city of Manila on its 432nd founding anniversary in 2003; Award of Merit for Outstanding Achievements in the field of humanities from the National Research Council of the Philippines on its 71st founding anniversary in 2004; Centennial Award for Services rendered as former president of the PUP Alumni Association given by the PUP on its Centennial Celebration in 2004; Parangal ng Bayan for Outstanding Achievements in Arts and Culture given by Parangal ng Bayan Foundation in 2005; Pama-As: Gintong Bai Award for Outstanding Lifetime Achievement in Theater given by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2005; and one of 31 Outstanding Filipino Artists and Cultural Leaders given in connection with the 2005 Centennial celebration of the Feminist Movement in the Philippines; one of The Outstanding Filipinos (TOFIL) in the field of Culture and Arts from the Junior Chamber International (JCI) Senate Philippines; and one of the Most Outstanding Citizens of Quezon City in 2011.   Written by Malou L. Maniquis, updated by Ma. Clara Rosario C. Palma

Jose N. Carreon (Jose Nadal Carreon), also known as Joecar, is a screenwriter and film director. He was born in Sampaloc, Manila on 19 Mar 1944.  His parents are Cristino Carreon and Lourdes Nadal. He studied at Kamuning Elementary School and the University of the Philippines where he finished high school and later took up English. He married Nanie Espadilla with whom he has two daughters. With Ricardo Lee, Jose F. Lacaba, Jorge Arago, and Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Carreon belongs to the 1970s generation of writers grounded on the humanities and literature who have significantly upgraded the standards of local films.

In 1977, Carreon co-wrote the script of Dalawang Pugad, Isang Ibon (Two Nests, One Bird) with director Ishmael Bernal. Since then, he wrote screenplays for such movies as Ikaw Ay Akin (You Are Mine), 1978; Salawahan (Fickle), 1979, with Bernal; Hot Property, 1984; Tubusin Mo ng Dugo (Ransom with Blood), 1988; and Isang Bala, Isang Buhay (One Bullet, One Life), 1989, which he also directed.

Carreon’s Broken Marriage, 1982, written with Bernal and Bing Caballero, copped the Gawad Urian and Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) awards for Best Screenplay. Batuigas II: Pasukuin si Waway (Batuigas II: Get Waway to Surrender), 1984, also got the FAP Best Screenplay. Taga sa Panahon (Ripe with Experience), 1980, won the Metro Manila Film Festival Best Screenplay and Boy Negro, 1988, the PMPC Star Award for the same category. Sandakot na Bala (A Handful of Bullets), 1988, Carreon’s first directorial job, won for him the Catholic Mass Media Awards trophies for Best Director and Best Screenplay. In 2000, the Young Critics Circle cited Carreon for Best Screenplay for Senswal: Bakit Masarap ang Bawal? (Sensual: Why Is the Forbidden Bliss?), 2000.

With a highly notable career and contribution in the film industry, Carreon became an honorary member of the Screenwriter’s Guild of the Philippines. From 2007 to 2008, he served as secretary of the Director’s Guild of the Philippines Inc.  Written by Rosalie Matilac, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

Monang Carvajal (Patrocinio Tagaroma Carvajal), also known as Patring Carvajal, was a stage and film actor. She was born in Manila on 30 Jun 1898. She died on 22 Jun 1980. Her parents are Jose Carvajal and Patrocinio Tagaroma, both actors and singers in Spanish dramas and zarzuelas at the turn of the century. The late Eliseo Carvajal, aka John Barrymore of the Philippines, who was dubbed “Dean of Filipino Actors,” is her half-brother. Another brother, Alfonso Carvajal, was a character actor of LVN Pictures. Her son, Ernesto Carvajal, a member of the American Society of Make-up Artists, introduced prosthetic makeup in Philippine movies. Former Sampaguita Pictures child star Perla Garcia is her daughter.

Carvajal started as a stage actor at age four, appearing with her father and mother in their zarzuelas. She was cast in El Trust de los Tenorios (The Trust of Lady Killers), 1920, Di Big Banana (The Big Banana), El Capricho de las Damas (The Caprice of Women), and Juana, La Loca (Juana the Madwoman), 1931. She appeared as Doña Consolacion, the alfereza (lieutenant’s wife), in Jose Nepomuceno’s silent screen version of Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1930. By the time she reached her teens, she had come into her own as comedian, the other half of the Monang and Sano comedy team, where she was paired with movie director Manuel Silos.

In later years, she came to be known as the “Queen of Horror Pictures.” She appeared as one kind of supernatural creature or another, terrifying audiences in films like Agapito Conchu’s Sumpa ng Aswang (Curse of the Viscera Sucker), 1935; Fermin Berba’s Gamu-gamong Naging Lawin (Moth That Became a Hawk), 1937; Carlos Vander Tolosa’s Hali, 1940; Tor Villano’s Halimaw (Monster), 1941; Antonio Verches’s Palaris, 1941; and Luis Silos’s Malaya: Mutya ng Gubat (Malaya: The Forest Nymph), 1948. But she is also fondly remembered as the woman who made people laugh, a superb comedian admired by her peers, in films like Ay, Monang! (Oh, Monang), 1939; Serenata sa Nayon (Country Serenade), 1941; Victory Joe and Honeymoon, 1946; O, Salapi! (Oh, Money!) and Maling Akala (Mistaken Notions), 1947; and Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), 1950. In 1977, she appeared in Mga Bilanggong Birhen (Caged Virgins), with Mario Montenegro, Leroy Salvador, and Alma Moreno.

Carvajal was 63 years old when the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences nominated her as Best Supporting Actress for her performance in Gerardo de Leon’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1962.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

Bayani Casimiro (Bayani Gutierrez Casimiro) was a dancer, singer, and a stage, film, and television actor. He was born in San Pablo, Laguna on 16 Jul 1918. He died in Manila on 27 Jan 1989. He was the son of Trinidad Gutierrez and Paulino Casimiro, a comedian of the sarsuwela and komedya. He finished elementary school at the Caloocan Elementary School. He married choreographer Nieves Manuel, with whom he had two children. His son Bayani Jr. is also an actor. 

At age seven, he entered show business as a clown and comedian, earning 50 centavos for his act. He loved to dance, particularly tap, and won in a song and dance contest at the Teatro Zorrilla. He also won in an amateur singing contest in 1928 for his rendition of “Rainbow on the River.” In 1936 he visited Hawaii as part of a performing troupe headed by Sarsuwela Queen Atang dela Rama. By the late 1930s, Casimiro’s tap dancing had earned him the nickname “The Fred Astaire of the Philippines,” as he was often dressed up in top hat and tails like Fred Astaire. During this time, he headlined numerous bodabil productions in Manila.

In 1938, Casimiro appeared in his first movie, Excelsior Films’ Bayan at Pag-ibig (Country and Love). After some time he transferred to Filippine Films and later became part of Lou Salvador’s stage shows. During World War II, when local film productions ceased, bodabil productions became the primary source of entertainment in Manila. Along with many other actors such as Rogelio de la Rosa and Norma Blancaflor, Casimiro became very popular. It was also during this time that Casimiro met his stage partner Jose Cris Soto, and the two performed at the Life Theater in Manila. Because of the success of their team, they came to be known as the “Oliver and Hardy of the Philippines.”

After the war, Casimiro went back to his film career. In 1947, he met Rodolfo Vera Quizon Sr, better known as Dolphy, who performed at the Orient Theater under the stage name “Golay.” The two became comic dance partners. Casimiro also continued to play small roles in more than a hundred films, such as Pilipino Kostum, No Touch (Filipino Custom, No Touch), 1955; Captain Barbell, 1973; Burlesk Queen (Burlesque Queen), 1977; and Titser’s Pet (Teacher’s Pet), 1981. In his old age, Casimiro would still perform as character actor in film comedies, playing the role of an eccentric old man prone to ridicule, such as in E.T. (Estong Tutong), 1983; Horsey Horsey Tigidig Tigidig, 1986; Buy One Take One, 1988; and Magic to Love, 1989. His most popular role in his later years was in the sitcom Okey Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), as the father of Vic Sotto’s character, Enteng Kabisote.   Written by Marge C. Enriquez, with notes from Franz Edric Bangalan

Gabby Castellano (Gabriel Badeo Castellano) is a film sound director. He was born in Homonhon Island, Guiuan, Eastern Samar on 24 Mar 1937. His parents are Pedro Castellano and Josefa Badeo. He finished elementary school in Eastern Samar and moved to Manila when he was 13 years old.

At 16, Castellano became a stuntman at Cinema Technicians Inc (CTI), which serviced sound, editing, and postproduction requirements of movie production outfits. He also studied sound recording at Sampaguita Pictures and was promoted to field sound mixer and then studio supervisor of sound mixing at CTI. Later, he moved to Santos Quilatan Laboratories as head of the sound department.

Castellano worked on movies of leading companies, such as LVN Pictures, Sampaguita, and Regal Films. Among his films are Imposibleng Dalawa (The Impossible Two) and Abel at Cain (Abel and Cain), 1979; Hubad na Anino (Naked Shadow), 1980; A Man Called “Tolonges” and Tacio, 1981; Karibal Ko ang Aking Ina (My Mother Is My Rival) and Andres de Saya: Mabagsik na Daw (Andres the Henpecked Husband: They Say He’s in Control Now), 1982; Jun Parak (Jun the Policeman), Par de Jack (Pair of Jacks), Naiibang Hayop (A Different Animal), and Destination: Cotabato, 1983; Wrong Rangers, 1984; Eden, 1985; Black Diary and Bakit Naglaho ang Magdamag? (Why Has the Night Disappeared?), 1986; Ulan, Init at Hamog (Rain, Heat and Fog) and Apoy (Fire), 1987; Patrolman, 1988; Ka Leon Oliver: Ex-Rebel and The Trident Force, 1989; and Zaldong Tisoy (Zaldo the Mestizo), 1993.

He won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences award for Best Sound for Urduja, 1974, which starred Amalia Fuentes and Vic Vargas. He also received from the Film Academy of the Philippines the Best Sound award for Sumuko Ka Na, Ronquillo (Surrender, Ronquillo), 1983.  Written by Raquel Hernandez, updated by Pamela Mathiel Lopez

Celso Ad. Castillo (Celso Adolfo Castillo) was a film director, screenwriter, and actor. He was born in Siniloan, Laguna on 12 Sep 1943. He died in Siniloan, Laguna on 26 Nov 2012. He was the son of lawyer-writer Dominador Ad. Castillo and Martha Adolfo. He studied at Manuel L. Quezon University and obtained his bachelor of arts degree in English literature in 1964. He married Ofelia Lopez, with whom he had four children. His eldest son, Christopher, was also a filmmaker.

Castillo started as a writer for a komiks magazine. With the help of his father, he published his own magazine where he wrote all the stories from cover to cover, using different names as authors. A movie producer commissioned him to write a script on the character named after Britain’s superspy. Directed by Luis San Juan, James Ban-dong, 1964, made money and it was followed by a sequel, Dr. Yes, 1965, a spoof on the British film Dr. No. He wrote and directed his first movie, Misyong Mapanganib (Dangerous Mission), in 1966.

The most memorable of his earlier films is Asedillo, 1971, based on a Filipino rebel of the 1920s who was hunted down as a bandit by the American colonial government. With this film, Fernando Poe Jr strengthened his image as a legendary gunslinger, a defender of the poor and oppressed. Castillo also made Ang Alamat (The Legend), 1972, with Poe as a reluctant hero who battles a whole private army all by himself to defend his townsfolk.

Succeeding Castillo films aspired toward thematic originality, with many explicitly covering controversial content, such as incest, rape, political and period gangsterism, which would earn him the label “enfant terrible.” It was Castillo who started a trend in Philippine movies known as the “wet look,” which later helped establish the bomba film as a definite genre. His other notable films include Nympha (Nymph), 1971; Ang Mahiwagang Daigdig ni Pedro Penduko (The Mysterious World of Pedro Penduko) and Ang Pinakamagandang Hayop sa Balat ng Lupa (The Most Beautiful Animal on the Face of the Earth), 1973; Patayin Mo sa Sindak si Barbara (Kill Barbara with Fright), 1974; Ang Madugong Daigdig ni Salvacion (The Bloody World of Salvacion) and Tag-ulan sa Tag-araw (Rainy Days in Summer), 1975; Daluyong at Habagat (Tall Waves and Wild Wind), 1976; Burlesk Queen (Burlesque Queen), 1977; Aliw-iw and Ang Alamat ni Julian Makabayan (The Legend of Julian Makabayan), 1979; Totoy Boogie, 1980; Uhaw na Dagat (Thirsty Sea), 1981; Pedro Tunasan and Snake Sisters, 1983; Virgin People, 1984; Isla (Island), 1985; Payaso (Clown), 1986; Pikoy Goes to Malaysia, 1988; Tag-araw, Tag-ulan (Summer Days, Rainy Days), 1992; Kapag Iginuhit ang Hatol ng Puso (When the Heart’s Judgement Is Fated), 1993; Comfort Women: A Cry for Justice, 1994; a remake of his earlier film, Ang Pinakamagandang Hayop sa Balat ng Lupa, 1996; Virgin People 2, 1996; Lihim ni Madonna (Madonna’s Secret), 1997; Virgin People 3, 2002; Nympha, 2003, another remake; and the made-for-television Medical Center, 2011.

From time to time, Castillo would appear in films and television series. He had a supporting role in ABS-CBN’s television series Reputasyon (Reputation), 2011-12. His other acting credits include Hiwaga ng Panday (Mystery of the Blacksmith), 1998; TV5’s Babaeng Hampaslupa (The Poor Heiress), 2011; and the independent films Rotonda (Roundabout), 2008, and Engkwentro (Clash), 2009. He appeared as himself on The Search for Weng Weng, 2013, a documentary about the midget actor Weng Weng.

Castillo won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) awards for Best Director and Best Story for Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Heron Turns Black), 1978, and also the Gawad Urian for Best Director and Best Screenplay for the same picture. He shared the story credits with Ruben Nicdao, and the screenplay credits with Lando Jacob, Ishko Lopez, and Ruben Nicdao. He won the FAMAS Best Director trophy again in 1985 for Paradise Inn, a Lolita Rodriguez–Vivian Velez starrer. He also earned a FAMAS Best Supporting Actor award for Sampung Ahas ni Eva (Ten Snakes of Eve), 1984. He received Lifetime Achievement Awards from FAMAS and the Film Academy of the Philippines in 2007, a Cinema One Originals Honorary Award in 2010, and a Posthumous Lifetime Achievement Award from the Cinemanila International Film Festival in 2012. Right before his death, Castillo was working on his autobiography, Celso Ad. Castillo: An Autobiography and His Craft, which was published posthumously in 2013.  Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Erika Carreon

Jade Castro (Jade Francis Cabales Castro) is a film and television director, screenwriter, and producer. He was born in Pasig City on 21 Aug 1978. He is the son of Manuel T. Castro and Ruby Cabales. He finished high school at Elizabeth Seton School in 1995 and bachelor of arts in communication, major in film and audiovisual communication, at the University of the Philippines Diliman in 2000.

Together with screenwriters Raymond Lee (aka Moira Lang), Michiko Yamamoto, Emmanuel de la Cruz, and Ned Trespeces, Castro formed the group UFO Pictures which produced films like de la Cruz’s Sarong Banggi (One Night) and Yamamoto’s Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros), both entries in the first Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, 2005. In 2007, Castro wrote and directed Endo (Love on a Budget), an entry in the 2007 Cinemalaya. This was followed by My Big Love, 2008; Zombadings: Patayin sa Shokot si Remington (Remington and the Curse of the Zombadings), 2011; My Kontrabida Girl (My Villain Girl), 2012; Juana C. The Movie, 2013; and My Lady Boss, 2013. He also wrote screenplays, like First Day High, 2006; RPG Metanoia, 2010; and My Amnesia Girl, 2010. For TV5, he directed the television series Hush Hush, 2008, and Beki Boxer, 2014, and various episodes of Wattpad Presents, 2014, and Mac & Chiz, 2015.

Castro’s Endo won the Special Jury Prize in the 2007 Cinemalaya and Best Screenplay in the 2008 Gawad Urian. Zombadings won the Best Asian Movie award in the 2012 Neuchâtel International Fantasy Film Festival.  Written by Christian Co, with notes from Nicanor G. Tiongson

The Catholic Mass Media Awards was established in 1978 under the auspices of the Archdiocese of Manila, through Archbishop Jaime Lachica Cardinal Sin. The awards are given in observance of International Social Communications Day to stress the importance of the mass media in the people’s lives and to instill in communicators a sense of responsibility.

Outstanding men and women and their works in mass media are chosen by a body of more than 50 jurors appointed by the archbishop of Manila. The jurors include academicians, civic and religious leaders, and the clergy. The awards are for 40 categories. The awards body stipulates that to be considered, works must be local productions produced and exhibited in the Archdiocese of Manila at any time during the year in consideration and must promote basic human values for total human development. These values include love for God, respect for the environment, positive Filipino values, and love for life. Over the years, CMMA has recognized works that reflect sensitivity to human rights and the integrity of creation; contribute to the country’s economic growth; promote equity and accountability in the use of public resources and performance of public duties; portray nationalism and values of pagkakaisa (unity), pagsasarili (independence), pakikipagkapwa-tao (human relations), pagkabayani (heroism), and pagiging makabuhay (pro-life); and provide access to and participation by people, especially the poor. Awardees need not be Christian or Catholic.

Winners are awarded a trophy called The Rock, a one-kilogram stone held on a wooden base with the staff of Saint Peter, a bronze banner, and an inscription: “A tribute to the men and women who are serving God through media – Cardinal Sin.” The trophy is composed of several symbolic figures: the rock, which underscores the role of the Catholic Church as the foundation of Filipino values in media; the mirror, which represents the Church’s desire to reflect Catholic standards that bring about transformative changes in society; the curved figure with an upward movement, which represents a transformed Philippine society through the responsible use of mass media; and the two figures, which symbolize the harmonious mother-and-child relationship. Cesario “Jhundy” P. de Lina Jr designed in 2000 the current CMMA trophy.

The CMMA has seven categories for media, one category for student works, and four special awards. Media categories include print, television, radio, film, advertising, music, and the Internet. Initially, the CMMA recognized communicators only in print, television, radio, and film in Manila. It added advertising in 1979 and music in 1980. In 1984, it began including entries from all over the country for assessment. In 2001, it added the category for the Internet, in response to the increased usage and distribution of content in new media platforms. On 7 Feb 2001, it instituted the Student CMMA, which recognizes the role of the youth in raising social consciousness through the media. In 2004, it began recognizing institutions and individuals with the Serviam Awards, primarily as a tribute to its founder, Cardinal Sin. The Pope John Paul Awards are given to a group or a person that creatively utilizes the mass media in evangelical service. The Hall of Fame Award is conferred on a mass media work that has won the CMMA for the same category for five times, though not necessarily in consecutive years.

A significant year in the history of the CMMA was 1981, when Pope John Paul II personally handed out the trophies at the Radio Veritas auditorium. In 1986, after the EDSA Revolt, communicators who served the resistance against the Marcos dictatorship, including foreign media persons, were all given recognition. The body of jurors also began to include members of the academe, civil society, and public service. CMMA took a hiatus from 1998 to 1999. Following its return in 2000, it expanded from being just an award-giving body and organized in 2001 the first CMMA Media Fair. In 2013, social networks were featured as “new spaces for evangelization.”

The first awardee for print in 1978 was Herky del Aguila’s “Service and Struggle in the Mountainsides,” which was awarded Best Feature Article. In 1979, new awards for print were conferred. Best Comic Story was “Santiago” by Jose Lad Santos, Silangan Komiks; Best Book in English was Myths and Symbols of the Philippines by Father Francisco Demetrio, SJ; best opinion piece in English was “Reflections” by Father Miguel Bernad, SJ, Philippine Daily Inquirer; best feature article in English was “Bicutan Behind Bars” by Chelo R. Banal, Panorama Magazine; and best feature article in Filipino was Noel Cabrera’s “MYRC Series,” Philippine Daily Express.

The first awardees for radio in 1978 were In Unum Deum (In One God), DZRH, best program; Err Ramos as best director for the drama program Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday); and Ric T. Santos, best writer for the drama episode “Buhay Pa si Plato” (Plato Lives On), DWRV.

The first awardees for television in 1978 were Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), BBC 2, best program in value formation; Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love my Fellowman), GMA 7, best public service program; and Concert at the Park, PTV 4, best program for cultural development. New categories were introduced in 1979. The award for best TV program for human development and value formation went to the drama anthologies Fort Santiago, RPN 9, Pananagutan (Responsibility), GMA 7, and Gulong ng Palad, and Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), both of BBC 2. Best children’s program went to Mario O’Hara’s Marcelino, Pan y Vino: Alamat o Milagro (Marcelino, Bread and Wine: Legend or Miracle?), BBC 2. In 1980, new categories were added. Outstanding instructional series program was Tele-Aralan ng Kakayahan (Knowledge Educational TV), PTV 4; outstanding documentary program was Bagong Sibol ang Gubat (The Forest is Budding), produced by the Bureau of Forest Development; outstanding TV magazine program was given to Metromagazine; and the award for Metro Manila Commission Outstanding TV Program was given to Uncle Bob & Friends, GMA 7. In 1981, new awards were given: the outstanding variety program award which went to Champoy, RPN 9, and the outstanding drama award which was given to Panagimpan (Dream) for its episode “The Neglected Mother,” PTV 4.

The first awardees for film in 1978 were in three categories: Hubad na Bayani (A Hero Stripped), best film; Robert Ylagan, best screenplay for the same movie; and Ishmael Bernal, best director for Dalawang Pugad, Isang Ibon (Two Nests, One Bird). In 1979, the awards were expanded to five categories, and the winners were: Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Mother, Sister, Daughter), best film; Lino Brocka, best director for the same movie; Mel Chionglo, best screenplay; Charito Solis, best lead performer, and Joonee Gamboa, best supporting performer.

The first awardees in advertising in 1979 were San Miguel Corporation and Magnolia Ice Cream’s Sundays with Lolo and Lola (Sundays with Grandfather and Grandmother), J. Romero and Associates, for branded print advertisement; National Bookstore’s Hallmark Memories, Ace Compton Advertising, as best radio ad; the Philippine Heart Association’s The Heart is the Source of Life, Bluebird Promotions, best public service radio ad; Love Fast was recognized best radio commercial by the Asian Federation of Advertising Association; and Pepsi Cola’s Have a Pepsi Day, Ace Compton Advertising, best television commercial.

The first awardee for music in 1980 was “Anak” (Child) by Freddie Aguilar, recognized as outstanding musical composition.

The first CMMA student awardees in 2001 were Xavier, St. Francis Xavier School, Best Student Organ in the High School Level; Owl Magazine, University of Santo Tomas (UST) College of Philosophy (CP) Student’s Forum, Best Student Organ in the College Level; Ustetika Folio, UST-CP Student’s Forum, Best Literary Publication; First Time, University of the Philippines (UP) College of Mass Communication (CMC), Best TV Public Service Advertisement; Alay Kamay, Alay sa Panahon (Offering of the Hand, Offering for Time), PAREF Southridge School, Best Print Public Service Advertisement; Pamanang Lason (Poisoned Legacy), Assumption College Department of Mass Communication, Best TV Production; Kabalintunaan (Paradox), Celeste V. Lumasac, UP-CMC, Best Short Film; and “Living Rosary,” Stephen Succor F. Patricio, UST Varsitarian, Best News Photo.   Written by Laya Boquiren and Mauro Tumbocon Jr, with notes from Eulalio R. Ryan Cayabyab (Raymundo Cipriano Pujante Cayabyab) is a music composer, conductor, musical director, film scorer, television host, and teacher. He is a National Artist for music. He was born in Manila on 4 May 1954. He is the son of Alberto Cayabyab and Celerina Pujante, a soprano and instructor at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music. He is married to Emelina Punsalan with whom he has two children. Daughter Cristina Maria is also a singer and a music composer and arranger.

He first studied accounting at the UP but soon left school to augment his income working as an accompanist for the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP) Chorale which was a special project of his uncle, an official of that government agency. He finished his bachelor of music major in composition at the UP College of Music in 1983. He was a faculty member of the UP College of Music Department of Composition and Theory from 1981 to 2003.

His friendship with composers Nonong Pedero and Jose Mari Chan led to an introduction to pop singer Cocoy Laurel, who hired him as musical director/accompanist for his stage and TV performances from 1972 to 1974. He did musical scores and directions for a number of established pop groups and solo performers from 1971 to 1978. A series of successes as musical director for noted pop performers like Celeste Legaspi, Kuh Ledesma, Basil Valdez, and Pilita Corrales soon followed at venues abroad like the Carnegie Hall and the Avery Fisher Hall of the Lincoln Center, both in New York; Kennedy Center in Washington DC; the Shrine Auditorium, Los Angeles; and the Circus Maximus of Caesars Palace, Las Vegas. He has also worked in the same shows with American performers like Sammy Davis Jr, Frank Sinatra, and Diane Schuur.

He set up the Ryan Cayabyab Music Studio in Makati, 1989, and Quezon City, 1992, as a means to alternative music education. The studio later moved to Robinsons Galleria in 2006, with the name The Music School of Ryan Cayabyab. He founded and managed groups like Smokey Mountain and 14 K in the early 1990s, Kayain 2000, and is at present the music director of The Ryan Cayabyab Singers that began in 2006.

As a requirement for his graduation, he presented his composition Misa (Mass), premiered by the UP Concert Chorus at the UP Abelardo Hall in 1983. At this time, he introduced his rearrangement of Nicanor S. Abelardo’s kundiman "Mutya ng Pasig" (Muse of Pasig) in a concert by Kuh Ledesma, followed by the recordings of Celeste Legaspi of Francisco Santiago and Abelardo’s kundiman arranged for piano and voice in a modern manner. These controversial arrangements drew mixed reactions from both the pop music and the serious music worlds. He has also set to music the words of St John of the Cross in a commissioned work titled “O, Noche Oscura” (Oh, Dark Night), a choral piece premiered by the Philippine Madrigal Singers in 1990. A series of two-piano pieces was begun with Pahilaga (Northbound), based on the folk songs of the north, which were performed by Raul Sunico and Rene Dalandan in their concert tours in the United States. Pahilaga was first composed for a violin, cello, and piano trio. He has composed Gloria, a choral work premiered by the UP Concert Chorus. Te Deum was his next major choral work incorporating kulintang and balimbing with piano. His work titled Ilocandia for solo flute and orchestra is a popular orchestral piece especially for outreach performances by the country’s premiere orchestra, the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra. It has been recently transcribed for flute and two pianos. His other orchestral work is a short character piece titled Pepe en Pilar (Pepe and Pilar). The motif of this piece is taken from the popular children’s folk song “Penpen de Sarapen.”

He was also the musical director for the stage performances for the three state visits to Morocco which earned the accolade of the King. In 1979, he was musical director of the show, Manila, Manila: As Time Goes By, for the grand reopening of the Manila Hotel. He also wrote the score of the hit musical Katy! The Musical, 1988, with libretto by Jose Javier Reyes, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1991, with libretto by Paul Dumol and Jovy Miroy. He also wrote music for ballets, like Rama, Hari (King Rama), 1980, with libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera and choreography by Alice Reyes, and Misa Filipina (Filipino Mass), 1984, with choreography by Basilio. His other musical theater credits include: Noli Me Tangere: The Musical (Touch Me Not: The Musical) and Alikabok (Dust), 1995; Ang Larawan (The Portrait) and Ilustrado, 1997; and Lorenzo, 2013.

Among his award-winning scores for the movies are: Karnal (Carnal), 1983, Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) and Gawad Urian; Misis Mo, Misis Ko (Your Wife, My Wife), 1988, Urian; Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait For You in Heaven), 1991, FAMAS; Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal (You’re the Only One I Have Loved), 1992, Urian, Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), and PMPC Star Awards; Kung Mawawala Ka Pa (If You Disappear), 1994, Metro Manila Film Festival, FAMAS; and Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin (Call Me Joy), 1998, FAP. Other film credits as musical scorer include Ophelia at Paris (Ophelia and Paris), 1973; Magandang Gabi sa Inyong Lahat (Good Evening to All of You), 1975; Paraisong Parisukat (Square Paradise), the theme song of which won the FAMAS in 1977; Agila (Eagle), 1980; Kailangan Kita (I Need You) and Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1993; Abot-Kamay ang Pangarap (Elena’s Redemption), 1996; Ang Lalaki sa Buhay ni Selya (The Man in Selya’s Life), Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin, and Anak ng Bulkan (Son of the Volcano), 1997; Kahapon, May Dalawang Bata (Yesterday, There Were Two Children), 1999; Deathrow, 2000; Azucena, 2000; and Mga Kuwentong Barbero (Barber’s Tales), 2013. Ang Larawan, the musical adaptation of Nick Joaquin's A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino with music by Cayabyab and libretto by Rolando Tinio, was turned into a movie in 2017, directed by Loy Arcenas. It won Best Musical Score, among many other awards, in the 2017 Metro Manila Film Festival, Movie Musical Scorer of the Year in the 2018 PMPC Star Awards, and Best Music in the 2018 FAP as well as in the 2018 Asia-Pacific Film Festival. 

In 1978, his song, “Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika” (How Beautiful is Our Music), won the grand prize in the first Metro Manila Popular Music Festival or Metropop as well as in the Seoul International Song Festival in Korea. In 1978, he received the Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) award. His other citations and awards are: the Cecil Award for Producer of the Year and a Special Album Award for Outstanding Contribution in Serious Music for his production of the album, Misa, 1984; and the Awit Awards for Best Composer, Best Record Producer, and Best Arranger in 1990. His TV show, Ryan, Ryan Musikahan (Music With Ryan), received the Catholic Mass Media Award in 1988, 1989, and 1990, and was also adjudged as one of the 10 best TV programs in 1987 and 1992 by the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon. The same awardgiving body gave Cayabyab a special citation for his significant contribution to Philippine music.

In 1992, his song “Mama,” garnered the Best Song award in the Voice of Asia Song Festival held in Alma Ata, Tajikhstan in the former Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. His composition, “Bagong Tunog” (New Sound), a jingle for a soft drink commercial, received a bronze medal for Best Jingle in the New York Film and TV Festival and the Jingle of Year award in the 1991 Philippine Advertising Congress. He led the group Smokey Mountain to win the grand prize in the 1992 Tokyo Music Festival for the song “Paraiso” (Paradise).

From 2000 to 2006, he was the executive and artistic director of the San Miguel Foundation for the Performing Arts where the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra and San Miguel Master Chorale are formed. Throughout these years with the foundation, he has arranged the music and produced the following albums: Great Filipino Love Songs, 2004; Great Original Pilipino Music, 2004; The Sacred Works of Ryan Cayabyab, 2004; Pasko I and Pasko II, 2005; and Spoliarium The Opera, Basil Valdez: Filipino Classics (With the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra), and Dancing in the Rain, all in 2006.

Cayabyab has received local and international recognitions: Lifetime Achievement Award from Awit Awards, 1996; Professional Award in Music from the University of the Philippines, 1998; CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts, 1999; second prize for music and dance at the 2001 Onassis Cultural Competitions, 2001; Gawad CCP sa Sining for Music, 2004; and the Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice Award from Pope Francis and the Vatican, 2013. He was conferred the National Artist Award for music in 2018. 

Cayabyab is recognized by many sectors for his ability to bridge the gap between Filipino pop and classical music. Some of the albums he has produced include Routes to Roots, 1977; ONE (A One-Man A Cappella Album), 1981; ONE Christmas, 1991; The Silver Album, 1997; and ONE MORE, 2001.  Written by Felizidad Z. Reyes, updated by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab

Levi Celerio (Levi Celerio Cruz) was a musician, lyricist, and poet. He is a National Artist for music and literature. He was born in Tondo, Manila on 30 Apr 1910. He died in Quezon City on 2 Apr 2002. He was the son of Cornelio Cruz, a native of Baliuag, Bulacan and Juliana Celerio of San Pablo, Laguna. He grew up in the slums of Tondo and went to the public elementary school there. At age 11, he started taking violin lessons from a Philippine Constabulary (PC) musician and became a member of the PC Band while attending classes at Torres High School. He finished two semesters of violin at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music. Alexander Lippay, then director of the Conservatory, recommended him for a scholarship at the Academy of Music of Manila and also made it possible for him to become the youngest member of the Manila Symphony Orchestra. However, a fall from a tree, which resulted in a broken wrist, ended Celerio’s dream of becoming a violinist. He worked for some time as a komiks illustrator.

In the mid-1930s, Celerio was asked to write the theme song of Filippine Films’s Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden) which starred Rogelio de la Rosa and Rosa del Rosario. He soon became the most sought after lyricist in the country. He was not only a master of the Tagalog language; he could finish a song’s lyrics in an average of 20 minutes. He wrote the lyrics of almost all of Santiago Suarez’s balitaw and harana, like “Caprichosa” (Capricious Woman), “Ang Tapis ni Inday” (Inday’s Overskirt), “Dungawin Mo, Hirang” (Look Out of the Window, My Love), and “Umaga na Neneng” (It’s Morning, Neneng). He was the lyricist of Lucio San Pedro’s "Sa Ugoy ng Duyan" (As the Cradle Rocks), as well as Tony Maiquez’s "Sapagkat Kami ay Tao Lamang" (For We are Only Human) which was made into a movie in 1963 and won the Best Theme Song award in the 1963 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS). He also wrote the lyrics of standard Tagalog songs such as Restie Umali’s "Saan Ka Man Naroroon" (Wherever You Are), Leopoldo Silos’s “Lagi Kitang Naaalala” (You Are Always in My Mind), and Ernani Cuenco’s “Gaano Ko Ikaw Kamahal” (How Much Do I Love You). He set lyrics to novelty songs like Juan Silos Jr’s “Waray-waray,” “Alembong” (Flirt), “Ikaw Kasi” (You’re to Blame), “No Money, No Honey,” and “Basta’t Mahal Kita” (So Long As I Love You), Santiago Suarez’s “Nabasag ang Banga” (The Jar Was Broken), Tony Maiquez’s "Pitong Gatang" (Seven Gantas), and Ernani Cuenco’s “Kalesa” (Horse-driven Carriage). He started the trend of putting lyrics to folk melodies like “Pandangguhan,” “Cariñosa,” "Subli,” and “Maglalatik.” The most memorable song he wrote the lyrics for is “Maligayang Pasko at Manigong Bagong Taon” (Merry Christmas and a Prosperous New Year), also known as "Ang Pasko ay Sumapit" (Christmas is Here).

Celerio landed in the Guiness Book of World Records for being the only man who could play music on a leaf. He also published two books: Filipino Palindromes and Take it From Levi, a collection of love poems.

Celerio was conferred a doctorate in humanities, honoris causa, by the UP in 1991. Acknowledged as the dean of Filipino lyricists, he has received numerous citations and awards of recognition, like those from the Popular Music Foundation of the Philippines, 1983; the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), 1989; Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, 1991; Natatanging Gawad Urian from the Manunuring Pelikulang Pilipino, 1993; and the FILSCAP Filipino Artist Award from KATHA Music Awards, 1997. Celerio was named National Artist for music and literature in 1997.   Written by Michael M. Coroza, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

Josefino Cenizal (Josefino Yamzon Cenizal), also known as Pepe Cenizal, was a music composer, musical director, pop music pianist, and a film actor. He was born in Tanza, Cavite on 14 Sep 1919. He died in Tanza, Cavite on 27 Mar 2015. He was the son of Julio Cenizal and Rosario Yamzon. He was married to film actor and singer Olivia Cenizal (Gloria Maigue). His mother played the violin, and she was his first music teacher. Cenizal played the banjo as his first instrument. At age eight in 1927, his mother enrolled him at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music under Francisco Santiago. He studied voice under Emilia S. Reysio-Cruz and Jose Mossesgeld Santiago-Font. He took up law at UP, while studying music at the UP Conservatory of Music. Eventually, he decided to give up law and concentrate on music. He played the banjo in the Ilaya and Ideal Orchestras, sang and playedpianoover the radio, and when he was 17, became the youngest orchestra leader of the US Army and Navy Club.

Cenizal first entered the movies as an actor, doing several pictures under Parlatone as supporting player and later as leading man. Then, the first picture he worked on as musical director was Susi ng Kalangitan (Key to Heaven), 1937. The song “Agam-Agam” (Doubts), a tango piece with Salvador R. Barros as lyricist, was composed for this film where Cenizal himself appeared. Later, he also worked for X’Otic Films, Lebran Film Productions, Nolasco Bros. Pictures, LVN Pictures, and Premiere Productions. He directed and starred in San Francisco del Monte Pictures’s Rosa Birhen (Rose Virgin), 1940, where opera singer and actress Raymonda Guidote was his leading lady.

Until the 1960s, most of his work was for the movies, many of them romantic ballads and modern jazz. The theme songs he composed for movies were “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut), 1938; “Bakit Mo Nilimot” (Why Did You Forget), 1938; “Forbidden Women,” 1948; “Kumander Sundang” (Commander Sundang), 1949; “Ang Lumang Bahay sa Gulod” (The Old House on the Hilltop), 1949; “Satur,” 1951; “Gamugamong Naging Lawin” (The Firefly That Became a Hawk), 1951; “Pangakong Puso” (Promise of Heart), 1955; “Wala Kang Kapantay” (You Have No Equal), 1960; “Krusaldo” and “Milagrosang Kamay” (Miraculous Hand), 1961; “Prinsesang Mandirigma” (Warrior Princess), 1962; “Adonis Abril” (Adonis April), 1963; and “Ilusyon” (Illusion), 2005. His best-loved compositions are “Hindi Kita Malimot” (I Cannot Forget You), which was used in a Sampaguita Pictures’s movie of the same title starring Carmen Rosales and Leopoldo Salcedo. The song was played on radio for many decades and is now considered a classic. He also composed balitaw like “Ang Paglaba” (Washing Clothes), “Masaganang Kabukiran” (Bountiful Farm), and “Amihang Bukid” (Country Breeze).

Cenizal worked with his best friend Levi Celerio whenever Cenizal needed a lyricist. They produced songs like “Araw ng Pasko” (Christmas Day) and “Paskong Walang Ikaw” (Christmas Without You). He also wrote the novelty song “Ayoko na sa ’Yo” (I Don’t Like You Anymore,) and “I’m Proud to be a Rotarian” in the 1970s. Among his other compositions in the 1970s were “Ang Pag-ibig Ko’y Ingatan Mo” (Take Care of My Love), “Ipagdiwang ang Araw ng Pasko” (Celebrate Christmas Day), “Low Waist: Cha-Cha,” “Simbang Gabi at Bagong Taon” (Dawn Mass and New Year).

In 1989, he received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the City of Manila, and in 2010, the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Filipino Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, the Dangal ng FILSCAP Award.   Written by Rolando B. Tolentino, updated by Josephine Baradas

Shamaine Centenera-Buencamino (Ma. Shamaine Estrada Centenera-Buencamino), also known as Shamaine Centenera or Shamaine Buencamino, is a theater, film, and television actor, and teacher. She was born in Naga City, Camarines Sur 28 Feb 1965. She is the daughter of Joseling M. Centenera and Nena A. Estrada. She is married to actor Nonie Buencamino. Dancer and actor Delphine Buencamino is their daughter, as well as the late television actor Julia. Their son, Jose, is a music student. She received her primary education in Naga City. She graduated with honors as a scholar of the Philippine High School for the Arts in 1981. She finished a bachelor’s degree in theater arts, cum laude, at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman in 1986. She taught Theater Arts at UP from 1988 to 1991. She was a participant in the 13th Singapore Drama Festival, 1987, and a delegate to the First ASEAN Theater Festival, 1988.

She has played major roles in Filipino and English productions. As a UP theater artist, she was mentored by Antonio Mabesa and has appeared in Dulaang UP productions as Solveig in Henrik Ibsen’s Peer Gynt, 1982; Anya in Anton Chekhov’s The Cherry Orchard, Helena in William Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream, and Polly Peachum in Bertolt Brecht’s The Threepenny Opera, all in 1983; Nina Mikhailovna in Chekhov’s The Seagull, 1984; Caroline in Odon von Horvath’s Casimir and Caroline, 1985; Marsha in Chekhov’s Three Sisters, 1987; Sisa in Noli, 1992, Ricardo Lee’s stage adaptation of Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not); Atang in Floy Quintos’s Atang, 2008; Queen Elizabeth in Fredrich von Schiller’s Mary Stuart, 2009; Clarissa/Lavinia in Tinarantadong Asintado, 2011, an adaptation of Shakespeare’s Titus Andronicus; and Sparkish in William Wycherley’s Ang Misis Kong Promdi (The Country Wife), 2014. Likewise, she performed as Sister Emily in the UP Playwrights’ Theatre staging of Quintos’s Fake, 2011.

As member of the Actors Company of Tanghalang Pilipino at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), she played a variety of roles: Margaret More in Taga sa Panahon (Robert Bolt’s A Man for All Seasons ), 1987; Mhyrene in Aristophanes’s Lysistrata, 1988; Roxanne in Edmund Rostand’s Cyrano de Bergerac, and Cora in Larawan (Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino), both in 1989; Nastya in Lusak (Maxim Gorky’s Lower Depths ), Hana in Ang Memorandum (Vaclav Havel’s The Memorandum), and Marissa in Larawan ng Pilipino Bilang Artist(a) (Nonon Padilla’s spoof of Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino), all in 1990; Magnanakaw in Ang Balkonahe (Jean Genet’s The Balcony) and Wendy in Jose Y. Dalisay Jr’s Mac Malicsi, TNT, both in 1991; Apo Baket in Hudhud, 2004; Andromache in Troyanas, 2005, an adaptation of The Trojan Women; Lady Torrance in Tennessee Williams’s Orfeo sa Impiyerno (Orpheus Descending), 2006; Ester in Mario O’Hara’s Stageshow, 2012; and Señora Margarita in Elmer Gatchalian’s Juego de Peligro, 2015, an adaptation of Pierre Choderlos de Laclos’s Les Liaisons Dangereuses.

She also acted in Andrew Lloyd Webber’s Cats as Cassandra, 1985; Moises Kaufmann’s 33 Variations as Katherine, 2015, and We’re Still Hot as Mamie Summers, 2006; and in original Filipino plays like Bienvenido Noriega Jr’s Takas (Fugitive) as Tess, 1981; Rene O. Villanueva’s May Isang Sundalo (There Was a Soldier) as the prostitute and Noriega Jr’s Pinoy Pers Klas (Filipino First Class) as Monica, both in 1984; Noriega Jr’s Batang Pro (Child Prostitute) as Milet and Quintos’s Gironiere as Anna Gironiere, both in 1985; Dalisay Jr’s Kalapating Dagat (Sea Dove) as Augusta, 1986; Villanueva and Rolando S. de la Cruz’s Kaaway sa Sulod (Enemy Within) as Elsa, Marcelino Agana Jr’s New Yorker in Tondo as Nena, and Dalisay Jr’s In Transit as the prostitute, all in 1987; Elsa Martinez-Coscolluela’s In My Father’s House / Sa Tahanan ng Aking Ama as Isabel, 1987 and 1989; and Layeta Bucoy’s Tu Dulce Estranjera (Your Sweet Stranger) as Josephine Bracken, 2011. For UP Tropang Bodabil (later Peryante), she played the role of the Huk leader Luningning in Marina Feleo-Gonzalez’s Dahong Palay (Rice Leaves), 1982, and Maria Clara, Salome, and Sisa in Kutsilyo, Pamaypay, at Yantok (Knife, Fan, and Cane), 1983, by Chris Millado and Nicolas Pichay.

Centenera-Buencamino worked for a time as an assistant director in TV commercials. She has also acted and worked behind the scenes in foreign and local films and television dramas. On screen, she was seen in films such as Kung Ako’y Iiwan Mo (Should You Abandon Me), 1992; Dahil Mahal Kita: The Dolzura Cortez Story (Because I Love You), 1994; Astigmatism, 2004; Lasponggols, 2005; Rotonda, 2006; Tukso (Temptation), 2007; One Last Chance, Ang Lihim ni Antonio (Antonio’s Secret), and Concerto, 2008; Biyaheng Lupa (Soliloquy), Agaton and Mindy, Behind Closed Doors, and In My Life, 2009; Babe I Love You, Cinco, Ikaw ang Pag-Ibig (You Are Love), Magkakapatid (Siblings), and Tsardyer (Charger), 2010; Requieme!, 2012; Mga Kuwentong Barbero (Barber's Tales), 2013; and Lorna, 2014. On television, she has acted in anthologies and drama series such as Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 2001; Mahiwagang Baul (Enchanted Chest), 2007; Prinsesa ng Banyera (Princess of the Fish Bucket), 2008; Majika (Magic), 2006; Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009; Pilyang Kerubin (Naughty Cherub), 2010; Little Star, 2010-11; and Midnight DJ, 2011; as well as in episodes of drama anthologies like Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), Magpakailanman (Forever), Untold Stories Mula sa Face to Face, and Star Drama Presents.

Her craft initially won her first prize for solo delivery at a British Council Shakespearean Competition in 1985. She is the recipient of four awards from the Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group Gawad Buhay! for the Performing Arts: Outstanding Lead Actress for Quintos’s Ang Kalungkutan ng mga Reyna (The Sadness of Queens), 2008, and Madonna Brava ng Mindanao, 2009, Nestor Horfilla's adaptation of Bertolt Brecht’s Mother Courage and Her Children; Outstanding Lead Actress in a Musical for Stageshow, 2012; and Outstanding Featured Actress in a Musical for PETA’s D’ Wonder Twins of Boac, 2013, Rody Vera's adaptation of Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night. Her performance in Ang Kalungkutan ng mga Reyna won her another Best Actress in a Non-Musical Play award from the Aliw Awards in 2008. In 2007, she was adjudged Best Actress for her performance in the Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival entry Prinsesa. In 2012, she won Best Supporting Actress awards from Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, Golden Screen Awards, and the 6th Asian Film Awards in Hong Kong for her role as a lesbian daughter in the Cinemalaya film Niño (Boy).   Written by Malou L. Maniquis, updated by Gilbert H. Cadiz

Behn Cervantes (Benjamin Holcombe Cervantes) was a theater and film director and actor, television director, and teacher. He was born in Iloilo on 26 Aug 1938. He died in Manila on 15 Aug 2013. He was the ninth of the 11 children of Cenon Cervantes and Rosario Elizabeth Holcombe, an American. After World War II, Cervantes finished his elementary studies at a small exclusive school in Iloilo and high school at De La Salle University in Manila. He took a bachelor’s degree in speech and drama at the University of the Philippines (UP), and a master’s degree in theater arts at the University of Hawaii. He also studied drama and film at Columbia University and at Beloit College in Wisconsin. He taught theater courses at UP from 1967 up to his early retirement in 1989. He also taught at De La Salle University and Philippine Christian University.

His theater activism led him underground when martial law was declared in 1972. He was arrested four times between 1972 and 1985, but continued to lead the UP Repertory Company, which he founded and guided as a nationalist theater company since 1974. In 1983, he and Lino Brocka spearheaded the Free the Artist Movement which gave birth to the Concerned Artists of the Philippines, which Cervantes chaired for three years. He served on the National Council of Bagong Alyansang Makabayan; on the Council of SINING, an organization of cultural organizations; and in various nationalist and cultural organizations. He was a founding member of the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) in 1967 and the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino in 1975; and was also a member of the Board of Trustees of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 2009-10.

While in college, he joined the UP Dramatic Club, and appeared in such plays as No Exit, The Caine Mutiny Court Martial, and Murder in the Cathedral. In the United States he worked in a summer company in Wisconsin, appearing in plays like Waiting for Godot and the Nigerian play Swamp Dwellers. In Manila he also acted with the Arena Theater, Barangay Theater Guild, Manila Theater Guild, and later PETA and Repertory Philippines. Among his memorable roles are the Mikado in The Mikado, Marquis de Sade in Marat/Sade, Rene Gallimard in M. Butterfly, Mr Guildenstern in Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead, and Candido in the male version of A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino.

His first directorial work included directing Lino Brocka in a scene from the UP Dramatic Club’s Mr. Roberts and another from Anastasia. In the 1960s and early 1970s, he directed mainly Western plays in English, such as Federico Garcia Lorca’s The House of Bernarda Alba, Ferenc Molnar’s The Play’s the Thing, and Jesus Christ Superstar. After his politicization in the 1970s, he turned to politically committed theater in Filipino. He joined the Samahang Demokratikong Kabataan (SDK), and later became resident director of SDK’s theater group, Gintong Silahis. Cervantes’s first Tagalog plays were Alay kay Ka Amado (Offering to Ka Amado), 1971, and Barikada (Barricade), 1971, a multimedia experiment reenacting the nine-day “Diliman Commune” at the height of the First Quarter Storm in 1970. He designed proletarian theater techniques for the time and its needs—for example, using a koro (chorus) because there were no microphones during rallies and discussing the play with the audience after the performance. He took Gintong Silahis to rallies at Plaza Miranda, to communities and schools, and to the streets.

For the UP Repertory Company, he directed Sobresaltos (Sudden Fears), 1973; Butil ng Buhay (Grain of Life) from Estrella Alfon’s Bigas (Rice), 1973; The Heart of Emptiness Is Black, 1974; Palabas ni Suwan (Suwan’s Show), Dahil sa Anak (Because of the Child), and Sino Ba Kayo ? (Who Are You All?) in 1975; Ang Bundok (The Mountain), 1976; Pagsambang Bayan (People’s Worship), 1977; Beatas, 1978; Ang Panahon ni Cristy (The Times of Cristy), 1979; Panginoon sa Driod (God in Driod) and Estados Unidos bersus Cruz, Abad at Tolentino (United States versus Cruz, Abad and Tolentino), 1981; Kaaway (Enemy) and Larawan (A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino), 1982; and Pagbibinyag sa Apoy at Dugo (Walking Canes and Fans), 1985. He is also known for Guys and Dolls, The Short, Short Life of Citizen Juan, and Iskolar ng Bayan (Scholar of the People). He also directed translations such as El Extensionista (The Agricultural Expert), 1984, and Ang Reyna at mga Rebelde (The Queen and the Rebels), 1986; and plays in English such as Agnes of God, 1988, and Twelve Angry Women, 1989.

Cervantes also directed for film and television. His film debut, Sakada (Seasonal Cane Workers), 1976, was hailed by critics but banned after a few days of exhibition by the Marcos military. He directed other films and became a member of the directors’ guild of the Film Academy of the Philippines. Among the programs that he directed for TV was the miniseries Angkan (Clan). He also contributed articles on theater in the Philippine Daily Inquirer and Business World.

Cervantes was given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Lifetime Achievement Award in 1989; the CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts in 1999; the Aliw Lifetime Achievement Award in 2010; and the UP Alumni Lifetime Distinguished Achievement Award in 2013. Cervantes won third prize in the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature for his English full-length play titled Istorya ni Bonipasyo: Kasla Gloria ti Hawaii (Bonipasyo’s Story: Hawaii Is Like Paradise) in 1997. He is also listed in the East-West Center’s Wall of Honor in Hawaii.   Written by Joi Barrios and Malou L. Maniquis, updated by David Quimpo

Chichay (Amparo Robles Custodio-Moya) was a stage, radio, film, and television actor, singer, and dancer. She was born in Tondo, Manila on 21 Jan 1918. She died in Manila on 31 May 1993. The 10th of 13 children born to Maria Robles and Jose Pacifico Custodio, a ship steward, she was educated at Tondo Elementary School and Torres High School. Orphaned early, she appeared in school stage shows and became a member of the Samahang Antonieta as a singer and tap dancer. She and sister Iluminada came to be known as the Custodio Singers. She married Hercules Saenz Moya of Iloilo, with whom she had six children.

Fellow vaudeville actor Atang de la Rama gave her the moniker “Chichay,” from the Japanese word “chiisai,” meaning “tiny.” Along with her short but stocky built, she was later known for her toothless appearance, whiny voice, and aged look, which gave her the chance to portray the role of a feisty but laughable grandmother in many broadcast sitcoms and films, becoming famous with the hoarsely delivered line “O, weno?” (So what?).

Chichay appeared in her first film, Premiere Productions’s Itanong mo sa Bulaklak (Ask the Flower), 1948, directed by Paquito Bolero and which starred Dely Atay-Atayan. She became famous through her comedic tandem with Tolindoy, beginning in Sampaguita Pictures’s Buhay Pilipino (Filipino Life), 1952, and Gorio at Tekla (Gorio and Tekla), 1953. The latter was directed by Olive La Torre, the father of actor-singer Sylvia La Torre, written by Mars Ravelo for the comics Tagalog Klasiks, and starred Fred Montilla, Norma Vales, and Ramon Revilla Sr, who would become a senator.

Chichay was one of the first talents of Manila Broadcasting Company’s DZRH beginning in 1949; one of ABS-CBN’s legion of radio and TV personalities on DZAQ and Channel 3 in the 1960s until the declaration of martial law in 1972; a mainstay of the TV variety program The Main Show, later retitled Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour), 1964, with Oscar Obligacion, Sylvia La Torre, and Ading Fernando; the main character in the radio show Miss Loudspeaker, 1965, with Al Mendez, Sylvia La Torre, Apeng Daldal, and Ike Lozada; part of the TV musical The Nida-Nestor Show, 1965, directed by Mitos Villareal, choreographed by Julie Borromeo, and written by Ading Fernando; anchor of the daily news program Radyo Patrol (Patrol Radio) in the late 1960s, with Rod Navarro and reporters Cris Daluz, Hector Villanueva, Edgar Malay, Jun Eusebio, and Orly Mercado; and a philanthropist in the pre-martial law sitcom Ginang Milyonarya (Madam Millionaire), 1972, with Rudy Manlapaz, later retitled Mrs. Milyonarya (Mrs Millionaire) when it went on air again in late 1973 on IBC 13, then on RPN 9. She was the first choice for the role of Doña Delilah for what would become RPN 9’s top-rating sitcom John en Marsha, starring Dolphy and Nida Blanca, but she opted to stay in Mrs. Milyonarya, with the role of Doña Delilah going to Dely Atay-Atayan.

During the martial law period, she appeared in the comedy programs of RPN 9: My Son, My Son with Jay Ilagan and Tange; Ang Biyenan Kong Mangkukulam (My Witch Mother-In-law), a local version of the US television program Bewitched and which featured Pancho Magalona; Ang Lola Kong Baduy (My Out-of-Style Grandmother), 1976, with Charo Santos; and Kaluskos Musmos (Kiddie Noise), 1979-89, RPN 9, a children’s program produced by Imee Marcos, directed by Johnny Manahan, with a cast of children headed by Maricel Soriano and Herbert Bautista, and adult mainstays Bert Marcelo, Gary Lising, and Estrella Kuenzler. She also appeared in the family comedy programs Two Plus Two, 1982, BBC 2, about the daily concerns of a young middle-class couple, with Vic Sotto, Dina Bonnevie, their daughter Danica who was then a toddler, Maricel Soriano, William Martinez, Gary Lising, and Herbert Bautista; and Bistek, 1990, Islands TV 13, with Bautista.

She appeared in 149 films. She played doting grandmother to an overgrown man-child portrayed by Fred Montilla in Sampaguita Pictures’s comedy films Bondying, 1954, and Tatay Na si Bondying (Bondying Is Now a Father), 1955, both directed by Armando Garces and story by Ravelo, and by Jimmy Santos in Viva Films’s Bondying: The Little Big Boy, 1989, directed by Mike Relon Makiling and written by Jose Javier Reyes. Her other movies include Sampaguita Pictures’s Barbaro (Barbarian), 1952, written by Francisco V. Coching and starring Pancho Magalona, and Madame X, 1952, written by Fausto J. Galauran; Dalisay Films’ comedy Pitong Atsay (Seven Housemaids), directed by Tony Santos Sr, and starring Patsy, Aruray, Menggay, Elizabeth Ramsey, Dely Atay-Atayan, and Metring David, and its sequel Ang Pinakamalaking Takas ng Pitong Atsay (The Great Escape of the Seven Housemaids), 1962; RVQ Productions’s comedy-musical Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life), 1967, directed by Luciano Carlos, written by Ading Fernando, and starring Dolphy and Susan Roces; NV Productions’s musical Annie Batungbakal, 1979, directed by Maryo J. de los Reyes, written by Jake Tordesillas, and starring Nora Aunor, and its sequel Associated Entertainment Corporation’s Bongga Ka 'Day! (You're Fabulous, Pal!), 1980; Viva Films’s love story Forgive and Forget, 1982, directed by Eddie Garcia, written by Orlando Nadres, and starring Sharon Cuneta and William Martinez; and Regal Films’s fantasy movie Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), 1985, in which she portrayed the folk storyteller Lola Basyang. Her last movie was Regal Films’s Cheeta-eh: Ganda Lalake? (Cheeta-eh: Handsome Guy?), 1991, which starred the comedian Rene Requiestas.

She was nominated Best Supporting Actress by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Bilangguang Puso (The Heart Is a Prison), 1972. She was the Citizen’s Awards for Television Best Female Supporting Performer for her performance in The Nida-Nestor Show from 1966 to 1969; Manila Film Festival Outstanding Actress, 1967 and 1968; one of the Top Ten TV-Radio Personalities, 1969; Tandang Sora Awardee, 1980; one of the Walang Kupas Awardees chosen by the Doña Josefa Edralin-Marcos Foundation, early 1980s; Gintong Ina Awardee for Arts and Culture, 1989; Philippine Movie Press Club (PMPC) Star Lifetime Achievement Awardee, 1989; Film Academy of the Philippines Lifetime Achievement Awardee, 1989; and PMPC Ulirang Artista Awardee, 1993. She received the Gawad Natatanging Kontribusyon sa Telebisyon Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines at the 7th Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon in 1994.   Written by Glecy Atienza, Malou Maniquis, and Doreen G. Fernandez, updated by Eulalio R. Guieb III and Rolando R. Santos

Mel Chionglo (Carmelo Tan Chionglo) is a film and television director, and production designer. He was born in Lucena City on 16 Jul 1946. His parents are Jose Chionglo Sr and Dominga Tan. He was educated at Maryknoll College, Lucena City, and Ateneo de Manila University. A sister, Elizabeth, is a cartoonist, while a brother, Joen, is a screenwriter. Chionglo was active in the Production Designers Guild of the Film Academy of the Philippines, the Directors Guild of the Philippines Inc, and the Concerned Artists of the Philippines.

Chionglo first gained recognition in the film Itim (The Rites of May), 1976, for which he received the Best Production Design award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences. The film was directed by Mike de Leon, his classmate at Ateneo. He also received Gawad Urian nominations for his production design of Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (When You Dream and Wake Up), 1977; Gumising Ka … Maruja (Wake Up … Maruja), 1978; Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Mother, Sister, Daughter), 1979; and Salawahan (Fickle), 1979. Chionglo was also responsible for the production design of Ishmael Bernal’s Walang Katapusang Tag-Araw (Eternal Summer), 1977, and Joey Gosiengfiao's Temptation Island and Eddie Romero’s Aguila, 1980.

Among Chionglo’s directorial works are Playgirl, 1980, Sinner or Saint, 1982, and Nasaan Ka Nang Kailangan Kita? (Where Were You When I Needed You?), 1986. He also directed the 1990 version of Mars Ravelo’s tale of a mermaid, Dyesebel, starring Alice Dixson. The year 1994 saw a rise in Chionglo’s career as a director with the release of his film Sibak (Midnight Dancers), a followup to Lino Brocka's similarly controversial Macho Dancer, 1988. The film was screened at the 1994 Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF) as well as in the United States, Japan, Spain, and the Czech Republic. Chionglo also directed Burlesk King (King of Stripteasers), 1999, and Twilight Dancers, 2006. Both films were screened at the TIFF and the Chicago International Film Festival in 1999 and 2006, respectively. Burlesk King was also screened at the 2000 Berlin International Film Festival and Los Angeles Asia Pacific Film Festival. Lagarista (The Film Biker), another Chionglo film released in 2000, featured then rising star Piolo Pascual in his first leading role. Lagarista was also screened at film festivals in Toronto, Chicago, Pusan, and Hong Kong. Chionglo's more recent movies are Bente (Twenty), 2009, Lauriana, 2013, and Iadya Mo Kami (Deliver Us), 2016.

For television, Chionglo directed several episodes of the drama series Rio del Mar, 1999-2001, for TAPE, Inc and GMA Network. He also directed two episodes of ABS-CBN's drama anthology, Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2000. 

Chionglo received the Gawad Urian for Best Production Design for Ikaw Ay Akin (You Are Mine), 1978, and the international award for Best Film at the 1992 London Environmental Film Festival for Lucia, a telemovie starring Lolita Rodriguez. Lucia was also a nominee at the Tokyo Global Film Festival, Wildscreen Festival (Bristol), and One World Broadcasting Trust Awards, 1992.

Chionglo continued to remain active in the film industry with the crucial role of heading the monitoring committee of the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival starting in 2014.  Written by Ramon Jocson, Ellen Bomasang, and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr and Elmer L. Gatchalian

Chiquito (Augusto Valdez Pangan Sr), also known as Tito Pangan, was a film, stage, and television actor, dancer, comedian, and producer. He was born in Manila on 12 Mar 1928. He died in Makati City on 2 Jul 1997. He was the son of Remedios Valdez and Manuel Eric Pangan, an executive of San Miguel Corporation. He studied at P. Gomez Elementary School and finished high school at Mapua Institute of Technology. He was married to his former dancing partner Vilma Isidro, with whom he had seven children. One of his daughters, Eliza, had a brief career as a comedienne acting in some of her father's movies, with the moniker Bukol.

During the Japanese Occupation, Chiquito was only 13 when he joined the shows of Lou Salvador Sr at the Manila Grand Opera House. At 14, he was appearing in stage shows at Life Theater. He learned all the ballroom dances of the time, especially the boogie, which he danced so well that he was fondly called “Tito Boogista” by his peers. He also performed at Inday Theater and Clover Theater, where he caught the attention of Fernando Poe Sr.

After the war, Poe gave him a chance to appear as an extra in his movie production, Death March, 1947. He was introduced with Ben Cosca (Bentot) as the comedy team in Ganyan Ka Pala (So That’s the Way You Are), 1956, a Nida Blanca–Nestor de Villa starrer. His first appearance as a supporting actor was in Premiere Productions’s Atribida (Eager-Beaver), 1958.

Often pitted against his contemporary Dolphy, the two comedians starred in six movies together: Ikaw na ang Mag-Ako (You Become Me), 1963; Adre, Ayos Na (Ang Buto-Buto) [Pal, It's a Done Deal], 1964; Kulog at Kidlat (Thunder and Lightning), 1965; and Doble Solo (Double Solo), Pambihirang Dalawa (Sa Combat) [Amazing Duo in Combat], and Dalawang Kumander sa WAC (Two Commanders in WAC), all in 1966. 

Popular comic-strip characters were brought to life on-screen by Chiquito, who played Asiong Aksaya, Mr Wong, Gorio, Tacio, Sariong Albularyo, Atorni Agaton, Barok, and Mang Kepweng. He spoofed Hollywood action movies in films like James Ban-dong and Adyong Untouchable, 1964; Akong Deadly, 1964; Alyas Dillinger, 1965; Agent Wooly-Booley, 1966; and Mr. Wong and the Bionic Girls, 1977. 

He is well-known as the two-gun fighter in Arizona Kid, 1970, with Hollywood actor Mamie Van Doren, a Premiere movie based on a story and screenplay by Lino Brocka, directed by Luciano B. Carlos. He also spoofed a Brocka film with his own Tinimbang Ka, Bakit Husto? (You Were Weighed and Found Exact?), 1977. The success of his Sotang Bastos (Jack of Clubs) series where he plays a real-life role as race jockey prompted him to put up his own Sotang Bastos Productions in the 1980s.

A few years before his death, Chiquito appeared in a number of comedy movies alongside younger comedians like Andrew E. in Pinagbiyak na Bunga (Lookalikes), 1994, and Bangers, 1995, and Janno Gibbs in Ang Pagbabalik ni Pedro Penduko (The Return of Pedro Penduko), 1994. Pinagbiyak na Bunga was turned into a short-lived comedy series on GMA Network titled D' Lookalayks: Puno't Bunga (The Lookalikes: Tree and Fruit). He also did a rare dramatic performance in an episode of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) titled "Tumba-tumba" (Rocking Chair), 1991. His last movie was Strict ang Parents Ko (My Parents are Strict), 1997.

Chiquito was nominated by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences as Best Supporting Actor for his performance in Lovingly Yours, Helen: The Movie, 1984. He served as municipal councilor of Makati from 1969 to 1972 and from 26 Jan 1988 to 24 Aug 1989, before he was appointed vice-mayor on 25 Aug 1989. He made an unsuccessful bid to run for the Philippine Senate in 1992. He served as Makati City councilor from 1995 until his death in 1997.  Written by Malou M. Maniquis and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu and Elmer L. Gatchalian

Manuel "Fyke" Cinco (Manuel Astorga Cinco), also known as Manuel Cinco, is a film director and screenwriter. He was born in Manila on 16 Nov 1940. His parents are Eusebio Cinco and Catalina Astorga. He attended high school at Colegio de San Juan de Letran and took up electrical engineering at Mapua Institute of Technology, but had to drop out due to financial reasons.

Long interested in Philippine movies, Cinco first got involved in the movies as an extra. He learned how to be a sound technician, then started writing scripts after he made friends with Augusto Buenaventura, a writer at Premiere Productions, and Adrian Cristobal, a journalist. Later, he became assistant director and, in 1970, directed his first movie, The Man From A.N.K.L.A., a comedy starring Pablo Virtuoso and Dencio Padilla, under Empire Pictures. The title is a spoof of the action-spy television series The Man from U.N.C.L.E., 1964. Cinco also directed movies for producers Elizabeth Poe, sister of Fernando Poe Jr, and her husband Bob Soler.

Cinco made over 50 films in his 28-year career as director. He first directed dramas, before shifting to action films. Directors Gerardo de Leon, Efren Reyes Sr, and Eddie Romero greatly influenced his own unique style. He made many movies for FPJ’s production company for several years, and also handled directorial jobs for Vanguard, Jowell Films, Myrick Films, Tagalog Ilang-Ilang, Seven Stars Productions, Rosas Films, Seiko Films, Viva Films, and Regal Films. His notable films include Isinilang Ko ang Anak ng Ibang Babae (I Gave Birth to the Child of Another Woman), 1973; Huwag, Bayaw (Don’t, Brother-in-Law), 1979 Batuigas II: Pasukuin si Waway (Batuigas II: Get Waway to Surrender), 1984; Lumuhod Ka sa Lupa (Kneel on the Ground), 1986; Ipaglalaban Ko (I Will Fight for It), 1989; Hinukay Ko Na ang Libingan Mo (I’ve Already Dug Your Grave), 1991; Galvez: Hanggang sa Dulo ng Mundo Hahanapin Kita (Galvez: I Will Hunt You Until the End of the Earth), 1993; and Guevara: Sa Batas Ko Walang Hari (Guevara: In My Law, There Is No King), 1998.  Written by Raquel Hernandez, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

article_title: Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival
text:
Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival is an annual festival of locally produced full-length films, documentaries, restored film classics and contemporary masterpieces, and select short films, as well as internationally acclaimed movies. It started in 2005 as a project of the ABS-CBN subsidiary Creative Programs Incorporated to encourage local film production, beef up the content of Cinema One, ABS-CBN’s cable movie channel, and serve as venue for the best films of Philippine and world cinema. The festival began to be held in July for three days in selected cinemas in Metro Manila. Currently, it is now being held for 10 days every November in selected cinemas in and outside Metro Manila.

In 2006, the festival introduced a competition category where local filmmakers from all over the country are invited to submit screenplays. A selection committee, headed by Cinema One channel head Ronald Arguelles, chooses finalists based on the quality of their scripts and their capacity to mount a full-length film project. The finalists are then given a production budget to finance their film’s production. When it started in 2005, only five finalists were selected to compete in the festival, and each of them were given 700,000 pesos. The cash grant was raised to one million pesos in 2007. The following year, the number of finalists also increased to seven. In 2012, the festival divided the competition into two categories: the Plus Category, where five films were given two million pesos each, and the Currents Category, where 10 films were granted one million pesos each. In 2014, however, the two categories were dissolved but the cash grant was raised to three million pesos. Over the years, the number of narrative films in competition increased to as many as 10 films. The short film category was introduced in 2014. While Cinema One is the exclusive owner of the screening and distribution rights of the submitted films in competition, grantees became co-owners of their works in 2011 as percentage sharing was introduced by the organizers in order to encourage more Filipino filmmakers to tell their stories through the medium of cinema.

Cinema One has become one of the most exciting film-related events in the country and a launching pad for some of the country’s young and fresh talents, both on and behind the camera. When the competition category started in 2006, Sherad Anthony Sanchez’s Huling Balyan ng Buhi (Woven Stories of the Other) was chosen as the festival’s first Best Film winner.
