Some of the directors whose careers were launched by Cinema One Originals are Jerrold Tarog, Sherad Anthony Sanchez, Jason Paul Laxamana, Richard Somes, Remton Siega Zuasola, and Antoinette Jadaone. More recent discoveries include the likes of Sigrid Andrea Bernardo, Eduardo Dayao, and Petersen Vargas. Some of the films in the festival have also been screened in film festivals abroad, won recognition in international and local award-giving bodies, and are now regarded as significant works in the canon of contemporary Philippine cinema.

The festival is also known for bringing regional cinema into the spotlight with the likes of Keith Deligero, Victor Kaiba Villanueva, Gutierrez Mangansakan II, and Sheron Dayoc, to name a few.

The festival continues to evolve parallel to the changing needs of Philippine contemporary cinema, together with all the progressive film festivals spawned by the digital film revolution in the early 2000s. Cinema One Originals continues to pave the way towards one diverse but united Philippine cinema.   Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, with notes from Ronald Arguelles

Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival was founded in 2005 by Cinemalaya Foundation Inc, a nonstock, nonprofit, nongovernment foundation committed to the development and the promotion of Filipino independent films. An annual film festival at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), Cinemalaya reflects the commitment of the foundation by encouraging the creation of new cinematic works by Filipino filmmakers. Organizers of Cinemalaya are businessman Antonio O. Cojuangco; the CCP, headed in 2005 by Nestor Jardin; the University of the Philippines College of Mass Communications, then headed by its dean Nicanor G. Tiongson; and the Film Development Council of the Philippines, then chaired by veteran actor and director Laurice Guillen. Jardin was festival director for 10 years, Guillen has been the Cinemalaya competition chairman since the start, while Tiongson was convenor of the Cinemalaya Congress for eight years.

Annually, Cinemalaya gives seed grants of around half a million pesos to independent filmmakers, and the finalists compete for the Balanghai awards in the New Breed Full Length Film category. Another category in the festival is the Short Features, which are chosen from submissions by amateur and professional filmmakers. For a time, from 2010 to 2014, the Cinemalaya also had the Directors Showcase, which granted seed money for directors who had already made more than three films.

Clodualdo del Mundo Jr’s Pepot Artista (Pepot Superstar), 2005, is the very first recipient of the Balanghai trophy for Best New Breed Full Length Film. Another Balanghai award given by the Cinemalaya is the Special Jury Prize, which has given recognition to films such as for the New Breed Auraeus Solito’s Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros), 2005. For the Short Feature category, the very first winner was Mansyon (Mansion), 2005, by Joel Ruiz. In the Directors Showcase from 2010 to 2014, the first film to win the top award was Mark Meily’s Donor, 2010. In 2008, the Audience Award was added to the list. In 2009, the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema or NETPAC Award was instituted in Cinemalaya. Individual awards are also given during the festival—for direction, screenplay, and performances. Veterans, young actors, and newcomers have won acting awards for their performances, both in the New Breed and Directors Showcase sections.

Cinemalaya also features different festival events like the Film Congress, which focuses on lectures and discussions on various film and filmmaking topics; Sine Taktakan, which focuses on conversations with filmmakers; exhibitions and special screenings, like tributes to National Artists; Kids Treats, featuring children’s films; book launches; and the Manila Film Financing Forum organized by the Independent Filmmakers Cooperative.

To reach a wider audience, the Cinemalaya extended its reach by simultaneously screening the festival at selected commercial mall cinemas, aside from the venues of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.  Written by Gregory del Carmen and Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

Cinemanila International Film Festival (CIFF) was founded by Filipino filmmaker Amable “Tikoy” Aguiluz VI in 1999. The festival was named after Lino Brocka’s production company, which was formed in 1974.

The festival’s goals include the revitalization of the Philippines as the center of Southeast Asian cinema and the production of international caliber Filipino films. The CIFF specifically aims to (1) nurture young Filipino directors by providing them with the opportunity to see the best of World Cinema, (2) discover new talents in the Philippines and Southeast Asia in order for the Philippines to become the hub of Southeast Asian films, and (3) create a revitalized Filipino film industry that will become a major player in the Asian content industry.

CIFF yearly gave tributes to outstanding independent filmmakers, and celebrated outstanding Filipino and foreign filmmakers. Some of its special awardees were American director Quentin Tarantino, Indonesian actor/producer Christine Hakim, Filipino-American actors Lou Diamond Phillips and Tia Carrere, and Brazilian filmmaker Fernando Meirelles.

When it opened, the festival had the following categories: International Competition, Southeast Asian Competition, Young Cinema: Documentaries, and Young Cinema: Shorts. Digital Lokal was added in 2006. The first batch of winners included Garin Nugroho’s Leaf on a Pillow (Indonesia), Grand Prize Lino Brocka Award; Santosh Sivan’s The Terrorist (India), Grand Jury Prize; Ricky Davao (Philippines), Best Actor for Saranggola (The Kite); Ana Capri (Philippines), Best Actress for Pila Balde (Fetch a Pail of Water); Mojtaba Rael’s Birth of a Butterfly (Iran), Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) Award; Carol Miu-Suiet’s Father’s Toys (Hong Kong), Best Short Film; Paul Rosdy and Joan Grossman’s The Port of Last Resort (Austria/USA), Best Documentary; and Fruto Corre’s Mountain of Waters (Philippines), Special Citation, Documentary.

For the 2006 Digital Lokal awards, the winners were Brillante Mendoza’s Manoro (The Teacher), Grand Prize; Khavn de la Cruz’s Squatterpunk, Jury Prize; Brillante Mendoza, Best Director for Manoro; Maricel Soriano, Best Actress for Numbalikdiwa (Reversion of the Soul); Archie Adamos, Best Actor for Raket ni Nanay (Mother’s Sideline); and Bobby Bonifacio Jr’s Numbalikdiwa and Briccio Santos’s Anino ng Setyembre (September’s Shadow), Audience Favorite Awards.

The Cinemanila festival icon is the bulol, which is a Cordillera rice deity that is believed to ensure good harvest. The bulol trophy was designed by National Artist Napoleon Abueva.

Due to lack of funding, the CIFF stopped in 2013, after 15 years of existence. Its future is now uncertain.  Written by Christian Co

Juanito Clemente (Juanito Bautista Clemente), also known as Nitoy Clemente, is a film sound designer. He was born in Paombong, Bulacan on 23 Jun 1930. His parents are Rafael Clemente and Veronica Bautista. He is married to Antonia Hovenia with whom he has two children. His son Emmanuel is also a sound director. He studied at Paombong Elementary School and Far Eastern University (FEU) High School. He finished two years of electrical engineering at FEU.

While still in high school, he began working at Liwayway Pictures. Starting as a joiner and projectionist in its editing department, he became printer operator, chief laboratory man, then sound production mixer. Later, he worked as production and recording mixer of Smith Sound Systems Laboratory and LVN Pictures. He served as operations manager at LVN for eight years. Clemente taught cinematography and sound engineering at the University of the Philippines College of Mass Communication. Many workers in the film industry were trained by Clemente in film sound engineering and other technical aspects of filmmaking, including Tito Arce, Jess Payumo, Elsa Abutal-Avellana, Pepe Mirador, Bening Pascual, and only son Manolet. His own company, J.B. Clemente Films, produced documentaries and short films.

Clemente set up the postproduction studios of major film production outfits, such as Liwayway Pictures, Nepomuceno Productions, Magnatech, LVN Pictures, and Regal Films. Since 1952, when he worked on his first film, Brilyanteng Putik (Mud Diamond), he was involved in some 200 movies for the local film industry including Dahil sa Isang Bulaklak (Because of a Flower) and Ang Langit sa Lupa (Heaven on Earth), 1967; Igorota (Mountain Maiden), Luha sa Karimlan (Tears in the Dark), and Manila: Open City, 1968; Where Love Has Gone, 1982; and Mumbaki (Shaman), 1996. He was also involved in several foreign films like Steel Cloth and Guerrillas in Pink Laces, made in the 1960s, and Oliver Stone’s award-winning film Platoon, 1986.

Clemente won Best Sound awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for his work in Dahil sa Isang Bulaklak and Igorota, and from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Olongapo … The Great American Dream, 1987.  Written by Rosalie Matilac, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

Joe Climaco (Jose Borja Climaco) is a film sound engineer. He was born in Zamboanga City on 22 Feb 1943. His parents are Nestor Climaco and Josefina Borja. He married Esther de los Santos, with whom he has three children. He had his early schooling at Zamboanga Normal College and Zamboanga School of Arts and Trades. He took an electronics course at FEATI University in Manila but did not finish it.

Climaco first worked at JBC Studios for a few years as a trainee in the sound department, then became a sound mixer at Premiere Productions. Later, he moved to Sampaguita Pictures and, in 1986, joined Regal Films.

Climaco did sound mixing for many movies. He specialized in creating soundtracks and albums for movie themes. He worked either as a sound supervisor or a sound engineer. He was credited for more than 200 films, among them are Barakuda (Barracuda), 1984; Nasaan Ka Nang Kailangan Kita? (Where Were You When I Needed You?), 1986; Bilangin ang Bituin sa Langit (Count the Stars in the Sky), 1989; Shake, Rattle & Roll III, 1991; The Fatima Buen Story, 1994; Sagot Kita: Mula Ulo Hanggang Paa (I Got You Covered from Head to Toe), 2000; Bagansya (Vagrancy) and Masikip Na ang Mundo Mo, Labrador (Your World Is Getting Smaller, Labrador), 2001; D’ Uragons, Tampisaw (Splash), and Bayaran (For Hire), 2002; Punla (Seed) and Alipin (Slave), 2003; Takaw-Tingin (Eye Candy), 2004; Lisensyadong Kamao (Licensed Fist) and Night Job, 2005.

He won two awards for sound: for Pahiram ng Isang Umaga (Lend Me One Morning), 1989, Film Academy of the Philippines; and Shake, Rattle & Roll II, 1990, Gawad Urian.  Written by Raquel Hernandez, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

Francisco V. Coching (Francisco Vicente Coching) is a komiks illustrator and National artist for visual arts. He was born in Buting, Pasig, Rizal on 29 Jan 1919. He died on 1 Sep 1998. He was the son of fictionist Gregorio Coching and Juana Vicente. His brother Vito is a sculptor, and another brother, Greco, is a set designer. He was married to Filomena Navales with whom he had six children, two of whom are portrait artists—Maridel and Lourdes. Francisco left school at an early age to work for the magazine Liwayway where his father was a novelist. Coching apprenticed with Tony Velasquez.

In 1934, he created his first komiks character, Bing Bigotilyo, for the magazine Silahis and the year after, Marabini or “marahas na binibini” (reckless maiden), which was abruptly ended by the onset of war. During the war years, he joined a guerrilla group, the Kamagong Unit of the Hunters-ROTC. After the war, he created Bulalakaw. However, it was Hagibis, his next work, that won him fame. Hagibis, which was inspired by Kulafu of Francisco Reyes and Tarzan of Edgar Rice Burroughs, ran for 15 years in Liwayway and was followed by sequels: Anak ni Hagibis (Son of Hagibis) and Si Gat Sibasib (Gat Sibasib). Coching’s creations were sought out by producers who made movies from them, such as Hagibis, 1947, with Fernando Poe and Erlinda Cortes; Satur, 1951, with Manuel Conde; Sabas: Ang Barbaro (Sabas: The Barbarian), 1951, with Pancho Magalona; Palasig, 1952, with Gloria Romero; Maldita (Naughty), 1953, with Rita Gomez; and Movie Fan, 1956, with Amalia Fuentes. All but five of his komiks novels were made into movies. His other well-known works are Bertong Balutan, Don Cobarde, El Ligio, Espada (Sword), Agilang Itim (Black Eagle), El Indio (The Native), Pedro Penduko, Dumagit, Lapu-Lapu, Salabusab (Greedy), Pusakal (Hardened Criminal), Ang Maton (The Tough Guy), Taga sa Bato (Cut on a Stone), Talipandas (Wayward), Vengativo (Prone to Vengeance), Thor, Pistolero (The Gunman), Dimasalang, El Vibora (The Viper), Ang Kaluluwa ni Dante (Dante’s Soul), Pagano (Pagan), Haring Ulupong (King Cobra), Bulalakaw (Shooting Star), Waldas (Spendthrift), and Contravida (Villain). Many of these appeared in Liwayway. At his peak, he was writing and illustrating three weekly serials simultaneously. Coching both wrote and illustrated his stories. His works had a strong narrative flow, brimmed with drama, and were punctuated by action and suspense. His illustrative style belonged to the romantic tradition of komiks illustration, which he dominated from 1934 to 1974, the year he retired, authoring 63 komiks novels.

His last novel, El Negro, was published in Liwayway and was turned into a film in 1974. The style was characterized by dynamic curvilinear lines and tonal modeling with a fluid, undulating effect. The leading male characters are stalwart in build, and of handsome mestizo or Malay looks, with curly hair and rippling muscles. The female leads are beautiful, graceful of build, and usually with long curly tresses. It is a style that gives life to the myths and legends of yore and to fantasies of love and adventure. Coching influenced other artists, such as Nestor Redondo, Larry Alcala, Emil Quizon-Cruz, and Emil Rodriguez, to pursue the art of komiks illustration.

An exhibit of his works opened at Nayong Pilipino in 1987. In 2001, an exhibit titled Komiks: Katha at Guhit ni Francisco V. Coching (Komiks: Stories and Drawings of Francisco V. Coching) opened at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). In 2009, another exhibit titled Francisco V. Coching: Filipino Master Komiks Artist was shown in New York and Hawaii. Coching’s restored El Indio: A Graphic Novel was published by Vibal Foundation. A dual exhibit with National Artist Carlos V. Francisco, titled Telling Modern Time: The Life and Art of Botong Francisco and Francisco Coching, opened at the National Museum also in 2009.

In 1981, he received the Makasining ng Komiks Award at the Tanging Parangal for Comics Art given by the Manila Commission of Arts and Culture. In 1984, he was given a Lifetime Achievement Award by the Komiks Operation Brotherhood Inc. Other awards include an Award for Excellence by the Pasay City government in 1998 for his contribution to the local art scene and a Gawad CCP para sa Sining for visual arts in 2008. Coching was declared National Artist for visual arts in 2014.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo and Rene B. Javellana, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

 

 

Sources

 

Flores, Patrick D., ed. 2010. The Life and Art of Francisco Coching. Quezon City: Francisco V. Coching Foundation and Vibal Foundation.

San Diego, Bayani Jr. 2006. “Kuwentong Coching.” Inquirer.net, 28 Aug. http://showbizandstyle.inquirer.net/entertainment/entertainment/view/20060828-17700/%91Kuwentong%92_Coching.

Gregorio Coching (Gregorio Cabral Coching), also known as Gat Kalingkingan, was a fictionist. He was born in Buting, Pasig on 13 May 1892. He died in Pasig on 18 Oct 1961. He was the son of Juan Coching and Andrea Cabral. The name Coching originated from his ancestor’s original province, Kuching, located in North Borneo. He married twice: first, to Juana Vicente, with whom he had five children; second, to Sixta Cagalingan, who bore him a son. Three sons are artists: Vito is a sculptor, Greco is a set designer, and Francisco was a well-known komiks illustrator and is a National Artist for visual arts. Coching received his early education from his relatives in Tondo, in a school called La Juventud, where he learned Spanish and Latin. At an early age, he became interested in metrical romances; he memorized Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura) and read Don Juan Teñoso and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird). After his father’s death, his mother moved the family to Pasay. Young Gregorio helped his mother earn a living by selling newspapers in the streets. They must have undergone very hard times, for at 15 he attempted to commit suicide. However, as he was making ready to plunge himself into a deep well, he saw miraculously carved on a guava branch a ladle which was his own handiwork and which he had left at home. From then on, he saw poverty in another light as he began using his hands to make engravings. That incident, in later years, would influence most of his novels.

His first attempt at writing began in 1925 when he joined a novel writing contest sponsored by Liwayway. His entry Sanggumay won first prize and 200 pesos. The novel, published in 1933, centers on Loleng, a once wealthy woman now impoverished, driven to prostitution to support and save a sick father.

His other novels include Baliya, which recounts the unsuccessful courtship of a woman by a Chinese; Nita Ravensky, about a Filipino adventurer who goes abroad and marries a princess; Okami San, about a Japanese woman who falls in love with a Filipino at much sacrifice; and Dalagang Pangit (Ugly Maiden), 1933, the love story of an ugly woman with a shapely body. Those that appeared serially in Liwayway, for which he received 25 pesos per installment, include Dama de Noche (Woman of the Night), about a bailarina (dancer) and a newspaperman; Nanay Ko (My Mother), the heartbreaking tale of a daughter unrecognized by her mother; and a translation of John Milton’s Paradise Lost (Ang Naglahong Paraiso). Two of his novels were filmed, Teniente Rosario (Lieutenant Rosario) and Ilaw ng Langit (Light of Heaven). He also wrote Babae ng Bayan (Everybody’s Woman), Batang Tulisan (Young Bandit), Gagamba (Spider), Kathlea, Kidlat ng Silangan (Lightning of the East), Mga Anak ng Kadiliman (Children of Darkness), Pag-ibig at Paghihiganti (Love and Revenge), Puso ng Diyos (Heart of God), Sa Impierno ng Ating Lahi (In the Hell of Our Race), Sa Langit ng Ating Lahi (In the Heaven of Our Race), Tatlong Pagkabirhen (Three Virginities), and Ulupong (Viper).

From 1927 onward, he was part of the Liwayway staff. In 1945, he joined the staff of Silahis, publishing his novels Mutya ng Mutya (Gem of Gems) and Pamanang Binhi (Heirloom Seedlings). He also wrote for Bulaklak.   Written by E. Arsenio Manuel

Gabby Concepcion (Gabriel Arellano Concepcion), also known as Gabo, is a film and television actor. He was born in Manila on 5 Nov 1963. His parents are Maria Lourdes Arellano and Rolando Concepcion. His great-grandfather is architect Juan Arellano. He had his elementary schooling at Ateneo de Manila, finished high school at Aquinas School, and took up a bachelor’s course in advertising at Maryknoll College (now Miriam College). He and estranged wife, actor-singer, Sharon Cuneta, have a daughter, actor KC (Kristina Cassandra) Concepcion.

After a stint as an advertising model, Concepcion appeared with Dina Bonnevie in Katorse (Fourteen), 1980, a Regal film. Throughout the 80s, Concepcion was a sought-after matinee idol and heartthrob, initially starring in teeny-bopper movies, and then graduating to more mature roles. His team-up with Sharon Cuneta brought him much success, as attested by a string of blockbuster films they did together, like Dear Heart, P.S. I Love You, and My Only Love, 1981; Dapat Ka Bang Mahalin? (Should You Be Loved?) and Sa Hirap at Ginhawa (In Bad Times and Good Times), 1984; and Pati Ba Pintig ng Puso? (And the Heartbeat, Too?), 1985. Their marriage, though short-lived, was a much celebrated showbiz affair. In 1990, years after their separation, they were reunited in Bakit Ikaw Pa Rin? (Why Still You?), a box-office hit. Concepcion's other notable films are Pinulot Ka Lang sa Lupa (You Were Merely Picked from the Ground), 1987; Pahiram ng Isang Umaga (Lend Me One Morning) and Hahamakin Lahat (All Be Damned), 1989; and Makiusap Ka sa Diyos (Plead with God), Una Kang Naging Akin (You Were Mine First), and Kislap sa Dilim (Spark in the Dark), 1991.

In 1994, Concepcion got involved in a scandal after his then talent manager, Lolit Solis, admitted to rigging the results of the Manila Film Festival in order to make Concepcion and beauty queen-actor Ruffa Gutierrez win the top acting trophies for their movie, Loretta. The scandal severely affected Concepcion's showbiz career and he was later forced to migrate to the United States where he stayed for more than a decade.

In 2009, Concepcion made a successful showbiz comeback via the romantic drama I Love You, Goodbye, a Star Cinema production, where he was cast alongside Angelica Panganiban, Derek Ramsey, and Kim Chiu. He was also seen in I'll Be There, 2010, where he acted opposite his daughter, KC; Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow, 2011; When the Love is Gone and A Moment in Time, 2013; Diary ng Panget (Diary of the Ugly), 2014; and Crazy Beautiful You and Felix Manalo, 2015. 

Concepcion’s later television series include TV5's remake of P.S. I Love You, 2011; ABS-CBN's Kahit Puso'y Masugatan (Even if the Heart Gets Wounded), 2012, and Bukas Na Lang Kita Mamahalin (I Will Love You Tomorrow), 2013; TV5's Cassandra: Warrior Angel, 2013; and GMA Network's Dyesebel, 2014.

As a singer, Concepcion has albums recorded under Warner Music Philippines. His 2009 album is self-titled and his second album is called Unforgettable, 2010.

Concepcion received Best Supporting Actor awards for Makiusap Ka sa Diyos from the Gawad Urian in 1992 and for Sinungaling Mong Puso (Your Lying Heart) from the PMPC Star Awards for Movies and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 1993. He won Best Actor awards for Narito ang Puso Ko (Here Is My Heart) in the 1993 Gawad Urian and for I Love You, Goodbye in 2010 from the FAMAS.  Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor and Elmer L. Gatchalian

Rudy Concepcion (Joaquin Concepcion) was a film actor. He was born in Manila in 1912. He died in 1940. He studied at Mapua High School, Manila. Known as the “Idolong Kayumanggi” (Brown Idol), Concepcion’s team-up with actor Rosario Moreno was well acclaimed by the public in movies like Mapait na Lihim (Bitter Secret), 1938; Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), 1939; and Pakiusap (Plea), 1940.

With actor Elsa Oria, he appeared in Paroparong Bukid (Country Butterfly), 1938, and Ikaw Rin (You, Too), 1940; and with Yolanda Marquez in Gabay ng Magulang (Parent’s Guidance), 1939. He was shooting Mahal Pa Rin Kita (I Still Love You), 1940, when he succumbed to peptic ulcer. A Japanese newsreel cameraman recorded his funeral when vast throngs of crowds attended to pay their last respects to their matinee idol. It is preserved in the film archives in Tokyo, Japan. In 1952, a biopic based on Concepcion's life, Ang Kasaysayan ni Rudy (Rudy's Life Story), was released by Sampaguita Pictures. Directed by Octavio Silos, it starred Pancho Magalona (as Concepcion) and Linda Estrella.  Written by Nenuca Jose

Carmen Concha, also known as Ciciel, was a film director, producer, screenwriter, and costume designer. She was born on 28 Oct 1902. She married Guillermo Romillo. She is the aunt of singer Irma Ponce-Enrile Potenciano and singer-movie actor and producer Armida Ponce-Enrile Siguion-Reyna.

Concha is one of the pioneer producers of the silent pictures era. Oriental Blood, 1930, the film featuring balagtasan (poetic joust) king Jose Corazon de Jesus and directed by Carlos Vander Tolosa, was made by Carmen Concha Productions. In this movie, Concha personally designed the Moro costumes of the cast, which included three leading ladies: Atang de la Rama, Purita Clariño, and Annie Harris.

When the talking picture came to the Philippine movies, Concha turned movie director. Among the films she directed, based on her own stories and screenplays, were Nagkaisang Landas (Paths That Met), 1939, starring Rogelio de la Rosa, Reynaldo Dante, and Virginia Oteyza; Yaman ng Mahirap (Wealth of the Poor), 1939, one of the earliest films that depicted the slaying of a worker during a factory strike; and Pangarap (Dream), 1940, an LVN picture starring Angel Esmeralda, Purita Santamaria, Tita Duran, and Hermogenes Ilagan. When World War II broke out in 1941 she was under government contract for the making of documentary films supervised by then senator Camilo Osias.

Concha was the costume designer of the Ateneo de Manila stage plays for more than two decades. After the war, she concentrated on writing and costume design. As Carmen Romillo, she authored a novel, Aklat ng Buhay (Book of Life), serialized in Bulaklak Magazine, which became a popular radio show and was made into an LVN movie in 1952 by director Lamberto V. Avellana. She also designed the costumes for fantasy films of Sampaguita Pictures and LVN Pictures, such as Principe Amante (Prince Amante), 1950; and Ang Prinsesa at ang Pulubi (The Princess and the Pauper), Tres Muskiteros (Three Musketeers), and Bernardo Carpio, 1952.  Written by Lena S. Pareja

Freddie Conde (Freddie Nolasco Conde) is a cinematographer. He was born in Antipolo, Rizal on 22 May 1927. The son of Vicente Conde and Socorro Nolasco, he studied commerce for two years at Bohol Colleges. He married Evangeline Sangkula with whom he has six children. Actor Lotis Key is his niece.

He entered the movie industry in 1947, working first as a gripman for Nolasco Bros. Pictures, then as sound recordist from 1949 to 1959. He became assistant cameraman at Premiere Productions from 1959 to 1962 and second unit cameraman for Emar Productions in 1962. From 1970 until the 1980s, he worked as director of photography for several American-produced films, like Hit Woman, Hayop (Animal), Twilight People, Big Doll House, The Deathhead Virgin, and the local film Kumander Alibasbas (Commander Alibasbas), 1981, directed by Augusto Buenaventura. He was a cameraman in Francis Ford Coppola’s Apocalypse Now, 1979, which was shot entirely in the Philippines. He was the camera operator for the movies Missing in Action, 1984, starring Chuck Norris, and P.O.W. The Escape, 1986, starring David Carradine. He did the second-unit photography for American Ninja, 1985, starring Michael Dudikoff. 

Conde received two awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Best Cinematography: for Psycho Sex Killer, 1970, and Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), 1977. He was nominated by the Film Academy of the Philippines for Pedring Taruc, 1982; Machunurin (Submissive One), 1983; and Bangkang Papel sa Dagat ng Apoy (Paper Boat on a Sea of Fire), 1984.  Written by Raquel Hernandez

Manuel Conde (Manuel Pabustan Urbano), also known as Manoling, was a film director, producer, actor, and cinematographer. He is a National Artist for film. He was born in Daet, Camarines Sur on 9 Oct 1915. He died in Manila on 11 Aug 1985. His parents are Dionisio Urbano and Lucia Pabustan. He married Julita Salazar, with whom he had seven children. Jun Urbano, who portrayed “Mr Shooli” in Mongolian Barbecue, is his eldest son. He studied geology at Adamson University, Manila, and worked for Marsman and Company, a mining firm.

In 1935, Conde got a bit part in Filippine Films’s Mahiwagang Biyolin (Mysterious Violin). He did odd jobs in between, then became assistant to director Carlos Vander Tolosa in LVN Pictures’s initial offering Giliw Ko (My Beloved), 1939. When Tolosa failed to complete his second film, Sawing Gantimpala (Lost Victory), 1940, Conde was asked to finish it. Among his other early directorial works for LVN Studios are Maginoong Takas (Gentleman Escapee), 1940; Binatillo (Young Man), Villa Hermosa, Ararong Ginto (Golden Plow), Caviteño (Man from Cavite), Hiyas ng Dagat (Gem of the Sea), and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941; and Prinsipe Teñoso (Prince Teñoso), 1942.

During the war, Conde directed stage shows like Kayumanggi (Brown), Timbangang Bakal (Scale of Steel), and Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng) at the Dalisay Theater. It was then that he met Carlos “Botong” Francisco who designed the sets for his shows while working as an artist in Conde’s Kiko Art shop.

After the war, he directed for LVN the films Orasang Ginto (Golden Clock), Alaala Kita (Thinking of You), Principeng Hindi Tumatawa (The Prince Who Does Not Laugh), and Nabasag ang Banga (The Claypot Broke), 1946; Doon Po sa Amin (In Our Town), 1947; and Apat na Alas (Four Aces), 1950.

In 1947, without cutting his ties with LVN, he set up the Manuel Conde Productions, which produced films like Vende Kristo (Christ for Sale), 1948; Prinsipe Paris (Prince Paris), 1949; Siete Infantes de Lara (Seven Devils) and Genghis Khan, 1950; Krus na Kawayan (Bamboo Cross), 1956; and later, Molave, 1961, a movie that called for the conservation of our natural resources. In 1951, he directed and starred in Sigfredo for Lebran Productions.

In 1951, Conde went to Hollywood, bringing with him a copy of Genghis Khan. Film critic James Agee liked what he saw and reedited it, and this version Conde brought to the 1952 Venice Film Festival where it was critically acclaimed. The movie was shown in Edinburgh Film Festival the following year and became the first Filipino film distributed worldwide by United Artists (UA). Sigfredo and Siete Infantes de Lara were also bought and distributed by UA.

After returning to LVN, Conde directed Señorito (Spoiled Brat), 1953; Pilipino Kostum, No Touch (Filipino Custom, No Touching) and Ikaw Kasi (You Are to Blame), 1955; Handang Matodas (Ready to Die) and Bahala Na (Come What May), 1956; and Tingnan Natin (We’ll See), El Robo (The Robbery), and Basta Ikaw (As Long as It’s You), 1957; Casa Grande (Mansion) and Venganza (Revenge), 1958; and Bayanihan (Community Spirit), 1959.

Conde, however, is best remembered for his Juan Tamad series, which he starred in and directed, and most of which were produced by his own outfit. The series, a critique of the social foibles and cultural values of Filipinos, include Si Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), 1947; Juan Daldal: Anak ni Juan Tamad (Chatterbox Juan: Son of Lazy Juan), 1947; Juan Tamad Goes to Congress, 1959; Juan Tamad Goes to Society, 1960; and Si Juan Tamad at Juan Masipag sa Pulitikang Walang Hanggan (Lazy Juan and Industrious Juan in Never-Ending Politics), 1963. In the Juan Tamad films, as well as in Genghis Khan, Sigfredo, and Siete Infantes de Lara, Manuel Conde collaborated with his best friend Carlos Francisco who was art director for these films, and his own wife, Julita, who executed most of the costumes designed by Botong.

In 1978, he received the Natatanging Gawad Urian from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino for his outstanding contributions to the movie industry. In 2006, former president Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo presented the Presidential Medal of Merit (for films) to his family to commemorate his contribution to Philippine arts. In 2007, he was posthumously awarded the Lamberto Avellana Memorial Award by the Film Academy of the Philippines. In 2008, Nicanor G. Tiongson’s study of Conde’s life and works, titled The Cinema of Manuel Conde, was published. In the same year, he received the Gawad CCP para sa Sining for film. In 2009, Conde was posthumously proclaimed National Artist for film.  Written by Joy Galvez, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

F. H. Constantino (Feliciano H. Constantino), also known as Felicing Constantino or Fely Constantino, was a film director, screenwriter, and actor. He was born on 15 Jun 1917. He died on 28 Aug 1981.  In the 1950s, when the entry of television threatened the movies as the most popular form of mass entertainment, Constantino kept the public going to the cinema houses with his comic films that always integrated song, dance, and the escapades of the common folk and country bumpkins. He was, in fact, partly responsible for the galawgaw (wacky) and tomboy image of Nida Blanca whose pairing with Nestor de Villa was well loved by the moviegoing public. Some of his films include Hijo de Familia (Son of the Family), 1953; Batangueña (Batangas Girl), 1953; Waray-Waray (Visayan Lass), 1954; Galawgaw (Wacky), 1954; Niña Bonita (Pretty Girl), 1955, Charito Solis’s first film; Talusaling (Oversensitive), 1955; Handang Matodas (Ready to Die), 1956; Medalyong Perlas (Pearl Medallion), 1956; and Sebya, Mahal Kita (Sebya, I Love You), 1957. He acted in the movies Gitano, 1949, and Edong Mapangarap (Edong The Dreamer), 1950. 

After LVN Pictures stopped production, Constantino directed films for other studios, among them Laff Story, 1971, Si Waray at ang Talyada (Waray and the Gay), 1971, Sosayting Batangueña (Society Girl from Batangas), 1971, The Prince and I, 1971, Ayos Lang Pare Ko (It’s Okay, My Friend), 1972, Asiong Aksaya (Wasteful Asiong), 1977, Dash a Lotsa Nonsents! (That’s a Lot of Nonsense!), 1978, and Mang Kepweng (Old Man Kepweng), 1979.

From the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, Constantino received Best Screenplay and Best Director nominations for Oy, Akin Yata Yan (Hey, I Think That’s Mine), 1962, and Best Director nomination for Naku, Yabang! (What a Braggart!), 1963.  Written by Ramon Jocson and Marlon Wui

Erlinda Cortes (Mary Boone) was a film, radio, and stage actor. She was born in San Pablo, Laguna on 5 Jan 1924. She died in Vermont, USA on 8 Sep 2015. The daughter of John Boone, a Belgian-born engineer, and a Filipina mother, she studied high school in Tacloban, Leyte. When World War II broke out, she became an undercover agent for the Civilian Intelligence Corps of the United States Army. After the war, she worked as a receptionist in a radio station, then joined an entertainment troupe that toured military camps in the country.

Cortes took up courses in movie techniques and radio-TV methods in New York in 1954. She displayed an equal facility in all these media. Her DZRH radio program Kasaysayang Panghapon ng Lux (Afternoon Stories from Lux) with Rogelio de la Rosa was among the most popular during the time.

She was introduced in Tagumpay (Victory), 1946, the second film made by LVN Pictures after the war. This was followed by Angelus, 1946, also by LVN. After a few more films, including Principeng Hindi Tumatawa (The Prince Who Does Not Laugh), 1946, and Backpay, 1947, she freelanced. Among her movies are The End of the Road, 1947, an all-English picture produced by the Ateneo Alumni Association and directed by Lamberto V. Avellana; He Promised to Return, 1950, with Hollywood actor Robert Neil; Sigfredo, 1951, with Manuel Conde; Tinig ng Tagumpay (Voice of Victory), 1953, a Lebran film starring tenor Don David; and Romeo at Julieta (Romeo and Juliet), 1951, where she played Juliet to Oscar Moreno’s Romeo.

She was nominated Best Actress by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences twice in 1953 for May Isang Tsuper ng Taxi (There Was a Taxi Driver) and Ang Bagong Maestra (The New Teacher).  Written by Danny Villanueva, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

Rez Cortez (Restituto Septimo Cortez Jr) is a film and television actor, and a dancer. He was born in Camarines Sur on 4 Jan 1956. He is the son of Restituto Cortez and Lydia Septimo. He took up electronics and communications engineering at the University of the East. He is married to Ma. Carmen “Candy” Aenlle. They have four children, one of whom is actor Cai Cortez. Rez Cortez served as president of the Actors Guild of the Philippines, member of the Board of Trustees of the Movie Workers Welfare Foundation Inc (Mowelfund) and the Cinema Committee of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

Before Cortez entered show business, he was a member of Alice Reyes’s CCP Dance Company. He got his first break in the movie Daigdig ng Sindak at Lagim (World of Fright and Terror), 1974, produced by MVN Cinema. It was immediately followed by Bakit May Bilanggo sa Anak ni Eba? (Why Is There a Prisoner among Eve’s Children?), 1973, also by the same production company. After being cast in small roles, Cortez was chosen to be part of Lino Brocka’s film Insiang, 1976, as the opportunistic boyfriend of Insiang played by Hilda Koronel. The film was shown at the prestigious Cannes Film Festival. It was chosen as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1970-79 by the Gawad Urian in 1981. Cortez played more roles in Brocka’s films—namely, Angela Markado (Angela the Marked One), 1980; Kontrobersyal (Controversial), 1981; Palipat-lipat, Papalit-Palit (Changing Partners), 1982; Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim (My Country: Gripping the Knife's Edge), 1984; and Kislap sa Dilim (Spark in the Dark), 1991. Although he is remembered for his villain roles, he also did comedy films like Annie Batungbakal, 1979, Bongga Ka 'Day (You're Fabulous, Pal), 1980, and Ibalik ang Swerti (Bring Back the Fortune), 1981.

For GMA Network, Cortez appeared in the following drama series: Captain Barbell, 2006; Joaquin Bordado, 2008; Time of My Life, 2011; Temptation of Wife, 2012; Villa Quintana, 2013; and Beautiful Strangers, 2015. For TV5, he had a recurring role in the comedy series Kapitan Awesome (Captain Awesome) and the drama series Valiente, 2012, and Trenderas (Trending Salesgirls), 2014. He was also a cast member of ABS-CBN's drama series Esperanza, 2005, Eva Fonda, 2009, and Dream Dad, 2014, and was a featured guest in several episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 1991-2015.

Cortez also appeared in some independent films, including Ang Anak ni Brocka (Brocka's Child), 2004; Saan Nagtatago si Happiness? (Where Does Happiness Hide?), 2006; I-Libings, 2011; REquieme! (Requiem), 2012; and Hari ng Tondo (Where I Am King), 2014. He received a Best Supporting Actor nomination from the Film Academy of the Philippines for playing the object of affection of Eddie Garcia's character in Jun Robles Lana's internationally acclaimed film, Bwakaw, 2012.  Written by Kathrina Alvarez, updated by Elmer L. Gatchalian

Fely Crisostomo (Felicisimo Crisostomo), also known as Felicing Crisostomo, was a film director and editor. He was born in Manila on 11 May 1914. He died in Manila on 2 Jul 1980. He and wife Dolores Crisostomo have four children. He finished elementary at Pandacan Elementary School. He worked as a projectionist at Savoy and Columbia theaters, Manila, and in Camp John Hay, Baguio; and as a still photographer for Manila Talkatone where he trained in laboratory and editing work. He eventually set up his own photo studio.

Crisostomo was film editor for various film outfits. He edited films like May Hangganan ang Pag-ibig (Love Has Limits), 1970; Malupit na Tadhana (Cruel Fate) and Liezl at ang Seven Hoods (Liezl and the Seven Hoods), 1971; Huwag Mong Kunin ang Lahat sa Akin (Do Not Take Everything from Me), 1976; and Mapupulang Labi (Red Lips), 1977.

His first directorial job was Tatlong Baraha (Three Playing Cards), 1961. He was the mainstay director of actor Amalia Fuentes’s AM Productions, directing movies that starred Fuentes herself. He also directed Butsoy, 1978, and Kakampi Ko ang Santo Niño (The Holy Infant Is on My Side), 1979.

He received the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Editing award for Hanggang sa Dulo ng Daigdig (To the Ends of the Earth), 1958, and Iginuhit sa Buhangin (Written on the Sand), 1965. In 1967 he won the FAMAS Best Director award for Kapag Puso’y Sinugatan (When the Heart Is Wounded).  Written by Lena S. Pareja

Ely Cruz (Eladio Ramos Cruz) is a cinematographer. He was born in Taguig, Rizal on 18 Feb 1948. His parents are Victoria Ramos and Crisanto Cruz, a farmer-fisher. He studied at Taguig Elementary School, Taguig Institute, and Arellano University where he took up two years of commerce. He was married to Delia Manlapaz by whom he has four children. He and second wife Lavinia Reyes have one child.

While working as a visual artist at IBC 13, he pinch-hit as a cameraman for the news department at one time. The station noted his natural abilities, so he was trained to become a cameraman for news and documentaries. He became the station’s chief cameraman and director for a series titled Vigilantes. In 1975, he worked as chief cameraman for the Metro Manila Commission’s TV program Metro Magazine. Sound engineer Juanito Clemente recommended him to director Mike de Leon for the latter’s experimental short film Monologo (Monologue), 1975. This assignment started him off as a full-fledged cinematographer. De Leon took him again for his first directorial assignment, Itim (The Rites of May), 1976.

Other more recent works that earned Cruz several nominations from various award-giving bodies are Pare Ko (Hey Dude) and Eskapo: The Sergio Osmeña–Geny Lopez Story (Fugitive), 1995; Istokwa (Stow Away), 1996; Babae sa Bintana (Woman by the Window), 1998; Lagarista (The Film Biker), 2000; Tatarin (St John’s Day Ritual), 2001; Mga Munting Tinig (Small Voices), 2002; Lastikman (Plastic Man), 2003; Enteng Kabisote 2: Okay Ka Fairy Ko … The Legend Continues (Enteng Kabisote 2: You’re Okay, My Fairy... The Legend Continues), 2005; and Enteng Kabisote 3: Okay Ka Fairy Ko … The Legend Goes On and On and On, 2006.

Cruz received Best Cinematography awards for Itim from both the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences and the Gawad Urian; ’Merika (America), 1984, from the PMPC Star Awards; Scorpio Nights, 1985, from the Gawad Urian; Kapag Napagod ang Puso (When the Heart Tires), 1988, and Shake, Rattle & Roll II, 1990, from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF); and Panaghoy sa Suba (The Call of the River), 2004, from the Film Academy of the Philippines, the Gawad Urian, and the MMFF.  Written by Rosalie Matilac, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

John Lloyd Cruz (John Lloyd Espidol Cruz), also known as Lloydie, is a film and television actor. He was born in Manila on 24 Jun 1983. He is the son of Luisito Llora Cruz, a businessman, and Aida Espidol. In 1995, he finished grade school at Marikina Catholic School. At age 14, he became part of ABS-CBN Star Magic’s Star Circle Batch 5.

His first appearances on television were in the crime-investigative show Calvento Files and in the situational comedy show Palibhasa Lalake (Because They Are Guys), 1997. After several cameo appearances, he had supporting roles in the teen-oriented show Gimik (Gimmick), 1998, and Sa Sandaling Kailangan Mo Ako (The Moment You Need Me), 1998. He was given his first major role in the youth-oriented show Tabing Ilog (Riverside), 1999. Cruz, along with Bea Alonzo became a part of the following drama series: Kay Tagal Kang Hinintay (So Long Have I Waited for You) and It Might Be You, 2003; Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin (You’re Everything to Me), 2005; Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), 2006; Maging Sino Ka Man: Ang Pagbabalik (Whoever You May Be: The Return) and I Love Betty La Fea, 2008; and A Beautiful Affair, 2012. Deviating from drama, he had a major role in the fantasy-oriented show Imortal (Immortal), 2010, with Angel Locsin. In 2014, he led the cast of the situational comedy show Home Sweetie Home, along with Toni Gonzaga. Some of his notable films were with Bea Alonzo: My First Romance, 2003; Now That I Have You, 2004; Close to You and All About Love, 2006; One More Chance, 2007; Miss You Like Crazy, 2010; The Mistress, 2012; and A Second Chance, 2015. His tandem with Sarah Geronimo was also notable in the success of the trilogy films A Very Special Love, 2008; You Changed My Life, 2009; and It Takes a Man and a Woman, 2013. Cruz also starred in Unofficially Yours, 2012, with Angel Locsin, and in Erik Matti’s Honor Thy Father, 2015.

He received Best Supporting Actor trophies for Dubai, 2005, from the PMPC Star Awards for Movies, the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, and Maria Clara Awards in 2006. He received the title Box-Office King several times from the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Scholarship Foundation for the films One More Chance, A Very Special Love, You Changed My Life, The Mistress, and In My Life (the last alongside Luis Manzano), 2009. Cruz has a string of awards and nominations for television as well. Some of the most notable awards were from the PMPC Star Awards for Television as Best Drama Actor for Tabing Ilog, It Might Be You, and Maging Sino Ka Man. In 2016 he won the Best Actor award from the Gawad Urian for his role in Honor Thy Father.  Written by Gregory del Carmen

Rodell Cruz was a film and television production designer and art director. He was born in San Fernando, Pampanga on 18 Apr 1959. He died in Quezon City on 19 May 2018. He finished his studies at the University of Santo Tomas Faculty of Engineering. He was married to Catalina Villaluna with whom he had a son, Miguel. His earliest work as production designer for film was for Peque Gallaga’s Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982; followed by Misteryo sa Tuwa (Joyful Mystery), 1983; the TV movie Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1992; Magic Temple, 1996; Sa Huling Paghihintay (The Final Wait), 2001; Dos Ekis (Two X’s), 2001; Ang Agimat: Anting-Anting ni Lolo (The Talisman: Grandfather’s Amulet), 2002; Mano Po 2: My Home (I Kiss Your Hand 2: My Home), 2002; Mano Po III: My Love (I Kiss Your Hand 3: My Love), 2004; Resiklo (Recycle), 2007; and Mana (Inheritance), 2014.

Cruz has also worked for American films shot in multiple locations like the United States, Hong Kong, and the Philippines. He worked on the production design of films such as Hong Kong 97, 1994; Spitfire, 1995; Heatseeker, 1995; Soldier Boyz, 1995; and the Philippine-American war film Amigo, 2011, directed by Academy-Award nominee John Sayles. He was also the art director for Behind Enemy Lines, 1985; Platoon, 1987; Braddock: Missing in Action III, 1988; Born on the Fourth of July, 1989; A Dangerous Life, 1989; and Delta Force 2: The Colombian Connection, 1989.

As production designer for TV, he is known for his work on several TV series on GMA Network such as Encantadia, 2005; Etheria, 2006; Atlantika, 2006; Captain Barbell, 2007; Lupin, 2007; Marimar, 2008; Kamandag (Venom), 2008; Zaido, 2008; Dyesebel, 2008; Survivor Philippines, 2008-10; Zorro, 2009; Amaya, 2011; and Indio, 2013. He has also worked on the production design of TV commercials for corporate institutions such as Cosmos Bottling Philippines, Unilever Philippines, Pilipinas Shell, Smart Communications, PLDT Company, and San Miguel Corporation, among others.

His awards include three Gawad Urian for Best Production Design for Oro, Plata, Mata, Misteryo sa Tuwa, and Amigo; three Film Academy of the Philippines awards for Best Production Design for Oro, Plata, Mata, Mano Po 2: My Home, and Resiklo; four Metro Manila Film Festival Best Production Design awards for Magic Temple, Mano Po 2: My Home, Mano Po III: My Love, and Resiklo; a PMPC Star Award for Production Designer of the Year for Mano Po 2: My Home; a Best Production Design award for Resiklo from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences; and Best Production Design award for Mana at the 2015 Madrid International Film Festival.  Written by Jhoanne Kristine Vinuya

Tirso Cruz III (Tirso Silvano Cruz III), also known as Pip, is a film and television actor, and singer. He was born in Manila on 1 Apr 1952. His parents are Tirso Cruz II and Elma Silvano. He was educated at Trinity College, Quezon City, where he took courses in commerce. He is married to actor Lyn Ynchausti with whom he has three children. His son Bodie and daughter Djanin are also actors. Cruz belongs to a clan of musicians and show business personalities. Actor Ricky Belmonte is a cousin. Actor Sheryl Cruz and singers Geneva Cruz and Donna Cruz are also nieces. Grandfather Tirso Cruz was the bandleader of Manila Hotel fame. An uncle, Carding Cruz, was also a bandleader and movie musical director.

In the late 1960s and throughout the 70s, Cruz was a matinee idol who partnered with Nora Aunor in the phenomenal love team Guy and Pip. He first appeared in a musical called Bang-Shang-a-Lang, 1967, and then starred in D’ Musical Teenage Idols, 1969. With Aunor, he did such movies as Young Love and Young at Heart, 1970; Guy and Pip and My Blue Hawaii, 1971; Nora, Mahal Kita (Nora, I Love You) and A Gift of Love, 1972. After a brief respite, he became more active in the mid-1970s, appearing in movies like Markadong Anghel (Marked Angel) and Magandang Gabi sa Inyong Lahat (Good Evening Everyone), 1976; Magdalena de la Paz and Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), 1977; and Mahal Mo, Mahal Ko (Your Love, My Love) and Pinagbuklod ng Pag-ibig (Bound by Love), 1978.

The Guy and Pip tandem had a brief revival in the 80s in movies like Till We Meet Again, Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), and I Can’t Stop Loving You, 1985, and Bilangin ang Bituin sa Langit (Count the Stars in the Sky), 1989, a critically acclaimed melodrama where he and Aunor played the older and younger versions of their respective characters. Throughout the 90s, Cruz became a perennial villain in action movies. But his more notable performance during this period was in the dramatic movie Inagaw Mo ang Lahat sa Akin, 1995, where he played the role of Maricel Soriano's forgiving husband. Cruz's other movies include Mano Po (I Kiss Your Hand), 2002; Minsan Pa (One Moment More), 2004; In My Life, 2009; No Other Woman, 2011; Bride for Rent, 2014; and Etiquette for Mistresses and Honor Thy Father, 2015.

His television appearances include TV5’s Valiente, 2012, a remake of the series with the same title which first aired in ABS-CBN and then in GMA Network, and in which he had also appeared, albeit in a different role; and GMA Network’s Sana ay Ikaw Na Nga (I Hope You're the One), 2002, Etheria, 2005, I Luv NY, 2006, Kaputol ng Isang Awit (Unsung Melody), 2008, Paano Nga Ba ang Mangarap? (Without Your Love), 2009, Endless Love, 2010, and I Heart You Pare (I Love You, Male Buddy), 2011. He also starred in ABS-CBN’s It Might Be You, 2003; 100 Days to Heaven, 2011; Budoy, 2011-12; Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw (You’re the One I Need) and Huwag Ka Lang Mawawala (Just Don't Disappear), 2013; and Hawak-Kamay (Holding Hands), 2014. He had numerous guest appearances in Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) and Wansapanataym (Once Upon a Time). 

Cruz was voted Most Promising Male Singer, 1970, by the Awit Awards. As an actor, he was Box Office King of the Philippine Movies, 1971; Best Supporting Actor, 1st Quezon City Film Festival, for For You, Mama, 1970; Best Actor, 3rd Quezon City Film Festival for And God Smiled at Me, 1972; and Best Actor, Film Academy of the Philippines, Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, and PMPC Star Awards for Movies for Bilangin ang Bituin sa Langit. He was chosen Gawad Urian Best Supporting Actor for Kahit Buhay Ko (Even My Own Life), 1992. For his performance in Sigwa (Rage), 2010, he won a Balanghai trophy for Best Supporting Actor at the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival and a Best Actor award from the PMPC Star Awards for Movies. Cruz was a recipient of a Dekada Award at the 10th Golden Screen Awards in 2013.  Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Erika Carreon, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu and Elmer L. Gatchalian

Ernani Cuenco (Ernani Joson Cuenco Sr) was a music composer, teacher, and a National Artist for music. He was born in Malolos, Bulacan on 10 May 1936. He died in Mandaluyong, Metro Manila on 11 Jun 1988. The son of Felix Cuenco and Maria Joson, he was married to Magdalena Marcial, also a musician, with whom he had two children. His son, Ernani Jr aka Jong, is also a musician and a film and television actor. Cuenco started taking piano and violin lessons at six. While in high school at the University of Santo Tomas (UST), he took up piano with Julio Esteban Anguita, and violin with Ramon Mendoza at the UST Conservatory of Music. He completed a music degree in piano and cello from the UST and a master’s degree in music education from Santa Isabel College.

A seasoned performer, Cuenco played with the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra and the Manila Symphony Orchestra from 1960 to 1968, and the Manila Chamber Soloists from 1966 to 1970 organized by Oscar C. Yatco and Basilio C. Manalo. In 1983 and 1987, he toured the United States with other Filipino performers and artists including the Kayumangging Kaligatan, a choral group he founded in 1982.

Cuenco was at one time or another on the faculty of the music departments of several major schools and colleges in Manila including the UST Conservatory of Music, where he taught for decades. He also helped initiate the annual Sampung Daliri (Ten Fingers) concert of the UST Conservatory of Music, featuring their piano faculty, alumni, and students.

He wrote award-winning musical scores for Filipino films. His first commission came in the early 1960s, for movie producer Joseph Estrada. For the next two decades, he continued scoring for numerous films and writing some of the most memorable songs, often in collaboration with lyricist Levi Celerio. His works include Diligin Mo ng Hamog ang Uhaw na Lupa (Sprinkle Dew on the Parched Land), 1975, and Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), 1977, both awardees of the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Best Musical Score; "Bato sa Buhangin" (Stone in the Sand), 1976, FAMAS Awardee for Best Theme Song, 1976; Ang Babaing Pinagtaksilan ng Panahon (A Woman Betrayed by Time), Gawad Urian for Best Music, 1980; and Pedrong Taruc,1982, and Isang Bala Ka Lang (You’re Only Worth a Bullet), 1983, Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) awardees for Best Musical Score. His greatest hit, “Gaano Ko Ikaw Kamahal” (How Much Do I Love You), 1979, shows how Cuenco enriched the Filipino love ballad by infusing it with elements of the classic kundiman. His song “Kahit na Magtiis” (As I Endure) with words by Joseph Ejercito Estrada became a hit when the latter assumed the Philippine presidency in 1998. Its revival by the Philippine Madrigal Singers with an arrangement by Christopher Borela lent prestige to the composition, and was included in the choir’s live concert recording of their international tour of 2000, titled Around the World in 2001. Another recent recording of his music is Renato Lucas and Raul Sunico’s rendition of his love song, “Nahan” (Where?) in the album Romanza, released by Tawid Publications in 2004.

Cuenco was posthumously conferred the CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts, and the National Artist award in 1999.   Written by Julie Ann Hallazgo, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) is the leading institution in the country that plans and implements programs for the development and promotion of the arts—music, dance, theater, visual, literary, cinematic, and broadcast arts. Since 1969 when it was created by Pres Ferdinand E. Marcos, it has sponsored programs and activities such as festivals, exhibitions, competitions, and publications to preserve, promote, and enhance the artistic and cultural heritage of the Filipino people, and to develop audiences that will appreciate and support artistic and cultural work. It is home to nine resident companies that present regular seasons of productions, workshops, and outreach performances: Ballet Philippines, Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company, Philippine Ballet Theatre, Philippine Madrigal Singers, Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group, Tanghalang Pilipino, and UST Symphony Orchestra.

Sitting on a 60-hectare complex on Roxas Boulevard in Pasay City, the CCP is part of a vast international network of arts and culture organizations that provide exchange opportunities between Filipino artists and artists from all over the world. This network also brings in performances and exhibitions that allow local audiences to experience arts and cultures from elsewhere. These organizations include the Association of Asia Pacific Performing Arts Center, the Conseil International des Organisations de Festivals de Folklore et d’Arts Traditionnels, the World Dance Alliance, the International Theater Institute, the Asian Theater Alliance, the ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information, and the ASEAN–Korea Traditional Music Orchestra.

The CCP is composed of several departments that promote arts education, direct outreach and exchange programs all over the country, mount productions and exhibitions, manage cultural holdings, and develop its assets. In its first two decades the CCP focused on what were later perceived as elitist performing arts—theater, ballet, opera, and similar shows—a bias that was shaped by its first board of trustees chair, then First Lady Imelda Romualdez Marcos. Following the successful EDSA revolt against Marcos and his martial rule and the subsequent change in the country’s leadership, the CCP expanded its scope to include literature, film, and broadcast arts, among others. It also reoriented its direction to emphasize original Filipino artistic and cultural expressions rooted in the Philippines and the participation of the regions in the definition of a national culture.

Music. The CCP is home to the country’s premier symphonic orchestra, the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO). Established in 1973, the PPO (then known as the CCP Philharmonic Orchestra) initially accompanied local and foreign performing artists at the CCP. It later evolved as one of the best music ensembles in the Asia-Pacific region, premiering works by Filipino and foreign composers, and promoting music appreciation throughout the country. Past conductors and musical directors of the PPO include Luis Valencia, Oscar Yatco, Ruggero Barbieri, Olivier Ochanine, and Yoshikazu Fukumura.Among the internationally renowned conductors who have performed with the PPO are Mendi Rodan, Piero Gamba, Enrique Batis, Sebastian Bereau, and Nicholas Koch. Some of the world’s best Filipino and foreign artists have also performed with the PPO, including Van Cliburn, Renata Tebaldi, Judith Engel, Anthony Camden, David Benoit, Cecile Licad, Raul Sunico, and Lea Salonga. The PPO is now on its 34th concert season. It has toured in Europe, Asia, and more recently, the United States, when it performed for the first time at the Carnegie Hall. Aside from its regular concert seasons at the CCP, the PPO also participates in the CCP Outreach Program by performing in public spaces and conducting workshops in the provinces.

Another resident company of the CCP is the Philippine Madrigal Singers. Organized in 1963 by Andrea O. Veneracion, later National Artist for music, the choir is composed of students, teachers, and alumni from the various colleges of the University of the Philippines. Performing a wide repertoire of various styles and forms, the ensemble has consistently won all the top prizes in most of the world’s prestigious choral competitions. The choir also maintains an active outreach and concert schedule every year and is regarded as one of the country’s most active ambassadors of goodwill and one of the world’s most traveled choirs.

The UST Symphony Orchestra is also a resident performing group of the CCP. It holds regular concerts at the CCP and participates in the CCP Outreach and Exchange Program. It also serves as a pool for additional players as the needs of the PPO dictate.

In 1987, the CCP launched the Filipino Artists Series (FAS), a monthly program featuring solo performances of acclaimed and emerging Filipino musical artists. Among those featured in the FAS were bass baritone Jonathan Zaens; flutist Antonio Maigue; cellist Wilfredo Pasamba; pianists Corazon Kabayao, Mariel Illusorio, Peter Porticos, and Rene Dalandan; violinists Gilopez Kabayao, Gina Medina, and Denise Huang; and sopranos Clarissa Ocampo and Maria Cristina Viguilla-Navarro. FAS was discontinued in 2009 but was later revived in 2012 as the Special Concert Series. Some of the performing artists in this series are pianist Charisse Baldoria, soprano Katrina Saporsantos, cellist Antoni Josef Inacay, trumpet player Raymond de Leon, percussionist Aimee Mina dela Cruz, and flutist Sarah Mae Gabuyo.

The CCP also embarked on the production of Filipino operas as well as Western operas that were adapted to a Philippine setting. In 1970, it partnered with the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines in producing El Filibusterismo (Subversion), the operatic adaptation of Jose Rizal’s novel, with music by Felipe Padilla de Leon and libretto by Guillermo Tolentino. De Leon and Tolentino’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), first staged at the FEU Auditorium in 1957, was also restaged at the CCP in 1974, with Don David as Ibarra, Ruby Salazar as Maria Clara, Jimmy Melendres as Padre Damaso, and Fides Cuyugan-Asensio as Sisa. In 1984, the CCP and Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines commissioned Francisco Feliciano to create the three-act opera La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf), with libretto by Cuyugan-Asensio. In 1987, the CCP partnered with Music Theater Foundation in another restaging of Noli… this time with Nolyn Cabahug as Ibarra, Andion Fernandez as Maria Clara, and Cuyugan-Asensio as Sisa (alternating with Luz Morete). Rolando Tinio’s Philippine adaptation of La Traviata and La Boheme were also produced by and staged at the CCP in 1991 and 1992, respectively. Two major opera productions of the CCP in the 21st century were Spoliarium , 2003, and Madame Butterfly, 2012. Spoliarium was inspired by Juan Luna ’s life and masterpiece, with music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, and co-produced by the CCP with the Opera Guild of the Philippines and Music Theater Foundation of the Philippines. Madame Butterfly was a co-production of the CCP and MusicArtes, Inc, with director Anton Juan giving local flavor to Puccini’s famous opera.

The CCP is also the organizer and main proponent of major music festivals including the biennial Andrea Veneracion International Choral Festival and the CCP International Jazz Festival which was merged with the Orchestra and Symphonic Band Festival, and the annual Flute/Woodwind Festival. It has also been actively supporting the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) since its inception in 1973. The CCP Arts Education Department also organizes masterclasses of renowned musical artists as well as yearly workshops in rondalla music, choral music, and band music.

Dance. The CCP has four resident dance companies: Ballet Philippines (BP), which is based at the CCP Main Building, and Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company, and the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (ROFC) which are all based outside the CCP.

Since its founding in 1969, BP has performed over 400 works at the CCP, ranging from full-length classical ballets to modern dance and neo-ethnic pieces, under its founding artistic director Alice Reyes, later National Artist for Dance, and after her, Denisa Reyes, Cecile Sicangco, Noordin Jumalon, Alden Lugnasin, Augustus Damian III, Alan Hineline, Max Luna III, and Paul Morales. The company has also collaborated with prominent foreign and local choreographers, dancers, librettists, actors, and set, costume, and lighting designers. Notable productions of BP include Amada, Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf), Rama, Hari, Tales of the Manuvu, Te Deum, For the Gods, Encantada (Enchantress), and La Revolucion Filipina (The Filipino Revolution). It has also produced some of the country’s top ballet dancers who have undergone training at BP’s official school, the CCP Dance School. BP also stages the yearly Neo-Filipino, a dance showcase featuring the latest works of the best and leading choreographers in the country.

Founded in 1987 by artistic directors of different ballet companies, PBT has become one of the country’s leading dance companies specializing in classical ballet. PBT’s regular performance season at the CCP consists of such classics as Romeo and Juliet , Carmen, The Nutcracker, Cinderella, Carmina Burana, and Swan Lake. PBT has been managed by a series of artistic directors, all belonging to the PBT Council, namely, Inday Gaston-Mañosa, Julie Borromeo, Eddie Elejar, Gener Caringal, and Ronilo Jaynario.

The Bayanihan, under choreographer Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, later National Artist for Dance, and later, under executive director Susie Benitez and dance director-choreographer Ferdinand Jose, and the ROFG under artistic director Ramon Obusan, later National Artist for dance, and later, under Dulce Obusan, have been acclaimed nationally and worldwide for their continuing efforts to research, perform, preserve, and perpetuate Philippine folk music and dance traditions. Both companies participate in CCP’s outreach programs by conducting folk dance workshops around the country.

Dance-related festivals organized or initiated by the CCP include the Pang-alay, which featured different Philippine folk dance groups; the Fiesta Folkloriada, an annual festival of folk dance groups all over the world where the Bayanihan is an active participant; the biennial CCP Ballet Festival where various ballet schools in the country gather and perform classical, modern, and neo-ethnic works; and Dance.MNL: The Philippine Dance Festival which was held for the first time in 2016. Dance.MNL is also intended to be a biennial festival which aims to unite and celebrate the Filipino dance community.

The CCP has also given grants or financial assistance to local dance groups which represented the Philippines in international competitions or festivals. Among the grantees were the Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company, the Dureza Ballet School, Quezon City Ballet of the Halili-Cruz School of Dance, and St Anne’s Dance and Music Studio in 1988; Dance Theater Philippines, Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe, Ben-Lor Ballet Academy, St Anne Dance Theater Company (Taguig), La Salle Dance Troupe, Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe, Odon Sabarre and the People’s Center School of Dance, and Hwa Yi Ethnic Dance Center in 1989; Dance Concert Company and Quezon City Ballet of the Halili-Cruz School of Dance in 1990; and Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement, Chameleon Dance Company, Araullo University Dance Troupe, and Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe in 1991.

In 2014, the CCP launched its first ever Ballet Competition held at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino. The biennial competition has a Junior and Senior category and requires contestants to perform both classical and contemporary pieces.

Theater. The CCP, in partnership with the NCCA, has organized the National Theater Festival (NTF), a quinquennial event that gathers theater artists, practitioners, scholars, and enthusiasts from all over the country in a 10-day celebration of the latest achievements in Philippine theater. The NTF, which started in 1992 and was last held in 2012, usually includes performances from various theater groups, a conference, exhibits, and film screenings.

During the first NTF, production and festival grants, as well as six workshop and one research grant, were given to the nine participating regional theater groups. These are Adela Community Organization of Silay City, Negros Occidental; the Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc.-UHAY of Malolos, Bulacan; Cebu Central Colleges Theater Workshop Company and University of San Carlos Theater Guild of Cebu City; Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company of Iloilo City; Komedya ng San Dionisio of Paranaque; Kulturang Atin Foundation Inc., and Kaliwat Theater Collective of Davao City; and the Salidummay Music Theater Company and Tadec Group of Baguio City. Production grants were also given to seven Metro Manila-based groups, namely Bulwagang Gantimpala, Dulaang UP, Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, and Tanghalang Pilipino. Many other groups have availed of these grants in subsequent CCP National Theater Festivals.

The CCP has also supported theater groups outside Metro Manila through its Outreach and Exchange Unit. It provided financial assistance to deserving applicants for the touring of produced local productions to different sites within the region. Theater companies that received touring grants are: in 1988, the Dula Agus Ensemble of Butuan City, Salidummay of the Cordillera, and Teatro Amakan of Iloilo; in 1989, the Sining Pananadem in Marawi City, Dance Theater of Tacloban City, and Susi ng Tayabas in Quezon; in 1991, Pantanghalang Sining ng Laguna and the Adela Community Organization from Silay City, Negros Occidental; in 1992, Sining Kambayoka Ensemble of the Mindanao State University and the Kaliwat Theater Collective of Davao; in 2014, the community-based theater guild in Sorsogon, Teatro Ambahanon and Kabpapagariya Ensemble of General Santos City, the Youth Advocates thru Theater Arts in Dumaguete City, the Integrated Performing Arts Guild in Iligan City, and the Sining Kambayoka Ensemble in Marawi City; and in 2015, Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc. of Malolos City, Artista Sillimania of Dumaguete City, Kuntaw Mindanao of Davao del Norte, and Kaliwat Performing Arts Collective of Davao City. Meanwhile, production venue and full grants were given to Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, UP Playwrights Theater, Telon, Sining Silangan, Philippine Drama Company, UP Repertory Company, Teatro Santa Ana, and Teatro Umalohokan.

In 1994, the CCP Coordinating Center for Dramatic Arts awarded playwriting fellowships to four writers, giving them cash grants to develop their full-length plays. The fellows chosen were JB Capino for his play Los Indios Bravos (The Brave Natives), Dennis Marasigan for Aves de Rapina (Birds of Prey), V. E. Carmelo Nadera for Hermano Puli, and Bebot Rodil for Datu Matu.

Prior to its reorganization after the 1986 EDSA Revolt, the CCP was the home of two local theater companies: Teatro Pilipino, under artistic director Rolando Tinio, and Bulwagang Gantimpala Theater, under artistic director Tony Espejo. Teatro Pilipino, the first resident theater company of the CCP from 1976-86, staged Filipino translations of plays by William Shakespeare, Anton Chekhov, George Bernard Shaw, August Strindberg, and Tennessee Williams, as well as a few Filipino works like Francisco Baltazar’s Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira), Bienvenido M. Noriega’s Bayan-bayanan (Little Country), and Tinio’s May Katwiran ang Katwiran (Reason Has Its Reason).

Bulwagang Gantimpala started out as the production arm of the winning works from the CCP Literary and Playwriting Contest. It staged original Filipino works like Jomar Fleras’s adaptation of Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere, titled Kanser (Cancer), Bonifacio Ilagan’s Katipunan: Mga Anak ng Bayan (Katipunan: Children of the People), Rene O. Villanueva’s Hiblang Abo (Strands of Gray), and Noriega’s Bongbong at Kris (Bongbong and Kris). In 1987, it became an independent theater company and has since moved its office elsewhere.

Tanghalang Pilipino (TP) is now the resident drama company of the CCP. Established in 1987, TP has staged more than 150 productions and is now on its 30th season. Its founding artistic director was Nonon Padilla who directed the company for 17 years until he was replaced by Herbie Go, Dennis Marasigan, and Nanding Josef. Its repertoire consists of original works by Filipino playwrights, restagings of Filipino sarsuwela, and translations and adaptations of foreign plays. TP maintains a stable of professional actors known as the Tanghalang Pilipino Actors’ Company. The company regularly conducts acting workshops and has also toured some of its productions in various provinces.

TP has also partnered with the CCP, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), and the Writer’s Bloc, Inc. in producing the highly successful Virgin Labfest, a laboratory festival of new, unproduced, and untested one-act plays by amateur and veteran playwrights. This yearly project which started in 2005 has now become one of the most anticipated theater events in the country and has also produced a canon of acclaimed works.

In 2011, the CCP and the NCCA organized the first Monodrama Festival, a four-day event featuring monologues and one-actor performances. In 2013, the CCP produced Triple Threats, a series of concerts featuring the stalwarts of Philippine musical theater. Among the artists who have performed for this series are Nonie Buencamino, Menchu Lauchengco-Yulo, Audie Gemora, and Bituin Escalante. The series has also featured composers Rony Fortich and Vincent de Jesus in 2015 and ensemble players in 2016.

Visual Arts. The CCP through its Visual Arts and Museum Division (VAMD) implements and manages the year-round contemporary art, design, and festival-related exhibitions at the various venues at the CCP. These exhibitions provide a showcase for current directions, trends, and movements in Philippine contemporary art, including the fields of architecture, sculpture, photography, digital art, and the allied arts. Aside from managing exhibit venues, providing curatorial assistance, and organizing forums, lectures, and talkback sessions with artists and designers, the VAMD also coordinates with the visual arts community on the activities and concerns of the visual artists all over the country.

The VAMD has organized and presented exhibits featuring artworks of notable Filipino artists among them: Fernando Amorsolo, Victorio Edades, Carlos V. Francisco, Cesar Legaspi, H. R. Ocampo, Vicente Manansala, Fernando Zobel, Lee Aguinaldo, Constancio Bernardo, Jose Joya, Napoleon Abueva, Roberto Chabet, Arturo Luz, Rodolfo Paras-Perez, Ang Kiukok, Justiniano Nuyda, Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi, Brenda Fajardo, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Romulo Olazo, Ray Albano, Nonon Padilla, Prudencio Lamarroza, Impy Pilapil, Ileana Lee, Danilo Dalena, Onib Olmedo, Jaime de Guzman, Julie Lluch, Solomon Saprid, Ben Maramag, Bencab, Tony Velasquez, Mars Ravelo, Francisco Coching, Roberto Feleo, Kidlat Tahimik, Mark Justiniani, Karen Flores, Claude Tayag, and Agnes Arellano. The VAMD has also presented exhibits of artists’ groups such as the Social Realists, Kasibulan Women Artists, Paete artists, Black Artists of Asia, Abstract Expressionists, Figurative Expressionists, Mabini Art Movement, Salingpusa, Baguio Arts Guild, VIVA Excon, and artists from various schools like the University of the Philippines, University of Santo Tomas, and the Philippine High School for the Arts.

The VAMD also gives recognition to Filipino artists through the 13 Artists Awards. Started by former CCP museum director Roberto Chabet in 1970, the 13 Artists Awards later became a biennial award under the management of Ray Albano, and a triennial award in 2009. The award is given to artists who take “the chance and risk to restructure, restrengthen, and renew art making and art thinking.” Since 2009, the recognition has been given to more than 170 artists in the fields of painting, sculpture, mixed and multi-media, and installation art. The most recent awarding was held in 2018 and the recipients were Zeus Bascon, Bea Camacho, Cian Dayrit, Janos Dela Cruz, Carlo Gabuco, Dina Gadia, Guerrero Habulan, Eisa Jocson, Doktor Karayom, Raffy Napay, Archie Oclos, Lynyrd Paras, and Shireen Seno. The awarding usually coincides with a month-long exhibition of the awardees’ works.

Literature. The Literary Arts division of the CCP, now known as the Intertextual Division (ID), undertakes activities that deal with literary text, performance text, and hypertext. Among its accomplishments is the publication of ANI (Harvest), a literary journal which is now on its 39th edition. The journal features short stories, essays, and poems in Filipino, English, and other Philippine languages. It also took care of other CCP special publications like Himala y Balagtas and Himalay Rizal.

In previous years, the CCP sponsored literary contests and awarded writing grants to writers in Filipino, English, and the major regional languages. It began sponsoring a playwriting contest in 1969 in both English and Filipino. The first winners of the CCP Playwriting Contest were: In Frailty’s Grace by Elsa V. Martinez, first prize; And the Day But One by Jose Ma. Hernandez, second; and The Onyx Wolf by Virginia Moreno, third; Tabak at Tanikala (Bolo and Chain) by Dionisio S. Salazar; Status Quo by Angel R. Makiling, and Halik sa Kampilan (Kiss the Sword) by Cipriano V. Ilagan, honorable mention.

A verse writing category was added in 1973. The first winners in the English division were Artemio Tadena for “The Bloodied Envelope,” first prize; Gemino Abad for “In Another Light,” second prize; and Federico Licsi Espino for “Scope of Movement,” third prize. The poets given honorable mention in the English division were Alfrredo Navarro Salanga for “Twelve,” Jolico Cuadra for “The Possibilitation Poems,” and Simeon Dumdum Jr for “Rainy Day.” In the Filipino division, the first winners were Teo Antonio for “Pilipino sa Isang Lawa ng Chicago” (A Filipino by the Lakeside in Chicago), first prize; Vict. V. de la Cruz for “Isang Pag-aalay sa Sining, sa Bayan, sa Bathala” (An Offering to Art, to Country, and to God), second prize; and Victor S. Fernandez for “Mga Bulaklak sa Parnaso” (Flowers on Parnasus), third prize. Given honorable mention were Gonzalo K. Flores for “Bahay sa Looban” (A House in the Interior), Eduardo P. Garrovillas for “Ang Bagong Pilipino” (The New Filipino), and Virgilio S. Almario for "Doktrinang Anakpawis" (Doctrine of the Laborer).

The following categories were added in 1974: epic narrative, won by Luwalhati C. Marquez for “Balante”; short story, won by Reynaldo Duque for “Bagani Ubbong at Iba Pang Kuwento” (Bagani Ubbong and Other Stories); novel, won by Benjamin P. Pascual for “Utos ng Hari” (King’s Command); essay, won by Pablo R. Glorioso for “Pamana ng Panitik at Iba Pang Sanaysay” (Legacy of Letters and Other Essays) and Virgilio S. Almario for “Ang Makata sa Panahon ng Makina” (The Poet in the Machine Age). A biography category was added in 1979. Honorable mention was given to Lydia Ingle for “Edades: Kites and Visions,” 1980 in the English division and to Lamberto Ma. Gabriel for “Padre Gregorio L. Crisostomo, Ulirang Pilipino” (Father Gregorio L. Crisostomo, a Model Filipino), Filipino division. Hernando J. Abaya won the grand prize when the award for the category was resumed in 1984 for “The Making of a Subversive.”

The novel category was also instituted in 1979. The first co-winners in the English division were F. Sionil Jose for Tree and Edith Tiempo for His Native Coast. In the Filipino division, the prize went to Dominador B. Mirasol for Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa (Gold is the Brown Earth).

A new category—criticism—was added in 1984. In the English division, an Appreciation Award was shared among Nick Nicolas Jr for “Theater, Films and Others: A Compendium of Critical Reviews,” Wilhelmina Q. Ramas for “Sugbuanon Theater: From Sotto to Rodriguez and Kabahar,” and Soledad S. Reyes for “Criticism and Ideology.” In the Filipino division, the grand prize in criticism was given to Virgilio S. Almario for “Taludtod at Talinghaga: Mga Sangkap ng Katutubong Pagtula” (Verses and Metaphor: The Elements of Folk Poetry).
