In 1987, the annual literary contest was transformed into the Gawad CCP Para sa Panatikan under the supervision of the CCP’s Coordinating Center for Literature. The contest dropped the English category in favor of an all-Filipino rule. The categories were poetry, short story, one-act play, three-act play, dance libretto (one-act dance drama), and the full-length musical drama.

The winners in the poetry category that year were Fidel D. Rillo for “Musa Insurekta” (Insurgent Muse), first prize; Teo Antonio for “Cespora Personata at Iba Pang Pagbubulay-bulay” (Cespora Personata and Other Ruminations), second prize; and Danton Remoto for “Kuwaderno” (Notebook), third prize. In the short story category, the winners were Reynaldo Duque for “Ang Gamugamo sa Lampara ni Julio Madarang” (The Firefly About Julio Madarang’s Lamp), first prize; Chit Balmaceda-Gutierrez for “Kulas,” second prize; and Tomas F. Agulto for “Ang Walang Lubay na Istasyon ng Pag-asa at Paghahanap” (The Eternal Station of Hope and Searching), third prize. The critical essay category on the different arts was instituted a year later.

The winning poems and stories in the Gawad CCP Para sa Panitikan have also been published in ANI, while the critical works have appeared in Kultura, the CCP magazine for critical essays. The Gawad CCP Para sa Panitikan was discontinued in 1990.

The CCP has also given grants to writers who applied for writing grants for drama in Filipino or a regional language, or for criticism in Filipino or a regional language, or for criticism in the performing arts. Grantees in drama are Reynaldo Duque, 1988, and Jose A. Bragado, 1989, for Ilocano; Ruperto Alaura, 1988, RobertoVillanueva, 1989, and Leonilo Estimo, 1993, for Cebuano; Carlos Ojeda Aureus, 1992, for Bicolano; Julian Jagudilla, 1989 and 1990, and Jose Galiza and Eugenio de Pablo, 1991, for Hiligaynon/Karay-a; and Rene O. Villanueva, 1988, and Ariel N. Valerio, 1993, for Filipino.

In 2015, the ID spearheaded the biennial event called Performatura 2015, Performing Literatures, a three-day intertextual festival held in various venues at the CCP. The event included conversations with National Artists; Chromatext Rebooted, an exhibit merging text and visual arts; performance poetry featuring young poets; and workshops on the poetic joust balagtasan, speech choir, and ventriloquism.

Film. The Media Arts Division is the main implementor of the CCP’s year-round film, broadcast, and emerging media events, which include screenings, productions, festivals, awards, workshops, and fora. It also coordinates with all sectors of the film community—both local and international, independent and mainstream, contemporary and classic.

In 1987, the CCP started to give recognition to Filipino alternative films and video. Known as the Gawad CCP Para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Bidyo or Gawad Alternatibo, this is considered the longest-running independent film competition of its kind in the Asian region. Gawad Alternatibo annually cites the best efforts of Pinoy filmmakers in four categories: Animation, Experimental, Documentary, and Short Feature. Each winner receives a cash prize and a certificate. Special citations are also awarded to the best work from the regions, as well as works on/for/by children. Many of today’s outstanding filmmakers and media practitioners are awardees of Gawad Alternatibo.

The Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival is one of the CCP’s most important cinema-related undertakings every year. Established in 2004, the festival has given birth to some of Philippine cinema’s contemporary masterpieces and is regarded as one of the most prestigious independent film competitions in the country, and a much awaited cultural event as well. Some of today’s acclaimed filmmakers have launched their careers via the annual festival and competition, including Kanakan Balintagos aka Aureaus Solito, Lawrence Fajardo, Chris Martinez, Jun Robles Lana, Alvin B. Yapan, Francis Pasion, and Eduardo Roy Jr. Simultaneous film-related events are also held during the festival, including the Cinemalaya Film Congress, a two-day conference that looks at all aspects of independent filmmaking and distribution; the Cinemalaya Sine Taktakan, a forum with the year’s batch of new Cinemalaya filmmakers; exhibitions that include Tributes to Past Indie Mavericks of Pinoy Cinema; a Cinemalaya Kids’ Treats; World Premieres of New Digital Works (the Cinemalaya/NETPAC Prize); and a host of other activities.

The CCP also holds annual film lectures and retrospectives on Filipino filmmakers and actors, like Gerardo de Leon, Manuel Conde, Luciano B. Carlos, Mona Lisa, Jaclyn Jose, and Fernando Poe Jr, as well as foreign film artists like Akira Kurosawa, Isabelle Huppert, and Olivier Assayas.

Broadcast Arts. In recognition of the broad reach and powerful influence of radio and television, the CCP established in 1987 a Coordinating Center for Broadcast Arts which was one of the units of the then Visual, Literary, and Media Arts Department. While all these units have been replaced by the Media Arts Division, the CCP—then and now—has continued efforts to equip ordinary citizens with the skills to produce radio programs and videos that reflect their realities and that allow them to promote their sectoral interests through broadcasting. It conducts hands-on training-workshops on radio and television production and scriptwriting, accepts apprenticeships, and awards production grants. While bringing its training program to as far north as Batanes and as far south as Tawi-tawi, the CCP encourages the use of Filipino languages in the programs and videos produced by its trainees. Among those who complete the training programs and are given grants to produce their own radio programs are farmers, fisherfolk, social development and cultural workers, students, and local leaders who produce and host talk shows, historical documentaries, instructional programs, public service announcements, music shows, and dramatizations of Filipino myths and legends. Their productions are aired in cooperation with local radio stations.

The CCP produces television programs as well as videos. In 1990 it produced Pinoy Eh, a magazine show aired on ABC Channel 5. Directed by Marilou-Diaz-Abaya and hosted by Ces Quesada, it had 13 episodes on such topics as the Filipino language, music, cinema, architecture, literature, dance, rituals, ethnic groups, and places. Another television production is the 1992 13-episode drama series Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) based on Jose Rizal’s novel, written and directed by National Artist for cinema Eddie Romero, starring Joel Torre and Chin-chin Gutierrez. The series is also available in DVD. The Red Carpet was a monthly program aired on Net 25 in 2009-12, featuring the shows at CCP and the cultural and artistic scene in the country. On Set, also on Net 25, 2009-12, highlighted the country’s top caliber artists such as Lea Salonga, Ryan Cayabyab, and Bienvenido Lumbera.

CCP is also on radio. Following the 1986 EDSA revolt, it produced the weekly radio magazine Kultura ng Bayan (Culture of the People), aired on DZRV in 1986-92, then on DZRM until 1996. It featured Filipino music and theater, talked about arts and culture in the Philippines, and held the balagtasan on current socio-political issues. Among CCP’s current radio programs is the weekly Culture Carousel, which has been airing on DZFE since 1990. It features CCP music artists as well as visiting music artists and airs their performances. Another production is DiskArte (Artistic Strategy) which discusses social issues using the arts. It airs on DZRH in partnership with the Manila Broadcasting Corporation (MBC). The program was formerly titled Sugpuin ang Korupsyon (Fight Corruption) which aired on DZRH in 2004-08 until it was reformatted. It was awarded The Freedom Project 2013 Jury Prize and the People’s Choice Award by The Friedrich Naumann Foundation for Freedom of Germany. Another CCP radio production was the children’s show Wan Dey Isang Araw (One Day), aired on DZAS in 2005-13, which tried to revive the tradition of storytelling in the Philippines. It featured stories by Luis P. Gatmaitan, Eugene Evasco, Augie Rivera, and Grace Chong.

In 1987-98, the CCP gave out the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon (CCP Awards for Television), annually to outstanding television programs, producers, directors, scriptwriters, performers, and other content producers. Among the awardees were the musicals Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing For You) and Ryan, Ryan Musikahan (Music With Ryan), the drama series Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) and Lovingly Yours, Helen, the children’s show Batibot (Small but Strong), the talk show Pep Talk, the public affairs programs Probe Team, Public Forum, and Viewpoint, and the gag show Sic O’Clock News. In 1990-1998, the Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo (CCP Awards for Radio) was given at the same time as the television awards, to outstanding radio programs, producers, directors, scriptwriters, performers, and music and sound designers. The radio awards were henceforth given every two years. Among the awardees in 1990 were the documentary Parangal (Tribute), on DZRM; the drama series Drama Filipina on DZEC, the arts and culture show Filipiniana on DZLC in Lucena, the music magazine shows Yukbo sa Musika on DYMR and Salam in sa Kaliwat on DXWG, both in Cebu, and radio pioneer Francisco “Koko” Trinidad for his contribution to Philippine radio.

Other Programs. The CCP organizes various year-round arts-affiliated events, such as Pasinaya, the biggest multi-arts festival in the country. Started in 2010, Pasinaya is an annual one-day open-house festival which serves as a gathering of CCP resident companies, patrons, and the general public. Simultaneous events are held in all of CCP’s venues, with designated zones for dance, theater, music, literature, film, visual arts, children and family, variety, and the artists market. There are also crash workshops, film screenings, visual arts exhibitions, food booths, and activities for children. Some of the resident companies also perform excerpts from their upcoming shows or past productions.

Outreach and exchange programs include: KUTITAP: Isang Piging ng Kabataang Makasining, an annual three-day event for children and young people that started in 2009 and is aimed at raising their awareness of and appreciation for indigenous arts, culture, and traditions; Ugnayan sa Sining, an annual series of cultural exchanges and community tours featuring some of the country’s prominent regional cultural groups; Lakbay Sining, a national touring program which features performances from CCP resident companies or art exhibitions previously mounted at the CCP; Kaisa sa Sining, a program which links CCP to regional cultural groups in order to facilitate regional cultural development, exchanges, artistic programs, and collaborations; Lakbay Sine, a project of CCP Media Arts Division; and Lakbay Harana , a joint project of the CCP and Tribung Pilipino Foundation which aims to promote and reawaken the public’s, and especially the young generation’s, interest and appreciation for Philippine traditional music like the kundiman, balitaw, danza, and immortal Filipino love songs. The CCP through its Cultural Exchange Department also provides local tour grants for regional performing groups. It is also active in giving art therapy workshops—called Kalinga ng Sining—in provincial areas devastated by natural calamities or armed conflicts.

The CCP has occasionally engaged in film production. It produced two movies: Hari sa Hari, Lahi sa Lahi (King and Emperor), 1987, directed by Eddie Romero, and Emir, 2010, directed by Chito Roño.

A heritage project of the CCP is the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art. First published in 1994, the CCP Encyclopedia remains to be the most authoritative and most comprehensive sourcebook on Philippine art, with volumes on the peoples of the Philippines, architecture, visual arts, dance, music, theater, film, literature, and broadcast arts. Prior to the encyclopedia, the CCP also published beginning in 1989, 28 videos and monographs on the seven arts, known collectively as Tuklas Sining. The first essays on the seven arts were compiled and published in a coffee table book with the same title in 1991. To encourage the staging of more sarsuwela, the CCP came out with the sarsuwela series which made available to scholars and performing groups the scripts and music of the classic Tagalog sarsuwela Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), and Walang Sugat (No Wounds) as performed and staged by Tanghalang Pilipino. The initial publication in 1991 included the cassette tapes and books for Paglipas ng Dilim and Dalagang Bukid, and in 1994, for Walang Sugat. The videotaped performances of Dalagang Bukid and Walang Sugat were released in DVD format in 2007.

The Gawad CCP Para sa Sining is the highest recognition awarded by the CCP to artists or groups of artists who have produced a body of outstanding works and excelled in their chosen artform. The award is also given to cultural workers who have helped in enriching Philippine art through their works in research, curatorship, and administration. The Tanging Parangal is given to individuals or organizations to honor their outstanding contributions to the development of the arts in the country.The first Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, then called by another name, was given in 1977 to Hubertus Kuhne (for cultural administration). The award was given annually from 1989 up to 1994, and thereafter every three years. The most recent conferment was in 2015 and the awardees were: Denisa Reyes for Dance; Fides Cuyugan-Asensio for Music; Antonio Mabesa for Theater; Roberto Chabet for Visual Arts; Ricardo Lee for Literature; Nora Aunor for Film and Broadcast Arts; Paulo Alcazaren for Architecture; and Ben Farrales for Design. Leoncio Deriada, Armida Siguion-Reyna, Basilio Esteban Villaruz, Talaandig School of Living Traditions, and The Missionary Society of St. Columban received the Tanging Parangal.

The Order of the National Artists, the highest state honor given every three years to individuals who have made significant contributions in Philippine arts, was administered by the CCP from 1972 to 1992, and after that, by the CCP and NCCA. The award is conferred by the President of the Republic of the Philippines upon the recommendation of the CCP and NCCA.Fernando Amorsolo was posthumously conferred the first National Artist Award in 1977. The award was most recently conferred in 2018to Larry Alcala (visual arts, posthumous), Resil B. Mojares and Ramon Muzones (literature), Francisco Mañosa (architecture), Ryan Cayabyab (music), and Kidlat Tahimik (film).   Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez, Lily Grace Tabanera, and Elmer L. Gatchalian

Sharon Cuneta (Sharon Gamboa Cuneta-Pangilinan), also known as Shawie, is a film and television actor, host, and singer. She was born in Manila on 6 Jan 1966. She is the daughter of Pablo Cuneta, former mayor of Pasay City, and Elaine Gamboa. Actor Helen Gamboa is an aunt. Cuneta has a daughter—Kristina Cassandra “KC” Concepcion, who is also an actor—by actor Gabby Concepcion. Cuneta married Concepcion in 1984, but their marriage was annulled in 1993. In 1996, she married Sen Francis Pangilinan. They have two daughters, Simone Francesca Emmanuelle and Mariel Daniella Sophia, and an adopted son, Miguel Samuel Mateo.

At 13, Cuneta started out as a recording artist for Vicor Records, popularizing teen love songs such as “Mr. D.J.,” “Kahit Maputi Na ang Buhok Ko” (Even When My Hair Turns White), and “Mahal Kita, Mahal Mo Siya, Mahal Niya Ay Iba” (I Love You, You Love Her, She Loves Someone Else). Barely a year as a singer, she was named Jukebox Princess by Bamci Productions in 1980. She also earned a nomination in the Cecil Awards of the music industry.

Cuneta's initial television exposure was in the long-running afternoon variety show Eat Bulaga, 1979, where she appeared as one of the hosts. That same year, she became one of German Moreno's cohosts for the Sunday musical variety show, GMA Supershow, 1979-1985. In 1986, Viva Television produced Cuneta's solo musical variety show, The Sharon Cuneta Show, 1986-1988, on IBC 13. The show later transferred to ABS-CBN where it became a Sunday night staple and ran for many years. She would later host two more shows for ABS-CBN: Sharon, a musical variety-talk show, 1998-2010, and The Biggest Loser: Pinoy Edition, a reality show, 2011. She transferred to TV5 a year later and hosted the talk show Sharon: Kasama Mo, Kapatid (Sharon: With You, Brothers and Sisters), 2012-13, and the musical variety show The Mega and the Songwriter, 2012-13, with singer-composer Ogie Alcasid. TV5 also produced Cuneta's first primetime drama series Madam Chairman, 2012-13. Two years later, Cuneta went back to ABS-CBN and became one of the judges of the singing competition, Your Face Sounds Familiar, 2015.

Cuneta’s first movie is Dear Heart, 1981, with Gabby Concepcion. She gained a stable following after the success of her succeeding movies. These include P.S. I Love You, 1981; Bukas Luluhod ang mga Tala (Tomorrow the Stars Will Kneel) and Dapat Ka Bang Mahalin? (Should You Be Loved?), 1984; Bituing Walang Ningning (Star Without Sparkle) and Pati Ba Pintig ng Puso? (And the Heartbeat, Too?), 1985; Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (May It Never End), 1986; Pasan Ko ang Daigdig (World on My Shoulders), 1987; Jack & Jill sa America (Jack and Jill in America), 1988; Babangon Ako’t Dudurugin Kita (I Will Rise and Crush You), 1989; Kahit Konting Pagtingin (Just a Little Love) and Biktima (Victim), 1990; Una Kang Naging Akin (You Were Mine First) and Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), 1991. Her later films are Minsan, Minahal Kita (Once, I Loved You), 2000; Magkapatid (Sisters), 2002; Crying Ladies, Walang Kapalit (Nobody Else), and Kung Ako Na Lang Sana (Wish It Were Me), 2003; Caregiver, 2008; Best Friends Forever and Mano Po 6: A Mother’s Love (I Kiss Your Hand 6: A Mother’s Love), 2009.

In 1985, Cuneta won Best Actress awards from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) for Sa Hirap at Ginhawa (In Bad Times and Good Times), 1984, and from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Dapat Ka Bang Mahalin? She also received the FAP Special Recognition Award in 1990. Later, she won more Best Actress awards: for Madrasta (Stepmother), 1996, from the FAMAS, FAP, PMPC Star Awards for Movies, and the Gawad Urian; for Magkapatid, from the 2002 Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF); for Crying Ladies, from the 2004 Brussels International Independent Film Festival; and for Mano Po 6: A Mother’s Love, from the 2009 MMFF. In 2010, she received the FAMAS Golden Artist Award for Cinematic Excellence.  Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

Anne Curtis (Anne Ojales Curtis-Smith) is a film and television actor and host. She was born in Yarrawonga, Victoria, Australia on 17 Feb 1985. The daughter of James Curtis-Smith, an Australian lawyer, and Carmencita Ojales, a Filipina, Curtis is the eldest of five children. Her younger sister Jasmine is also an actor.

In 1997, she auditioned for a part in the movie Mortal Kombat: Alamat ng Damortis (Mortal Combat: Legend of Damortis) aka Magic Kingdom, 1997, where she played the role of Princess Dahlia. Afterward, she signed up with Viva Films, where she appeared in minor roles in various films. After doing a few more minor roles in movies like Mahal Kita … Final Answer? (I Love You … Final Answer?), 2002, Lastikman (Plastic Man), 2003, and Filipinas, 2003, Curtis finally played a significant role in the romantic movie All about Love, 2006.

Curtis got her big movie break in 2008 when she starred in When Love Begins with Aga Muhlach. In the same year, she was tapped to star opposite Jericho Rosales in the historical drama Baler, 2008. With an all-star cast including Phillip Salvador, Michael de Mesa, Ryan Eigenmann, Carlo Aquino, and Rio Locsin, Baler garnered Best Picture awards in 2009 from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), and Metro Manila Film Festival, where Curtis won her first Best Actress award. In 2010, Curtis starred in the film Babe, I Love You with Sam Milby. Her next film in the same year was In Your Eyes, together with Claudine Barretto and Richard Gutierrez. Here she earned a Best Supporting Actress award in the FAP’s Luna Awards. Since then, Curtis also rose to become one of the top celebrity product endorsers in the country. Though not really a singer, she released two hugely successful music albums, Annebisyosa (Ambitious Anne), 2011, and The Forbidden, 2014, and embarked on a countrywide concert tour called AnneKapal: The Forbidden Concert (Anne the Overconfident: The Forbidden Concert), also in 2014.

Curtis delved into adult dramas in the succeeding years. The sexy love triangle No Other Woman was released in 2011. Here, Curtis potrayed the character of a mistress who wreaks havoc on a married couple played by Derek Ramsay and Cristine Reyes. No Other Woman was followed a year later by A Secret Affair, 2012, another sexy love triangle starring Derek Ramsay, with Curtis playing the wife and Andi Eigenmann portraying the mistress. The following year saw Curtis focusing more on her television work; but by 2014, Curtis reunited with Cristine Reyes in the black comedy The Gifted. She also appeared in the Hollywood horror movie Blood Ransom, 2014, opposite rising American television star Alexander Dreymon.

Curtis’s television credits include Hiram (Borrowed), 2004-5; Kampanerang Kuba (Hunchbacked Lady Bell Ringer), 2005-7; Dyosa (Goddess), 2008; and Mars Ravelo’s Dyesebel, 2014. She also co-hosts the noontime variety show It’s Showtime, from 2009 to the present.  Written by Elvin Valerio

Sari Dalena (Sari Raissa Lluch Dalena) is a film director, production designer, and producer. She was born in Quezon City on 28 Oct 1970. She is the eldest daughter of painter Danilo Dalena and sculptor Julie Lluch. She is the sister of visual artist Aba Lluch Dalena and filmmaker Kiri Dalena. She is the wife of filmmaker Keith Sicat, with whom she collaborated on several films, including Himala Ngayon (Miracle Today) and Ishma, 2012, and Sicat’s Room 213, 2008, and Woman of the Ruins, 2013. Like both her parents and her sister Kiri, Dalena is the recipient of the Thirteen Artist Awards of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

She graduated from the University of the Philippines with a bachelor of arts in film and audiovisual communication, and received the Best Thesis award, as well as the Best Short Film award from Gawad Urian for Mumunting Krus (Little Crosses), 1995. She received her master of fine arts in film production from New York University where she was cited for “Excellence in Filmmaking” for Rigodon (Quadrille), 2006, which she co-directed with Sicat. Rigodon is about the plight of Filipino-Americans after the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

Her earlier films were highly experimental and belonged to the thriving alternative cinema scene in the 1990s. Her first film, Asong Simbahan (Church Dog), 1994, inspired by her father’s painting of the same title, won the Best Short Film award from Gawad Urian and the Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video. White Funeral, 1998, evocative of Maya Deren’s imagery, is an adaptation of the Old Testament narrative of the adulterous bride. It melds cinema with contemporary dance, featuring choreography by Myra Beltran, and is set in the lahar landscape after the eruption of Mount Pinatubo.

Memories of a Forgotten War, 2001, is Dalena’s first documentary film, co-directed with Camilla Benolirao Griggers, which deals with the atrocities brought about by the Philippine-American War of 1899. It mixes fin de siècle archival materials with reenactments of quotidian and historic events, like the Bud Dajo massacre in Jolo, Sulu, to tell an indicting chronicle of the violence of American imperialism.

Her first major feature is Ka Oryang (Comrade Oryang), 2011, a tribute to women political detainees during martial law in the Philippines. It won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Cinematography (Kiri Dalena and Neil Daza), and Best Music (Teresa Barrozo) at the 2011 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival.

Ka Oryang demonstrates Dalena’s direction as political filmmaker and teller of women’s stories in cinema. It was succeeded by the documentary Guerrera (Women of Martial Law), 2012, which coincided with the 40th anniversary of the declaration of martial law under Ferdinand Marcos. Dalena co-directed two films with sister Kiri: The Guerilla Is a Poet, 2013, and the documentary-musical Ang Kababaihan ng Malolos (Women of Malolos), 2014. The former is a biopic of Jose Ma. Sison, the founding chair of the Communist Party of the Philippines. It won Best Actor (Karl Medina), Best Supporting Actor (Bong Cabrera), Best Editing (Keith Sicat and Kiri Dalena), and Best Music (Datu Arellano) at the 2013 CineFilipino Film Festival. Ang Kababaihan ng Malolos, with screenplay by Nicanor G. Tiongson, was based on his 2007 sarsuwela Basilia ng Malolos (Basilia of Malolos). Released to mark the 125th anniversary of Jose Rizal’s letter “To the Young Women of Malolos,” the documentary has been screened in local and international festivals.

Dalena also directed documentaries for television, notably “Plaza Miranda Bombing” and “Gen. Gregorio del Pilar: A Hero or Henchman?” for Case Unclosed, which aired on GMA Network in 2009.  Written by Patrick Campos

Jose Y. Dalisay Jr (Jose Yap Dalisay Jr), also known as Butch Dalisay, is a fictionist, playwright, screenwriter, biographer, and poet. He was born in Alcantara, Romblon on 15 Jan 1954. He is the eldest among the five children of Jose Dalisay Sr and Emilia Yap. He is married to painter June Poticar with whom he has a daughter. He studied at La Salle Greenhills and Philippine Science High School before entering the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1970. He finished his bachelor’s degree in English at UP in 1984, his master’s degree at the University of Michigan in 1988, and his doctorate in English at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee in 1991. He has worked with various newspapers, the National Economic and Development Authority, and the United Nations Development Programme. He received fellowships from Hawthornden Castle, British Council, David TK Wong, Rockefeller, and Civitella Ranieri, and has held the professorial chairs at various universities here and abroad. At present, he teaches literature and creative writing at UP and serves as a fellow for fiction at the UP Institute of Creative Writing. He also writes a column, "Penman," in the The Philippine Star.

Dalisay started writing in 1970. His prose and poems are in English but almost all his plays, in Filipino. His short stories were collected in Oldtimer and Other Stories, 1985; Sarcophagus and Other Stories, 1992; Penmanship and Other Stories, 1995; and Selected Stories, 2005. He has two novels: Killing Time in a Warm Place, 1992, and Soledad’s Sister, 2008, which was shortlisted for the inaugural Man Asian Literary Prize in Hong Kong and has been published in Italian, Spanish, and French editions. His poetry collection Pinoy Septych and Other Poems was published in 2011. Four of his plays were collected in Madilim ang Gabi sa Laot at Iba Pang Dula ng Ligaw na Pag-ibig (Dark Night on the Open Sea and Other Plays on Lost Love), 1993. His other books include The Best of Barfly, 1997, a compilation of his columns; and The Knowing Is in the Writing: Notes on the Practice of Fiction, 2006.

His plays have been produced by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), Bulwagang Gantimpala, and Tanghalang Pilipino, and staged in the Philippines and at Asian theater festivals. Some of his outstanding dramas include Madilim ang Gabi sa Laot (Dark Night on the Open Sea), Sugatang Lawin (Wounded Hawk), PagsabogngLiwanag (When the Light Breaks), Ambon sa Madaling-Araw (Early Morning Dew), Mac Malicsi, TNT, and Aninag, Anino (Glimmer and Shadow). About 15 of his scripts have been filmed, including Miguelito: Batang Rebelde (Miguelito: Young Rebel), Tahan Na Empoy, Tahan (Stop Crying Now, Empoy), Inay (Mother), Ina Ka ng Anak Mo (You Are the Mother of Your Daughter), and Ano ang Kulay ng Mukha ng Diyos? (What Is the Color of God’s Face?). He has also written about 10 television plays and one documentary. He has written and edited biographies of political personalities, business tycoons, and actors, and wrote for various government and international agencies.

Dalisay won several Palancas in various categories: for the one-act plays Kalapating Dagat (Sea Dove), third prize in the Filipino division, 1984, and In Transit, third prize in the English division, 1987; for the three-act plays in Filipino Ambon sa Madaling-Araw, second prize, 1980, and Aninag Anino and Ang Butihing Babae ng Timog (The Good Woman of the South), second and third prizes, respectively, both in 1993; for the short stories “Agcalan Point,” second prize, 1975, “Heartland,” first prize, 1982, “Old Timer,” first prize, 1983, “Merlie,” first prize, and “The Other Side,” second prize, 1986, “The Body,” second prize, 1987, and “The Woman in the Box,” 2000; for the essays “Tales of the Subdivided,” third prize, 1984, and “Killing Time in Planet Earth,” second prize, 1991; and for poetry, “Pinoy Septych and Other Poems,” second prize, 1990. “Killing Time in a Warm Place” won the grand prize for the novel in 1993. He was inducted into the Palanca Hall of Fame in 2000.

His script for the Lino Brocka movie Ano ang Kulay ng Mukha ng Diyos?, 1986, won Best Adapted Screenplay at the Catholic Mass Media Awards, while Miguelito: Batang Rebelde, 1985, won Best Story at the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. Dalisay won prizes at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Literary Contest for these plays: Madilim ang Gabi sa Laot, first prize, and A Guest of Honor, honorable mention, 1976; Ang Kalayaan sa Buhay ni Domingo Kang Tze (The Freedom in Domingo Kang Tze’s Life), first prize, 1977; and Sugatang Lawin, third prize, 1978. Pagsabog ng Liwanag received an honorable mention in the 1980 CCP Playwriting Contest. He received the Chamberlain Award for Achievement in Creative Writing from the University of Michigan. He was a first prize cowinner in the fiction contest of the Philippines Graphic, 1995. In 1998, he was awarded the CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts as one of the 100 most accomplished Filipino artists of the past century. He received National Book Awards from the Manila Critics Circle for Oldtimer and Other Stories, fiction; Killing Time in a Warm Place, fiction; Madilim ang Gabi sa Laot at Iba Pang Dula ng Ligaw na Pag-ibig, drama; Penmanship and Other Stories, fiction; The Island, 1996, with co-authors Jaime Zobel and Francisco Doplon, design; and Wash: Only a Bookkeeper; A Biography of Washington Z. Sycip, 2010, nonfiction prose.   Written by Malou L. Maniquis, Danton Remoto, and Elmer L. Gatchalian, updated by Om Narayan Velasco

Reynaldo Dante (Deogracias Cristobal) was a film actor. He was born in Bulacan on 12 Mar 1914. He died on 10 Feb 1985. He took up engineering at the University of the Philippines.

Dante first played a supporting role in Celia at Balagtas (Celia and Balagtas), 1938. Then he was assigned leading roles in Dolores, 1939; Nagkaisang Landas (Paths That Met), 1939; Kaban ng Tipan (The Covenant), 1939; Dugo ng Alipin (Blood of the Slave), 1940; Patawad (Pardon), 1940, with Purita Santamaria; Angelita, 1941; and Sisa, 1951, opposite Anita Linda. After a respite, Dante did Guwapo (Handsome), 1954, and Sumpa at Pangako (Vow and Promise), 1954. He appeared with most of the leading ladies of post-World War II cinema in films like Isang Dakot na Bigas (A Handful of Rice), 1948, with Ester Magalona; Bulalakaw (Shooting Star), 1948, with Rosa del Rosario; Anghel sa Lupa (Angel on Earth), 1948, and Bakit Ako Luluha? (Why Should I Cry?), 1949, with Anita Linda; and Labis na Pagtitipid (Stinginess), 1951, with Arsenia Francisco.

He is the first actor to win an award from an official award-giving body. At the first Maria Clara Awards rites, Dante received the trophy as Best Actor for Kamay ni Satanas (Hand of Satan), 1950, a film directed by Gerardo de Leon.  Written by Nenuca Jose

Marlene Dauden is a film and television actor.  She was born in Manila on 9 Nov 1938. She is married to former professional basketball and De La Salle Green Archer player Ernesto Hernaez. She studied at St. Scholastica’s College. She now lives in California, USA, with her husband and three children. Her daughter, Carol, is also an actor.

Dauden first appeared in Mga Ligaw na Bulaklak (Wildflowers), 1957, and played bit roles in Kundiman ng Puso (Love Song of the Heart), Berdaderong Ginto (Real Gold), and Alaalang Banal (Sacred Memory), all in 1958. She got her chance to play a lead role as a ballerina in Rosa Rossini, 1959. Her other films include Pagpatak ng Ulan (When the Rain Falls), Kuwintas ng Alaala (Necklace of Memories), and Ipagdarasal Kita (I Will Pray for You), all in 1960; Karugtong ng Kahapon (Continuation of Yesterday), 1961; and Sa Puso ng Isang Ina (In a Mother’s Heart), 1963. After her contract with Sampaguita Pictures expired, she became a freelance actor, starring in other movie companies’ films such as MVM’s Banal na Pag-ibig (Sacred Love), 1971; Mirick’s Siya’y Umalis, Siya’y Dumating (She Left, She Came), 1975; and Agrix Film’s Kung Kaya Mo, Kaya Ko Rin (If You Can Do It, So Can I), 1978. Her last cameo role was in Combat Killers, 1980.

She also appeared on television. She won the Citizens’ Awards for Television (CAT) as Best TV Female Performer for the series Salamisim (Reflections), 1967, and Best TV Female Performer in a continuing role for another series, Panagimpan (Imagination), 1970.

Dauden won Best Supporting Actress from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Anino ni Bathala (Shadow of God), 1958, Kamandag (Venom), 1959, and Sapagkat Kami’y Tao Lamang (For We Are Only Human), 1963; and Best Actress for Sa Bawat Pintig ng Puso (With Every Beat of the Heart), 1964, and Kapag Puso’y Sinugatan (When the Heart Is Wounded), 1967. She was nominated Best Supporting Actress by the FAMAS for Babae, Ikaw ang Dahilan (Woman, You Are the Reason), 1972.  Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

Ricky Davao (Frederick Charles Davao) is a theater, film, and television actor, and television director. He was born in Manila on 23 Mar 1961. He is the son of veteran actor Charlie Davao and Emma Marie, and sibling to Bing, Mymy, Charlon, and Mylene Davao. Bing and Mymy are also actors. He married actor and television host Jackie Lou Blanco with whom he has three children: Rikki Mae, Kenneth, and Arabella.

Davao started his acting career in theater, appearing in countless stage productions, such as Martin Sherman’s Bent, Jesus Christ Superstar, and Henrik Ibsen’s Hedda Gabler. Alongside his film career, he remained active in theater, playing lead roles in Felipe de las Casas, Larawan (A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino), Rebecca Defensor, Biyaheng Timog (Trip to the North), the stage version of the film classic Insiang, and Ang Larawan, the musical version of A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino.

His first film appearance is in the 1981 film Totoo Ba ang Tsismis? (Is the Rumor True?), which was instantly followed by Rock ’n’ Roll and Ang Babae sa Ulog (The Woman in the Sleeping Quarters). Davao’s career spanned almost four decades, with supporting and lead roles in the following films: Sinner or Saint and Bulaklak sa City Jail (Flowers of the City Jail), 1984; White Slavery, 1985; Kung Aagawin Mo ang Lahat sa Akin (If You Will Take Everything from Me) and Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig? (Where Does Love Hide?), 1987; Isusumbong Kita sa Diyos (To God I Will Tell on You), 1988; Imortal (Immortal), 1989; Kahit Konting Pagtingin (Just a Little Love), 1990; Kakambal Ko sa Tapang (My Twin in Bravery), 1993; Eskapo: The Sergio Osmeña–Geny Lopez Story (Fugitive), 1995; Kristo (Christ), 1996; Ang Lalaki sa Buhay ni Selya (The Man in Her Life), 1997; Bayaning 3rd World (Third World Hero), 1999; Azucena, 2000; American Adobo, 2001; Crying Ladies, 2003; La Visa Loca (Crazy Visa), 2005; Tukso (Temptation), 2007; Sabungero (The Cockfighter), 2009; Paglipad ng Anghel (Flight of an Angel), 2011; Porno, 2013; and Baka Siguro Yata (Perhaps, Maybe, Supposedly), 2015.

Davao also appeared on television in several episodes of the drama anthology Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 1999-2011, and series like Lupin, 2007, Darna, 2009-10, and Second Chance, 2015. He also directed episodes for GMA Network’s Magpakailanman (Forever), 2012-15, and drama series like Coffee Prince, 2012; Adarna and Forever, 2013; Dading, 2014; and Little Nanay (Little Mother), 2015.

Davao won the Gawad Urian as Best Supporting Actor for Ipaglaban Mo (Redeem Her Honor), 1995. He received Best Actor awards for Saranggola (The Kite), 1999, from the Cinemanila International Film Festival, the Gawad Urian, and the Star Awards for Movies. The Film Academy of the Philippines named him Best Actor for Minsan May Isang Puso (Once There Was a Heart), 2001.  Written by Mario Mendez Jr

Joel David (Jose Hernani Segovia David) is an essayist, film critic, and educator. He was born in Manila on 19 Dec 1958. His parents are Demetrio David and Prescy Segovia. He finished his secondary education at the University of the Philippines (UP) High School. He obtained his bachelor’s degree in journalism, cum laude, 1979, and bachelor’s degree in film, cum laude, 1986, both at the UP, and his master’s (as a Fulbright-Hays full-grant scholar) and doctorate degrees in cinema studies at the New York University in 1994 and 2002, respectively.

David was head of the writers’ section of the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines, 1982-86. He was a member and corporate secretary of the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino, 1980-85, and was a founding member of Kritika, 1990-92. At the UP Department of Film and Audiovisual Communication (later UP Film Institute), he was initially an instructor, 1987-94, then assistant professor, 2008-12, and associate professor, 2002-11, handling both undergraduate and graduate courses. He worked on finalizing the proposal to merge UP Film Center and the College of Mass Communication Film Department into the UP Film Institute, of which he became the founding director, 2002-04. He was a visiting faculty at Hallym University School of Communication in South Korea, 2004-07, and has lectured in various universities like the Lyceum of the Philippines in Manila, 1986-87, and the Yonsei University, 2005, and Inha University, 2006-07, both in South Korea.

His book, The National Pastime: Contemporary Philippine Cinema, 1990, received favorable reviews in the country and abroad, and was on the National Book Award shortlist for essay writing. He also authored Fields of Vision: Critical Applications in Recent Philippine Cinema, 1995, and Wages of Cinema: Film in Philippine Perspective, 1998. David also maintains a film and culture blog, Amateurish!, which has released digital editions of Fields of Vision and Wages of Cinema, both in 2014, as well as his other digital publications like Book Texts: A Pinoy Film Course and Millennial Traversals: Outliers, Juvenilia, & Quondam Popcult Blabbery, both in 2015.

As editor, David worked on the Aug 2012, Aug 2013, and Aug 2015 editions of Kritika Kultura. He also edited Huwaran/Hulmahan Atbp.: The Film Writings of Johven Velasco, 2009. He has also contributed various articles in The Urian Anthology 1970-1979, 1983, The Urian Anthology 1980-1989, 2001, and The Urian Anthology 1990-1999, 2010, as well as in Philippine Studies, 2008, and Cinema Filipinas: Historia, teoría, y crítica fílmica (1999-2009), 2010.

Fields of Vision won the National Book Award for Film Criticism from the Manila Critics Circle in 1996 while Wages of Cinema received the UP Centennial Book Award in 2008. Since 2013, David has been residing in Incheon, Korea where he works as a professor for cultural studies at the Inha University.  Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Elmer L. Gatchalian

Sheron Dayoc (Sheron Rebollos Dayoc) is a film director, cinematographer, and editor. He was born in Zamboanga City on 12 Jan 1981. His parents are Jovito Dayoc and Nydia Rebollos. He finished a bachelor’s degree in philosophy at Ateneo de Zamboanga University in 2001. He took workshops in various fields of filmmaking at the Mowelfund Film Institute, University of the Philippines Film Institute, and Jesuit Communications at Ateneo de Zamboanga University. Dayoc also attended the Asian Film Academy at the 2008 Busan International Film Festival and the NEXT Master Class of the 2010 Tokyo FILMeX. He is the founder of Southern Lantern Studios, a creative group and production company for multimedia short and long films and videos.

Most of Dayoc’s documentary and feature films have revolved around the marginalized peoples and tribes of Mindanao. He has done documentaries on them for international and local nongovernment organizations.

His short films Angan-Angan (Dreams), about a mute nine-year-old Yakan girl who is determined to pursue an education for herself in spite of the objections of her traditional parents, and the experimental Trails of Water, about a boy who makes a living by fetching water near a mining site, were two of the 10 short films chosen to compete in the 2008 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. His short film Mientras Su Durmida (As He Sleeps), 2012, about a married woman who wants to free herself from her paralyzed husband, won Best Director at the 2012 Cinemalaya and Best Film at the 2014 International Festival of Short Film “Short Form” in Serbia. Another short film is titled Hold-up, 2013.

His debut feature-length film, Halaw (Ways of the Sea), 2010, which uncovers illegal human trafficking on the seas of Southern Philippines to Malaysia, won Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, and Best Editing at the 2010 Cinemalaya. In 2011, it won the Best Picture award at the New York Hell’s Kitchen Film Festival, the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) Development Prize at the Asia Pacific Screen Awards, and a NETPAC Special Jury Mention at Berlin International Film Festival.

His full-length film Bukod Kang Pinagpala (Blessed Art Thou), 2015, is about a mother and daughter living in an old mansion who become more and more estranged from each other when the mother is consumed by religious fanaticism. The film won Best Production Design and Best Sound in the 2015 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival.

Women of the Weeping River, 2016, a feature film about two Muslim women who hope to undo the cycle of violence brought about by a blood feud generations ago, won Best Film, Best Actress, and Best Supporting Actor at the 2016 QCinema International Film Festival; Best Film and Best Director at the 2017 Gawad Urian; and Best Film at the 2017 Young Critics Circle Awards and 2017 War on Screen International Festival.

The Crescent Rising, 2015, is a full-length documentary on the interwoven portraits of women caught in the cross fire of contending military forces in Mindanao. It won Best Documentary at the 2015 QCinema International Film Festival, the 2016 Gawad Urian, and the 2016 Busan International Film Festival.  Written by Rica Arevalo, with notes from Nicanor G. Tiongson

Manet Dayrit (Ma. Martha Ines Araneta Dayrit) is a film editor. She was born in Makati City on 20 Jan 1969. Her parents are Jose Teodoro Dayrit Jr and Gloria Araneta. She is a mother to Jose Joaquin Dayrit. She graduated with a bachelor’s degree in communications at Ateneo de Manila University in 1990. She took further studies at the London International Film School in the art and technique of filmmaking from 1991 to 1993. She attended the executive development program of the Asian Institute of Management in 1999. Dayrit’s great grandfather, Toribio Teodoro, and her grandmother, Cecilia Teodoro-Dayrit, used to own the movie houses Vista on Claro M. Recto; Marta and Florence in Grace Park, Caloocan; and Palace, Prince, and Star in Iloilo from the 1950s to the 1970s. Her family also owned the iconic Manila Grand Opera House. Her distant cousins include Trina N. Dayrit, a television director, and Christine S. Dayrit, chair of the Cinema Evaluation Board.

For her first editing work in Antonio Jose Perez’s Mumbaki (Shaman), 1996, Dayrit won Best Editing at the 1997 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS). She shared Best Editing awards with co-editor Jess Navarro for Marilou Diaz-Abaya’s Jose Rizal, 1998, at the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF), and the PMPC Star Awards for Movies and the FAMAS in 1999. She also earned the Movie Editor of the Year award for Chito Roño’s Laro sa Baga (Playing with Fire), 2000, at the 17th PMPC Star Awards. She received a Best Editing award for Roño’s Yamashita: The Tiger’s Treasure, 2001, at the MMFF. For Maryo J. de los Reyes’s Magnifico, 2003, she won Best Editing at the PMPC Star Awards and the Golden Screen Awards in 2004. For Yam Laranas’s Sigaw (The Echo), she received Best Editing awards from the 2004 MMFF and 2005 Young Critics Circle. For Roño’s Sukob (The Wedding Curse), 2006, she won Movie Editor of the Year at the 2007 Star Awards. At the 2009 MMFF, she shared the Best Editing award with Efren Jarlego for Laurice Guillen’s I Love You, Goodbye, 2009.

Dayrit’s other films as editor are Carlos Siguion-Reyna’s Ang Lalaki sa Buhay ni Selya (The Man in Her Life), 1997; Mel Chionglo’s Lagarista (Film Cyclist), 2000; Roño’s Spirit Warriors, 2000; Dominique Zapata’s Mulawin: The Movie, 2005; Roño’s Caregiver, 2008; Peque Gallaga and Lore Reyes’s Sonata, 2013, and T’yanak (Changeling), 2014; Siguion-Reyna’s Hari ng Tondo (Where I Am King), 2014; and John Paul Su’s Toto, 2015.

Dayrit is the president and chief executive officer of Central Digital Lab, which specializes in the restoration and remastering of films. She is a member of the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board.  Written by Rica Arevalo

Neil Daza (Neil Gallardo Daza) is a cinematographer and photographer. He was born in Parañaque City on 8 Oct 1961. His parents are Colonel Juan C. Daza and Dhalia Gallardo (both deceased). Daza is married to Maria Reina Blacer and has a daughter, Maria Isabel. He finished his bachelor’s degree in advertising in 1985 at the University of Santo Tomas. After graduation, he became a painter and a photojournalist. In 1991, he attended a film production workshop at the Mowelfund Film Institute and became involved in cinematography.

He shot his first full-length film as a cinematographer in Chito Roño’s Laro sa Baga (Playing with Fire), 2000, followed by Spirit Warriors, 2000; Yamashita: The Tiger’s Treasure and La Vida Rosa (The Life of Rosa), 2001; Dekada ’70 (The 1970s), 2002; First Time and Spirit Warriors: The Shortcut, 2003; The Boobita Rose Story, Feng Shui, and segment 1 of BCUZ OF U, 2004; Coed Scandal and Reyna 2006; Emir, 2010; “Lost Command” segment of Shake, Rattle & Roll 14: The Invasion, 2012; Badil (Dynamite Fishing), 2013; and Feng Shui 2, 2014. Daza also actively worked on films for different directors: Seroks (Xerox), 2006; Ouija (The Séance), 2007; Sampaguita, National Flower, 2010; Ka Oryang (Comrade Oryang) and Sa Ilalim ng Tulay (Under the Bridge), 2011; Mamay Umeng (Mother Umeng), 2012; Bwaya (Crocodile), 2014; and Lakambini (Woman Leader), 2015.

Daza worked in television, lighting top-rated ABS-CBN shows such as Dream Dad, 2014-15; Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14; and several Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) episodes.

Yamashita: The Tiger’s Treasure earned him a Best Cinematography award at the Metro Manila Film Festival and the Young Critics Circle. Seroks won Best Cinematography at the 2006 Cinema One Originals Film Festival. Emir won Best Cinematography at the Film Academy of the Philippines, PMPC Star Awards, and Golden Screen Awards. Ka Oryang got the Best Cinematography award at the 2011 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival, and Bwaya won Best Cinematography at the 10th Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. He was one of the 20 Asian documentary photographers and filmmakers who was invited by the Gwangju Arts Council in South Korea to exhibit photographs and short films in a multimedia documentary exhibition, Conjunction Points, in 2005.  Written by Rica Arevalo

Janice de Belen (Catherine Janice Yap de Belen) is a film and television actor. She was born in Manila on 9 Nov 1968 to parents Philip de Belen and Susan Yap. She attended grade school at St. Theresa’s College and College of the Holy Spirit and obtained her secondary education through a home study program. She was formerly married to actor John Estrada with whom she has four children. She has a son by actor Aga Muhlach. Actor Gelli de Belen is her sister.

At the age of 11, she appeared on television playing the title role in the long-running afternoon soap opera Flordeluna, 1979-83. The popularity of the show helped her break into films. In 1980, she was given a minor role in Kasal? (Marriage?) and, in 1981, her first major role in Mga Basang Sisiw (Wet Chicks), directed by Agustin de la Cruz. Some of the films she starred in are I Will Wait for You and Home Sweet Home, 1983; Bakit Iisa Lamang ang Puso? (Why Is There Only One Heart?), 1989; Last Two Minutes and Flavor of the Month, 1990. Her other films include Pakasalan Mo Ako (Marry Me), 1991; Aswang (Mythological Ghoul), 1992; Maricris Sioson: Japayuki, 1993; The Fatima Buen Story, 1994; Araw-Araw, Gabi-Gabi (Every Day, Every Night), 1995; Hari ng Yabang (Cockiest Man Alive), 1997; Annie B., 2004; Last Viewing, 2009; Zombadings: Patayin sa Shokot si Remington (Remington and the Curse of the Zombadings), 2011; six of the fifteen films in the Shake, Rattle & Roll horror anthology franchise, as well as in Pridyider (Fridge), 2012, which was partly based on the original; Mga Mumunting Lihim (Those Little Secrets), 2012; and Call Center Girl, 2013.

De Belen later appeared in several television programs, such as GMA Network’s talent search Starstruck and Starstruck Kids, 2004, as judge; Darna, 2009-10; as co-host with sister Gelli de Belen and actor Carmina Villarroel in the talk show SiS, 2001-10; and Magic Palayok (Delicious Food), 2011. For ABS-CBN, she appeared in Familia Zaragoza (The Zaragoza Family), 1995; Budoy, 2011-12; Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Her Mother’s Daughter), 2012-13; Honesto, 2013-14; and Oh My G!, 2015.

De Belen was nominated Best Child Actress in Tropang Bulilit (Gang of Kids), 1980, by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS). She earned Best Supporting Actress nominations for Nasaan Ka Nang Kailangan Kita? (Where Were You When I Needed You?), 1986, from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP); for Isang Araw Walang Diyos (One Day without God), 1989, from the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA); and for Bakit Kay Tagal ng Sandali? (Why Is a Moment So Long?), 1990, from the FAMAS. She was nominated Best Actress for Abandonada (Abandoned Woman), 1989, by the PMPC Star Awards and for Rosenda, 1989, by the Gawad Urian, Star, FAP, and FAMAS. She earned her first Best Actress award from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Kailan Ka Magiging Akin? (When Will You Be Mine?), 1991. Tiktik: The Aswang Chronicles, 2012, won her the Best Supporting Actres award in the PMPC Star Awards for Movies. She earned Best Talk Show awards from the PMPC Star Awards for Television and the CMMA for Net 25’s Spoon, 2007-15, and SiS. Together with actors Judy Ann Santos, Iza Calzado, and Agot Isidro, de Belen won the Balanghai trophy for Best Ensemble award for Mga Mumunting Lihim in the 2012 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival.  Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Erika Carreon

Eduardo de Castro (Mervin Gardner) was a film and stage actor, and a film director. He was born circa 1912. He died on 17 Nov 1955. De Castro was an actor in silent films like Moro Pirates, 1931, and director of movies, which were mainly love stories and melodramas, in the 1930s and 1940s. His most outstanding prewar film was Zamboanga (Fury in Paradise), 1937. He worked for some of the leading studios of the period, including X’Otic Film Productions, Filippine Films, and Premiere Productions.

His earlier works include Anak ng Birhen (Child of the Virgin) released in 1935 through Filippine Films, starring Carlos Padilla and Rosa del Rosario; Bakas ng Kaaway (Traces of the Enemy), 1937, with Mari Velez and Fernando Poe Sr; Mga Tinik ng Isang Bulaklak (A Flower’s Thorns), 1939, with Lucita Goyena; Alaalang Banal (Sacred Memory), 1940; Bayani ng Buhay (Life’s Hero), 1941; and Bandilang Basahan (Tattered Flag), 1949. For Premiere Productions, he directed Ang Lumang Bahay sa Gulod (The Old House on the Cliff), 1949, one of the first fully colored films produced in the country. De Castro also acted on stage in the play Ang Batas na Ginto (The Golden Law), 1933, with bodabil actor Rita Rica. He was also paired with Mary Walter in Ang Gayuma (The Love Potion), 1932.  Written by Ramon Jocson and Marlon Wui

Pio de Castro III (Pio Manuel de Castro III) was a film and theater actor and director, screenwriter, copywriter, educator, and essayist. He was born in Manila on 4 May 1943. He died on 22 Mar 2001. He was the son of Pio G. de Castro Sr, an economist and journalist, and Elena G. Manuel. He married actor Joy Soler. He studied at the St. John’s Academy before going to Ateneo de Manila University where he finished a bachelor’s degree in English, 1963. A writer even in high school, de Castro eventually became a TV scriptwriter and wrote advertising copy for J. Walter Thompson Co. In 1967, he studied film production, TV, and theater on a Fulbright-Hays Scholarship at Michigan’s Wayne State University, where he obtained a master’s degree in mass communication, 1969. Upon his return in 1970, he joined the Philippine Educational Theate Association (PETA). Later he joined Image Films Inc, a TV commercial production outfit. He worked with Image Films Inc for 20 years, and was its senior vice president. De Castro lectured on film studies, acting, direction, and criticism at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Mass Communication and other schools. He is a founding member of the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino. He used to run a column for the Manila Chronicle.

On stage and for PETA, he appeared as the Senator in Malou Jacob’s Aidao and the Husband in Amador Daguio’s Adongan, both in 1972; and as Trabahador in Bertolt Brecht’s Ang Hatol ng Guhit na Bilog (The Caucasian Chalk Circle) and a Goon in Bienvenido Noriega Jr’s Artista sa Palengke (Movie Star in the Market), 1977. For Tanghalang Pilipino (TP), he played the title role of Paul Dumol’s Francisco Maniago, 1989, and Kosteilyov in Lusak (Maxim Gorky’s Lower Depths ) and Bitoy in Nonon Padilla’s Larawan ng Pilipino Bilang Artist(a) (spoof of Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino), both in 1990. He also directed two of Bienvenido Noriega Jr’s plays for TP: Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), 1987, and Bayan-bayanan (Little Country), 1989.

He appeared in Lino Brocka movies such as Tatlo, Dalawa, Isa (Three, Two, One), 1974, and Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light ). Other movies which he appeared in are May Isang Tsuper ng Taksi (There Was a Taxi Driver), 1975; Mga Uod at Rosas (Worms and Roses), 1982; and Dreaming Filipinos, 1991. He directed the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines’s Soltero (Bachelor) in 1984 and Seiko Films’ Ina, Kasusuklaman Ba Kita? (Mother, Should I Despise You?) in 1985.

As director of film and TV documentaries and drama anthologies, he won Best Drama Story in the television category of the Catholic Mass Media Awards for his Pira-pirasong Pangarap (Shattered Dreams) drama series, 1983. As a director for TV commercials, he won numerous awards at the Philippine Advertising Congress, 1976-83, and recognition at such international competitions as the Clio Awards in the United States and the All Japan Film-TV-Radio Awards.   Written by Malou L. Maniquis, updated by Athena Angela Aquino

Joseph de Cordova (Joseph Santiago Garner), also known as Jose de Cordova, was a film actor and screenwriter. He was born in Bongabon, Nueva Ecija on 27 Aug 1918. He died in Quezon City on 16 Dec 1990. His parents are Geronima Santiago and Allen Garner, a Turkish lawyer. He was married to Demetria Revagorda, by whom he had seven children. His daughter, Louella de Cordova, was a TV newscaster for People’s Television Network (Channel 4) and is also a television actor. A consistent scholar in high school, de Cordova took up law courses at National University, then shifted to journalism but did not go beyond his junior year.

In the 1940s, he entered show business as a singer in stage shows at the Royal Theater, together with actor Gil de Leon. He met film director Gregorio Fernandez who introduced him to Doña Sisang de Leon, producer of LVN Pictures. He became the company’s favorite character actor. Working under the best directors of the time—Gregorio Fernandez, Lamberto V. Avellana, and Manuel Silos—he appeared in such memorable films as Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956; Badjao, 1957; and Biyaya ng Lupa (Blessings of the Land) and Kundiman ng Lahi (Love Song of the Race), 1959. He played important roles in Gerardo de Leon’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1961, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1962.

As a screenwriter, he wrote the following movies: Sarung-Banggi (One Night), 1947; Pilipino Kostum No Touch (Filipino Custom No Touch), 1955; Abandonado (Abandoned), 1956; Kalyehera (Street-walker) and Troop 11, 1957; Kung Ako'y Mahal Mo (If You Love Me), 1960; Prinsipe Diomedes at ang Mahiwagang Gitara (Prince Diomedes and the Mysterious Guitar), 1961; Sagot Kita (I Got Your Back), 1962; and Mr. Wong, 1963.  

In 1970, de Cordova took on a job as salesman for Collier’s Encyclopedia, becoming manager in a month’s time. He was assigned to Mindanao and briefly stayed in Davao City. Returning to Manila, de Cordova resumed his career as a character actor. He also acted in an episode of the drama anthology Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember). His last movie, Kasalanan ang Buhayin Ka (It's a Sin to Keep You Alive), was released in 1990.

Though he never received any acting award, de Cordova was a perennial Best Supporting Actor nominee of the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Awards. He earned his first three FAMAS nominations for Lamberto V. Avellana’s Huk sa Bagong Pamumuhay (Huk in a New Life), Dagohoy, and Sa Paanan ng Bundok (At the Foot of the Mountain), all in 1953. He was also nominated as Best Supporting Actor by the FAMAS for Kundiman ng Lahi. He also received FAMAS nominations in the Best Story and Best Screenplay categories for Kung Ako’y Mahal Mo (If You Love Me), 1960.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

Armando de Guzman was a film director and screenwriter. He was born in Intramuros, Manila on 14 Jun 1920. He died on 13 Dec 1984. He was married to Luz de Guzman, with whom he had eight children, including film director Armando de Guzman Jr and musical director Lito de Guzman.

De Guzman started out as screenwriter and soon directed his own scripts as well. Among his earlier works as writer and director are Carmelita and Isang Dakot na Bigas (A Handful of Rice), both released in 1947. He directed more than 60 films until 1982.

De Guzman won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Director award for Sapagkat Kami’y Tao Lamang (For We Are Only Human), 1963. He was nominated by the FAMAS as Best Director for Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels Without Heaven), 1970.  Written by Rosalie Matilac

Benjie de Guzman (Benjamin Clamor de Guzman Jr) was a film and television production designer. He was born in Manila on 19 Feb 1955. He was the son of Benjamin de Guzman Sr, a civil engineer, and Aida Clamor, a teacher. A broadcast communication graduate at the University of the Philippines, he acted in theater and did productions for Dulaang Babaylan in 1973-76. He was president of the Production Designers Guild of the Philippines from 1986 to 1988.

De Guzman began in the movies as assistant production designer to Mel Chionglo in Aguila, 1980. When Chionglo became a director, de Guzman became a full-fledged production designer in Chionglo’s Playgirl, 1981. Some of the movies he designed are Summer Love, 1981; Init sa Magdamag (Midnight Passion), 1983; Kung Mahawi Man ang Ulap (Should the Skies Clear) and Working Girls, 1984; Kapag Puso’y Sinugatan (When the Heart Is Wounded), 1985; and the Lino Brocka films Macho Dancer and Natutulog Pa ang Diyos (God Is Still Asleep), 1988; Babangon Ako’t Dudurugin Kita (I Will Rise and Crush You) and Orapronobis (Fight for Us), 1989; Gumapang Ka sa Lusak (Dirty Affair), 1990; Kislap sa Dilim (Spark in the Dark), Sa Kabila ng Lahat (Despite Everything), and Makiusap Ka sa Diyos (Plead with God), 1991. He also designed Darna, 1991, Shake, Rattle & Roll V, 1994, and Yaya & Angelina: The Spoiled Brat Movie, 2009. Other notable films he designed include Ishmael Bernal's Relasyon, 1982, and Working Girls, 1984; Mario O'Hara's The Fatima Buen Story, 1994; Jose Javier Reyes's May Minamahal (Loving Someone), 1993, and Batang PX (Phil-American Boy), 1997; and Chito Roño's Babae sa Bintana (Girl in the Window), 1998. 

As a production designer for television, de Guzman worked on the drama series Kung Aagawin Mo Ang Langit (If You Take Heaven Away), 2011-12, for GMA Network. 

He received production design awards for Ano ang Kulay ng Mukha ng Diyos? (What Is the Color of God’s Face?), 1985, from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF); Nasaan Ka Nang Kailangan Kita? (Where Were You When I Needed You?), 1986, from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP); Sa Kabila ng Lahat, from Gawad Urian; May Minamahal, from the MMFF and FAP; and Bulaklak ng Maynila (Flower of Manila), 1999, from FAP and PMPC Star Awards for Movies. In 1995, de Guzman shared with cinematographer Romulo Araojo the Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design award for The Fatima Buen Story, from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk.  Written by Rosalie Matilac, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

Constancio de Guzman (Constancio Canseco de Guzman) was a music composer and film scorer. He was born in Guiguinto, Bulacan on 11 Nov 1903. He died in Manila on 16 Aug 1982. He was the son of Higino de Guzman, a writer in Spanish, and Margarita Canseco. He married Leonor Buensuceso with whom he had six children. He was the grandson of fictionist Severino Reyes, nephew of Tagalog fictionist and poet Lope K. Santos, and brother of film director and screenwriter Susana de Guzman. During his boyhood, he studied piano and composition under Nicanor S. Abelardo, but his father sent him to law school. Later he switched to commerce and finished business administration in 1931. After passing the Certified Public Accountancy board examinations, he started working in the movies, together with his sister Susana. He wrote numerous pieces of music for films beginning 1931, becoming one of the earliest, if the not the first, Filipino musical director for the movies. He composed music for the films of Sampaguita, LVN, Royal, Lea, National, X'Otic, Excelsior, and Tagalog Ilang-Ilang.

One of de Guzman’s compositions, “Panaginip” (Dream), became a big hit by accident. His father heard Constancio play the song and had it published, thinking it was the composition of a friend. It sold by the thousands, and the father was surprised to learn it was his own son’s work. Since then de Guzman has recorded hundreds of songs, principally under Vicor Records and Columbia Records. De Guzman was at one time director of Villar Records. He was also musical director in many music companies in the Philippines and served as a director of Filipino Society of Composers, Arrangers, and Publishers (FILSCAP).

Some of de Guzman’s notable compositions are: "Bayan Ko" (My Country), "Babalik Ka Rin" (You Will Come Back), "Ang Tangi Kong Pag-ibig" (My Only Love), “Birheng Walang Dambana” (Virgin Without a Shrine), "Pamaypay ng Maynila" (Manila Fan), “Lambingan” (Tender Caressing), “Ang Pag-ibig Ko’y Ikaw” (You are My Love), and "Maalaala Mo Kaya?" (Will You Remember?). He also composed music for the following movies: Arimunding-munding, Señorita (Miss), Sarung Banggi (One Night), Probinsyana (Provincial Lass), Darna, Roberta, and Ikaw ang Aking Buhay (You Are My Life) where he won the Best Musical Scorer award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 1959. He was also named the Best Composer and Lyricist in the 1969 Awit Awards.

In the EDSA Revolution of 1986, de Guzman’s song, “Bayan Ko” became the symbolic anthem of the Filipino people that represented their sentiments and eagerness to be freed from the Marcos's dictatorship. This resonated with the earlier purpose for which the song was written, as a hopeful expression of independence from the Americans. The song was incorporated into the restaging of Severino Reyes’s sarsuwela, Walang Sugat (No Wounds) in 1970. The Tagalog lyrics were written by Jose Corazon de Jesus. “Bayan Ko” won for de Guzman the gold medal at the Paris International Fair of 1948, together with his other song, “Kung Kita’y Kapiling” (When I’m With You). “Bayan Ko” has also been used in the Lino Brocka film Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim (My Country: Gripping the Knife’s Edge), 1985; in the TV documentary EDSA 25: Sulyap ng Kasaysayan (EDSA 25: A Glimpse of History), 2011; and in the movies Don’t Give Up on Us, 2006, Pisay, 2007, and Noy, 2010.

His other famous song, “Maalala Mo Kaya?”, was used by ABS-CBN for their TV series of the same title, which started in 1991 and is hosted by Charo Santos. Maalaala Mo Kaya is considered the longest running drama anthology in the Philippines to date.

De Guzman also acted for the movies, appearing in Huling Dalangin (Last Prayer), 1948, and Hiyas ng Pamilihan (Gem of the Marketplace), 1949.   Written by Flerida G. Nolasco, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

Mes de Guzman (Ramon Navarro de Guzman) is a fictionist, screenwriter, film director, and producer. He was born in Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya on 1 Dec 1971. He is married to Rhea Operaña. His parents are Ben G. de Guzman and Rosalina Navarro. He has a bachelor of arts in creative writing from the University of the Philippines Diliman.

De Guzman jumpstarted his film career with a 15-minute short film, Batang Trapo (Rags), 2001, winner of L’Etoile d’Or (Golden Star) for short film at the 2002 Marrakech Film Festival, Morocco. The film stars two street children selling rags, trying to survive in chaotic Manila.

He directed Ang Daan Patungong Kalimugtong (The Road to Kalimugtong), 2005, winner of Best Picture at the 2007 Festival de Cine de los Pueblos, Valenzuela. In the local front, it won Best Picture (Digital) at the 2006 Golden Screen Awards, Jury Prize for Best Picture at the 2005 Cinemanila International Film Festival, and Best Director at the 2006 Gawad Urian.

His Balikbayan Box, 2008, was supported by the Hubert Bals Fund (Rotterdam, Netherlands) in 2007. Sa Kanto ng Ulap at Lupa (Of Skies and Earth) won the Gawad Lino Brocka and Best Director at the 2011 Cinemanila International Film Festival.

In the 2012 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, de Guzman’s Diablo (Demon) won major awards in the New Breed category—namely, Best Picture, Best Director, Best Cinematography, Best Actress, and the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Prize.

Ang Kwento ni Mabuti (The Story of Mabuti), 2013, stars Nora Aunor as a faith healer who accidentally finds a bag with millions of cash and undergoes moral dilemma on whether to keep the money for her family or return it to the authorities. It won the awards for Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Screenplay at the 2013 CineFilipino Film Festival.

His other films include Tres Mundos (The Earth Trilogy), which includes Ang Mundo sa Panahon ng Yelo (Ice is the Earth) and Ang Mundo sa Panahon ng Bato (Stone is the Earth), 2010, and Ang Mundo sa Panahon ng Bakal (Steel is the Earth), 2013; Divina Gracia (Divine Grace), 2015; and Dyamper (Jumper) and Karatula (Signboard), 2016.

De Guzman actively promotes regional filmmaking by setting most of his films in his hometown, Nueva Viscaya.

For his short stories, de Guzman won four prizes at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature. His unpublished novel, Rancho Dyanggo, received the Writer’s Prize from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2004.  Written by Rica Arevalo

Susana C. de Guzman (Susana Canseco de Guzman-Astudillo) was a film director, screenwriter, fictionist, and radio dramatist. She was born in Binondo, Manila on 24 May 1912. She died in 1992. She was the daughter of Higino de Guzman and Margarita Canseco. She was the brother of composer Constancio C. de Guzman and the niece of writers Severino Reyes and Lope K. Santos. She married Antonio Astudillo, a reporter who later became the actor-director, Tony Arnaldo. She studied at Far Eastern University. She was a member of the literary groups 12 Panitik and Ilaw at Panitik.

She wrote scores of popular romantic novels, mostly for Liwayway, Tagumpay, Aliwan, and Ilang-ilang. Among these are Ang Pag-ibig ng Isang Ina (The Love of a Mother), Makalawang Ikinasal (Married Twice), Ave Maria, and Kalapating Puti (White Dove), all in 1938; Anak Ko (My Child) and Arimunding-Munding, 1939; Dalawang Bulaklak (Two Flowers), 1940; Ang Probinsyana (The Country Girl), Intramuros, and Bagong Buhay, all in 1945; Hara-kiri, Ilang-ilang, Traje de Boda (Wedding Ensemble), Ang Payaso (The Jester), and Romansa (Romance), all in 1946; Himala ng Birhen (Miracle of the Virgin), Pag-ibig na Walang Kasal (Love without Marriage), and Ang Pamana ng Tulisan (A Bandit’s Legacy), all in 1947; Biyernes 13 (Friday the 13th), 1950; Anak ng Pulubi (A Beggar’s Child) and Yolanda, 1951; Pilya (Naughty Girl), 1953; Kubrador ng Hueteng (Jueteng Collector), 1955; Ang Sumpaan Natin (Our Pledge) and Namumukod na Bituin (Special Star), 1960; Sa Puso ni Bathala (In God’s Heart), 1961; Magbayad ang May Utang (Those Who Owe Must Pay), 1962; Mayon and Labanan ng mga Sukat (Fight of the Veterans), 1969; Kumakaway Ka Pa, Irog (You Were Waving, Darling), 1970; Ibig Ko Pang Mabuhay (I Still Want to Live) and Pasko na Naman (It’s Christmas Again), 1971. She also published many stories.

De Guzman’s scripts for the movies are usually comedies with social messages or romantic melodramas. She adapted many of her novels into screenplays, among them Kalapating Puti, 1938; Namumukod na Bituin and Arimunding-Munding, 1939; Ave Maria, 1940; Anak ng Pulubi, 1951; Pilya, 1954; and Ang Sumpaan Natin, 1960. Her other screenplays include Pasang Krus (Cross on the Shoulder) and Azucena, 1939; Princesa ng Kumintang (Princess of Kumintang), Sawing Gantimpala (Lost Victory), and Ikaw Rin (You, Too), 1940; Ibong Sawi (Forlorn Bird) and Paraluman (Muse), 1941; Alaala Kita (Thinking of You), 1946; Ang Kamay ng Diyos (The Hand of God), 1947; Tenyente Carlos Blanco (Lt Carlos Blanco), 1952; Tumbalik na Daigdig (Topsy-Turvy World), 1953; Anak ng Berdugo (Executioner’s Son) and Dalagita’t Binatilyo (Young Boy and Girl), 1955; Society Girl, 1956; Veronica and Topo-Topo, 1957; Alaalang Banal (Sacred Memory), 1958; and Debutante (Debutant), 1959.

She directed her first film at Premiere Productions titled Probinsyana (Country Girl) in 1946, starring Rosa del Rosario and Jose Padilla Jr, but she did most of her films for LVN Pictures, among them Romansa (Romance), Violeta, Himala ng Birhen sa Antipolo (The Miracle of the Virgin of Antipolo) and Sarung Banggi (One Night), 1947; Sumpaan (Pledge), Hampas ng Langit (Heaven’s Wrath), and Huling Dalangin (Last Prayer), 1948; Milyonaria (Millionairess), Makabagong Pilipina (Modern Filipina), Camelia, starring Carmen Rosales and Rogelio de la Rosa, Lupang Pangako (Promised Land), starring Leopoldo Salcedo and Mila del Sol, 1949; Mahal Mo Ba Ako? (Do You Love Me?) and Tininti del Barrio (Barrio Lieutenant), 1950; Tapis Mo Inday (Your Overskirt, Inday) and Reyna Elena (Queen Helen), 1951; Correccional (Correctional), 1952; Sa Paanan ng Bundok (At the Foot of the Mountain) and Kuwintas ng Pasakit (Necklace of Suffering), 1953; Pasiya ng Langit (Heaven’s Will) and Hiram na Kasintahan (Borrowed Sweetheart), 1954; Sonny Boy and Banal o Makasalanan (Holy or Sinful), 1955, starring Mario Montenegro and Delia Razon; Among Tunay (True Master), Ilaw sa Karimlan (Light in Darkness), and Ulilang Bituin (Lonely Star), 1956; Ay Pepita, Villa Milagrosa, and Limang Dalangin (Five Prayers), 1958, the last starring Nida Blanca and Charito Solis; Ang Langit Ko’y Ikaw (You Are My Heaven) and Cover Girl, 1959; Black Beauty, Si Marita at ang Pitong Duwende (Marita and the Seven Dwarves), Dahlia, and Unos sa Laot (Storm in the Open Sea), 1960; and Sa Puso ni Bathala, 1961. For Sampaguita Pictures she directed Magbayad ang May Utang and Bulung-Bulungan (Rumors), 1962.

Her novel Ang Pamana ng Tulisan won first prize in the Liwayway novel writing contest, while her story “Ang Kanilang Lihim” (Their Secret) was anthologized in 50 Kuwentong Ginto ng 50 Batikang Kuwentista (50 Golden Stories by 50 Great Storytellers), 1939. In 1991 she received the Natatanging Gawad Urian from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

Jose Corazon de Jesus (Jose Cecilio Ramon Augo Pangilinan de Jesus), also known as Huseng Batute, Corazon, Huseng Katuwa, Anastacio Salagubang, Sundalong Lasing, Pepito Matimtiman, Viterbi, Ilaw, Paruparong Asul, Bayaning May Sugat, was a poet, theater actor, screenwriter, and playwright. He was born in Santa Cruz, Manila on 22 Nov 1894. He died on 26 May 1932. He was the second of three children of Vicente de Jesus of Santa Maria, Bulacan, and Susana Pangilinan of Pampanga. His brother Vicente de Jesus Jr was a poet in Spanish. He married Asuncion Lacdan in 1918, with whom he had three children. He grew up in Santa Maria, Bulacan, finished high school at the Liceo de Manila, and took up a law at the Escuela de Derecho. He also studied humanities, Italian opera, and piano at the University of the Philippines.

De Jesus did not pursue law as a profession and instead became a newspaperman. Beginning 1920, he ran the column "Buhay Maynila" (Manila Life) in the Taliba, using the pseudonym Huseng Batute. Later, he did a daily column, "Mga Lagot na Bagting ng Kudyapi" (Broken Chords of the Kudyapi), also in Taliba, and another column, "Mga Butlig ng Panahon" (Wens of Time), 1922, in weekly Liwayway. He edited Sampaguita and together with Florentino Collantes and Amado V. Hernandez, turned it into a magazine of exceptional quality. His columns showed him as a fierce patriot, inveighing against mendicancy to the United States and discrimination against Filipinos, praising the founding of the Bagong Katipunan and student rallies against abusive American teachers, and mounting a crusade to popularize locally made shoes, the barong tagalog, and Philippine songs. He was, however, unsuccessful in politics, failing in both of his attempts to become mayor of Santa Maria.

One of the foremost personalities of Ilaw at Panitik, de Jesus was a prominent literary figure among the older generation of writers like Lope K. Santos, Benigno Ramos, Iñigo Ed. Regalado, Rosauro Almario, and Pedro Gatmaitan. His works—in style, subject matter, and form—embodied the flowering of the Filipino literary movement named after Francisco Balagtas, balagtasismo. As early as 1912, one of his poems was published in The Reformer, bearing the romantic and lyrical style that would become his trademark. His poetry is melodic and poignant. Among his famous poems are “Ang Manok Kong Bulik” (My Speckled Rooster), 1919; “Ang Pagbabalik” (The Return), 1924; “Ang Pamana” (The Legacy), 1925; “Pag-ibig” (Love), 1926; “Manggagawa” (Worker), 1929; and “Isang Punongkahoy” (A Tree), 1932. He contributed poems to Taliba, Ang Mithi, Bagong Lipang Kalabaw, and Sampaguita. His poetry collection Mga Dahong Ginto (Golden Leaves) was published in 1920.

A colorful figure, he became Hari ng Balagtasan. The balagtasan was a poetic joust. De Jesus often won against his foremost opponent, Florentino Collantes. He and Collantes clashed on the topics “Paruparo at Bubuyog” (Butterfly and Bee), “Bakal at Ginto” (Steel and Gold), and, most famous of all, “Ang Dalaga Kahapon at ang Dalaga Ngayon (The Maiden of Yesterday and the Maiden of Today). He also debated with Pedro Gatmaitan on “Guro at Nars” (Teacher and Nurse), and later on “España at Amerika” (Spain and America). He and Amado V. Hernandez also did a balagtasan in print. Due in part to de Jesus, balagtasan became so popular that in 1934, Balagtasan on the Air began airing on KZRH. De Jesus had already died by then so Collantes became the program’s primary mambabalagtas, with Emilio Mar. Antonio, Jose Domingo Karasig, Epifania Alvarez, and other mambabalagtas.

De Jesus composed lyrics for songs, such as Constancio de Guzman’s "Bayan Ko" (My Country), Gregorio Pablo’s “Maawa Ka” (Have Pity), Lorenzo Fajardo’s “Una Kong Pag-ibig” (My First Love), Leon Ignacio’s “Masayang Dalaga” (Happy Maiden) and “Bakit Ka Lumuluha?” (Why Are You Weeping?), Miguel Trinidad’s “Ang Lambing Mo” (You Are So Loving), Gerardo Enriquez’s “Pusong Wasak” (Broken Heart), C. Ortanez’s “Luha ni Juan de la Cruz” (Tears of Juan de la Cruz), Luis del Barrio’s “Pananalig sa Pilipinas” (Faith in the Philippines) and “Kalayaan” (Freedom), Crispino Reyes’s “Arimundingmunding,” Francisco Santiago’s "Pakiusap" (Plea), and Nicanor S. Abelardo’s “Kundiman ng Luha” (Love Song of Tears).

His strong patriotism and social consciousness emerge in his literary works. His narrative poem, Sa Dakong Silangan (In the East), 1928, is a nationalist allegory that denounces American imperialist interests. In “Ang mga Itinapon ng Kapalaran” (Discarded by Fate), 1920, and “Maruming Basahan” (Dirty Rag), 1931, he touched on social problems.

He wrote scripts for and acted in movies like Oriental Blood, 1930, and Sa Pinto ng Langit (Heaven’s Door), 1931. He also acted in stage plays like Cirio A. Panganiban’s Veronidia, with Atang de la Rama in 1925.

He was crowned Hari ng Balagtasan in the 1920s, and awarded the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan posthumously by the city government of Manila in 1971.   Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson and Florentino Hornedo

Vincent de Jesus (Vincent Abenojar de Jesus), also known as Vince de Jesus, is a music composer, film and television scorer, librettist, musical director, and teacher, and a theater, television, and film actor. He was born in Manila on 10 Jun 1968. He is the son of Ariston de Jesus and Delia Abenojar. He majored in piano and voice for his music degree from University of the Philippines Diliman. He is an active member of the Writer’s Bloc; Playwrights Fellowship; Filipino Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (FILSCAP); and Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA).

When he was starting as a music scorer, de Jesus made his works for films with his mentor and associate composer Lutgardo Labad.
