Such works include Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), 1985; Joey Boy Munti: 15 Anyos Ka sa Muntinlupa (Joey Boy Munti: You Have 15 Years in Muntinlupa), 1991; Dinampot Ka Lang sa Putik (You’re Just Picked Up from the Mud), 1991; and Makiusap Ka sa Diyos (Plead with God), 1991.

De Jesus received Best Musical Score award for La Visa Loca (Crazy Visa), 2005, in the Gawad Urian, and for Let the Love Begin, 2005, in the PMPC Star Awards for Movies. His music for Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Moveeh (Zsazsa Zaturnnah: The Movie), 2006, received recognition from various award-giving bodies, like the PMPC Star Awards for Movies, Gawad Urian, and Film Academy of the Philippines. De Jesus received more music score awards for films like Pisay (Philippine Science High School), 2007; Baler, 2008; Ang Babae sa Septic Tank (The Woman in the Septic Tank), 2011; and I Do Bidoo Bidoo: Heto nAPO Sila! (I Do Bidoo Bidoo: The APO Is Here!), 2012.

De Jesus also worked for television and theater productions. He was the lyricist, composer, and musical scorer for ABS-CBN’s show Kokey @ Ako (Kokey and I), 2010; composer, theme song lyricist, and arranger for the television series Wako Wako, 2012; composer for the fantasy melodrama Mirabella, 2014, and for the comedy-drama television series Dream Dad, 2014. De Jesus’s theater credits include being the composer, musical director, and lyricist of Himala: The Musical (Miracle: The Musical), 2003, based on the 1982 Ishmael Bernal film; composer, musical director, and lyricist for When Snow Falls, 2003, which was performed at the Hong Kong Cultural Center with the Chung Ying Theater Company; and lyricist, composer, and musical director of the stage adaptation of Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Muzikal, 2006. Notable recognitions that he received include a Carlos Palanca Memorial Award for Literature for his one-act comedy play Ateng (Sister), 2005; Best Original Libretto for Skin-Deep and Best Musical Direction for Batang Rizal (Young Rizal), 2008, from the 1st Gawad Buhay Philstage Awards for Theater; Best Original Libretto, Best Original Composition, and Best Musical Production for Si Juan Tamad … (Lazy Juan …), 2009, from the 2nd Gawad Buhay Philstage Awards; Best Original Libretto, Musical Direction, and Musical Production for Care Divas, 2011, from the 4th Gawad Buhay Philstage Awards for Theater; and Best Original Filipino Musical Championship from the PAGCOR Nationwide Musical Competition for Ang Bahag-hari sa Buhay ni Pinoy 620-6819 (The Rainbow in the Life of the Filipino 620-6819), 2010, for which he was credited as writer, librettist, composer, music director, and co-director. In 2015, de Jesus released his own album titled Songs to Slash Your Wrist By, a collection of love songs. His works were also showcased in his own concert, Demented, Delightful, Deranged, 2015, which was part of the Triple Threat concert series of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.  Written by Gregory del Carmen

Katy de la Cruz (Catalina Mangahas de la Cruz) was a stage and film actor, and singer. She was born in Intramuros, Manila on 13 Feb 1907. She died on 10 Nov 2004. She was the daughter of Juan de la Cruz and Infanta Mangahas. She married Jose Yoingco. She dropped out of school after the first grade and concentrated on singing—for anybody, anywhere. She sang between fights at the cockpit, and with brass bands during fiestas for patron saints. At one of these fiestas, theater owner Henry Brown heard her and whisked her away to start a singing career at the age of seven. Her first contract called for singing between movie intermissions, for a starting salary of three pesos a week for three nights. Ambitious, she realized that she would have to stop being the “Sophie Tucker of the Philippines” and develop her own singing style. At the age of 13, she was well on her way to becoming the “Queen of Bodabil,” a title that no one has challenged. As torch singer, she is best remembered for her naughty renditions of "Balut" (Duck’s Egg), “Saging ni Pacing” (Pacing’s Banana), and “A Tear Fell.” She continued to perform for many years in the United States where she later resided with her family.

She performed with the stars of the period: Diana Toy, Hanasan, Dimples, and the “Queen of Kundiman” herself, Atang de la Rama. Later, de la Cruz began singing on her own at the Savoy, Palace, and Lux movie houses, with chorus girls who became movie stars, such as Patsy, Chuchi, Etang Discher, Rosa Aguirre, Chichay, the Custodio Sisters, and Mary Walter. At 18, she was the highest paid star, earning 150 pesos at the Savoy.

In 1957, she went on a Southeast Asian tour. She also sang in the Pacific region, the United States, Hong Kong, China, and Australia. In 1961, she starred in a Las Vegas show that cast 75 Filipinos, receiving many curtain calls for every performance.

De la Cruz’s biography appears in Walter Robb’s Filipino, 1941, in recognition of her achievements in the entertainment world. She was declared by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) as Best Supporting Actress for Inspirasyon (Inspiration) in 1953 and was named one of the 10 Most Outstanding Women of the Year in 1961. She was conferred the Lou Salvador Memorial Award by the FAMAS in 1973 and the Tandang Sora Award in 1975. In 1989, de la Cruz returned to Manila to witness Katy! The Musical, a musical on her life, with libretto by Jose Javier Reyes and music by Ryan Cayabyab and starring Mitch Valdes in the title role.   Written by Malou L. Maniquis

Khavn dela Cruz (Khavn Nicolas de la Cruz) is a film director, screenwriter, and poet. He was born on 23 Dec 1973. His parents are Leonardo Distor de la Cruz and Kelly Clarinda Nicolas. He graduated in 1995 with a bachelor of arts degree in interdisciplinary studies: film, literature, and development economics at Ateneo de Manila University.

A prolific independent filmmaker, de la Cruz did hundreds of short and long feature films. Among his digital feature films are Squatterpunk, 2006; Mondomanila (or How I Fixed My Hair after a Rather Long Journey), 2010; Kommander Kulas: Ang Kaisa-isang Konsiyerto ng Kagila-gilalas na Kombo ni Kommander Kulas at ng Kanyang Kawawang Kalabaw sa Walang Katapusang Kalsadang Kamyas (Commander Kulas: The One and Only Concert of the Amazing Combo of Commander Kulas and His Poor Carabao in the Long and Endless Road of Kamias), 2011; and EDSA XXX: Nothing Ever Changes in the Ever-Changing Republic of Ek-Ek-Ek, 2014, which all had world premieres at Rotterdam International Film Festival in the Netherlands.

Squatterpunk won the Grand Jury Prize at the 2006 Cinemanila International Film Festival (CIFF). He won Best Director for Mondomanila at the 2010 CIFF.

He is the editor of the books Philippine New Wave: This Is Not a Film Movement and Under the Storm: An Anthology of Contemporary Philippine Poetry and composer of 23 albums. In 1992, he founded .MOV International Digital Film Festival that screens local and international digital films in the country.  Written by Rica Arevalo

Uro dela Cruz (Rosauro Quevedo dela Cruz), also known as Rosauro Q. dela Cruz, Uro Q. Dela Cruz, Urbano R. Ordonyes, Bobby Cintones Jr, and Jessica Fuego, was a screenwriter, film and television director, film actor, playwright, fictionist, and photographer. He was born in Lucban, Quezon on 21 Oct 1951. He died in Manila on 4 Feb 2016. His parents are Ana Quevedo and Jose dela Cruz, a driver-mechanic. Poet Hermogenes Quevedo is his grandfather. Film and TV director and actor Abbo dela Cruz was his brother. He married Ana Marie Celestino with whom he had three children. He enrolled in chemical engineering courses at the University of the Philippines and National University.

Dela Cruz attended theater workshops in the Palihang Aurelio V. Tolentino from 1974 to 1975 and wrote plays such as Hermano Pule and Sisa for his group, Dulaang Banahaw, in Lucban.

Among the screenplays written by Dela Cruz are the “Manananggal” segment in Shake, Rattle & Roll, 1984; Virgin Forest and the controversial Scorpio Nights, 1985; the “Komiks” segment of Halimaw (Monster) and Unfaithful Wife, 1986; the folkloric epic movie Once upon a Time, 1987; Gaano Kita Kamahal (How Much Do I Love You), 1993; Diliryo (Delirium), 1997; Balahibong Pusa (Cat’s Fur) and Bahay ni Lola (Grandma’s House), 2001; and Singsing ni Lola (Grandma’s Ring), 2002.

Dela Cruz was second unit/assistant director in Scorpio Nights and Virgin Forest. He directed the “Poso” (Water Pump) episode of Shake, Rattle & Roll 2K5, 2005, and Scaregivers, 2008.

Dela Cruz directed television shows, like Bubble Gang, 1995-2016; Valentina, 2005; Do-Se-Na (Twelve Already), 2007; Show Me the Manny, 2009; Kaya ng Powers (Can Do), 2010; Tweets for My Sweet, 2012; and Celebrity Bluff, 2012-16. He was also featured in the I-Witness documentary “Ang Mahiwagang Ngiti ni Rizal” (Rizal’s Mysterious Smile), 2011.

As an actor, dela Cruz performed various roles in the films he either wrote or directed, such as Shake, Rattle & Roll; Virgin Forest; Scorpio Nights; Unfaithful Wife; Scorpio Nights 2, 1999; and Singsing ni Lola. He was also in the cast of Erik Matti's Prosti (Prostitute), 2002. Dela Cruz's novel, Antyng-antyng o Kwadrisentenyal: Kung Papaano Nakipagpatintero sa Kasaysayan ang Aming Bayan (Amulet or Quadricentennial: How Our Country Played a Game of Tag), was published in 2003.  Written by Rosalie Matilac, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

Atang de la Rama (Honorata de la Rama) was a theater and film actor and singer. She is a National Artist for music and theater. She was born in Pandacan, Manila on 11 Jan 1902. She died in Manila on 11 Jul 1991. She was raised by Pastora Matias who was married to the composer Leon Ignacio. In 1932, she married the poet, playwright, and labor leader Amado V. Hernandez. She grew up in a musical milieu. At the age of seven, she started playing child roles in such Spanish zarzuela as La Mascota (The Mascot), Sueño de un Vals (Dream Waltz), Marina, and Viuda Alegre (Merry Widow). She also sang in the literary-musical programs of the Lilliputiens, a group of young Spaniards managed by Orestes Marcaida and Jose del Pan. When she was 12, she began lessons in the violin with Ignacio and piano with Vincenzo Gambardella. But it was singing that came to her naturally, so she took voice lessons with Victorino Carrion and Galia Arellano. At the age of 14, she played Angelita in Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1917, which Ignacio and Hermogenes Ilagan had written for her. This made her a star. The show had some 1,000 performances before 1940 and was made into a movie, the first Tagalog full-length feature film, also starring de la Rama, in 1919. She completed a pharmacy course at the Centro Escolar de Señoritas (now Centro Escolar University) in 1922 and took courses at the Royal Dramatic Theater Academy in New York in 1925.

After Dalagang Bukid and the song “Nabasag ang Banga” (The Claypot Broke), which she made a hit, de la Rama was in great demand as sarsuwela lead in the productions of the Compañia Zarzuela Ilagan, Samahang Paguia of Tondo, Samahang Gabriel of Santa Cruz, Samahang Antonio Sempio of Bulacan, and Samahang Sarsuela Ballecer. She sang to the music of Ignacio in the sarsuwela written by the best-known playwrights of the time: Servando de los Angeles’s Ararong Ginto (Golden Plow), ca 1925, Alamat ng Nayon (Legend of the Village), 1927, and Ang Kiri (The Flirt), 1926; Julian Cruz Balmaseda’s Sa Bunganga ng Pating (At the Mercy of Sharks), 1921; Precioso Palma’s Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), 1920; Patricio Mariano’s Ang Anak ng Dagat (Child of the Sea), 1921; Engracio Valmonte’s Ang Mestiza (The Mestiza), ca. 1920s; and Florentino Ballecer’s Sundalong Mantika (Sluggish Soldier), ca 1920. She sang in Spanish, Tagalog, Kapampangan, Ilocano, and Ilonggo sarsuwela. She also starred in drama by Florentino Ballecer, Jose Ma. Rivera, Patricio Mariano, and Bernardino Buenaventura. In the 1930s, she wrote original librettos herself, with music by Ignacio, like Bulaklak ng Kabundukan (Mountain Flower), Aking Ina (My Mother), Anak ni Eba (Eve’s Daughter), and Puri at Buhay (Honor and Life). She also wrote skits in Tagalog, put lyrics to songs, and directed sarsuwela.

De la Rama was also known for singing kundiman (love songs) created by some of the most important composers of the 1920s and 1930s like Nicanor S. Abelardo, Francisco Santiago, Bonifacio Abdon, Francisco Buencamino, and Constancio de Guzman. She popularized the now classic songs “Bituing Marikit” (Beautiful Star), “Madaling-Araw” (Dawn), “Mutya ng Pasig” (Muse of Pasig), “Anak-Dalita” (Child of Woe), “Kundiman ng Luha” (Love Song of Tears), and “Kundiman ni Abdon” (Abdon’s Love Song). She premiered “Bayan Ko” (My Country) at a workers’ rally in 1928. She performed on the bodabil stage with entertainers like Katy de la Cruz and Diana Toy, and in Malacañan Palace, appeared on radio and television, and cut records. American impresarios brought her to Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, and American cities with large Filipino communities.

She was active in sociocivic organizations of patriotic women. She committed herself to nationalist principles propagating the sarsuwela and kundiman as Filipino art forms. During the imprisonment of her husband for involvement in the guerrilla and workers’ movements, she supported him and became a friend of the working class to which he had dedicated his life. Until her sickness, she accepted invitations to speak before various nationalist and people’s organizations and theater groups like the Babaylan Theater Group, Philippine Educational Theater Association, and UP Repertory Company.

In 1987, Atang de la Rama was named National Artist “for her sincere devotion to original Filipino theater and music, her outstanding artistry as singer and as sarsuwela actor-playwright-producer, her tireless efforts to bring her art to all regions and sectors of Filipino society and to the world.” As part of the nation’s tribute to her, she was honored with a performance by the Cultural Center of the Philippines’s Tanghalang Pilipino of the sarsuwela that had made her famous, Dalagang Bukid. In 2008, Dulaang UP presented Floy Quintos’s Atang, which dramatized scenes from de la Rama’s life and some of the kundiman she popularized.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, with notes from Nicanor G. Tiongson

Jaime de la Rosa (Tomas Lim de la Rosa) was a film actor. He was born in Lubao, Pampanga on 18 Sep 1922. He died in Manila on 3 Dec 1992. He was the son of Feliciano de la Rosa and Rosario Lim. He was the younger brother of actors Rogelio de la Rosa and Africa de la Rosa. He married Beatriz Santos, with whom he had three children. He graduated with a bachelor of arts degree from the National University in 1941. He served as Manila councilor from 1988 to 1992.

Director Octavio Silos discovered him for the movies, giving him a part in Cadena de Amor (Chain of Love), 1940. His first picture as a lead actor was Ibong Sawi (Forlorn Bird), 1941. He also starred with Carmen Rosales in Manuel Silos’s Batalyon XIII (13th Battalion), the first Filipino movie filmed entirely in color. Among his notable films are Garrison 13, 1946, with his brother Rogelio; Aladin, 1946; Ikaw Ay Akin (You Are Mine), 1947; Waling-Waling, 1948, with Rebecca Gonzales; Parola (Lighthouse), 1949, with Norma Blancaflor; In Despair, 1950, with Mila del Sol; Kontrabando (Contraband), 1950, with Celia Flor; Satur, 1951, with Delia Razon; Shalimar, 1951; Provinciano (Country Boy), 1951, with Evelyn Villar; Korea, 1952, with Nida Blanca; Sa Paanan ng Nazareno (At the Foot of the Nazarene), 1952, with Priscilla Cellona; Richard Abelardo’s Taong Paniki (Bat Man), 1952; Batangueña (Batangas Girl), 1953, with Nida Blanca; Doce Pares (Twelve Pairs), 1954, with Lilia Dizon; Donato, 1954, with Rosa Rosal; Tinalikdang Dambana (Rejected Shrine), 1954; Galawgaw (Wacky), 1954; Dinayang Pagmamahal (Cheated Love), 1955; Saydwok Bendor (Sidewalk Vendor), 1955; Niña Bonita (Pretty Girl), 1955, with Charito Solis; No Money, No Honey, 1956, with Carmencita Abad; Kumander 13 (Commander 13), 1956; Luksang Tagumpay (Dark Victory), 1956, with Delia Razon and Rebecca del Rio; and Hukom Roldan (Judge Roldan), 1957, with Emma Alegre. He was under exclusive contract with LVN Pictures, but in 1953 he was loaned out to Premiere Productions for the Gerardo de Leon film Dyesebel, as the leading man of Edna Luna.

In the 1950s, de la Rosa had a large following as a radio personality, hosting the Camay Theater of the Air, Sa Paghawi ng Tabing (When the Curtain Rises), and the game show Kwarta o Kahon (Cash or Surprise). He and Rosa Rosal were a popular radio team.

During the 1969 Asian Film Festival held in Cambodia, de la Rosa received a special award for the documentary film This Is the Philippines.   Written by Glecy Atienza

Rogelio de la Rosa (Regidor Lim de la Rosa), also known as Roger, was a film and theater actor, and film producer. He was born in Lubao, Pampanga on 12 Nov 1915. He died in The Hague, Netherlands on 26 Nov 1986. He was the son of Feliciano de la Rosa and Rosario Lim, and brother of actors Jaime de la Rosa and Africa de la Rosa. He married movie actor Lota Delgado with whom he had seven children. He was a champion athlete and orator in school and distinguished himself as an accomplished sarsuwela actor in Lubao. He studied at Lubao Central Elementary School and finished high school at Lubao Institute in Lubao, Pampanga. He has an associate in arts degree from the Far Eastern University and two years of law studies to his credit. His movie career was launched when movie mogul Jose Nepomuceno cast him opposite   in the silent film Ligaw na Bulaklak (Wildflower), 1932. It was not long before he emerged as the most bankable superstar of the prewar and liberation era. From 1937 until just before the outbreak of World War II, de la Rosa was on contract with Sampaguita Pictures.

He starred in movies considered outstanding during their time: Diwata ng Karagatan (Goddess of the Sea), 1936, with Adela Plunkers; Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), 1937, with Elsa Oria; Takip-silim (Twilight), 1939, with Carmen Rosales; Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1939, with Rosita Rivera; Principeng Hindi Tumatawa (The Prince Who Does Not Laugh), 1946, with Mila del Sol; and Jack and Jill, 1954, with Lolita Rodriguez. Of his screen pairings, it was the Carmen Rosales–Rogelio de la Rosa tandem that was most successful in films like Lambingan (Romance), Señorita (Young Mistress), Colegiala (Coed), and Diwa ng Awit (Sense of Song), all in 1940; and Panambitan (Lament) and Tampuhan (Lovers’ Quarrel), 1941. In 1941, he set up RDR Productions in partnership with J. Amado Araneta and Placido Mapa. RDR made Anong Ganda Mo (You Are So Beautiful), 1941, and Caballero (Cavalier), 1942. Later, he produced Irisan, 1951, on his own, with Lota Delgado and Ben Rubio as co-stars.

During World War II, he was a regular at variety shows held in Life Theater, working with Norma Blancaflor, Bayani Casimiro, Jose Cris Soto, and the comedy team of Pugo and Togo. After the war, de la Rosa became the biggest star of LVN Pictures in such films as Backpay and Sarung Banggi (One Night), 1947; and Kampanang Ginto (Golden Bell) and Camelia, 1949, with Carmen Rosales. For Sampaguita Pictures, he starred with Carmen Rosales once more in Maalaala Mo Kaya? (Will You Remember?), 1954; Ang Tangi Kong Pag-ibig (My Only Love) and Iyung-Iyo (Yours Only), 1955; and Lydia, 1956. During the decade of the 1950s, his most important films were costume epics, revealing the Filipino’s obsession with folklore and fantasy: Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), 1950, and its sequel, Prinsipe Amante sa Rubitanya (Prince Amante in Rubitanya), 1951; Haring Kobra (King Cobra), 1951; and Sohrab at Rustum (Sohrab and Rustum), 1950. Toward the mid-1950s, he shifted to dramatic roles playing husband to Cecilia Lopez in Sonny Boy, 1955, and Emma Alegre in Higit sa Lahat (Above All), 1955.

De la Rosa was elected senator in 1955. He ran for president in 1961—at the same time releasing Dugo at Luha (Blood and Tears), which highlighted the government’s neglect for the poor—but backed out at the last minute and supported Diosdado Macapagal who won over Carlos P. Garcia. Retiring from movies, he occupied a series of ambassadorial posts: Sri Lanka in 1963; Cambodia in 1965; and The Hague, Netherlands, up to 1983.

De la Rosa received Best Actor award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Higit sa Lahat, 1955, two years after he was nominated by the FAMAS for Sa Paanan ng Bundok (At the Foot of the Mountain), 1953. He won Best Actor at the 1956 Asian Film Festival held in Hong Kong also for Higit sa Lahat. In 1982 the National Press Club of the Philippines honored him with an Award of Merit for his outstanding achievements in motion pictures, politics, and foreign service. He was also a recipient of the Walang Kupas award that same year. In 1989 the Film Academy of the Philippines awarded him a Lifetime Achievement Award posthumously. In 2004, de la Rosa and Carmen Rosales, and other love tandems of their period, were given a tribute titled “Cinema Paraiso” by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. The tribute celebrated the theme of love in Philippine cinema and showcased their most awarded films.  Written by Glecy Atienza, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

Christopher de Leon (Christopher Strauss de Leon), also known as Boyet de Leon, is a film and television actor, singer, and film director. He was born in Manila on 31 Oct 1956. His parents are actors Gil de Leon and Lilia Dizon (Claire Dizon Strauss). His two sisters are both actors, Pinky and Lara Melissa. He was educated at Immaculate Heart of Mary Academy, Aquinas School, St Martin, and University of the East, where he took a course in fine arts. He has a son with estranged wife Nora Aunor, actor Ian, and four adopted children. Daughters Matet and Lotlot also became actors. He has five children with his spouse, actor Sandy Andolong. He worked briefly as a bellboy at the Hyatt Regency Hotel.

While a student at the University of the East, he was spotted by director Lino Brocka who cast him in Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (You Were Weighed and Found Wanting), 1974. After that, he appeared in other leading roles in Banaue, Tag-ulan sa Tag-Araw (Rainy Days in Summer), and Batu-Bato sa Langit (Bird in the Sky), 1975; Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?), Tisoy (Mestizo), Mrs. Teresa Abad … Ako Po si Bing (Mrs. Abad … I Am Bing), and Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos (Three Godless Years), 1976; Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (When You Dream and Wake Up) and Masarap, Masakit ang Umibig (Joy and Pain of Loving), 1977; Ikaw Ay Akin (You Are Mine) and Nakawin Natin ang Bawat Sandali (Let Us Steal Every Moment), 1978; Pakawalan Mo Ako (Release Me), Relasyon (An Affair), Haplos (Caress), and Cain at Abel (Cain and Abel), 1982; Broken Marriage, 1983; Bituing Walang Ningning (Star Without Sparkle), 1985; I Love You Mama, I Love You Papa, 1986; Maging Akin Ka Lamang (Anything to Have You), 1987; Kapag Napagod ang Puso (When the Heart Tires), 1988; Imortal (Immortal) and Babangon Ako’t Dudurugin Kita (I Will Rise and Crush You), 1989; My Other Woman, Biktima (Victim), and Gumapang Ka sa Lusak (Dirty Affair), 1990; and Ipagpatawad Mo (Forgive Me), 1991. His other films include Sana’y Ikaw Na Nga (May You Be the One), 1993; In the Name of Love, 1995; Madrasta (Stepmother), 1996; Tumutol Man ang Tadhana (Even If Fate Is Against Us), 1998; Yakapin Mo ang Umaga (Embrace the Morning), 2000; Sugatang Puso (Wounded Heart), 2001; Magkapatid (Siblings), 2002; Mano Po 2 (I Kiss Your Hand 2), 2003; Mano Po 3, 2004; Tulay (Bridge), 2006; Mano Po 6, 2009; Catch Me … I’m in Love, 2011; and El Presidente (The President), 2012.

De Leon’s first directorial job was “Komiks,” an episode of Halimaw (Monster), 1986. He also completed the directorial job for Huwag Mong Salingin ang Sugat Ko (Touch Not My Wound), 1991, which was left unfinished by his mentor Brocka when the latter died in a car accident.

He starred in many television programs, such as GMA Network’s Now and Forever, 2005-6, and Beautiful Strangers, 2015; TV5’s Sa Ngalan ng Ina (In the Name of the Mother), 2012, and Misibis Bay, 2013; and ABS-CBN’s The Legal Wife, 2014.

De Leon has a string of Best Actor awards: five from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang, Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon?, Kapag Napagod ang Puso, My Other Woman, and Ipagpatawad Mo; one from the Film Academy of the Philippines for Biktima; two from the Gawad Urian for Ikaw Ay Akin and My Other Woman; three from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Haplos, Imortal, and Mano Po 3; and two from the Catholic Mass Media Awards for Imortal and My Other Woman.  Written by Glecy Atienza, updated by Erika Carreon

Gerardo de Leon (Gerardo de Leon Ilagan), also known as Manong Gerry, was a film director and screenwriter, and is a National Artist for film. He was born in Manila on 12 Sep 1913. He died in Manila on 25 Jul 1981. Born to Hermogenes Ilagan (also spelled Ylagan), stage director and writer and head of a sarsuwela company, and singer-actor Casiana de Leon, he belongs to the famous Ilagan clan of film and stage. His brothers Conrado Conde, Tito Arevalo, Angel Esmeralda, and Edo Nagali; sisters Honor Ilagan and Laling Talti; and nephews Robert Arevalo, Jay Ilagan, and Eddie Ilagan, and uncle Mar Esmeralda (Marceliano Ilagan) have all been actors or directors. With Patricia Dicks, he has two daughters, Victory and actor Liberty (Ongpauco). With Fely Vallejo, he has a daughter, Maria Fe, wife of actor Ronaldo Valdez and mother of actor-singer Janno Gibbs. De Leon attended grade school at Legarda Elementary School and finished high school at Jose Rizal College. He completed his medical studies at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) and placed fifth in the medical board examinations.

While studying at UST, de Leon played a bit part in Mga Pusong Dakila (Noble Hearts), 1937. This was followed by roles in Ruben, Ang Pagbabalik (The Return), Makiling, Bago Lumubog ang Araw (Before the Sun Sets), Mga Sugat ng Puso (Wounds of the Heart), Binatang Bukid (Country Boy), Bukang Liwayway (Dawn), Dasalang Perlas (Pearly Prayerbook), and Isang Halik Lamang (One Kiss Only), all in 1938. By this time he was already considered one of the best character actors in the industry.

In 1938 he directed his first film, Bahay Kubo (Nipa Hut), a musical. Other movies that he directed before the war are Ama at Anak (Father and Son), 1939; Princesa ng Kumintang (The Princess of Kumintang) and Estrellita (Little Star), 1940; Panambitan (Lament) and Ang Maestra (The Teacher), 1941. The war caught up with him while he was directing Anong Ganda Mo (You Are So Beautiful) for RDR Productions of Rogelio de la Rosa, but he completed it and the movie was shown in May 1942, after the Japanese Occupation of Manila.

During World War II, de Leon directed stage plays at the Lyric and Capitol theaters. The Japanese commissioned him to make two films for Eiga Haikyusha: Dawn of Freedom, 1944, with Abe Yutaka; and Tatlong Maria (Three Marys), 1944. After the war, he made three films for Sampaguita Pictures: So Long, America, 1946; Isumpa Mo, Giliw (Make a Vow, My Love), 1947; and Mameng, Iniibig Kita (Mameng, I Love You), 1947. One of the Sampaguita stockholders, Pedro Vera Jr, commissioned him to direct an independent production, Tayug: Ang Bayang Api (Tayug: The Oppressed Town), 1947. Transferring to Premiere Productions afterward, he became a mainstay director for that studio for whom he made film classics like Sisa, 1951; Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo (Python in the Old Dome), 1952; Banga ni Zimadar (Zimadar’s Jar) and Dyesebel, 1953; Pedro Penduko, 1954; Sanda Wong, 1955; Kamay ni Cain (Hand of Cain) and Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), 1957; Ako ang Katarungan (I Am Justice), 1962; Kulay Dugo ang Gabi (Blood Is the Color of Night), 1964; and the “Caridad” episode of Fe, Esperanza, Caridad, 1974.

He also made films for other studios like Everlasting Pictures’ Walang Panginoon (No God), 1956; Lebran’s Saigon, 1956; MML’s The Moises Padilla Story, 1961; Hemisphere’s Walls of Hell: Intramuros, 1964, with Eddie Romero; AM Productions’ Ibulong Mo sa Hangin (Whisper to the Wind), 1966; Lea Productions’ The Gold Bikini, 1968; Adroit Films’ Brownout, 1970; Balatbat Productions’ Playpen, 1974; NV Productions’ Banaue, 1975; and FPJ Productions’ Juan de la Cruz, which was started in 1976 and left unfinished by his death.

De Leon received the first Maria Clara Best Director award for Kamay ni Satanas (Hand of Satan), 1950. He was also first to receive the Best Director award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Bagong Umaga, 1952. He won six other FAMAS Best Director awards for Hanggang sa Dulo ng Daigdig (To the Ends of the Earth), 1958; Huwag Mo Akong Limutin (Never Forget Me), 1960; Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1961; El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1962; Ang Daigdig ng mga Api (The World of the Oppressed), 1965; and Lilet, 1971. For having won more than five awards in this category, he was elevated to the FAMAS Hall of Fame. He also won FAMAS awards for Best Screenplay for the "Hatinggabi" (Midnight) episode of Apat na Kasaysayang Ginto (Four Golden Stories), 1956, and El Filibusterismo, and the Best Editing award for Huwag Mo Akong Limutin. In 1954 he won the Best Director award at the Asian Film Festival in Singapore for Ifugao, a film about a Filipino ethnic tribe. The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino (MPP) conferred on him the Natatanging Gawad Urian in 1977 to honor his lifetime achievements in film. The Film Academy of the Philippines conferred on him, posthumously, the Lifetime Achievement Award in 1983. After his death, he was declared National Artist for film in 1982. In 2013, de Leon’s centennial year, the Cultural Center of the Philippines held a yearlong tribute to the great director with free screenings of his works.  Written by Agustin L. Sotto and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

Gil de Leon (Guillermo de Leon) was a singer and film actor. He was born in Manila on 25 Jun 1919. He died in Manila on 19 Feb 1992. He married actor Lilia Dizon (Claire Dizon Strauss) with whom he had three children: Pinky, Christopher, and Lara Melissa, who are all singers and actors. At a very young age, he ran away from home and wandered from place to place, landing as a houseboy at the Cavite Naval Base. From 1937 to 1939, he served on the USS Blackburn, flagship of the United States Asiatic fleet. Upon discharge, he became a vocalist and band leader at the Great Eastern Hotel in Manila. He also did amateur boxing.

De Leon started in show business during the Japanese Occupation, performing in various theaters in Manila. After the war, he played character actor roles in the movies. Among the films he appeared in are Aladin, 1946; Sierra Madre and Engkantada (Fairy), 1948; Maria Beles and Ang Kuba sa Quiapo (The Hunchback in Quiapo), 1949; Taong Paniki (Bat Man), 1952; Philippine Navy and Hiyasmin, 1953.

After taking lessons under director Mike Caguin, he directed Glory at Dawn, 1954.

De Leon was the first actor to win the Best Supporting Actor award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for his role as a Filipino soldier in Lamberto V. Avellana’s Korea, 1952. In 1955, he was again nominated Best Supporting Actor by the FAMAS for his role in Sanda Wong, a Philippine-Hong Kong co-production.  Written by Danny Villanueva

Manuel de Leon (Manuel Buencamino de Leon) was a film producer and studio manager. San Miguel, Bulacan 30 Apr 1915. d. Quezon City 4 Feb 2005. Movie producer and studio manager. He was the son of LVN Pictures executive producer Narcisa “Doña Sisang” Buencamino vda de Leon and Jose “Don Pepe” de Leon. He was married to Imelda Pamintuan. Filmmaker Mike de Leon and Philippine ambassador Narcisa de Leon-Escaler are two of his children. He finished his undergraduate studies at Ateneo de Manila University, took up law at the University of the Philippines and topped the bar exams.

De Leon served as aide to President Manuel Roxas after World War II and afterward worked as general manager of LVN Pictures under his mother Doña Sisang. He produced the now classic films Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956, which won Best Film at the Asia-Pacific Film Festival in Hong Kong and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) International Prestige Award of Merit; Badjao, 1957, which received the awards for Best Director (Lamberto V. Avellana), Best Screenplay (Rolf Bayer), Best Cinematography (Mike Accion), and Best Editing (Gregorio Carballo) from the Asian Film Festival held in Tokyo; and Biyaya ng Lupa (Blessings of the Land), 1959, which won the Best Supporting Actor award in the 1960 Asian Film Festival and the awards for Best Picture and Best Story (Celso Al. Carunungan) from the FAMAS, and had a special screening at the 10th Berlin International Film Festival in 1960. He was also the executive producer of the film adaptation of Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965, directed by Avellana and financed under de Leon’s Diadem Productions.

Manuel de Leon was also a production associate in the Hollywood war drama Huk!, 1956, starring George Montgomery and directed by John Barnwell. He was also the executive producer of Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (When You Dream and Wake Up), 1977, and Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (Will Your Heart Beat Faster?), 1980, both directed by his son Mike.

De Leon received Lifetime Achievement Awards from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino in 1977 and the Film Academy of the Philippines in 1991 for his work as film producer and as one of the founders and first director of the FAP.  Written by Anne Frances Sangil

Mike de Leon (Miguel Pamintuan de Leon), also known as Miguel de Leon, is a film director, producer, screenwriter, and cinematographer. He was born in Manila on 24 May 1947. He is the son of LVN Pictures producer Manuel de Leon and Imelda Pamintuan. He is the grandson of Narcisa Buencamino vda de Leon. He received his bachelor’s degree in humanities at Ateneo de Manila University. He took up studies in art history at the University of Heidelberg, Germany.

Before making full-length feature films, de Leon made two short films: Sa Bisperas (On the Eve), 1972, and Monologo (Monologue), 1975. He established in 1975 his own film outfit, Cinema Artists Philippines, which produced its initial offering: Lino Brocka’s Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), of which de Leon was the cinematographer.

De Leon’s first major film, Itim (The Rites of May), 1976, shows his delicate balancing of cinematic elements to project mood and character. Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (When You Dream and Wake Up), 1977, a tribute to Doña Sisang, whose centennial was celebrated in 1978, showcases de Leon’s restrained handling of the relationship between two middle-class youths. In Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (Will Your Heart Beat Faster?), 1980, Kisapmata (In the Wink of an Eye), 1981, Batch ’81, 1982, and Sister Stella L., 1984, he tackles social and political issues in powerful and disturbing images. Hindi Nahahati ang Langit (An Indivisible Heaven), 1985, his most commercial film, did not have his screen credit due to a conflict with the producers. He also directed the Sony full-length video Bilanggo sa Dilim (Prisoner in the Dark), 1987, starring Joel Torre, Cherie Gil, and Rio Locsin.

Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag gave de Leon his first award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Best Cinematography. In 1976, Itim won the Gawad Urian for Best Cinematography, Best Music, Best Editing, and Best Sound, and was voted by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino (MPP) as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1970-79. It won for de Leon and Charo Santos, respectively, the awards for Best Director and Best Actress at the 1978 Asian Film Festival in Sydney, Australia. Kakabakaba won for de Leon the Gawad Urian for Best Director. Kisapmata won Best Actor (Vic Silayan), Best Supporting Actor (Jay Ilagan), Best Cinematography (Rody Lacap), Best Production Design (Cesar Hernando), Best Music (Lorrie Ilustre), and Best Sound (Ramon Reyes) at the Gawad Urian. Batch ’81 was chosen Best Picture by the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) and also won Best Screenplay for Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Raquel Villavicencio, and de Leon from both the Gawad Urian and FAP. Sister Stella L. gave de Leon the Best Director award from FAMAS and the Best Screenplay award from the Gawad Urian, and collected eight other Gawad Urian trophies, including Best Picture, in 1985. Kisapmata, Batch ’81, and Sister Stella L. were chosen as three of the 10 Best Films of the Decade, 1980-89 by the MPP. Kisapmata and Batch ’81 were shown in the Directors’ Fortnight at the 1982 Cannes Film Festival while Sister Stella L. was shown in Venice Film Festival in 1985.

After a brief hiatus from filmmaking, de Leon directed Aliwan Paradise (Entertainment Paradise), 1993, one of the four films under the omnibus Southern Winds produced by the Japan Foundation and NHK Enterprises. The film won Best Editing from the Young Critics Circle (YCC). In 1999, de Leon directed Bayaning 3rd World (Third World Hero) and the film won the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Supporting Actor (Torre), Best Cinematography, Best Music, and Best Sound. In the 2000 YCC Film Desk Citations, it won Best Film (tied with Tanging Yaman [A Change of Heart]), Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design, Best Editing, and Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration. In 1999, de Leon was awarded the Centennial Honors for the Arts by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

De Leon was also instrumental in the restoration of Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag, with the assistance of Martin Scorsese’s World Cinema Foundation and the Film Development Council of the Philippines (FDCP). The restored film won the Best Archive Restoration/Preservation Title award at the 11th Federation of Commercial Audiovisual Libraries International Awards. De Leon’s follow-up restoration project was A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965, in cooperation with the National Film Archives of the Philippines and the FDCP. The restored Portrait was screened at the CCP Little Theater on 25 Apr 2015.  Written by Galileo Zafra, updated by Anne Frances Sangil

Teofilo de Leon (Teofilo Jarlego de Leon), also known as Ka Pilo, was a film editor. He was born in San Leonardo, Nueva Ecija on 28 Dec 1926. His parents are Apolonio de Leon, a driver, and Teofista Jarlego. He finished high school at Cosmopolitan College and enrolled at Mapua Institute of Technology, at the same time working in order to support his brother and sister. He married Aurora San Miguel, with whom he had eight children, including Renato, a film editor as well.

Encouraged by his uncle, film editor Ike Jarlego Sr, de Leon worked as an apprentice at LVN Studios where he developed an interest in film editing. His first break was Krus na Bituin (Star Cross), 1948. De Leon edited several of the notable films produced at LVN. He also edited Ishmael Bernal’s first film, Pagdating sa Dulo (At the Top), 1971. He was associate editor for Francis Ford Coppola’s Apocalypse Now, 1979.

His work includes Kaaway na Babae (Female Enemy), 1948; Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1949; Mutya ng Pasig (Muse of Pasig), 1950; Pag-asa (Hope), 1951; Kambal Tuko (Siamese Twins), 1952; No Money No Honey (Above All), 1955; Faithful, 1958; Kundiman ng Lahi (Love Song of the Race), 1959; Pitong Makasalanan (Seven Sinners) and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1962; Masquerade, 1967; Triangulo (Triangle) and Love Letters, 1970; Daluyong (Tidal Wave), 1971; Roulette, 1972; Diwang Kayumanggi: Prinsesang Mandirigma (Brown Spirit: Warrior Princess), 1975; Holdup (Special Squad, D.B.), 1979; Cover Girl, 1981; Milagro sa Porta Vaga (Miracle at Porta Vaga), 1982; and Bagets 2 (Young Ones 2), 1984.

De Leon received the award for editing from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for The Moises Padilla Story, 1961, where he pioneered in using the two-track system that separated picture from sound; and another FAMAS award for Lilet, 1971, where he made use of the magnetic soundtrack. He also did pioneering work in the use of the lip-sync method for local movies.  Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

Van de Leon was a film actor. He was born on 16 Dec 1920. He died in 1982. Though not as popular as the romantic actors of his time, de Leon portrayed all kinds of roles with competence. He was kontrabida (antagonist) in Kilabot ng Makiling (Terror of Makiling), 1954, and in many other films of Sampaguita Pictures. He played the leading man in Roberta, 1951, which broke box-office records and bailed the company from bankcruptcy after its studio had been razed by a fire. Later, he was cast with Carmen Rosales in Inspirasyon (Inspiration), 1953, and Luha ng Birhen (A Virgin’s Tears), 1954. His other notable performances were in Munting Koronel (Little Colonel), 1953; Waldas (Spendthrift) and Lupang Kayumanggi (Brown Land), 1955; Condenado (Condemned), 1958; and Ipinagbili Ko ang Aking Anak (I Sold My Child), 1959.

After his stint with Sampaguita Pictures, de Leon appeared in Lea Productions’ Ako ang Katarungan (I Am Justice) and Markang Demonyo (Mark of the Demon), 1962; Simbangis ng Tigre (Ferocious as the Tiger), 1964; Miranda: Ang Lagalag na Sirena (Miranda: The Wayward Mermaid), Ako’y Magbabalik (I Shall Return), and Sino Ka, Madam X? (Who Are You, Madam X?), 1966. He made several films with Tony Ferrer, including Kidnappers, 1970, and Bagsik ng Kamao (Strength of a Fist), 1970. He appeared with Roberto Gonzales in Saan Man Sulok, Panganib (Danger Lurks in Every Corner), 1970. His other films are Shotgun Kid and Tukso (Temptation), 1970; Totoy Bato (Totoy the Rock), 1977; and a short film produced by Marichu Maceda, Soldado (Soldier), 1978, where he portrayed the role of Christopher de Leon’s father who died embittered when his son refused to be a soldier.

De Leon won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Actor award twice for Taga sa Bato (Cut on a Stone), 1957, and Kamandag (Venom), 1959. He received his third FAMAS award as Best Supporting Actor for Batingaw (Church Bell), 1974. He starred in Gerardo de Leon’s unfinished film Juan de la Cruz.  Written by Danny Villanueva

Maryo J. de los Reyes  (Mario Jorolan de los Reyes) was a film, theater, and television director and screenwriter. He was born in Santa Cruz, Manila on 17 Oct 1952. He died in Dipolog City, Zamboanga del Norte on 27 Jan 2018. He was the son of Lourdes Jorolan, a professor, and Pastor de los Reyes, a civil engineer. He attended Letran College and Malate Catholic School, finishing high school as valedictorian at Our Lady of Guadalupe Minor Seminary. There he directed plays for his English classes and later became acquainted with the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) through Lutgardo Labad, a fellow seminarian, who had invited him to play a minor role in Hoy, Boyet (Hey, Boyet). He attended theater workshops and seminars in 1965, then enrolled in the University of the Philippines (UP) mass communication program in 1970 and later became a lecturer at the UP Institute of Mass Communication.

De los Reyes received his first training in theater and stage directing from Cecile Guidote. He became active with PETA and directed Tatlong Manyika (Three Dolls), 1974; Limot at Ligaya sa Rhumbacita (Oblivion and Joy in Rhumbacita), 1977; and Artista sa Palengke (Movie Star in the Market), 1978. He later joined the PETA teaching force, the Central Institute of Theater Arts in Southeast Asia, and served as its program director from 1975 to 1979. He directed for other groups: Itay, Kain Tayo (Father, Let’s Eat), 1973, for UP-UNESCO; Ang Kombensyon ng mga Halimaw (The Meeting of Monsters), 1974, for UP; Kalbaryo (Calvary), 1975, for Las Piñas; Usok (Smoke), for San Sebastian College; and Ang Awit na Hindi Matapus-tapos (Song Without End), for Teatro Tomasino. He also directed Convent Bread, 1982, at Hotel Mirador and Sex’s a Deal, 1986, at the Rizal Theater.

His association with Lino Brocka gave him the training to direct for movies. Among his early films are Disco Fever, 1978; High School Circa ’65 and Annie Batungbakal, 1979; Saan Darating ang Umaga? (Where Will the Morning Come?), 1983; Bagets (Young Ones) and Kaya Kong Abutin ang Langit (I Can Reach the Sky), 1984; Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), 1985; Tagos ng Dugo (Bloodstain), 1987;  Kapag Napagod ang Puso (When the Heart Tires) and Stupid Cupid, 1988; and My Other Woman, 1990. His later films include Magnifico, 2003; Kulimlim (Overcast) and Naglalayag (Silent Passage), 2004; Happily Ever After, 2005; A Love Story, 2007; Torotot (Deception), 2008; Kamoteng Kahoy (Cassava) and Nandito Ako … Nagmamahal sa ’Yo (I’m Here … Loving You), 2009; I’ll Be There, 2010; Bamboo Flowers, 2013; and The Unmarried Wife, 2016.

De los Reyes received training in directing for TV from Lupita Aquino-Kashiwahara, then director of Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye). He directed the TV series Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora). His most recent TV drama series include ABS-CBN’s Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels Without Heaven), 2005, and Calla Lily, 2006; and GMA Network’s Little Star and Gumapang Ka sa Lusak (Secret Affairs), 2010; Munting Heredera (Little Heiress), 2011; Pahiram ng Sandali (Lend Me a Moment) and Biritera (Belter), 2012; Magkano Ba ang Pag-ibig? (How Much Does Love Cost?), 2013; Niño (Boy), 2014; Pari ’Koy (Father ’Koy), 2015; Someone to Watch Over Me, 2016; and Hindi Ko Kayang Iwan Ka (I Cannot Leave You), 2018. De los Reyes also directed numerous episodes of the drama anthology Magpakailanman (Forever), 2013-17.

He won a Papal Award for Best Film for Gabun, Ama Mo, Ama Ko (Gabun, Your Father, My Father), 1979, and the Catholic Mass Media Award for Best Director twice: for Tagos ng Dugo (Bloodstain) and My Other Woman. He also received Best Director awards for Kapag Napagod ang Puso (When the Heart Tires), 1988, and Sinungaling Mong Puso (Your Lying Heart), 1992, from the PMPC Star Awards for Movies. His film Magnifico won the 2003 Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay (Michiko Yamamoto), Best Actor (Jiro Manio), Best Supporting Actor (Albert Martinez), Best Supporting Actress (Gloria Romero), and Best Sound. It was also chosen as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 2000-2009 by the Gawad Urian. In 2004, the same film was awarded the Crystal Bear for Best Feature Film and the Deutsches Kinderhilfswerk Grand Prix for Best Feature Film at Berlin International Film Festival. Also in 2004, his film Naglalayag won the Special Jury Award in the international competition of Brussels International Independent Film Festival.  Written by Malou M. Maniquis and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

Michael de Mesa (Michael Edward Gil Eigenmann) is a film, television, and theater actor, and a film and television director. He was born in Manila on 24 May 1960. He belongs to a family of actors. He is the son of Eduardo Eigenmann aka Eddie Mesa and Rosemarie Gil. His siblings are actors Mark Gil and Cherie Gil. He was married to actor Gina Alajar, with whom he has three children—two of whom, Ryan Eigenmann and Geoff Eigenmann, are actors. De Mesa and Alajar separated ways in 2001, and their marriage was annulled in 2006. De Mesa married Julie Reyes in 2011. He studied at De La Salle Greenhills in his elementary years, then at Aquinas School and Central Colleges of the Philippines.

Among de Mesa’s most remarkable works are Ano ang Kulay ng Mukha ng Diyos? (What Is the Color of God’s Face?), 1985; Paradise Inn, 1985; and Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven), 1991. His other films include Nagkataon … Nagkatagpo (Chance Encounter), 1994; Batang X (Kid X), 1995; Abot-Kamay ang Pangarap (Elena's Redemption), 1996; Hawak Mo ang Buhay Ko (You Hold My Life), 1997; Cyber Wars, 2004; Dubai and Big Time, 2005; Nasaan si Francis? (Where Is Francis?), 2006; Selda (The Inmate), 2007; Baler, 2008; and On the Job and 10,000 Hours, 2013. He directed an episode in Calvento Files: The Movie, 1997, and the horror movie, Ika-13 Kapitulo (13th Chapter), 2000.

On television, he appeared in the long-running drama series Valiente, 1990, on GMA 7, as well as its remake in 2012 on TV5. He was also in the cast of Bisperas ng Kasaysayan (Eve of History), 1994, on RPN 9; GMA Network's Rio del Mar, 1999, Ikaw Lang ang Mamahalin (I'll Always Love You), 2001, Mulawin, 2004, Kasalanan ba ang Ibigin Ka? (Is It a Sin to Love You?), 2012, Indio (Native), 2013, Innamorata, 2014, and Destiny Rose, 2015; and ABS-CBN's Bituin (Star), 2002, and The Wedding, 2009. He acted in as well directed several episodes of Magpakailanman (Forever) and Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember).     

De Mesa was chosen Best Actor for Unfaithful Wife, 1986, and Best Supporting Actor for Ikasa Mo, Ipuputok Ko (You Cock, I’ll Shoot), 1990, by the Gawad Urian. He received Best Supporting Actor award for Paradise Inn, 1985, from the Film Academy of the Philippines.

De Mesa is also one of the movie actors who crossed to the stage with acclaimed performances in Rent, 2002; Hairspray, 2008; and La Cage aux Folles, 2015.  Written by Cristine Directo, updated by Mario Mendez Jr and Elmer L. Gatchalian

Alessandra De Rossi (Alessandra Tiotangco Schiavone), also known as Alex De Rossi, is a film and television actor. She was born in Yeovil, Somerset, England on 19 Jul 1984 to an Italian father, Luigi Schiavone, and a Filipino mother, Nenita Tiotangco. She and actor Assunta de Rossi are sisters.

De Rossi began acting as a teenager in Carlos Siguion-Reyna’s Azucena, 2000, earning for herself the Best Supporting Actress award in the 2000 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. The following year, 2001, she bagged the Best Supporting Actress award in the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) for her performance in Joel Lamangan’s Hubog (Wretched Lives), in which she co-stars with her sister Assunta. In the early 2000s, she appeared in Pakisabi na Lang … Mahal Ko Siya (Please Let Her Know … I Love Her), 2002; Message Sent, 2003; The Cory Quirino Kidnap: NBI Files, 2003; and Mano Po 2: My Home (I Kiss Your Hand 2: My Home), 2003. She also appeared in several other MMFF entries, including Spirit of the Glass, 2004; Kutob (Hunch), 2005; and One Night Only, 2008.

Her collaborations with director Gil Portes resulted in films that depict the various struggles of Filipinos who have chosen to work overseas. In Mga Munting Tinig (Small Voices), 2002, de Rossi plays the role of a Manila-educated teacher who chooses to work in a rural school and inspire young kids, but eventually decides to migrate abroad by the film’s end. In Homecoming, 2003, she plays a balikbayan from Canada who unwittingly spreads the SARS epidemic back home. In Barcelona, 2006, she plays a wife searching for her husband in Spain. She also played the role of an overseas Filipino worker in two non-Filipino productions. In the Singaporean horror film The Maid, 2005, directed by Kelvin Tong, she plays the titular role of a resilient domestic helper. In the Taiwan comedy film Pinoy Sunday, 2009, directed by Wi Ding Ho, she plays a bar hostess in Taipei, starring alongside Jeffrey Quizon and Bayani Agbayani.

In the late 2000s, de Rossi began to work on more independent film productions, many of which were screened in various international film festivals. In 2009, she played lead in Raya Martin’s Independencia (Independence). In 2010, she collaborated with Adolfo Alix Jr in Romeo at Juliet (Romeo and Juliet), 2010; the omnibus Manila, 2010; and Mater Dolorosa, 2012. She played the title role in Sari Dalena’s Ka Oryang (Comrade Oryang), 2011, and Keith Sicat’s Woman of the Ruins, 2013, both of which were made for Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival. She appeared in Auraeus Solito’s Baybayin (The Palawan Script), 2012, with her sister Assunta, as well as in Solito’s Busong (Palawan Fate), 2011, which won Best Picture in the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. In the following years, 2012 and 2013, respectively, she starred in two Cinemalaya entries, Manny Palo’s Sta. Niña (Saintly Girl), 2012, and Portes’s The Liars, 2013. Her other independent movies include Mauban: Ang Resiko (Mauban: The Treat), 2014, and Water Lemon and Bambanti, 2015. She also acted in the short film Ang Mga Alingawngaw sa Panahon ng Pagpapasya (Echoes in the Midst of Indecision), 2015.

For her performance in Sta. Niña, she won Best Actress in the 2013 ASEAN International Film Festival and Awards, and Best Supporting Actress in the 2013 Gawad Urian. In 2014, she received the Ani ng Dangal Award from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

De Rossi also performs for television. She starred in Etheria and Darna, 2005; Pasan Ko ang Daigdig (World on My Shoulders), 2007; Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009; Green Rose, 2011; Legacy and Pahiram ng Sandali (Lend Me a Moment), 2012; Magkano Ba ang Pag-ibig? (How Much is Love?), 2013; and Ang Dalawang Mrs. Real (The Two Mrs. Real), 2014. She has appeared in several episodes of Magpakailanman (Forever) and Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember). She has also been independently producing music since 2006, compiled in the 11-track album Adrift, 2012, for which she composed music, wrote lyrics, and sang.  Written by Patrick Campos

Demetrio de Santos was a film sound engineer. He was born ca 1925. De Santos started working in film postproduction when the Premiere Productions studio was established in 1947. He did the soundtrack for films like Bulaklak at Paru-paro (Flower and Butterfly), 1948; Kumander Sundang (Commander Bolo), 1949; and 48 Oras (48 Hours), 1950. He was also sound engineer of Diego Silang, 1951, and Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo (Python in the Old Dome), 1952.

Having established himself as a sound engineer, more films followed, including Dyesebel, 1953; Sanda Wong, 1955; Apat na Kasaysayang Ginto (Four Golden Stories) and Mr. and Mrs., 1956; Sweethearts, The Day of the Trumpet, Water Lily, Laban sa Lahat (Against All Odds), and Anak ng Lasengga (Child of a Drunkard Woman), 1958; Ang Matapang Lamang (Only the Brave), 1959; Krus na Daan (Crossroads), Kadenang Putik (Chain of Mud), and Mga Yapak na Walang Bakas (Footprints without a Trace), 1960; Presinto 13 (Precinct 13), 1961; Ako ang Katarungan (I Am Justice), 1962; Moro Witch Doctor, 1964; The Ravagers, 1965; Whisper to the Wind, 1966; Women in Cages, 1971; Ang Mahiwagang Daigdig ni Pedro Penduko (The Mysterious World of Pedro Penduko), 1973; Fe, Esperanza, Caridad, 1974; and Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?), 1976.

De Santos won six awards for Best Sound from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Desperado (Desperate), 1956; Kalibre .45 (Caliber .45), 1957; Singing Idol, 1958; Huwag Mo Akong Limutin (Never Forget Me), 1960; Passionate Strangers, 1966; and Rodolfo Valentino, 1970. He was elevated to the FAMAS Hall of Fame as sound engineer.  Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

Nestor de Villa (Gines Francisco Soriano) was a film, stage, and television actor and dancer. He was born in Cabanatuan City on 6 Jul 1928. He died in Muntinlupa City on 21 Feb 2004. He was the son of Priscilla Francisco and Emiliano Soriano. He took up medicine at the University of Santo Tomas until his second year. He married Marilou Cacho. They have four children, including Jeric, a filmmaker, whose son Paul Soriano is also a filmmaker. De Villa was a member of the Camera Club of the Philippines.

De Villa was a contract star of LVN Pictures from 1951 to 1960. His first movie was Amor Mio (My Love), 1951, with Tessie Quintana. He gained fame as a popular dancing matinee idol, and he and Nida Blanca eventually formed a popular movie love team in films like Hijo de Familia (Family Heir) and Squatters, 1953; Luneta and Waray-Waray (Visayan Lass), 1954; Darling Ko (My Darling), Ang Ibong Adarna (The Adarna Bird), and Ikaw Kasi (You Are to Blame), 1955; Ganyan Ka Pala (So That’s the Way You Are), “Grand Finale” episode of Medalyong Perlas (Pearl Medallion), Bahala Na (Come What May), and Handang Matodas (Ready to Die), 1956; “Bording Haus” (Boarding House), an episode of Casa Grande (Mansion), 1958; Baguio Fever, 1959; Walang Sisihan (No Blaming), 1961; and Everybody Dance, 1964.

Among the films that he made with leading ladies other than Nida Blanca are Dalagang Taring (Fiery Lady), 1955, with Delia Razon; Big Shot, 1956, with Rosa Rosal; Krisalis, 1957, with Charito Solis; Sebya, Mahal Kita (Sebya, I Love You), 1957, with Sylvia La Torre; Austerity Love, 1958, with Luisa Montesa; Chinita (Slit-eyed Woman), 1959, with Luz Valdez; and Limang Punglo (Five Bullets), 1959, with Tessie Quintana. He came back to films in the 1980s, and did Saan Darating ang Umaga? (Where Will the Morning Come?), 1983, where he was reunited with Nida Blanca; Anak ni Waray vs Anak ni Biday (Waray’s Child vs Biday’s Child), 1984; and Hindi Nahahati ang Langit (An Indivisible Heaven), 1985. His other films include Paglingon sa Kinabukasan (Looking to the Future), 1986; Prinsipeng Gusgusin (Unkempt Prince), 1987; Ligaw-Ligawan, Kasal-Kasalan, Bahay-Bahayan (Playing Lovers, Playing Married Couple, Playing House), 1993; and his last film, Forevermore, 2002.

De Villa and Blanca had their own television show under ABS-CBN called The Nida-Nestor Show, which aired from 1960 to 1964. His other television shows are ABS-CBN’s Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001-02, and GMA Network’s Biglang Sibol Bayang Imposibol (Sudden Blooming of the Impossible Hometown), 2001-02.

Among his TV awards is Best TV Male Performer in the 1967 Citizens’ Award for Television for the The Nida-Nestor Show. His son Gicky Soriano wrote his biography in 2013 titled The Last Man Standing: The Nestor de Villa Story.  Written by Glecy Atienza, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

Eddie del Mar (Eduardo Sangalang Magat) was a film actor. He was born in Candaba, Pampanga on 13 Oct 1919. He died in Manila on 8 Nov 1986. His parents are Albino Magat and Benigna Sangalang. He married Milagros Amansec, with whom he had nine children.

Del Mar started as second lead in Kapilya sa May Daang Bakal (Chapel by the Railroad Tracks), 1947. He appeared for Sampaguita Pictures and various outfits in movies like Paquito Bolero’s Kaputol ng Isang Awit (Fragment of a Song), 1948; Ulilang Kalapati (The Lonely Dove), 1949; Damit Pangkasal (Wedding Gown), 1949; Pinaghating Sandaaning Piso (One Half of a Hundred Peso Bill), 1949; Makapili (Collaborator), 1949; Ang Kampeon (The Champion), 1949; and the remake by Nolasco Bros. Pictures of the prewar hit, Ang Lumang Simbahan (The Old Church), 1949. Del Mar is best known as the “Rizal actor,” appearing as the hero in many Jose Rizal films, including Sa Dating Kandungan (The Old Nestling Place), 1959, with Aida Serna as Josephine Bracken. He also played Crisostomo Ibarra in Gerardo de Leon’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1961. Eddie was also the lead actor in Andres Bonifacio: Ang Supremo (Andres Bonifacio: The Supreme Chief), 1964, with Lolita Rodriguez.

Inspired by his portrayals of Rizal and the characters in the hero’s novels, he tried to enlist then senator Claro M. Recto’s support to produce a definitive film on the national hero. The project was aborted when Recto died.

For his performance in the role of the national hero in Buhay at Pag-ibig ni Dr. Jose Rizal (Life and Loves of Dr Jose Rizal), 1956, del Mar won the Best Actor award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences. As Crisostomo Ibarra in Gerardo de Leon’s Sisa, 1951, he was nominated Best Supporting Actor in the Maria Clara Awards.  Written by Danny Villanueva

Clodualdo del Mundo Jr (Clodualdo Agnes del Mundo Jr), also known as Doy del Mundo, is a screenwriter, film director, producer, and teacher. He was born in Manila on 11 Mar 1948. His parents are Clodualdo del Mundo Sr, essayist and fictionist, and Iluminada Agnes. He is married to Dreena Quito. They have one child, Ida Anita, a writer and filmmaker. His brother, Herky, is a cinematographer. Del Mundo Jr studied at San Sebastian College, graduating as high school valedictorian in 1964. He finished a bachelor of arts degree in humanities at Ateneo de Manila University, cum laude, in 1968. He has a master’s degree in radio-television-film at the University of Kansas, 1974, and a doctoral degree in communication studies (film) at the University of Iowa, 1994. He headed the Communication Arts Department of De La Salle University (DLSU) from 1975 to 1985. He was a founding member and former chair of the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino and vice president of the Screenwriters Guild of the Philippines. Del Mundo is former president of the Society of Filipino Archivists for Film (SOFIA) and Professor Emeritus in the Department of Communication at DLSU.

Del Mundo’s first produced screenplay is Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975, his screen adaptation of Edgardo Reyes’s novel Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag, directed by Lino Brocka. The film won for del Mundo the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences award for Best Screenplay. A series of notable screenplays followed, including Mike de Leon’s first film, Itim (The Rites of May), 1976, with co-writer Gil Quito; Sa Piling ng mga Sugapa (In the Company of Addicts), 1977; ’Merika, 1984, again with Gil Quito starring Nora Aunor; and with Herky del Mundo, an unproduced script, Alyas Raha Matanda (Alias Rajah Matanda), 1977, based on the life of Filipino hero Macario Sakay. Del Mundo teamed up with Mike de Leon and Raquel Villavicencio to write the screenplays for such award-winning movies as Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (Will Your Heart Beat Faster?), 1980; Kisapmata (In the Wink of an Eye), 1981; and Batch ’81, 1982. Batch ’81 won Best Screenplay in the Film Academy of the Philippines Awards and the Gawad Urian. Kisapmata won Best Screenplay at the Metro Manila Film Festival. He wrote Mike de Leon’s Aliwan Paradise, the Philippine episode of the omnibus film Southern Winds, 1993, produced by the Japan Foundation and NHK. Del Mundo’s other screenplay credits include Mulanay: Sa Pusod ng Paraiso (Mulanay: Deep in Paradise), 1996; Puerto Prinsesa, 1997; Bayaning 3rd World (Third World Hero), 1999, with Mike de Leon; and Markova: Comfort Gay, 2000. In 2005, he wrote, directed, and produced Pepot Artista (Pepot Superstar), 2005, which won Best Film in the first Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. He also directed, produced, and wrote the screenplay of Paglipad ng Anghel (Flight of an Angel), 2011, for De La Salle University, which received the Signis Award and Best Fiction Feature in the Spirituality section of the 2012 Dhaka International Film Festival. He also produced the Cinemalaya entry K’na the Dreamweaver, 2014, directed by his daughter Ida.

Del Mundo directed documentary films, like People Media, 1978, on media and society; Lupa (Earth), 1982, on land reform; Maid in Singapore, 2004, on Filipino domestic helpers; Ehem!Plo: Corruption and Integrity in Philippine Society, 2008; and Tinitingnan, ’Di Nakikita (Looking Without Seeing), 2010, on urban poverty.

He wrote books, including Writing for Film, 1983, published by the Communication Foundation for Asia (CFA), and Native Resistance: Philippine Cinema and Colonialism 1898-1941, 1998, published by De La Salle University Press, which received the National Book Award for film criticism from the Manila Critics Circle in 1999. Three of his screenplays were anthologized in a book published by De La Salle, Maynila …, ’Merika, Alyas Raha Matanda: Tatlong Dulang Pampelikula (Three Screenplays), 1992, while his two screenplays on Rizal in collaboration with de Leon were also published in a single book, also by the DLSU Press, Rizal/Bayaning 3rd World: Dalawang Dulang Pampelikula (Two Screenplays), 2000, which also won the National Book Award for screenplay. In 1983, he edited Philippine Mass Media: A Book of Readings, also published by CFA. He edited another book published by CFA, Spirituality in the Filipino Film, 2013. In 2014, he edited the 10th anniversary book of Cinemalaya, Making Waves: 10 Years of Cinemalaya, published by the Cultural Center of the Philippines.  Written by Emelie Capulong, updated by Anne Frances Sangil

Clodualdo L. del Mundo (Clodualdo Legaspi del Mundo), also known as Clodualdo del Mundo Sr, was a fictionist, playwright, essayist, and poet. He was born in Santa Cruz, Manila on 7 Sep 1911. He died on 3 Oct 1977. He was the son of Mariano del Mundo, a sculptor from Bocaue, Bulacan, and Remigia Legaspi. Son Clodualdo Jr is a filmmaker; another son, Herky, is a cinematographer. Del Mundo graduated from Mapa High School and obtained his associate in arts at Far Eastern College (now Far Eastern University) and bachelor of science degree in education at the National Teachers’ College. For a time, he also studied law at the Philippine Law School and fine arts at the University of the Philippines.

In 1935, del Mundo co-founded and served as the first president of Panitikan. He became president of Ilaw ng Bayan in 1937, a member of Ilaw at Panitik in 1938, and a member of Taliba ng Inang Wika (TANIW) in 1955, which he headed from 1967 to 1972. From the 1930s to the 1970s, he worked as associate editor, managing editor, or editor of the following magazines: Aliwan, Alitaptap, Orient Digest, Nautilus, Halakhak, Mabuhay, Paruparo, Daigdig, and Liwayway. He was editorial director of Liwayway at the time of his death.

Del Mundo wrote critical articles for Taliba and Liwayway, and became famous for his column “Tao sa Parolang Ginto” (The Man in the Golden Lighthouse), which came out with monthly and annual selections of the best literary works. In 1936, he co-edited with AlejandroG.Abadilla a compilation of the best short stories from 1925 to 1935, titled Mga Kuwentong Ginto (Golden Stories). Later, del Mundo compiled some of his critical essays in a book of criticism, Mula sa Parolang Ginto (From the Golden Lighthouse), 1969.

Some of del Mundo’s serialized novels are the following: Bituing Walang Langit (Heavenless Star), 1938; Sukdulan ng Pagmamahal (Limits of Love), 1963; Sambutil na Kanin (Grain of Rice), 1964; and Nang Magunaw ang Daigdig (When the World Ended), 1966. With GervasioSantiago he wrote the novels Ito ang Rebolusyon (This Is Revolution), 1972; Judas Iscariote: Kontrabidang Superstar (Judas Iscariot: Superstar Villain), 1972; and Inang Mahal (Beloved Mother), 1973.

Del Mundo was one of the prolific komiks writers in the 1950s, together with Mars Ravelo, Francisco V. Coching, and Pablo S. Gomez. Starting in 1947, Ace Publications’ Pilipino Komiks, Hiwaga, Espesyal, and Tagalog Klasiks propelled the Tagalog komiks into its golden years. Primarily with Fred Carrillo, one of the leading illustrators at that time, del Mundo produced memorable works such as the social dramas Everlasting, Malvarosa, Kadenang Putik (Chain of Mud), and Sandakot na Alabok (A Fistful of Dust); the costume dramas Kapitan Bagwis (Captain Bagwis), Pitong Sagisag (Seven Symbols), and Anak ni Prinsipe Amante (Son of Prince Amante); action stories Ripleng de Rapido (High-Powered Rifle), Paltik (Homemade Gun), and Asintado (Sharpshooter); and science-fiction stories Zarez, Tuko sa Madre Kakaw (Gecko in Madre Kakaw), and Brix Virgo: Filipino Astronaut. Many of his stories were adapted into movies by LVN, Sampaguita, and Premiere Productions, including Kadenang Putik, 1960. He also adapted Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) to the komiks medium. Illustrated by Ric Collado, the adaptation was compiled as a graphic novel in 1968.

Del Mundo also wrote radio serials, the most popular of which was Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), aired from 1949 to 1953. The story was made into a hit film by Lamberto V. Avellana. His other serialized soap operas include Kasaysayang Kayumanggi (Brown Stories), Kwentong Kapitbahay (Stories in the Neighborhood), Luha ng Birhen (The Virgin’s Tears), and Mga Kuwentong Ginto (Golden Stories). He also made radio adaptations of local and foreign classics. Under the series Obra Maestra (Masterpiece), he popularized Ben Hur, Lorna Doone, Rebecca, and The Greatest Story Ever Told. Among the local classics, he adapted Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) and El Filibusterismo (Subversion) and Francisco Baltazar’s Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura). In the 1950s, his radio plays for Holy Week, which were adaptations of stories from the Bible, drew avid listeners on DZRH.

Among his stage plays is Anong Tamis ng mga Sandali sa Sariling Bayan (How Sweet Are the Moments in One’s Own Country), a modern sarsuwela he wrote for the inauguration of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1969.

During his final years, del Mundo focused on writing a native form of poetry called the tanaga. This is a short poem, four lines with seven syllables for each line, that is playful, sometimes philosophical, sometimes metaphorical, but always with a penetrating insight into life. The collection is called Makabagong Tanaga (Modern Tanaga). Published weekly in Liwayway, he finished 283 pieces of these short poems.

Del Mundo’s Kadenang Putik was awarded Best Story in the 1960 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. He won three prizes from the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature: second prize for the short story “Binhi” (Seedling), 1961; second prize for the one-act play May Ningning ang Kinabukasan (Tomorrow Has Promise), 1955; and third prize for the one-act play Mr. Congressman, 1960. He received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city government of Manila in 1966, the Presidential Award for Literature and Nationalism in 1970s, and the Catholic Mass Media Award for his comics story Kakambal Ko’y Multo (My Twin Is a Ghost), awarded posthumously in 1978.   Written by Rosalinda Galang and Clodualdo del Mundo Jr

Pacita del Rio (Helen Johnson) was a film actor. She was born in Manila on 23 Sep 1921. She died in San Diego, USA on 13 Nov 1989. She quit convent school at age 14 to join the movies over the strong objections of her family.

Del Rio was Excelsior Pictures’ “It” girl in the late 1930s, playing intriguing roles as the lover of Jose Padilla Jr in Ako’y Maghihintay (I Will Wait), 1938; the rival of Carmen Rosales in Arimunding-Munding, 1939; and the seductress of Jaime de la Rosa in Ibong Sawi (Forlorn Bird), 1941. She also appeared in Filippine Films’ Matamis na Kasinungalingan (Sweet Lies), 1939, with Leopoldo Salcedo and Gloria Imperial, and Ikaw Rin (You, Too), 1940, the prewar box-office hit starring Elsa Oria and Rudy Concepcion. She worked with director Lamberto V. Avellana in Alitaptap (Firefly), 1940. When she transferred to Sampaguita Pictures, she became the best-known villain of the period in films like Carmen, Princesita (Little Princess), Panibugho (Jealousy), Sa Iyong Kandungan (In Your Cradle), Tampuhan (Lovers’ Quarrel), and Palikero (Playboy), all shown in 1941. She was the lead star of O Salapi (Oh Money), 1947, a comedy film directed by Manuel Silos and starring Bayani Casimiro and Jose Cris Soto.

Del Rio epitomized the society girl–kontrabida (villain) type of character actor in prewar movies, thwarted only when good triumphed over evil at movie’s end.  Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

Rosa del Rosario (Rosa del Rosario Stagner) was a film actor. She was born in Manila on 15 Dec 1919. She died in Novato, California, USA on 4 Feb 2006. She was the seventh of 13 children of United States Army lieutenant Frank Stagner and Aquilina del Rosario. Her sister Edna and Norma were actors as well. She married American John Summit; their marriage was dissolved in 1952. They had two children.

Already statuesque at 13, del Rosario caught the eye of director-producer Jose Nepomuceno who cast her in Satanas (Satan), 1932, after she spent months trying to learn straight Tagalog under Lazaro Francisco. After finishing high school, she starred opposite Rogelio de la Rosa in the silent movie Ligaw na Bulaklak (Wildflower), 1932, which was named outstanding movie of the year. In 1933 she appeared in her first talking movie, Dr. Kuba (Dr Hunchback), opposite Jose Padilla Jr. She made Mag-inang Mahirap (Destitute Mother and Child), 1934, also chosen outstanding movie of the year. Her other outstanding prewar movies are Zamboanga (Fury in Paradise), 1937, with Fernando Poe Sr; Ang Magmamani (The Peanut Vendor) with Rogelio de la Rosa, and Kalapating Puti (White Dove) with Leopoldo Salcedo, both in 1938; Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1939, which was based on the famous sarsuwela by Severino Reyes; and Huling Habilin (Last Will), 1940, and Ilang-Ilang, 1941, two films directed by Ramon Estella.

During World War II, del Rosario was in Hollywood, USA, where she played the seventh wife of the king in Anna and the King of Siam, 1946, with Irene Dunne as Anna and Rex Harrison as the king of Siam. She was the leading lady in a cowboy movie, Border Bandit, 1946, opposite Johnny Mack Brown. After the war, she resumed her career in the Philippines, making such big movies as Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng) with Leopoldo Salcedo, and Himala ng Birhen (Miracle of the Virgin) with Rogelio de la Rosa, both shown in 1947. Another memorable role she played was the Philippines’ most popular wonder-heroine in Darna, 1951. After doing May Karapatang Isilang (With the Right to Be Born), 1952, del Rosario again left for San Francisco, California, to work as a cosmetologist. She remained in California until her death.

In 1982, the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences honored her with the Walang Kupas award as one of the “15 Immortals of Philippine Movies.”  Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

Mila del Sol (Clarita Villarba Rivera-Young) is a film actor. She was born in Tondo, Manila on 12 May 1923. Her parents are Amado Rivera and Lorenza Villarba. She studied at Araullo High School. She married Alonzo Young, an American diplomat. A sister, Gloria Imperial, was an actor. Brother Doods Rivera was a newscaster on Channel 5 during the pre-martial law years. A daughter, Jeanne Young, became a popular movie actor and television host. Del Sol is the chair of the Pag-asa ng Kabataan Foundation and the Mila del Sol and Eddie Romero Fund for Community Development. She was also active in the Movie Workers Welfare Foundation Inc and the Philippine National Red Cross.

Del Sol was discovered by Doña Sisang of LVN who spotted her while she was chaperoning her sister Gloria. She was given a part in Parlatone’s Nasaan Ka Irog? (Where Are You, Beloved?), 1937. Later, she played a lead role with child actor Tita Duran in X’Otic Film’s Mariang Alimango (Maria the Crab), 1938. De Leon endorsed her to be part of Giliw Ko (My Beloved), 1939, under LVN Pictures. Director Carlos Vander Tolosa gave her the screen name of Mila del Sol.

She played lead roles in LVN’s biggest prewar movies, among them Gerardo de Leon’s Princesa ng Kumintang (Princess of Kumintang), 1940; Manuel Conde’s Sawing Gantimpala (Lost Victory), Ararong Ginto (Golden Plow), Villa Hermosa, and Lamberto V. Avellana’s Rosa Linda, all shown in 1941. Another Avellana film she made before the war which was shown during the Japanese Occupation was Tia Juana (Aunt Joan), 1943. She also appeared in Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941, the first Filipino film with color sequences, which were handpainted frame by frame; and Orasang Ginto (Golden Clock), 1946, the first Filipino film made after World War II.

After the war, she continued appearing in LVN costume productions like Principeng Hindi Tumatawa (The Prince Who Does Not Laugh), 1946, and Haring Solomon at Reyna Sheba (King Solomon and Queen Sheba), 1952, and love stories with rustic settings like Violeta and Sarung Banggi (One Night), 1947, and Hiyas ng Pamilihan (Gem of the Marketplace), 1949. She also appeared in Garrison 13, 1946, opposite Rogelio de la Rosa; Alaala Kita (Thinking of You), 1946, based on the song by Mrs Aurora Quezon; Dalawang Daigdig (Two Worlds), 1946; and Romansa (Romance), 1947, opposite Jose Padilla Jr.

In the 1950s, del Sol migrated to the United States, raising her six children there. She studied business at Glendale Community College following her retirement from the film industry. She made a comeback in Pakipot (Playing Hard to Get), 1960, with Jaime de la Rosa, and in Sampaguita Pictures’ Tatlong Magdalena (Three Magdalenes) with Carmen Rosales and Rita Gomez. In 1961 she appeared in Espionage Far East, a film starring Hollywood star Todd Andrews and directed by Ted Post, Gerardo de Leon, and Eddie Romero.

Del Sol received the Cinema’s Living Treasure Award from the Metropolitan Manila Development Authority and the Metro Manila Film Festival in 1994 and the Natatanging Gawad Urian from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino in 2013. In 2014, the Philippine Congress, through House Resolution 165, honored her for her contributions to the movie industry.  Written by Danny Villanueva, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

DELGADO, JOHNNY ( Juan Marasigan Feleo )b.Santa Cruz, Manila 29 Feb 1948. d. Quezon City, 19 Nov 2009. Movie, stage, and television actor. He was the son of scriptwriter-director Ben Feleo and Victorina Marasigan. Scriptwriter Marina Feleo-Gonzales is his aunt and visual artist Roberto “Bob” Feleo, his cousin. He took up banking and finance at the University of Santo Tomas. He married actor-director Laurice Guillen with whom he had two children, Ina and Anna, who are both actors. He was active in the Actors Workshop Foundation, which he and Guillen founded.

He first appeared in Sa Manlulupig, Di Ka Pasisiil (Never to Invaders Shall You Surrender), 1967, which was directed by his father. After playing lead roles in One-Man Army, 1967, and Machinegun Johnny and the Sexy Queen, 1970, he lay low for a while. Shifting to character roles, he was acclaimed in Hill 91, 1973; Banaue, 1975; Huwag Mong Kunin ang Lahat sa Akin (Do Not Take Everything from Me), 1976; Sa Putik Ihuhugas Ay Dugo (Mud Will Be Rinsed with Blood) and Jaguar (Guard), 1979; and Mga Uod at Rosas (Worms and Roses), 1982. He also appeared in several Mike de Leon films, such as Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (Will Your Heart Beat Faster?), 1980; Batch ’81, 1982; and Aliwan Paradise (Entertainment Paradise), 1992. Some of his later films include Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000; Crying Ladies, 2003; La Visa Loca (Crazy Visa), 2005; Ang Huling Araw ng Linggo (The Last Day of the Week), 2006; and Kaleldo (Summer Heat), 2006.

His first stage role was Andres Bonifacio in Behn Cervantes’s Dapithapon (Twilight). Then he was Elias in Kanser (Cancer), Bonifacio again in Ambon sa Madaling-Araw (Drizzle at Dawn), and a fisher in Rehas sa Tubig (Cage in the Water). He was also a mainstay in the TV spoof Bad Bananas with Christopher de Leon, Jay Ilagan, and Edgar Mortiz.
