Delgado was also cast as Lt Col “Red” Kapunan in the international TV miniseries A Dangerous Life, 1988, and appeared in other local television programs, such as in ABS-CBN’s Kay Tagal Kang Hinintay (So Long Have I Waited for You), 2002-3, Maria Flordeluna, 2007, and May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), 2009-10; and in GMA Network’s Te Amo: Maging Sino Ka Man (Speaking the Language of Love), 2004, and Kamandag (Venom), 2007.

Delgado won the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) Best Supporting Actor award for Ang Alamat ni Julian Makabayan (The Legend of Julian Makabayan), 1979, and the Gawad Urian Best Supporting Actor award for Kakabakaba Ka Ba? The Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences gave him the Best Actor award for his performance in Tanging Yaman. The Film Academy of the Philippines awarded Delgado back-to-back Best Supporting Actor trophies for La Visa Loca and Ligalig (Anxiety), 2006. He also shared the 2001 Young Critics Circle Best Performance by an Ensemble with the cast of Tanging Yaman. Delgado also won the 2006 MMFF Best Supporting Actor award for Ligalig. Written by Danny Villanueva and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Anne Frances Sangil

DELGADO, MARISSA ( Epifania Adoracion Flor Boyle ) b. Manila 6 Jan 1948. Movie and television actor. She is the daughter of Conrad Boyle, a Swedish-American, who married a Filipina. She finished high school at Far Eastern University. Delgado has two children from a previous marriage.

Delgado was discovered by director Artemio Marquez, who cast her in GM Film Organization’s Dalawang Kumander sa WAC (Two WAC Commanders), 1965. Her first starring role was in Code Name: Octopus, 1966, opposite Tony Ferrer. She played a supporting role in Lino Brocka’s Tubog sa Ginto (Dipped in Gold), 1970.

She played an important role in Nardong Putik, 1972. One of the big screen’s femme fatales in the early 1970s, Delgado was at her best in irrepressibly funny kontrabida (antagonist) roles like the ones she played in Inside Job and Devil Woman, 1970; Huwag Tularan: Pito Ang Asawa Ko (Do Not Imitate: I Have Seven Wives), 1974; Ursula, 1976; Bomba Star, 1978; and Darna, Kuno? (They Say It’s Darna), 1979. Her other films include Iskul Bukol (Truants) and Bona, 1980; Stariray, 1981; Santa Claus Is Coming to Town, 1982; Atsay Killer (Maid Lover), 1983, and its sequel Atsay Killer Buti Nga sa ’Yo (Maid Lover: Serves You Right!), 1984; Public Enemy No. 2 … Maraming Number 2 (Public Enemy No 2 Is a Playboy), 1985; Nakausap Ko ang Birhen (I Spoke with the Virgin Mary), 1988; Kapag Wala ng Batas (When the Law Is Gone), 1990; Pido Dida 2: Kasal Na (Pido Dida 2: Married Now), 1991; Campus Scandal, 1998; Mrs. Montero’s Lover, 1999; Pagdating ng Panahon (When the Time Comes), 2001; Sshhh … She Walks by Night, 2003; Bikini Open, 2005; Binibining K (Miss K), 2006; Apat Dapat, Dapat Apat: Friends 4 Lyf and Death (It Must Be Four, Four Must It Be: Friends for Life and Death), 2007; and Manila, 2009.

Delgado received two Best Supporting Actress awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Lumuha Pati mga Anghel (Even the Angels Wept), 1971, and Till Death Do Us Part, 1972. She earned FAMAS Best Supporting Actress nominations for her performance in Ang Tatay Kong Nanay (My Father the Mother), 1979, and Sa Akin Pa Rin ang Bukas (Tomorrow Still Belongs to Me), 1988. She was nominated in the same category by the Gawad Urian for Ligaw na Bulaklak (Wildflower), 1976.

She appeared in television series, including GMA Network’s Kamandag (Venom), 2007-8, and Bantatay (The Guardian), 2010-11; and ABS-CBN’s Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14, and Forevermore, 2014-15. Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Erika Carreon

DEOCAMPO, NICK ( Nick Armada Deocampo ) b. Mandaluyong, Manila 4 Jun 1959. Filmmaker, author, teacher. His parents are Leonardo Deocampo Sr and Aurelia Armada. He was educated at West Visayas State University and Iloilo National High School. He finished theater arts, cum laude, at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman in 1981. He received a scholarship in Paris to study at the Centre du Formación Au Cinéma Direct. As a Fulbright scholar, he earned a master’s degree in cinema studies at New York University, 1989. He headed several cinema-as-art workshops for the UP Film Center and organized the Manila Short Film Festival, as well as the Quezon City International Super 8 Film Festival, 1990. He served as executive director of the Mowelfund Film Institute from 1989 to 2008.

After his Paris stint, Deocampo made Oliver, 1983, a film on the struggle for survival of a gay entertainer. His Children of the Regime, 1986, deals with child prostitution, and Revolutions Happen Like Refrains in a Song, 1987, dwells on social change. These films form the trilogy that won various national and international awards, including the grand prize at the 9th International Super 8 and Video Festival in Brussels, Belgium.

In 1990, Deocampo’s A Legacy of Violence won the Best Documentary award in Belgium. Ynang Bayan: To Be a Woman Is to Live at a Time of War (Motherland), 1991, is his first full-length 16mm documentary. It was premiered at Yamagata International Documentary Festival in Japan. His other films include Memories of Manila, 1993; Junkzilla, 1995; Sex Warriors and the Samurai, Isaak, and Continuing Lives: Women of the Bases, 1996; Mother Ignacia: Ang Uliran (Mother Ignacia: The Ideal), 1998; Pedrong Palad (Pedro the Palm), 2000; Edades: Victorio C. Edades and Modernism in Philippine Art, 2004; and Cross Currents: Journey to Asian Environments, 2012.

Deocampo’s book Short Films: Emergence of a New Philippine Cinema, 1985, traces the history and practice of noncommercial films in the Philippines. Among his other books are Beyond the Mainstream: The Films of Nick Deocampo, 1997, Films from a “Lost” Cinema: A Brief History of Cebuano Films, 2005, Lost Films of Asia, 2006, Sinegabay: A Film Study Guide, 2008, Cine: Spanish Influences on Early Cinema in the Philippines, 2003, and Film: American Influences on Philippine Cinema, 2011. The last two books are accompanied by films titled Cine>Sine: Spanish Beginnings of Philippine Cinema and Film: American Beginnings of Philippine Cinema, 2012.

Deocampo received the Best Short Film award at the Catholic Mass Media Awards for Oliver. In 1990, the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences gave him a Lifetime Achievement Award. He won Best Student Documentary award for Ynang Bayan, 1991, from the Film Academy of the Philippines. In 1993, he was one of the Ten Outstanding Young Men awardees for cinema, and in the following year he received the cultural achievement award from the Ten Outstanding Young Persons of the World Program. He also received the Fribourg International Film Festival Best Short Film award for Memories of Manila in 1994. The film Private Wars, 1997, earned him the Citizen’s Prize at the Yamagata International Documentary Festival. He also received accolades for his published work. He won National Book Awards for Beyond the Mainstream: The Films of Nick Deocampo in 1997, Cine: Spanish Influences on Early Cinema in the Philippines in 2003, and Sinegabay: A Film Study Guide in 2008. Written by Danny Villanueva, updated by Pamela Mathiel Lopez

DIAZ, JULIO ( Mariano de Leon Regaliza ) b. Quiapo, Manila 18 Nov 1958. Actor. He studied medical technology and trained as an X-ray technician while working in a hospital in Pasig City. He was first seen in a print ad for a beer brand, which earned for him his first trophy at the AdProm Awards in 1983.

Diaz was christened the “Brown Adonis of Philippine Show Business” when he was launched with Patrick dela Rosa and nymphet Claudia Zobel in Regal’s Shame, 1983. His first few roles were for “bold movies,” like Sinner or Saint and Sariwa (Fresh), 1984; Sex Object, 1985; and Flesh Avenue, 1986. He made his mark in Takaw Tukso (Flirting with Temptation), 1986, where he was launched as a lead actor. Other films followed, notably Tatlong Mukha ng Pag-ibig (Three Faces of Love), Bukas Sisikat Din ang Araw (Tomorrow the Sun Shall Rise Again), and Paano Tatakasan ang Bukas? (How Does One Escape from Tomorrow?), 1988.

In 1989, he made a brief foray into theater for the coveted role of Valentin (to Mario O’Hara’s Molina) in Philippine Educational Theater Association’s Halik ng Tarantula (Kiss of the Spider Woman).

In the 1990s, Diaz appeared in Kolehiyala (Coed) and Kasalanan Bang Sambahin Ka? (Is It a Sin to Worship You?), 1990; Kailan Ka Magiging Akin? (When Will You Be Mine?), 1991; Aliwan Paradise (Entertainment Paradise) and Bayani (Hero), 1992; Sakay, 1993; Trudis Liit (Little Trudis), 1994; The Flor Contemplacion Story, 1995; Dyesebel and Segurista (Dead Sure), 1996; Roberta and Tirad Pass: The Story of Gen. Gregorio del Pilar, 1997; Masikip Masakit Mahapdi (Tight, Painful, Sore), 1998; and Hubad sa Ilalim ng Buwan (Naked under the Moon), 1999.

In 2001, Diaz announced that he would quit showbiz and move to the USA to become an X-ray technician. He was actually employed as a waiter and construction worker in Australia in 2002, then as an entertainer in Japan.

On his return to the Philippines, for many years he plodded through a lackadaisical career until he appeared in Dave Hukom and Adolf Alix’s Batanes, 2007, which was followed by three of Brillante Mendoza’s films: Tirador (Slingshot), 2007; Serbis (Service), 2008; and Kinatay (The Execution of P.), 2009. He also did Biyaheng Lupa (Soliloquy), 2009; Magkakapatid (Blood Ties), Halik sa Tubig (Kiss the Water), and Vox Populi, 2010; Pikit-Mata (With Eyes Closed), 2012; ABNKKBSNPLAAko?!: The Movie (Wow I Can Actually Read Now?!: The Movie) and Maratabat (Pride and Honor), 2014; and Taklub (Trap), 2015, all independent films.

Diaz did television movies, like Ang Liham ni Alberto (The Letter of Alberto), 1996, and Pangako ng Lupa (Promise of the Land), 2002; and the documentary Walang Bakas (No Trace), 2004. He was also part of the series Familia Zaragoza (The Zaragoza Family), 1995; Di Ba’t Ikaw (Isn’t It You?) 1999; Forever in My Heart, 2004; Gumapang Ka sa Lusak (Secret Affairs), 2010; Babaeng Hampaslupa (The Hapless Woman) and Wansapanataym (Once upon a Time), 2011; Pahiram ng Sandali (Lend Me a Moment), 2012; and several episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2009-12.

He continues to be active on television, with Inamorata (Loved One), Ilustrado (Educated Native), The Half Sisters, Carmela, and Magpakailanman (Forever), 2014; and Kailan Ba Tama ang Mali? (When Is Wrong Right?), Pari ’Koy (Father ’Koy), Marimar, Inday Bote (Inday the Bottle Trader), Pasion de Amor (Love Passion), Nathaniel, and FPJ’s Ang Probinsyano (FPJ’s The Country Boy), 2015. Written by Susan Claire Agbayani

DIAZ, LAV ( Lavrente Indico Diaz ) b. Datu Paglas, Maguindanao 30 Dec 1958. Filmmaker. His father, Mario Vigilia Diaz, is from Guimba, Nueva Ecija; his mother, Maria Indico, is from Lambunao, Iloilo. Both parents were teachers who volunteered to resettle as pioneer educators in Mindanao. Diaz received his bachelor’s degree in economics at Notre Dame University in Cotabato City, 1979. He married Minda Pongos with whom he has three children: Lara, Paolo, and Sultan.

In the 1970s, Diaz first found work writing scripts for the weekly TV drama anthology Balintataw and the children’s show Batibot. He also worked as a tabloid journalist for People’s Journal and Taliba while writing short stories, two of which won prizes at the 1990 and 1991 Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature.

At a filmmaking workshop in Mowelfund, Diaz directed his short film Banlaw (Cleansing), 1986, about an idealist who, unable to bear the weight of the world’s sufferings, commits suicide. An invitation for his video documentary about Manila’s street children to be part of a touring multimedia show brought Diaz to New York City. It was here that he discovered a number of his cinematic idols, like Andrei Tarkovsky whose themes reverberate through his works. Diaz eventually moved his family to New York, yet the Philippines remained his principal muse.

The first time that Diaz returned to Manila was occasioned by an offer from Regal Films producer Lily Monteverde to write and direct films for her ultra-low-budget productions. He managed to produce two classic films: Serafin Geronimo: Ang Kriminal ng Barrio Concepcion (The Criminal of Barrio Concepcion), 1998, a drama inspired by Dostoyevsky’s Crime and Punishment about a man who gets involved in a deadly crime then falls into a pit of remorse, and Hubad sa Ilalim ng Buwan (Naked under the Moon), 1999, a metaphysical sex drama about a lapsed priest and his family grappling with carnal agonies and spiritual crises.

Diaz took a quantum leap forward with Batang West Side (West Side Avenue), 2002, the first of his full-length films to be produced outside the studio system. With a screening time of almost five hours, it was also the first of his films that gave free rein to his belief in letting material and artistic vision determine the running time. The film follows the investigation of the death of a young Filipino immigrant in Jersey City and exposes along the way the psychological fractures of the Filipino diaspora struggling with displacement and the savage legacy of Marcos’s martial law. Batang West Side won a record-breaking 10 Gawad Urian including Best Picture and garnered the first of Diaz’s many awards at the international film festivals in Singapore and Brussels.

After a detour with a studio-produced film, Hesus, Rebolusyonaryo (Hesus the Revolutionary), 2003, a dystopian reflection on the martial law period, Diaz presented another independently produced film, Ebolusyon ng Isang Pamilyang Pilipino (Evolution of a Filipino Family), 2004. Relating the lives of a family of farmers and another family of miners during the martial law years, Ebolusyon had taken almost eleven years to make and displayed a further unfolding of Diaz’s filmmaking philosophy, one that eschewed emotional manipulation for the sake of a more organic presentation of the material, as expressed in unmoving camera shots, black-and-white cinematography, and paucity if not total absence of music scoring, close-ups, quick cuts, and other tricks that Hollywood-influenced films are prone to use with push-button abandon. Ebolusyon won Best Picture at the Gawad Urian.

Diaz’s long-form films eventually attracted an increasing following among cinephiles in the international film festival circuit. Heremias: Unang Aklat (Heremias: Book One), 2006, nine hours, about the travails of an itinerant rural merchant discovering the evils of the world, garnered a Special Jury Prize in Fribourg. His next film, Kagadanan sa Banwaan ning mga Engkanto (Death in the Land of Encantos), 2007, nine hours, is a tour de force incorporating documentary video of the ravages of Typhoon Reming and the fictional story of a trio of friends trying to find meaning and grace in the typhoon’s wake. The Venice International Film Festival selected the film to close its Orizzonti section where it garnered a Special Jury Mention. Melancholia, 2008, eight hours, about a triad of friends grappling with the disappearance of loved ones in their fight against fascism, also premiered as the closing night selection of the Orizzonti section and received the Grand Jury Prize.

The next years saw Diaz working on shorter films, like Walang Alaala ang mga Paruparo (Butterflies Have No Memories), 2009, one hour, set in a former mining town adrift in physical and spiritual decay, and Elehiya sa Dumalaw mula sa Himagsikan (Elegy to the Visitor from the Revolution), 2011, 80 minutes, the story of the visit by a woman from the 19th-century anti-Spanish revolution among present-day urban dwellers languishing in a world of lost ideals.

Siglo ng Pagluluwal (Century of Birthing), 2011, six hours, reflects Diaz’s attempt to find artistic regeneration during a period of aborted film projects and artistic doubts. Siglo follows the struggles of a filmmaker hounded by various characters to get his next opus finished. Siglo incorporates footage from one of Diaz’s unfinished film projects, and so does his next film Florentina Hubaldo, CTE, 2012, six hours, the story of a young rural woman suffering from chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a degenerative disease suffered by those whose heads have been subjected to repeated beating, a condition meant as a metaphor of the national psyche after repeated assaults by colonizers and oppressors through its arduous history.

If Diaz had been struggling for artistic rebirth, then his film Norte, Hangganan ng Kasaysayan (Norte, The End of History), 2013, four hours, confirmed it in spades. The film turned out to be his most internationally acclaimed and commercially successful work to date. Inspired by Dostoyevsky’s Crime and Punishment, it follows the struggles for redemption by a man who is wrongly jailed for a crime and by the real murderer who roams free (a brilliant but twisted character inspired, according to Diaz, by the young Marcos). It was the first of Diaz’s films in some dozen years to be released commercially in the Philippines, when it played to sold-out houses during its extended limited runs. The film premiered as an official selection at Cannes and subsequently became his most invited film in the international film festival circuit. It was named one of the year’s 10 best films in the annual British Film Institute/Sight & Sound international critics’ poll. It won several awards both at home and abroad, including the Gawad Urian for Best Picture. Norte led to major Lav Diaz retrospectives in Sao Paulo and at New York’s Lincoln Center.

Diaz followed up with Prologo sa Ang Dakilang Desaparecido (Prologue to the Great Desaparecido), 2013, 31 minutes, relating the search by Gregoria de Jesus for the slain body of her husband, Andres Bonifacio, and the death of Bonifacio’s faithful general, Emilio Jacinto. Diaz drew on childhood memories for Mula sa Kung Ano ang Noon (From What Is Before), 2014, four and a half hours, set in a remote hamlet on the eve of the declaration of martial law. The film tells the story of how the villagers’ individual and collective weaknesses and superstitions are exacerbated by the arrival of outsiders, a military officer and a peddler of panaceas. It debuted at the World Premieres Film Festival in Manila where it garnered the Grand Festival Prize. It also won the Golden Leopard at the 2014 Locarno International Film Festival, as well as the Best Film award at Gawad Urian in 2015.

In 2016, two of his films were recognized internationally. Hele sa Hiwagang Hapis (A Lullaby to the Sorrowful Mystery), 2016, eight hours and five minutes, which explores the role of Andres Bonifacio in the Philippine Revolution of 1896, won the Silver Bear Alfred Bauer Prize at the 66th Berlin International Film Festival. Ang Babaeng Humayo (The Woman Who Left), 2016, three hours and forty-six minutes, about a former schoolteacher, imprisoned for three decades, who plots revenge against her ex-boyfriend who framed her, won the Golden Lion at the 73rd Venice International Film Festival. Written by Gil Quito

DIAZ, PAQUITO ( Francisco Bustillos Diaz ) b. Arayat, Pampanga 28 May 1937. d. Daraga, Albay 3 Mar 2011. Movie actor. His parents are Ana Bustillos and Manuel Diaz. He studied at Lakandula Elementary School, finished high school at Far Eastern University, and studied at Ateneo de Manila. He is married to Josefa Gutierrez with whom he has four children. Son Joko Diaz, brother Romy Diaz, and brother-in-law Bob Soler are all movie actors. Daughter Cheska is also an actor.

Diaz was a popular basketball player during his high school days at FEU when he started his film career with a bit role in Pandora, 1955. He was given his first title role in Diegong Pusakal (Diego the Outlaw), 1956. Later, he became an established character actor playing villain roles in films like Simaron (Untamed), 1957; Walang Pagkalupig (No Defeat), 1962; Ang Pagbabalik ni Daniel Barrion (The Return of Daniel Barrion), 1968; Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin (You Are Everything to Me), 1970; Batang Blumentritt (Blumentritt Kid), 1971; Andalucia, 1975; Totoy Bato (Totoy the Rock) and Nagbabagang Asero (Flaming Steel), 1977; In Dis Korner (In This Corner), 1982; Umpisahan Mo, Tatapusin Ko (What You Start, I Will Finish), 1983; Pieta II, 1984; Muslim Magnum .357, 1986; Kumander Dante (Commander Dante), Patron, and Agila ng Maynila (Eagle of Manila), 1988; My Pretty Baby, Sa Kuko ng Agila (In the Claws of the Eagle), Hindi Pahuhuli Nang Buhay (Won’t Be Caught Alive), Isang Bala, Isang Buhay (One Bullet, One Life), and Leon at Tigre (Lion and Tiger), 1989; Michael and Madonna, Angel Molave, and May Isang Tsuper ng Taxi (There Was a Taxi Driver), 1990; Mahal Ko ang Mister Mo (I Love Your Husband), Mabuting Kaibigan, Masamang Kaaway (Good Friend, Bad Enemy), and Takas sa Impiyerno (Fugitive from Hell), 1991; Dito sa Pitong Gatang (Here in Pitong Gatang), Blue Jeans Gang, and Shotgun Banjo, 1992; Mga Syanong Parak (Provincial Police) and Manila Boy, 1993; Baby Paterno: Dugong Pulis (Baby Paterno: Born Policeman), Hataw, Tatay, Hataw (Dance, Father, Dance), and Marami Ka Pang Kakaining Bigas (You Still Have More Grains to Eat), 1994; Sino ang Maysala? (Who Is Guilty?) and Pamilya Valderama (The Valderama Family), 1995; Ikaw ang Mahal Ko (You Are the One I Love), Hagedorn, and Hindi Lahat ng Ahas ay Nasa Gubat (Not All Snakes Are in the Jungle), 1996; Papunta Ka Pa Lang, Pabalik Na Ako (You Are Just Beginning, I Am Already Winding Up), Pag-ibig Ko sa Iyo’y Totoo (My Love for You Is Real), Cobra, Bala para sa Katarungan (Bullet for Justice), and Lihim ni Madonna (Madonna’s Secret), Ang Pinakamahabang Baba sa Balat ng Lupa (The Longest Chin on the Face of the Earth), Enteng & Mokong: Kaming mga Mababaw ang Kaligayahan (Enteng & Mokong: We Who Are Easily Pleased), Kapag Nasukol ang Asong Ulol (When a Mad Dog Gets Cornered), and Duterte: Ang Barakong Alkalde ng Davao (Duterte: The Tough Mayor of Davao), 1997; Walang Katumbas na Dugo (No Blood Can Redeem), Squala (Scale), and Pagbabalik ng Probinsyano (Return of the Country Man), 1998; Kahit Demonyo Itutumba Ko (I Will Kill even the Devil), Isusumbong Kita sa Tatay Ko (I’ll Tell on You to My Father), Baryada Brothers, and Leon ng Maynila: Lt. Col. Romeo Maganto (Lion of Manila: Lt Col Romeo Maganto), 1999; Ayos Na ang Kasunod (The Next One Is Certain), Pera o Bayong: Not da TV! (Money or Basket: Not the TV!), and Ang Dalubhasa (The Master), 2000; Mahal Kita, Kahit Sino Ka Pa (I Love You, Whoever You Are), 2001; Sabayan sa Laban (Fighting Together), Batas ng Lansangan (Law of the Streets), and Mga Batang Lansangan Ngayon (Street Children Today), 2002; and Pakners (Partners), 2003.

He won Best Supporting Actor from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Ang Mananandata (The Warrior), 1965. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

. Quezon City 30 Mar 1955. d. Taguig City, Metro Manila 8 Oct 2012. Director and writer for film and television. She grew up in Quezon City, one of the seven children of affluent lawyers Conrado Diaz and Felicitas Correa. She graduated with a bachelor of arts in communication arts from Assumption Convent, 1976; master of arts in film and television from Loyola Marymount University (Los Angeles), 1978; and a diploma in film from the London International Film School, 1978. She married Manolo Abaya who would work as the cinematographer for some of the most celebrated films of the first half of her career. They have two sons: Marc, an actor/singer, and David, a cinematographer.

After finishing their film courses in London, the Abayas convinced their parents to finance their first film, a gothic mystery set in the 1930s, Tanikala (Chains), 1980, starring Susan Roces and Romeo Vasquez. The movie flopped in the tills but its assured storytelling caught the eye of independent film producer Jesse Ejercito who offered to bankroll their next film.

While developing the story of what would eventually become the film Brutal, 1980, Diaz-Abaya proposed Ricky Lee, whom she had never met but only heard of, to write the screenplay. Lee would eventually write or co-write half of Diaz-Abaya’s career output of twenty full-length feature films. Their collaboration would include some of the most famous works in Diaz-Abaya’s filmography, including Moral, 1982; Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983; Jose Rizal, 1998; and Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 1999.

Diaz-Abaya’s breakthrough came with Brutal, about an abused woman who kills her husband during a drug binge, with a structure that went back and forth in time. It was a box-office and critical success and won Best Director at the Metro Manila Film Festival. It was the first of what would come to be known as Diaz-Abaya and Lee’s “feminist trilogy,” films that sought to explore and protest the pernicious burdens set on women by society. Next in the trilogy was Moral, a complex story of four female classmates from the University of the Philippines negotiating the shifting social, political, and moral values of the country during the martial law years. The British Film Institute named it Outstanding Film of the Year. This was followed by Karnal, set in the 1930s, about a woman whose move from the city to the patriarchal hacienda milieu of her husband and father-in-law precipitates a tragic chain of events. The film exposes the violence wrought by the male chauvinism and despotism that continue to underlie Philippine society. It received Best Picture awards from the Metro Manila Film Festival and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), and the Gawad Urian named it one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1980-89. Another notable film she did in this decade was Senswal (Sensual), 1986.

After the fall of martial law, Diaz-Abaya took a respite from filmmaking, directing public affairs TV shows: Public Forum, featuring Randy David; Sic O’Clock News; The Big Story; and Pinoy Eh!.

She made her comeback to film in 1993 with Kung Ako’y Iiwan Mo (If You Should Leave Me), depicting the breakup of a marriage. She followed up with the female advocacy films Ang Ika-11 Utos (The Eleventh Commandment), 1994, and Ipaglaban Mo (Redeem Her Honor), 1995, commercially successful films that somehow lacked the rigor and freshness of her earlier feminist films.

Diaz-Abaya tried to break out of her customary social feminist mold with May Nagmamahal sa Iyo (Madonna and Child), 1996. In its story of a woman’s search for a child she had given up for adoption, its concerns were not about victimization but something more basic about woman’s nature, that of motherhood. Diaz-Abaya eventually broke loose with the enigmatic Milagros, 1997, written by Rolando Tinio and dedicated to Ishmael Bernal (both of whom she spoke of as her chief mentors), about a woman who, sleeping with all four men of a family, somehow retains an innocence at her core. The film finds Diaz-Abaya exploring a woman’s struggle for spiritual fulfillment rather than freedom from societal oppression. It won an unprecedented 10 trophies at the Gawad Urian, which eventually named it one of the best films of the decade.

Wishing to shake off her image as director of women’s films and using flourishes of magic realism, Diaz-Abaya followed up with Sa Pusod ng Dagat (In the Navel of the Sea), 1998, which centers on the memories of a young man growing up in a fishing community in the 1950s. The film garnered the International Federation of Film Critics / Network for the Promotion of Cinema Award at Singapore International Film Festival and opened the major Philippine film retrospective at New York’s Lincoln Center in 1998. Despite the film’s poor showing at the tills, its producer, GMA Films, asked Diaz-Abaya to direct a big-budget biography of the national hero, Jose Rizal, where she cast Cesar Montano in the titular role. The epic period film would cost 80 million pesos, the most expensive Philippine film at the time. Somehow weighed down by heavy-handed depiction of the Spanish friars and overly overt polemics, there was no denying the film’s ambitions and technical achievements. It won numerous awards, including Best Picture and Best Director, at the Metro Manila Film Festival and FAMAS, and was named one of Gawad Urian’s best films of the decade.

Diaz-Abaya explored environmental and social themes in Muro-ami in its story of a man (Cesar Montano) exploiting children in the illegal practice of reef hunting. It became another of Diaz-Abaya’s box-office and critical successes, winning Best Picture and Best Director at the Metro Manila Film Festival and FAMAS Awards. Montano once again starred in Diaz-Abaya’s next film, Bagong Buwan (New Moon), 2001, as a Muslim medical doctor caught in the war in Mindanao. Marred by a sense of forced plotting that sometimes weighed down her advocacy films, it nevertheless continued Diaz-Abaya’s streak of box-office successes coupled with wins for Best Picture and Best Director at the FAMAS Awards.

At about this time, Diaz-Abaya became more religious, volunteering as media specialist for the Silsilah Peace Institute, which espoused interfaith dialogue between Christians and Muslims, as well as the Jesuit Communications Foundation. Her religious faith became an anchor after she was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2007, the struggle with which she communicated with candor in public interviews. Her last films were an extension of her advocacy and preoccupation with faith. Maging Akin Muli (Be Mine Again), 2005, is a paean to the rituals of the Catholic Church. Its story of a young apprentice priest is one of the most directly affecting of her films. She struggled through illness to finish Ikaw ang Pag-ibig (You Are Love), 2011, and the strain somehow showed in a rather diffuse telling of a story about a family tested by cancer and eventually coming together in faith. In the same year, she filmed Yesterday, Today, Tomorrow, a movie that explores the lives of a family and their complex love affairs.

Needing to lighten her film directing activities, she established the Marilou Diaz-Abaya Film Institute and Arts Center, 2007, to train aspiring filmmakers. She received the Fukuoka Prize for Culture and the Arts, Japan, 2001. She reminisced about her career and filmmaking philosophy in the documentary Marilou Diaz-Abaya: Filmmaker on a Voyage, 2012. Written by Gil Quito

DIOKNO, PEPE ( Jose Lorenzo Aromin Diokno ) b. 13 Aug 1987. Film director. His parents are Jose Manuel Diokno and Divina Aromin. He got a bachelor’s degree in film from the University of the Philippines Diliman.

At 22 years old, his debut film Engkwentro (Clash), 2009, won the Luigi de Laurentiis Award and the Orizzonti Prize at the 2009 Venice International Film Festival, the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award for Best Asian Film at the 2010 Jeonju Film Festival, and a special citation from the 2009 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. Engkwentro tackles vigilante killings that are supported by some local governments.

Above the Clouds, 2014, obtained grants from France’s Aide Aux Cinemas du Monde, South Korea’s Asian Cinema Fund, Switzerland’s Visions Sud Est, and the 2012 Berlin Film Festival’s Arte Prize. It was premiered at the 2014 Tokyo Film Festival and competed at the 2014 Singapore Film Festival. The film deals with the emotional journey of a 15-year-old boy who goes hiking with his grandfather at the Mount Pulag National Park.

Kapatiran (Brotherhood), 2015, is an experimental take on fraternities. It was a finalist in the 2015 QCinema Film Festival and was an official selection at the 51st Karlovy Vary International Film Festival. Diokno also directed No Passport Needed, 2006.

Diokno was included in the world’s “100 Most Exceptional Emerging Filmmakers” in the Phaidon Press book Take 100: The Future of Film, and was also a recipient of the Ani ng Dangal Award from the Office of the President. Written by Rica Arevalo, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

DIZON, ALLEN ( Allen Tique Dizon ). Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental 3 Oct 1977. Movie and television actor. He is the son of Emerson Dizon and Rebecca Tique. At age 12, his father was gunned down by unknown assailants. His mother never remarried and devoted herself to raising her children. Dizon graduated in 1997 from De Ocampo Memorial College in Manila with a degree in Hotel and Restaurant Management. He is married to Crystle Maliwat with whom he has four children.

Dizon joined a male pageant in 1998 which jumpstarted his acting career. Initially, he appeared in a string of sexy movies. Later, he joined an all-male group called Viva Hotmen which did straight-to-video adult-themed features. His acting career got a big boost when he was cast in Mel Chionglo’s Twilight Dancers, 2006, for which he won two Best Supporting Actor awards: one from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) and another from the Philippine Movie Press Club’s Star Awards for Movies.

Dizon has appeared in a number of indie movies that further cemented his reputation as a serious actor, including Dukot (The Disappeared), 2009; Sigwa (Storm) and Pink Halo-Halo, 2010; Patikul and Deadline: The Reign of Impunity, 2011; Lauriana, 2013; Children’s Show and Magkakabaung (The Coffin Maker), 2014; and Imbisibol (Invisible), 2015. Dizon also ventured into producing independent features such as Paupahan (For Rent), 2008, and Marino (Marine), 2009.

His acting stint in television started with the drama series Pinakamamahal (Beloved), 2006, on GMA Network. Later, he appeared in ABS-CBN’s Nasaan Ka, Elisa? (Where Are You, Elisa?), 2011-12, and Princess and I, 2012-13. He was most recently seen in GMA Network and APT Entertainment’s Princess in the Palace and ABS-CBN’s Doble Kara (Double-faced). He also had regular guest appearances in ABS-CBN’s drama anthologies, Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) and Ipaglaban Mo (Fight for It).

Dizon’s most awarded performance as an actor was for his role as a single father and coffin maker who accidentally killed his daughter in Magkakabaung, written and directed by Jason Paul Laxamana. Set in his hometown Pampanga with the dialogue mostly in his native Kapampangan, the film won for Dizon 10 Best Actor trophies from both local and international award-giving bodies, including the 9th Harlem International Film Festival held in New York, the 3rd Hanoi International Film Festival in Vietnam, the 3rd Silk Road Film Festival in Dublin, Ireland, the Metro Manila Film Festival (under the New Wave Category), 13th Gawad Tanglaw, 17th Gawad Pasado, FAMAS, Urduja Heritage Awards, Gawad Genio Awards, and the 38th Gawad Urian from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino. In the first Sinag Maynila Film Festival organized by the City Government of Manila, Dizon also won the Best Actor award for his performance in Imbisibol, under the direction of Lawrence Fajardo. Dizon also won the FAMAS Best Actor award for his performance in Dukot and Paupahan and the FAMAS Best Supporting Actor award for his performance in Sigwa. Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian

DIZON, LILIA ( Claire Dizon Strauss ) b. 25 Nov 1930. Movie actor. Her parents are Regina Dizon and Abraham Strauss. She was first married to actor GildeLeon with whom she had three children: actors Pinky, Christopher, and Lara Melissa. In Hawaii with her second husband, Antonio Abad, she had two other children: Antoniette and Corrie. However, she and Abad also divorced years after their marriage.

Dizon’s first movie was Oo, Ako’y Espiya (Yes, I Am a Spy), 1946. Her first starring role was in Kamagong, 1947. This was followed by Binatang Maynila (Manila Boy), 1947. It was, however, in Alias Sakim (Alias Greedy), 1947, opposite LeopoldoSalcedo, that she caught the public’s attention.

As a contract star of LVN, Dizon became popular for doing what were then considered provocatively sexy roles, as in Kaaway ng Babae (Woman’s Enemy), Kambal na Ligaya (Twin Joys), and Perfidia, 1948; Makabagong Pilipina (Modern Filipina), 1949; Venus, 1951; Bathaluman (Goddess), 1952; Kuwintas ng Pasakit (Necklace of Suffering), 1953; and Doce Pares (Twelve Pairs), 1954. After her contract with LVN expired, she made films with other movie companies, among them Premiere’s SandaWong and Everlasting Pictures’ Simaron, both in 1955. Her other films are Umaalong Ginto (Waves of Gold), 1956; Kandilang Bakal (Iron Candle), 1957; Glory at Dawn, 1958; Pusong Bakal (Iron Heart) and The Moises Padilla Story, 1961; and Sakdalista, 1962.

In the 1970s, she appeared with Leopoldo Salcedo in Larry Santiago’s Mayo-Disyembre (May-December), and also in the debut film of his son Christopher, TinimbangKa NgunitKulang (You Were Weighed and Found Wanting), 1974, under the direction of LinoBrocka. Her most recent appearances include her role in the TV series Narito ang Puso Ko (Here Is My Heart) in 2003. She also appeared in the films Wrinkles, 2006, and Paraiso: Tatlong Kwento ng Pag-asa (Paradise: Three Stories of Hope), 2007.

Dizon received the Best Actress award for her performance in LVNPictures’ Kandelerong Pilak (Silver Candlesticks) at the 1954 Cambodia Film Festival. Written by Danny Villanueva, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

DIZON, MYLENE ( Mylene Lilibeth Dizon ) b. Manila 6 Sep 1974. Movie and television actor. Dizon studied communication arts at De La Salle University.

In 1996, alongside Marvin Agustin, Jolina Magdangal, Angelica Panganiban, and Diether Ocampo, Dizon joined Star Magic Batch 2, the elite circle of young talents being developed under ABS-CBN. Dizon’s first movie role was in Boots Plata’s Kulayan Natin ang Bukas (Let’s Color Tomorrow), 1997, where she co-starred with Judy Ann Santos. This was quickly followed by Calvento Files: The Movie, 1997. For her noteworthy performance in Calvento Files, Dizon was awarded New Movie Actress of the Year by the Star Awards for Movies.

The next two years, she focused more on her film work. In 1998, she co-starred with Romnick Sarmenta and Cris Villanueva in Gil M. Portes’s Miguel/Michelle, where she played the clueless fiancée to Villanueva’s closeted gay character. She was next seen in Laurenti Dyogi’s Magandang Hatinggabi (Pleasant Midnight), 1998. Later in the year, she rejoined the original cast of Gimik (Hang Out) for its film adaptation titled Gimik: The Reunion, 1998. In 2001, she reunited with Portes for her first starring role—the World War II adult drama Gatas … Sa Dibdib ng Kaaway (In the Bosom of the Enemy). Then, she appeared in Jon Red’s Utang ni Tatang (Grandpa’s Debt) and in Joyce Bernal’s Super B, 2002. She played the manananggal, a mythical half woman/half monster in Philippine folklore, in Ang Agimat: Anting-anting ni Lolo (The Talisman: Grandfather’s Amulet), 2002. Dizon later appeared in Mike Sandejas’s Tulad ng Dati (Just Like Before), 2006, an entry in the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, which won the Balanghai trophy for Best Film. In the same year, she played the lead role in a controversial indie film—Connie Macatuno’s lesbian drama Rome and Juliet. The film competed in the 2006 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival where Dizon received the award for Best Actress.

In 2008, Dizon lent her support to Judy Ann Santos by joining the cast of Dante Nico Garcia’s Ploning, which Santos co-produced. Later in the year, Dizon returned to the Cinemalaya for her most memorable film work to date—starring in Chris Martinez’s debut film 100. She plays Joyce, a young cancer-stricken woman who fulfills a list of things that she wants to do before she dies. Dizon won Best Actress from the Cinemalaya, Film Academy of the Philippines, Gawad Urian, and Golden Screen Awards. In 2012, Dizon played the challenging role of a nun undergoing a crisis of faith in Vicente Sandoval’s Aparisyon (Apparition), an entry in the Cinemalaya. Then, she starred in Maryo J. de los Reyes’s Bamboo Flowers and in Joyce Bernal’s action drama 10,000 Hours, 2013. She delivered impressive performances in Milo Sogueco’s Mariquina, 2014, another Cinemalaya entry, and in Jay Abello’s Red, 2014, which competed in the Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival.

Dizon became part of the original cast, together with Judy Ann Santos, Rico Yan, and Giselle Toengi, of the youth-oriented television series Gimik, from 1996 to 1999. After being a talent of ABS-CBN for 10 years, Dizon transferred to GMA Network, and appeared in its primetime soap operas, including Agawin Mo Man ang Lahat (Stolen Love) and Ang Kasagutan (The Answer), 2006; Mars Ravelo’s Captain Barbell, 2006-7; and Mars Ravelo’s Dyesebel, 2008. Over the succeeding years, Dizon would alternate her television work between the two rival stations. From 2009 to 2011, Dizon focused mostly on her television work. Some of the noteworthy soap operas are Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009; May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), 2009-10; Gilda Olvidado’s Magkano ang Iyong Dangal? (How Much Is Your Honor Worth), 2010; and Mara Clara, 2011, a remake of the Judy Ann Santos–Gladys Reyes drama from the 1990s. Written by Elvin Valerio

DOLPHY ( Rodolfo Vera Quizon )aka Pidol. b.Tondo, Manila 25 Jul 1928. d. Makati City 2 Jul 2012. Movie and television actor. At one time or another, he was romantically linked with Lotis Key, Alma Moreno, and Zsa Zsa Padilla. Among his children who have ventured in show business are Manny Quizon, Rolly Quizon, Sahlee Quizon, Dolphy Jr, Eric Quizon, Ronnie Quizon, Eric Quizon, Jeffrey Quizon, Vandolph, and Zia Quizon. Actor Boy 2 Quizon is his grandson.

Dolphy started out as a young bodabil dancer and singer, together with sister Zeny Quizon, at the Orient Theater during the Japanese Occupation. He was known as Golay, the dancing partner of Bayani Casimiro. Through actor Pancho Magalona, he met Dr Jose Perez of Sampaguita Pictures, who changed his name to Dolphy and started him off in bit and supporting roles in many Rogelio de la Rosa–Carmen Rosales starrers. He came into his own as the other half of the comedy duo Dolphy and Panchito. Their first outing was in Kalabog en Bosyo (Kalabog and Bosyo), 1950; later they appeared again in Si Lucio at si Miguel (Lucio and Miguel), 1962. Two other early films are Mambo-Dyambo, 1955, and Silveria, 1958.

Dolphy popularized gay roles in movies like Jack and Jill, 1954; Facifica Falayfay, 1969; Fefita Fofonggay vda. de Falayfay, 1973; Jack n’ Jill of the Third Kind, 1978; and Darna, Kuno? (They Say It’s Darna), 1979. This gay character was transformed and deepened in Lino Brocka’s Ang Tatay Kong Nanay (My Father the Mother), 1978, where Dolphy played an aging homosexual. In Markova: Comfort Gay, 2000, Dolphy plays the role of Walter Dempster Jr, one of the Filipino gay men who were supposedly abused by Japanese soldiers during the Japanese Occupation of the Philippines. His sons Eric and Jeffrey play the same role depicting Markova’s younger years. Markova was well-received in the 2011 Brussels International Film Festival where Dolphy, Eric, and Jeffrey received the Prix de la Meilleure Interpretation for their performance.

He did comic versions of classics, like in Cyrano at Roxanne (Cyrano and Roxanne), 1973; Ang Hiwaga ng Ibong Adarna (The Mystery of the Adarna Bird), 1973; and Tataynic (Father Nic), 1998.

In his other films, Dolphy played underdog-turned-loverboy roles, like in King and Queen for a Day, 1963; Rodolfo Valentino, 1970; and Tayo’y Mag-Up, Up and Away (Let’s Go Up, Up and Away), 1970. He played a martial arts master in Dancing Master, 1979; a cowboy in Barilan sa Baboy-Kural (Gunfight at the Pig Corral), 1962, and Mekeni’s Gold, 1970; and secret agent in James Bandong, 1964.

His recent films include Dobol Trobol: Let’s Get Redi 2 Rambol!, 2008, and Nobody Nobody but Juan, 2009. Dolphy also did a few out-of-the box films, one of them the serious film Rosario, 2010. As the narrator, he tells the colorful and scandalous story of his mother to his nephew, business magnate Manuel V. Pangilinan.

On television he created the lovable character of John, the long-suffering husband, in the TV series John en Marsha (John and Marsha), which was made into several movies. With partner Panchito, he starred in the long-running TV variety show Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life) where he did song-and-dance numbers as well as comedy skits. One of his longest-running TV series was ABS-CBN’s Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad), which aired from 1992 to 2003. He also played the lead role for TV5’s Pidol’s Wonderland, which ran from 2010 to 2012.

Dolphy received the Manila Film Festival Best Actor award in 1974 for John & Marsha and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Actor award for Omeng Satanasia, 1977. In 1992, he received the Film Academy of the Philippines Lifetime Achievement Award for his outstanding contributions to Philippine movies. Other Lifetime Achievement awards came from the Star Awards for Television, 1995, Gawad Urian, 1998, Cinemanila International Film Festival, 2000, and the Metro Manila Film Festival, 2009. His other special awards include the Cultural Center of the Philippines Centennial Honors for the Arts in 1999; Huwarang Bituin and the Exemplary Achievement awards given by the FAMAS in 2005 and 2010, respectively; the Grand Collar of the Order of the Golden Heart, the highest award given to private Filipino citizens by the president of the country, 2010; the Gawad Diwa ng Lahi, the highest award given to artists by the government of Manila, 2012; and the People’s Artist Award given by Dakilang Lahi Foundation, 2012. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

DOMINGO, EUGENE ( Eugenia Roxas Domingo ) aka Uge. b. Tondo, Manila 23 Jul 1971. Movie, television, and stage actor. Her parents are Reynaldo Domingo and Celia Roxas. She studied theater arts at the University of the Philippines Diliman.

Domingo started as a theater actor, having performed in several productions such as Mario O’Hara’s Open 25 Hours a Day back when she was still in college, and later on as Momayon in Floy Quintos’s And St. Louie Loves Dem Filipinos, 1993. Domingo’s most recent theater performance was with the Philippine Educational Theater Association’s 2012 stage adaptation of the 1980 Nora Aunor film Bona, where she played the title role. Domingo also worked on television, appearing in several ABS-CBN TV series, including Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001; Marina, 2003; Kampanerang Kuba (Hunchbacked Lady Bell Ringer), 2005; Kokey, 2007; and the small screen adaptation of the film Volta, 2008. She also appeared in various GMA Network programs such as Ako si Kim San Soon (I Am Kim San Soon), 2008, and Ang Babaeng Hinugot sa Aking Tadyang (Dangerous Love), 2008. She was in the cast of TV5’s Sa Ngalan ng Ina (In the Name of the Mother), 2012.

After doing minor roles in various movies and television soaps, Domingo was cast as Rowena, Ai-Ai de las Alas’s sidekick in Star Cinema’s production of director Wenn V. Deramas’s Ang Tanging Ina (The One and Only Mom), 2003. Domingo and de las Alas’s on-screen chemistry, with Deramas as director, was so loved by audiences that the three of them went on to make a superhero movie, Volta, 2004, and another family comedy, Ang Cute ng Ina Mo (Your Mother Is Cute), 2007.

From 2005 to 2007 Domingo became one of the busiest actors in the industry, appearing in 20 movies. By doing not just comedies but melodrama and horror films, she proved that she is not just a comedienne but a character actor. In 2007, Domingo appeared in Joel Lamangan’s comedy-drama Bahay Kubo: A Pinoy Mano Po! (Nipa Hut: A Pinoy Mano Po!) with Maricel Soriano and Eric Quizon. Soon, even independent or “indie” filmmakers started noticing her diverse talent. Her first foray into indie films was in Auraeus Solito’s (aka Kanakan Balintagos) Tuli (Circumcision), 2005. This was followed by Brillante Mendoza’s Foster Child, 2007; Solito’s Pisay (Philippine Science High School), 2007; and Dante Nico Garcia’s Ploning, 2008. She was tapped by Chris Martinez, a well-known playwright and an old friend of Domingo from her Dulaang UP days, to co-star with Mylene Dizon in Martinez’s directorial debut, 100, an entry in the 2008 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. The following year, Domingo played her first ever leading role in Kimmy Dora: Kambal sa Kiyeme (Kimmy Dora: Twins of Nonsense), 2009, directed by Joyce Bernal from a script by Chris Martinez. A certified blockbuster hit, the film spawned a sequel, Kimmy Dora and the Temple of Kiyeme (Kimmy Dora and the Temple of Nonsense), 2012, and even a prequel, Kimmy Dora: Ang Kiyemeng Prequel (Kimmy Dora: The Nonsense Prequel), 2013.

Domingo won her first acting award for her supporting role in Bahay Kubo at the 2007 Metro Manila Film Festival. In 2008, she won Best Supporting Actress at Cinemalaya for her performance in the film 100. In 2011, Domingo starred in the Cinemalaya entry Ang Babae sa Septic Tank (The Woman in the Septic Tank), directed by Marlon Rivera from Martinez’s script. This hilarious satire on indie filmmaking in the Philippines gave Domingo a Best Actress award from Cinemalaya, the People’s Choice Award for Best Actress from the 2012 Asian Film Awards in Hong Kong, and the Best Actress Award from Pau International Film Festival in France. She also won Best Actress in the main competition of the 26th Tokyo International Film Festival for her performance in Jun Robles Lana’s Mga Kuwentong Barbero (Barber’s Tales), 2013. In 2012, Domingo won the Aliw Best Actress award in theater for her role in Bona. The multi-awarded Domingo also appeared in the romantic-comedy musical I Do Bidoo Bidoo: Heto nAPO Sila! (I Do Bidoo Bidoo: The APO Is Here!), 2012; in Regal Films’ Status: It’s Complicated, 2013; and Instant Mommy, 2013, another Cinemalaya entry. Written by Elvin Valerio

DORMIENDO, JUSTINO M. (Justino Maghacot Dormiendo) aka Gino Dormiendo. b. Calbayog City 14 Apr 1947. d. Marikina City 4 Jan 2016. Essayist. He was born to Nemesio Dormiendo Sr and Ambrosia Maghacot. He lived in various places in the country, particularly in Manila, Marawi, and Cagayan de Oro, where he had his early schooling. He studied at the Philippine Normal College (now University) and Christ the King College, where he obtained his bachelor of science degree in elementary education. He completed the academic requirements for a master’s degree in education in 1975. He received several grants, including a film technology travel and observation grant to the United States in 1976, and attended the 1987 Moscow International Film Festival. Dormiendo taught at Ateneo de Manila University for 11 years. He also worked for a long period at San Miguel Corporation, editing corporate publications like the award-winning Kaunlaran magazine. In 1987 and 1988, he served as consultant to the Coordinating Center for Film of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. He was president of the Philippine Council of Industrial Communicators and founding member of Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino which he headed in 1984 and 1986, and was an active member of the Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas.

Dormiendo authored two books: Best of the Philippines, 1989, and Doon Po sa Amin, May Healer na Magaling (In Our Town, There Is a Capable Healer), 1993. He published numerous film reviews in the Times Journal, Daily Express, Sagisag magazine, Veritas, Manila Standard, Diyaryo Filipino, and Filipino Magazin. Some of his film reviews were anthologized in the Urian Anthology 1970-1979, 1983. From 1988 to 1990, he was film critic of Magandang Umaga Po (Good Morning), a daily morning show on Channel 2.

Dormiendo received the Highest Golden Leadership National Award for journalism from the Social and Civic Action Movement in 1991. Written byRosalinda Galang

D’SALVA, RAMON b. Honolulu, Hawaii USA 20 Dec 1920. Movie actor. He holds a law degree from the Philippine Law School, 1941.

D’Salva’s first movie is Anak ni Kulafu (Son of Kulafu), 1948. This was followed by Makislap na Bato (Sparkling Stone), 1949, which he wrote and directed. His other films include Suwail (Rebellious), Ang Lumang Bahay sa Gulod (The Old House on the Cliff), Kidlat sa Silangan (Lightning in the East), and Hindi Ako Susuko (I Will Not Surrender), 1949; Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fortune), Wanted: Patay o Buhay (Wanted: Dead or Alive), Punglo at Pag-ibig (Bullet and Love), and Ang Kampana ng San Diego (The Bell of San Diego), 1950; Kalbaryo ni Hesus (The Calvary of Jesus), 1952; Tiyanak (Changeling), 1953; Pedro Penduko, 1954; Adventures of DI-13, 1955; Desperado (Desperate) and Buhay at Pag-ibig ni Dr. Jose Rizal (Life and Loves of Dr Jose Rizal), 1956; Maskara (Mask), 1957; Marta Soler and Ramadal, 1958; Ang Kanyang Kamahalan (His Royal Highness), 1959; HuwagMoAkongLimutin (Never Forget Me) and Pautang ng Langit (Debt from Heaven), 1960; Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1961; El Filibusterismo (Subversion) and Prinsesang Mandirigma (Warrior Princess), 1962; Fil-American Girl, 1963; Scorpio, 1964; 7 Mukha ni Dr. Evans (7 Faces of Dr Evans), 1965; Hi Jack, 1966; Black Yoga, 1967; Valiente Brothers, 1968; Adriana, 1969; Playpen, 1971; The Hot Box, 1972; Death Force, 1978; and Twin Fists for the Blackmasters, 1979, among others. His films prior to retirement include Tukso Layuan Mo Ako (Temptation, Stay Away from Me), 1991; Sana Kahit Minsan (Even Just Once), 1992; Live by the Fist, 1993; and Caged Heat II: Stripped of Freedom and Ultimatum, 1994.

D’Salva epitomized the bemoustached city slicker and well-dressed gangster typical of the movie villains of the 1940s and 1950s. He won Best Supporting Actor in the 1957 FilipinoAcademyofMovieArtsandSciences for his performance in Desperado. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

DURAN, TITA ( Teresita Rigo Durango ) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 30 Sep 1927. d. Quezon City 26 Apr 1990. Movie actor. Her parents are Antonio Durango and Mary Rigo. She married actor Pancho Magalona. The late rap singer and actor Francis Magalona is her son. Duran’s grandchildren, Maxene Magalona and Elmo Magalona—Francis’ children—are also active in show business as TV actors. Elmo is also a rap singer.

Duran started in the movies in 1936 under Parlatone Hispano Filipino, assuming child roles for the characters played by actors Rosario Moreno, Elsa Oria, and Yolanda Marquez. She appeared in Awit ng mga Ulila (Song of the Orphans), 1936, Sa Paanan ng Krus (At the Foot of the Cross), 1936, Anak ng Kadiliman (Child of Darkness), 1937, and in Milagro ng Nazareno sa Quiapo (Miracle of the Nazarene in Quiapo), 1937. Other movie companies like Sampaguita Pictures, X’Otic Films, and Excelsior Pictures sought her out, making her the most popular child actor of the pre-World War II period. She starred in Filippine Films’ Ang Pusong Wasak (The Broken Heart), 1938, with Corazon Noble; X’Otic’s Mga Tinik ng Isang Bulaklak (A Flower’s Thorns), 1939, with Lucita Goyena; Excelsior’s Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), 1939, with Rosario Moreno; and Sampaguita’s Ang Magsasampaguita (The Flower Vendor), 1939, with Angelito Nepomuceno.

The four-year Japanese Occupation gave Duran the chance to move quietly from childhood to adolescence. She returned to the screen as a young guerrilla fighter in Sampaguita’s Guerilyera (Lady Guerrilla Fighter), 1946. Now under exclusive contract with Sampaguita, the roles were tailor-made for her. She was a young girl with a crush on Oscar Moreno in Unang Pag-ibig (First Love), 1947; the object of Fred Montilla’s courtship in Tatlong Puso (Three Hearts), 1948; and the girl who fell head over heels in love with Pancho Magalona in Dahil sa Iyo (Because of You), 1948. After their real-life marriage, the Pancho-Tita team became a byword in musicals. They appeared together in Always: Kay Ganda Mo (Always: You’re So Beautiful), 1949; Umaga Na Giliw (Morning Has Come, Love) and Kay Ganda Mo, Neneng, (You’re So Beautiful, Neneng), 1950; Sa Isang Sulyap Mo, Tita (With One Glance from You, Tita) and Vod-A-Vil, 1953; and Sa Isang Halik Mo, Pancho (With One Kiss from You, Pancho), 1954. Duran also appeared with her husband in other movies outside Sampaguita, like Premiere’s Bella Filipina (Beautiful Filipina), 1956, and People’s Pictures’ Mr. and Mrs., 1956, directed by Gerardo de Leon.

She was a mainstay in the TV drama series Kadenang Rosas (Chain of Roses), 1988-89.

Duran was nominated by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences as Best Actress for her performance in Yaya Maria (Nanny Maria). In 1987, the Film Academy of the Philippines honored Pancho Magalona and Tita Duran with a Lifetime Achievement Award for their contribution to Philippine cinema. Written by Galileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

ELLA, GREG ( Gregorio Salumbides Ella )b. Lucban, Quezon 28 Nov 1928. Movie sound director. His parents are Teodoro Ella, a barber, and Obdulia Salumbides, a relative of film director Vicente Salumbides. He married Rufina Marzo. They have four sons, one of whom, Ranier, is also a soundman. He finished a two-year course in radio and television technology at FEATI University, 1956.

Ella worked as a technician for ABS-CBN and Phil-Am Films. In 1964-68, he was audiovisual technician of the United States Embassy in Vietnam. Coming home, he worked as sound engineer for Filipino Films. He became head of the sound engineering department of the Communications Foundation of Asia.

Ella won Best Sound awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (You Were Weighed and Found Wanting), 1974, and Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), 1977. Written byCristine Directo

ESCUDERO, DON ( Placido A. Escudero Jr ) b.Manila, 27 Jun 1956. d. Pasig City 11 Jul 2011. Movie production designer, scriptwriter, and director. His parents are Placido Escudero Sr, an Air Force colonel at the time of his retirement, and Milagros Artadi. He received a bachelor of arts degree in communication arts from De La Salle University in 1976.

Escudero first worked as script supervisor and assistant production designer in Mike de Leon’s Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (When You Dream and Wake Up), 1977. He was art director under production designer Mel Chionglo in Ishmael Bernal’s Ikaw Ay Akin (You Are Mine) and Lino Brocka’s Gumising Ka… Maruja (Wake Up… Maruja), 1978. He did the production design of Marilou Diaz Abaya’s Tanikala (Chains), 1980. His first solo work as production designer was Abaya’s Brutal, 1980. Among the productions he designed are Eddie Romero’s Kamakalawa (Day before Yesterday) and Abaya’s Boystown (Juvenile Shelter), 1981; and Peque Gallaga’s Scorpio Nights, 1985.

He wrote the screenplay for Regal Films’ Tiyanak (Changeling), 1988; Isang Araw Walang Diyos (One Day without God), 1989; Too Young and Shake, Rattle & Roll II, 1990; and Shake, Rattle & Roll III, 1991. He also wrote the stories of Aswang and Shake, Rattle & Roll IV, 1992, and Dugo ng Panday (Blood of the Blacksmith), 1993.

From being a production designer, Escudero became a director in 1994, megging films such as Multo in the City (Ghost in the City) and Hindi Magbabago (Nothing Will Change), 1994; the “Maligno” (Evil Spirit) segment of Shake, Rattle & Roll V, 1995; Impakto (Terrifying Creature) and Taguan (Hide and Seek), 1996; Laging Naroon Ka (You’ll Always Be There), 1997; Halik (Kiss), 1998; Nag-aapoy na Laman (Flaming Flesh), Tugatog (Pinnacle), and Aray! (Ouch!), 2000. He also did bit roles in Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising; Jose Javier Reyes’s Iisa Pa Lamang (Only One), 1992; and Narinig Mo na Ba ang L8est? (Have You Heard the Latest?), 2001.

Escudero (with Rodell Cruz) won Best Production Design awards for Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982, in the Gawad Urian and the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) Awards. He also received Best Production Design awards from FAP for Virgin Forest, 1985; Once upon a Time, 1987; and Hiwaga sa Balete Drive (Mystery on Balete Drive), 1988. All these films were directed by Gallaga. He won the Gawad Urian Best Production Design for Abbo de la Cruz’s Misteryo sa Tuwa (Joyful Mystery), 1984, also with Rodell Cruz. Written byLena S. Pareja, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

ESMERALDA, ANGEL ( Angel de Leon Ilagan )b. Tondo, Manila 1 Oct 1914. d. Agana, Guam, 4 Jul 1985. Movie and stage actor. Esmeralda is the fifth of the 13 children of Hermogenes Ilagan and Casiana de Leon. He is the brother of film directors Gerardo de Leon and Conrado Conde, comedians Edo Nagali and Laling Talti, and music composer Tito Arevalo. He is the nephew of actor-director Mar Esmeralda or Marceliano Ilagan. With actor Corazon Noble he had a son, actor Jay Ilagan. He finished law at the University of Manila.

Esmeralda started out as a child actor in his father’s sarsuwela, playing opposite veterans like Atang de la Rama, Horacio Morelos, and Marceliano Ilagan. He continued to sing and act for the sarsuwela until he became busy with the movies.

Esmeralda’s first major appearance in the movies was in Ang Dangal (Honor), 1934, opposite Dolly Garcia and Patsy. He also appeared in the films Sa Paanan ng Krus (At the Foot of the Cross), 1936, with Tita Duran and Angelito Nepomuceno; Mga Pusong Dakila (Noble Hearts), 1937, with Rosario Moreno; Nasaan Ka Irog? (Where Are You, Beloved?), 1937, with Elsa Oria; Isang Halik Lamang (One Kiss Only), 1938, and Pangarap (Dream), 1940, both with Purita Santa Maria; Princesa ng Kumintang (Princess of the Kumintang), 1940, with Mila del Sol; and Estrellita (Little Star), 1940, with Corazon Noble. After the war, he made So Long, America, 1946; Ligaya (Happiness), 1946; Isumpa Mo, Giliw (Make a Vow, My Love), 1947; Manyika ng Santa Monica (Doll of Santa Monica), 1955; and Luis Nepomuceno Production’s Pipo, 1970.

In 1981, Esmeralda received the Walang Kupas award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences. Written by Nenuca Jose
(See MUSIC volume.)

ESTELLA, RAMON b. Hong Kong 13 Aug 1911. d. Florida, USA 4 May 1991. Movie director and scriptwriter. His father, Jose Estella, was known for his waltz compositions and called the “Filipino Johann Strauss,” and his aunt, Maria Tronqued, was a leading actor in the silent movies. He was educated at San Beda College and studied medicine at the University of Santo Tomas. In the 1920s, he became a radio star, singing Spanish songs on the air. Away from the Philippines since 1965, he lived in semiretirement in Florida, USA, with his Japanese wife.

Estella began his film career in the 1930s, when movies and radio had replaced the sarsuwela as the most popular cultural forms. His first movie assignment was in the first Filipino “talkie,” Punyal na Ginto (Golden Dagger), 1933, where he sang and made a guest appearance. He also wrote a few stories, particularly for director Carlos Vander Tolosa. By the 1950s, he had become one of the top-ranking directors of Philippine movies, together with Gerardo de Leon, Lamberto V. Avellana, and Manuel Conde—the four “wonder boys” who brought Philippine cinema to international prominence during that period. In a career that spanned 40 years, he made a total of 79 full-length feature films, 50 documentary shorts and features, and 50 TV commercials. Unfortunately, most of his films, including the most important ones, have been lost or are difficult to locate.

Estella directed his first film, Bayan at Pag-ibig (Country and Love), 1938, for Excelsior Pictures. Moving to Filippine Films, he made the movies that established him as a director of great promise. Two of them, Huling Habilin (Last Will), 1940, and Buenavista, 1940, were considered by the late art critic T. D. Agcaoili as two of the finest local pictures ever made. He also made Ang Tagala (The Tagalog Woman), Kundiman (Love Song), Singsing na Pangkasal (Wedding Ring), Paraiso (Paradise), and Ilang-Ilang, 1941. After World War II, he directed a succession of films: Voice of Freedom, 1946, which tackled guerrilla life during the Japanese Occupation; Tagumpay (Victory), 1946, a love story set during the war; Magkaibang Lahi (Different Races), 1947, the story of a Filipina who, after marriage to an American soldier and life in America, realizes that there is no place like home; Labi ng Bataan (Bataan Survivors), 1948, the story of those who miraculously survived the infamous Death March in 1941; and Ako Raw ay Huk (They Call Me Rebel), 1948, a violent tour de force, which was heavily censored and whose title was altered. He also wrote and directed Angelus, 1946, the movie version of the stage play Ave Maria, about a man who sold his soul to the devil. Other memorable films he did are Kenkoy, 1950, based on the popular komiks serial, and Sundalong Talahib (Grass Soldier), 1950, a story of the Hukbalahap movement. Other films he did after the war include Caprichosa (Lady of Whims), 1947; Anghel sa Lupa (Angel on Earth), Perfidia, and Hiram na Pangalan (Borrowed Name), 1948; Liham ng Bayani (Hero’s Letter), Kay Ganda ng Umaga (How Beautiful Is the Morning), and Dugo ng Katipunan (Katipunan Blood), 1949; Punglo at Pag-ibig (Bullet and Love), Bandido (Bandit), and Prinsipe Don Juan (Prince Don Juan), 1950.

In the 1950s Estella left for New York where he took up film and television courses and learned from prominent American directors like Fred Zinnemann and Robert Flaherty. He worked for the United Nations Secretariat as officer in charge of documentary films, newsreels, and TV shows—a job that brought him to parts of Latin America and Indochina. In 1955, he directed a full-length film, Twins, in Vietnam, a joint production between the United States Information Service and Thet Productions, Saigon. Returning to the Philippines in 1955, he completed two ambitious projects. One was Desperado (Desperate), 1956, a Philippine version of the Wild West, which director Lino Brocka described as “an exciting example of a B-movie.” The other one was Buhay at Pag-ibig ni Dr. Jose Rizal (Life and Loves of Dr Jose Rizal), 1956, a three-hour, slow-paced film that depicted major events in the patriot’s life. He also directed Sta. Rita de Casia and Ramir, 1958. Later, he directed films abroad, including Kim, 1957, a co-production of Thet Productions of Vietnam and Cirio Santiago Film Organization, and a couple of movies for Malay Films of the Shaw Brothers, Maria Menado Productions, and Cathay Keris, such as Kembali Saorang (One Came Back), 1957; Mata Hari (The Rape of Malaya), 1958; Samseng (Gangster), 1959; Darah-Ku (My Blood), 1963; Pontianak Kembali (The Pontianak Returns), 1964; and Pusaka Pontianak (The Accursed Heritage), 1965. Estella also did a number of movies set in Japan, such as Tokyo Calling, 1971, and Pedro Goes to Tokyo, 1961, which sought to promote brotherhood and cooperation among Asians. In New York, he produced and directed shorts for Charles Hans Film Productions. He also made one Italian movie, Consiglio Costoso. In 1969, he transferred to San Juan, Puerto Rico, where he filmed documentaries and commercials and produced a weekly reportage, Puerto Rico Today.

Estella was chosen Director of the Year by Philippine Cinema and Radio for Buenavista in 1941. He won Best Director from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Desperado, which also won the FAMAS awards for Best Picture and Best Editing. Samseng and Mata Hari won awards in Malaya-Singapore. Some of the documentaries he made in Puerto Rico received the Agney Bayani Award, a prestigious local prize. Written by Teddie Co and Rosalinda Galang, updated by Nicanor G. Tiongson

ESTRADA, JOSEPH ( Jose Marcelo Ejercito ) akaErap. b. San Juan, Rizal 19 Apr 1937. Movie actor and producer. His parents are Emilio Ejercito, a civil engineer, and Maria Marcelo. He attended elementary schooling at St. John Academy and high school at Ateneo de Manila. He enrolled at Mapua Institute of Technology, finishing three years of mechanical engineering. He is married to Luisa Pimentel, a doctor. They have three children, one of whom is Jinggoy Estrada, actor, former mayor of San Juan, Metro Manila, and member of the Philippine Senate. His son with former Asiong Salonga co-star Guia Gomez is senator JV Ejercito. Brother Jesse Ejercito is producer of Crown Seven and Seven Stars Productions. Another brother was actor GeorgeEstregan. His nephew ER Ejercito (aka Jeorge Estregan) is also an actor and politician. Another nephew is actor Gary Estrada.

Estrada founded the MovieWorkersWelfareFoundation Inc in 1974 and now serves as chairman emeritus of its Board of Trustees. He is a member of the board of advisers of the Actors Guild of the Philippines. He was also at one time president of the PhilippineMotionPicturesProducersAssociation. He was elected mayor of San Juan, Rizal, in 1969, senator in 1987, vice president in 1992, and president of the Republic of the Philippines in 1998, a position he held until he was deposed in 2001. In 2013, Estrada was elected mayor of the city of Manila.

Estrada first appeared in Kandilang Bakal (Iron Candle), 1954, and was introduced in LVN Pictures’ ?10,000 Pag-ibig (?10,000 Love), 1957. He established himself as a top-ranking action star in Larry Santiago Productions’ Asiong Salonga, 1961. His other films include Sapang Palay, 1965; Alamat ng 7 Kilabot (The Legend of the Seven Terrors), 1967; Galo Gimbal and Valiente Brothers, 1968; Dugo ng Bayani (Blood of a Hero), 1969; Hukom Bitay (Judge Executioner), 1971; Tatay Na si Erap (Erap Is Now a Father), 1972; Panic!, 1973; Manila Connection, 1974; Diligin Mo ng Hamog ang Uhaw na Lupa (Water the Parched Earth with Dew), 1975; Sa Dulo ng Kris (At Dagger’s End), 1977; Tatak ng Tondo (Mark of Tondo), 1978; Hoy, Tukso Layuan Mo Ako! (Hey, Temptation, Stay Away from Me!), 1980; and Pedring Taruc, 1982. In 1988 he produced and starred, together with representative Nikki Coseteng, in Sa Kuko ng Agila (In the Claws of the Eagle), an anti-foreign bases film that echoed his own nationalist sentiments. After a long stint in politics, he did Ang Tanging Pamilya: A Merry-Go-Round! (The Only Family: A Merry-Go-Round!), 2009.

Estrada won Best Actor awards from the FilipinoAcademyofMovieArtsandSciences (FAMAS) for Markang Rehas (Mark of the Prison Bars), 1962; GeronBusabos: Ang Batang Quiapo (Geron the Vagabond), 1964; Ito ang Pilipino (Behold the Filipino), 1966; Patria Adorada (Beloved Country), 1969; and Kumander Alibasbas (Commander Alibasbas), 1981. Estrada also set up Emar Pictures and JE Productions, which received the FAMAS Best Picture awards for the films Geron Busabos; Ito ang Pilipino; Kill the Pushers, 1972; Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), 1977; and Kumander Alibasbas. For this feat, he was twice elevated to the FAMAS Hall of Fame as actor and as producer. He also won Best Actor in the 1975 Metropolitan Film Festival for his performance in Diligin Mo ng Hamog ang Uhaw na Lupa. In 1989, he received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Film Academy of the Philippines. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Pamela Mathiel Lopez

ESTREGAN, GEORGE ( Jorge Marcelo Ejercito ) b.Manila 10 Jul 1939. d. 8 Aug 1988. Movie actor. Born to Emilio Ejercito and Maria Marcelo, he was the younger brother of actor-politician Joseph Estrada and film producer Jesse Ejercito. Estregan took up engineering at the National University. He had four children by his wife, Ramona Pelayo. Two of his children are actors Gary Estrada and ER Ejercito aka Jeorge Estregan.

He began with a small role in Jose Nazareno: Ang Taxi Driver (Jose Nazareno: The Taxi Driver), 1963, was introduced in Carnap, 1965, and was assigned a starring role in Kid Brother, 1967. He played the title role in Erik, 1970, opposite Rowena Romero. He often essayed kontrabida (antagonist) roles.

Estregan earned praise for his portrayals in Sapang Palay, 1965; Ang Babaing Ito ay Akin (This Woman Is Mine), 1966; Psycho Sex Killer, 1970; Legal, 1974; Lumapit… Lumayo ang Umaga (Morning Comes and Goes), 1975; Nunal sa Tubig (Speck in the Water), 1976; and Lalaki Ako (I Am a Man), 1982.

The Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) chose Estregan as Best Actor for his performance in Sukdulan (Climax), 1972, and Best Supporting Actor for Kid Kaliwete (Left-Handed Kid), 1978, and Lumakad Kang Hubad sa Mundong Ibabaw (Walk Naked in the World), 1980. He received Best Supporting Actor award from the Film Academy of the Philippines and a FAMAS nomination for his performance in Bulaklak ng Apoy (Fire Flower), 1984. Written by Danny Villanueva

ESTRELLA, LINDA ( Consuelo Vera Rigotti-Agana )b. Pandan, Catanduanes 3 Dec 1922. d. Indiana, USA 18 Feb 2012. Movie actor. Her parents are Jose Rigotti and Francisca Vera, sister of Judge Jose O. Vera of SampaguitaPictures. She studied home economics at Philippine Women’s University. She married Adriano Agana, a doctor. They had two daughters: Cynthia, who died a few days after being born, and Tessie. TessieAgana was the acclaimed child star of the 1950s. In 1954, the Aganas adopted another daughter, Maria Lourdes.

At 13, Estrella played the young CarmenRosales in Prinsesita (Little Princess), 1940. After World War II, she appeared in LVNPictures’ Garrison 13, The Voice of Freedom, and Dalawang Daigdig (Two Worlds), all made in 1946. By 1948, she was signed up as a contract star for Sampaguita. Her first picture as a lead actor was Dalawang Dambana (Two Altars), 1948. Among her notable films are Hindi Kita Malimot (I Can’t Forget You), 1948; Ilaw sa Landas (Light on the Path) and Damit Pangkasal (Wedding Gown), 1949; Baguio Cadets, 1950; and Kasaysayan ni Dr. Ramon Selga (History of Dr Ramon Selga), 1951.

Estrella and Tessie Agana formed a mother-and-daughter team in Campo O’Donnell (Camp O’Donnell), 1950; Kasaysayan ni Dr. Ramon Selga; Batas ng Daigdig (Law of the World) and Kerubin (Cherub), 1952; Munting Koronel (Little Colonel), 1953; and other films of Sampaguita Pictures. They appeared together in Alta Productions’ Kung Ako’y Maging Dalaga (When I Grow Up to Be a Lady), 1954, the first picture of the movie company that the Aganas put up as their own. Estrella was one of the first few female actors who used her own singing voice on-screen then. Written byDanny Villanueva, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

FABREGAS, JAIME ( Jaime Garcia Fabregas ) aka Jimmy Fabregas. b. Iriga City, Camarines Sur 28 Feb 1950. Film and television actor, music director. He is the son of Pedro Fabregas and Isabel Garcia. He is married to Ma. Consuelo Tordesillas, producer of the children’s show Batibot (Small But Strong). He has five children, three from a previous marriage and two with Tordesillas. His daughter Lara Fabregas is an actor. He finished elementary at Naga Parochial School and high school at Ateneo de Naga. He graduated with a degree in chemical engineering from De La Salle University in 1970.

Starting as a stage actor, Fabregas entered television and, from there, made his way to the movies. He appeared in such critically acclaimed films as Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?), 1976; Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), Haplos (Caress), and Ito Ba ang Ating mga Anak? (Are These Our Children?), 1982; and Paano Hahatiin ang Puso? (How Is the Heart to Be Divided?), 1986; and comedies like Bad Bananas sa Puting Tabing (Bad Bananas on Silver Screen), 1983, and Shoot That Ball, 1987. His later films are Jose Rizal, 1998; Ngayong Nandito Ka (Now That You’re Here), 2003; D’ Anothers, 2005; Eternity, 2006; Here Comes the Bride and Rosario, 2010; A Mother’s Story, 2011; Guni-guni (Illusion), I Do Bidoo Bidoo: Heto nAPO Sila! (I Do Bidoo Bidoo: The APO Is Here!), and The Strangers, 2012; Raketeros (Racketeers), 2013; and Trophy Wife, 2014.

On television, Fabregas is best known for his role as the newscaster in the satirical Sic O’Clock News. He also did TV sitcoms like Mana (Inheritance) and ATM, and drama series such as ABS-CBN’s My Little Juan and Juan dela Cruz, 2013, Mars Ravelo’s Dyesebel and The Legal Wife, 2014, and GMA Network’s Ang Dalawang Mrs. Real (The Two Mrs Real), 2014, and Pari ’Koy (Father ’Koy), 2015.

Apart from acting, Fabregas did music scoring for a wide variety of movies. Among these are Boatman and Misteryo sa Tuwa (Joyful Mystery), 1984; Virgin Forest, Private Show, and Batang Quiapo (Quiapo Kid), 1986; Once upon a Time, 1987; Ibulong Mo sa Diyos (Whisper to God) and Sandakot na Bala (A Handful of Bullets), 1988; Joe Pring and Ang Pumatay nang Dahil sa Iyo (To Kill for You), 1989; Kahit Konting Pagtingin (Just a Little Love), 1990; Sa Kabila ng Lahat (Despite Everything) and Ang Utol Kong Hoodlum (My Hoodlum Brother), 1991; Andres Manambit: Angkan ng Matatapang (Andres Manambit: Clan of the Brave), Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), Kamay ni Cain (Hand of Cain), and Tag-araw, Tag-ulan (Summer Days, Rainy Days), 1992. Later, he did the musical score for Abakada … Ina (ABC … Mother), 2001, and Kutob (Hunch), 2005.

Fabregas received Best Supporting Actor awards for Jose Rizal from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) in 1998 and from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, Gawad Urian, and the Star Awards for Movies in 1999.

Fabregas received music awards for Shake, Rattle & Roll, 1984, from the MMFF; for Scorpio Nights, 1985, from the Gawad Urian and the Star Awards; for Virgin Forest, 1985, from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP); for Tagos ng Dugo (Bloodstain), 1987, from the FAP; for My Other Woman, 1990, from the Gawad Urian; for Mumbaki, 1996, from the Star Awards for Movies; and for Kutob, 2005, from the MMFF. Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

FAJARDO, LAWRENCE ( Lawrence Anthony Vivero Fajardo ) b. 18 Sep 1976. Film director, producer, writer, editor. He is the son of seaman Amelito Fajardo and housewife Lourdes Vivero. His wife, Krisma Maclang, is a film producer. His brother Francis Danielle Fajardo is an art director. He received a bachelor of arts in mass communication at the University of Saint La Salle in Bacolod City, which he completed in 2000.

Among the films that Fajardo directed are Teniente (Lieutenant), 1999; Kultado (Boiling Point) and Raket ni Nanay (Mother’s Side Job), 2005; Prinsesa (Princess), 2006; Liwanag sa Dilim (Light in the Darkness), 2007; Bayani: Isang Imbestigasyon sa Pagkatao at Pakikibaka ni Dr. Jose Rizal (Hero: An Investigation into the Identity and Struggle of Dr Jose Rizal), Xdeal, and Amok, 2011; Posas (Shackled) and The Strangers, 2012; Imbisibol (Invisible), 2015; and Kasunduan (Agreement), 2016.

Fajardo also edited several films, many of which were also under his direction such as Teniente, Raket ni Nanay, Liwanag sa Dilim, Xdeal, Amok, Posas, The Strangers, and Imbisibol. Other films he edited are Boy, Sanglaan (Pawnshop), Colorum (Unlicensed Taxicab), and Dolores, 2009; Trespassers and Anatomiya ng Korupsyon (Anatomy of Corruption), 2011; Mana (Inheritance), 2014; Chain Mail, 2015; and Ned’s Project, 2016.

In 2005, Fajardo won a Special Jury Prize for his short film Kultado at Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. The following year, he won awards for Best Editing (shared with Jobin Ballesteros) and Best Sound from Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival for Raket ni Nanay, and the award for Best Short Film from the Gawad Urian for Kultado, 2005. In 2007, he won the Audience Choice Award from Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival for Prinsesa. In 2011, he won the Balanghai trophy for Best Editing (New Breed) from Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival for Amok.
