He also received the Cinemalaya Balanghai trophy for Best Film (Directors’ Showcase) for Posas in 2012. In the same year, Fajardo won a Gawad Urian for Best Editing for Amok. In 2015, he received from Sinag Maynila Film Festival the awards for Best Director and Best Production Design (the latter shared with Rolando Inocencio) for Imbisibol. Fajardo won the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award from the 2016 Vesoul Asian Film Festival for Imbisibol. Written by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

FALLORINA, HIGINO b. Calumpit, Bulacan 11 Jan 1909. d. 7 Nov 1985. Cinematographer. He married Soccoro Mapua, with whom he had five children. He studied cinematography by correspondence at the New York Institute of Photography.

Fallorina started out as a still photographer for Filippine Films in 1935, becoming an assistant cameraman a year later. In 1937 he rose to full-fledged cinematographer in Gamu-gamong Naging Lawin (Moth That Became a Hawk). In 1938 he transferred to Excelsior Pictures, and beginning 1939 he worked with Sampaguita Pictures until after World War II. During the war, Fallorina made Tatlong Maria (Three Marys) for a Japanese film exchange.

Among his films are Sonny Side, 1971, Katawang Lupa (Earthly Body), 1975, Mababagsik na Anghel (Ferocious Angels), 1975, and Saan Ka Pupunta, Lutgarda Nicolas? (Where Are You Going, Lutgarda Nicolas?), 1975.

Fallorina won two Maria Clara Best Cinematography awards: for Baguio Cadets, 1950, and for Roberta, 1951. He received Best Cinematography awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Lalaki, Kasalanan Mo (Man, This Is Your Fault), 1973, and Krimen: Kayo ang Humatol (Crime: You Be the Judge), 1974. He was also cited by the Manila Film Festival for the cinematography of Krimen. Written byLena S. Pareja

article_title: FAMAS (See Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences.)
text: (See FILIPINO ACADEMY OF MOVIE ARTS AND SCIENCES.)

FELEO-GONZALEZ, MARINA ( Marina Nabong Feleo-Gonzales ) b. Santa Rosa, Nueva Ecija 11 Jul 1930. Writer for radio, TV, film, and stage. She grew up in Santa Rosa, Nueva Ecija, where her father, Juan Tuazon Feleo, a schoolteacher, became a leader of the Philippine peasant movement, Pambansang Kalipunan ng mga Magbubukid sa Pilipinas. Her mother is Florencia David Nabong. She took up courses in philosophy and journalism at the University of Santos Tomas. Even though she did not finish her degree, she received the Outstanding Silver Jubilarian Award, Philosophy and Letters, in 1979. Her husband is Arling Palanca Gonzalez, a broadcast director; her daughter Marlina is a film curator; her son Jojo (aka Dodo) is a film-TV-stage actor. Her other relatives in the media are brother Ben Feleo, movie writer-director; Fred Gonzalez, twin brother of Arling, TV director-producer; nephew Johnny Delgado, husband of Laurice Guillen, actor; grandnieces Ina Feleo, actor, and Ana Feleo, actor-singer; niece Anita Feleo, author; and nephew Roberto Feleo, visual artist.

While still in high school, Feleo-Gonzalez started working as a voice talent for radio dramas. In the 1960s, she eventually began writing scripts for radio shows, like Ora Engkantada (Enchanted Hour), Pinagsisisihan Ko Ito (I Confess), Beinte Cuatro Oras (24 Hours), and Fiesta Filipina. She eventually branched out to TV as writer of Wansapanataym (Once upon a Time) from 1972 to 1982, a weekly children’s TV program retelling Philippine mythology and folklore. A fateful meeting with actor-producer Armida Siguion-Reyna led to her coming on board as writer for Aawitan Kita (I Shall Sing for You), from 1973 to 1983, the much-awarded television show that recreated Philippine cultural heritage and history through music, art, and poetry. Notable examples of Aawitan Kita episodes written by Feleo-Gonzalez are “Josefina, Josefina,” 1973, based on the letters of Josephine Bracken to Rizal; “Binhi” (Seedling), 1973, a sarsuwela for television about women’s reproductive rights; and “Ang Lakambini at ang Supremo” (The Muse and the Supreme Chief), 1976, about the assassination of Andres Bonifacio.

In the mid-1970s, Feleo-Gonzalez started writing screenplays, notably Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth), 1976; Laruang Apoy (Playing with Fire), 1977; Ibalik Mo ang Araw sa Mundong Makasalanan (Return the Sun to the Sinful World), 1978; and Ang Alamat ni Julian Makabayan (The Legend of Julian Makabayan), 1979. Her most acclaimed work is the screenplay for Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo, based on true events of children killed while scavenging for scraps outside Clark United States air base, which won trophies for her writing at both the Metropolitan Film Festival, 1976, and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards, 1977. For her television work, she received the Philippine Academy for Television Arts and Sciences awards for Wansapanataym and Aawitan Kita.

For the stage, Feleo-Gonzalez wrote A Song for Manong, 1988, a tribute to Carlos Bulosan and the initial wave of Filipino migrant workers to the United States.

Feleo-Gonzalez was founding chair of the Association of Radio/TV Writers of the Philippines and founding member of the Screenwriters Guild of the Philippines. She taught writing at the University of the Philippines, Ateneo de Manila University, De La Salle University, State University of New York, Hunter College, and Columbia University. As media specialist at the Independent Television Services and the New York Foundation for the Arts, she assisted as mentor in the development and financing of such films as My Architect, 2003; Sacco and Vanzetti, 2006; and Afghan Women: A History of Struggle, 2007. Written by Gil Quito

FERNANDEZ, GREGORIO b. Lubao, Pampanga 24 May 1904. d. Manila 14 Oct 1973. Movie director, actor. His parents are Eugenio Araneta Fernandez and Maria Montemayor. He married Ma. Paz Padilla of the well-known Padilla clan of the movies, with whom he had eight children, among them Rudy Fernandez, one of the country’s top action stars, and Merle Fernandez, an actor known for taking on daring roles.

In 1926, he bested 700 applicants who took screen tests for the lead role in the silent film Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas (Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow), based on Aurelio Tolentino’s revolutionary play. However, the film was never finished. Jose Nepomuceno then cast him in Hot Kisses, with Georgina Harris and Luis Tuason, and The Filipino Woman in 1927. He also appeared in films like Sampaguita and Ang Lumang Simbahan (The Old Church), 1928; Desperation, 1929, with Mary Walter; Ang Anak sa Ligaw (Child by Courtship), 1930; Moro Pirates and Ang Lihim ni Bathala (God’s Secret), 1931; Ang Gayuma (The Love Potion), Satanas (Satan), Ang Ilaw ng Kapitbahay (The Neighbor’s Light), Sa Labi ng Lumang Libingan (In the Ruins of an Old Cemetery), and Ang Impierno sa Mundo (Hell on Earth), all in 1932; Mga Kaluluwang Napaligaw (Lost Souls), 1936; Taong Demonyo (Demon Man) and Ang Birheng Walang Dambana (The Virgin without a Shrine), 1937.

The first film he directed was Filippine Films’ Asahar at Kabaong (Bridal Garland and Casket) in 1937 starring Rosa del Rosario, Jose Padilla Jr, and himself. In 1940, he came up with two box-office hits, Señorita (Young Mistress), and Colegiala (Coed), both starring Rogelio de la Rosa and Carmen Rosales. After this, he became the favorite of the two stars, whom he directed again after the war in Kampanang Ginto (Golden Bell), 1949. He also worked for LVN, making ?1,000 Kagandahan (?1,000 Beauty), 1948, considered one of his best films. In this movie and in Panagimpan (Imagination), 1959, he used his favorite theme of double and mistaken identity. Among other films he directed were Garrison 13, 1946; Puting Bantayog (White Monument), 1948; Capas, 1949; Rodrigo de Villa, 1952; Prinsipe Teñoso (Prince Teñoso), 1954; Awit ng mga Dukha (Song of the Poor), 1960; Hukom Roldan (Judge Roldan), 1957; Malvarosa, 1958; and Kung Ako’y Mahal Mo (If You Love Me), 1960. Rodrigo de Villa and Prinsipe Teñoso were filmed in color starring Mario Montenegro.

Fernandez won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) award for Best Director for Higit sa Lahat (Above All), 1955. This picture was the Philippine entry in the Asian Film Festival in Hong Kong, where Fernandez won the award for Best Director of Asia. He was also a FAMAS nominee for Best Director for Luksang Tagumpay (Dark Victory), 1956, and Emily, 1960. Written byEmelie B. Capulong and Cesar Hernando

FERNANDEZ, RUDY ( Rodolfo Padilla Fernandez ) aka Daboy. b. Manila 3 Mar 1952. d. Quezon City 7 Jun 2008. Movie and television actor, producer. His parents were movie director Gregorio Fernandez and Paz Padilla of the Padilla-Ruiz clan in show business. He was the brother of actor Merle Fernandez; cousin to movie actor and world boxing referee Carlos Padilla Jr, actor Robin Padilla, director Bebong Osorio, and former child star Tessie Santos; and nephew to director Ateng Osorio and to actors Maria Clara Ruiz, Jose Padilla Jr, Carlos Padilla Sr, and Amado Cortez. Singer-actor Zsa Zsa Padilla and actor Maritoni Fernandez are his nieces. He studied at Aquinas School and took up commerce at the University of Santo Tomas (UST). He married actor Lorna Tolentino, with whom he had two children, Ralph and Renz. He had another son, Mark Anthony, by actor Alma Moreno. Fernandez served as president of the Actors’ Guild, aka Katipunan ng mga Artista ng Pelikulang Pilipino, for three terms from 1990 to 1993.

His first appearance in film was as a toddler in LVN Pictures’ Luksang Tagumpay (Dark Victory), 1956, and as a child actor in Emily, 1960, both directed by his father. In the 1970s, he was an 18-year-old student at UST when his sister Merle encouraged him to join the movies. His father brought him to Sampaguita Pictures, where Dr Jose R. Perez gave him a build-up contract for four years. He was introduced in For You, Mama, 1970, as the boy-next-door who had a crush on Marifi. This was followed by Sweet Matutina, 1971, where he was paired with Connie Angeles. In Life Everlasting, 1971, he played a dramatic role as the rival of Pepito Rodriguez for Rosemarie. Alona Alegre was his love interest in Sandra Lee, 1973.

The death of Dr Perez nipped Fernandez’s Sampaguita career, and he was forced to freelance. His big break came when he made Bitayin si Baby Ama (Execute Baby Ama), 1976, directed by Jun Gallardo. This film set him as an action-dramatic star. It was so successful that producers made sure that his next films were also of the same genre: Wanted Dead or Alive and Usigin ang Maysala (Prosecute the Guilty One), 1976; Valentin Labrador, 1977; Ex-Convict and Anak sa Una, Kasal sa Ina (Child of the First Marriage, Married to the Mother), 1978; Hoodlum Killer, Hold-up, and Teritoryo Ko Ito (This Is My Territory), 1979. One of his most notable films during this period was Ang Leon, Ang Tigre, at ang Alamid (The Lion, the Tiger, and the Wildcat), 1979, where he shared title billing with two other action stars, Bembol Roco and Lito Lapid. Fernandez took on other main and supporting roles, such as those in the films Pader at Rehas (Walls and Bars), 1980; Pepeng Shotgun and Lukso ng Dugo (Blood Ties), 1981; Get My Son Dead or Alive, 1982; Sumuko Ka, Ronquillo (Surrender, Ronquillo), 1983; Bilang Na ang Oras Mo (Your Time Is Running Out) and Anak ng Tondo (Son of Tondo), 1985; Lumuhod Ka sa Lupa (Kneel on the Ground) and Mabuhay Ka sa Baril (Live by the Gun), 1986; Humanda Ka, Ikaw ang Susunod (Beware, You’re Next) and Vigilante, 1987; Tubusin Mo ng Dugo (Ransom with Blood), Kaaway ng Batas (Enemy of the Law), and Sandakot na Bala (A Handful of Bullets), 1988; Ipaglalaban Ko (I Will Fight for It), 1989; Markang Bungo: The Bobby Ortega Story (Skull Mark), 1991; Lagalag: The Eddie Fernandez Story (Vagabond), 1994; Birador (Hitman), 1998; Sagot Kita: Mula Ulo Hanggang Paa (I Got You Covered from Head to Toe), 2000; Markang Bungo 2: Iligpit si Bobby Ortega (Skull Mark 2: Execute Bobby Ortega), 2001; and Hula Mo, Huli Ko (Your Guess, My Bust), 2002. His last film role was as Inspector Randy Tuazon in Hula Mo, Huli Ko. Fernandez uttered the oft-quoted line, “Trabaho lang, walang personalan” (Just doing my job, nothing personal), in the original Bobby Ortega biopic.

Fernandez won Best Actor trophies from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA), and the Star Awards for Movies. He received FAP and FAMAS awards for Batuigas: Pasukuin si Waway (Batuigas: Get Waway to Surrender), 1984; another FAMAS for Victor Corpus, 1987; and the CMMA for Sandakot na Bala. His contributions to the Philippine cinema were acknowledged with lifetime achievement awards. He received the Fernando Poe Jr Lifetime Achievement Award from the FAP in 2007, the Fernando Poe Jr Memorial Award from the FAMAS in 2007, and the Ulirang Artista Lifetime Achievement Award from the Star Awards for Movies in 2008.

Fernandez also starred in a few television series for GMA Network, such as Daboy en da Girl (Daboy and the Girl), 2002, Now and Forever, 2006, and Atlantika, 2006-7, his last TV appearance as actor. Written byLena S. Pareja and Erika Carreon

FERNANDO, DINDO ( Jose Surban Chua ) b. Virac, Catanduanes 1941. d. Manila 27 Aug 1987. Movie and television actor. He married Maria Corazon David, with whom he had four children. He took premed courses at San Juan de Letran College, then shifted to business administration at Far Eastern University. He was one-time councilor of Marikina, Metro Manila.

Fernando’s appearance in Talipandas (Wayward), 1958, so impressed Dr Jose R. Perez that he signed him up for a Sampaguita buildup contract. He played his first lead role in Pitong Kalbaryo ni Inang (Mother’s Seven Calvaries), 1962. He was leading man to Rosemarie Sonora in most of his early films, including Dance-O-Rama and Class Reunion, 1963; Jukebox Jamboree and Magkakapatid na Waray (Waray Siblings), 1964; Magic Bilao (Magic Winnowing Basket) and Birhen sa Lupa (Virgin on Earth), 1965; and Jamboree ’66, 1966. He also appeared with other Stars ’66 leading ladies, among them Blanca Gomez in Mga Batang Artista (The Young Artists) and Mga Batang Milyonaryo (The Young Millionaires), 1964; Liberty Ilagan in Mga Espada ng Rubitanya (Swords of Rubitanya), 1965; Elizabeth Bankhead in Kung Wala Na ang Pag-ibig (When Love Is Gone), 1965; Loretta Marquez in Malupit ang Pag-ibig (Love Is Cruel), 1967, and Deborah, 1968; and Gina Pareño in Dalawang Mukha ng Anghel (Two Faces of an Angel), 1968.

Fernando’s talent as an actor was further put to the test after his contract with Sampaguita ended and he freelanced in films outside the studio, such as Binhi (Seedling), 1973; Fe, Esperanza, Caridad, 1974; Araw-Araw, Gabi-Gabi (Every Day, Every Night), 1975; Mortal, 1976; and Abel at Cain (Abel and Cain), 1979.

He was a mainstay in the popular TV series Flordeluna with Janice de Belen and Laurice Guillen. Fernando received Best Actor awards from Gawad Urian for Ikaw at ang Gabi (You and the Night), 1979, and from both the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) and Metro Manila Film Festival for Langis at Tubig (Oil and Water), 1980. He was a nominee for Best Actor in the 1962 Asian Film Festival for his performance in Sampaguita’s Mga Anak sa Pagkakasala (Children of Sin). He was Best Actor nominee for Psycho Maniac, 1968, Liku-Likong Landas (Crooked Paths), 1968, Panic, 1973, May Langit ang Bawat Nilikha (A Heaven for Every Creature), 1976, and Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan? (How Often Is Once?), 1982, in the FAMAS; for Inay (Mother), 1977, Langis at Tubig, and Alyas Baby Tsina (Alias Baby Tsina), 1984, in the Gawad Urian; and for Muling Buksan ang Puso (Open the Heart Again), 1985, in the Film Academy of the Philippines Awards. Written byGalileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja

FERRER, TONY (Antonio D. Laxa ) b. Macabebe, Pampanga 12 Jun 1934. Movie actor, director, and producer. He is the younger brother of producer Espiridion Laxa of Tagalog Ilang-Ilang Productions. Actor Maricel Laxa is his daughter with Imelda Ilanan; and actor Mutya Laxa and Falcon are his children with his Golden Child co-actor Alice T. Crisostomo, first Mutya ng Pilipinas.

Ferrer first appeared in Kilabot sa Barilan(Gunfight Terror), 1961, and portrayed supporting roles to Joseph Estrada, Zaldy Zshornack, Romeo Vasquez, and Fernando Poe Jr in Mga Tigreng Taga-Bukid (Tigers from the Countryside) and Suicide Commandos, 1962. His first starring role was inMarkong Bagsik (Marko the Cruel One), 1962.

It was not until Ferrer depicted the role of James Bond-like spy Tony Falcon, Agent X-44, in the 1966 Manila Film Festival top-grosser Sabotage that he became a box-office star and the most successful secret agent in local films. He was paired off with popular and attractive women in over a dozen X-44 movies afterward. Some of these films were shown throughout Asia. He also starred in international movies with Christopher Lee in The Vengeance of Fu Manchu, 1967; with Chris Mitchum in Cosa Nostra Asia, 1974; with Pat Anderson in Cover Girl Models, 1975; and with Fred Williamson in Blind Rage, 1978.

Ferrer established Margarita Productions, which made Efren Piñon’s Sabotage II,1978. He later wrote, produced, and directed Legs Katawan Babae (Legs Body Woman), 1981. He also appeared with Ramon Revilla in Nardong Putik, 1972; Niño Muhlach in Wonder Boy, 1976; Nora Aunor in Sa Lungga ng mga Daga (In the Rathole), 1978; Lito Lapid in Back to Back, Ramon Zamora in Experts, and Rey Malonzo in Deadly Fighters, 1979; Ace Vergel in Pangkat Do or Die (Do or Die Group), 1980; Weng-Weng in For Y’ur Height Only, 1981; Vic Vargas in Dope Godfathers and Bembol Roco and Efren Reyes Jr in Over My Dead Body, 1983; Bong Revilla in Chinatown: Sa Kuko ng Dragon (Chinatown: In the Claws of the Dragon), 1988; Jess Lapid Jr in Isang Milyon sa Ulo ng Cobra (A Million on the Head of the Cobra), 1990; and Vhong Navarro in the remake Agent X44, 2007; plus the music video of Manila-based band Juan Pablo Dream, 2009.

Ferrer won Best Actor at the Quezon City Film Festival for Sapagkat Sila’y Aming mga Anak (Because They Are Our Children), 1970, and was a recipient of the Don Ciriaco Memorial Award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences in 1974 for his achievements in the movies. A rated karateka, he was adjudged middle-weight karate champion by the Karate Congress of Asia, 1967, and awarded the gold trophy as Most Outstanding Exponent of Karate in Asia by the World Karate Federation, 1968. Written by Glecy Atienza, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

article_title: Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS)
text:
FILIPINO ACADEMY OF MOVIE ARTS AND SCIENCES ( FAMAS ) Established in July 1952 by a group of journalists and members of the film industry, FAMAS is the oldest existing award-giving body in the Philippines and one of the oldest in Asia. It was the most popular Filipino film award from 1952 to 1982, as well as the sole award-giving body in the country from 1952 to 1976.

Originally patterned after the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in Hollywood, which gives out annual “Oscar” awards, it had a Board of Regents composed of four representatives of the then major studios (Sampaguita, LVN, Premiere, Lebran) and four representatives of the independent movie producers: Everlasting Pictures, EddieRomero Productions, Deegar Cinema Films, and RoyalProductions. Movie Press Club representatives composed the majority membership. Elections were held yearly.

The name “FAMAS” was suggested by movie actor (later Manila councilor) Jaime delaRosa whose resolution was adopted by the body at a meeting held on 31 May 1953 at Far Eastern University in Manila. At this meeting the following were elected as the first set of officers: Flavio G. Macaso, president; Vicente R. Generoso, vice president; Delfin Ferrer Gamboa, secretary; Lynn Strait, treasurer; and Vivencio R. Isaac, public relations officer. The Board of Regents was composed of Julio EstebanAnguita (Lebran), GerardodeLeon (Premiere), FredMontilla (Sampaguita), RosaRosal (LVN), and the representatives of the independent movie producers: BenPerez, Eddie Romero, AristonAvelino, and Pedro Santos. The FAMAS suffered a crisis in 1960 when SampaguitaPictures and Vera Perez Productions withdrew their studio representation and returned all 33 trophies they had won since 1952. The other affiliated film companies similarly withdrew representation in the FAMAS although they did not return their trophies. As a result, the FAMAS was left with only a handful of magazine editors, movie columnists, and writers, including Alfredo Muñoz, Vic Generoso, Gemiliano Pineda, Lilia Rianzares, Letty Martillo, Mario Mijares Lopez, and Nazario D. Bas. They kept the organization from dying a natural death. The rift with Sampaguita and Vera Perez was resolved after a “Return-over Dinner” held during the term of FAMAS president Ramon Lopez. However, since 1961, membership has ceased to be by studio representation.

The annual FAMAS Awards was usually held sometime in May or June yearly to honor the previous year’s outstanding achievements in film production, such as best picture, director, story, screenplay, actor, actress, supporting actor, supporting actress, child performer, cinematography, production design, music, editing, sound, visual effects, and documentary film. Selection is made by a panel of jurors composed of FAMAS members. In the first FAMAS Awards in 1952, the following films won awards: Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo (Python in the Old Dome), Best Picture and Best Cinematography for Emmanuel Rojas; Bagong Umaga (New Morning), Best Director for Gerardo de Leon and Best Actor for Ben Perez; Buhay Alamang (Easy Come, Easy Go), Best Screenplay for Eddie Romero and Cesar Amigo; Basahang Ginto (Golden Rug), Best Actress for Alicia Vergel; Korea, Best Supporting Actor for Gil de Leon and Best Supporting Actress for Nida Blanca; and Kalbaryo ni Hesus (The Calvary of Jesus), Best Sound Engineering for Charles Gray and Best Musical Score for Julio Esteban Anguita. The FAMAS statuette, representing a woman standing on a pedestal and holding up a reel of film, was designed by Manuel Barreiro. Earlier trophies were cast in bronze by Leonides Valdez; later trophies were patterned after a sculpture etched in wood by A. C. Florentino.

Winners of five or more awards in a single category are elevated to the FAMAS Hall of Fame. Among those who have been elevated to the Hall of Fame are Eddie Garcia (supporting actor) in 1975, Angel Avellana (sound) in 1982, Joseph Estrada (actor) in 1983, Charito Solis (actress) in 1985, Fernando Poe Jr (actor) in 1988, George Canseco (music) in 1989, Vilma Santos (actress) in 1990, Eddie Garcia (director) in 1991, Nora Aunor (actress) and Lino Brocka (posthumously, director) in 1992, Christopher de Leon (actor) in 1993, Edgardo Vinarao (editing) in 1994, Eddie Garcia (actor) in 2004, Jesse Lucas (music) in 2010, and Carlo J. Caparas (story) in 2012.

The FAMAS also gave out international prestige awards for honors earned abroad, such as those given to Manuel Conde, who was nominated for the Golden Lion in the 1952 Venice Film Festival for Genghis Khan; Lamberto V. Avellana, who won the Asia-Pacific Film Festival’s Best Film award for Anak Dalita (The Ruins) in 1956 and also won twice at Bilbao International Festival of Documentary and Short Films in 1959 for El Legado (The Legacy) and in 1961 for La Campana de Baler (The Church Bell of Baler); Gregorio Fernandez, who won Best Director in the 1956 Asia-Pacific Film Festival for Higit sa Lahat (Above All); and Gerardo de Leon, who was also selected, though not nominated, for Best Foreign Language Film at the 32nd Academy Awards in 1960 for The Moises Padilla Story. The special recognition award called the Dr. Ciriaco Santiago Memorial Award was first given to Susan Roces in 1959 and was last given to Geneva Cruz in 2002; the LouSalvador Sr. Memorial Award was first given to Bobby Gonzales in 1998 and last given to Don Pepot in 2004.

Apart from these aforementioned awards, the FAMAS also gave out one-time awards. One of these is the Centennial Award, which was given during the 46th FAMAS Awards in 1998 to films that justly mirrored Philippine culture and traditions, specifically celebrating patriotism in commemoration of the country’s independence. The films released in 1997 that garnered this award were Rizal sa Dapitan (Rizal in Dapitan) and Damong Ligaw (Wild Grass).

In 2004, for the 53rd FAMAS Awards, the organization collaborated with ABS-CBN for the production of the annual awards night. As a result, the show turned out to be the first awards night in the Philippines to be broadcast all over the world via international satellite stations. Written byLena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

FILIPPINE FILMS Founded in 1933 by two Americans, George F. Harris and Edward Tait. Since Philippine corporation laws required Filipino participation in any business corporation, Harris and Tait drafted Dr Felix Paterno, Francisco Santamaria, and Guillermo Tiomico as incorporators. The Silos brothers Manuel, Octavio, Cesar, and Augusto were the studio’s first film hands. Manuel had gained a reputation as writer and director of some notable silent pictures and as the funnyman Sano, the other half of the Monang and Sano bodabil team. Octavio worked in the laboratory devising trick shots and supervised the preparation of costumes, props, and sets. The other brothers, Cesar and Augusto, were adept at the camera. William “Billy” Smith, an American, worked in sound technology. He and the Silos brothers became the “4 plus 1” team at Filippine Films.

During the 1930s the studio made one movie after another, the most successful of which was Zamboanga (Fury in Paradise), 1937, which starred Rosa del Rosario and Fernando Poe Sr and which became a hit in the United States. Billed as an exotic South Sea Island movie, it was still being shown in New York up to the 1950s. Aside from the Silos brothers, other directors who worked at the studio were Carlos Vander Tolosa, Agapito Conchu, and Eduardo de Castro, the production manager and director of Zamboanga.

When Harris and Tait decided to reside permanently in the United States, they sold all their shares in the company to a group of sugar landowners from the Visayas, the Aranetas. Under J. Amado Araneta and Placido Mapa, the company installed Carlos P. Romulo, publisher and chief executive of the DMHM publications, as president. The new administration recruited new talents, among them Nick Osmeña, Lamberto V. Avellana, Hermenegildo Atienza, Ramon Estella, and Enrique Davila. Osmeña’s only movie, Magdalena, 1941, was acclaimed as an art film and won for its star, Yolanda Marquez, a Best Actress award from a group of journalists. Atienza also made one picture, Hating Gabi (Midnight), 1940, before he joined city politics. Davila directed a film version of Severino Reyes’s sarsuwela Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1939, which starred Leopoldo Salcedo and Rosa del Rosario. The two directors who later became prominent in the industry made some of the company’s most memorable films. Estella directed Buenavista, 1940, a movie about land conflict in the Buenavista Estate, and Huling Habilin (Last Will), 1940, an unforgettable love story starring Salcedo and del Rosario. Avellana’s debut film, Sakay, 1939, starring Salcedo, Arsenia Francisco, and Salvador Zaragosa in the title role, launched his brilliant career in film. Filippine Films closed down when World War II broke out. Written by Mauro Tumbocon Jr

FILM ACADEMY OF THE PHILIPPINES (FAP) Established 5 Jan 1981 by Executive Order 640-A signed by then Philippine president Ferdinand Marcos, the FAP was mandated to help integrate and nationalize all existing and envisioned efforts designed to encourage the preservation, growth, and development of the motion picture art and science in the country. Initially, the academy consisted of creative and technical guilds representing motion picture producers, distributors, directors, actors, scriptwriters, editors, cinematographers, sound technicians, music directors, production designers, assistant directors, and production managers. These were the Movie Workers Welfare Foundation (Mowelfund); PhilippineMotionPictureProducersAssociation; Integrated Movie Producers, Importers and Distributors Association of the Philippines; Kapisanan ng mga Direktor ng Pelikulang Pilipino; Katipunan ng mga Artista sa Pelikulang Pilipino; Screenwriters Guild of the Philippines; Production Designers Guild of the Philippines; Filipino Society of Cinematographers; Film Editors Guild for Motion Pictures; United Film Musical Directors Association of the Philippines; Sound Technicians Association for Motion Pictures; and Assistant Directors and Production Managers Guild of the Philippines. The Organization of Specialized Filipino Filmmakers and the ActorsWorkshopFoundation were integrated into the academy in 1989.

The signatories to the FAP’s constitution and bylaws were the first elected chairs of the guilds: Ma. Azucena (Marichu) P. Maceda, Leonardo Monteverde, RobertArevalo, Nick Lizaso, Jose F.Lacaba, Ricardo Trofeo, JuanitoClemente, Gervacio Santos, JosefinoCenizal, DezBautista, Marcelo Victoriano Jr, and JosephEstrada. FAP has served as an umbrella organization for the betterment of the guilds in the collection of funding, projects, and other growth opportunities for learning and for experience of the organization members. It stands as the Philippines’ counterpart of the United States’ Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and the Oscars. Manuel de Leon, Espiridion Laxa, and Leo Martinez served as chairs of the FAP.

FAP supports member-guilds through subsidies and financial assistance to their activities; advocates legislative and administrative measures to promote the well-being of the film industry and its workers; mediates between guilds as well as between film producers and theater operators to promote better understanding, cooperation, and solidarity among the various sectors; and participates in civic and cultural projects. It used to send scholars to the Mowelfund Film Institute. It also used to publish Cinema, a quarterly publication.

The FAP co-sponsored with the National Commission for Culture and the Arts the annual Pelikula at Lipunan (Film and Society) Festival in February in conjunction with the Philippine Arts Month. FAP also contributes to the staging and managing of the annual Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) from which the organization gets a share of 20 percent of the MMFF earnings. The organization also chooses the country’s film entries and delegates to foreign film festivals. FAP oversees the partnership between the movie industry and the government agencies to gain opportunities for the guilds and its members. The organization also gives clearances for foreign productions to shoot films in the Philippines. FAP offers all the assistance required by such foreign producers—from location permits, equipment rentals, employing talents, and even accommodations and tours—in return for the partnership that enables the growth of the film industry.

The academy gives out annual awards and other forms of recognition for significant efforts and accomplishments toward the improvement of the motion picture arts and sciences in the country, because two of its goals are (1) to give credit to artistic and technical distinction of performances and (2) to highlight the value of quality works of people behind exceptional movie productions during the year. It seeks to encourage the upgrading of craftsmanship among the movie industry workforces who will eventually raise the bar for local films. The Film Academy of the Philippines started giving the FAP awards in 1983 to honor the achievements of films shown in 1982. It has continued this recognition, which was renamed Luna Awards in 2005 to honor the great Filipino artist Juan Luna. The voting process for the Luna Awards has beeen conducted by FAP with the help of the Asian Institute of Management starting in 2004.

The FAP gives awards for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress, Best Supporting Actor, Best Supporting Actress, Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Editing, Best Musical Score, and Best Sound. In the first FAP awards night held in 1983, Vilma Santos and Phillip Salvador won the Best Actress and Best Actor awards, respectively. The FAP also inducts into its Hall of Fame those who have garnered at least five competitive awards. The individuals include Willy Cruz in 1987 with 13 awards, Romy Vitug in 1988 with eight awards, Phillip Salvador in 1994 with eight awards, Edgardo Vinarao in 1991 with seven awards, and Ricky Lee in 1996 with seven awards.

Among the recipients of the Lifetime Achievement Awards from 1983 to 1992 are National Artists for film LambertoV.Avellana and GerardodeLeon, RichardAbelardo, LuisF.Nolasco, Consuelo P. Osorio, Manuel Silos, Totoy Torrente, Juan Silos Jr, William Smith, Mary Walter, Tita Duran, Pancho Magalona, Enrique Jarlego Sr, Felipe J. Sacdalan, Levi Celerio, Chichay, Bella Flores, Leopoldo Salcedo, Joseph Estrada, Rogeliode la Rosa, Eddie Romero, Atty Manuel de Leon, FernandoPoeJr, Mike Accion, Eddie Infante, Dolphy, Nora Aunor, and Atty Espiridion Laxa.

The FAP also gives out special awards called the Golden Reel Award, the Fernando Poe Jr Lifetime Achievement Award, the Manuel de Leon Award for Exemplary Achievements, and the Lamberto Avellana Memorial Award. Lino Brocka and Eddie Infante were recipients of the Lamberto V. Avellana Memorial Award in 1990 and 1993, respectively. Special Recognition Awards were also given to Rita Gomez, Carmen Rosales, Pugo and Togo, and German Moreno in 1989; the Ilagan, Salvador, and Padilla clans, Dr Uwe Schmelter, Robin Padilla, and Sharon Cuneta in 1990; and Kidlat Tahimik aka Eric de Guia in 1993. However, recent problems with regard to funding has affected the Luna Awards. The last Luna Award was given in 2013.

Several issues have hounded the FAP through the years. First, although it was organized to professionalize the film industry, some of its member guilds allegedly began to operate like unions to ensure work for its members. Moreover, many members allegedly refused to report how they used their annual budgets and were unwilling to study new cinematic technologies. Because of such concerns, some members split from the FAP, like the group of leading directors who formed the Directors Guild of the Philippines Inc.

These problems also manifested themselves in the failure of Marilou Diaz-Abaya’s Jose Rizal to receive a single FAP award in 1999—something considered unbelievable since the film won most of the MMFF awards the prior year. The controversy worsened after the academy officials admitted that the film became the victim of the resentment of certain guilds against the director. Apparently, Diaz-Abaya and her colleagues were being ostracized for putting their faith in free trade and professionalism in the local film industry. Written byMauro Tumbocon Jr, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor and Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

article_title: Film Development Council of the Philippines (FDCP)
text:
FILM DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL OF THE PHILIPPINES ( FDCP )Established in 2002 through Republic Act 9167, it is the government agency for film affairs under the Office of the President. The mandate of the FDCP is primarily to create and administer programs that would advance the craft of filmmaking in the country.

The mandate of the Film Development Council of the Philippines is, first and foremost, to create and implement programs that advance the craft of filmmaking and, second, to espouse the commercial production of films that touch on the human condition and portray the dignity of the human spirit. It also takes advantage of the country’s setting as a location site for international movie and television productions that can generate income.

One of the programs of the FDCP is to support the outstanding films through tax incentives. The Cinema Evaluation Board has an incentive reward system based on merit to encourage the production of quality films. Films that are graded “A” receive a 100 percent rebate of the amusement tax; films that are rated “B” receive 65 percent tax rebate. The remaining 35 percent of the amusement tax from the films rated “B” is credited to the funds of the FDCP.

The Philippine Film Export Services Office is also part of the FDCP that promotes the country as a site for foreign productions. One of the popular American films shot in the country is The Bourne Legacy, 2012.

The FDCP has also been active in sponsoring international film festivals, like the World Premieres Film Festival, through its International Film Festival Committee. The evaluation board selects local films to be showcased during the festival alongside films taken around the world. The participating filmmakers and participants receive film grants of varying amounts as well as awards for Best Picture (1st and 2nd place), Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, Best Editing, Best Musical Score, Best Sound Engineering, Best Production Design, Best Performance by an Actor, Best Performance by an Actress, Best Supporting Actor, and Best Supporting Actress.

The FDCP also aims to develop film audiences. The theme of its program, the Sineng Pambansa (National Cinema), is “bringing the Filipino films to Filipinos.” A vital part of this program is the establishment of cinémathèques in major cities like Baguio, Davao, Iloilo, and Zamboanga. Sineng Pambansa programs special screenings of classic Filipino films and contemporary independent films.

Another program of FDCP is the National Film Archive of the Philippines (NFAP), which aims to conserve the film heritage of the country. The NFAP was officially launched with the restoration of Manuel Conde’s Genghis Khan, 1950. Also restored were Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975, and Insiang, 1976, in cooperation with Martin Scorsese’s World Cinema Fund, and A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965, in cooperation with filmmaker Mike de Leon. The restoration of these films was done in L’Immagine Ritrovata laboratory in Bologna, Italy.

Laurice Guillen-Feleo was chair of the FDCP from 2002 to 2005; Rolando S. Atienza from 2005 to 2010. During the administration of Pres Benigno Aquino III, Briccio G. Santos was appointed head, 2010-16. Written byChristian Co

FLOR, CELIA ( Trinidad Buencamino Teodoro ) b. Manila 1 Nov 1926. Actor. Her parents are Jose Teodoro and Consolacion Buencamino. She married Jose Corominas with whom she has two children. She finished her college education at the University of Santo Tomas.

Flor was introduced by LVN Pictures in Hampas ng Langit (Heaven’s Wrath), 1948, opposite Rogelio de la Rosa. They were paired again in Sa Tokyo Ikinasal (Married in Tokyo), 1948. She appeared as the leading lady of almost all the big names of LVN: with Jose Padilla Jr in Ibigin Mo Ako, Lalaking Matapang (Love Me, Brave Man), 1949, Matador (Bullfighter), 1952, and Huk sa Bagong Pamumuhay (Huk in a New Life), 1953; with Leopoldo Salcedo in Capas, 1949, Hantik (Black Ant), 1950, and Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1950; with Jaime de la Rosa in Kontrabando (Contraband), 1950, and Tinalikdang Dambana (Abandoned Shrine), 1954; with Armando Goyena in Maria Beles, 1949; with Teody Belarmino in Ang Tapis Mo, Inday (Your Overskirt, Inday), 1951; and with Mario Montenegro in Pasiya ng Langit (Heaven’s Will), 1954, Correccional, 1952, and Panyolitong Bughaw (Blue Handkerchief), 1955.

Before she retired from films, she starred in an LVN-Hollywood co-production, No Place to Hide, 1955. Written by Cesar Hernando

FLORES, BELLA ( Remedios Papa Dancel ) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 27 Feb 1929. d. Quezon City 19 May 2013. Movie and television actor. Her parents are Emilia Papa and Matias Dancel. She married Nestor Reyes, a detective police officer, with whom she has one child. She studied at Cecilio Apostol Elementary School and Arellano High School, finishing her secondary education at Roosevelt College. She was a college sophomore at Far Eastern University when she decided on a movie career.

Flores was only 14 years old when she made her first movie, Tatlong Balaraw (Three Daggers), 1950, with Premiere Productions. She took a screen test at Sampaguita Pictures and was placed under a four-year buildup contract. Her first big role was in Roberta, 1951, as the cruel stepmother of child actors Tessie Agana and Boy Alano. The movie saved the studio from bankruptcy after it was razed by a fire in 1951. Among her early films with Sampaguita are Bernardo Carpio and Batas ng Daigdig (Law of the World), 1951; Rebecca and Kerubin (Cherubim), 1952; and Ang Asawa Kong Americana (My American Wife), 1953, the first Filipino movie to win a major award at the Asian Film Festival. Her other films include Mariposa (Butterfly), 1955; Mga Ligaw na Bulaklak (Wildflowers), 1957; Anino ni Bathala (Shadow of God), 1958; Tanikalang Apoy (Chain of Fire) and Mga Anghel sa Lansangan (Angels on the Street), 1959; Lupa sa Lupa (Soil on Soil) and Kaming Makasalanan (We Sinners), 1960; Makasalanang Daigdig (Sinful World), 1961; Susanang Daldal (Susan the Chatterbox), 1962; Trudis Liit (Little Trudis), 1963; Apat na Anak ni David (Four Children of David), 1963; The Dolly Sisters, 1964; Lastikman (Plastic Man) and Hamon sa Kampeon (Challenge to the Champion), 1965; Tatlong Kasaysayan ng Pag-ibig (Three Love Stories), Huling Baraha (Last Card), Sino Ka, Madame X? (Who Are You, Madame X?), James Batman, and Sa Bawat Lansangan (On Every Street), 1966; To Love Again, Anong Ganda Mo! (How Lovely You Are!), Alamid (Mountain Cat), Pogi (Handsome), and Kaibigan Ko’ng Sto. Niño (The Holy Infant Is My Friend), 1967; Magic Guitar, Juanita Banana, and Bakit Kita Inibig? (Why Did I Love You?), 1968; Teenage Jamboree, Nasaan Ka, Inay? (Where Are You, Mother?), and Tukso (Temptation), 1970; Nympha, Huwad (Fake), Annabella, and Nunal sa Balikat (Mole on the Shoulder), 1971; Polyanna and Mysterious Mad Killer, 1972; Esteban, 1973; Batingaw (Church Bell) and Isang Gabi … Tatlong Babae! (One Night … Three Women!), 1974; May Isang Tsuper ng Taksi (There Was a Taxi Driver) and Pira-pirasong Langit (Pieces of Heaven), 1975; Langit, Lupa, at Impiyerno (Heaven, Earth, and Hell), Tatlong Kasalanan (Three Sins), Sa Akin Kayong Lahat (You Are All Mine), and Sapagkat Kami’y mga Misis Lamang (Because We Are Only Wives), 1976; Herkulas, 1977; Mahal Mo, Mahal Ko (Your Love, My Love) and Dyesebel, 1978; Darna, Kuno? (They Say It’s Darna) and Pinay, American Style, 1979; John and Marsha ’80 and Kastilyong Buhangin (Sand Castle), 1980; Palengke Queen, Diary of Cristina Gaston, and Santa Claus Is Coming to Town, 1982; To Mama with Love and Estong Tutong: Ikalawang Yugto (Estong Tutong: The Second Chapter), 1983; Mga Batang Yagit (Pauper Children), Missing in Action, and Bulaklak sa City Jail (Flowers of the City Jail), 1984; Ride on Baby, Escort Girls, and Inday Bote (Inday the Bottle Trader), 1985; Prinsesang Gusgusin (Shabby Princess) and Ready, Aim, Fire!, 1987; Buy One, Take One, Tiyanak (Changeling), and Lord, Bakit Ako Pa? (Lord, Why Me?), 1988; Ayaw Matulog ng Gabi (The Night Doesn’t Want to Sleep) and Hukom .45 (Judge .45), 1990; Dugo ng Panday (Blood of the Blacksmith), 1993; Hataw Tatay Hataw (Dance Daddy Dance), 1994; Pamilya Valderama (Valderama Family), 1995; Ikaw ang Mahal Ko (You Are the One I Love), 1996; Nakawin Mo ang Aking Puso (Steal My Heart) and Huling Sayaw (Last Dance), 1997; Campus Scandal and Ginto’t Pilak (Gold and Silver), 1998; Crying Ladies, 2003; Ilusyon (Illusion) and D’Anothers (The Others), 2005; Imahe Nasyon (Portrait of a Nation), 2006; Ang Manghuhula (The Fortune-Teller), 2008; and Way Back Home, 2011.

On television, she was a mainstay of such popular shows as Dahong Lagas (Withered Leaf), 1973; Yagit (Trash), 1982; Victoria Hills, 1983; and Pa Easy-Easy (Taking It Easy), 1988. Because of her prolific movie acting career, it took Flores more than two decades before she could regularly appear on TV again. In 2004, she became part of Maid in Heaven, followed by Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels without Heaven) the following year. Also in 2005, she appeared in Ganda ng Lola Ko (My Grandma Is Pretty) and Dwarfina.

Flores won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Supporting Actress award for Kaibigan Ko’ng Santo Nino in 1968. She received the Best Supporting Actress award from the Olongapo Film Festival for her performance in Dugo ng Bayan (Blood of the Nation), 1973. In 1989, she received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Film Academy of the Philippines. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

FLORES, ODYSSEY ( Odyssey Marcelo Flores ) b. Manila 10 Oct 1974. Cinematographer. Flores is the son of Rogelio Flores and Isabel Marcelo. He graduated with a mass communication degree from Centro Escolar University. He also took workshops on sound and cinematography at the Mowelfund Film Institute.

Among the films for which Flores did cinematography are Magnifico, 2003; Naglalayag (Silent Passage), 2004; Ilusyon (Illusion), Happily Ever After, Lasponggols (Last Takes), Awaken, and Dilim (Darkness), 2005; Kaleldo (Summer Heat) and Ang Pamana (The Inheritance), 2006; Foster Child and Selda (The Inmate), 2007; Serbis (Service) and Kinatay (The Execution of P.), 2009; Oh, My Girl!: A Laugh Story and Lola (Grandmother), 2009; Thelma, 2011; Captive and Thy Womb, 2012; Filipina, 2014; Kid Kulafu and Taklub (Trap), 2015; and Ma’ Rosa and Dukot (Captured), 2016.

Flores won Best Cinematography awards for Naglalayag from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences in 2005, for Serbis from the Gawad Urian in 2009, for Lola from Las Palmas International Film Festival in Spain in 2010, for Thelma from the Film Academy of the Philippines, and for Thy Womb from the Metro Manila Film Festival in 2012. Written byJohann Vladimir J. Espiritu

FORTIN, JOSEPH ( Joseph Romasoc Fortin ) b. Sampaloc, Manila 1 Feb 1955. Cinematographer, filmmaker. Born to Mauro Fortin and Nemia Romasoc, he finished a bachelor of arts degree at the College of Fine Arts, University of the Philippines (UP). He took special studies in archaeology and prehistory as a scholar of the SEAMEO-Special Projects on Archaeology and Fine Arts. From 1980 to 1991, he attended film workshops sponsored by the UP Film Center, Mowelfund Film Institute, Varaan Atelier (Paris, France), Communication Foundation of Asia, and Goethe- Institut. He was a senior lecturer at the UP College of Fine Arts and chief cinematographer of the UP Film Center.

In his early film work from 1979 to 1984, Fortin earned recognition as cinematographer and director of ethnographic films and social documentaries. These works include Dua-a-Salamat (Thanksgiving), 1979; Allumna-Mai-Matahik, 1980; Salambao (Fishnet) and Pecha Bridge, 1982; Chumno, Samba, and Children of the Lake, 1983.

His work as cinematographer covered broad social and political issues. These are exemplified by No Time for Crying, 1987; Inside the Philippine Revolution: A Rustling of Leaves, 1988; Paglikas (Exodus), 1990; Lamat sa Kinabukasan (Crack in the Future) and Manggagawa: Kamanlilikha (Laborer: Co-creator), 1991; and Tulay (Bridge), 1992.

He also did photography work for several books, among them History of the Burgis (Bourgeois), GCF Books, 1988; Folk Architecture, GCF Books, 1989; and Pamana: The Jorge Vargas Art Collection, UP, 1992.

Fortin garnered awards for the following productions: Allumna-Mai-Matahik, 1980, Best Film, Manila Short Film Festival; Salambao, honorable mention, 2nd ECP Annual Short Film Festival; Pecha Bridge, 1982, third place, 3rd Manila Short Film Festival; Children of the Lake, 1983, second prize, Manila Short Film Festival; No Time for Crying, 1986, first prize, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Annual Independent Cinema and Video Competition; and Masakit sa Mata (Eyesore), a group work project sponsored by Goethe-Institut, first prize, documentary film, 1991 CCP Video Festival, and Silver Prize, KRITIKA Film Award. Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Pamela Mathiel Lopez

FPJ PRODUCTIONS Established in 1961 as a single proprietorship by Fernando Poe Jr, it was registered as a corporate entity in May 1963 with the following stockholders as incorporators and members of the board of directors: Fernando Poe Jr, Elizabeth Poe Gutierrez, Ernesto Paras, Ben Esteva, and Martha Kelley. Its studio and offices were located at San Francisco del Monte, Quezon City, at the site of the former Royal Productions of Fernando Poe Sr.

With his savings of 60,000 pesos as capital, Poe embarked on FPJ Production’s first movie, Kilabot sa Barilan (Gunfight Terror), 1961, which he co-produced with fellow actor Zaldy Zshornack, followed by Batang Maynila (Manila Boy), Callejon Onse (11th Alley), Ito ang Maynila (This Is Manila), and Pasong Diablo (Devil’s Pass), 1962; and Albano Brothers, 1963.

The establishment of FPJ Productions made Poe the first of his generation of stars to become his own producer. Others who also set up their own movie companies later were Joseph Estrada of JE Productions, Amalia Fuentes of AM Pictures, Dolphy of RVQ Productions, Vilma Santos of VS Films, and Nora Aunor of NV Productions.

On its third year, FPJ produced Sigaw ng Digmaan (War Cry), 1963, which was hailed as the Best Picture of the year by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS). Four years later, Poe won the FAMAS Best Actor award for his performance in FPJ’s Mga Alabok sa Lupa (Dust of the Earth), 1967. In 1970, Poe’s company won the FAMAS Best Picture again for Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels without Heaven), with Poe himself receiving the award for Best Story under his pseudonym Ronwaldo Reyes. Among the awardees for this picture were Augusto Salvador for editing, Restie Umali for music, and the two child actors, Lorna Tolentino and Roderick Paulate, who would later become important names in the industry.

FPJ later branched out into Jafere, D’Lanor (“Ronald,” Poe’s real first name, spelled backward), and Rosas Productions. It was under Rosas Productions that Susan Roces won her FAMAS Best Actress awards for Maligno (Evil Spirit), 1977, directed by Celso Ad. Castillo, and Gumising Ka … Maruja (Wake Up … Maruja), 1978, directed by Lino Brocka, under FPJ Productions.

Although he made films with other movie companies, Poe received all his Best Actor awards from FAMAS under the aegis of FPJ. After Alabok came Asedillo, 1971; Durugin si Totoy Bato (Crush Totoy the Rock), 1979; and Muslim Magnum .357, 1986. FPJ’s Ang Padrino (The Godfather), 1984, also won for Poe aka Ronwaldo Reyes, the FAMAS Best Director award.

FPJ entered the decade of the 1980s with the Ang Panday (The Blacksmith) series of action-fantasy films that won box-office acclaim and mostly technical awards from FAMAS: Best Cinematography, Ver Reyes, for Pagbabalik ng Panday (Return of the Blacksmith), 1981, and Ang Panday … Ikatlong Yugto (The Blacksmith … Third Chapter), 1982; Best Production Design, Rolando Sacristia, for Panday III; and Best Special Visual Effects, Ramje, for Ang Panday IV: Ika-Apat na Aklat (The Blacksmith: Fourth Book), 1984.

FPJ Productions also produced Captain Barbell, 1964; Zamboanga, 1966; Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin (You Are Everything to Me), 1970; Ang Kampana sa Santa Quiteria (The Bell in Santa Quiteria), 1971; Ang Leon at ang Daga (The Lion and the Mouse), 1975; Bato sa Buhangin (Rock on the Sand), 1976; Totoy Bato (Totoy the Rock), 1977; Isa para sa Lahat, Lahat para sa Isa (One for All, All for One) and Mahal … Saan Ka Nanggaling Kagabi? (Honey … Where Were You Last Night?), 1979; Ang Leon at ang Kuting (The Lion and the Kitten), 1980; Isang Bala Ka Lang! (Just One Bullet to Finish You Off!) and Umpisahan Mo, Tatapusin Ko! (What You Start, I Will Finish!), 1983; Kapag Puno Na ang Salop (When the Rice Measure Is Full), 1987; Dito sa Pitong Gatang (Here in Pitong Gatang), 1992; Walang Matigas na Tinapay sa Mainit na Kape (There’s No Hard Bread in Piping-Hot Coffee), 1994; and Ang Probinsyano (The Country Boy), 1997. The last was remade by ABS-CBN into a TV series starring Coco Martin. The last movie the company made was Pakners (Partners), 2003, which also starred nine-ball billiards champion Efren “Bata” Reyes.

FPJ Studios was also tapped for postproduction facilities for films such as Aguila and Bona, 1980; Lovingly Yours, Helen (The Movie), 1984; Kahit Konting Pagtingin (Just a Little Love), 1990; and Isusumbong Kita sa Tatay Ko (I’ll Tell on You to My Father), 1999. It was also the distributor of quite a number of films from 1967 to 2002.

In the mid-1980s, FPJ entered into a contract with GMA Network for the television airing of all the films starring Fernando Poe Jr under the program FPJ sa GMA (FPJ at GMA).

One of its most important productions is an unfinished opus by the late National Artist Gerardo de Leon, titled Juan de la Cruz, starring Gloria Romero, Fernando Poe Jr, Susan Roces, Johnny Delgado, Rosemarie Gil, Dranreb, Van de Leon, and Tony Carreon. The movie was 70 percent done when the director died in 1981. Fragments of the film were shown in a tribute to Gerardo de Leon at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1990, and once again by the Society of Filipino Archivists for Film in 2014 during the yearlong celebration of Gerardo de Leon’s birth centennial.

In its 40-odd years as a movie-producing company, FPJ Productions remained active in the industry, contributing to the legend of Fernando Poe Jr as star, producer, writer, and director.

FPJ was around 9 or 10 years old when the film collection of his actor-father Fernando Poe Sr was razed in a fire. Thus, when he was still alive, FPJ transferred his films from the highly flammable celluloid to whatever less flammable medium was available then until the coming of the digital era. Roces’s nephew, film archivist Jeffrey Sonora, manages the FPJ Archive using the latest equipment available to preserve FPJ’s legacy .

FPJ Productions may not be producing films anymore, but FPJ Inc remains the sole owner of the film rights to the titles in its catalog. In 2013, media conglomerate ABS-CBN acquired the rights to FPJ’s exclusive movie library, or movies that feature FPJ as an actor, director, or producer. The films are screened on free-to-air TV channels, cable TV channels (Studio 23, Cinema One, and Jeepney TV), as well as international TV networks like The Filipino Channel and Cinema One Global. Moreover, the FPJ compound in Quezon City hosts a mini-museum that showcases photos, movie stills, posters, and FPJ memorabilia items. Written byLena S. Pareja, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

FRANCISCO, ARSENIA b. 1920. d. 1972. Movie actor. She married actor Jose Padilla Jr with whom she had five children. Francisco’s early movie appearances include Julian Manansala’s Mutya ng Katipunan (Muse of the Katipunan), Tawag ng Bayan (Country Call), Azucena, and Sakay, all in 1939. Shortly before the outbreak of the war, she did Dama de Noche (Woman of the Night) and Kamuning, 1940; Kundiman (Love Song) and Paraiso (Paradise), 1941. After the war, she appeared in Tagumpay (Triumph), 1946, with Rogelio de la Rosa; Angelus, 1946, with Carlos Padilla; and in Gerardo de Leon’s Tayug: Ang Bayang Api (Tayug: The Oppressed Town), 1947. But her biggest hit was Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fortune), 1953, which was the year’s box- office record breaker.

She was cast in the omnibus film Apat na Kasaysayang Ginto (Four Golden Stories), 1956. In the 1960s, she made Una Kitang Naging Mahal (I Loved You First), Taginting ng Pilak (The Sound of Silver Coins), and Objective: Patayin si Magsaysay (Objective: Kill Magsaysay).

She received Best Supporting Actress award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for her role of the grandmother of a kidnapped child in Huwag Mo Akong Limutin (Never Forget Me), 1960. Written byDanny Villanueva
