FUENTES, AMALIA ( Amalia Margarita Amador Muhlach ) b. Manila 27 Aug 1940. Movie actor and producer. Her parents are Alvaro Muhlach Sr of French-Spanish ancestry, and Concepcion Amador. Fuentes was five years old when her father died. Her mother married Isagani Fuentes, from whom she took her screen surname. She was married to actor RomeoVasquez. They have a child, Anna Lisa aka Liezl, who had a short stint in the movies. Her second husband is Joey Stevens. She is the sister of D’Wonder Films producers Alex and Alvaro (aka Cheng) Muhlach and the aunt of actor AgaMuhlach and former child star NiñoMuhlach. She enrolled in a number of schools, including Santa Isabel College, St. Scholastica’s College, Philippine Women’s University, and a law school during her stay in the United States.

Fuentes joined a contest to promote Gloria Romero’s film Hindi Basta-Basta (Not an Ordinary Person), 1956, and emerged as “Miss Number One.” Among her early movies are Prince Charming and Rhodora, both released in 1956. Her first lead role was in Movie Fan, 1956. After playing opposite Vasquez in Pretty Boy, 1957, she and Vasquez formed a popular love team over the years. In the 1950s, she shared the title “Queen of Philippine Movies” with SusanRoces.

Her other movies as contract star of Sampaguita include Ismol Bat Teribol (Small but Terrible), where she portrayed a street urchin, and the remake of Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), 1957; Baby Bubut, 1958, where she played a woman-child counterpart of the popular Bondying; the celebrated Amy, Susie, Tessie, 1960, where she and Susan were joined by comebacking former child star TessieAgana; and the comedy Amaliang Mali-Mali (Amalia the Blunderer), 1962, and its sequel, Amaliang Mali-Mali versus Susanang Daldal (Amalia the Blunderer versus Susan the Chatterbox), 1963, which pitted her against Susan Roces. She was still under contract with Sampaguita when she made a movie with TagalogIlang-Ilang Productions, causing Sampaguita to sue her for breach of contract. The case was settled amicably and Fuentes returned to the Gilmore studio to finish Pitong Puso (Seven Hearts), 1962.

After freelancing for some time, she put up her own movie company, AM (Amalia Muhlach) Productions, with brothers Alex and Cheng Muhlach, and produced films like Tatlong Kasaysayan ng Pag-ibig (Three Love Stories), which she also wrote, and Room 69, 1966; and Sa Manlulupig, Di Ka Pasisiil (Never to Invaders Shall You Surrender), 1967. When the company folded up, she freelanced in movies like Ang Uliran (The Model), 1971; Babae, Ikaw ang Dahilan (Woman, You Are the Reason), 1972; Isang Gabi, Tatlong Babae (One Night, Three Women) and Psst … Halika Babae (Psst … Woman Come Here), both in 1974. In 1976, she acted in and directed the film Mga Reynang Walang Trono (Queens without Thrones). She also portrayed the role of FernandoPoeJr’s mother in Eddie Romero’s Aguila, 1980. Her other films are Dirty Games, 1981; My Only Love, 1982; Indecent Exposure, 1983; Paano Ba ang Magmahal? (How Is It to Love?), 1984; Asawa Ko Huwag Mong Agawin (Don’t Steal My Husband), 1987; Higit na Matimbang ang Dugo (Blood Weighs More), 1990; Reputasyon (Reputation), 1996; Kahit Isang Saglit (Even for a Moment), 2008; and Huwag Ka Lang Mawawala (Against All Odds), 2013.

Fuentes received the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Actress award for Gerardo de Leon’s Ibulong Mo sa Hangin (Whisper to the Wind), 1966. Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Mesandel Arguelles
(See LITERATURE volume.)

GALLAGA, PEQUE ( Maurice Luzurriaga Gallaga ) b. Manila 25 Aug 1943. Movie and television director, scriptwriter, production designer. His parents are Conchita R. de Luzurriaga, planter, and Ricardo S. Gallaga, manager of a trucking company. He had his elementary and high school education at De La Salle University (DLSU) in Manila and finished commerce and liberal arts at DLSU in Bacolod where he taught theater, film, and television. He is married to Madeleine Dacanay, with whom he has five children.

Gallaga initially directed TV musical variety shows. In 1971 he codirected with Antonio Jose Perez aka Butch Perez the movie Binhi (Seedling), 1973. He became engrossed in production design and worked with Laida Lim Perez on Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?), 1976, which won Best Production Design from both the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) and the Gawad Urian, and earned a nomination from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences. Gallaga’s production design in City after Dark, 1980, gave him his second Gawad Urian trophy, while his work in Ito Ba ang Ating Mga Anak? (Are These Our Children?), 1982, merited nominations from the Gawad Urian and the Film Academy of the Philippines.

Gallaga next tried his hand at screenplay writing. He won the scriptwriting contest sponsored by the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines (ECP), a feat which became his passage to directing films. As scriptwriter, he was nominated by the Star Awards for Tiyanak (Changeling), 1988; by the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) for Isang Araw Walang Diyos (One Day without God), 1989; and by the MMFF for Shake, Rattle & Roll 2, 1990, and Shake, Rattle & Roll 4, 1992. He won Best Screenplay for Once upon a Time, 1987, at the MMFF. His other screenplays include Hiwaga sa Balete Drive (Mystery on Balete Drive), 1988; Dugo ng Panday (Blood of the Blacksmith), 1993; Batang-X (Child-X) and Baby Love, 1995; Magic Temple, 1996, together with Lore Reyes and Erik Matti; Puso ng Pasko (Heart of Christmas), 1998; Ang Kabit ni Mrs. Montero (Mrs. Montero’s Lover), 1999; Ang Agimat: Anting-anting ni Lolo (The Talisman: Grandfather’s Amulet), 2002; and Agaton & Mindy, 2009.

Winning the ECP scriptwriting contest gave Gallaga a chance to direct his own entry, Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982, written for the screen by Jose Javier Reyes. Oro, Plata, Mata remains Gallaga’s most significant achievement in film. The epic movie was declared Best Picture of the year by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino, and Gallaga as director received the Gawad Urian. He also received for this film a Special Jury Award from the Manila International Film Festival and another award from the International Film Festival of Flanders-Ghent, Belgium, in 1983.

Gallaga’s filmography as director includes Scorpio Nights, 1985; Impaktita (Young Female Monster) and Abandonada (Abandoned), 1989; Trese (Thirteen), 1990; Ang Leon at ang Kuting (The Lion and the Kitten), 1991; Darna: Ang Pagbabalik (Darna: The Return), 1994; Magic Kingdom: Alamat ng Damortis (Legend of Damortis), Halik ng Bampira (Kiss of the Vampire), and Diliryo (Delirium), 1997; Gangland, 1998; Unfaithful Wife 2: Sana’y Huwag Akong Maligaw (Hope I Won’t Get Lost) and Sa Piling ng mga Aswang (In the Company of Monsters), 1999; Pinoy Blonde, 2005; and Seduction, 2013.

As director, Gallaga won awards for Unfaithful Wife from the CMMA and Star Awards in 1987. He and his co-director Lore Reyes won at the CMMA for their work in Isang Araw Walang Diyos in 1990 and the independent film Sonata, 2013. In 2014, the Star Awards for Movies honored Gallaga with the Ulirang Alagad ng Pelikula sa Likod ng Kamera (Exemplar Artist of the Cinema behind the Camera). In 2004, Gallaga received the Gawad CCP para sa Sining in the field of film. In 2008, he received the Natatanging Gawad Urian for his lifetime achievements in film. Written byGalileo Zafra, Ramon Jocson, Lena S. Pareja, and Mario Mendez Jr

GALLARDO, CESAR ( Cesar Gonzales Gallardo ) aka Chat Gallardo. b. 19 Nov 1920. d. 10 Jan 1989. Movie director. His parents are Faustino Pascual Gallardo and Francisca Gonzales. He married Amparo Violago. Director Jun Gallardo is his son. He took up law at Far Eastern University.

Gallardo worked as assistant to director Eduardo de Castro in Bandilang Basahan (Tattered Flag), 1949, for which he wrote the script. The first film he directed from his script was Kidlat sa Silangan (Lightning in the East), 1949, starring Rogelio de la Rosa and Leila Morena. His second film Tatlong Balaraw (Three Daggers), 1950, which is about agrarian disputes, had problems with the censors. His first color film was Kapitan Bagwis (Captain Wings), 1951, written by Clodualdo del Mundo and starring Efren Reyes. He made the period films Sagrado (Sacred), set during the Philippine revolution against Spanish rule; Solitaryo (Solitaire), 1953; and Conde de Monte Cristo (Count of Monte Cristo), 1956, starring Rogelio de la Rosa, Corazon Rivas, Jose Romulo, Cynthia Zamora, and Lauro Delgado. He also directed Trubador (Traveling Minstrel), 1952; Og, 1952; and Si Og sa Maynila (Og in Manila), 1953.

Gallardo employed realism in his works. His films gave a sense of the immediacy of the experience. Among these are Ginto sa Lusak (Gold in the Mire), 1954, whose story line was closely patterned after the love story of its lead characters, Jose Padilla Jr and Arsenia Francisco, who were estranged at the time it was filmed, and Anak ng Lasengga (Child of a Drunkard Woman), 1958. In 1964, he directed the action-drama Geron Busabos: Ang Batang Quiapo (Geron the Vagabond), starring Joseph Estrada who played a bum protecting the weak and the poor against hoodlums who terrorize vendors in Quiapo. The film won Best Picture, Best Actor (Estrada), and Best Screenplay in the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) awards. He also directed Joseph Estrada in Tatay Na si Erap (Erap Is Now a Father), 1972 and Ransom, 1974.

Gallardo won FAMAS Best Director awards for his work in Salabusab (Greedy), 1954, and Kalibre .45 (Caliber .45), 1957. He earned FAMAS nominations for Ang Maton (The Tough Guy), 1959; Suicide Susy, 1962; and Dapit-hapon: Oras ng Pagtutuos (Dusk: Hour of Reckoning), 1963. Written byRamon Jocson and Ellen Bomasang

GARCIA, EDDIE ( Eduardo Verchez Garcia ) aka Manoy. b. Sorsogon 2 May 1929. Film and television actor, director. His parents are Antonio Garcia and Vicenta Verchez. Garcia studied at Sorsogon Elementary School and finished high school at San Beda College, where he also took up psychology until third year. In 1946, Garcia joined the Philippine Scouts and was stationed in Guam. Upon his return in 1949, he entered the movies, playing a minor role in Manuel Conde’s Siete Infantes de Lara (Seven Devils). In 1950, he got his honorable discharge from the army and joined Sampaguita Pictures, playing kontrabida (antagonist) roles. Meanwhile, he continued his schooling and graduated from San Beda in 1953 with a bachelor of arts degree.

In his long career that started in 1949, Garcia has done almost 600 films and shows for television. In his home studio Sampaguita Pictures, he appeared as the resident villain—for example, in movies like Gilda, 1956; Taga sa Bato (Cut on a Stone) and Sino ang Maysala? (Who Is Guilty?), 1957; Condenado (Condemned), 1958; Kamandag (Venom) and Tanikalang Apoy (Chain of Fire), 1959. In the 1960s, after the studio years, he appeared in films by other production companies, including Ito ang Pilipino (Behold the Filipino), 1966; Manila: Open City, 1968; and Igorota (Mountain Maiden), 1968. In the 1970s, he appeared in some bomba (bold) movies when they were in vogue, like Erotika (Erotica), 1970, Huwag Kang Makiapid (Thou Shall Not Commit Adultery), and the bomba with a comic twist Batuta ni Drakula (Dracula’s Nightstick), 1971. But he also rendered some memorable dramatic performances, like in Lino Brocka’s Tubog sa Ginto (Dipped in Gold), 1970, and Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (You Were Weighed and Found Wanting), 1974; in Ishmael Bernal’s Pagdating sa Dulo (At the Top), 1971; in Eddie Romero’s Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?), 1976; and Celso Ad. Castillo’s Ang Alamat ni Julian Makabayan (The Legend of Julian Makabayan), 1979. He did comedy roles, in such films as May Lamok sa Loob ng Kulambo (There’s a Mosquito in the Net), May Daga sa Labas ng Lungga (There’s a Rat Outside the Burrow), Atsay Killer (Maid Lover), and Matukso Kaya ang Anghel? (Will the Angel Be Tempted?), 1984.

In the 1980s, Garcia was also noted for his lead roles in action films, such as Iyo ang Batas, Akin ang Katarungan (The Law Is Yours, Justice Is Mine), 1988; Arrest Patrolman Rizal Alih, Zamboanga Massacre and Ako … ang Huhusga (I … Will Make the Judgment), 1989; Ako ang Batas: General Karingal (I Am the Law: General Karingal) and Hukom .45 (Judge .45), 1990; Sgt. Patalinhug, 1991; Andres Manambit: Angkan ng Matatapang (Andres Manambit: Clan of the Brave) and Gobernador (Governor), 1992; and Cordora, Lulutang Ka sa Sarili Mong Dugo (Cordora, You Will Float in Your Own Blood), 1992.

Aside from mainstream films, Garcia also worked in independent films like ICU Bed #7, 2005; Fuschia, 2009; Bwakaw, 2012; Mga Kuwentong Barbero (Barber’s Tales), 2013; and Bonifacio: Ang Unang Pangulo (Bonifacio: The First President), 2014. Together with these indie films, he made a variety of mainstream films like Masamang Ugat (Bad Roots), 2003; Blue Moon, 2006; The Unkabogable Praybeyt Benjamin (Can’t Be Upstaged Private Benjamin) and Ang Panday 2 (The Blacksmith 2), 2011; Boy Golden: Shoot to Kill; The Arturo Porcuna Story, 2013; and The Amazing Praybeyt Benjamin, 2014. He was in Raymond Red’s Anino (Shadow), 2000.

Garcia’s first directorial assignment is Sampaguita’s Karugtong ng Kahapon (Continuation of Yesterday), 1961, starring Mario Montenegro, Rita Gomez, Ric Rodrigo, and Marlene Dauden. His other notable films include Sabotage, 1966; Crisis, 1970; Atsay (Housemaid), 1978; Hinukay Ko Na ang Libingan Mo (I Already Dug Your Grave), 1991; and Abakada … Ina (ABC … Mother), 2001.

On television, he appeared in various series, including TV5’s Rod Santiago’s The Sisters and Babaeng Hampaslupa (The Hapless Woman), 2011; GMA Network’s Aso ni San Roque (The Dog of Saint Roque) and Legacy, 2012; and ABS-CBN’s Honesto, Toda Max (Total Maximum), and Juan dela Cruz, 2013.

Garcia was elevated to the Hall of Fame of the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) thrice: as supporting actor, 1975; as director, 1991; and as actor, 2004. He has six FAMAS Best Supporting Actor awards for the following films: Taga sa Bato, 1957; Condenado, 1958; Tanikalang Apoy, 1959; Ito ang Pilipino, 1966; Patria Adorada (Beloved Country), 1969; and Nueva Vizcaya, 1973. He also won five FAMAS Best Actor awards for De Colores (In Colors), 1968; Tubog sa Ginto, 1970; Minsan Pa Nating Hagkan ang Nakaraan (Let Us Kiss the Past Once More), 1983; Bakit May Kahapon Pa (Why Is There a Yesterday), 1996; and Bahid (Stain), 2002. He received international film awards as Best Actor at the 55th Asia-Pacific Film Festival in Macau and the 7th Asian Film Awards in Hong Kong for his role in Bwakaw.

As director, he won five FAMAS awards for Pinagbuklod ng Langit (Joined by Heaven), 1969; Sinasamba Kita (I Worship You), 1982; Magdusa Ka (Suffer), 1986; Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig? (Where Does Love Hide?), 1987; and Imortal (Immortal), 1989. He was also chosen Best Director by the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) for Magdusa Ka and Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig?

In 1998, he was conferred the FAP Lifetime Achievement Award. In 2006, he received the Natatanging Gawad Urian for his work as actor and director. The first Dolphy Lifetime Achievement Award Ulirang Alagad ng Sining was awarded to him by the Entertainment Press Society during its Golden Screen Awards for Television in 2013. Written by Joy Galvez and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

article_title: Gatchalian, Elmer L. (See BROADCAST ARTS volume.)
text: (See BROADCAST ARTS volume.)

GEISLER, BARON ( Baron Frederick von Geisler ) b. Pampanga 5 Jun 1982. Film and television actor. He is the son of Gracia Bayonito and the late Donald David Geisler Jr. He has four siblings; one of them is the former Olympian taekwondo champion Donald David Geisler III.

Geisler started acting at the age of 12 for the third season of the popular youth-oriented show Ang TV (The TV), 1995-96. He became one of ABS-CBN’s Star Magic artists and was included in the teen trio Koolits with John Lloyd Cruz and Marc Solis. He also played Fonzy in the hit television series Tabing Ilog (The Riverside), 1999-2003. In 2007, Geisler joined the reality television series Pinoy Big Brother: Celebrity Edition 2 alongside his brother, Donnie. Following this, he played villain roles in projects such as the remake of Eva Fonda, 2008-9, Kidlat (Lightning), 2013, and Dyesebel, 2014, topbilled by Anne Curtis.

In film, Geisler appeared in family-oriented movies, like Haba-baba-doo! Puti-puti-poo!, 1998, and Anak (The Child), 2000. Among his others films are Jay, 2008; Manila, 2009; Donor, 2010; Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story, 2011; El Presidente (The President), 2012; and Boy Golden, 2013.

Geisler earned Best Actor awards at the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival for Jay, 2008, and Donor, 2010. The Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences gave him the Best Supporting Actor award for his performance as Erning Toothpick in Manila Kingpin. In 2014, the Star Awards for Movies honored his achievements as an actor by giving him the Dekada Award, covering the years 2003-13. Written by Kathrina Alvarez

GIL, CHERIE ( Evangeline Rose Gil Eigenmann ) b. Manila 12 May 1963. Movie, stage, and television actor, singer. Her parents are Eduardo M. Eigenmann aka Eddie Mesa, singer-actor, and Rosemarie Gil, movie actor. Her brothers Mark Gil and Michael de Mesa and former sister-in-law Gina Alajar are all actors. She attended elementary grades at St. Paul College in Manila and Quezon City and finished high school at St Joseph’s College. She married International Israeli violinist Rony Rogoff in 1994 but they separated in 2008. They have two children, Bianca and Raphael.

Gil trained for jazz dance with Julie Borromeo, Douglas Nierras, and Steps (New York) and took voice lessons under Barbara Miller, a Julliard graduate. She attended Actors’ Workshop activities in being, body movement, and craft under Eric Morris. She played the role of Mary Magdalene in the musical play Jesus Christ Superstar, and was Corie Bratter in the Neil Simon comedy Barefoot in the Park, directed by Jonas Sebastian. She also appeared in Adul de Leon’s Sundered Selves presented by Bulwagang Pilipino, and was a mainstay in the television shows Champoy, Cebu, and Buena Familia (Good Family). She also appeared in the full-length video Bilanggo sa Dilim (Prisoner in the Dark), 1987, directed by Mike de Leon. She was formally introduced in Elwood Perez’s Problem Child, 1980.

Gil is a dramatic actor known for her intense performances. Among her films are City after Dark, 1980; Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982; Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), 1985; Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig? (Where Does Love Hide?), 1988; Ang Bukas Ay Akin (Tomorrow Is Mine) and Imortal (Immortal), 1989; Ngayon at Kailanman (Now and Forever), 1993; Wating (Street-smart), 1994; Sonata, 2013; and Mana (Inheritance), 2014.

She won Best Supporting Actress in the Metro Manila Film Festival for God Save Me, 1985; Imortal, 1989; and Sugatang Puso (Wounded Heart), 2000. For Ang Bukas Ay Akin, she received Best Supporting Actress awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, the Film Academy of the Philippines, and the Catholic Mass Media Awards. She was chosen Best Actress in the 1992 Star Awards for Television for her performance in Cebu. She was proclaimed Best Actress at the 2nd ASEAN International Film Festival and Awards for her performance in Sonata, 2013, an independent film directed by Peque Gallaga and Lore Reyes. In 2015, she also won Best Actress in Madrid International Film Festival for her performance in Mana.

Her early training in theater blossomed in her stellar performances in Master Class, 2008; Full Gallop, 2014; and in Philippine Educational Theater Association’s Arbol de Fuego (The Cherry Orchard), 2015. Written byCristine Directo and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

GIL, MARK ( Raphael John Gil Eigenmann ) b. Manila 25 Sep 1961. d. Manila 1 Sep 2014. Movie and television actor. He was one of the three children of singer-actor Eddie Mesa and actor Rosemarie Gil. Actors Michael de Mesa and Cherie Gil are his siblings. Actors Sid Lucero, Maxine Eigenmann, Gabby Eigenmann, and Andi Eigenmann are his children. Actors Geoff Eigenmann, Ryan Eigenmann, and AJ Eigenmann are his nephews. He studied at De La Salle Greenhills and Aquinas College for his elementary and secondary schooling, respectively.

Gil appeared in two films as a child actor, then at age 17 became a professional movie actor with the help of movie scribe and talent manager Douglas Quijano. Among his films are Ishmael Bernal’s Salawahan (Fickle), 1979; Mike de Leon’s Batch ’81, 1982; Artemio Marquez’s Naiibang Hayop (A Different Animal); and Emmanuel Borlaza’s Laruan (Plaything), 1983. His other notable films are Itanong Mo sa Buwan (Ask the Moon), 1988; Bad Boy, 1990; Narito ang Puso Ko (Here Is My Heart), 1992; Eskapo: The Sergio Osmeña–Geny Lopez Story (Fugitive), 1995; Babae (Woman), 1997; Saranggola (The Kite), 1999; Magnifico, 2003; Amok, 2011; and Philippino Story, 2013. He appeared on television for various drama anthologies and series.

Acting honors came when he was in his early 20s. He was Gawad Urian Best Supporting Actor for Palipat-lipat, Papalit-palit (Changing Partners), 1982. He was the Gawad Urian Best Actor for Itanong Mo sa Buwan in 1989 and for Rotonda (Roundabout) in 2006. The Catholic Mass Media Awards chose him Best Supporting Actor for Kid, Huwag Kang Susuko (Kid, Do Not Give Up), 1987. Written byCristine Directo, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

GIL, ROSEMARIE ( Maria Rosa Francisca Catalina Castellvi Gil ) b. Manila 9 Mar 1942. Movie and television actor. Born to Carlos Gil Jr and Dolores Castellvi, she finished high school at Assumption Convent. She married singer-actor Eddie Mesa (Eduardo Eigenmann), with whom she has four children. Three of them—Michael de Mesa, Mark Gil, and Cherie Gil—became known for their acting talents.

In 1958, Rosemarie Gil played the lead role in her first film, Sta. Rita de Casia: Patrona ng Imposible (St Rita of Cascia: Patron Saint of the Impossible). In 1959, she starred in Aawitan Kita (I Shall Sing for You), directed by Gerardo de Leon; Gitarang Ginto (Golden Guitar); Hawaiian Boy; and Duke de Borgoña (Duke of Borgoña), with Fernando Poe Jr. In the 1970s, her films include Simon Bastardo (Simon the Bastard), 1970, with Joseph Estrada; Pagdating sa Dulo (At the Top), 1971; Florinda, 1973; Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were, What Happens to You Now?), 1976; and Burlesk Queen (Burlesque Queen), 1977. In the 1980s, her notable films include Gabi ng Lagim Ngayon (Night of Terror Today), 1980; Pagbabalik ng Panday (Return of the Blacksmith), 1981; and Dear Heart, 1981. Some of her later films are Lessons in Love, 1990; Sa Aking mga Kamay (In My Hands) and Mulanay: Sa Pusod ng Paraiso (Mulanay: Deep in Paradise), 1996; Bata, Bata … Paano Ka Ginawa? (Lea’s Story), 1998; Wansapanataym (Once upon a Time), 1999; Minsan Minahal Kita (Once I Loved You) and Eto na Naman Ako (Here I Am Again), 2000; Pagdating ng Panahon (When the Time Comes), 2001; Magkapatid (Siblings), 2002; and Pangarap Ko ang Ibigin Ka (It Is My Dream to Love You), 2003.

In the 1990s, she became active on television, playing a major role in the highly rated TV series Cebu and Buena Familia. In addition, she appeared in the following shows: Bisperas ng Kasaysayan (Eve of History), 1994, May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), 1999, Sa Puso Ko Iingatan Ka (I Will Cherish You in My Heart), 2001, and Hiram (Borrowed), 2004.

Gil won Best Supporting Actress for Burlesk Queen in the 1977 Metro Manila Film Festival. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

GLORIA, TONY ( Antonio Imperial Gloria ) b. Manila 21 Feb 1946. Film producer. He is the son of Alejandro Figueroa Gloria and Rosario Kaiser Imperial. He finished a bachelor of arts degree in speech and drama at the University of the Philippines Diliman. Gloria is the founder and former chief executive officer of Unitel Productions Inc. He is also the founder of two other companies: Optima Digital, a leading postproduction house in the country, and Straight Shooters Media, a production company.

Gloria has more than 35 years of experience in film, advertising, TV commercial production and postproduction. He started his early career with the Philippine Advertising Counselors where he worked as copywriter, producer, audiovisual director, and eventually as senior vice-president/creative director. In the 1980s, he was the supervising producer for Viva Films, the company behind countless box-office successes, among them the many hits of megastar Sharon Cuneta. Some of the films he supervised were Init sa Magdamag (Midnight Passion), 1983; Bagets (Young Ones), Working Girls, and Alyas Baby Tsina (Alias Baby Tsina), 1984; Bituing Walang Ningning (Star Without Sparkle), 1985; and Pasan Ko ang Daigdig (World on My Shoulders), 1987.

In 2001, he produced American Adobo. Later, Unitel embarked into film production for the first time and produced the critically acclaimed box-office hit Crying Ladies, starring Sharon Cuneta, which won top awards at that year’s Metro Manila Film Festival. It was subsequently selected as the Philippines’ official entry in the Oscars, and opened to positive reviews during its theatrical release in New York and Los Angeles in 2004. Its success led to other productions—among them, feature films like Santa Santita (Magdalena), 2004; La Visa Loca (Crazy Visa) and Pinoy Blonde, 2005; Nasaan si Francis? (Where Is Francis?), 2006; and the 2012 musical comedy I Do Bidoo Bidoo. In 2014, he produced Whistleblower, directed by Adolfo Alix Jr and starring Nora Aunor, Cherry Pie Picache, and Angelica Panganiban. Written byVicente Nebrida

GOMEZ, PABLO S. ( Pablo Salonga Gomez ) b. Sampaloc, Manila 25 Jan 1931. d. Quezon City 26 Dec 2010. Scriptwriter, komiks novelist. He is the son of Olimpio Gomez and Pacita Salonga.

Gomez started his career as a komiks writer in 1949 for Liwayway, Bulaklak, Aliwan, and Sinag-Tala. He then became the editor of Hiwaga Komiks for Ace Publications. When Ace Publications closed down in 1963 due to a labor strike, Gomez established his own PSG Publications and published in 1964 its flagship title United Komiks. He, together with his brother Dominador Gomez, wrote komiks novels using several pseudonyms including Rene Rosales and Tennessee Francel, respectively. Other titles published by Gomez’s company include Continental Komiks and Kidlat Komiks. Due to the economic downturn and the impending martial law in the 1970s, PSG Publications closed down.

Many of Gomez’s works were made into movies. His first komiks novel titled Apat na Taga (Four Slashes) was produced by Sampaguita Pictures in 1953. Other movies followed, such as Kurdapya (Screwball), 1955; Kandilang Bakal (Iron Candle), 1957; Anino ni Bathala (Shadow of God), 1958; Kaming Makasalanan (We Sinners) and Tatlong Magdalena (Three Magdalenes), 1960; Pitong Krus ng Isang Ina (A Mother’s Seven Crosses), 1968; Orang, 1970; Kampanerang Kuba (Hunchbacked Lady Bell Ringer), 1973; Alupihang Dagat (Sea Centipede) and Pagbabalik ng Lawin (Return of the Hawk), 1975; Andalucia and Mrs. Eva Fonda, 16, 1976; Little Christmas Tree, 1977; Inday Bote (Inday the Bottle Trader), 1985; Magdusa Ka (Suffer), 1986; Pasan Ko ang Daigdig (World on My Shoulders), 1987; Petrang Kabayo at ang Pilyang Kuting (Petra the Horse and the Mischievous Kitten), 1988; Agila ng Maynila (Eagle of Manila), 1989; and Hiram na Mukha (Borrowed Face), 1992.

Some of Gomez’s notable stories were also adapted for television, such as Pasan Ko ang Daigdig, 2007, and Magdusa Ka, 2008, for GMA; Kampanerang Kuba, 2005, Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels without Heaven), 2006, and Hiram na Mukha, 2007, for ABS-CBN.

Gomez received awards from the Citizens’ Council for Mass Media in 1977 and the Filipino Academy for Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 1988. In 2001, he received the Dr Jose Perez Memorial Award for Journalism from the FAMAS and, in 2006, the Fernando Poe Jr Lifetime Achievement Award from the Film Academy of the Philippines. In 2007, Gomez became the president of the Screenwriters Guild of the Philippines. Written by Gregory del Carmen

GOMEZ, RICHARD ( Richard Frank Gomez ) aka Goma. b. Manila 7 Apr 1966. Movie and television actor. Born to Eduardo Gomez and actor Stella Suarez, he attended the Holy Child Parochial School, Rafael Palma Elementary School, and Arellano University. When he was already an actor, he entered the University of the Philippines (UP) Institute of Mass Communication and took up film studies. He completed an associate in arts from the University of the Philippines Open University in 2009. In 1998, Gomez married model Lucy Torres, who became representative of the fourth district of Leyte. They have a daughter, Juliana Maria Beatrice.

Typecast as a glamour boy when he first entered the movies, Gomez emerged as a serious actor in his later films. His film credits include Tuklaw (Snakebite), 1986; Kid, Huwag Kang Susuko (Kid, Do Not Give Up), 1987; Nagbabagang Luha (Smoldering Tears) and Babaeng Hampaslupa (Downtrodden Woman), 1988; Isang Araw, Walang Diyos (One Day without God), 1989; Lumayo Ka Man sa Akin (Though You Stray from Me), Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal (You’re the Only One I’ve Loved), and Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin (You Are Everything to Me), 1992; Filipinas, 2000; Walang Kapalit (Nobody Else), 2007; Sonata, 2013; and The Trial, 2014.

Gomez was chosen Gawad Urian Best Actor for Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven) in 1991 and for Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are) in 1993. The Gawad Urian also named Gomez as Best Actor of the Decade 1990-99 in 2001. For the movie Dahas (Rage), 1995, Gomez received the Best Actor award from the Film Academy of the Philippines, Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, Star Awards for Movies, and the Metro Manila Film Festival. He also won an award as Outstanding Student Artist from the UP Presidential Committee on Culture and the Arts.

Gomez showed versatility outside his showbiz career. In the 2005 Southeast Asian Games, Gomez brought home the gold medal for fencing. He also became active in civic activities through his active participation in Mamamayan Ayaw sa Droga (Citizens Against Drugs). Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

GOMEZ, RITA ( Rita Arce Gomez ) b. Manila 22 May 1935. d. Jamaica Estates, New York 9 May 1990. Movie, stage, and television actor. Her parents are Luciana Arce and Angel Gomez. She married movie actor Ric Rodrigo. Actor Ronald Bregendahl is their son. After her first marriage was annulled, she married an American, Glenn Yunker. She finished her secondary education at Araullo High School and took up philosophy and letters at the University of Santo Tomas (UST).

Gomez was discovered by director Gerardo de Leon when he was filming at the UST campus and she was invited to appear as a background extra in the movie Bagong Umaga (New Morning), 1952. Later, on a visit to Premiere Studio, she was offered a bit role in Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo (Python in the Old Dome), 1952. She was so good in the role of Marta that her part in the komiks story was expanded in the screen version, for which she earned a nomination as Best Supporting Actress in the first Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) awards rites. She did other films with Premiere, among them Agilang Itim (Black Eagle), 1953, and an aborted television short feature by Manuel Conde, Umbra, before she transferred to Sampaguita Pictures where she signed an exclusive contract with Dr Jose R. Perez. Her first film was Maldita (Naughty), 1953, opposite Pancho Magalona, directed by Eddie Romero. This was followed by Reyna Bandida (Bandit Queen), 1953, with Cesar Ramirez and Ric Rodrigo. She appeared in drama and action films like Milyonarya at Hampaslupa (The Millionairess and the Tramp), 1954, and Anak ng Espada (Daughter of the Sword), 1954, as well as light situation comedies like Society Girl, 1956, and Selosang Selosa (Very Jealous Woman), 1958, and fantasy films like Diosa (Goddess), 1957. But her forte was the role of the good prostitute in films like Tatlong Magdalena (Three Magdalenes), 1960, Pitong Kalbaryo ni Inang (Mother’s Seven Calvaries), 1962, and Liku-Likong Landas (Crooked Paths), 1968.

After Sampaguita, Gomez freelanced in films like Elwood Perez’s Blue Boy, 1970; TIIP’s Lihim ng mga Makasalanan (Secrets of Sinners), 1970, with Tony Ferrer; and United Brothers’ Laman sa Laman (Flesh on Flesh), 1970, with the father-and-son team of Leopoldo Salcedo and Edgar Salcedo. Her first movie with Ishmael Bernal, Pagdating sa Dulo (At the Top), 1971, was chosen by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1970-79. Other Bernal films she made were Salawahan (Fickle), 1979, Gamitin Mo Ako (Use Me), 1985 and the unfinished Scotch on the Rocks. She also appeared in Pio de Castro III’s Inay, Kasusuklaman Ba Kita? (Mother, Should I Despise You?), 1985.

On stage, she starred in Larawan (the Filipino version of Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino), Rigodon de Honor, Who’s Afraid of Virginia Wolf?, A Streetcar Named Desire, Kuwadro (Portrait), Boses (Voices), and the Lenten play Makasalanan (Sinner). She also gained prominence in television, winning the Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining Best Actress award for Sangandaan (Crossroads), 1974. She also performed in Panagimpan (Imagination) and Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye).

Gomez was FAMAS Best Actress twice, for Talipandas (Wayward), 1958, and Bakit Ako Pa? (Why Should It Be Me?), 1970, a love-triangle drama that also gave her the Manila Film Festival Best Actress award for that year. She was nominated by the FAMAS for Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo (Python in the Old Dome), 1952; Kidnapped, 1959, a film based on Tony de Joya’s true story; and Pagdating sa Dulo, 1971. In 1990 she received posthumously the Film Academy of the Philippines Special Recognition Award for her achievements in Philippine movies. Written by Lena S. Pareja

GONZALES, LUIS ( Luis Franco Mercado ) b. Binondo, Manila Aug 1928. d. 15 Mar 2012. Movie actor. He was the youngest of five children of Restituto Mercado, a dealer in furniture, and Paulina Franco. His brother was singer/actor Bobby Gonzales who is known for the song “Hahabol-Habol” (Chasing After). He married Vina Concepcion with whom he had three children. He studied at Gregorio del Pilar Elementary School and Arellano High School. Before joining the movies, he was a law student at the University of the East.

Gonzales was discovered by actor Pancho Magalona who brought him to Dr Jose R. Perez of Sampaguita Pictures. He was introduced in Pilya (Naughty Girl), 1953, opposite Lolita Rodriguez. Gonzales and Rodriguez did other films together, such as Kontrabida (Villain), 1955; Tumbando Caña (Bottoms Up), 1956; Taga sa Bato (Cut on a Stone), 1957; Condenado (Condemned) and Alipin ng Palad (Slave of Fate), 1958; Cicatriz (Scar), 1959; and Lupa sa Lupa (Earth to Earth), 1960.

Gonzales also made several films with Rita Gomez, among them Society Girl, 1955; Pasang Cruz (Cross to Bear), 1957; Isang Milyong Kasalanan (A Million Sins), Tatlong Ilaw sa Dambana (Three Lights on the Altar), and Talipandas (Wayward), 1958; Kidnapped and Double Cross, 1959.

His team-up with Gloria Romero made him a big box-office star of Sampaguita Pictures. Together they made movies like Despatsadora (Salesgirl), 1955; Vacacionista (Vacationer), 1956; Colegiala (Coed), 1957; Ikaw ang Aking Buhay (You Are My Life), 1958; Sinisinta Kita (You Are My Love), 1963; Show of Shows and Ang Rosaryo at Tabak (The Rosary and the Machete), 1964; and Till the End of Time, 1966.

Gonzales stayed with Sampaguita from 1953 to 1969. His other notable films with the company are Jack and Jill, 1954; Ang Tangi Kong Pag-ibig (My Only Love), 1955; Paruparong Bukid (Country Butterfly), 1958; Trudis Liit (Little Trudis) and Dance-O-Rama, 1963. After Sampaguita, he made films for other companies, like Snooky, 1970, with Boots Anson-Roa for Lea Productions; Ang Bituin at Araw (The Star and Sun), 1974, directed by Howard Peterson for Prima; and Isang Gabi, Tatlong Babae (One Night, Three Women), 1974, for Juan de la Cruz Production. His later films include Lulubog Lilitaw sa Ilalim ng Tulay (Fall and Rise under the Bridge), 1975; Pieta, 1983; Anak ni Waray vs Anak ni Biday (The Child of Waray vs the Child of Biday), 1984; and Sa Akin Pa Rin ang Bukas (Tomorrow Still Belongs to Me), 1988; and Kamay ni Cain (Hand of Cain), 1992. His last known film is “Kama” (Bed), an episode of Xerex, 2003.

Gonzales received a special award in the Asian Film Festival in Seoul, Korea, for his portrayal of Ferdinand Marcos in Iginuhit ng Tadhana (Destined by Fate), 1965. He was nominated Best Actor by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for his performance in Pinagbuklod ng Langit (Joined by Heaven), 1969. His last public appearance was in December 2010, when he received a star in the Eastwood Walk of Fame. Written byGalileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

GOSIENGFIAO, JOEY b. Manila 15 Mar 1941. d. Quezon City 16 Mar 2007. Movie director, producer, writer. He finished his studies at the University of the East. Producer Victor Gosiengfiao is his brother.

Gosiengfiao began his career as a stage director, a role he shared with Lino Brocka and Elwood Perez, for the Philippine Educational Theater Association’s (PETA) weekly TV drama series Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), 1967. The series featured adaptations of foreign and local literary novels and plays. Balintataw was abruptly taken off the air with the declaration of martial law in 1972, but made its return in 1982.

The earliest works of Gosiengfiao include those that he both wrote and directed—namely, My Funny Girl, 1971, Takbo, Vilma, Dali! (Run, Vilma, Quick!), 1972, and Zoom, Zoom, Superman!, 1973. Films directed by Gosiengfiao include La Paloma: Ang Kalapating Ligaw (La Paloma: The Lost Dove), 1974; May Isang Tsuper ng Taksi (There Was a Taxi Driver), 1975; Ang Boyfriend Kong Baduy (My Out-of-Style Boyfriend), Si Raquel at si Rafael (Raquel and Rafael), Hide and Seek, and Puwede Ako, Puwede Ka Pa Ba? (I’m Good to Go, Are You?), 1976; Babae! (Woman!) and Bawal: For Men Only (Forbidden: For Men Only), 1977; Bomba Star (Porn Star), 1978; Iskandalo (Scandal), Kambal sa Uma (Twins in Uma), and Bedspacers, 1979; Nympha, Candy, Underage, Katorse (Fourteen), and Temptation Island, 1980; Blue Jeans, 1981; First Kiss, First Love, Where Love Has Gone, No Other Love, and Diary of Cristina Gaston, 1982; Indecent Exposure and Exploitation, 1983; Tender Age and 14 Going Steady, 1984; Rape of Virginia P., 1989; Secrets of Pura, 1991; and Ligaw-Ligawan, Kasal-Kasalan, Bahay-Bahayan (Playing Lovers, Playing Married Couple, Playing House), 1993. Before he devoted his time exclusively to producing films, he directed Nights of Serafina, 1996, and Masarap, Masakit ang Magmahal (To Love Is Bittersweet), 1997.

Gosiengfiao supervised the production of various films, including Sa Ngalan ng Pag-ibig (In the Name of Love), 1995; Batang Z (Z Kid), 1996; Nakaw na Sandali (Stolen Moment), 1997; Magagandang Hayop (Beautiful Animals) and Init ng Laman (Warmth of Flesh), 1998; Serafin Geronimo: Ang Kriminal ng Baryo Concepcion (The Criminal of Barrio Concepcion) and Pahiram Kahit Sandali (Spare Me a Moment), 1998; Pila Balde (Fetch a Pail of Water), Sa Paraiso ni Efren (In Efren’s Paradise), and Hubad sa Ilalim ng Buwan (Naked under the Moon), 1999; Pangarap ng Puso (Demons), 2000; Batang West Side (West Side Avenue) and Halik ng Sirena (Mermaid’s Kiss), 2001; Xerex, 2003; and Forever My Love, 2004. Written by Gregory del Carmen

GOYENA, ARMANDO (Jose IruyetagoyenaRevilla Jr) b. Manila 7 Dec 1922. d. 9 Mar 2011. Movie, stage, and television actor. Nicknamed “Pinggoy,” Goyena was the son of Jose Revilla and Florentina Goyena. He married Francisca Roces aka Paquita Roses—the first Camay model—in 1951, with whom he had eight children. His only son Juan, or Johnny, appears in television and the movies. His daughter Maritess was a Camay model; daughter Tina was a popular TV host. His other daughters are Malu, Rossi, Cecilia, Pita, and Cita. The third generation of Revillas who are also in show business are Maritess’s daughter Bianca Araneta, model; Cecilia’s daughter Lexi Schulze, TV and event host; Pita’s sons Mico and Bernard Palanca, actors.

A graduate of De La Salle College where he took up commerce, Goyena proceeded to manage a soda fountain in Manila, where one day Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero walked in to have coffee. Guerrero then invited Goyena to join a production of Filipino Players. He found himself performing before army veterans in an open-air benefit performance ofWanted: A Chaperone, 1946. Guerrero cast him in other productions, such as Condemned,1946, andWow! These Americans,1947, and even created a one-actor play for him titled What a Guy!,1948. He also acted for Lamberto V. Avellana and his Barangay Theater Guild, appearing inJoan of Lorraineas Dunois, inSummer and Smokeas John, and in A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino as Tony Javier.

Goyena later approached his mother’s friend, LVN Pictures producer Doña Narcisa de Leon aka Doña Sisang, to be a movie actor. After a long wait, he was finally given the role of an army lieutenant, as second lead to Leopoldo Salcedo in Puting Bantayog(White Monument), 1948. Following several more second lead roles (to Jose Padilla Jr, Rogelio de la Rosa, and Jaime de la Rosa), he was given his first starring role inMaria Beles,1949.

Right after his next movie,Prinsesang Basahan(Princess in Rags), 1949, LVN firmed up his love team with Tessie Quintana. They appeared together in 17 films, which were hits such as Sa Tokyo Ikinasal (Married in Tokyo), 1948; Ibigin Mo Ako, Lalaking Matapang (Love Me, Brave Man), Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), and Virginia,1949; Misteryoso (Mysterious) and Pagtutuus (Showdown), 1950; David at Goliath(David and Goliath), Talisman, and Pag-asa (Hope), 1951; Tia Loleng(Aunt Loleng), Isabelita, Tenyente Carlos Blanco (Lt Carlos Blanco), and Amor Mio (My Love), 1952; Philippine Navy, Hawayana(Hawaiian Girl), and Ligaw Tingin (Woo by Gazing), 1953; Kapitan Kidlat (Captain Lightning), 1953; Kidlat … Ngayon (Lightning … Now), 1954; Damong Ligaw (Wild Grass), 1954; Banda Uno (Band Number One), Anak ng Berdugo (Executioner’s Son), and Palasyong Pawid (Palm Palace), 1955; Abandonado (Abandoned) and Laging Ikaw (Always You), 1956. Having done more than 50 films in his prime, he quit while he was ahead to focus on the family business. His last movie during this period wasCasa Grande(Mansion), 1958. Goyena appeared in the first live family television showBahala si Mommy(Leave It to Mommy), 1960.

After being away from the limelight for three decades, he acceded to Helen Vela’s request to appear inLovingly Yours, Helen, 1990.He appeared in other television shows, such asConey Reyes, Buddy en Sol(Buddy and Sol), andMaricel, as well in Ishmael Bernal’s filmMahal Kita, Walang Iba(I Love No One Else but You), 1992. He also appeared in Eskapo: The Sergio Osmeña–Geny Lopez Story (Fugitive), 1995, and did his last film Annie B, 2004, at age 80.

He received his first and only Best Actor award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences late in life and in his career: for his role in Yamashita: The Tiger’s Treasure, 2001. He passed away in 2011 at age 88 due to pulmonary embolism. Written by Malou M. Maniquis, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

GOYENA, LUCITA (Luz Corral Serrano ) b. Taguig, Rizal 17 Nov 1914. Movie actor. She is the daughter of Urbano Serrano, a doctor, and Francisca Goyena Corral. Her sisters Carolina and Anita Serrano were also pre-World War II actors. She was the widow of Rodolfo Garcia, with whom she had two sons: Garry Boy and Marco Polo. Her second husband was Michael Charles Mayr. She studied at the University of the East.

Goyena was one of the most popular movie actors of the World War II era. She frequently appeared with FernandoPoeSr. They were called “King and Queen” of the local movie industry in 1940. Goyena’s first film was Parlatone Hispano-Filipino’s Teniente Rosario (Lieutenant Rosario), 1937, with RogeliodelaRosa. The role was intended for her sister Carolina, who got married at the time. Her next film is Pugad ng Agila (Eagle’s Nest), 1938, with Darmo von Frazer Acosta. In 1939, Goyena moved to X’Otic Pictures where she was paired with FernandoPoeSr in Punit na Bandila (Torn Flag). She also appeared in Tinik ng Isang Bulaklak (Thorns of a Flower), 1939, with EduardodeCastro and ReynaldoDante; Biak na Bato and Palaboy ng Diyos (God’s Vagabond), both in 1939; Alaalang Banal (Sacred Memory), 1940; and Alipin ng Alila (Servant’s Slave), Dalagang Filipina (Filipina Maiden), Sa Duyan ng Pagmamahal (In Love’s Cradle), and Viuda Alegre (Merry Widow), all in 1941.

Her marriage in 1941 marked her retirement from the film industry. After her retirement, she did a few cameo appearances on local TV upon her return from her stay in the United States. These appearances include Valiente in 2000, which she did with Michael de Mesa. Three years later, she did another cameo appearance in the original version of Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise) with Jericho Rosales and Kristine Hermosa. Goyena received the Walang Kupas award in 1982 from the Film Academy of the Philippines. Written by Cesar Hernando and Carol Afan, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

GUILLEN, LAURICE A. ( Laurice Andaya Guillen ) b. Butuan City, Agusan 29 Jan 1947. Movie, television, stage actor and director. She is the daughter of Gudiardo Guillen and Laura Andaya. She got a bachelor of arts degree in English from St. Theresa’s College, Cebu, and earned her master’s degree in communication arts at Ateneo de Manila University. She married actor Johnny Delgado (Juan Feleo) with whom she has two children, Ina and Ana Feleo, both actors. With her husband, Guillen established the Actors’ Workshop Foundation. She was chair of the Film Development Council of the Philippines from 2002 to 2005. She has been heading the Festival Competition Committee of the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival since 2005.

Guillen started out on the professional stage in 1967. She appeared in productions of the Drama Federation of the Philippines, Ateneo Drama Group, Repertory Philippines, UP Repertory Company, Philippine Educational Theater Association, Cultural Center of the Philippines, and Metropolitan Theater. She worked under directors Rolando Tinio, Salvador Bernal, Peque Gallaga, Behn Cervantes, Anton Juan, Tony Mabesa, and Lino Brocka. She played varied roles like Nancy in The Knack, 1968; Likain in The Promise and Anna in Anna Kleiber, 1970; Desdemona in Othello, 1974; Concha in Mga Ama, Mga Anak (Fathers and Sons), 1976; and Blanche Dubois in A Streetcar Named Desire, 1977 and 1980.

Guillen’s acting debut on the big screen was in Crush Ko si Sir (I’ve Got a Crush on Sir), directed by Nestor Torre under Lea Productions, followed by a role in Brocka’s Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (You Were Weighed and Found Wanting) and in Gerardo de Leon’s “Caridad” segment in Fe, Esperanza, Caridad, 1974. Her other films as an actor include Lunes, Martes, Miyerkoles, Huwebes, Biyernes, Sabado, Linggo (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday), 1976; Init (Heat), 1978; Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Mother, Sister, Daughter), 1979; A Dangerous Life and Baleleng, 1988; Sa Kuko ng Aguila (In the Claws of the Eagle), 1989; and Bakit Ikaw Pa Rin? (Why Still You?), 1990.

Guillen turned to film directing in 1980, starting with Kasal? (Marriage?), followed by Kung Ako’y Iiwan Mo (Should You Abandon Me). She also came out with a number of highly polished box-office hits, including Kung Mahawi Man ang Ulap (Should the Skies Clear), 1984, and the Sharon Cuneta–Gabby Concepcion starrer Una Kang Naging Akin (You Were Mine First), 1991. Her other films as director include Rosenda, 1989; Beautiful Girl, 1990; Ipagpatawad Mo (Forgive Me), 1991; Lumayo Ka Man sa Akin (Though You Stray from Me) and Apoy sa Puso (Fire in the Heart), 1992; Isang Sulok ng mga Pangarap (In One Corner of Dreams) and Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang? (Why Only Now?), 1994; and Sana Dalawa ang Puso Ko (Wish I Had Two Hearts), 1995. After a hiatus of five years, she returned to film, directing Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000. Her other films are American Adobo, 2001; Santa Santita (Magdalena), 2004; I Love You, Goodbye, 2009; Sa ’Yo Lamang (Only Yours), 2010; Maskara (Mask), 2011; and Once a Princess, 2014.

Guillen also appeared in several TV drama anthologies and had her work featured in The Director’s Hour, Wakasan, Carmi, and Viva Telesine. For five years, she was a mainstay in the long-running TV series Flordeluna. Guillen was very visible on television with her roles in Babangon Ako’t Dudurugin Kita (Sweet Revenge), 2008; Nagsimula sa Puso (It Began from the Heart), 2009; Reputasyon (Reputation), 2011-12; Genesis, 2013; and Carmela, 2014.

In 1970, Guillen was chosen Best Actress for a single performance on television for Babae (Woman) by the Citizens’ Award for Television. In 1980, she won as Best Stage Actress in the Aliw Awards for her portrayal of Blanche Dubois in A Streetcar Named Desire. She was named Best Supporting Actress in 1984 by the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA), Gawad Urian, and the Star Awards for her performance in Sister Stella L. For Salome, 1981, Guillen won Best Director in the Gawad Urian. In 1988, she received the Best Director award for Magkano ang Iyong Dangal? (How Much Is Your Honor Worth?) in the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF). In 1990, she won again in the same category for Kapag Langit ang Humatol (Heaven’s Judgement) at the Gawad Urian. Perhaps her most awarded work as a director is Tanging Yaman, which won for her Best Director awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, Gawad Urian, Young Critics Circle, and the MMFF. Written byMalou M. Maniquis, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

GUTIERREZ, CHUCK ( Carlo Joel Burgos Gutierrez ) b. Quezon City 10 Nov 1981. Editor, producer. He is the son of Joel Gutierrez and Teresita Burgos. He is married to journalist and filmmaker Baby Ruth Villarama. He studied at the University of Asia and the Pacific and took units in master of arts in media studies, major in film, at the University of the Philippines Film Institute. He also studied digital filmmaking and video production at the Film Arts Foundation in San Francisco, California, USA.

His debut as editor of Francis Xavier Pasion’s Jay, 2008, earned for him the Best Editor prize in the 2008 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, the 2009 Star Awards, and the 2009 Gawad Urian. In the Cinemalaya, he also won Best Editor for his work on Sheron Dayoc’s Halaw (Ways of the Sea), 2010, and Joselito Altarejos’s Pink Halo-Halo, 2010.

With his wife he founded Voyage Studios, which produces and markets Philippine independent films. It produced Villarama’s Jazz in Love, 2013, which he edited. It won the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award in the 2013 SalaMindanaw International Film Festival and it opened the 2013 Cinemalaya.

Gutierrez’s other works as editor include Yam Laranas’s Patient X, 2009; Pasion’s Sampaguita, National Flower, 2010; Henry Burgos’s Painted Reality, 2010; Zurich Chan’s Teoriya (Theory), 2011; Benito Bautista’s Boundary, 2011, Harana (Serenade), 2012, and Mumbai Love, 2014; Emerson Reyes’s MNL 143, 2012; Alvin Yapan’s Mga Anino ng Kahapon (Shadows of the Past), 2013; and Marlon Rivera’s Ang Huling Henya (The Last Genius), 2013.

His constant collaboration with regional filmmakers is noteworthy. His work for Arnel Mardoquio’s Ang Tigmo sa Aking Pagpauli (Riddles of My Homecoming), 2013, set in Mindanao, was awarded Best Editing in the 2014 Gawad Urian. He also edited Auraeus Solito’s Busong (Palawan Fate), 2011; Dayoc’s short film Mientras Su Durmida (As He Sleeps), 2012; and Yapan’s Debosyon (Devotion), 2013.

He directs music videos and short films. His short film Ulian, 2012, was screened in Cinemalaya and other festivals here and abroad, like the Thai Short Film & Video Festival, Guam International Film Festival, and Un Pays Un Film Festival International de Cinema in France. Written by Patrick Campos

GUTIERREZ, EDDIE ( Jorge Eduardo Pickett Gutierrez ) b. Manila 6 Feb 1942. Movie actor. The son of Mary Pickett, an American, and Antonio Gutierrez, he studied at San Beda College and finished high school at San Sebastian College. He took up a course in commerce at Letran College. He married actor Annabelle Rama with whom he has six children, including actor Ruffa Gutierrez and the twins Richard and Raymond. He has two other sons, both actors: Ramon Christopher, by actor-singer Pilita Corrales, and Tonton Gutierrez, by actor Liza Lorena.

After appearing as a bit player in Prinsesa Gusgusin (Shabby Princess), 1957, he was introduced in Handsome, 1960, and played lead roles in such movies as Kaming Makasalanan (We Sinners), 1960, and Eddie Long Legs, 1964. He was under contract with Sampaguita Pictures for eight years. His other films are Hiram na Kamay (Borrowed Hand), June Bride, and Pitong Puso (Seven Hearts), 1962; Sabina and Bird of Paradise, 1963; Eddie Loves Susie, 1964; Isinulat sa Dugo (Written in Blood), 1965; I’ll Dream of You, 1966; and All Over the World, 1967. His film pairings with actor Susan Roces became very popular with audiences in the 1960s. He acted in films like Katawang Lupa (Earthly Body), 1975; Ursula, 1976; Beerhouse and Bontoc, 1977; Balatkayo (Disguise), Bomba Star, Sari-saring Ibong Kulasisi (Different Lovebirds), and Lagi na Lamang Ba Akong Babae? (Must I Always Be Woman?), 1978; and Lumakad Ka, Gabi (Walk, Night), 1979. Sometime after a car accident in 1978, Gutierrez brought his wife and children to live in the United States, where they stayed for nine years. After a brief hiatus, he resumed his career in the Philippines, appearing in such films as Payaso (Clown), 1986; Asawa Ko Huwag Mong Agawin (Don’t Steal My Husband), 1987; Love Boat: Mahal Trip Kita (Love Boat: Darling, I Like You), 1988; Florencio Diño Public Enemy No. 1 of Caloocan, 1989; Anak ni Baby Ama (Son of Baby Ama), 1990; Magdaleno Orbos: Sa Kuko ng mga Lawin (Magdalena Orbos: In the Talons of the Hawk), 1991; Home along da Riles da Movie (Home along the Railroad: The Movie), 1993; Di Mapigil ang Init (Can’t Stop the Heat), 1995; Kamandag Ko ang Papatay sa Iyo (My Venom Will Kill You), 1997; Mister Mo, Lover Ko (Your Husband, My Lover), 1999; Hanggang Kailan Ako Papatay para Mabuhay (Killing to Live), 2002; and Hiram (Borrowed), 2003. He reprised his role in Mulawin: The Movie, 2005, a spin-off of the television fantasy series Mulawin, 2004-5. In My Monster Mom, 2008, he starred alongside his wife Annabelle Rama, daughter Ruffa, and son Richard.

He appeared on television in GMA Network’s Kung Mawawala Ka (A World without You), 2002-3, Zorro, 2009, and Captain Barbell, 2011. His son Richard played the title roles in the latter two shows. For ABS-CBN he starred in 100 Days to Heaven, 2011; Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Her Mother’s Daughter), 2012-13; and two episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember): “Limos” (Alms), 1993, and “Basura” (Trash), 2008, where he was reunited with Susan Roces.

In 1991 he was nominated Best Supporting Actor by the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) for Uubusin Ko ang Lahi Mo (I Will Exterminate Your Clan). He received the FAP award for Best Actor and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) award for Best Supporting Actor for Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal (You’re the Only One I’ve Loved), 1992. For the film For the First Time, 2008, Gutierrez was nominated Best Supporting Actor by FAMAS. In 2012, he was awarded by the Philippine Movie Press Club (PMPC) with the Ulirang Artista Lifetime Achievement Award.

He was part of the reality television show following the life of the Gutierrez family, It Takes Gutz to Be a Gutierrez, 2014, which received a Best Reality Show award from the PMPC. Written by Glecy Atienza, updated by Erika Carreon

GUTIERREZ, TONTON ( Eduardo Antonio Winsett Gutierrez Jr ) b. Manila, Philippines 11 Sep 1964. Film and television actor. He is the son of actors Eddie Gutierrez and Liza Lorena (Elizabeth Ann Jolene Luciano Winsett), and is married to actor Glydel Mercado with whom he has two daughters, Annyza and Annyka.

With both his parents working in show business, it only seemed natural for Gutierrez to take interest in the entertainment industry. His movies include Captain Barbell, 1986; Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (I Wish This Were Forever), 1986; Pasan Ko ang Daigdig (World on My Shoulders), 1987; Jack & Jill sa America (Jack and Jill in America), 1988; Kahit Wala Ka Na (Even If You’re Gone), 1989; and Sa Kabila ng Lahat (Despite Everything), 1991, Lino Brocka’s last film before he was killed in a car accident in the same year. Gutierrez also appeared in Kaputol ng Isang Awit (Fragment of a Song), 1991; Kapantay ay Langit (As High as Heaven), 1994; the remake of Celso Ad. Castillo’s horror-drama movie, Patayin sa Sindak si Barbara (Kill Barbara with Fright), 1995; Sariwang Bulaklak (Fresh Flowers), 1996; and Ambisyosa (Ambitious Woman), 1998, with Glydel Mercado who later on became his real-life partner. He also appeared in Ang Tanging Ina (The One and Only Mom), 2003; the multi-awarded film Magnifico, 2003; Rosario, 2010; Born to Love You, 2012; and Boy Golden: Shoot to Kill; The Arturo Porcuna Story, 2013.

Active in television, Gutierrez appeared in a number of TV series from different networks such as ABS-CBN’s Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000-02, where he played the role of Governor Eduardo Buenavista; GMA Network’s Te Amo: Maging Sino Ka Man (Speaking the Language of Love), 2004; and TV5’s Glamorosa (Glamorous), 2011-12. He also appeared in Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), 2006; Sana Maulit Muli (I Wish It Would Happen Again) and Mga Mata ni Anghelita (Anghelita’s Eyes), 2007; Babangon Ako’t Dudurugin Kita (Sweet Revenge), 2008; Aryana, 2012-13; and Sana Bukas Pa ang Kahapon (Hoping Yesterday Was Tomorrow), 2014.

Gutierrez garnered various nominations for his work, and in 1997 he won Best Actor in the Gawad Urian for his performance in Carlos Siguion-Reyna’s Abot-Kamay ang Pangarap (Elena’s Redemption), 1996. Written byLorelie Legisniana

HERNANDO, CESAR ( Cesar Asuzano Hernando ) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 11 Nov 1946. Movie production designer, director, writer, producer, graphic artist, photographer, teacher. His parents are Marcos V. Hernandoand Socorro C. Asuzano. Critic Mario is his brother. In 1967, he received a fine arts degree from the University of Santo Tomas (UST). Hernando was vice chair of the Committee on Cinema of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts from 2001 to 2004, and is a board member of the Society of Filipino Archivists for Film. He was associate professor in the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Fine Arts when he retired in 2011. Hernandotook film courses under Ben Pinga at the Film Institute of the Philippines in 1970.

Hernando first got involved in film production as assistant to Ishmael Bernal in Pagdating sa Dulo(At the Top), 1970, and to Mike de Leon inKung Mangarap Ka’t Magising(When You Dream and Wake Up), 1977. Director Mike de Leon chose Hernando to do the production designs of Kisapmata (In the Blink of an Eye), 1981; Batch ’81, 1982; Sister Stella L., 1984; Hindi Nahahati ang Langit (An Indivisible Heaven), 1985; Aliwan Paradise (Entertainment Paradise), 1992; and parts of Bayaning 3rd World (Third World Hero), 1999. He designed Maryo J. de los Reyes’s Tagos ng Dugo (Bloodstain), 1987; Raymond Red’s Bayani (Hero), 1992; and Lav Diaz’s Batang West Side (West Side Avenue), 2001. He was art director in the British film production of Return from the River Kwai, 1989. He did the production design for Clodualdo del Mundo Jr’s Pepot Artista (Pepot Superstar) and Paglipad ng Anghel (Flight of an Angel), 2011; Raymond Red’s Himpapawid (Manila Skies), 2010, and Kamera Obskura (Dark Room), 2012; and Mes de Guzman’s Diablo (Demon), 2012, and Ang Kwento ni Mabuti (The Story of Mabuti), 2013.

As a producer, writer, and director, he did the experimental films Botika Bituka (Drugstore, Intestine), 1987, and Kalawang (Rust), with co-directors Eli Guieb III and Jimbo Albano, 1989, shown in several film festivals abroad; the documentary film Masakit sa Mata (Eye Stinger), 1990; the short feature films Maalinsangan ang Gabi (The Restless Night), 1993, Motorsiklo (Motorcycle), 2001, and Kagat ng Dilim (Fangs of Darkness), 2006; and the unfinished digital feature film Puso ng Kadiliman (Heart of Darkness). During the Cinemalaya at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 2011, he had his first one-man photo exhibit, Mga Aninong Gumagalaw (Moving Shadows), featuring behind-the-scene photographs from the films of directors de Leon, Red, de los Reyes, and Diaz taken between 1971 and 2001.

Hernando designed three of the four Urian anthologies in 2001, 2010, and 2013; The CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, 1994; Tuklas Sining, 1989-94; and other books on cinema, theater, media, and literature. He also designed the logos of the UP Film Institute and the UP College of Mass Communication. He was project director, book designer, and pictorial researcher for The Cinema of Manuel Conde by Nicanor G. Tiongson.

Hernando won Best Production Design awards from the Gawad Urian for the films Kisapmata, Bayani (Hero), and Batang West Side, which he received in 1982, 1993, and 2002, respectively. In 2011, he won Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk for Himpapawid. The University of the Philippines bestowed on him the UP Artist II award in 2011. He also received the Benavides Outstanding Achivement Award from UST. Written by Emelie Capulong, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

HERNANDO, MARIO A. (Mario Asuzano Hernando) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 25 Oct 1948 d. Quezon City 5 Sep 2017. Essayist. He was the son of Marcos Hernando and Socorro Asuzano, and brother of movie production designer and filmmaker, CesarHernando. He earned his journalism degree from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1969. He was once a staff member of the San Miguel Corporation Public Relations Office, reporter for Manila Daily Bulletin and Manila Chronicle, and writer for the Sunday Variety of the Manila Times. He was managing editor for Malaya and later editor of its weekly supplement, Sunday Malaya.

Hernando is a founding member and former chairperson of the Manunuring PelikulangPilipino which yearly gives out the Urian Awards. He participated in the Manila International Film Festival, 1980-83, and attended the International Film Festival of Tashkent, 1988, as well as the International Film Festival of India in Calcutta, 1990, and Telluride Film Festival and New York Film Festival, 1991. He was a member of the jury for the FilipinoAcademyofMovieArtsandSciences (FAMAS) Awards, 1974; CatholicMassMediaAwards (CMMA), 1975-80; Short Film Festival sponsored by the ExperimentalCinemaofthePhilippines and, later, the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP); and the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon, 1988-90. He represented the Philippines in international film festivals in Singapore, Fukuoka, and Chicago. He sat as juror for the Metro Manila Film Festival for several years, and the Cinemalaya Independent Film Festival in 2015.

He was granted a professorial chair when he taught film and journalism at the UST Faculty of Arts and Letters. He has lectured on different aspects of journalism in workshops, and on the art of film in Manila universities in 1991 and provincial campuses in 1989 to 1990 as part of the various film and art outreach programs of the CCP. He toured seven cities in the United States in 1991 under the International Visitor Program of the United States Information Service (USIS).

Hernando authored the monograph “Ishmael Bernal: Merging Art and Commercialism,” 1980. He is the editor of the book, Lino Brocka: The Artist and His Times, published by the CCP in 1993. His articles have been published in the NotesonPhilippineCinema, 1982; Philippine Mass Media, 1986; and in the Urian Anthology 1970-1979, 1983; Urian Anthology 1980-1989, 2001; Urian Anthology 1990-1999, 2010; and Urian Anthology 2000-2009, 2013. His reviews on the arts and entertainment, as well as essays, interview pieces, feature articles, news reports and columns, were published in broadsheets, including Times Journal, Philippines Daily Express, and Manila Daily Bulletin, and in magazines, such as Mod, Weekend, Expressweek, Parade, Bulaklak, People, Ginoo, Manila Paper, and Modern Romances.

Hernando was the film reviewer of the celebrity-based TV talk show, Movie Magazine, aired on GMA 7, ca 1987. He also hosted Showbiz Star and Spies aired on IBC 13, and Tele-Vi, Pamana ni Brocka (Brocka’s Legacy), and Hollywood Manila on PTV 4.

For nearly 20 years, Hernando served as member of the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB). He received the Outstanding Alumnus Award from the UST Faculty of Arts and Letters in 1991. Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian

HIDALGO, JULY ( Julio P. Hidalgo ) b. ca 1920. Movie sound director. Mentored by William Smith, the first sound recording engineer in the country, Hidalgo became one of the earliest sound directors at LVN studio. He pioneered in setting up sound equipment that managed to compete with the best in Asia when his films came up for international competition, such as Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956, which won Best Picture at the Asian Film Festival held in Hong Kong, and Badjao, 1957, which won four major awards at the Asian Film Festival in Tokyo, Japan.

Among the other films he worked on are Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941; Aladin, 1946; Sarung Banggi (One Night) and Himala ng Birhen (Miracle of the Virgin), 1947; Huling Dalangin (Last Prayer) and Sa Tokyo Ikinasal (Married in Tokyo), 1948; Sipag Ay Yaman (Diligence Is Wealth), Ang Kandidato (The Candidate), Kampanang Ginto (Golden Bell), and Lupang Pangako (Promised Land), 1949; Hantik (Black Ant) and Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), 1950; Pag-asa (Hope), In Despair, Satur, Tapis Mo, Inday (Your Overskirt, Inday), Haring Cobra (King Cobra), and Anak ng Pulubi (A Beggar’s Child), 1951; Señorito, Hawayana (Hawaiian Girl), and Kuwentong Bahay-Bahayan (Playing House Stories), 1953; Galawgaw (Wacky), Waray-Waray, and Hiram na Kasintahan (Borrowed Sweetheart), 1954; Ikaw Kasi (You Are to Blame) and Sonny Boy, 1955; Biyaya ng Lupa (Blessings of the Land) and Kundiman ng Lahi (Love Song of the Race), 1959.

Hidalgo won the Best Sound Director award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences twice in succession: for Kandelerong Pilak (Silver Candlesticks), 1954, and Higit sa Lahat (Above All), 1955. Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

HULLEZA, ABELARDO ( Abelardo Villanueva Hulleza ) aka Dho, Ding, or Abel Hulleza. b. Negros Occidental 14 Apr 1947. Movie editor. His parents are Gabriel Hulleza and Lolita Villanueva. He studied at Cecilio Apostol Elementary School, Caloocan High School, and FEATI University, where he took up electrical engineering. He and wife Simplicia have five children.

The movies he edited include Banaue, 1975; Mag-ingat Kayo … Playboy Ako! (Be Careful, I’m a Playboy) and Aliping Saguiguilid (Hearth Slave), 1976; The Magnificent 3 and Iwasan: Alak, Babae at Sugal (Avoid: Wine, Women and Gambling), 1977; Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Heron Turns Black), 1978; Bakit May Pag-ibig Pa (Wherefore Love) and Coed, 1979; Unang Yakap (First Embrace), 1980; Uhaw na Dagat (Thirsty Ocean) and Matira ang Matibay (Survival of the Fittest), 1981; Miracle of Love, 1982; I’ll Wait for You (If It Takes Forever!), Digmaan … Sa Pagitan ng Langit at Lupa (War between Heaven and Earth), Tulume Alyas Zorro, Kumander Melody (Commander Melody), and Virgin People, 1983; Anak ni Waray vs Anak ni Biday (The Child of Waray vs the Child of Biday), and Snake Sisters, 1984; Lihim sa Likod ng Buwan (Secret behind the Moon) and And the World Became Flesh, 1985; Payaso (Clown), 1986; When Good Girls Go Wrong, 1987; Lorenzo Ruiz … The Saint … A Filipino!, 1988; Ang Babaeng Nawawala sa Sarili (The Woman Who’s Out of Her Wits), 1989; Humanda Ka Mayor! Bahala na ang Diyos (Beware, Mayor! Vengeance Is the Lord’s), The Vizconde Massacre Story: God Help Us!, and Inay (Mother), 1993; The Untold Story: Vizconde Massacre II; May the Lord Be with Us!, The Maggie de la Riva Story: God … Why Me?, and Lipa “Arandia” Massacre: Lord, Deliver Us from Evil, 1994; Anabelle Huggins Story: Ruben Ablaza Tragedy; Mea Culpa and The Marita Gonzaga Rape-Slay: In God We Trust!, 1995; Mananayaw (Dancer), 1997; and Chavit, 2003.

Hulleza won the editing award for the following films: Burlesk Queen (Burlesque Queen), 1977, Metro Manila Film Festival; Alapaap (Clouds), 1984, Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences; Itanong Mo sa Buwan (Ask the Moon), 1988, Star Awards and Gawad Urian. Written by Raquel Hernandez, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

IDIOMA, ALBERT MICHAEL ( Albert Michael Morales Idioma ) b. Daet, Camarines Norte 1 May 1966. Sound engineer. His parents are Alberto Idioma and Herminia Morales. He studied at Don Bosco Technical College where he obtained a degree in electronics and communications engineering.

Among the films that Idioma worked on as a sound engineer and supervisor are Junior Police, Eskapo: The Sergio Osmeña–Geny Lopez Story (Fugitive), and Dahas (Rage), 1995; Mumbaki (Shaman), Madrasta (Stepmother), Magic Temple, and Sa Aking mga Kamay (In My Hands), 1996; Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin (They Call Me Joy), Wala Na Bang Pag-ibig? (Is There No Love Anymore?), and Nasaan ang Puso (Where Is the Heart), 1997; Bata, Bata … Paano Ka Ginawa (Lea’s Story), Jose Rizal , and Ang Babae sa Bintana (Woman by the Window), 1998; Soltera (The Spinster) and Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 1999; Azucena, Live Show, Lagarista (Film Biker), Laro sa Baga (Playing with Fire), Sugatang Puso (Wounded Heart), Spirit Warriors, Markova: Comfort Gay, and Deathrow, 2000; Minsan May Isang Puso (Once There Was a Heart), Mila, and Bagong Buwan (New Moon), 2011; Mano Po (I Kiss Your Hand) and Dekada ’70 (The 1970s), 2002; Pinay Pie, 2003; Kutob (Hunch), 2005; Blue Moon, 2006; Sakal, Sakali, Saklolo (Strangle, Perchance, Help), 2007; Ploning, 2008; Kimmy Dora: Kambal sa Kiyeme (Kimmy Dora: Twins of Nonsense), 2009; Working Girls, Donor, and Rosario, 2010; Temptation Island, Trespassers, Ang Babae sa Septic Tank (The Woman in the Septic Tank), and Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story, 2011; Posas (Shackled), Bwakaw, Aparisyon (Apparition), Thy Womb, I Doo Bidoo Bidoo: Heto NApo Sila! (I Do Bidoo Bidoo: The APO Is Here!), Biktima (The Victim), and El Presidente (The President), 2012; Jazz in Love, Porno, and Sonata, 2013; Bwaya (Crocodile), The Gifted, and Niko: Journey to Magika, 2014; Anino sa Likod ng Buwan (Shadow behind the Moon), Old Skool (Old School), and Toto, 2015.

Idioma won many awards for sound, including the following from the Film Academy of the Philippines: in 2004 for Malikmata (Illusion), in 2005 for Feng Shui, in 2012 for Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story, and in 2013 for El Presidente. He won the Gawad Urian in 1999 for Jose Rizal; in 2001 for Deathrow, with Rudy Gonzales; in 2010 for Kinatay (The Execution of P.); and in 2012 for Amok, with Addiss Tabong. The Young Critics Circle honored Idioma’s work in 1996 for Dahas, with Jesse Lasaten; in 1999 for Curacha: Ang Babaeng Walang Pahinga (Curacha: The Woman without Rest), with Jaime Fabregas; in 2000 for Phone Sex, with Jesse Lucas; in 2001 for Sugatang Puso, with Jesse Lucas; in 2002 for Minsan May Isang Puso, with Jesse Lucas, and for Yamashita: The Tiger’s Treasure, with Ronald de Asis, Ross Diaz, Nathan Brenholdt, and Kormann Roque; in 2003 for Dekada ’70, with Alex Tomboc and Nonong Buencamino; in 2005 for Sigaw (The Echo), with Jesse Lucas and Arnold Reodica; and in 2014 for Porno, with Ari Trofeo.

Idioma won the Balanghai trophy for Best Sound from the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival for Rekrut (Recruit), 2010; Amok, 2011; Aparisyon, 2012; Quick Change, 2013; and The Janitor, 2014. He also won Best Sound in the 2013 Cinema One Originals Film Festival for Alamat ni China Doll (The Legend of China Doll). Written by Mario Mendez Jr
