ILAGAN, JAY ( Julius Abad Ilagan ) b. Manila 20 Jan 1953. d. Quezon City 3 Feb 1992. Movie and television actor. His parents are the popular prewar movie stars Angel Esmeralda and Corazon Noble. His grandfather is sarsuwelista Hermogenes Ilagan and his uncles are directors Gerardo de Leon and Conrado Conde, and musician Tito Arevalo. He has a daughter, Leona Paula, with actor Hilda Koronel. With actor Amy Austria, he has an adopted daughter, Alexandra.
He joined the movies at the age of six when Fernando Poe Jr gave him a role in Walang Duwag na Lalaki (No Man Is a Coward), 1959. He appeared with Joseph Estrada in Gerardo de Leon’s Barilan sa Pugad-Lawin (Shootout at Eagle’s Nest), 1963. His first starring role was in Batang Maynila (Manila Boy), 1969, followed by Hippie Holiday, 1970, with Mildred Ortega. He starred as a youth in films like Santiago, 1970; Inspiration, 1972; Tubog sa Ginto (Dipped in Gold), 1971; Sweet Matutina, 1971; and From Both Sides Now, 1970. Later, he appeared in more mature roles in Tatlo, Dalawa, Isa (Three, Two, One), 1974; Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth), 1976; Salawahan (Fickle) and 1979; Sino’ng Pipigil sa Pagpatak ng Ulan? (Who Will Stop the Rain from Falling?), 1979; and Sana, Bukas Pa ang Kahapon (Hoping Yesterday Was Tomorrow), 1983. He also made movies with Nora Aunor, among them Carmela, Kondesang Basahan (Countess in Rags), and Binibini ng Palengke (Muse of the Market), 1973.

Ilagan was a regular on the TV comedy show Goin’ Bananas, as part of the group Bad Bananas composed of Christopher de Leon, Edgar Mortiz, and Johnny Delgado.

Ilagan was chosen Metro Manila Film Festival Best Supporting Actor twice: for Brutal, 1980, and Kisapmata (In the Blink of an Eye), 1981. He won the Gawad Urian for Best Supporting Actor for Kisapmata and Best Actor for Sister Stella L., 1984. The Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences gave him the Best Supporting Actor award for Maging Akin Ka Lamang (Anything to Have You), 1987. He was nominated for acting awards in the Gawad Urian for Salawahan, 1979; Aguila, 1980; Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (Will Your Heart Beat Faster?) 1980; and Pio de Castro III’s Soltero (Bachelor), 1984. He was twice-nominated Best Supporting Actor by the Film Academy of the Philippines for Mga Batang Yagit (Pauper Children), 1984, and Nagsimula sa Puso (Obsession), 1990. He died of a fractured skull from a motorcycle accident at the age of 37. Written by Lena S. Pareja
(See MUSIC volume.)

INFANTE, J. EDDIE ( Jesus Eduardo Ferriol Infante ) b. Sampaloc 25 Dec 1917. Movie actor, director, writer. His parents are Maria Ferriol and Ramoncito Infante, a Spaniard. An only child, he was raised in Dagupan, Pangasinan, by his Mama Monang and Papa Emong after his parents died. He married Margarita Alzona, a retired nurse. He studied at Dagupan Elementary School and finished high school at Dagupan Institute. Infante was actively involved in several professional associations like the Filipino Academy of Movie ArtsandSciences, Movie and Television Review and Classification Board, Film Academy Classification Board, Kapisanan ng mga Direktor ng Pelikulang Pilipino, Screenwriters Guild of the Philippines, Writers Union of the Philippines, and International Poets, Essayists, and Novelists. He was the first Filipino to be admitted to the Screen Actors Guild of America in 1956.

In 1935, LouSalvador Sr gave him his break in bodabil. In 1937, Enrique H. Davila paired him with the “Queen of Jazz,” KatydelaCruz. Some of his notable films are Ama’t Anak (Father and Child), 1939; Tagumpay (Victory) and Angelus, 1946; The End of the World, 1947; Hen. Gregorio del Pilar (General Gregorio del Pilar), 1949; Hantik (Black Ant), 1950; De Colores (In Colors), 1968; Samson and Delilah and Death by Installment, 1972; Gisingin Mo ang Umaga (Wake Up the Morning), 1974; Haplos (Caress), 1982; and SisterStellaL. and Panday IV (Blacksmith IV), 1984. He was also active in Hollywood films shot on location in the Philippines like Fritz Lang’s An American Guerilla in the Philippines, 1950. He appeared as a Filipino military general in No Place to Hide, 1955; a priest and friend of John Agar in The Day of the Trumpet, 1958; Jeffrey Hunter’s soldier-buddy in No Man Is an Island, 1962; and George Montgomery’s doctor-friend in War Kill, 1968.

Among the films he scripted and directed are Maestro Pajarillo (Master Pajarillo), 1947; Tatlong Kabanata sa Buhay Ko (Three Chapters in My Life), 1952; Nenita Unit, 1954; Elephant Girl, 1955; Umasa Ka, Mahal Ko (Have Faith, My Love), 1960; and Father Jess, 1967. His last films as an actor include Madonna, Babaeng Ahas (Madonna the Snake Woman), Kidlat ng Maynila: Joe Pring 2 (Lightning of Manila: Joe Pring 2), and Ang Totoong Buhay ni Pacita M. (The Real Life of Pacita M.), 1991; Zaldong Tisoy (Zaldo the Mestizo) and Divine Mercy sa Buhay ni Sister Faustina (Divine Mercy in the Life of Sister Faustina), 1993; The Untold Story: Vizconde Massacre II; May the Lord Be with Us! and Mistah, 1994; and Pare Ko (Hey Dude), 1995.

In 1949, he started as a writer at the Philippines Herald. Some of Infante’s books are The Marshall Entries, 1969; The Final Curtain, 1972; Oh Philippines, My Philippines and Other Stories, 1976; Chase the Naked Sun, 1977; All the Stars in the Sky, 1978; Apparatik, 1982; Affairs, 1984; Stories and Poems, 1991; and Inside Philippine Movies, 1970-1990, 1991.

Infante received the Gawad ng Karangalan of the Screenwriters Guild of the Philippines in 1983, the Best Supporting Actor award for Ang Supremo (The Supreme Chief), 1988, from the FilmAcademyofthe Philippines (FAP), and a Lifetime Achievement Award from the FAP in 1992. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

ISLETA, LORETO ( Loreto Urrea Isleta ) aka Ka Islet. b. Rizal, Laguna 10 Dec 1930. Cinematographer. His parents are Maria Urrea and Juan Isleta, a farmer. He attended Rizal Elementary School and finished high school at Laguna College. He enrolled at Malayan College but did not go beyond the first year. He married Emiliana Olina with whom he has seven children.

Loreto learned the rudiments of film editing from Fred Buensuceso at LVN, and laboratory processing from BillySmith. He also learned shooting newsreels, documentaries, and commercials in 16mm and 35mm at Fame Inc. In 1964 his break came as cinematographer of Magno Films’ Pulis Walang Kaparis (Exceptional Cop).

Among his films are Igorota (Mountain Maiden), 1968; Ang Pulubi (The Beggar), 1970; Now and Lumuha Pati mga Anghel (Even the Angels Wept), 1971; Dito sa Aking Puso (Here in My Heart), Villa Miranda, and Ang Gangster at ang Birhen (The Gangster and the Virgin), 1972; Bakit May Pag-ibig Pa? (Wherefore Love?), 1973; Kung Bakit Dugo ang Kulay ng Gabi (Why Blood Is the Color of Night) and Daigdig ng Sindak at Lagim (World of Fright and Terror), 1974; The Pacific Connection and Sa Pagitan ng Dalawang Langit (Between Two Heavens), 1975; Walang Karanasan (Inexperienced) and Fiesta: Isang Halik! Isang Sayaw! Isang Peseta! (Fiesta: A Kiss! A Dance! A Centavo!), 1976; Kapangyarihan ni Eva (Eve’s Power) and Maligno (Evil Spirit), 1977; Halik sa Paa, Halik sa Kamay (A Kiss on the Foot, A Kiss on the Hand), 1979; Unang Yakap (First Embrace) and Salamat … Kapatid Ko! (Thank You … My Sibling!), 1980; Flor de Liza and Uhaw na Dagat (Thirsty Sea), 1981; Hindi Kita Malimot (I Can’t Forget You) and Cross My Heart, 1982; Friends in Love, 1983; Bulaklak ng Apoy (Flower of Fire), 1984; Markang Rehas (Mark of the Prison Bars), 1985; Mapaglaro (Playful), 1986; Petrang Kabayo 2: Anong Ganda Mo! Mukha Kang Kabayo (Petra the Horse 2: What a Beauty! Horse Face), 1990; and Kapag Iginuhit ang Hatol ng Puso (When the Heart’s Judgement Is Fated), 1993.

Isleta won the Manila Film Festival award for Best Cinematography for The Hunted in 1969 and for Cadena de Amor (Chain of Love) in 1971; and the FilipinoAcademyofMovieArtsandSciences award for cinematography for Igorota in 1969, Nympha (Nymph) in 1972, and Tag-araw, Tag-ulan (Summer Days, Rainy Days) in 1994. From the Young Critics Circle, he and Raymond Bajarias also won Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design for Tag-araw, Tag-ulan. Written byRosalie Matilac and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

JACINTO, EDUARDO ( Eduardo Fernandez Jacinto ) aka Totoy Jacinto. b. San Juan, Metro Manila 28 Dec 1942. Cinematographer. His parents are Quirino Jacinto, an electrician at SampaguitaPictures, and Dolores Fernandez. He is married to Perlita Gomez with whom he has six children. He graduated from V. Mapa High School, then worked as a crew member at Sampaguita Pictures in 1964.

After a year as a crew member, Jacinto became a camera clapper and lifter, and in another two years, he became assistant cameraman. In 1970, he got his first assignment as cameraman for a movie directed by Tony Cayado. He worked as cinematographer for Sampaguita Pictures until 1973, freelanced from 1974 to 1979, then joined Agrix Films in 1979. In 1981 he moved to Regalfilms, staying there for the next 10 years, followed by a stint at VivaFilms. He also worked for various production companies.

Jacinto’s later films include Sugatang Puso (Wounded Heart), 2001; Bakat (Conspicuous) and 9 Mornings, 2002; and Then and Now, 2003. His works on television include Vietnam Rose, 2005, and nine episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2003-9.

Jacinto won several awards for cinematography: the Gawad Urian and the Star Awards for Pahiram ng Isang Umaga (Lend Me One Morning), 1987, shared with co-cinematographers Nonong Rasca and Manolo Abaya; the Film Academy of the Philippines award for Tiyanak (Changeling), 1988, Isang Araw Walang Diyos (One Day without God), 1989, and Apoy sa Puso (Fire in the Heart), 1992; another Gawad Urian for Milagros, 1997, which also won for him the Young Critics Circle award for Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design; and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for his work in Mumbaki (Shaman), 1996, and Bagong Buwan (New Moon), 2001. Written byRaquel Hernandez, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

JARLEGO, EFREN ( Efren Maningas Jarlego ) aka Loging Jarlego. b. Manila 24 Sep 1950. Movie editor, director. His father is EnriqueJarlegoSr, film editor and director, whose marriage to Juliana Maningas, produced several sons—George, Ike, Edgardo, Emmanuel, and Edmundo—who became award-winning film editors. He is married to Erlinda Elazegui with whom he has four children. He finished his elementary and secondary schooling at the University of the East.

Jarlego edited such films as Kastilyong Buhangin (Sand Castle) and Kasal? (Marriage?), 1980; Salome and PX, 1981; Cain at Abel (Cain and Abel), 1982; Hot Property and Init sa Magdamag (Midnight Passion), 1983; Bulaklak sa City Jail (Flowers of the City Jail), 1984; Bagong Hari (New King) and Halimaw (Monster), 1986. His later films include Ipagpatawad Mo, 1991; Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 1992; Maalaala Mo Kaya: The Movie (Will You Remember: The Movie), 1995; American Adobo, 2001; Santa Santita (Magdalena), 2004; I Love You, Goodbye, 2009; Sa ’Yo Lamang (Only Yours), 2010; and Maskara (Mask), 2011. He also directed films, mostly comedies, like Twist: Ako si Ikaw, Ikaw si Ako (Twist: I Am You, You Are Me) and Crocodile Jones: The Son of Indiana Dundee, 1990; Home along da Riles 2 (Home along the Railroad 2), 1997; Haba-baba-doo, Puti-puti-poo, 1998; and Tik Tak Toys: My Kolokotoys, 1999.

Jarlego received Best Editing awards from Gawad Urian for Salome in 1982; Bagong Hari in 1987; and Kapag Langit ang Humatol (Heaven’s Judgment) in 1991. He won Best Editing awards in the Metro Manila Film Festival for his work in the “Banga” episode of Halimaw, 1986, and I Love You Goodbye, 2009, which he shared with Manet Dayrit. He also received Best Editing awards for Ipagpatawad Mo (Forgive Me) from the Film Academy of the Philippines in 1992 and for Maalaala Mo Kaya: The Movie (Will You Remember: The Movie) from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences in 1995. Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

JARLEGO, ENRIQUE SR ( Enrique del Rosario Jarlego ) aka Ka Iking. b. San Leonardo, Nueva Ecija 12 Dec 1918. d. Toronto, Canada 3 Feb 2015. Movie editor, director. His parents are Teodora del Rosario and Doroteo Jarlego, a farmer. He finished grade school at San Anton Elementary School in San Leonardo, Nueva Ecija, but did not proceed to high school. His marriage to Juliana Maningas produced 13 children, six of whom also became film editors: Enrique Jr aka Ike, Efren aka Loging, Edgardo aka Totoy, Ernesto aka George, Emmanuel aka Itok, and Edmundo aka Bot. His nephews Teofilo (and son Renato de Leon), Armando, and Eduardo Jarlego are all editors. The two elder Jarlego sons, Ike and Efren, also directed movies.

Jarlego started as a laboratory man at ParlatoneHispano-Filipino and apprenticed as film editor. He soon became a full-fledged film editor. His first movie is Tenyente Rosario (Lieutenant Rosario), 1937, directed by OctavioSilos. Among the prewar films he edited are Sawing Gantimpala (Lost Victory), 1940, and IbongAdarna (Adarna Bird), 1941.

Notable among the films he edited after the war are Garrison 13, 1946; Romansa (Romance), 1947; Pista sa Nayon (Barrio Fiesta) and Kaaway ng Babae (Woman’s Enemy), 1948; Parola (Lighthouse), 1949; and Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), 1950.

In 1951, Doña Sisang of LVN promoted him to movie director with the film Talisman, which was followed by Bathaluman (Goddess), 1952; Ganyan Lang ang Buhay (That’s the Way Life Goes), 1953; and Dambanang Putik (Shrine of Mud), 1954. But it was in film editing that Jarlego excelled. He continued to edit films like LuksangTagumpay (Dark Victory), 1956; Venganza (Revenge) and Rebelde (Rebel), 1958; Biyaya ng Lupa (Blessings of the Land), 1959; and A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965. His later films include Ikaw at ang Gabi (You and the Night), 1979; Langis at Tubig (Oil and Water), 1980; Dear Heart, 1981; and Nang Masugatan ang Gabi (When the Night Was Wounded), 1984.

He received the FilipinoAcademyofMovieArtsandSciences Best Editing award twice: for HigitsaLahat (Above All), 1955, and Nagalit ang Buwan sa Haba ng Gabi (The Moon Got Angry at the Long, Long Night), 1983. The FilmAcademyofthePhilippines honored him in 1988 with the Lifetime Achievement Award for his contributions to Philippine cinema. Written by Rosalie Matilac and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

JARLEGO, GEORGE (Ernesto Maningas Jarlego) b. Manila 20 Oct 1954. Movie editor. He is one of the Jarlego brothers in the movie industry—Ike, Efren, Edgardo, Emmanuel, Edmundo—whose parents are film editor EnriqueJarlegoSr and Juliana Maningas. His elementary years were spent at Ponciano Bernardo Elementary School and his high school at the University of the East. He studied aeronautical engineering at PATS School of Aeronautics.

The films he edited include Haplos (Caress), 1982; Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim (My Country: Gripping the Knife’s Edge), 1984; Till We Meet Again, White Slavery, and Hindi Nahahati ang Langit (An Indivisible Heaven), 1985; Orapronobis (Fight for Us) and Bilanginang BituinsaLangit (Count the Stars in the Sky), 1989; Biktima (Victim), 1990; Huwag Mong Salingin ang Sugat Ko (Touch Not My Wound), Sa Kabila ng Lahat (Despite Everything) and My Other Woman, 1991; Sinungaling Mong Puso (Your Lying Heart), 1992; May Minamahal (Loving Someone), 1993; The Secrets of Sarah Jane: Sana’y Mapatawad Mo (May You Be Able to Forgive), 1994; Sana Maulit Muli (Second Chances); Sa Ngalan ng Pag-ibig (In the Name of Love) and Pare Ko (Hey Dude), 1995; and Sisa, 1999. His later work as editor includes Anak (The Child) and Markova: Comfort Gay, 2000; Gatas … Sa Dibdib ng Kaaway (In the Bosom of the Enemy), 2001; Homecoming and Lupe: A Seaman’s Wife, 2003; The Mourning Girls, 2006; Otso (Eight), 2013; and Trophy Wife and Esoterika: Maynila (Esoterica: Manila), 2014.

Jarlego received Best Editing awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Ibulong Mo sa Diyos (Whisper to God), 1988, Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000, and Mga Munting Tinig (Small Voices), 2002; from the Young Critics Circle for Gumapang Ka sa Lusak (Dirty Affair), 1990; from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Ang Totoong Buhay ni Pacita M. (The Real Life of Pacita M.), 1991; and from the Gawad Urian for The Fatima Buen Story, 1994. Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

(Enrique Maningas Jarlego Jr) b. Manila 3 May 1944. d. Manila 24 Aug 2012. Movie editor, director. His parents are Juliana Maningas and EnriqueJarlegoSr. He comes from a family of film editors: both his parents, his five brothers—Efren, Edgardo, George, Emmanuel, and Edmundo—and uncle, TeofilodeLeon, are all professional editors. Efren is also a movie director. Jarlego attended the University of the Philippines Elementary and High School, and finished his secondary education at Far Eastern University. He took up commerce at the University of the East but did not proceed beyond his junior year.

Jarlego started out as a child actor at age seven in the movie Pag-asa (Hope), 1951. He was playing at the LVN compound while a film was being shot by director LambertoAvellana. Avellana made him run toward the gate, shouting “Shoe shine!” That was his first film. His other films as child actor include Probinsiyano (Country Boy), 1951; Harana sa Karagatan (Serenade on the Seas), 1952; Kuwentong Bahay-Bahayan (Playing House Stories) and Batangueña (Batangas Girl), 1953; Waray-Waray (Visayan Lass), 1954, where he was paired with another child star, Nora Dy; Sonny Boy, No Place to Hide, and Higitsa Lahat (Above All), 1955.

As film editor, he worked for Manito de Leon at Image Films from 1969 to 1974. When Manito’s brother, MikedeLeon, returned from his studies in USA and Germany to form his own company, Jarlego quit Image Films to join the new firm, Cinema Artists. He also freelanced for other movie producers. Among the films he edited are Babae, Ngayon at Kailanman (Woman, Now and Forever), Mga Bilanggong Birhen (Caged Virgins), Ang Isinilang Ko Ba’y Kasalanan (Did I Give Birth to Sin?), and Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (If You Dream and Wake Up), 1977; Boy Pana (Bow and Arrow Kid), 1978; Sino’ng Pipigil sa Pagpatak ng Ulan? (Who Will Stop the Rain from Falling?), 1979; Pepeng Shotgun, 1981; Sinasamba Kita (I Worship You), 1982; Working Girls, Alyas Baby Tsina (Alias Baby Tsina), Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim (My Country: Gripping the Knife’s Edge), and Nang Masugatan ang Gabi (When the Night Is Wounded), 1984; Boy Negro (Negro Boy), 1988; Andres Manambit: Angkan ng Matatapang (Andres Manambit: Clan of the Brave), 1992; Forever, 1994; and Abakada … Ina (ABC … Mother), 2001.

Jarlego directed about a dozen films, including Andres Manambit: Angkan ng Matatapang; the remake of Wanted: Perfect Mother, 1996; and Bridesmaids, 1997.

He won several awards for Best Editing: from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Maynila: Sa mgaKukongLiwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light) in 1976, Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (Will Your Heart Beat Faster?) in 1981, and Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan? (How Often Is Once?) in 1983; from Gawad Urian for Itim (Rites of May) in 1977 and KakabakabaKaBa? in 1981; from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Himala (Miracle) in 1982 and Andres Manambit: Angkan ng Matatapang in 1992; from the Film Academy of the Philippines for Nasaan Ka nang Kailangang Kita? (Where Were You When I Needed You?) in 1987, Rosenda in 1990, Forever in 1995, and Abakada … Ina in 2002; and from the Young Critics Circle for Kailan Ka Magiging Akin? (When Will You Be Mine?) in 1992 and Nena in 1996. Written by Rosalie Matilac and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

JETURIAN, JEFFREY (Jeffrey Reyes Jeturian) b. Manila 1959. Film and television director, writer, producer. His parents are Rolando Jeturian and Cristina Reyes. He studied broadcast communication at the University of the Philippines.

Jeturian started as a production assistant and got involved in several projects as script continuity supervisor, art director, production designer, and assistant director, working with the likes of Marilou Diaz-Abaya, Chito Roño, and Maryo J. de los Reyes.

Nida Blanca, Angel Aquino, and Gerald Madrid star in his first film Sana Pag-ibig Na (Enter Love), 1998, one of the pito-pito (seven-seven) movies produced by Regal Films. “Pito-pito” are movies made on shoestring budgets, shot in around seven days with another seven days for postproduction; hence the name. His next film Pila Balde (Fetch a Pail of Water), 1999, was produced similarly. Starring Ana Capri and Marcus Madrigal, it is set in a poor housing community in Quezon City, with its characters struggling to live and love. Tuhog (Larger Than Life), 2001, also tackles poverty, but this time focusing on exploitation in art and in real life. He directed two films in 2004: the sex-comedy Bridal Shower and the indie drama Minsan Pa (One Moment More). The commercial success of Bridal Shower led to another film of the same nature, Bikini Open, 2005. Considered a turning point in his career and one of the key films in the resurgence of Filipino independent cinema in the 2000s is Kubrador (The Bet Collector), 2006, starring Gina Pareño. Despite his busy schedule doing TV series, he was able to do two more films after Kubrador—namely, Bisperas (Intruders), 2011, and Ekstra (The Bit Player), 2013, both of which were entries in the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival.

Jeturian’s TV credits as director include The Wedding, 2009; Rosalka and Juanita Banana, 2010; Reputasyon (Reputation), 2011; Mundo Man Ay Magunaw (Even If the World Ends) and Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14; Dream Dad and Ningning, 2015, in addition to numerous episodes of ABS-CBN’s drama series Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember).

Jeturian’s numerous awards include the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) Special Mention Award at the Cinemanila International Film Festival and the Gold Award at WorldFest Houston International Film Festival for Pila Balde; Best Director at the Golden Screen Awards and Best Film from the Young Critics Circle for Minsan Pa; Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) Award at Brisbane International Film Festival, Asian and Arab Competition Award and International Federation of Film Critics Prize (FIPRESCI) Prize at the Cinefan Festival of Asian and Arab Cinema, Lino Brocka Award at the Cinemanila International Film Festival, Best Director at the Gawad Urian and the Golden Screen Awards, and FIPRESCI Prize at Moscow International Film Festival for Kubrador; Best Director at Cinemalaya and Asian Film Award at Tokyo International Film Festival for Bisperas; and Special Jury Prize and NETPAC Award at Cinemalaya for Ekstra. Two of his films, Tuhog and Kubrador, were selected by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino as two of the best films of the decade 2000-2009. Written by Richard Bolisay, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

JOCSON, MAX (Maximo Vasquez Jocson) b. Naic, Cavite 2 Jan 1945. Music director. His parents, Josefina Vasquez and Moises Jocson, were rice-mill owners in their town. His father taught piano privately while running the family business. The eldest son in the family, Domingo, finished music, major in piano, at the University of the Philippines College of Music. Jocson wanted to pursue music as a profession, but his father dissuaded him because his elder brother was already in that field. In deference to his father’s wishes, he took up civil engineering at the University of Santo Tomas, but shifted to classical guitar, church choir music, conducting, and photography in his fifth year.

Jocson’s interest in photography led him to the LVN studio where he worked as a color timer in the laboratory. Exposed to the world of filmmaking, he attended seminars and training programs in editing and directing. During free periods on the job, he tinkered with the piano at LVN and this was how he was “discovered” by friends. Finally, he was introduced to MikedeLeon, who was then looking for people to work for him. He joined the team of IkeJarlegoJr, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, and Mike de Leon in Maynila: SamgaKukongLiwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975, as a music director.

Consequently, Jocson worked on the music score of more films by Lino Brocka, like Jaguar (Guard), 1979; Bona, 1980; Kontrobersyal (Controversial) and Caught in the Act, 1981; and Cain at Abel (Cain and Abel), 1982. His other films include Carnival Queen and Playgirl, also in 1981; Anak (Offspring), 1982; BrokenMarriage, 1983; Sinner or Saint and Hotshots, 1984; Babaeng Hampaslupa (Downtrodden Woman) and Lord, Bakit Ako Pa? (Lord, Why Me?), 1988; Lucia, a BBC-produced drama starring LolitaRodriguez and directed by Mel Chionglo; Dreaming Filipinos, 1991; and Suwapings, 1994. Jocson won the Gawad Urian Best Musical Score trophy for Mike de Leon’s Itim (Rites of May), 1976. Written by Rosalie Matilac, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

JOSE, JACLYN(Mary Jane Santa Ana Guck) b. San Juan, Manila 21 Oct 1963. Movie and television actor. Her parents are Edward Larry Guck, a United States Air Force officer, and Rosalinda Santa Ana, a singer. She studied at Santo Rosario Elementary School in Angeles City; Perpetual College in Rizal, Karilagan; and the Philippine School of Interior Design. Her elder sister is actor Veronica Jones.

Jose’s first appearances were in sex-oriented films like White Slavery, 1985, Flesh Avenue, 1986, and Private Show, 1986, so she was identified as a “bold” star during her early years in the movies. She veered away from that mold and became known as a serious actor. Some of her notable films include Mulanay: Sa Pusod ng Paraiso (Mulanay: In the Navel of Paradise), 1996; Mula sa Puso: The Movie (From the Heart), 1999; Tuhog (Larger Than Life), 2001; and Minsan May Isang Puso (Once There Was a Heart), 2001, for which she received nominations from various award-giving bodies.

Jose also appeared in stage plays, such as Pitik-Bulag sa Buwan ng Pebrero (Guessing Game in the Month of February), 1989, and Salome, 1993. She is also known for her work in television, such as in ABS-CBN’s Prinsesa ng Banyera (Fishbucket Princess), 2007-8, Sabel, 2010-11, Kahit Puso’y Masugatan (Hearts on Fire), 2012-14; GMA Network’s Zorro, 2009, Ilustrado (Educated Native), 2014, More Than Words, 2014-15; and TV5’s Valiente, 2012.

Early in her career, she won Best Actress awards for Takaw Tukso (Flirting with Temptation), 1986, in the Gawad Urian; for Private Show, 1986, in the Star Awards; and for Itanong Mo sa Buwan (Ask the Moon), 1988, in the Gawad Urian and the Star Awards. She received Best Supporting Actress awards for Celestina Sanchez, Alyas Bubbles, 1988, from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF); for Macho Dancer, 1989, from the Gawad Urian and the Star Awards; for The Flor Contemplacion Story, 1995, from the Gawad Urian, Star Awards, and Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP); and for Naglalayag (Silent Passage), 2004, from the Manila Film Festival and the FAP. Her role as a prostitute hired by a teenage client in Sarong Banggi (One Night), 2006, won her a Gawad Urian for Best Actress. In 2013, her role in A Secret Affair, 2012, won her a Best Supporting Actress award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS). In 2016, Jose won the Palme d’Or for Best Actress at the 69th Cannes Film Festival in France for Brillante Mendoza’s Ma’ Rosa, making her the first actor from Southeast Asia to bag the highly coveted award. Written byCristine Directo, updated by Erika Carreon, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

JUEZAN, DOMINGO aka Dodong Juezan, Undo Juezan. b. Cebu 18 Mar 1946. Stage, radio, and movie actor. His father, Leon Juezan, was a stage actor, playwright, and producer-director of Cebuano movies. His mother Nieves Diao was also a stage actor. He studied at Cebu City Central School.

At age four, Juezan appeared in Dimakaling, 1950. With the Antingan drama troupe of the Juezan Brothers, he toured the Visayas and Mindanao. He played various roles in the plays Mga Anak Intawon (Pitiful Children) and Katapusang Awit (Last Song), both written by his father; and in Ikaw na Masayud Kanino (You Know Yourself) and Duhay Ilang Inahan (They Have Two Mothers) by Natalio Bacalso.

Juezan was selected Best Child Actor by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for his performance in Salingsing sa Kasakit (New Branch of Sorrow), 1955. Earlier, he appeared in his first movie, Sumatra, directed by his father and starring an uncle, Tancred. His other films were Humonhon, 1956, also directed by his father; and Ug Unya Nalinaw (And Then Peace Came), 1957, with Gloria Sevilla and Mat Ranillo. Written by Erlinda K. Alburo

KEESEE, OSCAR(Oscar Keesee Jr) b. Manila ca 1915. d. 1969. Movie actor. He made his mark in the movie world as a character actor of Premiere Productions and LVN. He usually portrayed the bad guy, such as the father who lusted after his own son’s sweetheart in Ang Lumang Bahay sa Gulod (The Old House on the Cliff), 1949. Among his early movies are Doble Cara (Two Faces), 1950; Santa Cristina, Labis na Pagtitipid (Stinginess), 1951; Bathaluman (Goddess), Rodrigo de Villa, and Aklat ng Buhay (Book of Life), 1952; Banga ni Zimadar (Zimadar’s Jar), 1953; Lapu-Lapu, Karnabal (Carnival Fair), Higit sa Lahat (Above All), and No Place to Hide, 1955; Handang Matodas (Ready to Die), Anak Dalita (The Ruins), Luksang Tagumpay (Dark Victory), and Gintong Pangarap (Golden Dream), 1956; Walang Sugat (No Wounds), Hukom Roldan (Judge Roldan), and Badjao, 1957; Kundiman ng Lahi (Love Song of the Race) and Aawitan Kita (I Shall Sing for You), 1959. Another role frequently assigned to him was that of a Spanish officer during colonial times, which he played in Dugo ng Katipunan (Blood of the Katipunan), 1949, and Diego Silang, 1951. He also played an important role in Kamay ni Satanas (Hand of Satan), 1950, which won the first Maria Clara Award as Best Picture of the year. He reached his peak as a character actor in the 1960s when he made Gerardo de Leon’s Ako ang Katarungan (I Am Justice), 1962; Lagablab sa Maribojoc (Flames over Maribojoc), 1964; and Ang Daigdig ng mga Api (The World of the Oppressed), 1965.

Keesee won Best Supporting Actor twice from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), for his role of the grandfather of a kidnapped victim in Huwag Mo Akong Limutin (Never Forget Me), 1960, and for his portrayal of Padre Damaso in the movie based on Rizal’s novel, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1961. He was nominated by the FAMAS for May Isang Tsuper ng Taksi (There Was a Taxi Driver), 1953; Higit sa Lahat, 1955; and Albano Brothers, 1962. Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja

KIDLAT TAHIMIK(Eric Oteyza de Guia) b. Baguio City 3 Oct 1942. Actor, filmmaker, installation and performance artist. His parents are Victor de Guia, a civil engineer, and Virginia Oteyza, a former movie actor and mayor of Baguio City. He is married to Katrin Mueller, a German stained glass artist. They have three boys: Kidlat, Kawayan, and Kabunyan. He studied at Maryknoll Convent School; St. Louis Boys High School; University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman; and Wharton School of Finance, University of Pennsylvania. He worked in Paris as an economist in the late 1960s, but tore up his master of business administration diploma in 1972 to become an artist. Kidlat is also an installation and performance artist, who did shows at the Pinaglabanan Art Gallery and the Baguio Arts Festival, as well as in Japan and the USA. He is one of the founding members of the Baguio Arts Guild.

Kidlat was first acclaimed for the noncommercial Mababangong Bangungot (Perfumed Nightmare), 1977, a film about cultural imperialism, which won three prizes: the International Federation of Film Critics Prize in the 1977 Berlin Film Festival, the Folk Prize in Rotterdam Film Festival, and the Blue Ribbon Prize in New York. The movie was shown in film festivals in Cuba and Belgrade and distributed in the United States by Francis Ford Coppola. Turumba, 1983, a film about the clash between the old and new worlds, won the Red Ribbon Prize in the American Film Festival as well as the top cash awards in the 1985 Mannheim Film Festival in Germany.

His other films include Sinong Lumikha ng Yoyo? Sinong Lumikha ng Moon Buggy? (Who Invented the Yo-yo? Who Invented the Moon Buggy?), 1981; Yan-ki: Made in Hongkong, 1980, about a woman worker in Hong Kong; I Am Furious (Yellow), 1986, a collage of events leading to the 1986 EDSA Revolt; and its sequel, I Am Curious (Pink), 1989. These last two became chapters in a longer opus, Bakit Dilaw ang Gitna ng Bahaghari? (Why Is Yellow the Middle of the Rainbow?), 1993, which created in international festivals a new genre called “never-ending docu.” He also acted in the following films: Jeder für Sich und Gott Gegen Alle (The Enigma of Kaspar Hauser), 1974, directed by German filmmaker and Kidlat Tahimik’s mentor Werner Herzog; Jose Rizal, 1998; and Abong: Small Home, 2003.

Kidlat Tahimik’s other films include Celebrating the Year 2021, Today, 1995; Dalawang Atang at Isang Pasalubong (Our Film-grimage to Guimaras), 2005; and Bubong! (Roofs of the World! Unite!), 2006.

A work in progress since 1980 is Memories of Overdevelopment (Ang Balikbayan), about a Filipino slave of Ferdinand Magellan named Enrique (played by the director himself) who becomes the first person to circumnavigate our planet. After a 25-year hiatus, Kidlat Tahimik revisited the alternative history project and included it in a larger metanarrative, Balikbayan # 1 Memories of Overdevelopment Redux III, 2015. The film also stars other members of Kidlat Tahimik’s family. The film premiered at the 65th Berlin International Film Festival and won the Caligari Prize.

Kidlat Tahimik was the recipient of the Lifetime Achievement Award in the 2008 Gawad Urian. In 2009, he was given the Gawad Plaridel of the UP College of Mass Communication. He was given the Gawad Balanghai Lifetime Achievement Award in the 10th Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival in 2014, which he returned in 2015 as a form of protest against the decision of the festival organizers to remove the New Breed category of the festival, and as criticism of the direction toward which the film festival was heading as a result of this decision. Written by Rene de Guzman, updated by Erika Carreon

KORONEL, HILDA (Susan Higum Reid) b. Plaridel, Angeles City 17 Jan 1957. Movie, stage, and television actor. She was one of two children of Marina Higum and David Reid. She married actor Jay Ilagan with whom she has one daughter, Leona Paula. She grew up in Leveriza, Pasay City, and finished her elementary and high school at Manuel L. Quezon University. She finished a bachelor of arts degree in international studies at Maryknoll College.

Even at a young age, she was already winning beauty titles, Miss Community Chest of Pasay City at age seven and twice as Miss Night Owl of Channel 11 at age 11. She was an extra in the Nida-Nestor Show and the Rosemarie-Pepito Show. Her first movie, Leslie, 1969, with Boots Anson-Roa and Liza Lorena, served as her screen test with Lea Productions, which gave her a five-year contract. Director Lino Brocka noticed her great potential as an actor and cast her at age 13 as a blind and deaf-mute girl in Santiago, 1970, over the objections of studio managers. She became a full-fledged star in the same year in Haydee, 1970. To improve her poise and grace, her company sent her to a finishing school. She was in great demand as a magazine cover girl, commercial model for beauty products, and fashion model.

For Lea Productions, she made Now, 1971; Crush Ko si Sir (I Have a Crush on Sir), 1971; Ang Gangster at ang Birhen (The Gangster and the Virgin), 1972; Cherry Blossoms, 1972; and Villa Miranda, 1972. After her contract with Lea expired, she made films with other companies: Ibigay Mo sa Akin ang Langit (Give Me Heaven), 1975, with Christopher de Leon for Andyrose Productions; Hello, Goodnight, Goodbye, 1975, for Mever; Sakada, 1976, directed by Behn Cervantes for Sagisag Films; and Hayop sa Hayop (Beast to Beast), 1978. She stopped making movies for a while but returned to make Sana, Bukas Pa ang Kahapon (If Only Yesterday Were Tomorrow), 1983, for Viva Films. She also acted in such plays as Nick Joaquin’s Mga Ama, Mga Anak (Fathers and Sons), 1979, and Maxim Gorky’s Kaaway, 1982, translated by Bienvenido Lumbera and directed by Behn Cervantes.

Brocka honed her acting talents in the weekly TV show Hilda, which ran for almost five years on KBS-Channel 9 and won her the Best Continuing Performance by an Actress award in the 1971 Citizens’ Awards for Television. Koronel also appeared in several teleseryes (TV drama series), such as in ABS-CBN’s Esperanza, 1997-99, and Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin (You Are Everything to Me), 2005, and in GMA Network’s Kung Mawawala Ka (A World without You), 2002-3.

She won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Supporting Actress award for Santiago, 1970. One of her most memorable roles was that of a slum-dweller in Insiang, 1976, which won for her the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) Best Actress award and nominations from the Gawad Urian and FAMAS. She had earlier portrayed the role on television at the age of 14. Other movies for which she received nominations for acting awards are Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (When You Dream and Wake Up), 1977, Gawad Urian; Babangon Ako’t Dudurugin Kita (I Will Rise and Crush You), 1989, Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) and FAMAS; PX, 1982, FAMAS; Crying Ladies, 2003, FAMAS and Gawad Urian; and Santa Santita (Magdalena), 2004, FAP. In 2001, she shared the Young Critics Circle Best Performance by an Ensemble award with the cast of Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000. In 2006, Koronel won both the Gawad Urian and the FAP Best Supporting Actress awards for her performance in Nasaan Ka Man (Wherever You Are), 2005, and in 2013 the FAP Best Supporting Actress award for The Mistress, 2012. Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Anne Frances Sangil

LACAP, RODY(Rodolfo Austria Lacap) b. San Juan, Metro Manila 29 Jan 1950. Cinematographer. He was born to Raymundo Lacap, one of LVN Pictures’ best cinematographers, and Generosa Austria. He attended Ponciano Bernardo Elementary School, Ramon Magsaysay High School, and Arellano University. He is married to Zenaida Redoble, His daughter is a cinematographer.

Lacap worked as color grader and optical printer operator in the LVN color film laboratory. He was then trained in stills photography at the LVN. Mike de Leon hired him to work in his short film Monologo (Monologue) as gaffer and lighting director. Later, he became the cinematographer of de Leon’s first film Itim (Rites of May), 1976, made in collaboration with another cinematographer, Ely Cruz, who was the camera operator. Lacap also did the cinematography of other de Leon films like Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (Will Your Heart Beat Faster?), 1980; Kisapmata (In the Blink of an Eye), 1981; Batch ’81, 1982; and Sister Stella L., 1984. He worked with other noted directors, such as Mel Chionglo in Playgirl, 1980; Laurice Guillen in Kung Ako’y Iiwan Mo (Should You Abandon Me), 1980; Eddie Romero in Aguila, 1980; Peque Gallaga in Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982; Ishmael Bernal in Hinugot sa Langit (Wrenched from Heaven), 1985; and Lino Brocka in Pasan Ko ang Daigdig (World on My Shoulders), 1987, Maging Akin Ka Lamang (Anything to Have You), 1987, and Orapronobis (Fight for Us), 1989. He also worked on films like Hotshots, 1984; Muling Buksan ang Puso (Open the Heart Once Again), 1985; Kumander Gringa (Commander Gringa), 1987; Smith and Wesson and Jack & Jill sa America (Jack and Jill in America), 1988; Kailan Mahuhugasan ang Kasalanan? (When Will Sin Be Washed Away?), 1989; Dyesebel, 1990; Lahar, 1996; the short film Kagat ng Dilim, 2006; and Paglipad ng Anghel (Flight of an Angel), 2011.

Lacap received several awards for TV commercials from the Ad Congress and Creative Guild. He won his first Best Cinematography award for Itim from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) and the Gawad Urian. In succeeding years, he received three more Gawad Urian trophies for Kisapmata, Oro, Plata, Mata, and Misteryo sa Tuwa (Joyful Mystery), 1984, and one from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) for Kung Ako’y Iiwan Mo. He also won three Best Cinematography awards for Jose Rizal, 1998: from the MMFF, the Gawad Urian, and the FAMAS. Lacap also received MMFF and FAMAS awards, shared with Manolo Abaya and Marissa Floirendo, for his work in Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 1999. In 2012, Lacap was awarded the Natatanging Gawad Urian by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Anne Frances Sangil

LACUESTA, AMADO JR (Amado Larroza Lacuesta Jr) b. Davao City 8 Mar 1947. d. Baguio City 1 Jan 1997. Movie and television scriptwriter. His parents are Amado Lacuesta Sr, a former government employee, and Gloria Larroza, a public school teacher. He was married to LolitaRodriguez, a scholar and professor. Lacuesta obtained his bachelor of arts degree in English from Ateneo de Davao and finished his master of business management in 1968 at the Ateneo Graduate School of Business.

From 1968 to 1974, Lacuesta worked for Bancom, a banking firm. He moved on to become partner and general manager in 1974 for Multinational Investment Bancorp (MIB). While working for the MIB, he joined a scriptwriting contest of the ExperimentalCinemaofthePhilippines, and became one of 10 finalists. Inspired by this, he wrote a script for VivaFilms, Makati Girls, which was retitled Working Girls, 1984, and directed by IshmaelBernal. The film was a box-office hit.

He wrote a number of scripts that were produced by Viva Films, including the comedy Puto (Rice Cake), 1982; Balweg: The Rebel Priest, 1987, a movie based on the life of a priest who became a leader of the New People’s Army; and Tag-araw, Tag-ulan (Summer Days, Rainy Days), 1992.

Lacuesta also wrote the scripts for Ishmael Bernal’s HinugotsaLangit (Wrenched From Heaven), 1985, and Celso Ad. Castillo’s Kailan Tama ang Mali? (When Is Wrong Right?), 1986. He co-wrote with RickyLee the scripts for Lino Brocka’s Macho Dancer, 1988, and Mel Chionglo’s Sibak (Midnight Dancers), 1994. His last works were the critically acclaimed Segurista (Dead Sure), co-written with JoseF.Lacaba and directed by Tikoy Aguiluz, and Mumbaki (Shaman), directed by Butch Perez. Both movies were produced by Neo Films and released in 1996.

Lacuesta won Best Screenplay for the “Pridyider” (Refrigerator) episode of Shake, Rattle & Roll in the 1984 Metro Manila Film Festival. He also won Best Screenplay for Balweg in the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) Awards. Macho Dancer won for him and Lee the Star Award for Best Screenplay. Segurista won the 1996 Gawad Urian for Best Original Screenplay. It was also exhibited in the 1996 Toronto International Film Festival and was the official Philippine entry in the 1996 Oscar Awards. In 1997, Lacuesta received for Mumbaki the Best Screenplay awards from the Young Critics Circle and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, and the Best Story Adaptation award from FAP.

Lacuesta wrote the lyrics of theme songs for various movies. He wrote the opening song to the 1991 ASEAN Games held in the Philippines, titled “We Are Tomorrow’s Children.” He also wrote the scripts for the TV series of the Cultural Center of the Philippines called Pinoy Eh!, directed by Marilou Diaz-Abaya. His one-act play Abril 1521 won third prize in the 1988 Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature. “The Little Girl Who Saved Her Yawns,” a short story for children that he co-wrote with Andrea Patricia Lacuesta, also won third prize in the 1989 Palanca Awards. Written by Raquel Hernandez, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

LAMANGAN, JOEL (Joel C. Lamangan) b. Cavite City, Cavite 21 Sep 1954. Film, television, and stage director, actor. He grew up with his grandparents, Francisco and Juanita. Joel had 15 half-brothers and half-sisters, all of whom went abroad to serve in the Unites States military. Lamangan attended the University of the Philippines. He was with the Philippine Educational Theater Association when he was imprisoned twice in 1973 and 1977 for joining rallies against martial law.

Lamangan’s directorial debut was Kalapating Musmos (Young Pigeon), 1985. It was followed by a prolific roster of memorable films such as Darna, 1991; Hiram na Mukha (Borrowed Face) and Ngayon at Kailanman (Now and Forever), 1992; Ikaw (You), 1993; Kadenang Bulaklak (Chain of Flowers), Anghel na Walang Langit (Angel without Heaven), Kapantay ay Langit (As High as Heaven), and Pangako ng Kahapon (Yesterday’s Promise), 1994; Silakbo (Outburst), The Flor Contemplacion Story, and Muling Umawit ang Puso (The Heart Sings Again), 1995; Bakit May Kahapon Pa? (Why Is There a Yesterday?), 1996; The Sarah Balabagan Story, 1997; Pusong Mamon (Soft Hearts), Sidhi (The Story of Ah), Warat: Bibigay Ka Ba? (Torn Apart: Are You Giving Up?), and Bulaklak ng Maynila (Flower of Manila), 1999; Deathrow and Abandonada (Abandoned Woman), 2000; Mila and Hubog (Wretched Lives), 2001; Mano Po (I Kiss Your Hand), 2002; Walang Kapalit (Nobody Else), Ang Huling Birhen sa Lupa (The Last Virgin), and Filipinas, 2003; I Will Survive, Sabel, Mano Po 3: My Love (I Kiss Your Hand 3: My Love), Aishite Imasu 1941 (I Love You) and So … Happy Together, 2004; Mano Po: Ako Legal Wife (I Kiss Your Hand: I Am the Legal Wife), 2005; Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Moveeh (Zsazsa Zaturnnah: The Movie), Pacquiao: The Movie, Manay Po! (I Am Gay!), Blue Moon, and Mano Po 5: Gua Ai Di (I Kiss Your Hand 5: I Love You), 2006; Happy Hearts, Silip (Peek), Bahay Kubo (Nipa Hut), and Desperadas (All They Need Is Love), 2007; Manay Po 2: Overloaded, Walang Kawala (No Escape), and Desperadas 2 (All They Need Is More Love), 2008; When I Met U, I Luv Dreamguyz, Heavenly Touch, and Mano Po 6: A Mother’s Love (I Kiss Your Hand 6: A Mother’s Love), 2009; Lihis (Slanted), 2013; Hustisya (Justice), 2014; and Felix Manalo, 2015.

Lamangan won the Best Film award from the Young Critics Circle in 1995 for Pangako ng Kahapon. He got five trophies from the Star Awards for Movies: Movie Director of the Year for The Flor Contamplacion Story in 1996, Bulaklak ng Maynila in 2000, and Blue Moon in 2007; Digital Movie Director of the Year for Sigwa (Rage) in 2011; and the Dekada Award for his directorial works representing 2003-13 in 2014. He received two Best Director awards from the Metro Manila Film Festival: for Muling Umawit ang Puso in 1995 and Mano Po 6: A Mother’s Love in 2009. In 2006, he received the Best Director award from the Golden Screen Awards for Blue Moon. He won Best Director at the Gawad Urian for The Flor Contemplacion Story in 1996. He got five Best Director awards from the Film Academy of the Philippines: for Pangako ng Kahapon in 1995, The Flor Contemplacion Story in 1996, Bulaklak ng Maynila in 2000, Aishite Imasu in 2005, and Blue Moon in 2006. He won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Director award for Dukot (Desaparecidos) in 2009 and Best Story for Sigwa in 2010. He has four awards from the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival: the Audience Award and the National Council for Children’s Television Award for Patikul in 2011, and the Audience Award and the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award for Hustisya in 2014. His film The Flor Contemplacion Story won the Golden Pyramid (Best Film) in the main competition of the 19th Cairo International Film Festival in 1995. In 2014, he won the Best Film award from Harlem International Film Festival for Kamkam (Greed), 2014. Written by Christian Co, with notes from Mario Mendez Jr and Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

LAMASAN, OLIVIA M. b. 17 Oct 1963. Film and TV director, screenwriter, and producer. Lamasan started as a production assistant in 1984, became a line producer for feature films and executive producer for television in 1987, a screenwriter for both film and television in 1991, a TV director in 1992, and a film director in 1994. In 2015, Lamasan is the senior vice president for creatives at ABS-CBN Film Productions Inc, and screenwriter and director at ABS-CBN Corp (TV) and ABS-CBN Film Productions.

Lamasan wrote and directed Madrasta (Stepmother), 1996; Hanggang Kailan Kita Mamahalin? (Until When Will I Love You?), 1997; and Minsan, Minahal Kita (Once, I Loved You), 2000. She co-wrote and directed Got2Believe, 2002; The Mistress, 2012; and Starting All Over Again, 2014.

Lamasan directed the following episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) on television: “Sa Kandungan Mo, Inay” (On Your Lap, Mother), 1993; “Talaarawan” (Diary), 1998; and “Otosan” (Father), 1999. She wrote scripts for the TV series Sa Sandaling Kailangan Mo Ako (The Moment You Need Me), 1998-2001.

Lamasan received the following awards: Best Story and Best Screenplay from the Star Awards for Movies, and Best Screenplay from the Gawad Urian for Ipagpatawad Mo (Forgive Me), 1991; Best Story and Best Picture from the Manila Film Festival and Best Movie of the Year from the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) for Maalaala Mo Kaya, The Movie, 1994; Best Original Screenplay from the Film Academy of the Philippines and the Gawad Urian for Sana Maulit Muli (Second Chances), 1995, for which she also won Best Picture at the Gawad Urian; Best Screenplay and Best Director at the 2005 Star Awards for Movies for Milan, 2004; Best Screenplay, Best Director, and Best Picture from the Star Awards for Movies for In My Life, 2009; Original Movie Screenplay of the Year from the Star Awards for Movies for In the Name of Love, 2011.

She also won the following awards for direction of various episodes of the Maalaala Mo Kaya drama anthology: Best Drama Anthology from the Star Awards for Television for “Lupa” (Land), 1994; Best Drama Anthology from the CMMA for Television and Star Awards for Television for “Abo” (Ash), 1996; Best TV Drama from Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon for “Pahiram ng Isang Pasko” (Lend Me One Christmas), 1997; Best Single Drama from the Asian TV Awards for “Aklat” (Book), 1998; Best TV Drama from the 15th KBP Golden Dove Award for “Regalo” (Gift). Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), which she co-directed and where she was creative head from 2000 to 2002, was adjudged Best TV Drama Series at the 15th Star Awards for Television. Written by Susan Claire Agbayani

LANA, JUN ROBLES (Rodolfo Robles Lana Jr) aka Jun Lana. b. Manila 10 Oct 1972. Playwright, screenwriter, and film director. He is the eldest son of Rodolfo Lana Sr and Ofelia Robles. He graduated from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) with a bachelor’s degree in communication arts.

Mentored in playwriting by Rene O. Villanueva, he became the resident playwright of Telon Playwrights Circle and the Philippine Educational Theater Association. He transitioned into writing screenplays, and his debut screenplay Sa Pusod ng Dagat (In the Navel of the Sea), 1998, was optioned and directed by another mentor, Marilou Diaz-Abaya, and had its world premiere at the Panorama section of Berlin International Film Festival.

He collaborated with Diaz-Abaya on three more critically acclaimed films: Jose Rizal, 1999, which was also screened at Berlin International Film Festival; Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 2000; and Bagong Buwan (New Moon), 2001. In 2007 he was hired by Regal Films to be one of its resident directors. For the next five years, he directed some of the studio’s mainstream releases, including horror movies like Kulam (Witchcraft), 2008, and Tarot, 2009.

In 2012, when his contract with Regal Films expired, he decided to write, direct, and produce Bwakaw. The film received acclaim on the festival circuit, screening in over 30 international film festivals, including Toronto, New York, and Tokyo and was picked up for international distribution. It also became the Philippines’ official entry in the Academy Awards that year.

In 2013, he submitted his work-in-progress Mga Kuwentong Barbero (Barber’s Tales) to the Hong Kong Asia Film Financing Forum (HAF), where it won the Best Project Award and received in-kind grants from ARRI and the postproduction laboratory Technicolor Bangkok. Completed in five months after HAF, Barber’s Tales had its world premiere in the competition section of the 2013 Tokyo International Film Festival and picked up a Best Actress award for its lead Eugene Domingo. In 2014, Lana received the Best Director award for Barber’s Tales from Madrid International Film Festival.

Lana is the youngest Filipino to be inducted into the Hall of Fame of the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, having won five first prizes for his literary works: Karinyo-Brutal (Brutal Love), screenplay, 1995; Mga Bangka sa Tag-araw (Boats in Summer), screenplay, 1996, later retitled and reworked as Sa Pusod ng Dagat; Sa Daigdig ng mga Taksil (In the World of Traitors), teleplay, 1996; Pula (Red), teleplay co-written with Peter Ong Lim, 1997; and Milagroso (Miraculous), teleplay, 2006.

In 2015, Lana wrote, produced, and directed the one-shot film Anino sa Likod ng Buwan (Shadow behind the Moon), which made history at the 13th Pacific Meridian Film Festival in Russia where it won four major awards: Best Asian Film, Best Director, Best Actress, and Critics Prize. For the same film, Lana also won Best Director at Kerala International Film Festival in India.

Lana’s mainstream projects have also been successful. For 17 years he was a consultant—and later on creative director—at GMA Network, where he supervised some of the industry’s top-rating drama anthologies and soap operas. He also taught for six years at UST and the University of the Philippines. Currently, he is the Chief Creative Officer of The IdeaFirst Company, Inc., a content production company he established with his life partner, film and television producer and director Percival M. Intalan. Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian

LANG, MOIRA (Raymond Abanilla Lee) b. Makati City 24 May 1971. Screenwriter, producer. Her parents are William Lee and Carmelita Abanilla. She took up business administration in the University of the Philippines in Diliman and graduated magna cum laude in 1992. Starting out in the movie industry as a brainstormer for the then-new movie outfit Star Cinema, she went on to co-write some of the studio’s best-loved hits, namely Anak (Child), 2000; Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000; Kailangan Kita (I Need You), 2002; Milan, 2004; D’Anothers, 2005; and In My Life, 2009.

In 2004, together with four of her screenwriter friends, Moira branched out to independent film producing. Their output began with what is now considered a landmark in local cinema, the coming-of-age social drama/romance Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros), 2005.

Moira combined her passion for cinema and knack for marketing and headed the successful, groundbreaking campaigns for the local release of several independently produced and distributed films. Of the films she has produced, three have had international distribution: Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros, Zombadings 1: Patayin sa Shokot si Remington! (Remington and the Curse of Zombadings), 2011, and Norte, Hangganan ng Kasaysayan (Norte, The End of History), 2013.

Ang Pagdadalaga… and Norte were Best International Film nominees at the Film Independent Spirit Awards, to date the only Filipino films nominated for the award. They were also the Philippines’ official entries to the Oscars in 2007 and 2015, respectively.

Moira’s other producing credits include the critically acclaimed films Sarong Banggi (One Night), 2005; Endo (End of Contract), 2007, the script of which she co-wrote with Jade Castro and Michiko Yamamoto; and Juana C. The Movie, 2013. She has taught screenwriting and producing at the University of the Philippines, De La Salle University College of Saint Benilde, and Asia Pacific Film Institute. She continues to mentor filmmakers. Written byElmer L. Gatchalian

LAO, ARMANDO (Armando Yasin Lao) aka Bing Lao. b. Davao City 6 Sep 1948. Screenwriter and director. Lao is second to the youngest of the six children of Haokhon Lao, a Chinese businessman, and Sylvia Yasin, a housewife. He graduated from University of the East in 1971 with a commerce degree. He attended several scriptwriting workshops conducted by JoseF.Lacaba, Ricky Lee, and RolandoS.Tinio in the early 1980s. He also attended a basic filmmaking workshop at Mowelfund Film Institute in 1981.

Lao started as a resident writer for the TV drama series Aklat ng Puso (Book of Heart), 1981, produced by ArmidaSiguion-Reyna. He was also a resident writer of three other drama anthologies on TV: Quiapo, 1982; Chat Silayan Drama, 1983; and Spotlight, 1990-93. He served as the head writer of the TV miniseries Davao, directed by ChitoRoño for RPN 9.

Lao’s first produced screenplay is Chikas (Babes), 1984, a sex-oriented film directed by William Pascual. This was followed by Naked Paradise, 1985; Takaw Tukso (Flirting with Temptation) and Di Maghilom ang Sugat (The Wound Never Heals), 1986; and Hubad na Pangarap (Naked Dream), 1987.

In 1987, he adapted Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig? (Where Does Love Hide?), a popular komiks novel, for the screen. He wrote the scripts for director Lupita Aquino-Kashiwahara’s comeback film, Hati Tayo sa Magdamag (Let’s Split the Night), and Chito Roño’s Itanong Mo sa Buwan (Ask the Moon), both in 1988. He also wrote Stupid Cupid, 1988, directed by MaryoJ. de losReyes for Regal Films; Dear Diary, 1989, directed by LeroySalvador and LupitaAquino-Kashiwahara for VivaFilms; and Oras-Oras, Araw-Araw (Every Hour, Every Day) and Bakit Ikaw Pa Rin? (Why Still You?), 1990, both directed by EmmanuelH.Borlaza for Viva Films. For Cine Suerte Productions, he wrote Tayo Na sa Dilim (Come with Me in the Dark), 1990, directed by Borlaza. Lao continued writing for film, and his later scripts include Sana Pag-ibig Na (Enter Love), 1998; Pila Balde (Fetch a Pail of Water), 1999; Tuhog (Larger Than Life) and La Vida Rosa (The Life of Rosa), 2001; Bridal Shower and Minsan Pa (One Moment More), 2004; Kubrador (The Bet Collector), 2006; Serbis (Service), 2008; and Kinatay (The Execution of P.), 2009. He also turned to directing, debuting with the film Biyaheng Lupa (Soliloquy), 2009. His second directorial work is Dukit (Carving), 2013.

Armando Lao is known for his concept of the “Found Story,” where the narrative of a film is heavily premised on the actuality of a place and the people in it and transpires in one day.

Lao’s screenplay Pinilakan (Silver Plated) won the grand prize in the 1984 Experimental Cinema ofthePhilippines Scriptwriting Contest. In 1987, his screenplay Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig? received a Star Award. In 1991, Oras-oras, Araw-araw won for him screenplay awards from the Catholic Mass Media Awards and the Film Academy of the Philippines. He won five Gawad Urian for screenplay: in 1987, for Takaw Tukso; in 1989, for Itanong Mo sa Buwan; in 2000, for Pila Balde; in 2001, for Tuhog; and in 2002, for La Vida Rosa. He won two screenplay awards from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk: in 2005, for Minsan Pa, and in 2010, for Biyaheng Lupa, for which he also received the Grand Jury Prize in the Digital Lokal section of the 2009 Cinemanila International Film Festival. His film Dukit won Best Film in the New Wave Section of the 2013 Metro Manila Film Festival. Written by Raquel Hernandez, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

LAPID, JESS (Jesus Songco Lapid) b. Guagua, Pampanga 7 Jan 1933. d. Quezon City 13 Jul 1968. Movie actor. His parents are Catalino Lapid and Irene Songco. He was married to Bella Flake with whom he had three children. Action star JessLapid Jr is his son and LitoLapid is his nephew.

He first appeared as a bit player in Premiere Productions’ Larawan ng Buhay (Portrait of Life), 1952, directed by EfrenReyes Sr. He was a bit player in Dyesebel, 1953, where part of his chores were to put on the fishtails of EdnaLuna and the other mermaids as a stuntman and as double for established stars in risky scenes. He excelled in the fast draw, fistfights, and horse riding. He was also in the cast of Gerardo de Leon's Huwag Mo Akong Limutin (Never Forget Me), 1960.

Lapid got his big break when he played villain in the FernandoPoe Jr–Zaldy Zshornack starrer Pasong Diablo (Devil’s Pass), 1961. He became a big star in Kardong Kidlat (Lightning Kardo) and Ito ang Lalake (This Is a Man), 1964. In both movies directed by Armando Garces, he was cast with actor Divina Valencia. Lapid also starred in Barako (Male), 1967, Banahaw Pictures’ initial offering, with Jill Hamilton and PaquitoDiaz.

During the 1960s, he became the top action star of TagalogIlang-IlangProductions and LeaProductions, appearing in films like Pistolero (Triggerman), Black Jack, Tiagong Lundag (Leaping Tiago), Batang Muntinlupa (Muntinlupa Youth), and Operation XYZ, all shown in 1966, and Killer Patrol, 1968. At the height of his popularity, he was fatally shot in a nightclub in Quezon City. He was buried in his hometown in Guagua, Pampanga.

His life story was made into a movie in 1978, with his nephew Lito Lapid in the lead role. Written by Lena S. Pareja

LAPID, LITO(Manuel Mercado Lapid) b. Porac, Pampanga 25 Oct 1955. Movie actor, director, producer. His parents are Jose Lapid and Eleuteria Mercado. He married Marissa Tadeo with whom he has four children. He has another son with movie actor Melanie Marquez. Actor and stuntman JessLapid Sr was his uncle. Cinematographer Rey Lapid and actors Jess Lapid Jr, Frank Lapid, Efren Lapid, Rolly Lapid, and Joe Lapid are his cousins. Lapid studied at Porac Elementary School and graduated from high school at St. Catherine Academy in his hometown. He was vice-governor of the province of Pampanga in 1992-95 and governor of the province in 1995-2004. He then became a senator of the Philippines in 2004.

Lapid zoomed to stardom and national celebrity status when he successfully appeared in The Jess Lapid Story, 1978, a true-to-life story of the first movie stuntman in Philippine cinema to become a big box-office action star. Like his uncle and predecessor, Jess Lapid Sr, he also refused to use a double when doing death-defying stunts to add credibility to his performance.

Among his early films are Batang Salabusab (Young and Lustful), Alas at Reyna (Ace and Queen), Haring Cobra (King Cobra), and Dangerous Fist, all in 1979; and Aguila sa Puting Bato (Eagle in Puting Bato), Isaac, Dugo ni Abraham (Isaac, Blood of Abraham), and Gunfighter, all in 1983. In 1983, he put up his own film company, LL (Lito Lapid) Productions, which produced his films Desperado (Desperate) and Pedro Tunasan, both released in 1983.

His most memorable films are those with other top action stars of the industry, such as TonyFerrer in Back to Back, and RudyFernandez and BembolRoco in Ang Leon, ang Tigre, at ang Alamid (The Lion, the Tiger, and the Wildcat), both in 1979; FernandoPoeJr in Kalibre .45 (Caliber .45), 1980; and VicVargas in Gamugamo sa Pugad Lawin (Moth in Pugad Lawin), 1983. Most of his early films were directed by Cesar“Chat”Gallardo and his son, Jun Gallardo. He also appeared opposite NoraAunor in Kastilyong Buhangin (Sand Castle), 1980, and Gaano Kita Kamahal (How Much Do I Love You), 1981.

His most recent films include Fidel Jimenez: Magkasubukan Tayo (Fidel Jimenez: I Challenge You); Pasasabugin Ko ang Mundo Mo (I Will Blow Up Your World), Huwag Mong Ubusin ang Bait Ko (Don’t Wait for My Kindness to Run Out), Eskort (Escort), and Patigasan (Toughen Up), all in 2000; Masikip Na ang Mundo Mo, Labrador (Your World Is Crowded, Labrador), Bukas Babaha ng Dugo (Tomorrow Blood Will Shed), and Dugong Aso: Mabuting Kaibigan, Masamang Kaaway (Dog Blood: Good Friend, Bad Enemy), all in 2001; Lapu-Lapu, 2002; Tatlong Baraha (Three Playing Cards), 2006, a remake of his own film; and 10,000 Hours, 2013. He was also part of ABS-CBN’s television show Little Champ, which aired in 2013.

In 1981, Lapid became a movie director himself when he made Tatlong Baraha. In the same year, he produced and starred in San Basilio. He also directed and starred in Maruso, 1987, and Aguinaldo, 1993, the last based on the life of the controversial governor of Cagayan Province.

Lapid received a Best Actor award from the Film Academy of the Philippines for his role in Lapu-Lapu, 2002. The Star Awards for Movies also gave him a Lifetime Achievement Award in 2013. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

LARANAS, YAM (William Laranas) b. Davao City, Mindanao 12 Dec 1978. Cinematographer, director, writer, producer. He is married to Gin de Mesa. He took up bachelor of science in medical technology at Immaculate Conception College, but left school when he was in second year. He took a filmmaking workshop at the Mowelfund Film Institute.

Laranas is known for his short film Unison, 1990, and for the films that he photographed like Raymond Red’s Bayani (Hero), 1992, and Nick Deocampo’s Memories of Old Manila, 1993, and Isaak (Isaac), 1994. He won Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design from the Young Critics Circle (YCC) Film Desk for Ikaw Lamang Hanggang Ngayon (Only You until Now), 2002, shared with production designer Sammy Aranzamendez. He also did the cinematography of Balahibong Pusa (Cat’s Fur), 2001, Radyo (Radio), 2001, and Hibla(Strand), 2002.

Laranas’ Sigaw (The Echo), 2004, won him a Special Award at Brussels International Festival of Fantasy Film, and Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design from the YCC Film Fesk, shared with Sammy Aranzamendez. His later cinematographic work for The Road, 2011, won him Best Cinematography from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, and the Movie Cinematographer of the Year from the Star Awards for Movies. He was also the cinematographer of Patient X, 2009.

Aside from doing the cinematography, Laranas also directed Radyo and Balahibong Pusa, 2001; Sigaw, 2004; The Echo, 2008, the Hollywood remake of Sigaw; Patient X, 2009; and The Road, 2011. Written byChristian Co

LASATEN, JESSIE(Constancio Jesus Quiming Lasaten) b. Quezon City 24 Dec 1967. Pianist, film music composer, and producer. He is the son of Col Constancio S. Lasaten Sr of the Philippine Constabulary and Dr Celerina J. Quiming, a dentist.He started playing the piano at age 10, but in second year high school he shifted to organ lessons, studying in Musar Yamaha School of Music, Baguio City. It was during this time that Jessie got hooked on George Lucas’s Star Wars series, which stirred his interest in film music scoring and led him to dream of becoming a musician. However, after graduating from high school, his parents discouraged him from choosing music as a career, so he took up political science at Saint Louis University (SLU), Baguio City. Nonetheless, his engagement with music continued, playing the xylophone for a marching band that paid for his college tuition and teaching organ lessons. In addition, he was active in the school’s musical activities and even staged a concert titled “Finger Touch,” which was his first venture in concert producing, musical directing, and performing. Proceeds from that concert went to the purchase of a piano for the SLU College of Human Sciences.

In 1988 he graduated with a political science degree. In the same year, he won second place in the National Yamaha Electone Festival. He then moved to Manila and became an organ sales demonstrator for Yupangco Yamaha in Makati and in various branch offices of the said company. He augmented his income by working at various piano bars in Manila as solo pianist or organist.Beginning 1990, he studied film scoring with minor in commercial arranging at the Berklee College of Music in Boston, Massachusetts. He graduated summa cum laude from this school.

By 2016, his staggering creative output already reached over a hundred film scores for feature films. A short list of this film music scores includes Dahas (Rage), 1995; Nasaan Ka Man (Wherever You Are), 2005; Ploning, 2008; Si Agimat at si Enteng Kabisote (Agimat and Enteng Kabisote) and Ang Tanging Ina Mo: Last Na To! (Your One and Only Mom, This Is the Last One!), 2010; Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story, 2011; El Presidente (The President), 2012; and Nilalang (The Entity), 2015.

On television, Lasaten carries the distinction of being a pioneer in creating original scores for TV drama series, particularly his ABS-CBN hit teleserye Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), which was broadcast in 2000-2002. Since then, he has scored over 50 drama series for this broadcast medium, among them Mula sa Puso (From the Heart), 2011; 100 Days to Heaven, 2011; Reputasyon (Reputation), 2011-12; Kung Ako’y Iiwan Mo (Without You), 2012; and Aryana, 2012-13.

He also ventured into music, audio, and video production services for the advertising, television, and movie industries, founding a company named Cutting Edge Productions Inc in 2003. In 2008, he produced Dayo: Sa Mundo ng Elementalia (The Wanderer in the Land of Elementalia), which is the first fully digital 2D-3D animated feature film in the Philippines.

Thirty-nine of his prolific output in film music were nominated by various award-giving bodies and 17 of these won awards: Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Music Score for Nasaan Ka Man, Ploning, Si Agimat at si Enteng Kabisote, Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story, and El Presidente; Film Academy of the Philippines Best Music Score for El Presidente; Metro Manila Film Festival Best Music Score for Dayo, Ang Tanging Ina Mo: Last Na ’To!, Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story, El Presidente, and Nilalang; Star Awards for Movies Original Theme Song of the Year for El Presidente; and Young Critics Circle Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration for Dahas. Written byJosé S. Buenconsejo

LATONIO, JUN(Felipe Arcilla Latonio Jr) b. Ermita, Manila 1 Mar 1956. Movie musical director, composer. Born to Felipe Latonio Sr and Angelina Arcilla, he finished his elementary education at La Salle Greenhills and attended St. Anselms in England and Ateneo de Manila for high school. He received his bachelor of music in composition and conducting from the University of the Philippines College of Music.

Director MikedeLeon recruited Latonio into the movie industry. One of Latonio’s notable works is the musical score for de Leon’s Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (When You Dream and Wake Up), 1977. His other films are Kasal? (Marriage?), 1980; Ang Boyfriend Kong Kano (My American Boyfriend), and Gunfighter, 1983; Kumander Toothpick (Commander Toothpick), Kapitan Pablo (Captain Pablo), Target: Sparrow Unit, and Boy Tornado, 1987; Afuang: Bounty Hunter, The Sisterhood, Fast Gun, Lost Command, Ex-Army, and Boy Negro, 1988; and Dino … Abangan ang Susunod Na… (Dino… Wait for the Next…), 1993.

Latonio’s musical score for Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising won in the 1978 Gawad Urianand the 1977 Tinig Awards. His work “Element of the Earth” was chosen best composition in the 1976 National Music Competition for Young Artists (NAMCYA), while another composition, “There’s Nothing I Want More,” was adjudged Best Song in the 1982 Seoul Song Festival. Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

LAZARO, RONNIE (Ronnie Zabala Lazaro) b. Sagay City, Negros Occidental 14 Nov 1957. Movie, stage, and television actor, producer, and director. He is husband to Spanish professor Lola Pizarro and father to son Gabriel. He graduated with a commerce degree, major in accounting, at the University of Saint La Salle in Bacolod City.

Lazaro was introduced to cinema by his father who worked as projectionist in a local movie theater called Vista in Negros Occidental. In college, he was a member of the theater troupe under the tutelage of award-winning film director Peque Gallaga. He landed his first role in Philippine cinema in Lino Brocka’s Gumising Ka … Maruja (Wake Up … Maruja), 1978. Gallaga then directed him in the landmark film Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982, where he earned his first nomination at the Gawad Urian for Best Supporting Actor. He played the title role in Boatman, 1985. While his role as a live sex performer was not a personal favorite for Lazaro, he earned another nomination for it from the Gawad Urian as Best Actor. He also landed roles in foreign films like Return from the River Kwai, 1989, Braddock: Missing in Action III, 1988, and Delta Force 2: Operation Stranglehold, 1990, with the latter two starring American iconic action star Chuck Norris. Lazaro later appeared in Bayani (Hero), 1992; Sa Pusod ng Dagat (In the Navel of the Sea), 1998; the Cannes-winning short film Anino (Shadows), 2000; and Bagong Buwan (New Moon), 2001. For the latter, he won Best Supporting Actor at the Metro Manila Film Festival. He received his first Gawad Urian for the Ilongo horror film Yanggaw (Affliction), 2008, for which he was also recognized as Best Actor at Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival. Lazaro directed his first indie film, Edna, 2014; co-produced Tumbang Preso (In the Can), 2014; and was the associate producer for Ang Beerhouse (The Beerhouse), 2009. Lazaro was also the art director for Ishmael Bernal’s City after Dark, 1980.

Lazaro is also passionate about theater and photography. He appeared in dozens of theater productions, including Hiblang Abo (Strands of Gray), 1977, for which he was also artistic director; San Lorenzo Ruiz, 1989; and And St. Louie Loves Dem Filipinos, 2005. He also launched photo exhibits in Manila and Spain.

Lazaro also appeared in television shows. He was part of the 1980s gag show Champoy, 1980-86; Esperanza, 1997-99; Kay Tagal Kang Hinintay (So Long Have I Waited for You), 2002-3; Nagsimula sa Puso (It Began from the Heart), 2009-10; and Amaya, 2011-12. Written byKathrina Alvarez

LEA PRODUCTIONS Established in Jun 1962 by theater owner Emilia Bias aka Aling Miling and her sister, Teodorica Santos aka Aling Toreng, Lea Productions started operations as a distributor of films. On its first year, it acquired the rights to distribute Premiere Production’s Ako Ang Katarungan (I Am Justice), a Gerardo de Leon film starring Fernando Poe Jr, and Apat na Kilabot (Terror Times Four), starring Efren Reyes, Mario Montenegro, Joseph Estrada, and Johnny Monteiro. That same year it produced its first movie, Markang Demonyo (Mark of the Demon), 1962, starring Cesar Ramirez, Van de Leon, Johnny Monteiro, and Chiquito.

For the next 10 years from 1963 to 1972, Lea’s production output averaged 10 to 11 pictures a year, most of which established for the company a reputation for producing wholesome film entertainment. During the 1960s and the 1970s, it is credited with having discovered new faces and major talents, such as Lino Brocka, Hilda Koronel, Dante Rivero, Snooky Serna, Alicia Alonzo, and Orlando Nadres.

Brocka directed the Lea films Wanted: Perfect Mother, Santiago, and Tubog sa Ginto (Dipped in Gold), 1970; Stardoom, Now, Lumuha Pati mga Anghel (Even the Angels Wept), and Cadena de Amor (Chain of Love), 1971; and Villa Miranda and Cherry Blossoms, 1972. After his stint with Lea, Brocka moved on to make award-winning films with different movie companies in the Philippines and abroad, establishing himself as one of the finest directors of the Philippine New Cinema.

Hilda Koronel was introduced in the Lea film Haydee, 1970, directed by Armando de Guzman from a Mars Ravelo komiks creation. In Santiago, 1970, she rendered a performance that won the Best Supporting Actress award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS). She sustained her career with credible appearances in other Lea films like Crush Ko si Sir (I Have a Crush on Sir), 1971; Ang Gangster at ang Birhen (The Gangster and the Virgin), 1972; Till Death Do Us Part, 1972; May Isang Brilyante (There Was a Diamond), 1973; and Lupang Hinirang (Beloved Land), 1973.

Child star Snooky Serna zoomed to nationwide popularity in Lea’s Wanted: Perfect Mother and became one of the industry’s biggest talents. Alicia Alonzo proved her mettle as awardwinning actor in two Lea films, Villa Miranda and Bago Kumalat ang Kamandag (Before the Venom Spreads), 1983. Dante Rivero won his FAMAS Best Actor award for Wanted: Perfect Mother and proved his durability in other Lea films like Santiago, Cadena de Amor, Crush Ko si Sir, Cherry Blossoms, and Tanikalang Dugo (Blood Chain), 1973. Nadres distinguished himself as scriptwriter and director of the Lea films, Nora, Mahal Kita (Nora, I Love You), 1972; Dito sa Aking Puso (Here in My Heart), 1972; Lupang Hinirang; and Somewhere over the Rainbow, 1973. Susan Roces, who was Sampaguita movie queen in the 1950s, became a dramatic actor after she appeared in Lea’s Maruja, 1967.

Lea Productions president Emilia Blas served as co-administrator of the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines Film Fund together with Jesusa S. Poe aka Susan Roces from 1984 to 1986. Although Lea produced only one or two films a year in the 1980s, it continued to be active in industry affairs and efforts of the Film Academy of the Philippines to improve the film situation in the country. Written by Mauro Tumbocon and Lena S. Pareja

LEBRAN, INC Established in 1949 by William A. Brandt, Manuel Valdes, Rafael Anton, Rita Valdes Araneta, and Carmen Valdes Nieto, this movie company is also known as Lebran International. Anton served as general manager of both Lebran and Movietec, the studio where Lebran films were made. He was instrumental in forming the Big Four association of movie producers in the early 1950s, which was composed of Lebran, Sampaguita Pictures, LVN Pictures, and Premiere Productions. Lebran’s offices were located at No 20 Santa Mesa, Manila, while its studio was in San Francisco del Monte, Quezon City.

Lebran geared its productions for international release following the success of He Promised to Return, 1950, which was shown in Guam, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Formosa. Its other films made entirely in English are His Darkest Hour, 1950, starring Erlinda Cortez, Fred Castro, and Cris de Vera; The Pirates Go to Town, 1950, with singer Lirio del Valle; The Spell, 1950, starring Leopoldo Salcedo, Erlinda Cortez, Eddie del Mar, and Cris de Vera; and Song of Santo Tomas, 1950, starring Ricardo Montes, Lou Salvador Sr, Mario Bari, and the famous diva Fara Lizardo. These films were shown in Burma, Malaysia, India, Indonesia, and Thailand.

Lebran was the first movie studio to professionalize production design in film. Its art department was headed by Carlos V. Francisco aka Botong, who designed the sets, costumes, and props for Romeo at Julieta (Romeo and Juliet), 1951, the film based on Shakespeare’s play; and Sigfredo, 1951, a famous German epic. Manuel Conde portrayed Sigfredo while Oscar Moreno and Erlinda Cortez played the roles of Romeo and Julieta.

Lebran’s biggest production was the all-star opus Kalbaryo ni Hesus (The Calvary of Jesus), 1952, directed by Carlos Vander Tolosa. It won the first Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) award for Best Musical Score for Prof Julio Esteban Anguita, director of the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music. The FAMAS award for Best Sound went to Charles Gray for the same picture.
