Two other FAMAS winners produced by Lebran are Buhay Alamang (Easy Come, Easy Go), 1952, for the screenplay by Eddie Romero and Cesar Amigo, and May Isang Tsuper ng Taksi (There Was a Taxi Driver), 1952, for sound recording by Angelo Larraga.

Other notable films from Lebran include the sequel to Kalbaryo ni Hesus titled Ang Pagsilang ng Mesiyas (The Birth of the Messiah), 1952; the fantasy pictures Babaing Kalbo (The Bald Woman), 1953, and Paniwalaan Dili (Believe It or Not), about a talking frog; the action-drama No Place to Hide, 1955; and Gerardo de Leon’s Saigon, 1956, starring Leopoldo Salcedo and the former Miss Philippines, Cristina Pacheco.

Lebran stopped producing pictures in 1956 when poor returns from investments prompted its stockholders to concentrate on the real estate business. Written by Lena S. Pareja
LEE, RAYMOND (See LANG, MOIRA.)

LEE, RICARDO aka RickyLee. b. Daet, Camarines Norte 19 Mar 1948. Movie scriptwriter, essayist, novelist. He was born to a Chinese father, Dy Hien Chin, and Bicolana mother, Clarita Arriola, both of whom died when he was young. He helped his aunt run a liquor store, and she gave him the money to study at Chung Hua High School in Bicol. He used the earnings from his first short story published in the Filipino Free Press, “Mayon,” to finance his trip to Manila. To survive, he worked as waiter, messenger, and did other odd jobs. When he had saved enough money, he enrolled at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman to pursue a bachelor of arts degree in English. He dropped out in 1972 and never finished college. He taught scriptwriting at UP and Ateneo de Manila University. He worked as a creative manager at ABS-CBN Broadcasting Corporation. He also heads the Philippine Writers Studio, which he established to help beginning writers.

Lee is one of the country’s most respected scriptwriters, and among his screenwriting credits are Jaguar (Guard), 1979, with Jose F. Lacaba; Brutal and Miss X, 1980; Playgirl, 1981; Relasyon (An Affair), Moral, Cain at Abel (Cain and Abel), Himala (Miracle), and Haplos (Caress), 1982; Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983; Sinner or Saint, 1984; White Slavery, 1985; Private Show, 1986; Andrea, Paano Ba ang Maging Isang Ina? (Andrea, How Does One Become a Mother?), 1990; Ang Totoong Buhay ni Pacita M. (The Real Life of Pacita M.), 1991; Takbo, Talon, Tili (Run, Jump, Scream), 1992; Muling Umawit ang Puso (The Heart Sings Again), 1995; Jose Rizal, 1998, with Jun Lana and Peter Ong Lim; and Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 1999, with Jun Lana. His other notable films are Lagarista (Film Biker), 2000, Aishite Imasu 1941 (I Love You), 2004, Dubai, 2005, and independent films like Kamoteng Kahoy (Cassava), 2009; Burgos and Lauriana, 2013; and Hustisya (Justice), 2014.

To help struggling scriptwriters, Lee holds workshops, free of charge. The Ricky Lee Writers’ Studio gave members written assignments for TV programs, like the public affairs show Isip Pinoy (Filipino Mind), the sitcom Pubhouse, the Actor’s Workshop drama series Wakasan (Vignettes), and made-for-TV movie productions by VivaFilms. Lee himself wrote for the TV drama series Lambat (Fishnet) and Kuwentong Buhay (Living Stories), 1985; Desaparecido (Missing), Obrero (Laborer), Evelio Javier, and Ina (Mother), all in 1986; Ano’ng Naghihintay Bukas? (What Awaits Tomorrow?), 1988; Paalam, Uncle Sam (Goodbye, Uncle Sam) and Bilanggo (Prisoner), 1989; and Ang Lihim ni Esper (Esper’s Secret), 1990.

Lee’s first play, Pitik-Bulag sa Buwan ng Pebrero (Guessing Game in the Month of February), was staged at the Manila Film Center in 1989. The same year, he also wrote the play Balisawsaw, Pusong Ligaw, an adaptation of Dog Day Afternoon, and in 1992, DH (Domestic Helper), for the Philippine EducationalTheaterAssociation.

Lee’s published works include his screenplays Brutal/Salome, 1981, Moral, 1982, and Bukas May Pangarap (Tomorrow There’s Hope), 1984; his play, Pitik-Bulag …; and two books which he co-edited, Sigwa (Rage), 1972, a collection of short stories in Filipino, and All-Star Cast, 1981, a collection of articles by Emmie Velarde. His screenplay Salome was translated into English by the University of Wisconsin and is used as a text in film studies. He also published Trip to Quiapo in 1998, a manual for scriptwriting. He compiled 20 years of his creative works in a book, Si Tatang at ang mga Himala ng Ating Panahon (Tatang and the Miracles of Our Time), 1989. In 2008, he published his first novel, Para Kay B o Kung Paano Dinevastate ng Pag-ibig ang 4 out of 5 sa Atin) (For B or How Love Devastated 4 out of 5 of Us). It was followed by Si Amapola sa 65 na Kabanata (Amapola in 65 Chapters) in 2011. He published Sa Puso ng Himala (In the Heart of the Miracle) in 2012, a coffee-table book that commemorates the 30th anniversary of the film Himala.

Among his literary awards are as follows: first prize, short story, Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, 1969, for “H’wag, H’wag Mong Kukuwentuhan ang Batang si Wei-fung” (Don’t, Don’t Tell the Child Wei-Fung Any Stories); first and third prizes, Pilipino Free Press Annual Literary Awards, 1969, for “H’wag …” and “Pagtatapos” (In the End); first prize, short story, Palanca Awards, 1979, for “Servando Magdamag”; National Book Award, Manila Critics Circle, 1982, for Brutal/Salome; and an award from the Surian ng Wikang Pambansa, 1982, for his outstanding contribution to literature in Filipino.

Lee is a multi-awarded scriptwriter. He won the Gawad Urian for screenplay for Jaguar, with JoseF.Lacaba, in 1980; Salome in 1982; and GumapangKasaLusak (Dirty Affair) in 1991. He also received Best Screenplay awards for Andrea, Paano Ba ang Maging Isang Ina? from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk, the Filipino Academy of MovieArtsandSciences (FAMAS), and the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) in 1991. From the 1992 FAMAS and FAP Awards, he received Best Screenplay for Ang Totoong Buhay ni Pacita M. His other FAMAS awards are for his work in Jose Rizal, with Jun Lana and Peter Ong Lim, in 1999; Bagong Buwan (New Moon), with Jun Lana, in 2002; Nasaan Ka Man (Wherever You Are), with Cholo Laurel, in 2011; and The Trial, with Enrico Santos and Kris Gazmen, in 2015. His other FAP screenwriting awards are for his work in Dahil Mahal Kita: The Dolzura Cortez Story (Because I Love You) in 1994, Pangako ng Kahapon (Yesterday’s Promise) in 1995, The Flor Contemplacion Story in 1996, Bulaklak ng Maynila (Flower of Manila) in 2000, and Anak (The Child) in 2001. Lee also received numerous awards from the Metro Manila Film Festival and the Star Awards for Movies.

In 2000, he received the Centennial Honors for the Arts from the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and the Gawad Balagtas for Tagalog Fiction from the Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas. He was also awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award in the 2000 Cinemanila International Film Festival, the 2003 Natatanging Gawad Urian, the 2015 Gawad Plaridel, and the 2015 Gawad CCP sa Sining for literature. Written byNenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

LIM, NOEL F.(Noel Fernandez Lim) b. Manila 15 Feb 1964. Filmmaker. Born to Hermenigildo Lim and Edita Fernandez, he received his elementary and secondary education at San Beda College and Arellano University, and studied painting at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts. He began making films in 1987, starting with Wrist-Warp, in Super 8mm, and had produced a total of 11 films by 1992. A “one-man movie production team,” he directed, wrote the script, edited, photographed, did the animation, and composed the musical scores for all his works. His films are all in Super 8 except for the collaborative works Prayle (Friar), 1988, in 35mm (with Joey Agbayani, Patrick Purugganan, and Roxlee), and Magkakahoy (Wood Gatherer), 1989, in 16mm (with Teddie Co and At Maculangan). The others are The Battle of Concepcion Aguila and Siopao, 1988; Necro-Concerto and Basura (Garbage), 1990; Concepcion Aguila, 1991; Stray and Garden Monster, 1992.

Lim represented the Philippines in several international film festivals. He was a consistent winner in the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ annual film and video competition, with his Wrist-Warp, Gamay, and The Battle of Concepcion Aguila winning in the experimental category, and Siopao, Prayle, and Necro-Concerto in the short feature category. The Battle of Concepcion Aguila won Best Short Feature Film in the 1988 Gawad Urian, while Magkakahoy was chosen as Best Short Feature by the Film Academy of the Philippines in 1989 and Grand Prix winner in the 1st Southeast Asian Film Competition in 1992. Written byRosalinda Galang

LINDA, ANITA (Alice Buenaflor Lake) b. Pasay City 23 Nov 1924. Movie and television actor. Her parents are James Lake, a mining engineer, and Gorgonia Buenaflor. She married actor Fred Cortes, with whom she has a son, actor Fred Cortes Jr. She attended Polo Elementary School and graduated from Good Shepherd Convent High School.

Before World War II, she appeared in Lamberto V. Avellana’s Tia Juana (Aunt Juana) with Leopoldo Salcedo and Ester Magalona. The film was released in 1943. During the Japanese Occupation she appeared in stage shows at the Avenue Theater. In 1947, Avellana cast her in Sekretang Hong Kong (Hong Kong Spy), opposite Domingo Principe. In the same year, she became a lead star in Alyas Sakim (Alias Greedy). She also appeared in Buhay Alamang (Easy Come, Easy Go), 1952; Agilang Itim (Black Eagle), 1953; Mutya ng Paaralan (School Muse) and Basagulera (Trouble-maker), 1954; Bandilang Pula (Red Flag), 1955; Takya, 1956; Ukulele Boy, 1957; and Ambrocia, 1958. Since the 1970s, she has been playing mother roles in films like Jaguar (Guard), 1979, and Bakit Bughaw ang Langit? (Why Is the Sky Blue?), 1981. Later on, she progressed to playing grandmother characters, such as in Nagkataon … Nagkatagpo (Chance Meeting), 1994; Puso ng Pasko (Heart of Christmas) and Babae sa Bubungang Lata (Woman on a Tin Roof), 1998; Muling Ibalik ang Tamis ng Pag-ibig (Rekindle Love’s Sweetness), 1998; Aishite Imasu 1941 (I Love You), 2004; Ilusyon (Illusion), 2005; Ouija (The Séance) and Tambolista (Drumbeat), 2007; Caregiver and Adela, 2008; Dalaw (Visit) and Lola (Grandmother), 2009; Presa (Female Prisoner), 2010; Paglipad ng Anghel (Flight of an Angel), 2011; Sta. Niña (Saintly Girl) and Mater Dolorosa (Sorrowful Mother), 2012.

Linda also worked on television, having appeared in various TV programs, such as in ABS-CBN’s Mara Clara, 1993-97, Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You May Be), 1999, Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000, Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009, Ikaw ay Pag-ibig (You Are the Love), 2011-12, and in GMA Network’s Wagas (Sincere), 2013, Indio (Christianized Native), 2013, and Sa Puso ni Dok (Village Doctor), 2014.

In 1952, Linda won her first major acting award, Best Actress in the Maria Clara Awards for Premiere Productions’ Sisa, 1951, directed by Gerardo de Leon. She won Best Supporting Actress in the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Awards for Tatlo, Dalawa, Isa (Three, Two, One), 1974. She received the Sinag award for Outstanding Single Performance by an Actress from the Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining for her performance in an episode of the TV drama anthology Huwaran (Model), titled “Lata, Kariton at Karton” (Tin, Cart, Carton), 1976. In 1986, she was chosen Best Supporting Actress by the Gawad Urian for Takaw Tukso (Flirting with Temptation). She was FAMAS nominee for Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo (Python in the Old Dome), 1952, Mrs. Teresa Abad … Ako Po si Bing (Mrs. Teresa Abad … I Am Bing), 1976, and Itanong Mo sa Buwan (Ask the Moon), 1988, and later on won her second FAMAS Best Supporting Actress award in 1999 for her work in Babae sa Bubungang Lata. She received the Natatanging Gawad Urian (Lifetime Achievement Award) from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino, 1981; the Ulirang Artista (Model Actor) Award from the Philippine Movie Press Club, 1988; and the Gawad CCP sa Sining, 1994. For her performance in Lola, Linda won Best Actress awards, shared with her Lola co-actor Rustica Carpio, in the 2011 Las Palmas de Gran Canaria International Film Festival, the 2011 Fajr International Film Festival, and the 2011 Gawad Urian; she also won Best Actress in the 2010 Asia-Pacific Film Festival. The film Adela gave Linda the Best Performance award in the 2009 Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations and the Best Actress award in the Southeast Asia Film Competition of the 2008 Cinemanila International Film Festival. Sta. Niña earned for her Best Supporting Actress awards from the 2012 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival and the 2013 ASEAN International Film Festival and Awards. Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Anne Frances Sangil

Mona Lisa ( Gloria Lerma Yatco ), also known as Fleur de Lis, is a movie and television actor. She was born in Tondo, Manila on 22 June 1922. Her parents are Melecia Lerma and Manuel Yatco of the United States Navy. She attended the Girls High School in San Francisco and took acting courses in Los Angeles in 1937.

Under her first screen name Fleur de Lis, she appeared in Parlatone’s Ang Pagbabalik (The Return), 1938, and LVN’s Giliw Ko (My Beloved), 1939. Her first starring role was opposite Serafin Garcia in Tinangay ng Apoy (Taken by Fire), 1940, where she changed her screen name to Mona Lisa. She appeared in Datu Talim, 1940, with Fernando Poe and Luningning; Palaris, 1941, with Poe and Paraluman; Puting Dambana (White Shrine), 1941; Alipin ng Alila (Servant’s Slave), 1941; and Luksang Bituin (Mourning Star), 1941. By her next film, Viuda Alegre (Merry Widow), also in 1941, where she shared star billing with Lucita Goyena, Fernando Poe, and Serafin Garcia, Lisa was already among the most popular actors in Philippine cinema. She continued making movies after the war, many times with Fernando Poe Sr, including Intramuros: The Rape of a City, 1946, and Sagur, 1949. Her other notable movies were Maria Kapra, 1947, with Angel Esmeralda; Sunset over Corregidor and Siyudad sa Ilalim ng Lupa (Underground City), 1949, both with Fernando Royo; and Ulila ng Bataan (Bataan Orphans), 1952, with Fred Montilla.

After an absence of 25 years, she came back to films in Lino Brocka’s Insiang. Since then, she played mother and grandmother roles in movies like Itim (Rites of May), 1976; Cain at Abel (Cain and Abel), 1982; Minsan Pa Nating Hagkan ang Nakaraan (Let Us Kiss the Past Once More), 1983; Bayan Ko : Kapit sa Patalim (My Country: Gripping the Knife’s Edge), 1985; Huwag Mong Salingin ang Sugat Ko (Touch Not My Wound) and Umiiyak Pati Langit (Even Heaven Weeps), 1991; Pagsubok sa Hirap at Ginhawa (Trials in Sickness or in Health), 1996; and Camiling Story, 2005.

For her critically acclaimed performance in Insiang, Mona Lisa won the Metro Manila Film Festival and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Supporting Actress awards in 1976 and 1977, respectively. In 1999, the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino conferred on her the Natatanging Gawad Urian. This was followed by a recognition from the Gawad Lino Brocka that gave her a Lifetime Achievement Award in 2005.

In 2013, Celine Beatrice Fabie—Mona Lisa’s granddaughter—published Mona Lisa: A Portrait (From the Memoirs of a Grandmother), a biography of Mona Lisa.Written byGalileo Zafra, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

LOBO, SERGIO (Sergio Laderas Lobo) b. Tondo, Manila 3 Aug 1925. Cinematographer. His parents are Rosario Laderas and Severino Lobo, an office clerk. He is married to Flordeliza Cadatal. He was a second-year mechanical engineering student at Mapua Institute of Technology when he became a driver-mechanic for producer-director Fernando Poe Sr. A cameraman, Remigio Young, showed him how to use the film camera and he taught himself thereafter.

Lobo’s first break as a full-fledged cameraman was Garbosa, 1955, a Visayan production of Natalio Bacalso. From 1962 to 1980, he worked as cameraman and cinematographer for FPJ Productions. His first major work was Perlas ng Silangan (Pearl of the Orient), 1967, the first Filipino movie to be shot in CinemaScope. Lobo worked on more than 100 films, among which are Alas, Hari, Sota (Ace, King, Jester), 1971; Salaginto’t Salagubang (Golden Butterfly) and Ang Alamat (The Legend), 1972; Esteban and Dugo ng Bayan (Blood of the Nation), 1973.

He received Best Cinematography awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Sigaw ng Digmaan (War Cry), 1963, Sa Daigdig ng Pantasya (In the World of Fantasy), 1964, and Pilipinas Kong Mahal (My Dear Philippines), 1965; from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Ang Agila at ang Araw (The Eagle and the Sun), 1973, and Himala (Miracle), 1982; and from the 1974 Baguio Film Festival for Sanctuario (Sanctuary). Written by Rosalie Matilac
(See LITERATURE volume.)

LORENA, LIZA(Elizabeth Luciano Winsett) b. Manila 31 Oct 1948. Movie actor. Her parents are Josefina Luciano and George Winsett. With actor Eddie Gutierrez, she has a son Tonton Gutierrez, also a movie actor. Winning as runner-up in the Bb. Pilipinas contest became her passport to a movie career.

Lorena’s first movie role was that of Charito Solis’s daughter in Dahil sa Isang Bulaklak (Because of a Flower), 1967. She was already a contract star of Nepomuceno Productions when she made Ang Langit sa Lupa (Heaven on Earth), 1967. She also appeared in Lea Productions’ Leslie, 1969, with Dante Rivero; Baron Gustavo, 1969, with Eddie Gutierrez; and Wanted, Perfect Mother, 1970, with Boots Anson-Roa under Lino Brocka’s direction. As a freelance actor, she made Tierra Sangre (Blood Earth), My Little Angel, and El Pinoy Tom Jones (The Filipino Tom Jones), 1970; Kapantay ay Langit (As High as Heaven), Binili Ko ang Aking Asawa (I Bought My Wife), and Kung Bakit May Tinik ang mga Rosas (Why Roses Have Thorns), 1971; Kung Bakit Kita Minahal (Why I Love You), 1972; Walang Katapusang Tag-araw (Eternal Summer), 1977; and Matang-Lawin (Hawk-Eyed), 1979. Her other commendable films are Gabun: Ama Mo, Ama Ko (Gabun: Your Father, My Father), 1979; Santa Claus Is Coming to Town, 1982; Sister Stella L., 1984; Pahiram ng Ligaya (Lend Me Happiness), 1985; Oras ng Kagitingan (Hour of Bravery), 1986; Anak Badjao (Badjao Children), 1987; Paano Tatakasan ang Bukas? (How Does One Escape from Tomorrow?) and Babaeng Hampaslupa (Downtrodden Woman), 1988; Imortal (Immortal), 1989; Ngayon at Kailanman (Now and Forever), 1992; May Minamahal (Loving Someone), 1993; Separada (Separated Woman), 1994; and Segurista (Dead Sure), 1996. Her later films include La Vida Rosa (The Life of Rosa), 2001; Sukob (The Wedding Curse) and Inang Yaya (Mother Nanny), 2006; Katas ng Saudi (Fruit of Labor in Saudi), 2007; Working Girls and Rosario, 2010; and Starting Over Again, 2014.

Lorena also appeared in several television shows, including GMA Network’s Twin Hearts, 2003-4; Magdusa Ka (Suffer), 2008, a remake of the 1986 film with the same title, and in which Lorena also had a role; and Akin Pa Rin ang Bukas (Perfect Vengeance), 2013; ABS-CBN’s Maria Flordeluna, 2007; Lobo (Wolves), 2008; Apoy sa Dagat (Raging Love), 2013; some episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2001-14; and a special appearance in TV5’s My Driver, Sweet Lover, 2010-11.

Lorena received awards for her performances—notably, the Best Supporting Actress award from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) for her role of Nena Ojeda, the gentle and overprotective mother in Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982. She also won the Gawad Urian and the Catholic Mass Media Award trophies for Best Supporting Actress for her performance in Miguelito: Batang Rebelde (Miguelito: Young Rebel), 1985. She was chosen Best Actress by the Metro Manila Film Festival for the “Banga” episode of Halimaw (Monster), 1986. For her work in Presa (Female Prisoner), 2010, a film that follows the lives of women in a correctional facility, Lorena got Best Supporting Actress nominations from the FAP and the Gawad Urian. Written byNenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Erika Carreon

LUCAS, JESSE(Jesse Uy Lucas) b. Manila 11 Mar 1969. Pianist; composer of music for dance, theater, film, and TV; and music director. He is the only son of Elsie Uy and Jesus Lucas. He started playing the piano at age five. He got a bachelor’s degree in psychology, cum laude, from Saint Louis University in Baguio City, preparatory to a medical degree in the late 1980s. But instead, he pursued studies in music at the University of the Philippines College of Music, studying composition under Chino Toledo and Ryan Cayabyab in the early 1990s.

Lucas’s forte is in the field of collaborative musical multimedia or works that integrate other art media, like voice, words, images, movement, and narrative, into a composition. For music theater, he composed original Filipino musicals for Tanghalang Pilipino, such as Aguinaldo 1898, 1998, and Ang Pagpatay kay Luna (The Assassination of Luna), 2002. For dance, he composed full-length ballets for the Philippine Ballet Theater (namely, Bonifacio, 1997; Sarimanok, 1998; Darangen ni Bantugen, 2008; and Chanted Journeys, 2010) and Ballet Philippines (Darna , 2003). Aside from these, he did collaborative works with Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas, Drama tis Personae, and Gantimpala Theater Foundation.

In broadcast media, Lucas made scores for noted teleserye (TV drama series) such as Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), 2006 and 2008; Kahit Isang Saglit (Even for a Moment), 2008; Lovers in Paris, 2009; Magkaribal (Rivals), 2010; and Princess and I, 2012.

His music for films reaped awards such as the Gawad Urian Best Music Score for Babae sa Breakwater (Woman of Breakwater), 2003; the Young Critics Circle Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration for Phone Sex, 1999, Sugatang Puso (Wounded Heart), 2000, Minsan May Isang Puso (Once There Was a Heart), 2001, Babae sa Breakwater, and Sigaw (The Echo), 2004; the Star Awards Best Music Score for Filipinas, 2003; the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Music Score for 9 Mornings, 2003, Filipinas, Mano Po 3: My Love, 2004, Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo (Partner, Participant, Partaker), 2006, and A Love Story, 2007; and the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) Best Original Song for Babae (Woman), 1997, and Best Music Score for Luksong Tinik (Game of Thorns), 1999. He won Best Music at the 2005 Screamfest International Film Festival in Los Angeles for the film Sigaw. In 2010, he was elevated to the FAMAS Hall of Fame as a music scorer.

In 2015, Lucas’s most outstanding works were showcased in a successful concert at the CCP titled “Full Range: Triple Threats,” featuring his colleagues in the professional art world of dance, theater, and music. In that year, he also released a CD album titled Ginugunita Kita (Remembering You), featuring his eight settings of Maningning Miclat’s suite of poems Voice from the Underworld, 2000. Written by José S. Buenconsejo

LUCERO, SID (Timothy Mark Pimentel Eigenmann) b. Manila 12 Mar 1981. Film and television actor. He is the son of actors Bing Pimentel and Mark Gil. He is the brother of Maxene Eigenmann and half-brother of Gabby, Ira, Andi, and Stephani Cherie Eigenmann. He took up a technical theater course at De La Salle College of Saint Benilde. Lucero’s stage name was taken from his father’s character in Mike de Leon’s Batch ’81, 1982.

Although he already belongs to a family of actors, he made a name for himself in film and television. His first screen appearance was for the GMA Network drama series Hanggang Kailan (Circle of Hearts), 2004, topbilled by veteran actors Christopher de Leon, Lorna Tolentino, and Alice Dixson. In 2006, he made his presence felt in the film Donsol, Adolf Alix’s entry in the 2nd Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. He then appeared in various award-winning indie films like Selda (The Inmate) and Tambolista (Drumbeat), 2007; Paglipad ng Anghel (Flight of an Angel), 2011; and Norte, Hangganan ng Kasaysayan (Norte, The End of History), 2013. He won the Best Actor award, shared with his co-star Emilio Garcia, for Selda at Thessaloniki International Film Festival in Greece. He also won the Gawad Urian Best Actor trophy for the same film. At the 2007 Cinema One Originals Film Festival, he won Best Actor for Tambolista.

In 2010, Lucero gained international recognition with his nomination as Best Actor at the International Emmy Awards for his appearance in the primetime series Dahil May Isang Ikaw (Because There Is You), 2009-10. Lucero also starred in the television drama Amaya, 2011-12, and the historical docudrama Katipunan, 2013, a story about Filipino hero Andres Bonifacio and the revolution he led. Both drama series were produced by GMA Network. Written byKathrina Alvarez

LUNA, EDNA b.San Antonio, Cavite City 14 Feb 1938. Actor. She was born to Juan Luna and Aurea Miñon, and graduated from Cavite National High School. She has four children, and now resides in Las Vegas, Nevada, USA.

Luna appeared in her first film, Aklat ng Buhay (Book of Life), in 1952. She was an extra at Sampaguita Pictures and LVN Pictures before she became a contract star of Premiere Productions. She starred in Premiere’s hit movie Dyesebel, 1953, directed by Gerardo de Leon from the popular Pilipino Komiks novel. Among her other movies are Gerardo de Leon’s Banga ni Zimadar (Zimadar’s Jar), 1953, a costume movie; period films like Eskrimador (Sword Fighter) and El Jugador (The Gambler), 1955, with Jose Romulo; Sa Kabila ng Bukas (In Spite of Tomorrow), 1953, with Jose Padilla Jr; Paladin, Si Eva at si Adan (Eve and Adam), and Pedro Penduko, 1954; Guerrero, 1955; Apat na Kasaysayang Ginto (Four Golden Stories), Santa Lucia, Cinco Hermanas (Five Sisters), and Exzur, 1956, with Danilo Montes; Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), with Zaldy Zshornack, and Kamay ni Cain (Hand of Cain), 1957; Obra Maestra (Masterpiece), “Macao Story,” 1958; Mr. Basketball and Anak ng Lasengga (Child of a Drunkard Woman), 1958; Anak ng Bulkan (Child of the Volcano), 1959; Konsiyerto ng Kamatayan (Concert of Death), 1961; and Anak ni Dyesebel (Dyesebel’s Child), 1964. Written byCesar Hernando

LVN PICTURES Established in 1938 by Narcisa Buencamino vda de Leon, Carmen Villongco, and Eleuterio Navoa Jr, from whose initials the name LVN was formed, it was one of the Big Three studios during what was called the golden age of the studio system in the 1950s. It dominated the movie industry for three decades, producing both entertainment-oriented pictures and socially relevant films. Executive producer Narcisa de Leon aka Doña Sisang became involved in the movie industry when in 1934 she bought a movie house on her lot on Rizal Avenue. Later she was encouraged to produce her own pictures with her eldest son, Manuel de Leon, as general manager. The studio was at P. Tuazon Boulevard in Cubao, Quezon City.

LVN’s first movie, Giliw Ko (My Love), 1939, directed by Carlos Vander Tolosa, starring Mila del Sol and Fernando Poe, was a commercial success and had a run in the USA for the Filipino community. It was premiered at the Metropolitan Theater with President Manuel L. Quezon as guest of honor. The studio made over 350 films, from musical comedy pictures, such as the Nida Blanca–Nestor de Villa starrer Waray-Waray, 1954, to costume adventure movies like Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante) and Apat na Alas (Four Aces), 1950, to films that are now considered classics of Philippine cinema, like Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941; Victory Joe and Garrison 13, 1946; Higit sa Lahat (Above All), 1955; Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956; Badjao, 1957; and Biyaya ng Lupa (Blessings of the Land), 1959. LVN produced or developed some of local cinema’s greatest talents—among them, directors Lamberto V. Avellana, Gregorio Fernandez, Manuel Conde, and Manuel Silos; actors Tony Santos, Armando Goyena, Jaime de la Rosa, Lilia Dizon, Tessie Quintana, Mario Montenegro, Rosa Rosal, Charito Solis, and Nida Blanca; and cinematographers Mike Accion and Remigio Young.

LVN was active in movie production from 1939 to 1961. Since the institution of the Maria Clara Awards in 1950, when Doña Sisang received the Producer of the Year award and Tony Santos won Best Supporting Actor for Hantik (Black Ant), 1950, LVN Pictures had taken a big share of movie awards. Among the LVN films that won awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) are Korea, 1952, Best Supporting Actor for Gil de Leon and Best Supporting Actress for Nida Blanca; Huk sa Bagong Pamumuhay (Huk in a New Life), 1953, Best Director for Lamberto V. Avellana, Best Actor for Jose Padilla Jr, and Best Supporting Actor for Leroy Salvador; Higit sa Lahat (Above All), 1955, Best Picture, Best Director for Gregorio Fernandez, Best Actor for Rogelio de la Rosa, Best Story for Mario Mijares Lopez, Best Sound for July Hidalgo, and Best Editing for Enrique Jarlego Sr; Sonny Boy, 1955, Best Actress for Rosa Rosal and Best Screenplay for Susana de Guzman; Ikaw Kasi (You Are to Blame), 1955, Best Color Photography; Philippine Rhapsody, 1955, Best Featurette in Color; Luksang Tagumpay (Dark Victory), 1956, Best Picture and Best Cinematography for Remigio Young; Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1957, Best Cinematography for Mike Accion; Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1957, International Prestige Award of Merit; Gerilyang Patpat (Stick Guerillas), 1958, Best Short Feature; Malvarosa, 1958, International Prestige Award of Merit; Biyaya ng Lupa, 1959, Best Picture and Best Story for Celso Al. Carunungan; Kundiman ng Lahi (Love Song of the Race), 1959, Best Actress for Charito Solis; Emily, 1960, Best Actress for Charito Solis; Bayanihan (Community Spirit) and My Serenade, both International Prestige Award of Merit, 1961.

On the international scene, LVN films received awards from various film festivals as follows: Kandelerong Pilak (Silver Candlesticks), Best Actress (Lilia Dizon), 1954 Cambodian Film Festival; Anak Dalita, Best Picture, 1956 Asian Film Festival in Hong Kong; Higit sa Lahat, Best Director (Gregorio Fernandez) and Best Actor (Rogelio de la Rosa), 1956 Asian Film Festival; Badjao, Best Director (Lamberto V. Avellana), Best Screenplay (Rolf Bayer), Best Cinematography (Mike Accion), and Best Editing (Gregorio Carballo), 1957 Asian Film Festival in Tokyo; Malvarosa, Best Supporting Actress (Rebecca del Rio), 1958 Asian Film Festival in Manila; Biyaya ng Lupa, Best Supporting Actor (Leroy Salvador), 1960 Asian Film Festival in Tokyo; Bayanihan, Special Cultural Award, 1960 Asian Film Festival; and My Serenade, special award for Best Comedy Film, 1961 Asian Film Festival.

LVN’s firsts in Filipino movies include Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941, the first Filipino movie with color sequences painted frame by frame; Orasang Ginto (Golden Clock), 1946, the first Filipino post-World War II movie; Batalyon XIII (13th Battalion), 1949, the first Filipino full-color movie; Rodrigo de Villa, 1952, the first Filipino co-production with a foreign film company, P.T. Persari of Indonesia; and Bahala Na (Come What May), 1956, the first Filipino movie filmed in widescreen.

After World War, LVN Pictures set up a full color processing laboratory. Despite the fact that film company was no longer active in moviemaking in the 1970s, it continued to offer color processing and postproduction facilities and was usually credited as LVN Studios, LVN Laboratory, or LVN Digital, well into the mid-2000s.

In 1977, Doña Sisang’s grandson, Mike de Leon, regarded as one of the country’s leading contemporary directors, made Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (When You Dream and Wake Up) as the studio’s centennial celebration of Doña Sisang’s birthday. It received awards for Best Music (Jun Latonio) and Best Sound (Ramon Reyes and Luis Reyes) at the Gawad Urian in 1978. Mike de Leon’s Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (Will Your Heart Beat Faster?), 1980, was the last film produced by the studio. In 1981, it received from the Gawad Urian the awards for Best Music (Lorie Ilustre), Best Sound (Ramon Reyes), Best Editing (Ike Jarlego Jr), Best Supporting Actor (Johnny Delgado), and Best Director (Mike de Leon). Its restored and remastered version was shown on the big screen at Trinoma in December 2015.

In 1989, LVN celebrated its 50th anniversary with a film retrospective at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Shortly after the closure of LVN Pictures, media conglomerate ABS-CBN acquired the extant LVN films. The LVN collection is now being archived in the ABS-CBN Archives in Quezon City. Some films are screened now and then via ABS-CBN cable television channel Cinema One.

The LVN film memorabilia are stored at the Lopez Memorial Museum in Pasig City. The museum is now home to 12,250 rare and original photos, posters, music sheets, scripts, and newspaper clippings of about 327 LVN movies and productions from 1939 to 1965. Written byMauro Tumbocon Jr, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

MACAMAY, VIC(Victor Mercado Macamay) b. Tacloban City, 26 Mar 1945. Movie sound engineer. Born to Julio Macamay and Paula Mercado, he was married to Estrella Villegas, with whom he had eight children. He attended Mapua High School and finished a two-year electronics course at the Philippine Center for Arts and Trade. Macamay worked for five years at AdSmith, an advertising company, where he trained in various aspects of postproduction. Later, he worked as soundman for JE Productions and Magnatech.

He did much of his work for PremiereProductions International. His patience and skill made him a favorite choice of top movie producers and directors, and a mentor to many promising sound technicians. Among his works are Himala (Miracle) and Relasyon (An Affair), 1982; Broken Marriage and Paano Ba ang Mangarap? (How Does One Dream?), 1983; Bulaklak sa City Jail (Flowers of the City Jail), 1984; Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), Tinik sa Dibdib (Thorn in the Heart), and Muling Buksan ang Puso (Open the Heart Once Again), 1985; Palimos ng Pag-ibig (Begging for Love), Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (I Wish This Were Forever), Gabi na, Kumander (It’s Nighttime, Commander), and Magdusa Ka (Suffer), 1986; Kapag Napagod ang Puso (When the Heart Tires) and Hiwaga (Mystery), 1988; Rosenda, Kapag Langit ang Humatol (Heaven’s Judgment), and Sa Kabila ng Lahat (Despite Everything), 1989.

He received four awards for sound: for Bakit May Pag-ibig Pa (Wherefore Love), 1979, from Gawad Urian; Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan? (How Often Is Once?), 1983, from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) and the FilipinoAcademyofMovie ArtsandSciences; and Biktima (Victim), 1990, from FAP. Written by Raquel Hernandez, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

MAGALONA, PANCHO (Enrique Gayoso Magalona Jr) b. Sarabia, Negros Occidental 22 Jan 1923. d. Manila Apr 1998. Movie and television actor. His parents are Consuelo Gayoso and ex-senator Enrique Magalona Sr. He married actor Tita Duran who died in 1990. One of their children is the late Francis Magalona, rap singer and movie actor, whose children, Maxene Magalona and Elmo Magalona, are movie and TV actors. He studied at Ateneo de Manila.

His first film appearance was, upon the recommendation of former First Lady Aurora Aragon Quezon, for a part in Prima Donna, 1947. Later, he was assigned a prime role in Tatlong Bulaklak (Three Flowers), 1947. His first movie in Sampaguita Pictures was Bulaklak na Walang Pangalan (Flower with No Name), 1948, a love story based on Hilaria Labog’s serialized novel. This was followed by Dahil sa Iyo (Because of You), 1948, an adaptation of Dr Fausto J. Galauran’s Liwayway novel, which was inspired by the composition of Mike Velarde. In both films, his leading lady was former child star Tita Duran. By the time they made Eddie Romero’s Sa Piling Mo (In Your Arms), 1949, the Pancho-Tita on-screen/offscreen romance had captured the imagination of screen audiences. After their marriage, Magalona made films with other leading ladies, but Duran appeared only with Magalona in such romantic musicals as Huwag Ka Nang Magtampo (No Hard Feelings), Umaga Na Giliw (Morning Has Come, Love), and Kay Ganda Mo, Neneng (You Are So Beautiful, Neneng), 1950; Kasintahan sa Pangarap (Sweetheart in My Dreams), 1951; Vod-a-Vil (Vaudeville) and Sa Isang Sulyap Mo, Tita (With One Glance from You, Tita), 1953; and its sequel, Sa Isang Halik Mo, Pancho (With One Kiss from You, Pancho), 1954.

After his contract with Sampaguita expired, Pancho freelanced in films like Gerardo de Leon’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1962, where he played the character of Simoun; Bella Filipina (Beautiful Filipina), 1956; Mr. and Mrs., 1956, where he teamed up again with Tita Duran; and Cry Freedom, 1959, a war film by Lamberto V. Avellana. He played lead in more than 80 movies like Maharlika (The Noble Race), 1948; Milagro ng Birhen ng mga Rosas (Miracle of the Virgin of the Roses), 1949; Buhay Pilipino (Filipino Life), 1952; and Ang Ating Pag-ibig (Our Love), 1953. He also did several American films. He appeared opposite Nida Blanca in Tayo’y Magsaya (Let’s Have Fun), 1959; with Rosa Rosal in Cry Freedom, 1959; with Charito Solis in Emily, 1960, and Luis Latigo (Luis the Whip), 1961; and with Lita Gutierrez in Tres Mosqueteros (Three Musketeers), 1960. In 1970 he appeared in Luis Nepomuceno Productions’ Pipo, set during the Japanese Occupation.

Magalona won a Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Actor award for his performance in Hanggang sa Dulo ng Daigdig (To the Ends of the Earth), 1958. Written byGalileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu
(See MUSIC volume.)

MALAYAN MOVIES Founded on 15 May 1917 by Jose Nepomuceno, it was one of the first movie production companies organized by a Filipino. A reaction to the dominance of Hollywood movies in the country, it developed a monopoly of production for nearly six years during the era of silent films. The first production of Malayan Movies was the popular sarsuwela Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), written by Hermogenes Ilagan. The movie, which starred Atang de la Rama, premiered in September 1919 and became a hit. One of Malayan’s films, Ang Tatlong Hambog (The Three Braggarts), 1926, is well remembered because it featured the first lips-to-lips kissing scene on-screen, between Luis Tuason and Elizabeth “Dimples” Cooper.

In 1930, Malayan produced the much-acclaimed Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), and in 1933 its first talking picture, Punyal na Ginto (Golden Dagger).

Nepomuceno, however, had to stop operations later on due to increasing problems in distribution and exhibition. In the latter part of the 1960s, his son Luis Nepomuceno put up Nepomuceno Productions, which made big-budget films like Dahil sa Isang Bulaklak (Because of a Flower), Pipo, and Manila: Open City, 1967; Ang Pulubi (The Beggar), 1969; and The Pacific Connection, 1974.

Other silent films of Malayan Movies are Un Capullo Marchito (One Withered Bud), 1920; Hoy O Nunca, Besame (Now or Never, Kiss Me), 1922; Mariposa Negra (Black Butterfly), 1923; The Filipino Woman, 1927; Ang Manananggal (The Viscera Sucker), 1929; Maria Luisa, 1930; and Anak sa Ligaw (Child by Courtship), 1930, a film based on the novel by Julian Cruz Balmaseda which introduced Gregorio Fernandez to screen audiences for the first time.

Among the early “talkies” of Malayan Movies are Dr. Kuba (Dr Hunchback), Magkabilang Mukha (Both Faces), and Ang Ganid (The Greedy One), 1933; Ang Kamay ng Diyos (The Hand of God) and Sawing Palad (The Unfortunate), 1934; and Krus na Bato (Stone Cross), 1936. Written by Mauro Tumbocon Jr

MANALO, JAY(Jay Lan Manalo) b. Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam 30 Jan 1973. Television and movie actor. Manalo was born in Vietnam but was raised by his grandmother in Tondo, Manila. His father, Eustaquio G. Manalo Jr, was a Filipino musician who was based in Vietnam where he met Manalo’s Vietnamese mother.

Manalo first appeared on film through Una Kang Naging Akin (You Were Mine First), 1991, and Parañaque Bank Robbery, 1993. His major film debut, Brat Pack, came in 1994. This was followed by action films Urban Rangers, 1995, and Paracale Gang, 1996. Moving from action to sexy films, he starred in Gayuma (Love Potion), 1996, which was then followed by Totoy Mola, 1997, and more sexy films like Kaliwa’t Kanan, Sakit sa Katawan (Left and Right, Body Pain), 1997; Bayad Puri (Paid with Dignity), 1998; and Balahibong Pusa (Cat’s Fur), 2001.

Aside from action and sexy roles, he also moved to more serious and dramatic roles through Bayaran (For Hire), 2002, which won him Best Actor in the Gawad Urian and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences; Prosti (Prostitute), 2002, winning for him the Best Actor in the Gawad Urian; and Ang Huling Birhen sa Lupa (The Last Virgin), 2003. He also starred in well-known films like Aishite Imasu 1941 (I Love You), Mano Po 3: My Love (I Kiss Your Hand 3: My Love), I Will Survive, Gagamboy (Spider Boy), and Feng Shui, 2004; Mano Po 4: Ako Legal Wife (I’m the Legal Wife), 2005; and Shake, Rattle & Roll 13, 2011.

On television, Manalo started with the reality TV series Ang TV in 1992. He jumpstarted his career in television with Mula sa Puso (From the Heart) in 1997, produced by ABS-CBN. He also made appearances in Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000, and Kung Mawawala Ka (A World without You), 2002. These were followed by distinguished television series like Vietnam Rose, 2005; Bakekang, 2006; Zaido: Pulis Pangkalawakan (Zaido: Police of the Universe), 2007; All My Life, 2009; and The Last Prince, 2010. He continued to appear on TV the following decade with Ang Utol Kong Hoodlum (My Hoodlum Brother), 2011; Isang Dakot na Luha (A Handful of Tears), 2012; Kidlat (Lightning), 2013; and Niño (Boy), 2014. Written byChristian Co

MANANSALA, JULIAN (Julian Mendoza Manansala) b. Masantol, Pampanga 28 Jan 1896. d. 13 Nov 1970. Movie actor, director, producer. His parents are Miguel Manansala and Lucia V. Mendoza. He married Donata P. Quito, by whom he had four children. He obtained a law degree from Liceo de Manila.

Manansala was one of the pioneers of Philippine cinema and was known for producing patriotic films. In 1929, he organized his movie outfit, Oriental Film Company, with Jose Nepomuceno providing production technical services. For his initial venture, Patria Amore (Beloved Country), he was story writer, lead actor, and director. The Spanish community, sensitive to the film’s theme, tried to stop its public exhibition. However, the court allowed it and the film became an artistic and financial success. Later, Manansala changed the name of his company to Banahaw Pictures and produced such films as Dimasalang, 1930, starring Mary Walter and Gregorio Fernandez; Pag-ibig ng Kadete (Love of a Cadet), 1934, with Rosario Reyes and Amado Yuson; and Ang Kilabot ng mga Tulisan (Terror of the Bandits), 1934, starring Dolly Garcia and Faustino Zaragosa. With the advent of sound, Manansala produced the talkies Mutya ng Katipunan (Muse of the Katipunan), 1939, with Arsenia Francisco and Ricardo Brillantes, and Tawag ng Bayan (Country Call), 1939, also starring Francisco and Brillantes. Written by Nenuca Jose

MANATAD, CARLO(Carlo Francisco Yanuario Manatad) b. Victoria, Northern Samar 4 Oct 1987. Editor, director, cinematographer. He is the son of Ruben Manatad and Lorna Yanuario. He earned his bachelor of arts in film at the University of the Philippines Film Institute (UPFI), where his short film Hungkag (Hollow), 2010, received the Best Thesis award.

In 2012, when SM Cinemas gave student filmmakers grants to produce feature-length films for the SM Bigshot Film Festival, Manatad edited the works of his UPFI peers: Archie Dimaculangan,Franne Cheska Ramos,and Jose Antonio de Rivera’s Balang Araw (Some Day), and de Rivera and Bianca Catbagan’s Suntok sa Buwan (A Shot at the Moon).

Manatad went on to edit more indie films: in 2011, Charliebebs Gohetia’s Crossroads; in 2013, Jason Paul Laxamana’s Babagwa (The Spider’s Lair), Mikhail Red’s Rekorder (Recorder), Christopher Ad. Castillo’s The Diplomat Hotel, and Alvin Yapan’s Gaydar (Gay Radar); and in 2014, Louie Ignacio’s Asintado (Between the Eyes), Arlyn de la Cruz’s Maratabat (Pride and Honor), Kip Oebanda’s Tumbang Preso (In the Can), Francis Xavier Pasion’s Bwaya (Crocodile), Zig Dulay’s M.: Mother’s Maiden Name. For Khavn de la Cruz, Manatad edited EDSA XXX and Ruined Heart, 2014. For Richard Somes, he edited Mariposa sa Hawlang Gabi (Mariposa in the Cage of the Night) and Supremo (Supreme Chief), 2012. His work in Chito Roño’s Badil (Dynamite Fishing), 2013, earned for Manatad the Indie Movie Editor of the Year award from the Star Awards for Movies.

Manatad also edited films for the mainstream, including Roño’s Boy Golden: Shoot-to-Kill; The Arturo Porcuna Story, 2013, co-edited with Jason Cahapay and Ryan Orduña; the segment “Lost Command” in Roño’s Shake, Rattle & Roll XIV: The Invasion, 2013; and Antoinette Jadaone’s Beauty in a Bottle, 2014.

Manatad’s short film Oasis Redux, 2012, was screened in various festivals abroad, including the 2013 Cannes Film Festival, Short Film Corner. He was a fellow at the 2010 Asian Film Academy in South Korea, the 2012 Berlinale Talent Campus in Germany, and the 2014 DOCNET Campus in Indonesia. He also directs and edits television advertisements and music videos. Written by Patrick Campos

MANGANSAKAN, GUTIERREZ II(Gutierrez Matalam Mangansakan II) aka Teng Mangansakan. b. Cotabato City 30 May 1976. Director, writer, producer, actor, cinematographer. He is the son of Gutierrez Mangansakan, a former government official and undersecretary of the Department of Education, and Bai Matalam, a former mayor of Pagalungan, Mindanao. He took up mass communication at Ateneo de Davao University and development communication at the University of Southern Mindanao.

Mangansakan’s first film is a documentary called House under the Crescent Moon, 2002, about his grandfather’s ancestral house, which serves as a metaphor for the history of the struggles of the Moro peoples. Most of his other films were directed, produced, written, and edited by him, such as Limbunan (The Bridal Quarter), 2010; Cartas de la Soledad (Letters of Solitude), 2011; Qiyamah (The Reckoning) and Obscured Histories and Silent Longings of Daguluan’s Children, 2012. His other works are Daughters of the Three Tailed Banner, Under a Canopy of Light, and Forbidden Memory, 2016. Limbunan had the distinction of being the closing film of the 2010 Venice International Film Festival.

Mangansakan won the grand prize in the 2002 Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video for House under the Crescent Moon. He received the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) and the Golden Hanoman Awards from Jogja-NETPAC Film Festival in 2012 for Cartas de la Soledad. On the same year, he won the Lino Brocka Award and Best Director for Obscured Histories and Silent Longings of Daguluan’s Children in the Digital Lokal section of Cinemanila International Film Festival. In 2013, Mangansakan won the Best Film and Best Editing awards—the latter shared with Arnel Barbarona—from the Young Critics Circle (YCC) Film Desk for Qiyamah. In 2016, he won the Grand Jury Prize from the World Premieres Film Festival for Daughters of the Three Tailed Banner.

Mangansakan is also the editor of two anthologies on Moro writing: Children of the Ever-Changing Moon, 2007, and Rays of the Invisible Light, 2015. He is also an essayist. In 2013, Mangansakan started an important international film festival in Mindanao, the SalaMindanaw Asian Film Festival. Written by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu, with notes from Nicanor G. Tiongson

MANIO, JIRO (Jiro Santos Katakura) b. Manila 9 May 1992. Television and movie actor. He is the son of Yusuke Katakura and Joylene Santos. He graduated from high school at Rizal Experimental Station and Pilot School of Cottages Inc at the age of 19. He has two daughters, Sisha Calliope and Mishka Caxiopeia.

Manio started his career at the age of seven, but what catapulted him to popularity was his performance in the film Magnifico, 2003, where he won Best Actor in the Gawad Urian, Best Actor in the Film Academy of the Philippines Awards, and Best Child Actor in the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards. Manio was also recognized as Best Child Performer by the Metro Manila Film Festival for his role as Francis in the Marilou Diaz-Abaya movie Bagong Buwan (New Moon) in 2001. Manio displayed worthy performances in Mila, 2002; Foster Child, 2006; and Tambolista (Drumbeat), 2007. Manio also appeared as Shammy in the hit comedy film Ang Tanging Ina (The One and Only Mom), 2003, and the sequels Ang Tanging Ina N’yong Lahat (Everyone’s One and Only Mom), 2008, and Ang Tanging Ina Mo, Last na ’To! (Your One and Only Mom, This Is the Last One!), 2010. He also portrayed a gay character named Orwell in the films Manay Po! (I Am Gay!), 2006, and Manay Po 2: Overload, 2008. His other films include La Vida Rosa (The Life of Rosa), 2001; Anghel sa Lupa (Angel on Earth), 2003; Green Paradise, 2007; Bahay Kubo (Nipa Hut), 2007; and Ang Lihim ni Antonio (Antonio’s Secret), 2008.

Manio was part of ABS-CBN’s Star Magic from 2000 to 2009. He also appeared in GMA Network’s Pilyang Kerubin (The Naughty Cherubim), 2010, and Little Star, 2010. Written by Kathrina Alvarez

MANUNURI NG PELIKULANG PILIPINO(Critics of Filipino Cinema) aka Urian, Gawad Urian. The first organized film critics group in the Philippines, the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino (MPP) was established in 1976 by Pio de Castro III, Behn Cervantes, Petronilo Bn. Daroy, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Justino Dormiendo, Mario A. Hernando, Bienvenido Lumbera, and Nicanor G. Tiongson, with Nestor Torre as founding chair and Manny Pichel as secretary.

In the same year, the MPP held the first Gawad Urian, with Eddie Romero’s Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?), 1976, winning the awards for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, and Best Production Design. The awards for Best Cinematography, Best Editing, Best Music, and Best Sound were given to Mike de Leon’s Itim (Rites of May), 1976. The acting awards went to Nora Aunor, Best Actress for Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos (Three Godless Years), 1976; Vic Silayan, Best Actor for Ligaw na Bulaklak (Wildflower), 1976; Maya Valdez, Best Supporting Actress for Lunes, Martes … (Monday, Tuesday …), 1976; Yvonne, Best Supporting Actress for Ligaw na Bulaklak; and Ruel Vernal, Best Supporting Actor for Insiang, 1976. The first Natatanging Gawad Urian, a lifetime achievement award, was given to producer Manuel de Leon.

The MPP also gives out awards for short films and documentaries. The MPP also names the Gawad Urian Best Actor and Best Actress of the Decade, the 10 Best Films of the Decade, and, once, they gave a special Golden Award for Mike de Leon’s Aliwan Paradise (Entertainment Paradise) in 1992.

On its 25th anniversary, the MPP cited 10 Filipino films as the best of Philippine cinema from 1976 to 2001—namely, Lino Brocka’s Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975, Insiang, 1976, and Orapronobis (Fight for Us), 1989; Ishmael Bernal’s Nunal sa Tubig (Speck in the Water), 1976, Manila by Night / City after Dark, 1980, and Himala (Miracle), 1982; Mike de Leon’s Kisapmata (In the Blink of an Eye), 1981, Batch ’81, 1982, and Bayaning 3rd World (Third World Hero), 1999; and Eddie Romero’s Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon?

Coming from various academic and professional backgrounds, the members of the MPP wield different styles and critical judgments in their film reviews and criticism. However, they have abided by two avowed agenda in their writings, which are to “make audiences more critical of the films which, whether they realize it or not, have an impact on their lives” and to “give producers systematic feedback on their products.” The articles, reviews, and interviews of the MPP members were anthologized and edited in four volumes by Manunuri Nicanor Tiongson: The Urian Anthology 1970-1979, 1983, The Urian Anthology 1980-1989, 2001, The Urian Anthology 1990-1999, 2010, and The Urian Anthology 2000-2009, 2013, which altogether document and provide commentary on four decades of Philippine cinema.

The current members of the MPP are co-founders Hernando, Lumbera, and Tiongson, with Grace Javier Alfonso, Butch Francisco, Miguel Q. Rapatan, Benilda S. Santos, Rolando B. Tolentino, and Tito Genova Valiente. Former members include Mario E. Bautista, Isagani Cruz, Joel David, Paul Daza, Christian Ma. Guerrero, Alice Guillermo, Jose Sevilla Ho, Ricardo Lee, Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo, Mauro Feria Tumbocon Jr (aka Mike Feria), Ellen Paglinauan, Tezza O. Parel, Emmanuel A. Reyes, Jun Cruz Reyes, Agustin L. Sotto, Alfred A. Yuson, and Lito Zulueta. Written byPatrick Campos

MANZANO, EDU(Eduardo Barrios Manzano) aka Doods. b. San Francisco, California 14 Sep 1955. Actor, host, and politician. His parents are Adriano Manzano and Nenita Barrios. He is the father of host-actor Luis Manzano by his previous marriage to actor Vilma Santos. Manzano has two other children with former model Rina Samson. He was also briefly married to actor Maricel Soriano.

At 17, Manzano joined the United States Armed Forces. After his four-year military service, he came to the Philippines and entered showbiz. Manzano is best remembered for the film version of Captain Barbell, 1986; Separada (Separated Woman), 1994; and Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000. He is also known for his villain roles. He was awarded Best Supporting Actor by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for the movie Kaaway ng Batas (Enemy of the Law), 1990. He also earned nominations for Palimos ng Pag-ibig (Begging for Love), 1986; Contreras Gang, 1991; Ama, Ina, Anak (Father, Mother, Child), 1996; and Tatarin (St John’s Day Ritual), 2001. Manzano also had hosting gigs for television such as Late Night with Edu, 1992-94; the Philippine version of The Weakest Link, 2001; and Pilipinas: Game KNB? (Philippines, Are You Game?), 2007-9, for which he was awarded Best Game Show Host in the Star Awards for Television for two consecutive years in 2007 and 2008.

Aside from show business, Manzano was also involved in public service as vice mayor of Makati from 1998 to 2001. In 2004, he was appointed chairman of the Optical Media Board, a government agency combating media piracy. He resigned in August 2009, months before his unsuccessful bid for vice president in the 2010 national elections. Written by Kathrina Alvarez

MARCELINO, RICARDO (Ricardo Francisco Marcelino) aka Mang Andoy. b. Polo, Bulacan 13 May 1892. d. Manila May 1968. Cinematographer. His parents are Bartolome Marcelino and Victoria Francisco. He married Elvira Cabangis with whom he had seven children. His deep interest in photography influenced his sons Lucio, who worked as a consultant of Kodak Philippines; Paquito, who was a photographer; and Tomas, who became a cinematographer. He taught painting at Letran for 10 years. He studied still and film photography, by correspondence, at the New York Institute of Photography. In 1915 he established his own photography studio.

In 1930 he made his first silent picture, The Tragic Death of General Luna. He also made The Song of a Fisherman, 1931. He worked as technical demonstrator in Kodak Philippines and later as cameraman for Parlatone-Hispano Filipino, Del Monte Pictures, and Sampaguita Pictures. During the Japanese Occupation, when bodabil again became the main form of entertainment, Marcelino worked for several theaters in Manila as stage lighting director. His first film after the war was Oo, Ako’y Espiya (Yes, I Am a Spy), 1947. This was followed by Wala Na Akong Luha (I Have No More Tears), 1948. Marcelino was one of the founders of Premiere Productions Inc, where he was also chief of the camera department. He was responsible for Premiere’s first color production, Ang Lumang Bahay sa Gulod (The Old House on the Cliff), 1949.

Marcelino’s innovations in the field of visual special effects, using the limited equipment during his time, can be considered his major contribution to Philippine cinema. His techniques paved the way for the development of fantasy as film genre.

He received Best Cinematography awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Habang Buhay (For a Lifetime), 1953, and for Huwag Mo Akong Limutin (Never Forget Me), 1960. Written byNenuca Jose

MARCELINO, TOMMY(Tomas Cabangis Marcelino) b. Manila 27 Dec 1914. Cinematographer. His parents are Elvira Cabangis and RicardoMarcelino. He was considered the “Dean of Filipino Cinematographers” in the 1930s and 1940s. He married former actor Ester Buenaobra. One of his sons, Ramon, is also a cinematographer. Marcelino finished high school at Colegio de San Juan de Letran but gave up college to work as photographer at the Philippines Free Press.

In 1947, Marcelino was his father’s assistant cameraman at PremiereProductions. By 1948, he was a full-fledged cameraman, doing Hiram na Pangalan (Borrowed Name) and Bulaklak at Paru-paro (Flower and Butterfly) for Premiere. He collaborated with his father in developing camera techniques and special visual effects. They shot Premiere’s first color movie, Ang Lumang Bahay sa Gulod (The Old House on the Cliff), 1949. Among his other films are Wanted: Patay o Buhay (Wanted: Dead or Alive), 1950; Sisa and Santa Cristina (Saint Cristina), 1951; Rosa Villa, 1953; Pedro Penduko, 1954; Apollo Robles, 1961; Ako ang Katarungan (I Am Justice), 1962; Si Adiang Waray (Adiang the Waray) and Kami’y Kaawaan (Have Mercy on Us), 1963; Mabangis: Walang Patawad (Cruel: Merciless) and Prinsesang Kalapati (Pigeon Princess), 1964; Nympho, Batuta ni Drakula (Dracula’s Nightstick), and Avenida Boy, 1971; Lipad, Darna, Lipad (Fly, Darna, Fly), 1973; Pandemonium, 1975; Isinumpa (Cursed) and Peter Pan de Sal (Peter the Bread of Salt), 1977; Dyesebel, 1978; Darna, Kuno? (They Say It’s Darna), Kuwatog, and Tonyong Bayawak (Tonyo the Water Monitor Lizard), 1979; Darna at Ding (Darna and Ding) and Enteng-Anting (Enteng the Talisman), 1980; and Kamakalawa (Day before Yesterday), 1981.

Marcelino won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Cinematography award for Paltik (Homemade Gun), 1955. Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

MARDOQUIO, ARNEL(Arnel Mutia Mardoquio) b. Davao City 20 Sep 1964. Director, screenwriter, producer, playwright, lyricist, fictionist. He is the son of Manuel Tambor Mardoquio and Almida Mutia. Born and raised in Davao City, his filmic materials are primarily based on life in Mindanao; his narratives are tapestry-like in their multicharacter and multi-setting structures, and his themes are vehicles for his self-avowed peace advocacy.

Mardoquio’s first film, Hunghong sa Yuta (Earth’s Whisper), 2008, is set in a mountain community where Christians, Muslims, and lumads (indigenous people) all have to survive the ongoing conflict between the military and the rebel forces. It revolves around the character of a deaf-mute boy who sees the tragedies of war that befall even those whose lives have been devoted to reconciliation and education. His second film, Hospital Boat, 2009, is a narrative organized around the roving medical mission of development workers in the coastal villages of Sulu. The film depicts the poverty-stricken lives of island communities inhabited by different cultures and religions, as well as the efforts of selfless individuals that run counter to the purposes of warlords and despots.

Sheika, 2010, follows the travails of the titular character as she runs away from war-torn Jolo, where she lost her husband, to take shelter in the equally devastating city of Davao, where she loses her two sons. The film was awarded Best Film by the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema at the 2010 Cinemanila International Film Festival (CIFF) and Best Screenplay and Best Actress (Fe GingGing Hyde) at the 2011 Gawad Urian.

Mardoquio’s succeeding films probe further the many facets of war and the people that become helplessly involved in it. Crossfire, 2011, follows the lives of bakwits or displaced refugees who are caught between warring factions and are forced to take sides. Ang Paglalakbay ng mga Bituin sa Gabing Madilim(The Journey of Stars into the Dark Night), 2012, traces the escape of Faidal, whose parents were once Muslim freedom fighters but ended up as kidnap-for-ransom bandits. When he ends up orphaned, with a bagful of money, Faidal flees, with the aid of his relatives and with local and American troops, as well as the military, hot on his trail. The film received the Jury Prize at the 2012 Cinema One Originals Film Festival and the 2012 CIFF, as well as the Best Screenplay award from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk in 2013.

Ang mga Tigmo sa Akong Pagpauli (Riddles of My Homecoming), 2013, is an experimental feature-length film without dialogue. Shot in typhoon-ravaged Compostela Valley, dreamlike imagery rather than narrative drives the film and its visualization of the conflicted history of Mindanao. It won Best Director, Best Cinematography, Best Production Design, Best Music, and the Special Jury Prize in the 2013 Cinema One Originals Film Festival and Best Editing in the 2014 Gawad Urian.

Alienasyon (Alienation), 2014, is not set in Mindanao but in the “Diliman Estates,” although it follows the trajectory of Ang mga Tigmo sa Akong Pagpauli in its interest in history and war. Alienasyon centers on the memories of a university professor who recalls his youth during the war and depicts how land, along with time, changes. Written byPatrick Campos

MARIA CLARA AWARDS Established in 1950 by the Manila Times Publishing Company, the Maria Clara Awards was the first award-giving body for film in the country. It formally institutionalized movie industry awards in the Philippines.

A panel of jurists was appointed to choose the best picture of the year and to honor individual achievements in local cinema during the past year. The symbol of excellence was the Maria Clara bronze trophy designed by sculptor Guillermo E. Tolentino, later National Artist for sculpture. The first Maria Clara Awards for the year 1950 were conferred on winners at ceremonies held at the Golden Lotus, Bay View Hotel, Manila, on 8 Jul 1951. The first honorees were Doña Narcisa vda de Leon of LVN Pictures, Producer of the Year; Kamay ni Satanas (Hand of Satan), Best Picture; Gerardo de Leon, Best Director, for Kamay …; Nena Cardenas, Best Actress, for Doble Cara (Two Faces); Reynaldo Dante, Best Actor for Kamay …; Alicia Vergel, Best Supporting Actress for Mapuputing Kamay (White Hands); Tony Santos, Best Supporting Actor, for Hantik (Black Ant); Julio Esteban Anguita, Best Music Score for The Spell; Higino Fallorina, Best Cinematographer for Baguio Cadets; Charles Gray, Best Sound Director for The Spell; and Mila Nimfa, Best Child Performer for Nanay Ko (My Mother).

The Maria Clara Awards was short-lived; it lasted only for two years. The second and last awards night was held at the Riviera on 30 Jan 1952. The panel of judges who chose the Best Picture and most outstanding performances of 1951 was headed by Narciso Pimentel as chair with the following members: Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, Sarah Joaquin, Ramon Tapales, and Joaquin Roces. The guest of honor, Vice-President Fernando Lopez, awarded the Maria Clara trophies to the following winners: Judge Jose O. Vera of Sampaguita Pictures, Producer of the Year; Sisa, Best Picture; Eddie Romero, Best Director for Prinsesa at Pulubi (The Princess and the Pauper); Jose Padilla Jr, Best Actor for Diego Silang; Anita Linda, Best Actress for Sisa; Andres Iturbi, Best Supporting Actor for Diego Silang; Rosa Mia, Best Supporting Actress for Roberta; Teodorico Santos, Best Screenplay for Diego Silang; Tito Arevalo, Best Music Score for Diego Silang; Higino Fallorina, Best Cinematography for Roberta; and Tessie Agana, Best Child Performer for Prinsesa at Pulubi.

The Maria Clara Awards ceased when the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) was established in 1952. The FAMAS took over the function of recognizing yearly outstanding achievements in the movie industry.

In 2006, when FAMAS members were divided into two factions, one group revived the Maria Clara Awards. It was called the 55th Maria Clara Awards like it was the continuation of the FAMAS. Blue Moon by Regal Entertainment garnered four major awards: Best Picture, Best Director (Joel Lamangan), Best Story (Allen Tijano), and Best Cinematography (Lyle Sacris). Dubai by Star Cinema won Best Screenplay (Ricky Lee and Rafael Hidalgo), Best Sound (Arnold Reodica), Best Editing (Marya Ignacio), Best Actor (Aga Mulach), Best Actress (Claudine Barretto), and Best Supporting Actor (John Lloyd Cruz). Exodus: Tales from the Enchanted Kingdom received three awards: Best Child Performer (BJ “Tolits” Forbes), Best Visual Effects (Ignite Media Inc), and Best Production Design (Richard Somes). Other winners include Hilda Koronel, Best Supporting Actress for Nasaan Ka Man (Wherever You Are); Jessie Lucas, Best Music Score for Can This Be Love?; and Imaginary Friends, Best Special Effects for Enteng Kabisote 2: The Legend Continues. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

MARTIN, COCO(Rodel Luis Nacianceno) b. Novaliches, Quezon City 1 Nov 1981. Movie and television actor. His screen name was taken from singers Coco Lee and Ricky Martin. He earned his degree in hotel and restaurant management from the National College of Business and Arts. Martin currently lives with his grandmother who raised him.

At the age of 20, Martin started as an ABS-CBN Star Magic talent who was part of Star Circle Batch 9. He first appeared in cameo role in the film Luv Text, 2001. His independent film journey started in Brillante Mendoza’s Masahista (The Masseur), 2005. He was also part of Mendoza’s Kaleldo (Summer Heat), 2006; Tirador (Slingshot), 2007; Serbis (Service), 2008; and Kinatay (The Execution of P.), 2009, which were applauded by international audiences. His other indie films include Daybreak, 2007; Jay, 2008; Noy, 2010; and Sta. Niña, 2010. Martin received Best Performance award from the Young Critics Circle in 2006 for Masahista; Best Supporting Actor awards from the Gawad Urian and the Golden Screen Awards in 2009 for Jay; Best Performance by an Actor in a Leading Role from the Golden Screen Awards in 2010 for Kinatay; Movie Actor of the Year from Star Awards for Movies in 2011 for Noy; and Actor of the Decade award from the Gawad Urian in 2011. Martin also starred in mainstream films such as Sa ’Yo Lamang (Only Yours), 2010; Born to Love You, 2012; A Moment in Time, 2013; Maybe This Time and Feng Shui 2, 2014; and You’re My Boss and Beauty and the Bestie, 2015.

Martin joined the GMA Network in 2007 and became part of shows starting with Daisy Siete (Seven Daisies). He was also a member of the boy group The Studs. A year later, he came back to ABS-CBN and appeared in Ligaw na Bulaklak (Wildflower), 2008. He starred in the drama series Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009, which won him Best Drama Actor in the Star Awards for Television. In 2010, he appeared in the primetime drama Kung Tayo’y Magkakalayo (If We Were to Be Apart). He had his first lead role in the action series Agimat Presents: Tonyong Bayawak (Tonyo the Water Monitor Lizard), 2010. He led the TV series Minsan Lang Kita Iibigin (I Will Love You Only Once), 2011; Walang Hanggan (My Eternal), 2012, an adaptation of Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven), 1991; Juan dela Cruz, 2013; and Ikaw Lamang (No Greater Love), 2014; and FPJ’s Ang Probinsyano (FPJ’s The Country Boy), 2015. Written by Christian Co

MARTIN, RAYA(Raya Perfecto Lopez Martin) b. Manila 1984. Filmmaker. He is the son of Perfecto Martin and Nilia Lopez. He took up journalism at the University of the Philippines Baguio and later on shifted to film. He graduated from the University of the Philippines Film Institute in 2005. He was the first Filipino filmmaker accepted at the Cinéfondation Residence du Festival de Cannes in Paris, France.

Martin got interested in filmmaking through his journalist father and by being exposed to films and making videos on a camcorder at an early age. He later took an internship under Kidlat Tahimik, a prominent figure in the Philippine independent cinema. His works include the short film Bakasyon (The Visit), 2004, which was given the Ishmael Bernal Award for Young Cinema at the 2004 Cinemanila International Film Festival; Maicling Pelicula nang Ysang Indio Nacional (A Short Film about the Indio Nacional), 2005, which won the Lino Micciche Award at the 2006 Pesaro Film Festival, Italy; Ang Isla sa Dulo ng Mundo (The Island at the End of the World), 2005, which won Best Documentary at the 2005 .mov International Digital Film Festival and was also screened in the 2005 Yamagata Film Festival in Japan; the semi-autobiographical Autohystoria, 2007; Possible Lovers, 2008; Now Showing, 2008, which was given a Hubert Bals Fund film grant and was co-produced by Atopic Films; Next Attraction, 2008; Independencia (Independence), 2009; Manila, 2009, co-directed with Adolfo Alix Jr; Buenas Noches, España (Good Evening, Spain), 2011; and The Great Cinema Party, 2012. He also did a number of short films: Track Projections, 2007; Long Live Philippine Cinema! and Life Projections, 2009; Boxing in the Philippine Islands and Ars Colonia, 2011; and Scotch Pilgrim, 2013.

His recent works, the horror and experimental film How to Disappear Completely, 2013, starring Shamaine and Nonie Buencamino, was screened in Locarno Film Festival in Switzerland, Hamburg Film Festival in Germany, and International Film Festival Rotterdam in the Netherlands. His documentary La Ultima Pelicula (The Last Film), 2013, was screened in different film festivals, such as Toronto International Film Festival, Vienna International Film Festival, Berlin International Film Festival, Cinéma du Réel in France, Jeonju International Film Festival in South Korea, and Melbourne International Film Festival. Written byLorelie Legisniana

MARTINEZ, ALBERT(Alberto Pineda Martinez) b. Manila 19 Apr 1961. Film and television actor, producer, and director. He is the son of 1960s actor Bert Martinez and Margarita Pineda. He is the eldest brother to actors William, Ronnie, and Bernadette Martinez; husband to actor Liezl Sumilang-Martinez; and father to three children: Alyanna, Alfonso, and Alyssa. He took up mechanical engineering at the University of Santo Tomas but had to stop schooling because of numerous project offers.

Martinez was one of the rising actors in the 1980s dubbed Regal Babies of movie producer Lily Monteverde. His first film is Totoo Ba ang Tsismis? (Is the Rumor True?), 1980, starring Nora Aunor and Gabby Concepcion. He was launched in the musical comedy Blue Jeans, 1981, with fellow teen stars then. He was also paired up with Snooky Serna in films such as First Love First Kiss, 1981, and Boystown, 1984. His other films include Bata Pa si Sabel (Sabel Is Still a Child) and Bakit Ba Ganyan? (Why Is It So?), 1981, Di Mo Ako Kayang Tapakan (You Can’t Step on Me), 1984, before his career was put to a halt after eloping with Liezl, only daughter of former movie queen Amalia Fuentes and actor Romeo Vasquez, to start a family in the USA.

In the mid-1990s, the Martinez family came back to the Philippines. In 1995, Martinez did Muling Umawit ang Puso (The Heart Sings Again), which won for him the Best Supporting Actor award at the Metro Manila Film Festival. For Segurista (Dead Sure), 1996, he received another Best Supporting Actor award from the Gawad Urian and the Film Academy of the Philippines. For Rizal sa Dapitan (Rizal at Dapitan), 1997, he won Best Actor at the 1998 Brussels International Independent Film Festival. For Magnifico, he won the Gawad Urian Best Supporting Actor award. His other notable films include Mumbaki (Shaman), 1996; Pusong Mamon (Soft Hearts) and Bata, Bata … Paano Ka Ginawa? (Lea’s Story), 1998; Scorpio Nights 2 and Sidhi (The Story of Ah), 1999; Ika-13 Kapitulo (The Thirteenth Chapter), 2001; Laman (Flesh), 2002; and Anak Ka ng Tatay Mo (You Are Your Father’s Child), 2004.

Martinez made his directorial debut with Rosario, 2010, an official entry in the Metro Manila Film Festival. For this film, he was awarded Best Director by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences in 2011. The film was featured at the 14th Shanghai International Film Festival.

Martinez also appeared in various drama series for television, including Anna Liza, 1980-86; episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) from 1995; May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), 2009-10; Nasaan Ka, Elisa? (Where Are You, Elisa?), 2011-12; Princess and I, 2012-13; Juan dela Cruz, 2013; Mars Ravelo’s Dyesebel and Sana Bukas Pa ang Kahapon (Hoping Yesterday Was Tomorrow), 2014; and FPJ’s Ang Probinsyano (FPJ’s The Country Boy), 2015. Written by Kathrina Alvarez

MARTINEZ, CHRIS(Christopher Dacanay Martinez) b. Manila 10 Jul 1971. Screenwriter, playwright, and film director and producer. His parents are Pedrito Martinez and Leticia Dacanay. He graduated from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman with a bachelor of science in business administration.

Martinez was active in the theater scene in UP. His notable play Last Order sa Penguin (Last Order at Penguin) was first staged by the UP Theater Council in 2000 (under the direction of Martinez himself). The play tells the story of five longtime friends who, after not seeing each other for several years, meet one night at the Penguin Café, a café cum art gallery in Malate, to catch up on each other’s lives. The play captures the fears of people who are entering their 30s, that pivotal moment in life when one finally says goodbye to youth and starts facing real responsibilities. In 2001, Last Order sa Penguin won for Martinez the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature.

Martinez’s first foray into movies was writing the screenplay for Jeffrey Jeturian’s sex comedy Bridal Shower, 2004, an entry in the Metro Manila Film Festival. This was followed by another Jeturian comedy, Bikini Open, 2005. Then, he co-wrote with director Chito S. Roño the screenplays for Roño’s Sukob (The Wedding Curse), 2006, and Caregiver, 2008. Martinez’s directorial debut came when he joined the 2008 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival with his drama 100, starring Mylene Dizon as a young cancer patient who writes a list of 100 things that she wants to do before she dies. 100 won for Martinez the awards for Best Screenplay, Best Director, and Best Film at Cinemalaya, as well as the Audience Award at the 2008 Pusan International Film Festival and the Emile Guimet Award at the 2009 Vesoul Asian Film Festival. Martinez wrote the screenplay for Eugene Domingo’s first starring role, Kimmy Dora: Kambal sa Kiyeme (Kimmy Dora: Twins of Nonsense), 2009, under the direction of Joyce Bernal. The following year, Martinez wrote and directed Here Comes the Bride, 2010. He then co-wrote (with Marlon Rivera) and directed a segment of the omnibus film My Valentine Girls, 2011. The hilarious segment, “Gunaw” (End of the World), takes place after the world has ended and it is up to the seemingly last two persons on earth, Aidan (Richard Gutierrez) and Ivy (Eugene Domingo), to mate and repopulate the earth.

In 2011, Martinez embarked on a remake of Joey Gosiengfiao’s 1980 cult classic, Temptation Island. Martinez also wrote Ang Babae sa Septic Tank (The Woman in the Septic Tank), 2011, an entry in the 6th Cinemalaya and directed by Marlon Rivera. The film is a satire on the “indie” film scene and stars Eugene Domingo as a narcissistic movie star who is convinced by three young filmmakers to appear in their film about poverty, titled “Walang-Wala” (Destitute). Ang Babae sa Septic Tank won for Martinez the Best Screenplay award at Cinemalaya. The following year, Martinez wrote the sequel Kimmy Dora and the Temple of Kiyeme (Kimmy Dora and the Temple of Nonsense), 2012. After the Kimmy Dora sequel, Martinez wrote and directed I Do Bidoo Bidoo: Heto nAPO Sila! (I Do Bidoo Bidoo: The APO Is Here!), 2012, a musical film that features the music of the Apo Hiking Society.

The year 2013 was another prolific year for Martinez. He wrote the screenplay for Leo Abaya’s Instant Mommy, an entry in the 2013 Cinemalaya. Next, he co-wrote (with Jose N. Carreon) and directed the comedy Status: It’s Complicated. Then he wrote and directed the third installment of the Kimmy Dora series: Kimmy Dora: Ang Kiyemeng Prequel (Kimmy Dora: The Nonsense Prequel).

In 2014, Martinez wrote and directed The Gifted, a comedy about two geeks fighting for the attention and affection of their school crush. Also in 2014, Martinez co-wrote with director Antoinette Jadaone the satirical comedy Beauty in a Bottle. In 2015, he directed You’re Still the One, from a screenplay by Aloy Adlawan. Written by Elvin Valerio

MATTI, ERIK(Erik Charles Seminio Matti) b. Bacolod, Negros Occidental 1965. Film and television director, screenwriter, producer. His parents are Enrique Celemente Buenaflor Matti and Julieta Parra Seminio. He went to Colegio de San Agustin for his primary and secondary education and the University of St. La Salle for college. He founded the film production company Reality Entertainment with Dondon Monteverde, son of Regal Films matriarch Lily Monterverde.

Matti started his career in the 1990s and first gained credit as a writer for the films of Peque Gallaga and Lore Reyes, including Magic Temple, 1996; Mortal Kombat: Alamat ng Damortis (Mortal Combat: The Legend of Damortis), 1997; and Gangland, 1998. In 1999, he debuted as director with Scorpio Nights 2, an unrelated sequel to Gallaga’s original, followed by Ekis (X) in the same year, starring Sunshine Cruz and Albert Martinez. These two movies, including Dos Ekis (Two X’s) in 2001 and Prosti (Prostitute) in 2002, marked Matti as director of sexy, erotic work, one of the genres he would be known for. In 2001, he directed Sa Huling Paghihintay (The Final Wait), starring Rica Peralejo and Bernard Palanca. He took over directing duties of Lily Monteverde’s popular franchise Mano Po 2: My Home, 2003. Since then, he ventured into fantasy, action, and horror films: Gagamboy (Spider Boy), 2004; Pa-Siyam (Nine-Day Novena), 2004; and Exodus: Tales from the Enchanted Kingdom, 2005. Quite different from his string of genre films is The Arrival, 2009, which he considers his most personal film. He went back to titillate audiences with Rigodon, 2012, starring Yam Concepcion, John James Uy, and Max Eigenmann. With the success of Tiktik: The Aswang Chronicles, 2012, he made a sequel titled Kubot: The Aswang Chronicles 2, 2014, but he garnered more acclaim with On the Job, 2013, which was shown in the Directors’ Fortnight at Cannes Film Festival. Also in the same vein of crime thriller is Honor Thy Father, 2015, starring John Lloyd Cruz.

For television, Matti directed the ABS-CBN show Rounin, 2007, which delves into fantasy and martial arts, starring Diether Ocampo and Angelica Panganiban.

Matti won Best Screenplay for Magic Temple, shared with Gallaga and Reyes, at the Metro Manila Film Festival.
