On the Job won Movie Director of the Year and Movie Screenwriter of the Year from the Star Awards; Best Director, Best Screenplay, and Best Story from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences; and the Jury’s Choice Award from the 2013 Puchon International Fantastic Film Festival. Written byRichard Bolisay, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

MEDINA, PEN(Crispin Parungao Medina) b. Arayat, Pampanga 27 Aug 1950. Movie, television, and stage actor. His parents are Eliseo Medina Sr and Trinidad Parungao. Pen is married to Victoria Aquino Chupungco and is the father of Karl, Ping, Alex, and Victor Medina who are also film and television actors. He obtained his high school education from Arayat Institute in Pampanga, 1963-67. Medina went to several schools for college, including the University of Santo Tomas, the Far Eastern University, and the University of the East—enrolling in fine arts, premed, and bachelor of arts programs but eventually dropping out to go full time into acting.

He had numerous stage, TV, and movie appearances. He acted in Teatro Kabataan productions of AngPaglilitisniMangSerapio (The Trial of Old Serapio), 1977, as Ikalawang Tagapagtanong, and Nang Pista sa Aming Bayan (During Our Town’s Feast), 1978, as Lucio. He frequently appeared in plays staged at the Cultural Center of the Philippines: in Andres Bonifacio, 1980, as Emilio Jacinto; Kanser (Cancer), 1981, as Kapitan Tiago, and again in 1993 as Elias; Bombita, 1981, as Corporal; Gregorio Aglipay, 1982, as Fr Brillantes; Rebecca Defensor, 1983, as Fr Cab, SJ; Paghihintay kay Godot (Samuel Beckett’s Waiting for Godot), 1984, as Vladimir; Mga Multo (Henrik Ibsen’s Ghosts), 1985, as Pastor Manders; Puntilla at Matti (Bertolt Brecht’s Puntilla and Matti), 1986, as Surkkala; Makinig Kayong Mabuti (Listen Carefully), 1986, as Gen Henry Baltazar; Lasong Itim (Black Bow), 1986, as the publisher; Maniago, 1988, as a revolutionary; Bien Aligtad, 1989, as Bien Aligtad; Lusak (Maxim Gorky’s The Lower Depths), 1990, as Satin; and Ginintuang Bayan (Shusako Endo’s Golden Country), 1990, as Fr Ferreira.

On University of the Philippines stages, he was seen in Patay Na si Sizwe Banzi (Athol Fugard’s Sizwe Banzi Is Dead), 1986, as Styles; Tatalon, 1987, as the Jeepney Driver; and Supremo (Supreme Chief), 1991, as Andres Bonifacio. At the Metropolitan Theater, he played the role of Alila in Gironiere, 1985, and Simoun in ElFilibusterismo (Subversion), 1991. At Puerta Real, he was Rizal/Ibarra in NoliMeTangere (Touch Me Not), 1986. He performed for TanghalangPilipino, BulwagangGantimpala, TeatroPilipino, and other campus or independent theater groups.

He appeared as guest in various TV programs, such as Krimen (Crime), Sic O’Clock News, Dingas (Flame), Goin’ Bananas, True Story, La Aunor, Carmi, Director’s Hour, Batibot (Small But Strong), and Photographs and Memories. Medina also appeared in GMA Network’s Villa Quintana, 1995-97, and ABS-CBN’s Tabing Ilog (Riverside), 1999-2003; Sa Puso Ko Iingatan Ka (I Will Cherish You in My Heart), 2001-2; Encantadia, 2005; Mga Mata ni Anghelita (The Eyes of Anghelita), 2007; Joaquin Bordado (Tattooed Joaquin), 2008; I.T.A.L.Y: I Trust and Love You, 2008; Ilumina, 2010; Guns n Roses, 2011; E-boy, 2012; Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14; Aso ni San Roque (San Roque’s Dog), 2012-13, as “Mother Ben,” the gay guardian of the lead character Fatima; and My BFF, 2014.

As a movie actor, he appeared in Himala (Miracle), 1982; Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983; Sister Stella L., 1984; Scorpio Nights, 1985; and Unfaithful Wife, 1986. He also appeared in foreign films, such as Sweet Revenge, 1987; Saigon Commandos and A Dangerous Life, 1988; and Deathstone, 1990. He was also in Orapronobis (Fight for Us), 1989; Isang Araw Walang Diyos (One Day without God), 1989; Bayani (Hero), 1992; and Sakay, 1993. His other noteworthy films are Mumbaki (Shaman), 1996, which was shot in the Banaue Rice Terraces in Ifugao; Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin (They Call Me Joy), 1997; Sa Pusod ng Dagat (In the Navel of the Sea), 1998; and Jose Rizal, 1998, where he played Jose Rizal’s older brother Paciano. Also, Medina played Rizal in the documentary Jose Rizal: Ang Buhay ng Isang Bayani (Jose Rizal: A Hero’s Life), 1996, directed by Butch Nolasco and produced by Ateneo de Manila University. He was also part of Baryoke, 2005, which was an official entry in the 1st Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. In 2012, he played the main character in Kamera Obskura (Dark Room), an entry in the Directors Showcase of Cinemalaya.

For his performance in Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 1999, Medina won Best Supporting Actor in the 1999 Metro Manila Film Festival. He won the Film Academy of the Philippines Best Supporting Actor award for his performance in Deathrow, 2000. He was also given the Best Actor award at the 6th Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival for his performance in Layang Bilanggo (Imprisoned Freedom), 2010. In 2013, his performance in 10,000 Hours earned him Best Supporting Actor awards from the Metro Manila Film Festival and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences. Written by Malou M. Maniquis, updated by Lorelie Legisniana

MEILY, MARK(Edward Mark Afable Meily) b. Makati City 18 Aug 1966. Director, writer, and producer. His parents are Eduardo Meily and Lourdes Afable. He married cinematographer Lee Briones. He took up visual communications courses at the University of the Philippines. He studied at the Mowelfund Film Institute and was a Cinema-French Government scholar at the Ecole Supérierure d’Etudes Cinématographiques in Paris, France.

Meily’s short film Sentry, 1989, won first prize at the 1989 Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video. In 2003, he directed his first full-length feature film Crying Ladies, 2003, which won the award for Best Director at the 2003 Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) and the Silver Crow Pheasant Award for Best Director at the 2004 Kerala International Film Festival. He directed La Visa Loca (Crazy Visa), 2005, winner of Best Picture at the Catholic Mass Media Awards and Best Original Screenplay at the 2006 Golden Screen Awards. In 2008, he made the period film Baler, which earned him Best Director awards from the 2008 MMFF and the 2009 Star Awards for Movies and the Film Academy of the Philippines. Also in 2008, he adapted and directed the French comedy series Caméra Café, which won Best Comedy Programme at the 13th Asian Television Awards in Singapore and Best Comedy Programme at the 2009 Gawad Tanglaw para sa Mass Media.

In the Director’s Showcase of the 6th Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, Meily directed Donor, 2010, which won the Cinemalaya Best Film and received the Grand Prize at the 30th Brussels Independent Film Festival. He directed the biopic of General Emilio Aguinaldo, El Presidente (The President), 2012, which won Best Director at the FAMAS and Star Awards for Movies in 2013 and the Best World Showcase Award at the 2013 SOHO International Film Festival in New York. His other films include ABNKKBSNPLAko?! (Wow I Can Actually Read Now?!: The Movie), 2014, and Lumayo Ka nga sa Akin (Will You Please Stay Away from Me), 2015.

Meily’s screenplays Bayad Luha (Pay with Tears), 2000, and Penitencia Republic (Republic of Penitence), 2004, won third prize and first prize, respectively, at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature. His participation in industry affairs includes his chairmanship of the Directors’ Guild of the Philippines from 2007 to 2013. Written by Rica Arevalo

MENDOZA, BRILLANTE(Brillante Manguerra Mendoza) aka Dante Mendoza, Brillante Ma. Mendoza. b. San Fernando, Pampanga 30 Jul 1960. Director and production designer. His parents are Pastor Mendoza and Gervacia Manguerra. He finished fine arts, major in advertising, at the University of Santo Tomas, Manila.

Mendoza started as a production designer in movies, television, and TV commercials. Among his works as production designer are Takaw Tukso (Flirting with Temptation), 1986; Private Show, 1986; and Olongapo … The Great American Dream, 1987.

His debut film, Masahista (The Masseur), 2005, is about a masseur, played by Coco Martin, in a gay massage parlor who meets a romance novelist at the same time that he is helping his mother prepare the burial of his estranged father. The film won the Golden Leopard (video competition) at the 58th Locarno Film Festival. It was given the Interfaith Award at the 2006 Brisbane Film Festival and the Audience Award at the Torino International Gay & Lesbian Film Festival. It also received the Best Film award from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk in 2006.

Kaleldo (Summer Heat), 2006, which revolves around a widower and his three grown-up daughters in Pampanga, won the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) Award at the 8th Jeonju International Film Festival and the Best Actress award for Cherry Pie Picache at the 27th Durban International Film Festival in South Africa.

Manoro (The Teacher), 2007, about literacy among the Aetas in Pampanga, won Best Film and Best Director at the 8th Cinemanila International Film Festival. It was also given the CinemAvvenire Award at the 24th Torino International Film Festival.

Foster Child, 2007, produced by Seiko Films, is about child adoption in the country. It was given the Signis Award at the 9th International Film Festival of Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Special Jury Awardat the 3rd Eurasia International Film Festival, Prix de la Fiction at the 25th Palmarès du Festival International du Film d’Environement, and the NETPAC Award at Brisbane International Film Festival. Actor Cherry Pie Picache was awarded Best Actress at the 9th Osian’s Cinefan International Festival in India.

Tirador (Slingshot), 2007, which is set during Holy Week, follows the intersecting lives of four men as they fight to survive in the filthy slums of Quiapo, Manila. It won the Special Jury Award at the 7th Marrakech International Film Festival; Best Film, Best Director, and the NETPAC Award at the 21st Singapore International Film Festival; the Caligari Prize at the 58th Berlin Film Festival; and the Grand Jury of Long Metrage and Press Jury Award at 10th Festival de Cinéma du Grain à Démoudre in France. At the 31st Gawad Urian, it won Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Supporting Actress, Best Sound, and Best Cinematography.

Serbis (Service), 2008, is about a sleazy movie theater in Pampanga operated by the Pineda family, led by its matriarch Nanay Flor. The film competed in the main competition of the 61st Cannes Film Festival. It won Best Director and Best Actress at the 6th Vladivostok International Film Festival. In the 6th Bangkok International Film Festival, it was named Best Feature Film in the Southeast Asian Competition. It garnered the Premi Cinematk (Cinematk Award) at the 11th Festival de Cinema Asiatic de Barcelona. In the 32nd Gawad Urian, it won Best Picture, Best Production Design, and Best Cinematography. The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino also cited Serbis as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 2000-2009.

Mendoza’s seventh film, Kinatay (The Execution of P.), 2009, about a criminology graduate who is desperate for money and is tasked to help kill and chop a woman to pieces, made Mendoza the first Filipino to win the Palme d’Or for Best Director at the 62nd Cannes Film Festival. He was also awarded Best Director at the 42nd Sitges International Film Festival and the 33rd Gawad Urian.

Lola (Grandmother), 2009, stars Anita Linda and Rustica Carpio as grandmothers dealing with loneliness and the loss of their respective grandsons—one in jail and the other in death. It was awarded the Muhr Asia Africa Feature Award at the 6th Dubai International Film Festival. It then received the Golden Lady Harimaguada Award at the 11th Las Palmas de Gran Canaria International Film Festival and the Crystal Simorgh Award at the 29th Fajr International Film Festival. It won Best Film at the 8th Rome Asian Film Festival and the Grand Knight Award at the 27th Miami Film Festival. In the 24th Fribourg Film Festival, it received the Don Quijote Award, Ecumenical Jury Award, and the International Jury Special Mention.

Captive, 2012, starring French actor Isabelle Huppert, competed at the 62nd Berlin Film Festival. The film is inspired by the hostage crisis involving tourists kidnapped by armed rebels in an island resort in Palawan. It was nominated Best Film at the 39th Ghent International Film Festival in Belgium.

Thy Womb, 2012, starring Nora Aunor, is about a Sama Dilaut (Badjao) midwife in Tawi-Tawi who cannot bear a child while her husband, played by Bembol Roco, wishes to be a father. At the 69th Venice Film Festival, it was given special prizes by different film organizations—namely, La Navicella Venezia Cinema Award, the P. Nazareno Taddei Award–Special Mention, and the Bisato d’Oro for Best Actress (Nora Aunor) from the European critics group that gives Premio della Critica Indipendente. It also won Achievement in Directing and Best Performance by an Actress at the 6th Asia Pacific Screen Awards, Best Actress at the 7th Asian Film Awards, Special Jury Mention at the 7th Granada Film Festival Cines del Sur, and Best Actress at the 3rd Sakhalin International Film Festival. At the 38th Metro Manila Film Festival, it won Best Director, Best Actress, Best Original Story, Best Cinematography, and Best Production Design.

Sapi (Possession), 2013, tackles the ratings-driven competition of two rival television networks as they cover an incident of satanic possession caught on tape. News producer (Meryll Soriano) acquires the footage illegally, disregarding the journalists’ code of ethics.

Taklub, 2015, was screened in the 68th Cannes Film Festival (Un Certain Regard) where it was given a commendation by the Ecumenical Jury. A sensitive depiction of survivors of super typhoon Haiyan that ravaged Tacloban, it stars Nora Aunor and Julio Diaz. It won Best Picture at the 2016 Gawad Urian. Written by Rica Arevalo

MENDOZA, CARLO(David Carlo Canlas Mendoza) b. Manila 8 Oct 1980. Cinematographer. He is the son of Jaime Mendoza and Roseanna Canlas. He went to Ateneo de Manila High School and finished his degree in communications technology management at the Ateneo de Manila University in 2002. He attended the Asian Film Academy in Busan, South Korea in 2007 where he trained under the tutelage of Iranian director Mohesen Mahkmalbaf, Thai director Pen-ek Ratanaruang, and Japanese cinematographer Kurita Toyomichi. In 2011, he was selected to participate in Berlinale Talents, an annual gathering of young film industry professionals from around the world.

Mendoza’s career in the local film industry started when he apprenticed for acclaimed cinematographer Lee Briones-Meily from 2005 to 2007. His first work as a cinematographer was for Jay Abello’s Ligaw Liham (Letters of Nor), an entry to the 2007 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. This was followed by Francis Pasion’s Jay, another entry to the 2008 Cinemalaya, where he also portrayed the role of an enterprising cameraman who accompanies the opportunistic reporter and title character played by Baron Geisler.

Mendoza’s work as a cinematographer can be seen in movies by both new and more established directors, including: Maryo J. delos Reyes’s Torotot (Deceit), 2008; Albert Martinez’s Rosario, 2010; Tikoy Aguiluz’s Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story, 2011; Ralston Jover’s Bakal Boys (Children Metal Divers), 2009, Bendor (Vendor), 2013, and Da Dog Show (The Dog Show), 2015; Mark Meily’s El Presidente (The President), 2012; Cesar Montano’s Alfredo S. Lim: The Untold Story and Chito S. Roño’s Boy Golden, both in 2013; Gino M. Santos’s #Y (with Mendoza as coproducer), Pepe Diokno’s Above the Clouds, and Enzo William’s Bonifacio: Ang Unang Pangulo (Bonifacio: The First President), all in 2014; and Carlo Catu’s Ari: My Life with a King, 2015. He was also the cinematographer of Jun Robles Lana for many of his movies, including Bwakaw, 2012; Mga Kuwentong Barbero (Barber’s Tales), 2013; So It’s You, 2014; and Anino sa Likod ng Buwan (Shadow Behind the Moon), The Prenup, and Haunted Mansion, all in 2015.

Mendoza was a participant at the 2012 IMAGO (European Federation of Cinematographers) Annual Conference in Paris and the 1st ARRI Lighting Symposium in Gut Ising, Germany in 2015. He was a resource speaker and facilitator of the 2014 FLY Workshop in Yangon, Myanmar and the Malaysian Next New Wave Workshop in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

Mendoza won best cinematography awards for the following films: Rosario (Metro Manila Film Festival [MMFF], Film Academy of the Philippines [FAP], Pasado Awards and Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences [FAMAS]); Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story (Star Awards, Golden Screen Awards, Gawad Tanglaw, MMFF, and FAMAS); El Presidente (Star Awards, FAP, Pasado Awards and FAMAS); Bonifacio: Ang Unang Pangulo (MMFF, FAMAS, and Star Awards); Boy Golden (FAMAS); Bakal Boys (Young Critics Circle); and Bwakaw (Golden Screen Awards). The FAMAS has elevated him to its Hall of Fame after he won the award for Best Cinematography five times. He has been accepted in the prestigious American Film Institute where he is set to finish his master of fine arts degree in cinematography in 2018. Written byElmer L. Gatchalian

MERCADO, GLYDEL (Flordeliza Loriaga Sanchez-Gutierrez) b. Quezon City 10 Mar 1974. Movie and television actor. She is the daughter of Francisco Sanchez and Lucila Loriaga. She is wife to actor Antonio “Tonton” Gutierrez, son of movie actors Eddie Gutierrez and Elizabeth Winsett, aka Liza Lorena. Glydel and Tonton have two daughters, Aneeza and Aneeka.

Mercado started her career in television with the hit youth-oriented variety show That’s Entertainment, 1986-96, hosted by German Moreno. The show gathered promising young talents who wanted to make a name for themselves in the entertainment industry. Her first movie project was Lt. Madarang: Iginuhit sa Dugo (Lt. Madarang: Written in Blood), 1993, topbilled by Edu Manzano and Jean Garcia. She was still using her birth name then. Mercado was cast in comedy films like Ang Misis Kong Hoodlum (My Hoodlum Wife), 1996; I Do? I Die!, 1997; and Pipti-pipti: 1 por U, 2 por Me (Fifty-Fifty: One for You, Two for Me), 1997. She was then known as a sexy star in Anak ng Yakuza (The Yakuza’s Child), Takaw Tukso (Temptation), 1998, and Mister Mo, Lover Ko (Your Husband, My Lover), 1999. She got her biggest break in Sidhi (The Story of Ah), 1999, an award-winning film based on National Artist Rolando Tinio’s teleplay. For her acting in this film, she scored a grand-slam victory, winning all the Best Supporting Actress trophies from the Gawad Urian, the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, the Star Awards for Movies, and the Film Academy of the Philippines.

While Glydel was still active in the movie industry in 2000, she was kept busy by numerous television projects like Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001-3; Sana Maulit Muli (I Wish It Would Happen Again), 2007; and Gumapang Ka sa Lusak (Secret Affairs), 2010. In 2014, she was recognized by the Golden Screen Awards for Television as Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Drama Series for the gay-themed primetime drama My Husband’s Lover, 2013. Written byKathrina Alvarez

MESA, EDDIE (Eduardo de Mesa Eigenmann) b. 17 Feb 1940. Movie actor, singer. His parents are Mary de Mesa and Valentine Eigenmann, a Swiss-German businessman. He married actress RosemarieGil. He is the father of actors Michael de Mesa, Mark Gil, and Cherie Gil and the grandfather of actors Ryan, Geoff, AJ, Gabby, Sid, Andi, and Maxene Eigenmann.

Mesa started out as a member of the combo “The Trippers,” which performed in the provinces. Later on, he sang at the Clover Theater and the ManilaGrandOperaHouse. As a singer, Mesa was known as the “Elvis Presley of the Philippines.”

Mesa made his first movie Shirley, My Darling in 1958 as a contract star of Premiere Productions. In his first starring role, as well as in many of his later films, he played the part he knew best: that of a singing idol. His films include Bon Voyage, Hawaiian Boy, and Gitarang Ginto (Golden Guitar), 1959; Diyes Isang Kanta (Ten Centavos for a Song) and Zoom Zoom, 1970. He quit show business in the 1970s and became a Christian preacher. In 1991 he did a comeback movie, Kaputol ng Isang Awit (Fragment of a Song), together with SharonCuneta and GaryValenciano. Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

MIA, ROSA (Rosita Manuel Quinto-de Asis) b. Baclaran, Pasay City 21 Sep 1924. d. Cavite 28 Nov 2006. Movie actor and director. She married Larry de Asis. Her younger sister, Lucy Quinto, is a dubber and character actor.

Mia started in theater during the Japanese Occupation, acting in the play Amihan (Breeze),1943. In 1946 she appeared in her first movie, Dugo ng Bayan (I Remember Bataan), a Palaris FilmProduction. She appeared in Sumpaan (Pledge), 1948, with ElyRamos and NormaBlancaflor. For portraying the suffering and sorrowful mother in more than 80 films, she became known as the mater dolorosa of Philippine movies. Among her films are Sino ang Maysala? (Who Is Guilty?), 1957; Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), 1958; Pitong Pagsisisi (Seven Atonements) and Mga Ligaw na Bulaklak (Wildflowers), 1959; Ipagdarasal Kita (I Will Pray for You) and Ginang Hukom (Madame Judge), 1960; Batas ng Lipunan (Society’s Law), Pitong Kalbaryo ni Inang (Mother’s Seven Calvaries), and No Man Is an Island, 1962; Historia de un Amor (Story of Love) and Anak, ang Iyong Ina! (Child, Behold Your Mother!), 1963; Fighting Warays sa Ilokos (Fighting Warays in Ilokos) and Magkakapatid na Waray (Waray Siblings), 1964; Ana-Roberta, 1965; Love and Devotion, 1967; Guerilla Strike Force, 1970; Hindi Kita Malimot (I Can’t Forget You) and Hanggang sa Kabila ng Daigdig: The Tony Maiquez Story (Till the Other Side of the World: The Tony Maiquez Story), 1973; Sa Kagubatan ng Lunsod (In the Jungle of the City), 1975; Tatlong Patak ng Dugo ni Adan (Three Drops of Adam’s Blood) and Pinay, American Style, 1980.

Mia also ventured into directing. She did Pagdating ng Takip-silim (When Twilight Comes), 1956, for SampaguitaPictures, a remake of the prewar Carmen Rosales–Rogelio de la Rosa film with their roles reenacted by GloriaRomero and Luis Gonzales. Other films she directed include Debutante (Debutant), 1959, with CarmenRosales and SusanRoces as mother and daughter; Octavia, 1961, with LolitaRodriguez and RicRodrigo; Sa Linggo ang Bola (Sunday Lottery Draw), about sweepstakes winners, 1961; June Bride, 1962, with EddieGutierrez and Josephine Estrada; Class Reunion, 1963; the remake of a prewar hit, Leron-Leron Sinta (Leron-Leron Beloved), 1964, with Susan Roces and Eddie Gutierrez; Summer Love and Let’s Do the Psychedelic, 1968, for Gilbert Roland Productions.

Mia won the Maria Clara Best Supporting Actress award for Roberta, 1951, and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Supporting Actress award for Tumbando Caña (Bottoms Up), 1956. Her other notable performances are in Recuerdo (Remembrance), 1953; Rosana, 1955; and Kamandag (Venom), 1959. Written byGalileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

MIRANDA, OSCAR (Oscar Talise Miranda) b. Iba, Zambales 17 May 1933. d. 23 Nov 2002. Movie scriptwriter. His parents are Casimiro Miranda, former mayor of Cabangon and provincial secretary of Zambales, and Segundina Talise, a school teacher in Iba and public librarian in Olongapo. A product of the public school system of Zambales, he graduated from Zambales High School in 1949. He completed a bachelor’s degree in liberal arts from Far Eastern University in 1954.

Miranda scripted such films as Sakada (Seasonal Cane Workers), 1976, which he also produced; Walang Katapusang Tag-Araw (Eternal Summer), 1977; Pag-ibig na Walang Dangal (Love without Honor) and Swing It, Baby, 1980. He also scripted and directed the film Rock, Baby, Rock, 1981. His other films include Home Sweet Home, 1983; Paradise Inn, 1985; Kung Mawawala Ka Pa (If I Lose You), 1993; and Inagaw Mo ang Lahat sa Akin (Harvest Home), 1995.

Miranda began work on television in the 1970s, writing, directing, and producing several TV shows and documentaries. He was a copywriter for several advertising firms and handled promotional work for some TV and movie production companies. He was a board member of the MovieandTelevisionReviewandClassificationBoard and the entertainment editor of Ang Pilipino Star Ngayon. While writing scripts for movies and television, he wrote a daily entertainment column in the newspaper Malaya.

He won the FilipinoAcademyofMovieArtsandSciences (FAMAS) award for Best Screenplay twice: for Isang Gabi sa Iyo, Isang Gabi sa Akin (One Night with You, One Night with Me), 1978, and Paradise Inn. He also received the FilmAcademyofthePhilippines Best Screenplay award for Paradise Inn. In 1996, he and Bibeth Orteza were awarded Best Story by the FAMAS for Inagaw Mo ang Lahat sa Akin. Written byCristine Directo, updated by Pamela Mathiel Lopez
(See THEATER volume.)

MONTANO, CESAR(Cesar Manhilot) b. Santa Ana, Manila 1 Aug 1962. Movie and television actor, screenwriter, and director. Montano traces his roots to the Manhilots of Baclayon in the province of Bohol, Central Visayas. Montano studied industrial engineering at the Lyceum of the Philippines.

Montano’s first film appearance was a bit role in Mario O’Hara’s To Mama with Love, 1983. But his early years as a movie actor are often associated with legendary director Ishmael Bernal since the young Montano would always be given small roles in Bernal’s films. These include appearances in Broken Marriage, 1983; Working Girls, 1984; Hinugot sa Langit (Wrenched from Heaven), 1985; and The Graduates, 1986.

After appearing in a series of sexy adult dramas, such as Ibigin Mo Ako nang Higit sa Lahat (Love Me More Than Anyone Else), 1987; Mahirap ang Magmahal (It Is Difficult to Love), 1989; Bihagin ang Dalagang Ito (Capture This Maiden), 1989; and Kokak, 1989, Montano got the break of his career when he was paired with popular sexy actors Rita Avila and Rina Reyes in Mauro Gia Samonte’s fantasy drama Machete: Istatwang Buhay (Machete: Live Statue), 1990. In the film, Montano plays Machete, a wooden statue who comes to life to fulfill the desires of his beautiful but lonely creator Lorna (Avila). Despite its flimsy narrative, Machete was a huge box-office success and made a movie star out of Montano.

For the rest of the decade, Montano’s career continued to thrive. Some of his noteworthy films from this period are Hiram na Mukha (Borrowed Face), 1992; Markadong Hudas (Marked Judas), 1993; Silakbo (Outburst) and Asero (Steel), 1995; and Kadre (Cadre), 1997. In 1998, Montano was tapped to play the role of the Philippine national hero in GMA Films’ big-budget production of Jose Rizal, 1998, which was directed by Marilou Diaz-Abaya. It won major awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), Gawad Urian, Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF), and Star Awards. Montano himself was named Best Actor at the FAMAS, MMFF, and Star Awards. Montano and Diaz-Abaya also collaborated in the environmental drama Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 1999, and Bagong Buwan (New Moon), 2001, a film about the Muslim insurgency in Mindanao.

Montano also tried his hand at writing, directing, and producing. The first movie that he co-produced, co-directed (with Toto Natividad), and starred in was Warfreak, 1998, with action star Ace Espinosa and Mickey Ferriols. The first movie that Montano wrote (with Bien Ojeda), produced, directed, and starred in was Bullet, 1999, with Sunshine Cruz. Montano would eventually marry Cruz, though the two are now separated. Montano’s more noteworthy productions are his self-produced Panaghoy sa Suba (The Call of the River), 2004, and the suspense-thriller Ligalig (Anxiety), 2006, where he stars with Sunshine Cruz and Johnny Delgado. Panaghoy won for Montano the Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Actor awards at the 2005 Gawad Urian, as well as the Special Jury Prize and the Best Director award at the 2005 Brussels International Independent Film Festival.

Montano also embraced independent films. He appeared in Adolf Alix Jr’s Alamat ni China Doll (The Legend of China Doll), 2013, from a screenplay by Lav Diaz. The film was an entry in the Cinema One Originals Film Festival. Montano also appeared in Paul Soriano’s Kid Kulafu, 2015, a film based on world boxing champion Manny Pacquiao’s early days as a young, struggling boxer. Written by Elvin Valerio

MONTEIRO, JOHNNY(John Monteiro Montgomery) aka Juan Monteiro b. Pasay City 11 Nov 1923. d. San Francisco 1981. Movie and stage actor. His parents are Maria Monteiro and Moses Montgomery. During the Japanese Occupation, Monteiro acted on stage with DramaticPhilippines. Right after the war, he worked as a merchant marine for the Army Transport Service.

Monteiro’s interest in acting was rekindled when he appeared as background extra in Palaris Films’ Kanto Boy (Streetcorner Boy), 1947. Meanwhile, he took up fencing under Tony Gosalvez. When director ManuelConde learned of his skill in swordsmanship, he cast Monteiro as one of the seven brothers in SieteInfantes deLara (Seven Devils), 1950. This was followed by GenghisKhan, 1950, and Sigfredo, 1951, where he played major roles. Director CarlosVander Tolosa was so impressed with his acting that he chose him for the role of Judas in the Lebran superproduction Kalbaryo ni Jesus (The Calvary of Jesus), 1952. Monteiro crossed swords with EfrenReyes Sr in Carlos Trece (Charles XIII), 1953; Eskrimador (Swordsman), 1955; and Prinsipe Villarba (Prince Villarba), 1956.

He became a full star in Paladin, 1954. Among his early movies are five films directed by GerardodeLeon: Banga ni Zimadar (Zimadar’s Jar), 1953; Ifugao and Si Eva at si Adan (Adam and Eve), 1954; Simaron (Untamed), 1956; Don Cabarde, 1957; and NoliMeTangere (Touch Me Not), 1961.

Among his other films are May Isang Tsuper ng Taksi (There Was a Taxi Driver), 1953; Pusang Itim (Black Cat), 1958; Apat na Anino (Four Shadows) and Ultimatum, 1959; and Sa Bawa’t Patak ng Dugo (With Every Drop of Blood), 1960; Guillermo Bravado, 1965; Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1966; Dalawang Daigdig ni Carlota (The Two Worlds of Carlota), 1969; The Deadly Desperados, 1970; Dugo at Pag-ibig sa Kapirasong Lupa (Blood and Love in a Piece of Land), 1975; Langit, Lupa at Impiyerno (Heaven, Earth, and Hell) and Fantastika vs Wonderwoman, 1976; Ang Leon at ang Kuting (The Lion and the Kitten), 1980; Mad Warrior, 1985; and Revenge of the Street Warrior, 1987.

Monteiro played a character actor’s role in Salabusab (Greedy), 1953, which was chosen by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) as the Best Picture of the year. He was also nominated for acting awards by the FAMAS for his performance in the films Ang Matapang Lamang (Only the Brave), 1959, Suicide Susy, 1962, and God Knows, 1963. Written byNenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

MONTENEGRO, MARIO(Roger Collin Macalalag) b. Pagsanjan, Laguna 25 Jul 1928. d. Manila 27 Aug 1988. Movie and television actor. His parents are Gerardo Macalalag, a planter, and Daisy Collin, a Frenchwoman. He married movie actor Letty Alonzo (Letty Arrastia) with whom he had two daughters, Marilen and Honeylet, and an adopted son, Joey. Cinematographer Mike Accion is his brother-in-law. He finished high school at Far Eastern University and took up fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas where Carlos Francisco (Botong Francisco) was one of his teachers. During World War II, he became a member of the Hunters ROTC Guerrillas at age 14. He assisted in the liberation of the Los Baños concentration camp internees, among them Fr James Reuter SJ. In 1946 he was honorably discharged from the Philippine Army after receiving eight medals and awards for valor in the military service.

Montenegro began his movie career in LVN Pictures’ Capas, 1949, a film about survival in a Japanese concentration camp, and Batalyon XIII (13th Battalion), 1949. His first lead role was Apat na Alas (Four Aces), 1950, directed by Manuel Conde. He won recognition as the star of the first Philippine co-production with Indonesia in Rodrigo de Villa, 1952. He appeared as the Filipino hero in historical films like Dagohoy, 1953, where he played the title role; Kilabot sa Makiling (Terror of Makiling), 1959, as Asedillo; Alyas Sakay (Alias Sakay), 1959, as the rebel branded as an outlaw by the Americans; Heroes of Dimataling, 1974, as Capt Reginaldo Abalon; and Terrorize Panay, 1980, as Ramon Magsaysay. He also appeared in costume movies based on metrical romances and folklore like Doce Pares (Twelve Pairs), 1954, Prinsipe Teñoso (Prince Teñoso), 1954, and Higit sa Korona (Above the Crown), 1956. He made films for international release such as Passionate Strangers, 1965; Operation Manila, 1965; Brides of Blood Island, 1966; Manila: Open City, 1968; Igorota (Mountain Maiden), 1968; and The Hunted, 1970. A versatile actor, he also excelled in dramas like Dugo sa Dugo (Blood against Blood), 1951; Bathaluman (Goddess), 1952; Mga Pusong May Lason (Poisoned Hearts), 1953; Dambanang Putik (Shrine of Mud), 1954, Banal o Makasalanan (Saint or Sinner), 1955, and Mga Bilanggong Birhen (Caged Virgins), 1977; in action films like Tatlong Labuyo (Three Hotheads), 1953; and in situation comedies like Indian Pana (Indian Bow and Arrow), 1955, and Pilipino Kostum, No Touch (Filipino Custom, No Touching), 1955.

He starred in television shows like Lino Brocka’s Dung-aw (Lament), 1975, and Montenegro starred in more than 150 films and was nominated six times by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Best Actor for his performances in the following movies: Lapu Lapu, 1954; Ulilang Bituin (Lonely Star), 1956; Everlasting, 1956; Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1957; Rebelde (Rebel), 1958; and Venganza (Revenge), 1958. He was nominated Best Supporting Actor by the FAMAS and the Gawad Urian for Itim (Black), 1976, and again for Anak ng Supremo (Son of the Supreme Chief), 1986, by the FAMAS. He received Sinag award for Outstanding Single Performance in a Television Show from the Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining for his role of Andres Bonifacio in Lino Brocka’s Unang Alay (First Offering), 1975. He guested in other regular TV programs, like Coney Reyes on Camera and Lovingly Yours, Helen. Written byGalileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja

MONTES, DANILO(Hernando Javier Silva) aka Roy de Silva. b. 17 Nov 1930. Actor. Born to Agapito Silva and Rosa Javier, he studied at Bulacan High School in Malolos, Bulacan. He was married to Natividad Estacio with whom he had two children. He first appeared in productions of Sampaguita Pictures in 1948, then moved to Fernando Poe’s Palaris Studio. He made 72 movies in all, playing supporting or lead roles in Sor Remedios, 1948, starring Paraluman and Fred Montilla; 24 na Pag-ibig (24 Loves), 1948; Bulaklak na Walang Pangalan (Flower with No Name), 1948; Biro ng Tadhana (Joke of Fate), 1949; Bella Vendetta, 1950, with Patricia Mijares; Ang Magpapawid (The Pawid Vendor), with Carmen Rosales, 1950; Takas sa Bataan (Escape from Bataan), 1950; Sinag sa Kalbario (Glimmer in the Calvary), 1950; Mag-inang Ulila (Orphaned Mother and Child) and Anak Ko! (My Child!), 1951; Salome, 1952; Paniwalaan Dili (Believe It or Not), 1953, a Lebran film starring Lopito, Patsy, and Gregorio Ticman; Gerardo de Leon’s Sanda Wong, 1955, with Lilia Dizon and Jose Padilla Jr; the title role in Heneral Pawa (General Pawa), 1956; Exzur, 1956, with Edna Luna and Jose Velez; Treasure of General Yamashita, 1956, with Leopoldo Salcedo; Kalibre 45 (Caliber 45), 1957, with Efren Reyes; and his last movie Wala Nang Luha (No More Tears), 1958, with Cynthia Zamora. Written byTeddie Co and Cesar Hernando

MONTES, VIRGINIA Corregidor, Cavite 22 Jun 1929. Movie actor. With actor EfrenReyes Sr, she has two children, actors Efren Reyes Jr and Cristina.Montes starred in Eddie Infante’s first directorial assignment, Ina (Mother), 1948, for LVNPictures, together with LeopoldoSalcedo and RosaAguirre. The following year she appeared in Padre Burgos (Father Burgos), 1949. She also appeared in the first full-color production to be filmed and processed at PremiereStudio, Ang Kampana sa San Diego (The Church Bell in San Diego), 1950, starring Efren Reyes Sr, with EduardodeCastro as director. She and Reyes formed an ideal love team, on-screen and off.

Her other movies are Hiwaga sa Tulay na Bato (Mystery at the Stone Bridge) and Bandido (Bandit), 1950; Birtud (Virtue), 1951; Luha ng Langit (Tears of Heaven), 1952; Paltik (Homemade Gun), 1955; and Hokus-Pokus (Hocus-Pocus), 1956. In her later years, she made Rebecca Marasigan, 1976; Herkulas, 1977; Tatak ng Tundo (Mark of Tondo), 1978; Dear Heart, 1981; Palabra de Honor (Word of Honor) and To Love Again, 1983; Kung Mahawi Man ang Ulap (Should the Skies Clear), 1984; Sugat sa Dangal (Dignity’s Affliction) and Paradise Inn, 1985.

One of her most memorable movie roles is that of the virginal Filipino komiks character Rosing in Premiere Productions’ Kenkoy, 1950. Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

MONTILLA, FRED(Alfredo Albino Francisco) b. Tondo, Manila 16 Nov 1919. d. 5 Dec 2003. Movie and television actor. His parents are Cornelio Francisco and Amalia Albino. Lawyer-actor Rudy Francisco is his brother. He married Socorro Marquez-Zaballero of Lucena, Quezon, with whom he had five children. His son Panggoy is also an actor. He studied at Arellano High School and at the University of the Philippines where he received an associate in arts diploma. He was taking up law journalism when World War II broke out. After the war, he resumed his movie career and later entered politics.

Montilla spent some 49 years in show business and made close to 200 movies, starting as an extra in Vicente Salumbides’s Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1939. After the war, he played a villain in Gerardo de Leon’s So Long, America, 1946. He became a lead actor in Tor Villano’s La Paloma (The Dove), 1947.

Some of his notable films are Octavio Silos’s Awit ng Bulag (Song of the Blind Man), 1948, with Paraluman and Linda Estrella; Susana C. de Guzman’s Pamana ng Tulisan (A Bandit’s Legacy), 1949, with Lilian Leonardo; Olive La Torres’s Takas sa Bataan (Escape from Bataan), 1950, with Norma Blancaflor; Nardo Vercudia’s Tres Muskiteros (Three Musketeers), 1951, an adaptation of Alexander Dumas’s famous classic, where he shared top billing with Oscar Moreno and Cesar Ramirez; Vercudia’s Siklab sa Batangas (War in Batangas), 1952, with Gloria Romero; Silos’s Tulisang Pugot (Headless Outlaw), 1953; La Torre’s Kontra-Bida (Villain), with Myrna Delgado; Silos’s fantasy film Mambo-Dyambo (Mumbo Jumbo), 1955, with Dolphy; Selosang Selosa (Very Jealous Woman), 1958, with Rita Gomez; and Jose de Villa’s Kamandag (Venom), 1959.

Montilla at first refused the title role in Bondying, 1954, until Dr Jose Perez of Sampaguita Pictures convinced him to accept it. He won the 1955 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Actor award for playing the man-child role.

Montilla was encouraged to run for public office after doing two films: Tagumpay ng Mahirap (Triumph of the Poor), 1965, where he played Pres Diosdado Macapagal, and The Arsenio Lacson Story, 1963, where he depicted the role of the colorful Manila mayor. Tagumpay ng Mahirap was directed by Lamberto V. Avellana, Eddie Romero, and Gerardo de Leon. He was a councilor of the fourth district of Quezon City for two terms: before the martial law period, and again from 1988 to 1998. Written by Danny Villanueva and LenaS. Pareja, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

MORENA, LEILA(Consuelo Bien Sayson) b. Guiñangan, Quezon 16 Mar 1930. Actor. Her parents are Lupo Sayson and Leona Bien. FernandoPoeSr discovered Morena and gave her a bit role in Palaboy ng Tadhana (Vagabond of Fate), 1947. She later appeared in Gerardo de Leon’s Diego Silang, 1951, with Jose PadillaJr, and Ifugao, 1954, with EfrenReyes, and played the title role in Cesar Gallardo’s Pandora, 1955, with Jose Romulo.

Her other movies include Hindi Ako Susuko (I Will Not Surrender) and Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), 1948; Pedro, Pablo, Juan, at Jose (Pedro, Pablo, Juan, and Jose), Kidlat sa Silangan (Lightning in the East), and Ang Lumang Bahay sa Gulod (The Old House on the Cliff), 1949; Wanted: Patay o Buhay (Wanted: Dead or Alive), Tigang na Lupa (Parched Earth), and Kamay ni Satanas (Hand of Satan), 1950; Bahay na Tisa (Tile-Roofed House) and Gamu-gamong Naging Lawin (Moth That Became a Hawk), 1951; Trubador (Traveling Minstrel), Raul Roldan, Salome, and Si Og sa Maynila (Og in Manila), 1952; Ander di Saya (Henpecked Husband), 1954, with Efren Reyes; Palahamak (Haughty), Mag-asawa’y Di Biro (Getting Married Is No Joke), Pandora, and Sagrado (Sacred), 1955; Ako’y Tao, May Dugo at Laman! (I Am Human, with Blood and Flesh!), Sino ang Aking Ina? (Who Is My Mother), and Ana Victoria, 1970. Written byCesar Hernando, updated by Mesandel Arguelles
(See BROADCAST ARTS volume.)

MORENO, LIZA (Louise Mitchell de Mesa) aka Dalisay Moreno. b. Clark Field, Angeles City ca 1933. Movie actor, producer, story writer. Her parents are Domingo de Mesa and Felicidad Arna Mitchell. She resided in the United States with husband John Windhorst.

Moreno first appeared in Lebran Films using the screen name Dalisay Moreno in a movie fantasy about a talking frog, Paniwalaan Dili (Believe It or Not), 1953.

Later, she made films for LVNPictures, among them Ang Langit Ko’y Ikaw (You Are My Heaven), Bayanihan (Community Spirit), Baguio Fever, and Ginintuang Tinig (Golden Voice), all shown in 1959. Her other films include Juan Tamad Goes to Society and Tres Mosqueteros (Three Musketeers), 1960; Oh, Sendang and Triplets, 1961; Kapag Buhay ang Inutang (When Life Is Taken), 1962; The Macapagal Story, The Arsenio Lacson Story, and Si Darna at ang Impakta (Darna and the Evil Creature), 1963; Babaing Kidlat (Lightning Woman), 1964; Hell of Borneo, 1967; and Mga Tigre sa Looban (Tigers in the Inner City), 1968.

In the 1960s, she and actor Eddie Rodriguez established their own movie company, Virgo Films, which produced a number of films based on stories that she wrote which Rodriguez directed under the name Luis Enriquez and which starred both or either one of them as LizaMoreno and EddieRodriguez. These films were usually melodramas revolving around love triangles.

Moreno was nominated as Best Actress twice by the FilipinoAcademyofMovie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Sino ang Matapang? (Who Is the Brave One?), 1962, and The Arsenio Lacson Story, 1963. As Louise de Mesa, she won four FAMAS awards for Best Story: for Kapag Puso’y Sinugatan (When the Heart Is Wounded), 1967; Kasalanan Kaya? (Is It a Sin?), 1968; Babae, Ikaw ang Dahilan (Woman, You Are the Reason), 1972; and Lalaki, Kasalanan Mo (Man, You Are to Blame), 1973. She also won the Manila Film Festival (MFF) award for Best Story in 1968 for Kasalanan Kaya?Written by Doreen Fernandez and Rosalie Matilac, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

MORENO, OSCAR(Oscar Gamboa Anson) b. Camalig, Albay 25 Oct 1921. d. Quezon City 19 Jul 2003. Movie actor, dancer. His parents are Ramon Anson and Elisa Gamboa. He married Belen Cristobal, a University of the East professor. His daughter Boots Anson-Roa is an actor. He studied at the University of the Philippines before the outbreak of World War II. In his travels to Paris, London, Madrid, Tokyo, and the USA, he learned much about acting and dancing.

He was accompanying a friend for a screen test when the Sampaguita Pictures matriarch, Dolores H. Vera, asked him to take it, too. He passed it; his friend didn’t. He played second lead to Carmen Rosales in Guerilyera (Lady Guerrilla Fighter), 1946; Mameng, Iniibig Kita (Mameng, I Love You) and Hele, Hele, Bago Quiere (Pretending Not to Care), 1947; 24 na Pag-ibig (24 Loves), 1948; ROTC (Reserved Officers Training Cadet), 1955; and Binibiro Lamang Kita (I Was Only Joking), 1964. He also played the lead role in Unang Pag-ibig (First Love), 1947, opposite Tita Duran in her first grown-up appearance. He also made Objective: Patayin si Magsaysay (Objective: Kill Magsaysay), 1965, opposite Aida Cariño. His other films include Baguio Cadets, 1950, where he played his dream role of cadet officer; Romeo at Julieta (Romeo and Juliet), 1951, as the tragic Shakespearean hero opposite Erlinda Cortes’s Juliet; May Isang Tsuper ng Taxi (There Was a Taxi Driver), 1953; and Babalu, 1956, with Paraluman.

In 1953 he was nominated by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences as Best Actor for his role in May Isang Tsuper ng Taksi, a Lebran film. Written byDanny Villanueva, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

MORENO, ROSARIO(Rosario Tenorio Ventaja) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 4 Oct 1916. d. Manila 9 Jan 1945. Movie actor. Her parents are Rowena Tenorio and Jose Ventaja, a Spanish soldier who later found work at the Manila Grand Opera House. She was married to actor Fernando Royo, known for his villain roles. A sister, Paz Ventaja, and a niece, Lucila Ventaja Viscarra, also played parts in the movies. She finished grade 7 in San Miguel Elementary School. She died pregnant when an American bomb hit her house in Sampaloc during the Battle of Manila.

Moreno and sister Paz were playing “extras” in a movie for Jose Nepomuceno, when the director asked Moreno to appear in Parlatone Hispano-Filipino’s Diwata ng Karagatan (Goddess of the Sea), 1936. Her first starring role was Luha ng Ina (A Mother’s Tears), 1936, with Carlos Padilla. She also worked at Excelsior Pictures and Sampaguita Pictures and became one of the most popular prewar actors, doing more than 20 films. Her team-up with Rudy Concepcion—in such pictures as Alipin ng Palad (Slave of Fate) and Mapait na Lihim (Bitter Secret), 1938; Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), 1939; and Pakiusap (Plea), 1940—was one of the most successful in local movies, rivaled only by the Carmen Rosales–Rogelio dela Rosa love team. It ended when Concepcion died while they were making the movie Mahal Pa Rin Kita (I Still Love You), 1940.

She also starred in Anak Dalita (Child of Poverty), 1936; Mga Pusong Dakila (100">Sublime Hearts) and Ang Kambal (The Twins), 1937; Inang Mahal (Mother Dear), 1938; and Siya’y Aking Anak (He/She’s My Child), 1939. She was paired with Jose PadillaJr in Dating Sumpaan (Old Vows), 1938, and with RogeliodelaRosa in Inang Mahal and Lagot na Kuwintas (Broken Necklace), 1939. Her films Pakiusap and Tunay na Ina are two of the existing prewar films available. Written by Danny Villanueva

MOVIE WORKERS WELFARE FOUNDATION INC (MOWELFUND) Established 7 Mar 1974 by movie actor and then San Juan mayor Joseph Estrada, it was organized for the benefit of movie workers and their social, educational, and economic welfare. It has contributed a lot to the training and education of film practitioners.

The first members of the Board of Trustees were Joseph Estrada, Jessie Garcia, Jess Lee, and Rolfie Velasco, who worked together in planning the mechanics of the foundation. For the first months, it sought to raise funds through the holding of the first Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) in 1975, the first Filipino Film Festival Tour in the United States and Canada, and the Supershow ’76 at the Araneta Coliseum. Only the last was successful in bringing in the much needed funds.

The Metro Manila Commission (MMC) took over the MMFF in 1977, which was marred by a controversy brought about by insults from the judges causing Dolphy, Lino Brocka, and Mike de Leon to return their trophies. In 1978 the MMC gave back the filmfest to Mowelfund’s management until 1985. The year 1979 saw the establishment of the Mowelfund Film Institute (MFI) in response to the need to raise consciousness among filmmakers and their audience of a better film culture in the country. Through the years, the MFI successfully filled its role as mentor and training ground for film students and professionals alike via scholarship programs, film workshops, etc.

In 1986 many changes happened. First, the foundation established a permanent home in a wholly owned prime location on Rosario Drive in the heart of Quezon City by April. It was a timely investment of 5.1 million pesos, made before the post-EDSA Revolt government almost sequestered its assets. In December, the former MMC, now the Metro Manila Development Authority, once again took over the MMFF, continuing to manage it until today. However, the Mowelfund is awarded 60 percent share of the net total of the amusement tax, while 20 percent goes to the Film Academy of the Philippines and 20 percent to the Anti-Film Piracy Board.

With its share in the MMFF earnings, the foundation is able to fulfill its social commitments, including medical and death benefits to about 5,000 members, composed of workers in the artistic, creative, technical, and labor sectors in the industry, most of whom come from the low-income group.

In addition, the Mowelfund is able to honor its educational commitments, through the Mowelfund Film Institute, established in 1979, which trains would-be filmmakers in the craft of filmmaking through practicum-oriented workshops on directing, photography, scriptwriting, editing, and other aspects of filmmaking, and in coordination with other institutions for seminars and lectures. The MFI has been one of the industry’s leading training ground for innovation and cinematic excellence both for mainstream and independent productions. Some of the MFI’s distinguished graduates include Brillante Mendoza, Lav Diaz, Raymond Red, Nick Deocampo, Yam Laranas, Mark Meily, Joey Agbayani, Armando “Bing” Lao, Jon Red, Roxlee, Topel Lee, Neil Daza, Robert Quebral, Mel Bacani, Ellen Ramos, Paolo Villaluna, Ricky Orellana, Auraeus Solito, Larry Manda, Sari Dalena, Kiri Dalena, Ogie Sugatan, Odyssey Flores, Mike Alcazaren, Ellen Ongkeko-Marfil, Ditsi Carolino, Jo Atienza, Regiben Romana, Albert Banzon, Shane Sarte, and Rica Arevalo.

The Mowelfund also maintains an audiovisual and literature library under the wings of its Research and Documentation Department. Its wealth of research materials on Philippine cinema answers the needs of film students, the local media people, and foreign film researchers.

The Mowelfund celebrated its 40th anniversary in 2014 with a horseracing fundraising called the Mowelfund Benefit Trophy Races. Written by Mauro Tumbocon Jr, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

MUHLACH, AGA (Ariel Aquino Muhlach) b. Manila 12 Aug 1969. Movie and television actor. Born to actor Alvaro Muhlach and Anita Aquino, he belongs to a prominent movie clan. Well-known relatives include cousin Niño Muhlach, the most popular child actor of the 1970s; uncle Alex Muhlach, a producer; and aunt Amalia Fuentes, an actor and a producer. Two sisters, Almira and Arlene, are also in the movies. He studied at the Aquinas College from elementary to high school and went to San Beda College for his tertiary education. He is married to actor Charlene Gonzales with whom he has two children. He also has a son with former partner Janice de Belen.

Muhlach first appeared in May Lalaki sa Ilalim ng Kama Ko (There’s a Man under My Bed), 1978. He played the son of Christopher de Leon in Aguila, 1980. A few years after, he made teenybopper films—like Bagets (Young Ones), 1984; Super Wan Tu Tri, 1986; and When I Fall in Love, 1986—winning the hearts of young fans with his boyish good looks and charm. He came up with an exceptionally good performance in Miguelito: Batang Rebelde (Miguelito: Young Rebel), 1985, where he starred with veteran actor Nida Blanca. After a period of coasting along on his movie career, he became one of the top choices for male dramatic lead roles in the 1990s. Muhlach’s other memorable films include Basta’t Kasama Kita (As Long as I’m with You) and Sana Maulit Muli (Second Chances), 1995; Bayarang Puso (Heart for Hire), 1996; Dahil May Isang Ikaw (Because There Is You), 1999; Pangako … Ikaw Lang (Promise … It’s Just You), 2001; Kailangan Kita (I Need You), 2002; Kung Ako na Lang Sana (Wish It Were Me), 2003; All My Life, 2004; Dubai, 2005; A Love Story, 2007; When Love Begins, 2008; In the Name of Love, 2011; and Of All the Things, 2012.

He also worked on television, having appeared in ABS-CBN’s Oki Doki Doc (Okay, Doc), 1993-2000, OK Fine Whatever, 2003, That’s My Doc, 2007, and as host for TV5’s Pinoy Explorer, 2011-14.

Muhlach’s performance in Napakasakit, Kuya Eddie (It Hurts, Brother Eddie), 1986, earned him the Best Actor award from the Catholic Mass Media Awards and nominations from almost all the award-giving bodies. Six years later, he won Best Actor in the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards and Star Awards for Sinungaling Mong Puso (Your Lying Heart), 1992. Earlier, he won the same award in the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) for Bakit Labis Kitang Mahal? (Why Do I Love You So Much?), 1992. In 1993, Muhlach won the MMFF Best Actor award for his performance in May Minamahal (Loving Someone), 1993. In 1994, he won the Young Critics Circle Film Desk award for Best Performance for the film Hindi Kita Malilimutan (I Won’t Forget You), 1993. His performance in Sana Maulit Muli earned several nominations from major award-giving bodies and gave him the Best Actor award from Gawad Urian in 1995. In 2009, Muhlach, alongside 14 other actors, received the Cinema One Legend Award from the Cinema One Originals Digital Movie Festival for his body of work and his contributions to Philippine cinema. Written by Cristine Directo, updated by Anne Frances Sangil

MUHLACH, NIÑO(Angelo Jose Muhlach) b. Manila 27 Oct 1971. Movie actor. His parents are actor Rebecca Rocha and producer Alex Muhlach, brother of actor-producer Amalia Fuentes. His maternal grandmother is actor Nela Alvarez. He is the nephew of producer Alvaro Muhlach aka Cheng Muhlach. Niño is cousin to actors Aga Muhlach, Arlene Muhlach, and Liezl, wife of actor Albert Martinez. He studied at the International School in the Philippines. He was married to Edith Millare in 2000-2005 and has a child with her. He has a second child with Diane Tupaz. Their son, Alonzo Muhlach, is now in the film industry as an actor as well.

Muhlach was only three years old when he appeared in the movie May Lalaki sa Ilalim ng Kama Ko (There’s a Man under My Bed), 1975. His first starring role was in Lulubog, Lilitaw sa Ilalim ng Tulay (Under the Bridge: Now You See It, Now You Don’t), 1975. He became the most popular child star of the 1970s starting with the box-office hit Ang Leon at ang Daga (The Lion and the Mouse), 1975, where he starred opposite Fernando Poe Jr. During this period, he made movies with action stars like Joseph Estrada in Magkaaway: Aso’t Pusa (Enemies: Cat and Dog), 1978; Ray Malonzo in Bruce Liit (Little Bruce), 1978; and Jun Aristorenas in Harabas con Bulilit (Harabas with Bulilit), 1976. He also made Tropang Bulilit (Troop of Small Tots), 1981, with Janice de Belen, Sheryl Cruz, and Lea Salonga. He was known as the “Wonder Boy” of Philippine movies, appearing in movies produced by his own outfit, D’Wonder Films, like Si Amihan at si Hagibis (Amihan and Hagibis) and Jack and Poy, 1977; Butsoy, 1978; Darna at Ding (Darna and Ding), Hepe (Chief), Juan Tamad, Junior, and Nognog, 1980; and Hepe Goes to War, 1981.

Muhlach’s more recent films include Minsan Ko Lang Sasabihin (I Will Tell You This Only Once), 2000; Mahal Kita, Kahit Sino Ka Pa (I Love You, Whoever You Are), 2001; One Percent Full, 2007; Slumber Party, 2011; On the Job and Juana C: The Movie, 2013. Apart from this, he is also active in filming television shows for ABS-CBN, GMA Network, and TV5. He appeared in the television shows Eat Bulaga! (Peek-a-Boo!), 2010; Willing Willie, 2010-11; Untold Stories Mula sa Face to Face (Untold Stories from the show Face to Face), 2010; Magic Gimick, 2011; Star Confessions, 2011; Bet on Your Baby, 2013; and Gandang Gabi, Vice! (Good Evening, Vice!), 2015.

Muhlach holds three Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards as Best Child Actor for Kutong Lupa (Earth Lice), 1976; Tahan Na Empoy, Tahan (Stop Crying Now, Empoy), 1977; and Ang Tatay Kong Nanay (My Father the Mother), 1978, which he made with Dolphy under the direction of Lino Brocka. Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

article_title: National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA)
text:
NATIONAL COMMISSION FOR CULTURE AND THE ARTS (NCCA) Created by Republic Act 7356 on 3 Apr 1992, it was preceded by the Presidential Commission on Culture and Arts, established by Executive Order 118 in 1987. The NCCA is tasked to formulate policies for the development of culture and arts; encourage artistic creation within a climate of artistic freedom; develop and promote the Filipino national culture and arts; and preserve Filipino cultural heritage.

The law stipulates the objectives of NCCA: “to formulate policies for the development of culture and the arts; implement such policies and programs in coordination with cultural agencies affiliated to it: the Cultural Center of the Philippines , the National Historical Institute (now the National Historical Commission of the Philippines), the National Museum, the National Library, the Commission of Filipino Language, and the Records Management and Archives Office; administer the National Endowment Fund for Culture and the Arts (NEFCA); encourage artistic creation within a climate of artistic freedom; develop and promote the Filipino national culture and arts; and preserve the Filipino national culture” (NCCA, n.d.).

In particular, the NCCA seeks to encourage the continuing and balanced development of a pluralistic culture—that is, multiethnic—by the people themselves; conserve and promote the nation’s historical and cultural heritage; ensure the widest dissemination of artistic and cultural products within the country and overseas; preserve and integrate traditional culture and their various creative expressions as a dynamic part of the national cultural mainstream; and ensure that standards of excellence are pursued in programs and activities by encouraging and supporting continuing discussions and debates on Philippine culture.

The NCCA has four subcommissions. Under these subcommissions are 22 independent committees composed of artists and cultural workers considered experts in their fields, who advice the NCCA on matters of direction, policies, and programs. The Subcommission on Cultural Heritage is composed of six national committees: the National Committees on Archives, Art Galleries, Historical Research, Libraries and Information Services, Monuments and Sites, and Museums. The Subcommission on the Arts includes the National Committees on Architecture and Allied Arts, Cinema, Dance, Dramatic Arts, Literary Arts, Music, and Visual Arts. The National Committee on Literary Arts evaluates and funds projects that include regional and national writing workshops, literary awards, conferences, and its flagship Philippine Writers Festival project, often held during the Philippine Arts Festival on February of each year. The Subcommission on Cultural Dissemination is composed of the National Committees on Education, Communication, and Language and Translation. The Subcommission on Cultural Communities and Traditional Arts includes the National Committees on Northern Cultural Communities, Central Cultural Communities, and Southern Cultural Communities.

The NCCA is governed by a Board of Commissioners composed of 15 members—namely, the NCCA chairman and executive director; the chairpersons of the Senate Committee on Education, Arts, and Culture, the House Committee on Basic Education and Culture, the Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino, and the National Historical Commission of the Philippines; the director of the National Museum and the National Library of the Philippines; the executive director of the National Archives of the Philippines; the president of the Cultural Center of the Philippines; as well as representatives from the Departments of Education and Tourism and the private sector. This Board of Commissioners is also assisted by a National Advisory Board composed of 19 national committee heads.

Its projects and activities have covered skills enhancement; research, documentation, and data banking; awards; scholarships; competitions; publications; conferences, seminars, or workshops; performances, exhibits, or festivals; international desk; and women’s concerns. Examples of supported projects for 2015 include festivals in Bokod (Benguet) and Sagada (Mountain Province); Rizal Arts Festival; 40th International Bamboo Organ Festival, Las Piñas; Cinema in the Regions; performing arts and exhibitions, like Manhid : The Pinoy Superhero of Ballet Philippines Foundation and the Salvador Bernal retrospective; and seminars, workshops, and historical conferences like the 24th Annual Manila Studies Conference and the Seminar Workshop on Waray Poetry Performance. It is also actively involved in the restoration of the heritage churches damaged during the Oct 2013 earthquake that devastated the Visayas. NCCA has a publication department, which carries some 103 titles consisting primarily of print, although CDs and e-books as media of dissemination have been introduced. Some printed works are monographs and journals, like Bulawan , Ani , and Espasyo, which are published periodically. Written by NCCA, Rosalinda Galang, updated by Glenn Diaz

NAVARRO, FRED(Alfredo del Prado Navarro) b. Malate, Manila 9 Mar 1919. Movie scriptwriter. Born to Francisco Navarro, a doctor, and Carmen del Prado, he studied at Letran College from elementary to high school and took fine arts at the University of the Philippines. He was a police officer before he became a scriptwriter.

Navarro did most of his work for FernandoPoeJr. Among his films are Fastbreak, 1971; Santo Domingo, 1976; Totoy Bato (Totoy the Rock), 1977; Kumander Ulupong (Commander Ulupong), 1978; Hold-up, 1979; Ang Leon at ang Kuting (The Lion and the Kitten) and Ang Agila at ang Falcon (The Eagle and the Falcon), 1980; Pepeng Kaliwete (Pepe the Lefty) and Pamilya Dimagiba (The Dimagiba Family), 1982; Isang Bala Ka Lang (I’ll Kill You with Just One Bullet), 1983; Isa-Isa lang! (Just One at a Time!), 1985; Isang Kumot Tatlong Unan (One Blanket and Three Pillows), 1986; Kapag Lumaban ang Api (When the Oppressed Fights Back), 1987; Moises Platon, Pamilya Banal (The Banal Family) and Ako … ang Huhusga (I … Will Be the Judge), 1989; and Para sa Iyo ang Huling Bala Ko (My Last Bullet Is for You), 1991.

His notable films that won nominations from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) are Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels without Heaven), 1970; Ang Alamat (The Legend), 1972; and Ang Panday … Ikatlong Yugto (The Blacksmith … Third Chapter), 1982. He also earned nominations from the FilmAcademyofthePhilippines (FAP) for Ang Panday III and Kahit Konting Pagtingin (Just a Little Love), 1990. He received other nominations from the FAMAS, Manila Film Festival, Metro Manila Film Festival, and FAP for Ito ang Maynila (This Is Manila), 1964; Lihim ng Guadalupe (Secret of Guadalupe), 1980; Ang Maestro (The Teacher), 1982; and Umpisahan Mo, Tatapusin Ko (What You Start, I Will Finish), 1984. He won Best Screenplay from the FAMAS for Durugin si Totoy Bato (Crush Totoy the Rock), 1979. Writtenby Rosalinda Galang, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

NAVARRO, JESS(Jesus Macaraeg Navarro) b. Tarlac, Tarlac 24 Jun 1948. Movie editor. Born to Eduardo Navarro and Priscila Macaraeg, he took up commerce at the University of the East in 1967. He married Caroline Bunque. They have three children.

His uncle, Marcelino Navarro, a film editor and director, brought him to Sampaguita Pictures to help edit films. Later, he worked as assistant editor under Augusto Salvador, Ike Jarlego Jr, Edgardo Vinarao, Rogelio Salvador, Ben Barcelon, and Jose H. Tarnate. He was associate editor for films like Happy Days Are Here Again, 1974; Atsay (Housemaid), 1978; and Rubia Servios, 1978. He was given his break as film editor in MVP Pictures’ Batch ’81, 1982, and Bancom Audiovision’s Kisapmata (In the Blink of an Eye), 1981, both directed by Mike de Leon. He also worked under such noted directors as Ishmael Bernal, Carlos Siguion-Reyna, Chito Roño, Peque Gallaga, and Mel Chionglo, earning a reputation as one of the movie industry’s most competent film editors.

Aside from films, Navarro edited two TV specials for Vilma Santos and documentaries for the Intramuros Administration. He also worked as music editor from 1988 to 1991 for Fil-Cartoons Inc, a Hollywood-based animation company.

For four consecutive years, Navarro won Best Editing awards from the Gawad Urian for Batch ’81, 1982; Broken Marriage, 1983; Sister Stella L., 1984; and Hinugot sa Langit (Wrenched from Heaven), 1985. He also won Gawad Urian trophies for Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven), 1991; Narito ang Puso Ko (Here Is My Heart), 1992; Milagros, 1997; and Deathrow, 2000, shared with Kelly Cruz. He received a Natatanging Gawad Urian for Lifetime Achievement in 2005. He won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences awards for Best Editing for Sister Stella L., 1985; Hihintayin Kita sa Langit, 1991; Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal (You’re the Only One I’ve Loved), 1992; The Sarah Balabagan Story, 1997; Jose Rizal, 1998; Sidhi (The Story of Ah), 1999; Bagong Buwan (New Moon), 2001; and Naglalayag (Silent Passage), 2004. He won the Film Academy of the Philippines awards for Best Editing for Sidhi, 1999; Deathrow, 2000; Silip (Peek), 2007; and Torotot (Destierro), 2008. From the Star Awards, he received the Movie Editor of the Year awards for Hinugot sa Langit, 1985; Unfaithful Wife, 1986; Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal, 1992; Pangako ng Kahapon (Yesterday’s Promise), 1994; and Jose Rizal, 1998. Star Awards also gave him the Indie Movie Editor of the Year award for Bamboo Flowers, 2013. From the Metro Manila Film Festival, he received Best Editing awards for Kisapmata, 1981; Shake, Rattle & Roll, 1984; Jose Rizal, 1998; and Deathrow, 2000. He garnered two Young Critics Circle awards for Best Editing for Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal, 1992, and Milagros, 1997. He won Best Editing in the 2004 Manila Film Festival for Kulimlim (Overcast). Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

NAVARRO, ROD(Rod Bowers) b. Manila 10 Mar 1931. d. Quezon City 9 April 2003. Movie actor. He was the son of Joseph and Florence Bowers. He married Dolores Ofracio with whom he had seven children. He took criminal investigation and military intelligence courses at the Philippine Constabulary School and later at the Military Intelligence School, Philippine Army. He entered the Philippine Constabulary in 1947 and retired as a second lieutenant in 1968. He also served as a Pasig councilor. He also became popular as a broadcast commentator and host.

Rod Navarro is best remembered for being mahangin (boastful) in the comedy films that he made since he was introduced in Sampaguita Pictures’ Kurdapya (Screwball), 1954. Navarro’s films are a mix of drama, action, and comedy, like Ang Langit sa Lupa (Heaven on Earth), 1967; Inside Job and The Manhunt, 1970; Ang Magsasaging (Banana Vendor), 1971; Ang Larawan ni Melissa (Melissa’s Portrait) and May Isang Brilyante (There Was a Diamond), 1972; The Lineman, 1976; Mong and Mamang Sorbetero (Mr Ice Cream Vendor), 1979; A Man Called “Tolongges,” 1981; Life Begins at 40, 1984; Ben Tumbling: A People’s Journal Story, 1985; Anak ng Cabron: Ikalawang Ugat (Son of a Thief: Second Root), 1991; Walang Matigas na Pulis sa Matinik na Misis (No Tough Cop to a Clever Wife) and Ikaw ang Miss Universe ng Buhay Ko (You Are the Miss Universe of My Life), 1994; Judge Max Asuncion: Hukom Bitay (Judge Max Asuncion: Judge Executioner) and Alfredo Lim: Batas ng Maynila (Alfredo Lim: The Law of Manila), 1995; and Kalabog en Bosyo (Kalabog and Bosyo), 1997.

He won the FilipinoAcademyofMovieArtsandSciences Best Supporting Actor award for Dahil sa Isang Bulaklak (Because of a Flower), 1967. Written by Romulo Baquiran Jr, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

NEPOMUCENO, ANGELITO (Angelito Acuña Nepomuceno) b. Manila 24 Jun 1928. d. 31 Oct 2010. Movie actor. His parents are Isabel Acuña and producer Jose Nepomuceno aka the “Father of Philippine Movies.” He is the father of sportsman Rafael Nepomuceno, who has six world titles in bowling. He married Teresita Villareal. His brother, Luis Nepomuceno, became a director and producer.

Nepomuceno was the first child star of Philippine movies. When he was eight years old, he appeared with his brother, Lubin, and another child star, Tita Duran, in Sa Paanan ng Krus (At the Foot of the Cross), 1936. He played a dual role in Hampaslupa (Vagabond), 1937, which broke all box-office records of Filipino movies at that time. Among his other films are X’Otic Pictures’ Leron-Leron Sinta (Leron-Leron Beloved), 1939, with Lucita Goyena and Fernando Poe Sr; Palaboy ng Diyos (God’s Vagabond), 1939, directed by Gregorio Fernandez; Tatlong Pagkabirhen (Three Times a Virgin), 1939, with Tita Duran, Lucita Goyena, and Reynaldo Dante; and Ang Lihim ng Lumang Simbahan (The Secret of the Old Church), 1940, with Luningning, Reynaldo Dante, Pugo, and Togo.

He is best remembered for his films with Tita Duran, like Mariang Alimango (Maria the Crab), 1938, a Cinderella story based on a Filipino folktale, and Mga Tinik ng Isang Bulaklak (A Flower’s Thorns), 1939. In 2014, he received his Walk of Fame star posthumously in Eastwood City. Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

NEPOMUCENO, JOSE (Jose Zialcita Nepomuceno) aka Don Jose. b. Quiapo, Manila 15 May 1893. d. Manila 1 Dec 1959. Movie producer and director, acknowledged as the “Father of Philippine Movies.” His parents are Jose Nepomuceno and Teofila Zialcita. He married Isabel Acuña, by whom he had eight children, among whom are child actors Lubin and Angelito Nepomuceno, and Luis Nepomuceno, who became a film director. He graduated with a bachelor of arts degree from San Beda College and finished a course in fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas. An accredited correspondent for Pathe News and Paramount News of Hollywood, Nepomuceno acquired experience in his career by making documentaries and newsreels on various events, such as the funeral of the first wife of Sergio Osmeña Sr and the great Kanto earthquake in Japan, and by making English and Spanish subtitles for films that were then imported from Europe.

Nepomuceno started out as a photographer and proprietor of his photo studio Electro-Photo-Studio Parhelio. Later he sold his studio, then the biggest and most expensive in the country, and founded Malayan Movies in 1917. After two years of experimentation and training, he finally made Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), 1919, the first Filipino-produced feature film. This was followed by La Venganza de Don Silvestre (The Vengeance of Don Silvestre), 1919, a sequel to Dalagang Bukid; Un Capullo Marchito (A Withered Bud), 1920; Hoy o Nunca Besame (Kiss Me Now or Never), 1923; and La Mariposa Negra (Black Beauty), 1923. In 1926, he made Ang Tatlong Hambog (The Three Braggarts), starring Luis Tuason and Elizabeth “Dimples” Cooper who did the first kissing scene in the local movie industry. In 1933, he produced Punyal na Ginto (Golden Dagger). His films dominated the first years of the talkies: Dr. Kuba (Dr Hunchback), 1933, starring Rosa del Rosario and Jose Padilla Jr; Sawing Palad (The Unfortunate), 1934, starring Leopoldo Salcedo, Corazon Noble, and Rogelio de la Rosa; Santong Diablo (Holy Devil), 1936, starring Leopoldo Salcedo and Purita Santa Maria.

Constantly plagued by lack of capital, he was producer, storyteller, scriptwriter, cameraman, labman, art director, film editor, distributor, and exhibitor of his films. His home and studios burned down in 1921 and 1923 but he never gave up. He then formed Malayan Pictures Corporation in 1923, Nepomuceno Productions in 1932, the Nepomuceno-Harris-Tait partnership in 1933, Parlatone Hispano-Filipino Inc in 1935, X’Otic Films in 1938, and Polychrome Motion Pictures Corporation in 1946.

Nepomuceno shared his skills with other pioneering producers like Vicente Salumbides and Julian Manansala. Among the talents whom he discovered and developed were Atang de la Rama, Leopoldo Salcedo, Gerardo de Leon, Mary Walter, Gregorio Fernandez, Rogelio de la Rosa, Rosa del Rosario, Fernando Poe Sr, Remigio Young, Corazon Noble, Armando Crisostomo, Nita Carmona, Domingo Principe, Tita Duran, Celia Marcaida, Naty Fernandez, Elsa Oria, Lucita Goyena, Angel Esmeralda, and Dolly Garcia.

In 1983, writer Jose Quirino published a book titled Don Jose and the Early Philippine Cinema, an account of Nepomuceno’s life and contribution to the film industry. Written byDanny Villanueva, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

NOBLE, CORAZON (Patrocinio Decano Abad) b. Sampaloc, Manila 17 Apr 1919. d. 2001. Movie actor. Her parents are Dr Tirso Abad and Antonina Decano. Actor Carmencita Abad is her sister. She was a student at Far Eastern University when she entered the movies. She and actor Angel Esmeralda are the parents of actor Jay Ilagan.

Noble was discovered by Jose Nepomuceno who cast her in the title role of Malayan Pictures’ Anak ng Pari (Child of a Priest) in 1937. The film ran into censorship problems and was not shown. Her second film, Batang Tulisan (Young Bandit), almost suffered the same fate, but the censors allowed it to be shown later under a different title, Binatang Bukid (Country Lad), 1938. Her third picture, Dugong Hinugasan (Blood Rinsed), 1938, was likewise banned. She transferred to Sampaguita Pictures and the course of her movie career changed. Her team-up with Rogelio de la Rosa in Octavio Silos’s Pasang Krus (Cross on the Shoulder), 1939, was well received by movie audiences. This was followed immediately by Manuel Silos’s Dalisay (Chaste), 1939, where she and de la Rosa formed a quartet with Fely Vallejo and Ernesto La Guardia; and Gregorio Fernandez’s Ang Magsasampaguita (The Flower Vendor), 1939, which had child stars Tita Duran and Narding Anzures adding luster to the story of her love affair with de la Rosa. Her other films made during the pre-World War II era were Magbalik Ka, Hirang (Come Back, Beloved), Gunita (Reminiscence), Bahaghari (Rainbow), and Kahapon Lamang (Only Yesterday), 1940; Panibugho (Jealousy), Tarhata, Sa Iyong Kandungan (In Your Bosom), Balatkayo (Pretense), and Ang Tagala (The Tagalog Woman), 1941. During the war, Noble was hit by a stray Japanese bullet, which left her with a disabled right arm. Despite her handicap, she was able to make several postwar movies with Sampaguita Pictures, among them Maynila (Manila), 1946, with Ely Ramos; Landas na Ginto (Path of Gold), 1946, with Jose Padilla Jr; Kaputol ng Isang Awit (Fragment of a Song), 1948, with Paraluman and Eddie del Mar; and Tatlong Puso (Three Hearts), 1948, with Tita Duran and Fred Montilla.

She made two films for LVN Pictures: Backpay and Magkaibang Lahi (Different Races), both in 1947. In her time, Noble was known as the “Queen of Tearjerkers.” Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

NOLASCO BROS PICTURES It was established in 1941 by Luis F. Nolasco, former production and publicity manager of Jose Nepomuceno who also served with Parlatone-Hispano Filipino, Excelsior Pictures, Sampaguita Pictures, Filippine Films, and LVN.

The filming of Nolasco Bros’s first picture, Ginoong Patay Gutom (Mister Destitute), was interrupted by the outbreak of the Pacific War in 1941. Production resumed immediately after the return of the Americans in 1945 and the film was shown on 15 Jul 1946. Encouraged by the success of its first movie, Nolasco proceeded to make Fort Santiago, 1946, which broke box-office records when it was shown for 34 days continuously at the Bataan Theater. Other films made by Nolasco Bros in the 1940s were Kamagong and Amoritis (The Love Bug), 1947; Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows) and Mga Busabos ng Palad (Slaves of Destiny), 1948; Ginang Takaichi (Mrs Takaichi), Apat na Dalangin (Four Prayers), Ronquillo, and Muntinlupa, 1949; and the remake of a prewar film, Ang Lumang Simbahan (The Old Church), 1949.

Among its stars who made it to the top were Vida Florante, Leila Morena, Norma Blancaflor, Rosa Rosal, Lilia Dizon, Ernesto La Guardia, and Rodolfo Ruiz. Written by Lena S. Pareja

NOLASCO, LUIS F. Manila 25 Aug 1901. d. Manila 7 May 1990. Scriptwriter, director, producer. He studied at Ateneo de Manila. In the late 1930s he was editor of two movie magazines, Literary Song Movie and Philippine Cinema and Radio. He was also literary editor of a weekly Spanish newspaper, Nuevo Horizonte. He wrote “Cronicas Parlamentarias” (Parliamentary Views), a political column, and “Desde Mi Butaca” (From My Armchair), a critical column on the local screen and stage. He is the author of two novels in Spanish, El Calvario (The Calvary) and Mujer (Woman), and a volume of poems in Spanish, Catarata de Ensueños (Waterfall of Dreams).

Nolasco began his film career during the silent pictures era as publicity director and dialogue writer of Don Jose Nepomuceno in Malayan Pictures. Later, he became production manager of Parlatone Hispano-Filipino Pictures. He also helped establish and manage the movie studios of Sampaguita Pictures, Excelsior Pictures, X’Otic Films, and Filippine Films after it changed hands from the Americans to Filipino entrepreneurs.

Among his screenplays are the biggest movie productions of the pre-World War II era such as Nasaan Ka Irog? (Where Are You, Beloved?), Milagro ng Nazareno sa Quiapo (Miracle of the Nazarene in Quiapo), and Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), 1937; Madaling Araw (Break of Dawn), 1938; Pakiusap (Plea), 1940; and Ibong Sawi (Forlorn Bird), 1941. Together with director Carlos Vander Tolosa and music composer Miguel Velarde Jr, Nolasco formed a team that produced unforgettable movies of the late 1930s and early 1940s.

After World War II, Nolasco put up his own film company, Nolasco Bros Pictures, for which he produced films that he himself scripted and directed. These include Ginoong Patay-Gutom (Mister Destitute), 1946; Kamagong and Amoritis (The Love Bug), 1947; Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows) and Mga Busabos ng Palad (Slaves of Destiny), 1948; and the remake of a prewar film, Ang Lumang Simbahan (The Old Church), 1949. To Nolasco belongs the credit of having discovered such film stars as Rosa Rosal, Leila Morena, Eddie del Mar, Vida Florante, and Lilia Dizon. In the mid-1950s Nolasco worked as assistant to LVN’s Doña Narcisa de Leon.

Nolasco won the Zobel Prize in 1979 for his writings in Spanish for such publications as El Debate, La Opinion, and Academia Filipina. Written by Lena S. Pareja

O'HARA, MARIO (Mario Herrero O’Hara) b. Zamboanga City 20 Apr 1946. d. Pasay City 26 Jun 2012. Movie, stage, and television scriptwriter, actor, and director. He is the son of Basilisa Herrero and one-time University of the Philippines (UP) Dramatic Club member Jaime O’Hara. He studied at Padre Zamora Southeastern College, Pasay City, and took up chemical engineering at Adamson University. He worked in radio station DZRH and TV channels 11 and 2.
