O’Hara joined the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) in 1969 and worked with director Lino Brocka, later National Artist. He appeared in numerous stage plays for PETA, Dulaang UP, Tanghalang Pilipino, and other theater groups. He played major roles in Kabesang Tales, Panunuluyan (Christmas Play), Immigration Blues, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), El Filibusterismo (Subversion), Laruang Kariton (Toy Cart), Mac Malicsi TNT, and Sa North Diversion Road (On the North Diversion Road). In 1998, the Centennial Literary Prize for sarsuwela was given to O’Hara for Ang Palasyo ni Valentin (Valentin’s Palace), 2003. The play was later staged by PETA in 2005. He also penned Stageshow and collaborated with Tanghalang Pilipino for its performance in 2012.

He wrote the scripts of some films directed by Brocka, like Cadena de Amor (Chain of Love), 1971; Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (You Were Weighed and Found Wanting), 1974; the episode “Hellow Soldier” in Tatlo, Dalawa, Isa (Three, Two, One), 1974; Insiang, 1976, co-written with Lamberto Antonio; and Hayop sa Hayop (Beast to Beast), 1978. As a movie actor, he appeared in films like Tubog sa Ginto (Dipped in Gold), 1970, Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang, Tatlo, Dalawa, Isa, and Gumising Ka … Maruja (Wake Up … Maruja), 1978. His first directorial work was Mortal, 1975, which he also wrote. After that, he wrote and directed Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos (Three Godless Years), 1976; Mga Bilanggong Birhen (Caged Virgins), 1977; Kastilyong Buhangin (Sand Castle), 1980; Bakit Bughaw ang Langit? (Why Is the Sky Blue?), 1981, co-written with Lydia Collantes Villegas; Condemned, 1984, co-written with Jose Javier Reyes and Frank Rivera; Bagong Hari (New King), 1986; “Banga” (Jar) episode in Halimaw (Monster), 1986; Takot Ako, Eh! (I’m Scared!), 1987, co-written with Tito Rey; Tatlong Ina, Isang Anak (Three Moms, One Child), 1987, co-written with Frank Rivera; Babae sa Bubungang Lata (Woman on a Tin Roof), 1998; Sisa, 1999; Babae sa Breakwater (Woman of Breakwater), 2003; and Ang Paglilitis ni Andres Bonifacio (The Trial of Andres Bonifacio), 2010. The last was for the Directors Showcase of the 6th Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival.

O’Hara acted in and directed episodes in the TV series Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) and directed the TV series Lovingly Yours, Helen. In 2012, he directed the TV5 miniseries Sa Ngalan ng Ina, his last project.

O’Hara won the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) Best Screenplay award for Rubia Servios, 1978. He also copped the MMFF Best Director award for Bulaklak sa City Jail (Flowers of the City Jail), 1984, and again for his episode in Halimaw (Monster) in the 1986 MMFF, where he was also awarded Best Actor. He also won Best Director in the Gawad Urian for The Fatima Buen Story, 1994. O’Hara’s work earned recognition in international festivals, such as the Singapore International Film Festival for Pangarap ng Puso (Demons), 2001, which was nominated Best Asian Feature Film. The film Babae sa Breakwater earned a number of accolades, including the Young Critics Circle Best Film and Best Screenplay awards in 2004, and a Gawad Urian recognition in 2011 as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 2000-09. It was also nominated at Fribourg International Film Festival for its direction. The film was shown in the Directors’ Fortnight at the 2004 Cannes Film Festival. In 2011, Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival rendered Mario O’Hara a special tribute as “The Silent Master of the Filipino Film.” Written by Malou M. Maniquis, updated by Erika Carreon and Nicanor G. Tiongson

OPTICAL MEDIA BOARD (OMB ) It was created in Feb 2004 by Republic Act 9239 otherwise known as the Optical Media Act of 2003 as approved by Pres Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo to replace the Videogram Regulatory Board (VRB). It is under the direct supervision of the Office of the President.

The Optical Media Bill was introduced in Congress in 2002 to reorganize the VRB, which was established by Presidential Decree 1987 and signed by Pres Ferdinand Marcos, to address the worsening piracy of films, music, and software, and to strengthen local movie production. Two years later, the proposed legislation was signed into law by President Arroyo, in effect creating the OMB. The OMB’s authority covers the entire territory of the Philippines. Host-actor Edu Manzano was appointed by President Arroyo as the first chairman of the OMB. Manzano was replaced by action star Ronald “Ronnie” Ricketts after the former resigned in August 2009. In 2013, Ricketts was given the Special Recognition Award by the Metro Manila Film Festival for his work at the OMB.

To further strengthen its campaign against media piracy, the OMB also works with police authorities and other organizations, such as the National Cinema Association of the Philippines and the Movie Picture Anti-Film Piracy Council of the Philippines. Law enforcement agencies, including the OMB, confiscated around 6.8 billion pesos worth of fake goods during the first half of 2014. With the help of the OMB, the Philippines was removed from the United States’ list of piracy hot spots or the Special 301 Watch List. Written by Kathrina Alvarez

ORIA, ELSA (Elsa Iringao Oria) b. Manila 5 Mar 1916. d. Los Angeles, California 28 Dec 1995. Movie actor and singer. She is the daughter of Mercedes Iringao and Tomas Gonzales Oria. She went through high school at Santa Rosa College in Manila and trained in voice under her father.

Oria’s fine coloratura soprano voice caught the attention of producer Jose Nepomuceno, who gave her a starring role in Awit ng mga Ulila (Song of the Orphans), 1936. She also starred in Huling Awit (Last Song), with Jose Padilla Jr, and Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), 1937, with Rogelio de la Rosa; Paroparong Bukid (Country Butterfly), with Rudy Concepcion, and Madaling Araw (Break of Dawn), with Ely Ramos, 1938; and Mabangong Bulaklak (Fragrant Flower), 1939, with Fernando Poe Sr. Her other films are Nasaan Ka Irog? (Where Are You, Beloved?), 1937; Ikaw Rin (You, Too), Alitaptap (Firefly), and Inday, 1940, with Ernesto La Guardia. She was called the “Singing Sweetheart of the Philippines,” and she and Ely Ramos were dubbed the “Jeannette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy of the Philippines” during the pre-World War II years. Her most memorable film is Isumpa Mo, Giliw (Make a Vow, My Love), 1947, directed by Gerardo de Leon. Written by Glecy Atienza, updated by Pamela Mathiel Lopez

OROPESA, ELIZABETH (Jackilyn Elizabeth Oropesa Freeman) b. 17 Jul 1954. Movie and television actor. She was a former Miss Luzon and is now known as Dr Elizabeth O. Freeman, a healer. She is the daughter of Dr Freeman, a military physician. She was married to Taipei-based Chinese martial arts actor Meng Fei, later to Mark Roces, and then to physical therapist Joel Valdez. She has a son by Fei and a daughter by Roces. She studied alternative medicine in the United States and finished traditional Chinese medicine, including herbology and acupuncture, at the University of the East Ramon Magsaysay Memorial Center.

Oropesa’s career started in 1973. Her films include Lumapit… Lumayo ang Umaga (Morning Comes and Goes) and Mister Mo, Lover Boy Ko (Your Husband, My Lover) 1975; Nunal sa Tubig (Speck in the Water), 1976; Aguila and Si Malakas, si Maganda at si Mahinhin (The Strong, the Beautiful, and the Demure), 1980; Mahinhin vs Mahinhin (Demure vs Demure) and Uhaw na Dagat (Thirsty Sea), 1981; Palabra de Honor (Word of Honor), 1983; Kailan Tama ang Mali (When Is Wrong Right?), 1986; The Untold Story: Vizconde Massacre II; May the Lord Be with Us!, 1994; Milagros, 1997; Sa Pusod ng Dagat (In the Navel of the Sea) and Kasal-Kasalan (Sakalan) (Pretend Marriage [Strangling Each Other]), 1998; Esperanza: The Movie and Bulaklak ng Maynila (Flower of Manila), 1999; Balahibong Pusa (Cat’s Fur), 2001; Laman (Flesh), 2002; Lastikman (Plastic Man), 2003; Shake, Rattle & Roll 2K5, 2005; Apoy sa Dibdib ng Samar (Fire in the Bosom of Samar) and Captain Barbell, 2006; Ded Na si Lolo (Grandpa Is Dead), 2009; Batang Ama (Young Father), 2011; Maratabat (Pride and Honor), 2014; and Felix Manalo, 2015.

Oropesa’s works on television include the drama series Esperanza, 1997; Sana ay Ikaw Na Nga (I Hope You’re the One), 2002; Te Amo: Maging Sino Ka Man (Speaking the Language of Love), 2004; Adik sa ’Yo (Addicted to You), 2009; Obsession, 2014; and Flordeliza, 2015. She also appeared in various episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 1995-2013. She was also part of the TV movie Pagsubok sa Paanan ng Bulkan (Trial at the Foot of the Volcano), 2002.

Oropesa received a Best Actress award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 1976 for her performance in Lumapit, Lumayo ang Umaga and a Best Supporting Actress award from Gawad Urian in 1998 for Milagros. Her next major win was a grand slam for her performance in Bulaklak ng Maynila, for which she won the awards for Best Actress from the 1999 Metro Manila Film Festival, and from the FAMAS, Film Academy of the Philippines, Gawad Urian, Star Awards for Movies, and Young Critics’ Circle in 2000. In 2003, she again won a Gawad Urian for Best Supporting Actress for her performance in Laman. Written by Susan Claire Agbayani
(See BROADCAST ARTS volume.)

OSORIO, CONSUELO P. (Consuelo Ruiz Padilla-Osorio) aka Ateng Osorio, Consuelo Ruiz. b. 1 Sep 1907. d. Jan 1987. Movie director, scriptwriter, and actor. Her parents are actors Jose Padilla Sr, former governor of Bulacan, and Clarita Ruiz, who had 10 children, all connected with show business. Her four siblings are actor Jose Padilla Jr, husband of actor Arsenia Francisco; actor-director Carlos Padilla Sr, father of world-boxing referee and movie actor Carlos Padilla Jr and grandfather of singer-actor Zsa Zsa Padilla; actor Maria Clara Ruiz, wife of cinematographer Pedro R. Santos and mother of former child star Tessie Santos; and Paz Padilla, wife of director Gregorio Fernandez and mother of actors Merle and Rudy Fernandez. Her other half-siblings are actor Bob Padilla, a stuntman; actor-politician Roy Padilla, father of action star Robin Padilla; actor Amado Cortez, husband of actor Gloria Sevilla; actor Pilar Padilla; and actor Cristina Aragon of Valentina fame, the snake-headed woman in Darna, 1951. She married scriptwriter-director Salvador Osorio. Bebong Osorio, former child actor turned movie director, is their son.

As scriptwriter, she was first known under her pseudonym Consuelo Ruiz. She wrote the screenplay of Bahay Kubo (Nipa Hut), 1938, the first big musical of Gerardo de Leon starring Fely Vallejo, Rogelio de la Rosa, and Fleur de Lis aka Mona Lisa.

The Salvador Osorio–Consuelo Ruiz team scripted and directed such films as Dolores, 1939, starring Gloria Imperial and Reynaldo Dante, and Pagsuyo (Courtship), 1941, starring Norma Blancaflor and Jose Padilla Jr. As actor, she appeared in Asahar at Kabaong (Bridal Garland and Casket), 1937, playing the mother of real-life brother Jose Padilla Jr.

Osorio was one of the first women directors in the movie industry. Her first picture was Dalagang Luksa (Lady in Mourning), 1938, a Parlatone film starring her sister Maria Clara Ruiz. After World War II she directed most of her films under Premiere Productions, including Bagong Sinderella (Modern Cinderella), Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), and Pangarap Ko’y Ikaw Rin (I Dream of You), 1947; Bulalakaw (Shooting Star) and Maliit Lamang ang Daigdig (The World Is a Small Place), 1948; Anak ng Panday (Son of the Blacksmith), 1949; and Hiwaga ng Tulay na Bato (Mystery of the Stone Bridge), 1950. In Halik sa Bandila (A Kiss to the Flag), 1948, she was recognized as the first Filipino woman director of a war film.

Osorio was nominated for Best Screenplay twice by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences: for Kung Ako’y Mahal Mo (If You Love Me), 1960, shared with Joseph de Cordova; and Kami’y Kaawaan (Have Mercy on Us), 1963. Written by Ramon Jocson, Ellen Bomasang, and Lena S. Pareja

PADILLA, CARLOS (Carlos Ruiz Padilla Sr) b. 6 Sep 1909. d. 8 Mar 1964. Movie actor, director, and producer. The second of five children of former Bulacan governor Jose Padilla Sr and actor Clarita Ruiz, Padilla’s siblings were all in the movies. They are actor Jose Padilla Jr, husband of actor Arsenia Francisco; director Consuelo P. Osorio, mother of actor-director Bebong Osorio; actor Maria Clara Ruiz, wife of cinematographer Pedro R. Santos and mother of former child star Tessie Santos; and Paz Padilla, wife of director Gregorio Fernandez and mother of actors Merle and Rudy Fernandez. His half siblings are actor Bob Padilla, a stuntman; actor-politician Roy Padilla, father of Robin and Rommel Padilla; actor Amado Cortez, husband of actor Gloria Sevilla; actor Pilar Padilla; actor Cristina Aragon of Valentina fame, the snake-headed woman in the early Darna movies. He is the father of world-boxing referee Carlos Padilla Jr who is also an actor, and grandfather of singer-actor ZsaZsa Padilla. He is granduncle to actors Robin Padilla, BB Gandanghari (formerly Rustom Padilla), and Rommel Padilla. He is great granduncle to actors Daniel Padilla and Bella Padilla.

Padilla first appeared in Don Jose Nepomuceno’s silent film La Monjita (The Nun) and Lilies of Benguet, 1931. He was lead actor opposite Alma Bella in the first Tagalog talking picture, Jose Nepomuceno’s Punyal na Ginto (Golden Dagger), 1933. His other early films include Makata at Paraluman (Poet and Muse), 1933, with Rosario Moreno; Anting-Anting (Amulet), 1934; Mga Kaluluwang Napaligaw (Lost Souls), 1936; Hiram na Ligaya (Borrowed Happiness) and Gagamba (Spider), 1937; Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1939; Anghel na Tukso (Tempting Angel), 1940; and Ararong Ginto (Golden Plow), 1941. He also played lead roles in many LVN and Premiere Productions movies. He starred in four movies made by Padilla Bros Productions, which was set up in 1949 and which he managed. These are Ina ng Awa (Mother of Mercy) and Bulakeño (Native of Bulacan), 1949; Bulaklak ng Digmaan (War Flower), 1950; and Ngipin sa Ngipin (A Tooth for a Tooth), 1952, directed by Consuelo P. Osorio.

Padilla directed several pictures for Parlatone Hispano-Filipino and Sampaguita Pictures. Among his films as director are Manyikang Putik (Doll of Mud) and Bukang Liwayway (Dawn), 1938; Lagot na Kuwintas (Broken Necklace), 1939; and Magpakailan Man (Forever and Ever) and Cariñosa (Lovable), 1940. He usually acted in the films he directed. He was both actor and director in Namumukod na Bituin (Special Star), with Rosita Rivera; Siya’y Aking Anak (He/She’s My Child); and Walang Tahanan (Homeless), all in 1939. While doing postproduction work, he suffered a fatal stroke. Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

PADILLA, JOSE JR. (Jose Ruiz Padilla Jr) aka Pempe Padilla b. Manila 16 Jul 1912. d. 18 Jun 1979. Movie actor. His parents are actors JosePadilla Sr, former governor of Bulacan, and Clarita Ruiz. He married actor ArseniaFrancisco, with whom he had five children. Almost all of Padilla’s siblings are in show business: actor-director CarlosPadillaSr, father of world-boxing referee and movie actor Carlos Padilla Jr and grandfather of singer-actor Zsa Zsa Padilla; and director ConsueloP.Osorio, mother of actor-director Bebong Osorio. Halfsiblings are actor Bob Padilla, a stuntman; actor-politician Roy Padilla, father of Robin Padilla and BB Gandanghari (formerly Rustom Padilla) and grandfather of Daniel Padilla; actor Amado Cortez, husband of actor GloriaSevilla; actor Maria Clara Ruiz, wife of cinematographer Pedro R. Santos and mother of former child star Tessie Santos; actor Pilar Padilla; actor Cristina Aragon of Valentina fame, the snake-headed woman in the early Darna movies; and Paz Padilla, wife of director Gregorio Fernandez and mother of actors Merle and RudyFernandez. He became an amateur boxing champion and represented the Philippines in the 1936 World Olympics held in Berlin, Germany.

It was his brother-in-law, director GregorioFernandez, who convinced Padilla to enter the movies. He appeared in Dr. Kuba (Dr Hunchback), 1933, and Mag-inang Mahirap (Destitute Mother and Child), 1934, both with RosadelRosario. He was the leading man of CarmenRosales in her first and only film for Excelsior Pictures, Arimunding-Munding, 1939. When she transferred to Sampaguita Pictures, he appeared as her leading man in such films as Carmen, Princesita (Little Princess), and Lolita, 1941, the Filipino movie that was showing in a downtown theater when Manila was declared “open city” in January 1942. Before this, he had appeared with other leading ladies of the prewar era: RosarioMoreno in Magpakailan Man (Forever and Ever), 1940; Corazon Noble in Panibugho (Jealousy), and NormaBlancaflor in Pagsuyo (Courtship), 1941.

After the war, he appeared in The Voice of Freedom and Probinsyana (Country Girl), 1946. He was teamed up with MiladelSol in Binatang Taring (Elegant Bachelor), Romansa (Romance), Violeta, and Maling Akala (Mistaken Notions), 1947. His other postwar movies include Bagong Sinderela (Modern Cinderella), with Rosa del Rosario, and Ngayon at Kailanman (Now and Forever), with Ester Magalona, 1947; Perfidia, with Anita Linda and LiliaDizon, Halik sa Bandila (A Kiss to the Flag), with Efren Reyes Sr, Hiram na Pangalan (Borrowed Name), Labi ng Bataan (Bataan Survivors), and Lihim na Bayani (Secret Hero), with VirginiaMontes, 1948; Anak ng Panday (Son of the Blacksmith) and Hen. Gregorio del Pilar (General Gregorio del Pilar), 1949. Padilla teamed up again with Rosales in Premiere Productions’ Sipag Ay Yaman (Industry Is Wealth), 1949, and Ang Bombero (The Firefighter), 1950. With Rebecca Gonzales, he made Pista sa Nayon (Barrio Fiesta) and Mutya ng Pasig (Muse of Pasig), 1950. He also appeared in Tatlong Balaraw (Three Daggers), Punglo at Pag-ibig (Bullet and Love), Sa Oras ng Kasal (At the Time of the Wedding), and Bahay na Tisa (Tile-Roofed House), with LeilaMorena and Patria Plata, 1950. His more notable films in the 1950s include Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo (Python in the Old Dome), 1952; Habang Buhay (For a Lifetime), 1953; Dakilang Hudas (Great Judas) and Paltik (Homemade Gun), 1955; and Huling Mandirigma (The Last Warrior), 1956. He continued making films up to the 1970s, with Inside Job and Dalawang Daigdig ni Carlota (The Two Worlds of Carlota), 1970; Guadalupe, Toro! Toro! Toray!, Digmaan ng mga Angkan (Clash of Clans), and Currimao, 1971; Ang Alamat (The Legend), 1972; Florinda, 1973; and Batingaw (Church Bell), 1974.

Padilla was chosen Best Actor by the MariaClaraAwards for his portrayal of the Filipino hero in Diego Silang, 1951, and by the FilipinoAcademyofMovieArts andSciences for his role of a reformed rebel in Huk sa Bagong Pamumuhay (Huk in a New Life), 1953.Written by Joy Galvez and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

PADILLA, ROBIN (Robinhood Ferdinand Cariño Padilla aka Abdul Aziz Padilla) b. Daet, Camarines Norte 23 Nov 1969. Movie and television actor and screenwriter. He is the son of Casimiro Padilla Sr aka Roy Padilla, a movie director who became vice-governor of Camarines Norte in the 1970s and an assemblyman in the 1980s, and Lolita Eva Cariño, a former movie actor. Padilla belongs to one of the most prominent clans in Philippine show business that spans four generations. His father’s brother, actor Carlos Padilla Sr, is the father of former actor turned professional boxing referee Carlos “Sonny” Padilla Jr. In turn, Carlos Padilla Jr is the father of singer/actor Zsa Zsa Padilla and the grandfather of singer/TV host Karylle (Zsa Zsa’s daughter). Erstwhile actor Melanie Padilla, a sister of Roy and Carlos Sr, is the mother of singer Gino Padilla. Another sister, Paz, is the mother of the late action star Rudy Fernandez and former actor Merle Fernandez. Out of Padilla’s seven siblings, three are in show business: BB Gandanghari (formerly Rustom), Rommel, and Royette. Three of Rommel’s sons have also turned to acting: Rommel Antonio (screen name: RJ), Ralph Matthew (screen name: Matt), and their half-brother Daniel (Rommel’s son with actor Karla Estrada). Padilla is the father of television actors Kylie and Queenie, his daughters with ex-wife Liezel Sicangco. He is also the uncle of actor Bela Padilla, whose grandmother is the sister of Lolita Eva Cariño (Padilla’s mother). After divorcing his first wife, Padilla married TV host Mariel Rodriguez on 19 Aug 2010 at the Taj Mahal in India.

Exposed by his parents to show business at a young age, Padilla decided to follow in their footsteps. At the age of 16, he first appeared in a small role in the action-comedy Public Enemy No. 2: Maraming Number 2 (Public Enemy No. 2: So Many Number 2s), 1985. His first major movie role is in director Ricardo “Bebong” Osorio’s action-packed Bala Ko ang Hahatol (My Bullet Will Be the Judge), 1985. The following year, he teamed up with Jinggoy Estrada and E.R. Ejercito in Augusto Buenaventura’s Bagets Gang (Teenage Gang), 1986. After a series of supporting roles in more action movies, Padilla starred opposite Dawn Zulueta in Hindi Ako Pahuhuli ng Buhay (I Will Not Be Caught Alive), 1989. He also headlined action director Deo Fajardo Jr’s Carnap King: The Randy Padilla Story, 1989.

The year 1990 signaled the arrival of Robin Padilla as Philippine cinema’s newest action star, making five movies in that year alone; three of which firmly established his unique action star persona. First was Deo Fajardo Jr’s Anak ni Baby Ama (Son of Baby Ama), 1990, where Padilla plays the son of Baby Ama, a famous character in the Filipino action genre portrayed in an earlier movie by no less than his cousin Rudy Fernandez. This was quickly followed by Willy Milan’s Barumbado (Troublemaker), 1990, and Eddie Rodriguez’s Bad Boy, 1990. The latter earned Padilla the moniker “Bad Boy of Philippine Movies.” His “Bad Boy” image embodied the chain-smoking, hard-drinking, uncouth yet handsome young man of the 1990s, ready to self-destruct at any moment due to his excesses.

The following year, Padilla teamed up with Sharon Cuneta and again with director Eddie Rodriguez in what would turn out to be his most memorable movie: Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), 1991. The film employs one of the most time-tested formulas in Filipino movies—that of a wholesome rich girl who falls in love with a poor petty criminal with a heart of gold. Its use of action, romance, and touches of comedy ensured its box-office success and officially turned Padilla into a major movie star.

Riding on the triumph of Maging Sino Ka Man, Padilla chose one of his co-stars in that movie to be his next leading lady. Ang Utol Kong Hoodlum (My Hoodlum Brother), 1991, features Padilla with Vina Morales, the teenage newcomer who played Loleng in Maging Sino Ka Man (the big sister to the group of kids adopted by Padilla’s character Carding). Ang Utol Kong Hoodlum was such a hit at the box office that Padilla decided to make a sequel right away. Miss na Miss Kita: Ang Utol Kong Hoodlum 2 (I Miss You So Much: My Hoodlum Brother 2), 1992, reunites Padilla with Vina Morales and signals Padilla’s first foray as a screenwriter (using his real name: Robinhood Cariño Padilla). Padilla would go on to write the screenplays in some of his succeeding movies, but with less success.

By the 2000s, perhaps sensing that the action genre was on its way out, Padilla transformed himself into a leading man and ventured into other genres. He topbilled a slate of romantic films—including Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw (You’re the One I Need), 2000; Pagdating ng Panahon (When the Time Comes), 2001; You and Me against the World, 2003; Till I Met You, 2006—and horror movies like Kulimlim (Overcast), 2004; Blackout, 2007; and Sundo (Fetch), 2009. He also became interested in independent films and starred in Jon Red’s ASTIGmatism, 2004, and Mark Meily’s delightful satire La Visa Loca (Crazy Visa), 2005, where he gave one of his best and most mature performances as an actor.

With the decline in film production in the 2000s, Padilla wisely established a career in television. He signed with GMA Network and headlined some of its top television series: Asian Treasures, 2007; Joaquin Burdado (Tattooed Joaquin), 2008; and Totoy Bato (Totoy the Rock), 2009. In 2009, Padilla transferred to rival network ABS-CBN to serve as host of the network’s popular noontime variety show Wowowee after its original host, Willie Revillame, abruptly left.

Padilla went on to appear in some of ABS-CBN’s television series, including Guns and Roses, 2011; Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw, 2013; and the sitcom Toda Max (To the Max), 2011-13. In 2013, he starred in Joyce Bernal’s thriller 10,000 Hours, an entry in the Metro Manila Film Festival. In 2014, Padilla played another memorable role as Philippine hero Andres Bonifacio in Philippian Films’ Bonifacio: Ang Unang Pangulo (Bonifacio: The First President). Written by Elvin Valerio

PADILLA, ZSA ZSA (Esperanza Perez Padilla) b. Manila, Metro Manila 28 May 1964. Singer and television and movie actor. She is the daughter of actor Carlos “Sonny” Padilla Jr and Esperanza Felipa “Kating” Perez. Carlos Padilla Sr is her grandfather. She was the longtime partner of the late comedian Dolphy. She is the mother of singer and actor Karylle and singer Zia Quizon. She is a contract star of ABS-CBN.

Padilla appeared during her preteens in TV commercials and played bit parts in movies like Disco Madhouse, 1980. She became a member of the band Hotdog in the late 1970s and went solo at age 18 in 1982. One of her early albums is Am I Your Kind of Woman, 1984, which was reissued in the same year as Kahit Na (Even If). She appeared as a solo artist by doing the front act for Kuh Ledesma and the group Music and Magic. It was followed by appearances in concerts of established singers like Lea Salonga and Basil Valdez. Her first major concert was held on 29 Sep 1984 at the Araneta Coliseum.

Padilla eventually branched out to acting. Her first TV role was as a wife of a gay man in the series Lovingly Yours, Helen, 1987. In the same year, she appeared in her first movie, Mga Anak ni Facifica Falayfay (Children of Facifica Falayfay) with Dolphy. It was followed by more films like Black Magic, 1987; Hiwaga sa Balete Drive (Mystery on Balete Drive), 1988; and Magkano ang Iyong Dangal (How Much Is Your Honor Worth), 1988. She starred in Starzan I, II, and III, 1989-90; Pahiram ng Isang Umaga (Lend Me One Morning), 1989; Minsan Lang Kita Iibigin (I Will Love You Only Once), 1994; Tataynic (Father Nic), 1998; Home Alone da River, 2002; Mano Po 2, 4, and 6, 2003-5; and the musical I Do Bidoo Bidoo: Heto nAPO Sila! (I Do Bidoo Bidoo: The APO Is Here!), 2012.

In 2002-4, she hosted TV shows like Morning Girls with Kris and Korina and Star in a Million. She played notable roles in the TV series Labs Ko si Babe (I Love Babe), 2000, and Lastikman (Plastic Man), 2007. She also appeared in other series, including Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), 2005-6; Budoy, 2011-12; Juan dela Cruz, 2013; and Mars Ravelo’s Dyesebel, 2014. Padilla continues her singing career in the Sunday variety show ASAP.

Padilla was awarded Best Actress by the Gawad Urian and the Star Awards for Batang PX (Phil-American Boy), 1997, and by the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) for the same film, tied with Maricel Soriano who won for Nasaan ang Puso (Where Is the Heart). She also won Best Actress for her role in Mano Po 4: Ako Legal Wife (I Kiss Your Hand 4: I Am the Legal Wife), 2005, from the Metro Manila Film Festival and the FAP. Written by Christian Co
(See THEATER volume.)

PANGANIBAN, ANGELICA Manila 4 Nov 1986. Television and movie actor, comedian. She is the adopted daughter of Melania David Panganiban. Her biological father is Mark Charlson, a former member of the United States Navy, whom she only met in 2010, two years after her biological mother had died.

Panganiban started her career at the age of six in the youth-oriented television show Ang TV (The TV), 1992-97. She landed her first movie role in Antipolo Massacre, 1993. She was known for her roles in Separada (Separated Woman), 1994, for which she received Best Child Actress awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) and the Star Awards, and Sarah … Ang Munting Prinsesa (Sarah … The Little Princess), 1995, wherein she played the role of Becky. She also won Best Child Actress for Ama, Ina, Anak (Father, Mother, Child), 1997, in the Star Awards. She appeared with her screen partner Carlo Aquino in the television series G-Mik, 1999-2001, and Berks (Youth Gang), 2002-4, and in the film Ang Tanging Ina (The One and Only Mom), 2003.

She won Best Supporting Actress for A Love Story, 2007, in the Film Academy of the Philippines Awards; Best Performance by an Actress in a Leading Role for Here Comes the Bride, 2010, in the Golden Screen Awards; FAMAS Best Supporting Actress for Segunda Mano (Secondhand), 2011; and Best Actress awards for Alamat ni China Doll (The Legend of China Doll) and That Thing Called Tadhana (That Thing Called Fate) in the 2013 and 2014 Cinema One Originals Film Festival, respectively.

Panganiban topbilled ABS-CBN’s primetime drama television series Rubi, 2010, a remake of the Mexican telenovela, and Apoy sa Dagat (Raging Love), 2013, opposite Piolo Pascual and Diether Ocampo. She is also part of the comedy gag show Banana Split, which celebrated its fifth anniversary in 2013. Panganiban won Outstanding Performance by an Actress in the Golden Screen Awards for Television in 2011 and 2013, and Best Comedy Actress in the 24th Star Awards for Television in 2010. Written by Kathrina Alvarez

PARALUMAN (Sigrid de Torres Von Giese) b. Manila 14 Dec 1923. d. Manila 27 Apr 2009. Movie actor. Her parents are Lothar Von Giese, a German architect, and Tecla de Torres of Tayabas, Quezon. She finished grade school at Assumption Convent, Manila, but discontinued her secondary schooling in favor of the movies. Her first marriage was to Yoshifume Abe, a Japanese officer stationed in Manila in 1944. They had one child, Baby, who was adopted by Tony O’Brien, Paraluman’s second husband, after she was divorced from the Japanese. O’Brien died in Hawaii and Paraluman married Brigido Sibug in 1965. They have an adopted son, Alex Sibug. A granddaughter, Rina Reyes, Baby O’Brien’s daughter, is also a movie actor.

As a one-year contract talent under Filippine Films, she was given the screen name of Mina de Gracia in her first screen appearance as second lead in Flores de Mayo (Flowers of May), 1940. She did Huling Habilin (Last Will), 1940; Hatinggabi (Midnight), 1940; and Dalaga (Lady), 1940, with co-stars Norma Blancaflor and Ely Ramos. She was renamed Paraluman when she played lead opposite Fernando Poe Sr in Paraluman (Muse), 1941. After the war, she joined Sampaguita Pictures. Among the movies she made were Lydia, 1956; Veronica, 1957; Anino ni Bathala (Shadow of God), 1958; Baby Face, 1959; Kuwintas ng Alaala (Necklace of Memories), 1960; Limos na Dalangin (Alms Prayer), 1961; Pitong Puso (Seven Hearts) and Gerardo de Leon’s Ako ang Katarungan (I Am Justice), 1962; Nais Ko Pang Mabuhay (I Want to Live), 1966; Dahil sa Isang Bulaklak (Because of a Flower), 1967; Lilet, 1972; and Mister Mo, Lover Boy Ko (Your Husband, My Lover), 1975. After World War II, she made films with foreign producers. She appeared in Elephant Girl for the Shaw Brothers of Singapore in 1951.

Paraluman won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Actress award in 1957 for Sino ang Maysala? (Who Is Guilty?). Written by Danny Villanueva, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

PAREÑO, GINA Geraldine Ocura Acthley) aka Gerry. b. Manila 20 Oct 1949. Movie and television actor. She is the daughter of Patricia Dory Ocura and Bouffard Acthley. Pareño has two sons and one daughter, Raquel, a stage actor. Pareño started her career in show business when she won a dance contest on television called Dance-O-Rama, hosted by Boots Anson and Pete Roa, during her high school sophomore year. After seeing her in the show, Dr Jose Perez asked her to join the new batch of young stars that Sampaguita Pictures was building up. She then became one of the Stars ’66, together with Blanca Gomez, Rosemarie Sonora, Shirley Moreno, and Loretta Marquez.

Her first film roles were in Sabina, Ang Class Reunion (The Class Reunion), Umibig ay Di Biro (Loving Is No Joke), and Mga Batang Artista (Young Actors), 1963; Mga Batang Milyonaryo (Young Millionaires), Isinulat sa Dugo (Written in Blood), and Mama, 1965; Jamboree ’66, 1966, where she was featured as part of the Stars ’66; Kamatayan Ko ang Ibigin Ka (It Is My Death to Love You) and Donata, 1967. She was supposed to be launched in her first lead role in 1968 but she became pregnant. A year later, she made a comeback with Si Darna at ang Planetman (Darna and the Planetman), 1969. She lay low for a few years, then came back and did films like Krimen: Kayo ang Humatol (Crime: You Be the Judge), for which she won Best Actress in the 9th Manila Festival, and Dragon Fire, 1974; Pagsapit ng Dilim (When Darkness Comes), 1975; and Tatlong Kasalanan (Three Sins), 1976. She again disappeared from the movie scene as she struggled with personal problems, and returned after about eight years, to do films like Bukas Luluhod ang mga Tala (Tomorrow the Stars Will Kneel) and Working Girls, 1984; Like Father, Like Son and Sa Totoo Lang! (As a Matter of Fact!), 1985; Ibigay Mo sa Akin Ang Bukas (Give Me Tomorrow) and Halimaw (Monster), 1986; Natutulog Pa ang Diyos (God Is Still Asleep), 1988; and Kung Tapos Na ang Kailanman (If Forever Is Finished), 1989. After an absence of another five years, she came back and appeared in The Fatima Buen Story, 1994; Sana Maulit Muli (Second Chances), 1995; May Nagmamahal sa Iyo (Madonna and Child), 1996; Hanggang Kailan Kita Mamahalin (Until When Will I Love You), 1997; Pagdating ng Panahon (When the Time Comes) and Ikaw Pa Rin ang Iibigin (I Will Still Love You), 1998; Anak ng Dilim (Child of Darkness) and Hey, Babe, 1999; Booba, 2001; Till There Was You, 2003; Bridal Shower, 2004; Ang Lagusan (The Portal), 2005; Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo (Partner, Participant, Partaker), 2006, for which she won the Best Supporting Actress Award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences; Sakal, Sakali, Saklolo (Strangle, Perchance, Help), 2007; Ploning and Serbis (Service), 2008; Bakal Boys (Children Metal Divers), 2009; Dalaw (Visit), Working Girls, and Of All the Things, 2010; The Adventures of Pureza: Queen of the Riles (The Adventures of Pureza: Queen of the Railroad Tracks), 2011; The Reunion and One More Try, 2012; Alfredo S. Lim: The Untold Story, 2013; and Let the Love Begin, 2015.

Pareño gained international recognition for her performance in two independent films. For her portrayal of Amelita in the film Kubrador (The Bet Collector), 2006, she won Best Actress at the Osian’s Cinefan Festival of Asian and Arab Cinema in India, Amiens International Film Festival in France, and Brussels International Independent Film Festival in Belgium. Locally, she won the Best Actress trophies from the Gawad Urian and the Golden Screen Awards for the same film. For the film Serbis, Pareño was awarded for her performance in the Pacific Meridian International Film Festival of Asian-Pacific Countries in Vladivostok, Russia,and Best Supporting Actress at the Asian Film Awards. In 2011, the Manunuring Pelikulang Pilipino honored her, along with Cherry Pie Picache and Coco Martin, as one of the three Actors of the Decade 2000-2009.

Pareño appeared in several television shows, including Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009, where she bagged the Best Drama Actress trophy from the Star Awards for Television. She also appeared in Mara Clara, 2010-11; My Binondo Girl, 2011-12; Juan dela Cruz, 2013; Mars Ravelo’s Dyesebel, 2014; Let the Love Begin and FPJ’s Ang Probinsyano (FPJ’s The Country Boy), 2015.

In 2010, Pareño was given a Lifetime Achievement Award by the Star Awards for Movies. On the same year, she won an award for Global Achievement by a Filipino Artist from the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Scholarship Foundation Box-Office Entertainment Awards. Written by Kathrina Alvarez, Johann Vladimir Espiritu, and Nicanor G. Tiongson

PARLATONE HISPANO-FILIPINO Incorporated in 1935 by Jose Nepomuceno with Raymundo Navarro, Julian Salgado, Pedro Carriedo, Natalio Carriedo, Jesus Cacho, and Jesus Nepomuceno, it established its own studio on a one-hectare lot in Mandaluyong which used to house Nepomuceno’s Malayan Movies. Its first movie was Carlos Vander Tolosa’s Diwata ng Karagatan (Goddess of the Sea), 1936, which starred Rogelio de la Rosa and Adela Plunkers. Among the members of the studio staff were Luis Nolasco as publicity director and dialogue/scriptwriter; Mike Caguin in the script and production department; Enrique Jarlego in the editing and laboratory sections; and Jorge C. Santos as assistant director. Vicente Salumbides came in later as production manager, and directed the movie that introduced Gerardo de Leon as bit player, Mga Pusong Dakila (Noble Hearts), 1937.

Other directors who emerged from the studio included Mar Esmeralda who directed Awit ng mga Ulila (Song of the Orphans), 1936, and Anak Dalita (Child of Poverty), 1936, a box-office hit that starred Doris Young and Rosario Moreno. The latter was billed as the first local picture with Tagalog and English dialogue. In 1938, Parlatone president Raymundo Navarro also directed a movie about Asedillo, a folk hero in the Sierra Madre mountains, which starred Lucita Goyena and Darmo von Fraser Acosta and was filmed in two versions: Eagle’s Nest in English and Pugad ng Agila in Tagalog. In 1938, the studio became the country’s most successful production company. Its biggest hit for the year was Gerardo de Leon’s Bahay Kubo (Nipa Hut), which starred Ernesto Vallejo, Fely Vallejo, Rogelio de la Rosa, Fleur de Lis (later Mona Lisa), and Gregorio Ticman.

In 1939, a big fire destroyed a portion of the studio; and later, the war completely destroyed what was left of it. Written by Mauro Tumbocon Jr

PASCUAL, PIOLO (Piolo Jose Nonato Pascual) aka PJ. b. Manila 12 Jan 1977. Movie and television actor, singer, model. Pascual is the youngest of the six children of Amelia Nonatoand Philip Herzig Pascual. He started his early education at San Miguel Catholic School and St. Francis School where he was introduced to acting through Teatro ni Kiko (Kiko’s Theater). He took up physical therapy at the University of Santo Tomas where he became a member of Teatro Tomasino.

Pascual was introduced in the film Vizconde Massacre: God Help Us!, 1993. Later, he did supporting roles in films like Batang PX (Phil-American Boy), 1997, and Esperanza: The Movie, 1999. His role in Lagarista (Film Biker), 2000, was a breakthrough for him. This was followed by Kahit Isang Saglit (Even for a Moment), 2000; Mila, 2001; I Think I’m in Love and 9 Mornings, 2002; and Till There Was You, 2003. His notable films include Dekada ’70 (The 1970s), 2002; Milan, 2004; Dreamboy, 2005; Don’t Give Up on Us, 2006; and Paano Kita Iibigin (How Will I Love You), 2007. His other notable films are Love Me Again and Manila, 2009, which he himself produced. This was followed by Every Breath U Take and 24/7 in Love, 2012; On the Job, 2013; and Starting Over Again, 2014. Pascual was also the executive producer of the comedies starring Eugene Domingo: Kimmy Dora: Kambal sa Kiyeme (Kimmy Dora: Twins of Nonsense), 2009; Kimmy Dora and the Temple of Kiyeme (Kimmy Dora and the Temple of Nonsense), 2012; and Kimmy Dora: Ang Kiyemeng Prequel (Kimmy Dora: The Nonsense Prequel), 2013.

On television, Pascual started in That’s Entertainment and ATBP (Etc.), 1994, Mara Clara, 1995, and Gimik (Hang Out), 1996. After a brief stay in the USA, he came back and became part of the Star Magic Circle, the young actors of ABS-CBN. He appeared in TV drama series like Sa Sandaling Kailangan Mo Ako (The Moment You Need Me) and Esperanza, 1998, where he was first teamed up with Judy Ann Santos. This was followed by major roles in shows like Sa Puso Ko Iingatan Ka (I Will Cherish You in My Heart), 2001; Buttercup, 2003; and Mangarap Ka (Dream On), 2004. He started performing and hosting in A.S.A.P. in 2005 and hosted other shows like Be Bench: The Model Search, 2007. He also appeared in Sa Piling Mo (With You), 2006; Walang Kapalit (Nobody Else), 2007; and Lobo (Wolf), 2008. He played lead roles in Lovers in Paris, 2009; May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow) and Noah, 2010; Dahil sa Pag-ibig (Because of Love), 2012; Apoy sa Dagat (Raging Love), 2013; and Hawak-Kamay (Holding Hands), 2014.

Pascual also pursued quite successfully a singing career. Through Star Records, he was able to release albums like Piolo, 2003; My Gift, 2004; Rendition and Platinum Hits, 2005; Paano Kita Iibigin and Timeless, 2007; and Decades, 2009.

Pascual won a number of awards. For his performance in Dekada ’70, he received Best Supporting Actor awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), the Film Academy of the Philippines, the Gawad Urian, and the Young Critics Circle in 2003. In 2005, he won FAMAS Best Actor for his performance in Milan. He received Best Actor awards from the Star Awards for Movies for Don’t Give Up on Us in 2007 and for Starting Over Again in 2015.Written by Christian Co

PASION, FRANCIS(Francis Xavier E. Pasion) b. Manila 8 Feb 1978. d. Quezon City 6 Mar 2016. Director, writer, producer, and editor. He graduated with a bachelor’s degree in mass communication and media studies from Ateneo de Manila University. He founded the Loyola Film Circle at Ateneo.

In Philippine independent filmmaking, Pasion is most known for writing, producing, and directing Jay, 2008, a film about how TV segment producers falsify or suppress the truth to get better ratings, and Bwaya (Crocodile), 2014, about a family that is victimized by crocodiles, animal and human. He also directed and produced Sampaguita: National Flower, 2010, about street children who eke out a living by hawking sampaguita garlands on the streets of Manila.

He had a more prolific career as a TV director. The most popular of his works include Project Runway Philippines, 2009; Gimik (Hang Out), Beautiful Girl, and Andi, 2010; Sabel, 2010-11; My Binondo Girl, 2011-12; Princess and I, 2012-13; Kahit Konting Pagtingin (Just One Glance) and My Little Juan, 2013; Dyesebel, 2014; Nathaniel and On the Wings of Love, 2015. He also directed several episodes of Wansapanataym (Once upon a Time) from 2011 to 2015. All of Pasion’s TV works were aired on ABS-CBN.

In 2008, Pasion won a Balanghai trophy for Best Editing from the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival for the film Jay, which he shared with co-editors Kats Serraon and Chuck Gutierrez. On the same year, he won a Special Mention from Bangkok International Film Festival for the same film. In 2009, Jay won the Audience Award from Black Movie Film Festival; the Special Mention and Special Distinction Awards from Jogja-NETPAC Asian Film Festival; a Star Award for Movies for Digital Movie Editor of the Year, which he shared with his co-editors; and a Gawad Urian for Best Editing. In 2010, Pasion won a Special Jury Prize and a Balanghai trophy for Best Film (New Breed) from Cinemalaya for Sampaguita: National Flower. In 2014, he won the Balanghai trophy for Best Film (New Breed) for Bwaya. On the same year, Pasion won the Grand Prize at the Tokyo FILMeX for the same film.Written by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu, with notes from Nicanor G. Tiongson

PERALTA, CHARLIE (Carlos Sanchez Peralta) b. Manila 11 Mar 1956. d. Manila 23 May 2015. Movie cinematographer. He is the son of Romeo Peralta and Conchita Sanchez. He took up premed at the University of the East-Manila but did not finish it, as he was soon introduced to photography under the mentorship of his father, Romeo. With no formal education in filmmaking, Peralta subscribed to the American Society of Cinematography magazines, hoping to pick up techniques and ideas that he could use in his films.

In 1987, Peralta had his first break as cinematographer for the film Hubad na Pangarap (Naked Dreams), 1987. He is credited as cinematographer for the following films, among others: Itanong Mo sa Buwan (Ask the Moon), 1988; Valentina, Jessa: Blusang Itim 2 (Jessa: Black Blouse 2), and Oras-Oras, Araw-Araw (Every Hour, Every Day), 1989; My Other Woman, 1990; Dinampot Ka Lang sa Putik (You’re Just Picked Up from the Mud) and Secrets of Pura, 1991; Sinungaling Mong Puso (Your Lying Heart), Ngayon at Kailanman (Now and Forever), and Narito ang Puso Ko (Here Is My Heart), 1992; Abel Morado: Ikaw ang May Sala (Abel Morado: You Are the Culprit), 1993; Ang Ikalabing Isang Utos: Mahalin Mo Asawa Mo (The Eleventh Commandment: Love Your Spouse), 1994; Sa ’Yo Lamang (Only Yours) and Sa Ngalan ng Pag-ibig (In the Name of Love), 1995; Abot-Kamay ang Pangarap (Elena’s Redemption), 1996; Curacha: Ang Babaeng Walang Pahinga (Curacha: The Woman without Rest), Bata, Bata … Paano Ka Ginawa? (Lea’s Story), Pahiram Kahit Sandali (Spare Me a Moment), and Babae sa Bintana (Woman by the Window), 1998; Katawan (Body) and Dahil May Isang Ikaw (Because There Is You), 1999; Tunay na Tunay: Gets Mo? Gets Ko! (It’s True: Do You Get It? I Do!) and Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw (You’re the One I Need), 2000; Pagdating ng Panahon (When the Time Comes), 2001; Singsing ni Lola (Grandma’s Ring) and Till There Was You, 2003; Dubai, 2005; Pisay (Philippine Science High School), 2007; Ploning, 2008; No Other Woman, 2011; Of All the Things, The Healing, and One More Try, 2012; and Maria Leonora Teresa, 2014.

In 1996, he received the Gawad Urian for Best Cinematography for the movie Dahas (Rage). His work in Nasaan Ka Man (Wherever You Are) won Best Cinematography both from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences and the Film Academy of the Philippines in 2006. He also won Best Cinematography in the 2006 Metro Manila Film Festival for the film Mano Po 5: Gua Ai Di (I Love You). He also bagged Movie Cinematographer of the Year trophies from the Star Awards for Don’t Give Up on Us, 2007, and In My Life, 2009.Written by Gregory del Carmen

PEREZ, BARBARA (Barbara Muñoz Perez-Ylagan) b. Urdaneta, Pangasinan 4 Jan 1937. Movie, stage, and television actor. Her parents are Dr Benito Perez and Barbara Muñoz. She is married to actor RobertArevalo (Robert Ylagan). They have two daughters, Anna and Georgina.

Perez was a journalism student at the University of Santo Tomas when she entered show business. Dr Jose R. Perez of SampaguitaPictures was so struck by her resemblance to Hollywood actor Audrey Hepburn that he signed her up for a four-year buildup contract. In 1956, she appeared in her first movie Chabacano and in Señorita de Campanilla (Lady of the Manor). The following year, she played the title role in Ate Barbara (Elder Sister Barbara), 1957. Her other films include Dewey Boulevard, 1958; Pitong Pagsisisi (Seven Atonements), 1959; Gumuhong Bantayog (Fallen Monument), 1960; Liko-likong Landas (Crooked Path), 5 Yugto ng Buhay (5 Life Episodes), and Harangan Man ng Sibat (Even If Blocked with a Spear), 1961; and Haliging Bato (Pillar of Stone), 1963. After her contract with Sampaguita expired, she freelanced. She also appeared in the Hollywood film No Man Is an Island, 1961, with Jeffrey Hunter. Teaming up with husband Robert, she appeared in GerardodeLeon’s Ang DaigdigngmgaApi (The World of the Oppressed), 1965.

Her other films are Dear Kuya Cesar (Dear Brother Cesar), 1968; Asedillo, 1971; Supergirl, 1973; Ang Boyfriend Kong Baduy (My Out-of-Style Boyfriend), 1976; P.S. I Love You, 1981; Exploitation, 1983; The Sisters, 1987; Ibulong Mo sa Diyos (Whisper to God), 1988; Bihagin ang Dalagang Ito (Enslave This Lady), 1989; Bakit Labis Kitang Mahal (Why Do I Love You So Much), 1992; Ang Boyfriend Kong Gamol (My Crazy Boyfriend), 1993; Ang Ika-Labing Isang Utos: Mahalin Mo Asawa Mo (The Eleventh Commandment: Love Your Spouse), 1994; Malikmata (Illusion), 2003; and The Bicycle, 2007.

In the 1950s and early 1960s, Perez modeled for famous couturiers. She also appeared on stage. She was in Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s Pagbibinyag sa Apoy at Dugo (Baptism of Fire and Blood). She and Susan Valdez played the Marasigan sisters Candida and Paula, respectively, in Behn Cervantes’s staging of Larawan (Filipino version of Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino). She also appeared in television drama anthologies.

In 1966, Perez and Arevalo won the FilipinoAcademyofMovieArtsandSciences Best Actress and Best Actor awards for Ang Daigdig ng mga Api.Written by Galileo Zafra, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

PEREZ, BEN (Benito Acuña Perez) b. Quiapo, Manila 12 Jan 1920. d. 6 Jul 1986. He attended grade school at Jefferson Elementary School and finished high school at Mapa High School. He was in his third year of law studies at the University of the Philippines when World War II broke out. He enlisted as a lieutenant in the United States Army Forces in the Far East. He married Pacita Medrana, with whom he had two children.

Perez made about 80 movies. He first appeared in Liwayway sa Kalayaan (The Dawning of Freedom), 1946. Under the screen name Arturo del Mar, he played the title role in Anak ni Kulafu (Son of Kulafu), 1947. As BenPerez, he became a star in Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), 1948, produced by NolascoBros. Pictures. Several of his films were made by director GerardodeLeon, among which are Ang Bagong Maestra (The New Teacher), 1953; Saigon, 1956, with LeopoldoSalcedo and Cristina Pacheco; HanggangsaDulongDaigdig (To the Ends of the Earth), 1958, with PanchoMagalona; The Moises Padilla Story, 1961, with Leopoldo Salcedo, JosephEstrada, and LiliaDizon; El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1962, with Pancho Magalona; AngDaigdigngmgaApi (The World of the Oppressed), 1965, with RobertArevalo and BarbaraPerez; Banaue, 1975, where he played the role of the tribal father to NoraAunor. He also appeared in a foreign production titled Tiger Man, 1983.

Perez was the first recipient of the FilipinoAcademyofMovieArtsandSciences Best Actor award for Bagong Umaga (New Morning), 1952.Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

PEREZ, BUTCH(Antonio Jose Domingo Perez) b. 25 Oct 1993. Film director and writer. His parents are Antonio Paz Perez and Virginia Domingo. He is married to Adelaida Lim. Perez graduated from the Ecole Supérieure des Etudes in France with a degree in cinema studies in 1979.

Perez’s first film is Binhi (Seedling), 1973, co-directed with Peque Gallaga, which also happened to be the latter’s debut movie. It stars Rosemarie Sonora, Dindo Fernando, Ronaldo Valdez, and Divina Valencia. In 1982, he directed Haplos (Caress), a gothic horror and love story starring Rio Locsin, Christopher de Leon, and Vilma Santos. In Balweg: The Rebel Priest, 1986, Perez turns his attention to Conrado Balweg, a Catholic priest who defended the ancestral land rights of the Tingguians, a tribal minority in the Cordillera, and went on to join the New People’s Army. Balweg was played by Phillip Salvador, and the film was written by Amado Lacuesta. Teaming up with Emmanuel Borlaza and Uro de la Cruz as writers, he made Gaano Kita Kamahal (How Much Do I Love You), 1993, which tests the boundaries of love, with Christopher de Leon and Lorna Tolentino in the lead roles. Perez’s last film to date is Mumbaki (Shaman), 1996, about the son of an Ifugao chieftain, now a doctor, who returns to his tribe after the death of his father. Co-written with Amado Lacuesta, it stars Raymart Santiago, Albert Martinez, and Joel Torre.

In 1997, Perez received the Best Film and Best Screenplay awards from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk for Mumbaki. Written by Richard Bolisay, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

PEREZ, ELWOOD (Elwood Mendoza Perez) b. Mabalacat, Pampanga 4 Feb 1945. Movie director, scriptwriter. His parents are Pedro Esguerra Perez and Edna Cunanan Mendoza. His father’s sister, Teresita, is the wife of director Artemio Marquez. He is the brother of actor Chuck Perez.

Perez started his movie career with Blue Boy, 1970, a movie based on Bert Bornay’s komiks serial. After his first movie, he stopped making films for a while, until his friends at Sine Pilipino convinced him to direct Si Popeye Atbp. (Popeye and Others), 1973, from his own story and screenplay. Later, he did Divorce, Pilipino Style, and Inday Garutay, 1976; Beerhouse, Masarap, Masakit ang Umibig (Joy and Pain of Loving), and Masikip Maluwang: Paraisong Parisukat (Narrow and Wide: Square Eden), 1977; Sari-saring Ibong Kulasisi (Different Lovebirds), 1978; and Stepsisters and Magkaribal (Rivals), 1979. With Regal Films’ Disgrasyada (Fallen Woman), 1979, he established himself as a box-office director. His other films include Waikiki: Sa Lupa ng Ating mga Pangarap (Waikiki: In the Land of Our Dreams), 1980; Santa Claus Is Coming to Town!, 1982; Shame, 1983; Till We Meet Again and I Can’t Stop Loving You, 1985; Bilangin ang Bituin sa Langit (Count the Stars in the Sky), 1989; Island of Desire, 1990; Ang Totoong Buhay ni Pacita M. (The Real Life of Pacita M.), 1991; Yakapin Mo Akong Muli (Embrace Me Once More), 1992; and Tatlong Kasalanan (Three Sins), 1998. Perez went through another dry spell after his film Ssshhh … She Walks by Night, 2003, this time for 10 years, focusing on his family life during his hiatus. Afterward, he returned with the meta-film Otso (Eight), 2013. The film was among the roster of movies showcased during the 2013 Sineng Pambansa (National Film) Festival: All-Masters Edition. His film Esoterika: Maynila (Esoterica: Manila), 2014, was the opening feature for the 10th Cinema One Originals Film Festival.

Perez received the Best Director award from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) for Bilangin ang Bituin sa Langit, for which he was nominated in the same category by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) and the Gawad Urian. He won Best Director in the FAMAS for Ang Totoong Buhay ni Pacita M., for which he was nominated by FAP in the same category. Earlier, the FAMAS honored him with the Best Director award for Ibulong Mo sa Diyos (Whisper to God), 1988. In acknowledgement of his impact on the local film industry, Cinema One honored Perez, together with producer “Mother Lily” Monteverde, with a tribute and the Philippine Cinema Originals Award in 2013.Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Erika Carreon

PHILIPPINE MOTION PICTURE PRODUCERS ASSOCIATION (PMPPA) The Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association was established in 1963 by a group of 16 Filipino movie producers, which included the Big Four studios of Sampaguita Pictures, LVN Pictures, Premiere Productions, and Lebran International. The Big Four had earlier combined to form the Philippine Movie Producers Association (PMPA), which became the nucleus of the new organization. Their first move was to pen a petition for the government to suspend a tariff directive imposing import quotas on raw film stock.

At that time, first-run theaters in Manila were dominated by American movies except for two that showed exclusively Filipino films: Life Theater in Quiapo and Dalisay Theater on Rizal Avenue. Two other cinema houses along Quezon Boulevard that sometimes showed Filipino films, Center Theater and Globe Theater, also exhibited American movies. All the rest showed only foreign films.

To alleviate the situation, the PMPPA forged an alliance with Manila Mayor Antonio Villegas to hold the first Manila Film Festival for a period of 10 days beginning 24 Jun 1966 with the celebration of “Araw ng Maynila” (Manila Day). The city’s major thoroughfares and street corners were emblazoned with movie posters announcing a “Parade of Stars” and the titles of Filipino movies to be shown in the different theaters, which formerly showed only American films. To complete the Filipinization of the event, radio and television stations, jukeboxes, and the “sound row” on Raon street in downtown Santa Cruz, Manila, played only Filipino music for 10 days.

Three years later, the PMPPA found a champion in Sen Jose Diokno who filed Senate Bill 205 imposing graduated import quotas on foreign movies and allotting 30 percent annual playing time for Filipino films. However, a strong pro-American lobby in Congress defeated the bill. Nevertheless, a 49-day annual quota for local films was won over by PMPPA producers from the local theater distributors who conceded, following the results of the festival, that there was indeed a market for Filipino films. Meanwhile, PMPPA producers set the trend for full-color production so that by 1975, all films were color, and black-and-white movies were a thing of the past.

In the early 1970s, PMPPA producers of big-budgeted films lost heavily in the face of keen competition from non-PMPPA producers whose bomba and X-rated films dominated the theater circuits together with cheap karate imports. Some of the legitimate producers closed shop and/or joined the bandwagon using other trade names. Proclamation 1081 in 1972 discouraged the production of bomba films.

In 1974, the PMPPA leadership under then San Juan mayor Joseph Estrada created the Movie Workers Welfare Foundation Inc (Mowelfund) as a private entity to help the workers of the industry. Later, during the term of Marichu Perez Maceda in 1981, the PMPPA instituted the formation of the Film Academy of the Philippines while pursuing at the same time an aggressive program for government to grant subsidies and aid to producers through the Film Fund and the Film Ratings Board.

Past presidents of the PMPA and PMPPA include Judge Jose O. Vera of Sampaguita Pictures, Atty Manuel de Leon of LVN Pictures, Albert Joseph of Tamaraw Productions, Liza Moreno of Virgo Films, Atty Espiridion Laxa of Tagalog Ilang-Ilang Productions, Fernando Poe Jr of FPJ Productions, Joseph Estrada of JE/Emar Pictures, Marichu Maceda of Sampaguita/MVP Pictures, and Ramon Revilla of Imus Productions. The organization is presently headed by Manuel Nuqui of Four-N Films. Written by Mauro Tumbocon Jr and Lena S. Pareja

PHILIPPINE MOVIE PRESS CLUB(PMPC) Established in 1966 by a group of movie journalists, the PMPC aimed to promote professionalism and better understanding among the movie press and the motion picture industry and to participate in nonprofit civic, religious, social, cultural, educational, and other worthy projects. Its original incorporators include Virtudes Guinto, Romeo Galang, Francisco Ortega Jr, Gemiliano Pineda, Cora Mendoza, Cipriano Roxas, Ethelwolda Ramos, Jose Mari Cavanna, and Daniel Villanueva, who was elected as its first president. The PMPC was preceded by the Movie Press Club of the Philippines, which was established in 1949. Other PMPC presidents after Villanueva were Andy Salao, Franklin Cabaluna, Ethel Ramos, Tony Mortel, Ronald Constantino, Boy de Guia, Billy Balbastro, Hermie Francisco, Ernie Pecho, Ricky Calderon, Letty Celi, and Veronica Samio.

PMPC holds fund-raising activities, like movie premieres, for the benefit of charitable institutions, as well as annual summer outings, Christmas caroling, and movie writing and photography contests for its members. It became popular for its annual “Paistaran” organized in 1979 under de Guia’s term, which sought to bring the movie press and celebrities together in an atmosphere of fun and camaraderie. Esoteric awards like the “Darling of the Press” and the “Kalabasa awards” were given out. This would act as the springboard for the institution of the annual Star Awards for Movies in 1985 under the administration of Hermie Francisco.

In 1987, the Star Awards for Television was started in order to give recognition to the efforts and aesthetic excellence of TV filmmakers, hosts, and actors. Before several awards were merged and revised, the Star Awards for TV gave out trophies for the following: Best Drama Special, Best Cooking Show and Host, Best Cultural Magazine Show and Host, Best Movie Talk Show and Host, Best Woman-Oriented Show and Host, and others. Throughout the years, the PMPC Star Awards for TV has succeeded in becoming one of the most credible award-giving bodies for television in the country.

In 2003, several PMPC members, mostly newspaper writers and journalists, broke away from the group and formed the Entertainment Press Society (ENPRESS). The following year, this group established its own awards, the Golden Screen Awards for Television. Their awarding ceremonies are held annually and give recognition to the following:

Outstanding Performance by an Actor/Actress in a Drama Series, Outstanding Single Drama Program, Outstanding Variety Program, Outstanding Comedy Program, Outstanding News Program, Outstanding Documentary Program and Host, Outstanding Celebrity Talk Program and Host, Outstanding Public Service Program and Host, Outstanding

Educational Program and Host, and many more. Running side by side with their TV awards, ENPRESS also holds the Golden Screen Awards for Movies annually. Among their first winners in 2004 were Magnifico, Best Motion Picture (Drama), Best Director (Maryo J. de los Reyes), Best Performance by an Actor in a Lead Role (Albert Martinez), Best

Screenplay (Michiko Yamamoto), Best Cinematography (Odyssey Flores), Best Production Design (Gerry Santos), Best Editing (Manet Dayrit), and Best Musical Score (Lutgardo Labad); Bridal Shower, Best Motion Picture (Musical or Comedy), Best Performance by an Actress in a Lead Role (Cherry Pie Picache), and Breakthrough Performance by an Actor (Alfred Vargas); Kung Ako Na Lang Sana (Wish It Were Me), Best Performance by an Actor in a Lead Role in Musical or Comedy (Aga Muhlach); The Debut, Best Supporting Actor (Tirso Cruz III) and Best Sound (John Davis); Pangarap Ko ang Ibigin Ka (It Is My Dream to Love You), Best Original Song (Ogie Alcasid and Regine Velasquez); Malikmata (Illusion), Best Visual Effects (Dodge Ledesma); Mano Po 2: My Home (I Kiss Your Hand 2: My Home), Best Supporting Actress (Judy Ann Santos); Ang Huling Birhen sa Lupa (The Last Virgin), Breakthrough Performance by an Actress in a Lead Role (Ara Mina); and Lifetime Achievement Award (Dolphy). Written by Mauro Tumbocon Jr, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

(Cherry Pie Sison Picache) b. Metro Manila 27 May 1970. Movie and television actor. Her parents are Ceferino M. Picache and Zenaida Vidor Sison Picache. Picache attended St. Mary’s College in Quezon City and De La Salle University. She also took a predentistry course at Centro Escolar University–Manila.

Picache first appeared in Kahit Ako’y Tupang Itim, May Langit Din (Though I’m a Black Sheep, There’s Still Heaven), 1988, and continued to star in movies like Makati Ave. (Office Girls), 1993; Buhay ng Buhay Ko (Life of My Life) and Hataw Na (Groove), 1995; Baby Love, 1996; Ama, Ina, Anak (Father, Mother, Child) and Batang PX (Phil-American Boy), 1997; Hiling (Wish), 1998; Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000; American Adobo, 2002; Mano Po: Ako Legal Wife (I Kiss Your Hand: I’m the Legal Wife), 2005; Kaleldo (Summer Heat), Manay Po! (I Am Gay!), Twilight Dancers, and Wag Kang Lilingon (Don’t Look Back), 2006; Pitong Tagpo (Seven Events) and Foster Child, 2007; Boses (Voice), 2008; When I Met You, 2009; Here Comes the Bride, Noy, and Hating Kapatid (Fair Share), 2010; Just One Summer and The Strangers, 2012; and Feng Shui 2, 2014.

Aside from a very successful film career, Picache is also a familiar face on television, appearing in GMA Network’s Ikaw Na Sana (I Hope It’s You), 1997, and Atlantika (Atlantic), 2006; and in ABS-CBN’s Oka Tokat! (I Am Afraid), 1997; Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1998-2001; Bituin (Star), 2002; Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (I Wish This Were Forever), 2003; Maid in Heaven, 2004; Kampanerang Kuba (Hunchbacked Lady Bell Ringer), 2005; Hiram na Mukha (Borrowed Face) and Pangarap na Bituin (Dream Star), 2007; Iisa Pa Lamang (Just One), 2008; Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009; Rubi and Noah, 2010; 100 Days to Heaven and My Binondo Girl, 2011; Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Her Mother’s Daughter), 2012; and Ikaw Lamang (No Greater Love), 2014.

Picache received Best Supporting Actress awards from the Film Academy of the Philippines for American Adobo in 2003 and from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Mano Po: Ako Legal Wife in 2005. In the Golden Screen Awards, she won Best Performance by an Actress in a Lead Role for Bridal Shower in 2004; Best Performance by an Actress in a Supporting Role for Twilight Dancers in 2007; and Best Performance by an Actress in a Lead Role for Foster Child in 2008. The Gawad Urian gave her the Best Acress awards for Bridal Shower and Foster Child in 2004 and 2008, respectively. In 2011, she received the Gawad Urian for Best Actress of the Decade 2000-2009. Picache won Best Actress for Kaleldo in the 27th Durban International Film Festival and for Foster Child in the 9th Osian’s Cinefan International Festival.Written by Christian Co, with notes from Mario Mendez Jr and Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

PILAPIL, PILAR (Pilar Veloso Pilapil) b. Liloan, Cebu 12 Oct 1950. Movie and television actor. Born to Carlos Pilapil, an agriculturist, and Elena Veloso, she had her early schooling at Liloan Elementary School and Colegio de la Inmaculada Concepcion, Cebu City, where she acted and danced in school productions. In Manila, she took drama courses at St. Joseph’s College but her studies were interrupted when she won in the Miss Philippines beauty pageant in 1967. This crown led to a show business career. Actor Pia Pilapil is her daughter.

In 1968, she got her first movie role in El Niño (The Boy), which Fernando Poe Jr starred in and directed. She made more than 100 movies since then, among them: El Pinoy Matador (Filipino Bullfighter), 1970; Cherry Blossoms and Ang Alamat (The Legend), 1972; Inday ng Buhay Ko (Inday of My Life), 1973; Isang Gabi, Tatlong Babae (One Night, Three Women), 1974; Postcards from China, 1975; Buhay Mo, Buhay Ko (Your Life, My Life), 1976; Pag-ibig, Magkano Ka? (Love, How Much Are You Worth?), 1979; Tinik sa Dibdib (Thorn in the Chest), 1985; Bakit Ako Mahihiya? (Why Must I Be Ashamed?), 1992; Mula Noon Hanggang Ngayon (From Then Until Now), 1996; Leona Calderon, 2013; and Etiquette for Mistresses, 2015.

She also starred in TV drama anthologies and guested in various TV programs. At 17, she appeared in Tisoy (Mestizo), a sitcom on Channel 5, followed by Maribotbot. To date, she remains active on television, appearing in various series mostly by ABS-CBN, such as Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001; Kahit Isang Saglit (Even for a Moment), 2008; and Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2015.

Pilapil was nominated as Best Actress several times: by the Manila Film Festival for Ang Uliran (The Model), 1971, and by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Isinilang Ko ang Anak ng Ibang Babae (I Gave Birth to the Child of Another Woman), 1972; Lalaki, Kasalanan Mo (Man, This Is Your Fault), 1973; Isang Gabi, Tatlong Babae (One Night, Three Women), 1974; and May Langit ang Bawat Nilikha (A Heaven for Every Creature), 1976. She won Best Actress in the Gawad Urian for Napakasakit, Kuya Eddie (It Hurts, Brother Eddie), 1986.Written by Raquel Hernandez, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

PINGA, BEN(Benedicto Guevara Pinga) b. Tondo, Manila 1 Mar 1920. d. Montalban, Rizal 20 Aug 2010. Filmmaker. His parents are Andrea Guevara and Claro R. Pinga. He is married to Dolores Concepcion with whom he has eight children. Movie actor Sandy Andolong is his niece. He studied at Washington Elementary School and finished high school at Far Eastern University (FEU). He was in his third year of commerce at FEU when World War II broke out in 1941. After the war, he went to New York and took up courses in documentary film production at the City College of New York, 1952-55; television production at the School of Radio-TV, 1953; TV scriptwriting, TV production, and motion picture for TV at the University of New York, 1954-55; and Screen Education Workshop at Fordham University, 1965. He taught at the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila and served as director of its Film and TV Center. He also became a commissioner for the Manila Arts and Culture Commission and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, as well as an honorary member of the Screenwriters Guild and the Pilipino Film Directors Association.

Pinga was responsible for the establishment of the Film Institute of the Philippines (FIP), forerunner of the Organization of Specialized Filipino Filmmakers, an affiliate of the Film AcademyofthePhilippines. FIP initiated the First National Film Festival of Short Films in the country in 1962. Pinga was also one of the founders of the FilipinoAcademyofMovie Arts and Sciences, the oldest award-giving institution in the Philippines. In 1970, with the support of Manila Mayor Antonio J. Villegas, Pinga initiated the establishment of the Department of Cinema and Television at the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila. It was among the first educational institutions in the country to offer courses in film.

In 1964, Pinga produced the antiwar documentary Soul of a Fortress, which won the second prize, Miguel de Plata Award, in the International Section of the 1964 Bilbao Film Festival in Spain. The film also won Best Documentary at Frankfurt Film Festival, and Award of Merit from the International Federation of Film Societies at Vancouver and San Francisco Film Festivals, all in 1964. It also garnered awards from film festivals in Berlin, Milano, and Melbourne, all in 1965.

Pinga is acknowledged as the “Father of the Documentary Film” in the Philippines. Written by Rene de Guzman, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

POE, FERNANDO(Fernando Reyes Poe) b. San Carlos, Pangasinan, 27 Nov 1916. d. Manila 23 Oct 1951. Movie actor, director, producer. His parents are Marta Reyes and Lorenzo Poe. He married an American, Elizabeth Kelley, with whom he had six children, two of them actors Fernando Poe Jr (Ronald Allan Poe) and Andy Poe (Fernando Poe Jr). He has another actor-son, Conrad Poe, by actor Patricia Mijares. He attended elementary grades at Meisic Primary School and Sampaloc Intermediate School. He graduated from Arellano High School and earned a bachelor of science degree in chemistry at the University of the Philippines in 1935. He was a chemist for Blue Star Products Company from 1937 to 1938. He received the degree of doctor of dental medicine from the Philippine Dental College but failed to take the board because World War II broke out. On 20 Dec 1941 he was called to active duty as 2nd lieutenant. He served in the United States Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE) during World War II and received the gold cross for outstanding valor in Bataan.

While working as a chemist, Poe appeared in Filippine Films’ Ang Birheng Walang Dambana (The Virgin without a Shrine), 1937, opposite Rosa del Rosario. He became a big star in Zamboanga (Fury in Paradise), 1937. His other prewar films include Punit na Bandila (Torn Flag), 1939, with Lucita Goyena; Leron-Leron Sinta (Leron-Leron Beloved), 1939, with child star Angelito Nepomuceno; Hanggang Langit (Until Heaven), 1939, with Maria Miranda; Giliw Ko (My Beloved), 1939; Mabangong Bulaklak (Fragrant Flower), 1939, with Elsa Oria; Biak na Bato, 1939, with Luningning; Alaalang Banal (Sacred Memory), 1940; Datu Talim, 1940, with Sonia Reyes; Paraluman (Muse), 1940, with Paraluman and Tessie Quintana; Bayaning Buhay (Living Hero), 1941, and its sequel, Puting Dambana (White Shrine), 1941; and Palaris, 1941, a film about the folk hero of Pangasinan.

During the Japanese Occupation of the Philippines, Poe was involved in setting up stage shows and theater productions in Manila. He was an undercover USAFFE soldier whose appearance in the anti-American propaganda war movie Dawn of Freedom, 1944, directed by Abe Yutaka and Gerardo de Leon, aroused some controversy. After the war he formed his own company, Palaris Films, which later became Fernando Poe Productions Inc, of which Royal Productions was a subsidiary. He produced films that dispelled any doubts about his patriotism, such as Dugo ng Bayan (I Remember Bataan), 1946, and Intramuros: The Rape of a City, 1946. He wrote, directed, and starred in most of his films, including Limbas, 1948, where he portrayed the Filipino Tarzan, with Erlinda Cortes as his leading lady. His company also produced the first Darna movies, with Rosa del Rosario as the wonder woman in Darna, 1951, and Darna at ang Babaing Lawin (Darna and the Hawkwoman), 1952, with Cristina Aragon as her nemesis.

Poe died at the age of 35, from rabies inflicted by a dog bite in his home.Written by Galileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja

POE, FERNANDO JR(Ronald Allan Kelley Poe) aka Ronwaldo Reyes, FPJ, Da King. b. Manila 20 Aug 1939. d. Quezon City 14 Dec 2004. National Artist for film. Movie actor, producer, director. His parents are Elizabeth Kelley and actor-producer Fernando Poe Sr. His brother Andy is also an actor. He is married to actor Susan Roces (Jesusa Sonora). They have a daughter, Mary Grace Poe, a politician. Actor Lovi Poe is also Poe’s daughter. He quit high school to work as a messenger in a film exchange office.

Poe was initiated into the movies as a stuntman for Everlasting Pictures. He was actor Lilia Dizon’s double in Simaron (Untamed), 1955. In his first acting role in Anak ni Palaris (Son of Palaris), 1950, Poe shared top billing with Rosita Noble and Mario Escudero. Director Mario Barri gave him his screen name, taken from his father who had earlier played the title role in Palaris, 1946. But Poe’s biggest break was Lo’ Waist Gang, 1956, which marked the local cinema’s shift from the fantasy world of costume productions to the trendy realism of action movies. His first solo movie was Tough Guy, 1957. He was then signed up by Premiere Productions as a contract actor. Poe proved his box-office appeal in Kamay ni Cain (Hand of Cain), 1957, for his performance in which he earned a nomination from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS). When Hollywood Far East Productions opened, Poe was offered to do Markado (Branded), 1959, and upon his demand, was paid a much higher talent fee than what he used to get. He invested his savings in his own company, the FPJ Productions and D’Lanor Productions.

Other movies where Poe played lead roles are Apollo Robles and Sandata at Pangako (Weapons and Promises), 1961; Ako ang Katarungan (I Am Justice), 1962; Santo Domingo (Saint Domingo) and Ang Alamat (The Legend), 1972; Perlas ng Silangan (Pearl of the Orient), 1973; Sanctuario (Sanctuary), 1974; Patayin si Mediavillo (Kill Mediavillo), 1978; and Lihim ng Guadalupe (Secret of Guadalupe), 1979.

Under the name Ronwaldo Reyes, Poe directed many of the FPJ films that he himself acted in, like Alupihang Dagat (Sea Centipede), 1975; King, 1978; Tatak ng Tundo (Mark of Tondo), 1978; Ang Padrino (The Godfather), 1984; and Panday (Blacksmith) 1, 2, 3, and 4. Awarded by the FAMAS were Panday II, 1981, for Best Cinematography; Panday III, 1982, for Best Cinematography and Best Production Design; and Panday IV, 1984, for Best Special Visual Effects. Poe received nominations for Best Director from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) for Panday III and Ang Padrino. In most of these movies, he plays a hero who is peace loving, until he is pushed against the wall by all sorts of kontrabida (villains), and magnificently rises in defense of the poor and the oppressed.

He won FAMAS Best Actor awards for Mga Alabok sa Lupa (Dust of the Earth), 1967; Asedillo, 1971; Durugin si Totoy Bato (Crush Totoy the Rock), 1979; Umpisahan Mo, Tatapusin Ko (What You Start, I Will Finish), 1983; and Muslim Magnum .347, 1986. These five films elevated him to the FAMAS Hall of Fame. He also copped the FAP Best Actor awards for his performance in the last two films. In 1991 he was awarded the FAP Lifetime Achievement Award. Adjudged Best Pictures by the FAMAS were Poe’s Sigaw ng Digmaan (War Cry), 1963; Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels without Heaven), 1970; and Ang Padrino, 1984.

Considered the “King of Philippine Cinema,” FPJ reigned the box office with countless blockbusters, such as Ang Leon at ang Daga (The Lion and the Mouse), 1975; Little Christmas Tree, 1977; Batang Quiapo (Quiapo Kid), 1986; Gawa Na ang Bala na Papatay sa Iyo (The Bullet That Will Kill You Has Been Made), 1988; Hindi Ka Na Sisikatan ng Araw (You’ll Never See Another Sunrise) and Kahit Konting Pagtingin (Just a Little Love), 1990; Dito sa Pitong Gatang (Here at Pitong Gatang), 1992; Ang Probinsyano (The Country Boy), 1997; and Batas ng Lansangan (Law of the Streets), 2002. Pakners (Partners) in 2003 was Poe’s last film.

Poe entered politics as presidential candidate of the Koalisyon ng Nagkakaisang Pilipino (KNP) or Coalition of United Filipinos during the 2004 national elections. Poe lost to Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo in a controversial election.

He was posthumously proclaimed National Artist for film in 2006.Written by Glecy Atienza, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

POE, LOVI (Lourdes Virginia Moran Poe) b. Manila 11 Feb 1989. Movie and television actor. She is the daughter of the late iconic star Fernando Poe Jr and Rowena Moran, a former actor and beauty queen. She grew up in Angeles City, Pampanga, and attended high school at Angeles University Foundation. She later enrolled at the International Academy of Management and Economics and then at Miriam College.

In 2006, Poe got the break of her career when she was chosen by the Thailand-based Canadian pop duo Same Same to do a duet titled “Without You” for their album The Meaning of Happy. Poe’s first movie role was in Regal Films’ popular franchise Shake, Rattle & Roll IX, 2007. But it was in independent films where Poe really showed her talent as a serious actor. In 2009, she starred in Paolo Villaluna and Ellen Ramos’s Walang Hanggang Paalam (Endless Farewell) and in Joel Lamangan’s Sagrada Familia (Holy Family), which won for her Best Actress from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences. Continuing her success in indie productions, Poe appeared in two films that competed in the 2010 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. In the New Breed category, she played the lead role in Dan Villegas’s Mayohan, 2010, which won for her the Balanghai trophy for Best Actress. She also had a supporting role in Joel Lamangan’s Sigwa (Rage), 2010, which competed in the Director’s Showcase category. Poe ended the year by starring in Topel Lee’s horror movie White House, 2010, with Gabby Concepcion and Iza Calzado.

In 2011, Poe starred in Jun Lana’s Yesterday Today Tomorrow, which won for her Best Supporting Actress from the Film Academy of the Philippines and the Star Awards for Movies; Joel Lamangan’s Deadline: The Reign of Impunity; Jerrold Tarog’s Aswang; Regal Films’ My Valentine Girls and Temptation Island, the latter being director Chris Martinez’s remake of Joey Gosiengfiao’s 1980 camp classic; and Jun Lana’s My Neighbor’s Wife. Poe continued her busy streak in 2012, appearing in Tara Illenberger’s Guni-guni (Hallucinations), Regal Films’ Shake, Rattle & Roll XIV: The Invasion, and Erik Matti’s Tiktik: The Aswang Chronicles, and starring opposite Nora Aunor and Bembol Roco in Brillante Mendoza’s Thy Womb.
