From 2013 to 2014, Poe made more significant work, including Joel Lamangan’s The Bride and the Lover; Arturo San Agustin’s Talamak (Chronic); Jerrold Tarog’s Sana Dati (If Only); and for the fifth time, she collaborated with Joel Lamangan for Lihis (Deviate), 2013, one of the films produced through a grant given by the Film Development Council of the Philippines. In 2014, she played the lead in Remton Siega Zuasola’s Soap Opera, an entry in the 2014 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival.

In 2006, Poe signed with GMA Network and began appearing in several television programs, including Love to Love and Bakekang. She then went on to become a regular in GMA Network’s primetime programs, including Zaido: Pulis Pangkalawakan (Zaido: The Space Police), 2007; Kaputol ng Isang Awit (Unsung Melody) and La Lola, 2008, an adaptation of a top-rated Argentine television series of the same title. Poe joined the cast of Ang Babaeng Hinugot sa Aking Tadyang (Dangerous Love), 2009, a television adaptation of Carlo Caparas’s komiks series. In 2010, she appeared in television soap operas Beauty Queen and Little Star. She also starred in GMA Network’s socially relevant miniseries Titser (Teacher), 2013. Written by Elvin Valerio

PORTES, GIL M. (Gil Merluza Portes) b. Pagbilao, Quezon 13 Sep 1945. d. Manila 24 May 2017. Director, scriptwriter, and producer. His parents are Bernabe P. Portes and Higina Merluza. He married Estela Davao with whom he had two sons, Carlo and Justin. He obtained his bachelor of philosophy degree from the University of Santo Tomas in l965. He finished his master of arts in film and television at Brooklyn College of the City University of New York in 1971. He received a diploma in film and television from the British Broadcasting Corporation in 1974.

An independent filmmaker, his first film is Tiket Mama, Tiket Ale (Ticket Sir, Ticket Ma’am), 1976. His socially relevant films include Miss X, 1980; ’Merika (America), 1984; Andrea, Paano Ba ang Maging Isang Ina? (Andrea, How Does One Become a Mother?), 1990, for which he won Best Director and Best Story (shared with Ricky Lee) in the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF), the Gold Prize from the Young Critics Circle, and Movie Director of the Year in the Star Awards for Movies; Mulanay: Sa Pusod ng Paraiso (Mulanay: Deep in Paradise), 1996, about the country’s doctors-to-the-barrio program, which was a runaway winner at the Manila Film Festival; and Saranggola (The Kite), 1999, about an ex-cop trying to cover up a murder witnessed by his son, which was awarded the MMFF Best Picture, Best Actor, Best Original Story, Best Screenplay, and Best Theme Song. It also won for Portes and Jose Dalisay Jr the Original Screenplay of the Year and for Ricky Davao the Movie Actor of the Year at the Star Awards for Movies in 2000. Davao also won Best Actor in the 1999 Cinemanila International Film Festival and the 2000 Gawad Urian. Lester Llansang won Best Child Actor from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 2000. Other notable films are Miguel/Michelle, 1998; Gatas … Sa Dibdib ng Kaaway (In the Bosom of the Enemy) and Huwag Kang Kikibo (Do Not Make a Sound), 2001; and Homecoming, 2003.

His other award-winning films are Markova: Comfort Gay, 2000, which won the Prix de la Meilleure Interpretation for Dolphy, Eric Quizon, and Jeffrey Quizon at the 2001 Brussels International Film Festival; Mga Munting Tinig (Small Voices), 2002, which won Best Director in the 2003 FAMAS and Gawad Urian, and the awards for Best Feature, Best Director, and Best Screenplay in the 2003 Palm Beach International Film Festival; and Two Funerals, 2010, which won the Special Jury Prize and Best Director (Directors Showcase category) at the 2010 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. Written by Rica Arevalo

PREMIERE PRODUCTIONS INC Established in 1946 in Grace Park, Caloocan City, by Dr Ciriaco Santiago, Adela Hermoso Santiago, Silvestre M. Punzalan, Ricardo Marcelino, Jose P. Osorio, Ricardo Balatbat, and Generoso Santiago, Premiere Productions was the only postwar film company that was still active in movie production even after the turn of the millennium, until it finally stopped production in 2004, a few years before the demise of producer and director Cirio H. Santiago.

Together with Sampaguita and LVN, Premiere was one of the “Big Three” film studios in the Philippines in the 1950s. Premiere’s first movie was Probinsiyana (Country Girl), 1946, starring Carmen Rosales and Jose Padilla Jr, directed by Susana C. de Guzman. The studio’s other notable productions are Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), 1947; Anghel sa Lupa (Angel on Earth), 1948; Anak ng Panday (Son of the Blacksmith), 1949; Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fortune), 1950; Kenkoy, 1951; Dyesebel, 1953; Pedro Penduko, 1954; Mag-asawa’y Di Biro (Getting Married Is No Joke), 1955; Cinco Hermanas (Five Sisters), 1956; Bakasyon Grande (Grand Vacation), 1957; Anak ng Bulkan (Child of the Volcano), Pitong Gatang (Seven Chupas), and Terror Is a Man, 1959; Batingaw (Bell), 1960; Lagalag (Vagabond), 1964; El Pinoy Matador (Filipino Bullfighter), 1970; Fe, Esperanza, Caridad, 1974; Kumander Agimat (Commander Amulet), 1975; Kapitan Kidlat (Captain Lightning), 1981; The Expendables, 1988; To Saudi with Love, 1997; Damong Ligaw (Wild Grass) and Anak ng Bulkan (Son of the Volcano), 1997; Takaw Tukso (Temptation), 1998; Cariño Brutal (Brutal Love) and Captain Barbell, 2003.

Premiere blazed a trail in action films with social relevance under the direction of Chat Gallardo, Ramon Estella, Alex Sunga, and Gerardo de Leon. It established a home studio for popular action stars Efren Reyes, Johnny Monteiro, Jose Padilla Jr, Fernando Poe Jr, Zaldy Zshornack, Jose Romulo, Bob Soler, Danilo Montes, and Eddie Fernandez. It also boasted of famous actresses like Anita Linda, Leila Morena, Edna Luna, Carol Varga, and Shirley Gorospe.

It was under the banner of Premiere Productions that Gerardo de Leon, later to be declared National Artist for film, made many of his notable films, among them 48 Oras (48 Hours) and Padre Burgos (Father Burgos), 1950; Diego Silang, 1951; Bagong Umaga (New Morning), 1952; and Ifugao, 1954. De Leon’s Dyesebel, 1953, starring Edna Luna, was one of the studio’s biggest hits.

During the incumbency of Dr Ciriaco Santiago and later his son, Cirio, it produced many award-winning films, including Kamay ni Satanas (Hand of Satan), 1950, and Sisa, 1951, which won the Maria Clara awards for Best Film. Ifugao won the Asian Film Festival award for Best Director in 1954. From the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, it won the Best Picture awards for Salabusab (Greedy), 1954; Kalibre .45 (Caliber .45), 1957; Huwag Mo Akong Limutin (Never Forget Me), 1960; and Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth), 1976.

Premiere Productions Inc morphed into Premiere Films International in 1988 when it ventured into foreign movie productions. In 1993, it introduced Roving Cinema, a theater-cum-advertising van that screened movies, television programs, and documentaries, with ads in between. However, it underwent a corporate restructuring in 1996 when it morphed into Premiere Entertainment Philippines Inc (PEP). PEP’s shares of stock were listed in the Philippine Stock Exchange on 5 May 1997. It became the first publicly listed company engaged in the production of motion pictures. It also forayed into the gaming industry, as part of its whole entertainment offer. PEP offers broadcast rights to its film library titles for television, video, cable, and other media.

In Aug 2008, PEP acquired the gaming company Digiwave Solutions Inc (Digiwave), through a share swap transaction. The Securities and Exchange Commission issued on 13 Feb 2009 the certificate of approval of valuation certifying the shares of stock of Digiwave amounting to 1.03 billion pesos or the aggregate of 500,000 shares of stock in exchange for the shares of stock of PEP. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

PRINCIPE, DOMINGO(Domingo Alcaraz Principe) b. Bocaue, Bulacan 3 Aug 1912. d. Manila 6 Oct 1996. Movie actor, film and stage director, scriptwriter and playwright. He is the son of Jacinto Principe, a musician, and Ciriaca Alcaraz. He married Juanita de la Cruz with whom he had six children. He studied at Torres High School in Tondo, Manila, and obtained his bachelor of laws from Far Eastern University.

Principe was recommended to director-producer JoseNepomuceno by Vicente Albo of Lyric Film Exchange in Santa Cruz, Manila. For his screen test, Nepomuceno gave him a bit role in Sa Landas ng Pag-ibig (The Road to Love), 1929, starring Paquito Villa and Anne Harris. He starred in Dalaga (Maiden) 1931, with CarlosPadilla, MaryWalter, and Flora Vidal; Mang Tano: Nuno ng mga Aswang (Old Man Tano: Aswang Ancestor) and Satanas (Satan), with RosadelRosario, both in 1932. He also appeared in films like Awit ng Pag-ibig (Song of Love), 1935; Taong Demonyo (Demon Man), Sanga-sangang Dila (Forked Tongues), and Nang Magulo ang Maynila (When Manila Was in Chaos), with Rosa del Rosario, all in 1937; Hatol ng Mataas na Langit (Judgment of High Heavens) and Kalapating Puti (White Dove), 1938; Inang Pulot (Adopted Mother), 1939; Alaalang Banal (Sacred Memory), Maginoong Takas (Gentle Fugitive), and Rosa Birhen (Virgin Rose), 1940.

During World War II, he acted in stage shows at different movie houses in Manila. In 1946 he appeared in the first postwar film, Orasang Ginto (Golden Clock), starring MiladelSol and Bimbo Danao, under the direction of ManuelConde. His other films after the war are Aawitan Kita (I Shall Sing for You), Barung-barong (Shanty), Tomadachi Zona, all with MonaLisa in 1946; Sekretang Hongkong (Spy in Hongkong), 1947; Kung Sakali Ma’t Salat (Though I May Be Poor), 1949; and Huling Konsiyerto (Last Concert), 1951, with Carmen Rosales.

In the 1950s he wrote and directed several dramas on radio. In 1962 he appeared in Hindi Kami Laos (We Are Not Has-Beens), with LeopoldoSalcedo, Jose PadillaJr, ReynaldoDante, BenPerez, and Teody Belarmino. Written by Cesar Hernando, updated by Mesandel Arguelles
(See BROADCAST ARTS volume.)

PUGO AND TOGO Pugo (Mariano Contreras, b. Malate, Manila 12 Jul 1910; d. Manila 14 Dec 1978) and Togo (Andres Solomon, b. ca 1910; d. ca 1952). Movie and stage actors. Pugo and Togo were a popular comic team on stage and in the movies who made their baldness their distinctive mark. When they still had their hair, the duo appeared in bodabil shows at the Star Theater in 1936. Like Oliver Hardy and Stan Laurel of Hollywood, Togo played the fat man and Pugo, his skinny sparring partner. They were great ad-libbers and hardly needed a script.

Their first movie was Ang Lihim ng Lumang Simbahan (The Secret of the Old Church), 1940. Later, they were cast in Utos ng Hari, Hindi Mababali (The King’s Command Is Law), 1941, and Binibiro Lamang Kita (I Was Only Joking), 1941.

During World War II when movie companies shut down, the comic duo performed at the Life, Lyric, and Avenue Theaters, together with CarmenRosales, Rogeliode laRosa, FernandoPoeSr, and LeopoldoSalcedo. Since the name of the Japanese war hero was Admiral Tojo, they had to change their names to Puging and Tuging.

After World War II, the PugoandTogo team became a mainstay of LVNfilms. They appeared together in Tambol Mayor (Big Drum), Ang Kandidato (The Candidate), and Biglang Yaman (Sudden Wealth), 1949; Magkumpareng Putik (Mud Buddies), Nagsaulian ng Kandila (Breakup), Doctor X, and Edong Mapangarap (Edong the Dreamer), 1950; Dalawang Prinsipeng Kambal (Two Twin Princes) and Pulo ng Engkanto (Enchanted Island), 1951; Kambal Tuko (Siamese Twins), Saykopatic (Psychopatic), and Dalawang Sundalong Kanin (Two Rice Soldiers), 1952, which was Togo’s last film.

After Togo died, Pugo continued as a solo performer and appeared regularly on radio and in television shows until the 1970s. He was a mainstay in the weekly radio comedy Sebya, Mahal Kita (Sebya, I Love You), with SylviaLaTorre, which was made into a movie in 1957, and in the TV shows Tang Tarang Tang and Si Tatang Kasi (Blame It on Father).

It was for these two TV shows that Pugo received the Citizens’ Award for Television for Best Actor in 1967 and 1971. In 1989 the FilmAcademyof thePhilippines posthumously conferred on Pugo and Togo a Special Recognition Award for their outstanding contribution to Philippine cinema. Written by Galileo Zafra
(See DANCE volume.)

QUINTANA, TESSIE (Teresita Talampas Quintana) b. Santa Cruz, Laguna 17 Jul 1931. d. 25 Feb 1969. Movie actor. Her parents are Francisco Quintana and Consuelo Talampas. She married actor Johnny Reyes with whom she had three children. She started her career in show business as an amateur contest singer. Hustled up a platform by her parents to sing in the finals, the young Quintana won over some 50 contestants and brought home a prize of 30 pesos.

A popular prewar child star, Quintana performed onstage during the Japanese Occupation. She also appeared briefly in the Japanese war movie Dawn of Freedom, 1944, directed by Gerardo de Leon. After the war, she was given a role in Puting Bantayog (White Monument), 1948, starring Leopoldo Salcedo and Norma Blancaflor. In the same year, she was paired with Armando Goyena in Sa Tokyo Ikinasal (Married in Tokyo), starring Rogelio de la Rosa. Goyena became her leading man in 17 LVN films, including Prinsesang Basahan (Princess in Rags) and Virginia, 1949; Misteryoso (Mysterious) and Pagtutuos (Reckoning), 1950; David at Goliath (David and Goliath) and Talisman, 1951; Tia Loleng (Aunt Loleng) and Isabelita, 1952; Hawayana (Hawaiian Girl), 1953; and Damong Ligaw (Wild Grass), 1954. Quintana made more than 30 pictures with other leading men. Among other films she made are Hen. Gregorio del Pilar (General Gregorio del Pilar), 1949, with Jose Padilla Jr; Kapitan Cristina sa Candaba (Captain Cristina in Candaba), 1950, with Teody Belarmino; Bayan o Pag-ibig (Country or Love), 1951, with Rogelio de la Rosa; Nasaan Ka Giliw (Where Are You Dear), 1951, with Mario Montenegro; Dagohoy, 1953, also with Montenegro; Abarinding, 1954, with Carlos Salazar; Singsing na Tanso (Bronze Ring), 1954, and Limang Punglo (Five Bullets), 1959, also with de Villa; Juan Tamad Goes to Congress (Lazy Juan Goes to Congress), 1959, Juan Tamad Goes to Society (Lazy Juan Goes to Society), and Si Juan Tamad at si Juan Masipag sa Politikang Walang Hanggan (Lazy Juan and Industrious Juan in Never-Ending Politics), 1963, with Manuel Conde.

When LVN stopped producing films, she moved to Premiere Productions and made films like Tokyo 1960, 1957, and Kadenang Putik (Chain of Mud), 1960, with Efren Reyes and Alicia Vergel. She remained active in the movies until her death in 1969.

Quintana won a Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Actress award for Alaala Kita (Thinking of You), 1961, a Cesar Gallardo film. Written byDanny Villanueva

QUINTOS, RORY(Ma. Aurora Baltazar Quintos) b. 31 Oct 1962. Film and TV director. Her parents are Vicente G. Quintos and Emma Baltazar, both deceased. She graduated with a bachelor of arts in broadcasting from University of the Philippines Diliman in 1984.

Quintos rose from the ranks. She worked as production assistant, production manager, talent coordinator, floor director, associate producer, and assistant director before becoming a producer and director. She was assistant director to Laurice Guillen in 10 films. In 1992, she was given a break to direct the ABS-CBN drama anthology Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember). Her film debut, Basta’t Kasama Kita (As Long as I’m with You), 1994, was produced by Star Cinema. Her other films include Mangarap Ka (Dream On), 1995; Sa Aking mga Kamay (In My Hands), 1996; Paano ang Puso Ko? (How about My Heart?), 1997; Ipaglaban Mo: The Movie II (Fight for It: The Movie 2), 1998; Kay Tagal Kang Hinintay (So Long Have I Waited for You), 1999; Anak (The Child), 2000; Kailangan Kita (I Need You), 2002; Dubai, 2005; Love Me Again, 2008; and Suddenly It’s Magic, 2012.

Quintos is one of ABS-CBN’s most sought after television directors. Aside from Maalaala Mo Kaya, she directed for Star Drama Theater, Calvento Files, and Wansapanataym (Once upon a Time), 1992-96; Esperanza, 1996-98; Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000-2002; Darating ang Umaga (Till Morning Comes), 2003; Krystala, 2004; Sa Piling Mo (With You) and Ysabella, 2006; Maging Sino Ka Man 2 (Whoever You May Be 2), 2007; Only You, 2008; Cheating Hearts, 2009; Kristine, 2010; Maria del Barrio, 2012; Princess and I, 2013; Legal Wife, 2014; and Pangako sa ’Yo 2 (The Promise 2), 2015. Written by Rica Leticia Arevalo

QUIZON, ERIC(Enrico Smith Quizon) aka Kaizz. b. Manila 20 Jan 1967. Movie and television actor and director. He is the son of comedian Dolphy (Rodolfo Vera Quizon) and Alice Smith. He studied at Ateneo de Manila University from grade school to college. He is brother to actor Jeffrey Quizon and half-brother to actors Sahlee Quizon, Rolly Quizon, and Vandolph.

Quizon is a versatile actor who is good in both drama and comedy. His memorable films include Pusong Mamon (Soft Hearts), 1998; Markova: Comfort Gay, 2000; Mano Po (I Kiss Your Hand), 2002; and Crying Ladies, 2003. He also worked as director in films such as Pagdating ng Panahon (When the Time Comes), 1998; Dito sa Puso Ko (Here in My Heart), 1999; and Home Alone da Riber (Home Alone the River), 2002. Quizon also appeared in TV programs such as Mula sa Puso (From the Heart), 1997-99; Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1999-2001; Sana ay Ikaw Na Nga (I Hope You’re the One), 2001-3; and Babaeng Hampaslupa (The Hapless Woman), 2011. In addition, he produces movies and TV shows, among them, a top-rating television comedy show, Buddy en Sol, 1991-93, with Redford White. He also directed for television the following TV programs: Darna, 2005; My Driver Sweet Lover, 2010; Isang Dakot na Luha (A Handful of Tears), 2012; and a few episodes for the shows Ipaglaban Mo (Fight for It), 2014, and Seasons of Love, 2014.

Quizon won Best Supporting Actor in the Star Awards and the Gawad Urian for the movie Pahiram ng Isang Umaga (Lend Me One Morning), 1989, which also earned him nominations from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) and the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA). He won in the same category at the FAMAS for Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven), 1991, and was Best Actor at the 1991 Metro Manila Film Festival for Juan Tamad at Mister Shooli sa Mongolian Barbecue: The Movie. He received the Producer of the Year award in 1992 from the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Foundation, and special citations from the CMMA as producer of Unang Tibok ng Puso (First Heartbeat) and Si Lucio at si Miguel (Lucio and Miguel), 1992. Together with his father Dolphy and his brother Jeffrey, he received the Prix de la Meilleure Interpretation (Best Actor and Best Actress awards) from the 2002 Brussels International Independent Film Festival for Markova: Comfort Gay. In 2004, he won the Best Supporting Actor award from the Film Academy of the Philippines for his performance in Crying Ladies. Written by Cristine Directo, updated by Anne Frances Sangil

RAMIREZ, CESAR(Arlen Quindoy Aguilar) b. Jul 1924. d. Quezon City 18 Jul 2003. Movie actor. He married actor Alicia Vergel, with whom he had two children, actors Ace Vergel and Beverly Vergel. After his film career, he resided in the United States.

Ramirez first appeared as an extra in the Sampaguita musical Huwag Ka Nang Magtampo (No Hard Feelings), 1950, starring Pancho Magalona and Tita Duran, and in LVN’s Ang Bombero (The Firefighter) and Dayang-Dayang, 1950. He then played a co-starring role with Fred Montilla in Teniente Ramirez (Lieutenant Ramirez), 1950, and the title role in Bernardo Carpio, 1951, a film about a legendary Filipino folk hero. Ramirez possessed the looks, stature, and physique of a “Mr Philippines,” which gave him an edge over other contenders for the role of Bernardo Carpio. After this, he played swashbuckler roles in costume movies like Tres Muskiteros (Three Musketeers), 1951; Espada (Sword), 1952; El Indio (The Native), 1953; and Tres Ojos (Three Eyes), 1954. He also played Tarzan roles in films like Diwani, 1953, and Ukala and Dumagit, 1954.

After Sampaguita, Ramirez transferred to Premiere Productions where he made action films like Apat na Anino (Four Shadows) and Ang Matapang Lamang (Only the Brave), 1959; Sandakot na Alabok (A Handful of Dust), Dead or Alive, Sa Bawa’t Patak ng Dugo (With Every Drop of Blood), and Apat na Bandila (Four Flags), 1960; Sa Baril Mag-uusap (The Language of the Gun), 1961; and Labanan sa Balicuatro (Fight at Balicuatro), 1962. He continued making films up to the 1970s with other movie production outfits, among them Aguilar, Pulang Lupa (Red Earth), Signos Trece (Omen Thirteen), and Maton ng Pondohan (Tough Guy of the Neighborhood), 1971; Karateka Boxer, 1973; and Heroes of Dimataling, 1974.

Ramirez was one of the principal actors in Gerardo de Leon’s Huwag Mo Akong Limutin (Never Forget Me), 1960, which won Best Picture and other major awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS). He was nominated Best Actor by the FAMAS for Suicide Susy, 1962. Written byNenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

RAMOS, ELLEN (Eleanor Cruz Ramos) b. Manila 26 May 1967. Animator, editor, and director. Her parents are Ernesto S. Ramos and Evangelina B. Cruz. She has a bachelor of science in architecture from the University of the Philippines Diliman and ranked 9th place in the 1990 Architect Licensure Examination given by the Board of Architecture of the Professional Regulation Commission. She is a grantee of the UNESCO-Aschberg Residency for Artists Scholarship, Cologne Academy of Media Arts, Germany, in 1997.

Ramos’s illustration of Ang mga Diwata ng Lawa (Goddess of the Lake) won the grand prize at the Philippine Board on Books for Young People Illustrators Prize in 1992. Her animation shorts Animated Self-Portraits and Tetris o Aso (Tetris or Dog), 1992, and paint-on-glass Doon sa Kabila ng Bulkan (The Other Side of the Volcano), 1997, all won first prize at the Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video.

In 2005, she made her feature film debut with co-director Paolo Villaluna titled Ilusyon (Illusion), the first of a trilogy. The film was the first independent digital film to be graded “A” by the Cinema Evaluation Board. It was also one of the five winners of the “CJ Selections” at the 2006 Pusan International Film Festival, South Korea. Her second film with Villaluna, Selda (The Inmate), 2007, was in the official selection of the 2008 Montreal World Film Festival (Canada) and 2008 Thessaloniki International Film Festival (Greece). The ending to their love trilogy is Walang Hanggang Paalam (Endless Farewell), 2009, winner in the Best World Showcase Feature at the 2010 Soho International Film Festival, New York, USA.

Ramos co-directed with Rica Arevalo and Sarah Roxas a film trilogy about women titled Ganap na Babae (Garden of Eve), 2010, produced by Hubo Productions. It was the 2010 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival opening film and winner of Excellence in Cinematography at the 2011 Soho International Film Festival and the Mountain of Hope Project Award at the 2012 International Film Festival Manhattan in New York, USA.

Her mixed-media animation Buhay Kubo (Life in a Hut), 2012, won the grand prize at the 2013 Animahenasyon Festival. Written by Rica Arevalo

RAMOS, ELY 19 Jul 1915. d. 23 Oct 1972. Actor, singer. He is the son of Judge Ramos of Gubat, Sorsogon. He married Julie Carpenter with whom he had three children. He studied at Ateneo de Manila and took law at the National University (NU).

He was one of the pre-World War II singing matinee idols. He starred in lavish musicals like Sampaguita’s first film Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), 1937, and Madaling Araw (Break of Dawn), 1938, both starring Elsa Oria and under the direction of Carlos Vander Tolosa. He also starred in LVN’s first film, the musical Giliw Ko (My Love), 1939, with Mila del Sol, Fernando Poe, and Fleur de Lis (aka Mona Lisa), directed by Tolosa, then in Hali, 1940, and Sawing Gantimpala (Lost Victory), 1940, both with Mila del Sol. For Filippine Films, he starred with Norma Blancaflor in Carlos Vander Tolosa’s three films: Dalaga, Isang Ngiti Mo Lamang (Lady, Just One Smile from You), 1940; Binibini ng Palengke (Muse of the Market), 1941; and Binibiro Lamang Kita (I Was Only Joking), 1941. After the war, he was teamed with Corazon Noble in Ramon Estella’s Magkaibang Lahi (Different Races), 1947, about the conflict of a Filipina marrying an American after World War II. LVN Pictures paired him once again with Norma Blancaflor in Manugang at Biyenan (The In-Laws) and Sumpaan (Pledge), 1948. His other films are Dahong Lagas (Withered Leaf), 1938; Hatinggabi (Midnight), 1940; Sa Iyong Kandungan (In Your Cradle) and Palikero (Playboy), 1941; Ang Tagala (The Tagalog Woman) and Maynila (Manila), 1946; Isumpa Mo, Giliw (Make a Vow, My Love), 1947; and Ang Selosa (The Jealous Woman), 1948.

He was declared Best Actor of 1940 for Dalaga at awards rites sponsored by the Bureau of Commerce held at the Metropolitan Theater. Written byCesar Hernando

RANILLO, MAT JR(Mat Kaper Ranillo Jr) b. Dipolog, Zamboanga del Norte 21 Sep 1923. d. 12 Sep 1969. Movie actor and director. Born to Matias Ranillo Sr, twice governor and representative of Zamboanga del Norte, and Sotera Kaper, he studied in public and private schools in Dipolog and went to Manila for his college education. He finished his bachelor of arts at the University of the Philippines and took up law at Manuel L. Quezon University and the Univerity of Southern Philippines. He was married to Gloria Sevilla, the premier actor of Visayan films, with whom he had six children. Many of his children have become actors, among them Mat Ranillo III, Dandin, Suzette, and Lilibeth.

Ranillo and his wife Gloria Sevilla were known as the “King” and “Queen” of Visayan movies during the heyday of the industry in the 1950s. Among the movies they starred in together are Princesa Tirana (Princess Tirana), Pardista, Rosas Pandan, Pailub Lang (Just a Moment), and Badlis sa Kinabuhi (Life Lines), 1969, directed by Leroy Salvador. Ranillo also appeared in some Tagalog films, such as Isabelita, 1952; Pantalan Trece (Wharf 13), 1961, with Joseph Estrada, Amado Cortez, and Ramon Revilla; and Sa Dulo ng Ating Landas (At the End of Our Road), 1966, opposite Alona Alegre.

Badlis sa Kinabuhi earned 10 nominations from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS). Ranillo received a posthumous award from the FAMAS in 1970. Written by Erlinda K. Alburo

RANILLO, MAT III(Matias Archibald Sevilla Ranillo III) b. Cebu City 5 Oct 1956. Movie actor. He comes from a well-known movie family. His father is producer-actor Mat Ranillo Jr and his mother, actor Gloria Sevilla. Two of his brothers, Dandin and Junius, and two of his sisters, Lilibeth and Suzette, acted in the movies. He is married to Linda Tupaz, with whom he has three children. One of them, Krista, was a television and movie personality until she settled down in the USA in 2010. After his elementary education at Lourdes School in Quezon City and high school at San Sebastian College, he studied customs administration at PMI Colleges.

Ranillo appeared with popular female leads Vilma Santos, Nora Aunor, Lorna Tolentino, Alma Moreno, Alona Alegre, and Vivian Velez. His films include Mariposang Dagat (Sea Butterfly), Dalawang Pugad, Isang Ibon (Two Nests, One Bird), Walang Katapusang Tag-Araw (Eternal Summer) and Sa Piling ng mga Sugapa (In the Company of Addicts), 1977; Dyesebel, Rubia Servios, Baby Doll, Kampus (Campus), and Pag-ibig, Magkano Ka? (Love, How Much Are You Worth?), 1978; Salawahan (Fickle), 1979; and Girlfriend, 1980.

He decided to put a temporary halt to his movie career in the early to late 1980s, settled down in the USA with his family, and only appeared occasionally in the movies and on stage—in his role as Jesus Christ in the Lenten play Kristo (Christ) during brief visits to the Philippines. Upon his return, he made films including Kumander Bawang (Captain Garlic) and Lorenzo Ruiz … The Saint … A Filipino!, 1988; Huwag Mong Salingin ang Sugat Ko (Touch Not My Wound), 1991; Minsan Lang Kita Iibigin (I’ll Only Love You Once), 1994; Sarah … Ang Munting Prinsesa (Sarah … The Little Princess), 1995; Istokwa (Stowaway) and Kristo, 1996; and Jologs, 2002.

Ranillo was also very visible on television, appearing in various series like Anna Karenina, 1996; Esperanza, 1998; Buttercup, 2003; Inday sa Balitaw, 2006; Dyesebel and My Girl, 2008; Katorse (Fourteen) and Darna, 2009. He also appeared in various episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) from 1993 to 2009.

Ranillo won two acting trophies from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences: Best Supporting Actor for Masarap, Masakit ang Umibig (Joy and Pain of Loving), 1977, and Best Actor for Isang Ama, Dalawang Ina (One Father, Two Mothers), 1978. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

RASCA, NONONG (Marcelino Rasca) aka Jun Rasca, Nonoy Rasca, Mars Rasca. b. Alaminos, Pangasinan 2 Jan 1932. Cinematographer. Rasca was initially a stillman in film productions. He had already been behind the camera since the early 1960s, either as stills photographer or assistant cameraman, when his first big break came with the bomba film Ganid sa Laman (Bestial), 1970, where he became a full-fledged cinematographer. Using the name Mars Rasca, he developed his own style in subsequent movies, like Nunal sa Balikat (Mole on the Shoulder), 1971; Hulihin si Tiagong Akyat (Get Tiagong Akyat), 1973; The Rebel Hunter, Bertong Suklob, Beloy Montemayor, and Inday Garutay, 1976; and Napoleon Agra, 1978.

Rasca and Ramon Revilla aka Jose Yandoc worked together on many significant film biographies about famous and infamous Cavite personalities whose real and fictional lives made movie history—notably, Bergado: Terror of Cavite, 1976; Gulapa: Ang Barakong Mayor ng Maragondon (Gulapa: The Macho Mayor of Maragondon) and Bianong Bulag (Biano the Blind Man), 1977; and Tonyong Bayawak (Tonyo the Water Monitor Lizard), 1979. His other notable films are Pepeng Agimat (Pepe the Amulet), 1973, with co-cinematographer Tommy Marcelino; Lumapit … Lumayo ang Umaga (Morning Comes and Goes), 1975; Task Force Kingfisher, Walang Katapusang Tag-araw (Eternal Summer), and Dalawang Pugad, Isang Ibon (Two Nests, One Bird), 1977; Matang-Lawin (Hawkeyed), 1979; Maranatha and Task Force King Fisher Beloy Montemayor, 1982; Hanggang sa Huling Bala (Till the Last Bullet), 1984; SFX Retaliator, 1987; Death Bond, 1988; and Pahiram ng Isang Umaga (Lend Me One Morning), 1989. His last film was Markang Bungo: The Bobby Ortega Story (Skull Mark: The Bobby Ortega Story), 1991.

Rasca received Best Cinematography awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Nardong Putik, 1972, directed by Tony Cayado; from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Kapitan Kulas, 1975, directed by Lamberto V. Avellana; and from Gawad Urian for Ishmael Bernal’s Pahiram ng Isang Umaga, 1987, with co-cinematographers Manalo Abaya and Eduardo Jacinto. Written byLena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr
(See LITERATURE volume.)

RAZON, DELIA(Lucy May Duling Grytz) b. Iloilo City 8 Aug 1931. Movie actor. Her parents are Karl Grytz, a German-American, and May Duling. She married Aurelio Reyes. Daughter Rea Reyes also acted in the movies. Actor Carla Abellana is her granddaughter. Razon quit school at Colegio de Santo Angel, Iloilo City, to become an actor. An avid movie fan, she caught the attention of the people at Sampaguita during a visit to the studios. She was promptly given a screen test, which she passed. She was initially an extra in Apat na Bulag (Four Blind Men), 1948, and several other movies.

She was asked to appear in LVN Pictures’ Malaya: Mutya ng Gubat (Malaya: The Forest Nymph), 1948, starring Mila del Sol and Teddy Benavides, and when producer Doña Sisang saw the film’s rushes, she was impressed enough to give Razon a three-picture contract. Razon was introduced in Krus na Bituin (Star Cross), 1948. She played second lead in Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1950, and leading lady to Rogelio de la Rosa in Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), 1950, and its sequel Prinsipe Amante sa Rubitanya (Prince Amante in Rubitania), 1951. She then appeared in many other costume films, including Manuel Conde’s Apat na Alas (Four Aces), 1950; Shalimar, 1951; Rodrigo de Villa, 1952; Tatlong Labuyo (Three Hotheads) 1953; Doce Pares (Twelve Pairs), 1954; the remake of Prinsipe Teñoso (Prince Teñoso), 1954; and Higit sa Korona (More Than the Crown), 1956.

Aside from period and costume movies, Razon also appeared in the historical film Lapu-Lapu, 1955, and dramatic films like Dakilang Pagpapakasakit (Great Sacrifice), 1954; Ikaw ang Dahilan (Because of You), 1954; Dambanang Putik (Shrine of Mud), 1954; Banal o Makasalanan (Saint or Sinner), 1955; Ilaw sa Karimlan (Light in Darkness), 1956; and Luksang Tagumpay (Dark Victory), 1956, directed by Gregorio Fernandez. She also appeared in Lamberto V. Avellana’s Satur, 1951, starring Manuel Conde and Jaime de la Rosa; Señorito (Spoiled Brat), 1953, with Manuel Conde; Manuel Silos’s musical 1-2-3, 1955, with Nestor de Villa; Salamangkero (Magician), 1955, with Carlos Salazar; and El Robo, 1957, with Armando Goyena.

Razon starred in the first Filipino co-production with a foreign film company, Persari Productions of Indonesia. The film was Rodrigo de Villa, 1952, where her leading man was Mario Montenegro. She made many popular movies with Mario Montenegro like Bohemyo (Playboy), 1952; Mga Pusong May Lason (Poisoned Hearts), 1953; Among Tunay (True Master), 1956; Balae (In-Law), 1958; and Rebelde (Rebel), 1958.

Razon continued to appear in the movies such as Haplos (Caress), 1982; Ibigay Mo sa Akin ang Bukas (Give Me Tomorrow), 1986; Ipagpatawad Mo (Forgive Me), 1991; Patapon (Useless), 1993; Ika-13 Kapitulo (13th Chapter), 2000; and Buenavista: Ang Kasaysayan ng Lucena (Buenavista: The History of Lucena), 2010. Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

RED, JON(Epifanio Lucas Red Jr) aka Juan Pula. b. Quezon City 23 Oct 1963. Film director, producer, writer, editor. His parents are engineer Epifanio Red Sr and schoolteacher Leonor Lucas. He comes from a family of filmmakers. His brother Raymond Red is a director. Daniel and Roy Red, his other brothers, are production designers. His wife, Carol Bunuan, is a producer. Mikey Red, his son, is a production designer and filmmaker. His daughter Rae Red is a writer and filmmaker. He took up visual arts at the Philippine High School for the Arts and painting at the University of the Philippines Diliman. He also attended a filmmaking workshop at Mowelfund Film Institute. Red is also a painter.

Red is known for films such as Es, 1988; Kuwentong Barbero (Barbers’ Stories), 1991; Tiempo, 1992; Trip, 1993; Ang Pabrika (The Factory), 1994; Still Lives, 1999; Utang ni Tatang (Grandpa’s Debt), 2002; Astigmatism, 2004; Boso (Voyeur), Anak ng Tinapa (Something Fishy), and Cut, 2005; Coup B’etat, 2006; and Motorcycle, 2008. Still Lives, which is about characters involved in the illegal drugs trade, has the distinction of being the first film shot on a digital video camera.

Red also wrote the screenplay for the films Radyo (Radio) and Ilusyon (Illusion) and, with his wife, conceptualized and line- produced the omnibus film Imahe Nasyon (Portrait of a Nation), in commemoration of the 25th anniversary of the EDSA Revolt of 1986.

For TV, Red directed drama series like Eva Fonda, 2008-9; Ang Beerhouse, 2009; Mga Nagbabagang Bulaklak (Smoldering Flowers), Sa Ngalan ng Ina (In the Name of the Mother), and Glamorosa (Glamorous), 2011; Third Eye, 2012; Ang Pirata (The Pirate), 2013; and More Than Words, 2014.

In 1991, Red’s 12-minute film Es won a Special Jury Prize at Mondiale de la Video in Brussels, Belgium, and first prize in the experimental video category of the 2nd Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video. In 1993, Red won a Gawad Urian for Best Short Film for Tiempo. The following year, he won the same award for Trip. In 2000, his work Still Lives was officially selected for the Singapore International Film Festival. Utang ni Tatang won Best Cinematography and Best Production Design in the 2002 Manila Film Festival. In 2004, he won a Silver DV Award from Hong Kong International Film Festival for Astigmatism. His TV show Sineskwela (School on the Air) won the Grand Prix at the Science and Images Festival in Paris, France. Written byJohann Vladimir J. Espiritu, with notes from Nicanor G. Tiongson

RED, RAYMOND(Raymond Lucas Red) aka Goto. b. Quezon City 22 Mar 1965. Filmmaker. He was born to Epifanio Red Sr and Leonor Lucas. His brother Epifanio Jr aka Juan Pula is also a filmmaker and a painter. He studied at Ateneo Grade School and the Philippine High School for the Arts. He took up painting at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Fine Arts, but shifted his interest to filmmaking after viewing German and Russian films at the UP Film Center. He married Sheila Nicolas, with whom he has two children, Mikhail and Nicolas, who are both filmmakers.

In the 1980s, Red made films for the annual contests of the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines. His work earned the notice of British film critic Tony Rayns and he was invited to join international film festivals. Abroad, he gained a reputation for his thought-provoking films.

Most of Red’s works are experimental short films that are introspective and philosophical, imbued with grim humor. From 1983 to 1985, he made such films as Ang Magpakailanman (Eternity), Kabaka (Enemy), Ang Hikab (Yawn), Kamada (State of Being), and Pelikula (Film), all in Super 8mm format. Later, he did short features in 16mm—like Mistula (Something Like), 1987; A Study for the Skies, 1988; and Pepe, 1989—and an MTV experimental film, Pinoys in Berlin, 1988. In 1992 he made his first full-length film in 16mm blown up to 35mm, Bayani (Hero), on the Philippine revolution of 1896, produced by Christoph Janetzko and German Television-ZDF. Some of his other works are Sakay, 1993; Anino (Shadow), 2000; a short film in the anthology ImaheNasyon (Portrait of a Nation), 2006; Himpapawid (Manila Skies), 2010; and Kamera Obskura (Dark Room), 2012.

Red’s films were screened and acclaimed at major film festivals in Asia, Europe, and North America. Among several nominations in the Gawad Urian, he won three awards: Best Short Film for A Study for the Skies in 1990, Best Sound for Bayani in 1993, and Best Cinematography for Himpapawid in 2010. Himpapawid also won the awards for Best Film, Best Editing, Best Cinematography and Visual Design, and Best Screenplay from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk. Internationally, Red won the Palme d’Or for Best Short Film for Anino in the 2000 Cannes Film Festival. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

REGAL FILMS Established on 2 Mar 1965 by a group of film distributors headed by Leonardo Monteverde and his wife, Lily “Mother Lily” Yu Monteverde, Regal Films or Regal Entertainment Inc, as it is known today, is a movie production company currently located in Quezon City. The other incorporators are Marie Sherida Monteverde, Richard Goldwyn Monteverde, Leonida Monteverde Go, and Roselle Monteverde-Teo.

The Monteverdes entered the movie business as film distributors and started producing movies in the mid-1970s with the sex comedy Kayod sa Araw, Kayod sa Gabi (Work All Day, Work All Night), 1976, starring Elizabeth Oropesa. In the same year, Regal released Walang Karanasan (Inexperienced), starring Alma Moreno, and Peter Pan de Sal (Peter the Bread of Salt), a takeoff from the popular Italian film Marcelino Pan y Vino (The Miracle of Marcelino), 1955, with NiñoMuhlach as the irrepressible tyke. On its second year, it produced Beerhouse, with CharitoSolis and Chanda Romero, followed by Disco Baby, with NoraAunor, Didith Reyes, and Rico J. Puno, and Sugar Daddy, with LuisGonzales and Alma Moreno. In 1978, Regal made a trilogy about cabaret girls with three directors—ElwoodPerez, Joey Gosiengfiao, and Danny Cabreira—directing Elizabeth Oropesa, Beth Bautista, and Alma Moreno in Iwasan … Kabaret (Avoid the Cabaret). In the same year, Regal produced films in various genres, such as romance in Mahal Mo, Mahal Ko (Your Love, My Love), with Nora Aunor, Tirso Cruz III, and Christopher de Leon; action in Boy Pana (Bow and Arrow Kid), with BembolRoco; comedy in Facundo Alitaftaf, starring Dolphy, and Starzan, starring Joey de Leon and ReneRequiestas; and bold in Bomba Star, starring Alma Moreno, and Disgrasyada (Fallen Woman), starring Rio Locsin.

In the years that followed, Regal’s output continued to grow. Some of these releases include Underage, 1980; Boystown, 1981; Anak (Child), 1982; I Love You … I Hate You, 1983; Shake, Rattle & Roll, 1984; Scorpio Nights, 1985; Kid, Huwag Kang Susuko! (Kid, Do Not Give Up!), 1987; Bobocop (Stupid Cop), 1988; Student Body, 1989; Dyesebel and Shake, Rattle & Roll II, 1990; Shake, Rattle & Roll III, 1991; Shake, Rattle & Roll IV, 1992; Kailangan Kita (I Need You), 1993; Shake, Rattle & Roll V, 1994; Batang X (Child X), 1995; Suicide Rangers, 1996; Shake, Rattle & Roll VI, 1997; Kahit Pader Gigibain Ko (I Will Break Down Even Walls), 1998; Markado (Marked), 1999; Huwag Mong Ubusin ang Bait Ko! (Don’t Wait for My Kindness to Run Out!), 2000; Yamashita: The Tiger’s Treasure, 2001; Pistolero (Gunman), 2002; Mano Po 2: My Home (I Kiss Your Hand 2: My Home), 2003; Sigaw (The Echo), 2004; Bahay ni Lola 2 (Grandma’s House 2), 2005; Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Moveeh (Zsazsa Zaturnnah: The Movie), 2006; The Promise, 2007; My Monster Mom, 2008; When I Met U, 2009; You to Me Are Everything, 2010; Yesterday Today Tomorrow, 2011; Boy Pick-Up: The Movie, 2012; Seduction, 2013; and Once a Princess, 2014. Regal’s latest film productions in 2015 include You’re Still the One, Resureksyon (Resurrection), The Prenup, No Boyfriend since Birth, and Haunted Mansion.

Since it started, it has been very successful as a prime movie producing and distributing outfit. In 1989, Regal produced 31 pictures or 26 percent of the total number of movies made in the Philippines for that year. It set the trend of lavish promotional campaigns, giving rise to criticism of excessive commercialism. To counter this unfavorable image, Regal produced some of the outstanding film classics of the 1980s. CityafterDark, 1980, won the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Screenplay, Best Production Design, and Best Actor, BernardoBernardo. BrokenMarriage, 1982, won the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Editing, Best Sound, and Best Actress for VilmaSantos. Relasyon (An Affair), 1982, received Best Actress awards for Vilma Santos from four award-giving bodies: Gawad Urian, Filipino AcademyofMovieArtsandSciences (FAMAS), Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), and Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA). SisterStellaL., 1984, won the FAP awards for Best Picture and Best Director, and the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Music, Best Editing, Best Sound, and acting awards for Vilma Santos, JayIlagan, TonySantos Sr, and LauriceGuillen. It also won the FAMAS Best Supporting actor award for Santos Sr. HinugotsaLangit (Wrenched from Heaven), 1985, received the Gawad Urian for Best Director, Best Production Design, and Best Editing and was chosen by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1980-89. Pahiram ng Isang Umaga (Lend Me One Morning), 1989, won the Gawad Urian for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Cinematography, and acting awards for Vilma Santos and EricQuizon. It was also cited by FAP for Best Sound. VirginForest, 1985, won the FAP awards for Best Production Design and Best Music Score. ScorpioNights, was cited by the Gawad Urian for Best Cinematography, Best Music, and Best Sound. Bilanginang BituinsaLangit (Count the Stars in the Sky), 1989, won eight FAMAS awards: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Production Design, Best Sound, Best Song, and acting awards for Nora Aunor and TirsoCruzIII. It also won the Gawad Urian for Best Actress, Best Music, and Best Production Design, and the FAP awards for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actress, Best Actor, Best Screenplay, and Best Production Design.

Throughout the years, Regal Films established film subsidiaries. One of these is MAQ Productions, which produced films such as Nasaan Ka Nang Kailangan Kita (Where Were You When I Needed You), 1996, Manananggal in Manila (Self-segmenting Ghoul in Manila), 1997, and Spirit Warriors, 2000, among many other productions. Another is Good Harvest Unlimited, established in 1998 by Mother Lily, which produced the “pito-pito” (literally, seven-seven) films supposed to be shot in seven days and edited in another seven, made on a budget ranging from 2.5 to 5 million pesos. Often criticized for low quality, the pito-pito still undeniably produced some important directors and films, including Jeffrey Jeturian with his Sana Pag-ibig Na (Enter Love) and Lav Diaz with his Serafin Geronimo: Kriminal ng Baryo Concepcion (The Criminal of Barrio Concepcion). Other divisions are Regal Home Video and Mother Studios Films.

Regal proudly showcases the “babies” it gave birth to for its movies, among them Maricel Soriano, Snooky Serna, Gabby Concepcion, William Martinez, Dina Bonnevie, Richard Gomez, Ruffa Gutierrez, Carmina Villarroel, Gretchen Barretto, Aiko Melendez, Marian Rivera, Dennis Trillo, Carla Abellana, Andi Eigenmann, and Richard Gutierrez.

Regal produced programs and TV series with two of the country’s major television networks. From the late 1980s to the 1990s, Regal produced for ABS-CBN at least 10 TV shows per week, such as Regal Drama Presents, Palibhasa Lalake (Because They Are Guys), and Maricel Drama Special. For GMA 7, Regal produced even more shows, such as Mother Studio Presents and Regal Shocker. Another subsidiary is Regal Multimedia, which is responsible for the execution of Regal’s bigger projects. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor, Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu, and Nicanor G. Tiongson

REMY, RONALD(Ronald Kookooritchin) b. ca 1935. d. 1990. Movie and television actor, director, producer. His father, Euremy Kookooritchin, was a member of the Russian navy who settled in Bicol. Remy married actor Lily Marquez, with whom he appeared in some movies. His daughter Jackie is a television host. He took up aeronautical engineering in the United States, but later shifted to communication arts. He sought to elevate the standards of TV programming and was a member of the board of trustees of the Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining.

Back in the late 1950s, Remy acted on TV, especially in the presentation of classic works by the Caltex Star Caravan. He hosted variety and game shows until the 1960s. Signing up as a Premiere Productions contract actor, he was introduced in Gerardo de Leon’s Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing for You), 1959. This was followed by second-lead appearances in Emmanuel Rojas’s Anak ng Bulkan (Child of the Volcano), 1959; Nemesio Caravana’s Prinsesa Naranja (Princess Naranja), Dan Santiago’s Akin ang Paghihiganti (Vengeance Is Mine), and Cirio H. Santiago’s Pagsapit ng Hatinggabi (When Midnight Comes), 1960; and Teodorico C. Santos’s Viva Caballeras (Long Live Lady Cavaliers), 1961. Remy himself directed 16 of the 72 movies he appeared in.

He produced about 20 movies for his own movie company, Medallion Films. He had two co-ventures with Universal Pictures: The Longest Hundred Miles, 1967, and Escape to Mindanao, 1968. Among his other films are Kadenang Putik (Chain of Mud) and Kalawang sa Bakal (Rust on Steel), 1960; Krusaldo and Dakilang Siyam (Great Nine), 1961; Bus to Bataan, 1962; Death Is a Stranger, 1963; Kulay Dugo ang Gabi (Blood Is the Color of Night), 1964; No Way Out, 1967; Mad Doctor of Blood Island, 1968; Infiltrators, 1969; and Ophelia & Paris (Ophelia and Paris), 1973.

The Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences nominated Remy as Best Supporting Actor three times: for Ang Maton (The Tough Guy), 1959; Lakas sa Lakas (Strength against Strength), 1962; and Zigzag, 1963. Written by Malou M. Maniquis and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

REVILLA, RAMON(Jose Acuña Bautista) aka Jose Yandoc, Gallardo Acuña. b. Imus, Cavite 8 Mar 1927. Movie actor, director, producer. His parents are Andrea Acuña and Ildefonso Bautista. Daughter Princess Revilla and son Ramon aka Bong Revilla are actors. Another son, Marlon Bautista, is a movie director. Revilla attended grade school at Imus Elementary School and finished high school at Imus Institute. He took up a course in commerce at Far Eastern University. In 1992 he was elected senator of the Republic of the Philippines. He was reelected in 1998 and ended his term in 2004.

Revilla started his movie career in Yolanda and Pulo ng Engkanto (Enchanted Island), 1951, and Tatlong Bagwis (Three Wings), 1952, using the screen name of Gallardo Acuña. When he became a contract star of SampaguitaPictures, Dr Jose R. Perez changed his screen name to RamonRevilla. He was introduced together with singer-actor SylviaLaTorre in the war drama Ulila ng Bataan (Bataan Orphan), 1952, starring TessieAgana. In his next film, Cofradia, 1953, he was Gloria Romero’s leading man. They appeared together in light romantic dramas and comedies like Mister Kasintahan (Mr Lover) and Recuerdo (Remembrance), 1953; Anak sa Panalangin (Child of Prayer) and Kurdapya (Screwball), 1954; and Bim Bam Bum, 1955.

Revilla worked at the Manila Customs from 1962 to 1968 and then made a successful comeback in Liku-likong Landas (Crooked Path), 1968, with Gloria Romero, LuisGonzales, and RitaGomez. He put up his own film company, Cavite Pictures, which he later changed to Imus Productions. His first picture as a movie producer is Nardong Putik, 1971, a film bio about Cavite’s most notorious “Robin Hood” bandit. It was directed by the late Tony Cayado and scored phenomenally at the box office.

As movie director, Revilla used the pseudonym Jose Yandoc. Most of the movies he directed, with himself in the starring role as Ramon Revilla, are film bios of real-life characters from his home province of Cavite. Among his films are Kapitan Eddie Set: Mad Killer of Cavite (Captain Eddie Set), 1974; Bergado: Terror of Cavite, 1976; Gulapa: Ang Barakong Mayor ng Maragondon (Gulapa: The Macho Mayor of Maragondon) and Bianong Bulag: One-Eyed Terror of Cavite (Biano the Blind Man), 1977; and Boy Imus: Anak ni Tiagong Akyat (Boy Imus: Son of Tiagong Akyat), 1978. His name became synonymous with the anting-anting (amulet) identified with Pepeng Agimat, Nardong Putik, Tiagong Akyat, Bianong Bulag, Gulapa, Kapitan Eddie Set, and other characters from his films, real or fictional. His other films include Cordillera, 1986; Ang Mahiwagang Daigdig ni Elias Paniki (The Mysterious World of Elias the Bat) and Bala, Dapat kay Cris Cuenca: Public Enemy No. 1 (A Bullet for Cris Cuenca: Public Enemy No 1), 1989; Apo: Kingpin ng Maynila (Apo: Manila’s Kingpin), David Balondo ng Tondo (David Balondo of Tondo), and Target Police General: Major General Alfredo Lim Story, 1990; Pepeng Agimat (Pepe the Amulet), 1999; Ang Agimat: Anting-anting ni Lolo (The Talisman: Grandfather’s Amulet), 2002; and Exodus: Tales from the Enchanted Kingdom, 2005. Some of his major films were adapted by ABS-CBN into a television series titled Agimat: Ang mga Alamat ni Ramon Revilla (Amulet: The Legends of Ramon Revilla), 2009-11.

Revilla received the Best Actor award from the FilipinoAcademyofMovieArts andSciences for Hulihin si Tiagong Akyat (Get Tiagong Akyat), 1973. He was given a Lifetime Achievement Award by the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 2011. Written by Galileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mesandel Arguelles
(See LITERATURE volume.)

REYES, EFREN (Efren Ongpin Reyes) b. Manila 18 Jun 1924. d. Manila 11 Feb 1968. Movie actor, director, producer. His parents are Pedrito Reyes, fictionist, and Luisa Ongpin. He is the brother of actor Johnny Reyes and the grandson of the famous sarsuwelista, Severino Reyes. He was married to Primitiva Reyes with whom he had three children. He had another actor-son, Efren Reyes Jr, by actor Virginia Montes.

Reyes was studying at Arellano High School in Manila when director Gregorio Fernandez discovered him and gave him a bit part in LVN Pictures’ Garrison 13, 1946, and Manugang at Biyenan (The In-Laws), 1948. He was introduced in Consuelo P. Osorio’s Bulalakaw (Shooting Star), 1948. He went on to star in action movies like Halik sa Bandila (A Kiss to the Flag) and Hindi Ako Susuko (I Will Not Surrender), 1948; Kumander Sundang (Commander Bolo), 1949; Wanted: Patay o Buhay (Wanted: Dead or Alive) and Bandido (Outlaw), 1950; and Kapitan Berong (Captain Berong), 1953. In Carlos Trece, 1953, at Premiere Productions, he displayed his fencing skill. He also starred in films based on metrical romances, such as Prinsipe Don Juan (Prince Don Juan), 1950, and Prinsipe Alejandre at Don Luis (Prince Alejandre and Don Luis), 1957. He was well-loved as the folk hero in Pedro Penduko, 1954.

Later, he directed some of his own films including Sa Ngalan ng Espada (In the Name of the Sword), 1958, Mabilis Pa sa Lintik (Faster Than Lightning), 1959, and Basta Pinoy (The Filipino Character), 1960.

In 1952 he organized the Efren Reyes Productions. The first film he wrote and directed was Larawan ng Buhay (Portrait of Life), 1952, in which he also acted together with Virginia Montes. His next film was Lola Basyang (Grandmother Basyang), 1953, based on a series of folk narratives written by his grandfather and published in Liwayway magazine. The screenplay was written by his father Pedrito, and Reyes himself acted in the film. His pictures were made at Premiere Studios.

Reyes won the Asian Film Festival Best Actor award for his role of a tribesman in Ifugao, 1954, and was adjudged Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Actor for Kadenang Putik (Chain of Mud), 1960. In the FAMAS, he was nominated as Best Actor for Ang Maton (The Tough Guy), 1959, and as Best Director for Albano Brothers, 1962, and Sigaw ng Digmaan (War Cry), 1963. Written by Joy Galvez

REYES, ELVIRA (Gloria Tan Madison) b. Manila 24 Aug 1926. d. 7 Mar 1982. Movie actor. Her parents are Felisa Villamor Tan and John Jorge Madison. Her studies were interrupted by World War II, but she was able to finish high school.

After the war, she joined LVN Pictures and was introduced in its very first post-World War II movie, Orasang Ginto (Golden Clock), 1946, directed by Manuel Conde and starring Mila del Sol and Bimbo Danao. Her other early films with LVN are Alaala Kita (Thinking of You), 1946, where she and Fidel de Castro were featured players, and the Rogelio de la Rosa starrer Principeng Hindi Tumatawa (The Prince Who Does Not Laugh), 1946, where she played second lead to another new star, Erlinda Cortes. Her first starring role was in Nabasag ang Banga (The Claypot Broke), 1946.

Reyes was known for her films with Manuel Conde, notably his costume movies and the Juan Tamad series. When Conde put up Manuel Conde Productions in 1947, he chose her as his leading lady in such films as Si Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), 1947; Juan Daldal (Talkative Juan), 1947; Principe Paris (Prince Paris), 1949; Siete Infantes de Lara (Seven Devils), 1950; and Genghis Khan, 1950.

Reyes also made pictures with another major studio, Lebran International. Among her Lebran movies are Tatlong Patak ng Luha (Three Drops of Tears), 1951, as leading lady to Leopoldo Salcedo under the direction of Lorenzo P. Tuells; Kalbaryo ni Hesus (The Calvary of Jesus), 1952, directed by Carlos Vander Tolosa; and Sigfredo, 1951, written and directed by, and starring Manuel Conde, where she portrayed his leading lady.

After her stint with Lebran, Reyes moved on to Royal Productions where she appeared as Rosa del Rosario’s nemesis in Darna at ang Babaing Lawin (Darna and the Hawkwoman), 1952. She was active in the movies until the late 1950s when she decided to reside in the United States. Written byNenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja

REYES, EMMANUEL aka Manny Reyes b. Manila 20 Jan 1960. Filmmaker, essayist, photographer. His parents are Epifanio Reyes and Ester Anastacio. He obtained his bachelor of arts degrees, major in communication arts and major in marketing management, at the De La Salle University (DLSU) in 1980 and 1981, respectively, and his master of arts degree in film at Ohio University in Athens, Ohio, USA, in 1983. He taught film and photography at DLSU, 1983-91, and was chair of DLSU’s Communication Arts Department, 1984-89. He wrote and directed corporate videos and commercials for Media Plus, Inc. He joined the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino (MPP) in 1984 and became its chair from 1987 to 1989.

Reyes has done film and video projects, including VicSilayan: An Actor Remembers, 1985, and Dreaming Filipinos, 1990, a 16-mm color feature he wrote, directed, co-edited, and co-produced. He exhibited his color photographs, under the title Berlin Pictures, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines and the Goethe-Institut in 1989.

Reyes has written numerous essays and reviews on film for such national newspapers as the Malaya, Manila Times, and Tempo. In 1989 he published his book, NotesonPhilippineCinema.

His film Dreaming Filipinos was entered in several international film festivals and won an Urian award for Best Short Film in 1991 from the MPP and the grand prix at the ASEAN Young Cinema Festival in Tokyo, Japan, in 1992. It was also screened at the Guggenheim Museum in New York City in 1999 and has been acquired by Harvard University for its video collection. In 1994, he wrote and directed a feature film, Suwapings (The Greedy Ones), a satire on Philippine politics, which starred Lou Veloso, Noel Trinidad, and Nanette Inventor. It was shown at the Berlin and Tokyo Film Festivals in 1995. Reyes is into painting. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Elmer L. Gatchalian

REYES, JOSE JAVIER aka Joey Reyes. b. Manila 21 Oct 1954. Movie and television writer, director, and line producer. He is the son of Marciano Reyes Sr and Belen Javier and uncle of movie-television director Mark A. Reyes VI. He finished elementary and high school at Letran College. He earned his bachelor’s degree in liberal arts, with honors, from De La Salle University (DLSU). He took up courses in Indiana University, USA, for advanced studies in folklore and comparative literature. He is a consultant to the School of Design and Arts of De La Salle College of Saint Benilde. He also teaches communication arts courses at DLSU.

Reyes won prizes for his plays Dingas sa Langit (Fire in Heaven), second prize, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Playwriting Contest, 1982; Lamat (Crack), second prize, Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, 1983; and Butong Pakwan (Watermelon Seeds), first prize, CCP Playwriting Contest, 1983. He wrote the libretto for the musical Katy, with music by Ryan Cayabyab. He also wrote the lyrics of the song “Iisa Pa Lamang” (One and Only), with music by Danny Tan, and sung by Joey Albert, as well as the popular Christmas song “Kumukutikutitap” (Sparkling Lights) with music by Cayabyab and also sung by Albert.

Reyes’s screenplays account for 17 of his 32 awards, including Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982, Asia Pacific Film Festival; Pahiram ng Isang Umaga (Lend Me One Morning), 1989, Gawad Urian; My Other Woman, 1990, Catholic Mass Media Awards; Dinampot Ka Lang sa Putik (You’re Just Picked Up from the Mud), 1991, Young Critics Circle (YCC); Iisa Pa Lamang , 1992, YCC; Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin (You Are Everything to Me), 1992, Star Awards; May Minamahal (Loving Someone), 1993, Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF); Makati Avenue (Office Girls), 1993, Gawad Urian; Hindi Kita Malilimutan (I Will Never Forget You), 1993, YCC; Batang PX (Phil-American Boy), 1997, YCC; Minsan May Isang Puso (Once There Was a Heart), 2001, YCC; and Mga Mumunting Lihim (Those Little Secrets), 2012, Cinemalaya.

Reyes won awards for directing May Minamahal, MMFF; Makati Avenue (Office Girls), Gawad Urian; and Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo (Partner, Participant, Partaker), 2006, Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, Film Academy of the Philippines, and Star Awards for Movies. In 2014, the Star Awards for Movies honored him as Direktor ng Dekada (Director of the Decade) for 2003-13.

In 2000, Reyes found himself a new niche as a line producer for his two production companies: Available Light, formed with Manny Castañeda and Don Escudero, which caters to big commercial studios; and LargaVista Entertainment Corporation, which caters to smaller independent production companies. One of the popular and controversial films he line-produced is Live Show, 2000, which he also wrote and directed.

Reyes is also known for having created “Doña Buding,” TV’s wacky social-climbing character popularized by Nanette Inventor in the 1980s. He wrote the television serials Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Watch for the Next Chapter), 1991-97; Attagirl, 2001; Bora: Sons of the Beach, 2005; and Madam Chairman, 2013. He also wrote for Pira-pirasong Pangarap (Broken Dreams), Barberya Siete (Barber Shop No 7), Palibhasa Lalake (Because They Are Guys), Eh Kasi Babae (Because They Are Women), and The Bud Brothers Series.

Reyes directed television shows like Tropang Trumpo (Spintop Troop), 1992; Whattamen, 2001; Hanggang Kailan (Circle of Hearts), 2004; and George and Cecil, 2009.

In 2008, Reyes also appeared as media performance mentor in the reality TV talent search Pinoy Dream Academy. He is also Inside Showbiz Magazine’s editor in chief. Written by Rosalinda Galang and Camilo Villanueva Jr, with notes from Clodualdo del Mundo Jr

REYES, LUIS b. Manila 9 Nov 1923. d. 21 Feb 1991. Movie sound engineer. He married Victoria Arevalo, with whom he had seven children, one of whom, Ramon Reyes, was also a sound engineer of local movies. He started in LVN Pictures in 1947. A pioneer in sound engineering, he learned the craft on his own and taught the trade to others. Many sound technicians trained under him. He stayed at LVN for 38 years until 1985.

From 1960 to 1977, while he was at LVN, Reyes did the sound recording for about 30 pictures a year. Some of the notable films in Philippine cinema that Reyes worked on are Mutya ng Pasig (Muse of Pasig), 1950; A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965; Jaguar (Guard), 1979; and Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982.

He won Best Sound from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1962, one of his favorite films. He also received two Gawad Urian Best Sound trophies for Itim (Rites of May), 1976, and Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (When You Dream and Wake Up), 1977, which he did with son Ramon. Written byRaquel Hernandez, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

REYES, RAMON(Ramon Arevalo Reyes) aka Monching. b. Manila 26 Jan 1946. Movie sound engineer. His parents are Victoria Arevalo and Luis Reyes, who also worked in the sound department of LVN Pictures. He studied at Immaculate Heart of Mary College, San Sebastian College, and Don Bosco Technical Institute. He took up electronics and communications at the University of the East, up to third year. He married Virginia Alvarez with whom he had three children.

Reyes’s first film job was with Smith Sound Systems owned by film sound pioneer William Smith. From 1972 to 1988, he was LVN’s sound mixer. Director Gerardo de Leon gave him his first full-movie assignment in Tatlong Kasaysayan ng Pag-ibig (Three Love Stories), 1966. He also did movies like Exploitation, Strangers in Paradise, and Commandos, 1983; Once upon a Time, 1987; Nagsimula sa Puso (Obsession), 1990; Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1993; Abot-Kamay ang Pangarap (Elena’s Redemption), 1996; Bulaklak ng Maynila (Flower of Manila), 1999; Mga Batang Lansangan Ngayon (Street Children Now), 2002; Sabel, 2004; and Ang Lihim ni Kurdapya (Kurdapya’s Secret), 2008.

Reyes’s achievements include six Gawad Urian for Best Sound Recording in Itim (Rites of May), 1976; Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (When You Dream and Wake Up), 1977; Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (Will Your Heart Beat Faster?), 1980; Kisapmata (In the Blink of an Eye), 1981; Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982; and Sister Stella L., 1984. He received Best Sound awards from the Star Awards for Once upon a Time, 1987; from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975, Itim, and Kisapmata; and from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Kisapmata. He won the first Film Academy of the Philippines award for sound for Oro, Plata, Mata in 1983. Written byRosalie Matilac, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

REYES, VER(Virgilio Putungan Reyes) b. San Juan, Metro Manila 9 Jan 1942. Cinematographer. Born to Benjamin Reyes, a musician, and Consolacion Putungan, he studied commerce at Foundation College in Santa Ana, Manila. He has three children with his wife, Virginia.

Reyes did not finish his studies and instead joined the apprentice crew at Tagalog Ilang-Ilang Productions, studying for seven years under cameraman Ben Lobo. In 1974, he got his first assignment as cinematographer for Pagbabalik ni Dimasalang (The Return of Dimasalang) of Junar Films. In 1979, he was taken in by FPJ Productions and worked on about a dozen pictures for the company. Reyes worked for Fernando Poe Jr exclusively.

Reyes got four Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Cinematography awards to his name: for Pagbabalik ng Panday (Return of the Blacksmith), 1981; Ang Panday … Ikatlong Yugto (The Blacksmith … Third Chapter), 1982; Muslim Magnum .357, 1986; and Kahit Butas ng Karayom (Even the Eye of the Needle), 1995. He also received the Metro Manila Film Festival Best Cinematography award for Pagbabalik ng Panday, 1981. Written by Raquel Hernandez, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

RIVERO, DANTE(Louisito Ramos Mayer Jr) b. Floridablanca, Pampanga 5 Aug 1946. Movie actor. Born to Louis Mayer Sr, a United States Navy man, and Paciencia Ramos, he studied at Floridablanca Elementary School, St Augustine Academy, and the Philippine College of Criminology. He is married to Ma. Theresa Inopea, with whom he has three children.

Among Rivero’s films are The Gold Bikini, 1968; Wanted: Perfect Mother, 1969; Crush Ko si Sir (I’ve Got a Crush on Sir), 1971; Ang Gangster at ang Birhen (The Gangster and the Virgin), Villa Miranda, Cherry Blossoms, and Adbenturero (Adventurer), 1972; Lupang Hinirang (Beloved Land), 1973; Patayin Mo sa Sindak si Barbara (Kill Barbara with Fright), 1974; Sagisag ng Katapangan (Symbol of Valor), 1976; Kapitana Ester (Captain Ester), 1977; Andrea, 1978; Dalaga (Young Lady) and Anak ng Atsay (Housemaid’s Daughter), 1979. Years later, he starred in Kailan Mahuhugasan ang Kasalanan? (When Will the Sin Be Washed Away?), 1989; Milagros, 1997; Azucena, 2000; Tuhog (Larger Than Life), 2001; and A Love Story, 2007.

On television, Rivero appeared in some episodes of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 1993-2012; Wansapanataym (Once upon a Time), 2011-13; and Magpakailanman (Forever), 2012-14. His other television appearances include GMA Network’s Sana Ngayong Pasko (A Christmas Wish), 2009-10, Adarna, 2013-14, and Niño (Boy), 2014; and ABS-CBN’s Muling Buksan ang Puso (Open the Heart Once Again), 2013, and Nathaniel, 2015. He appeared in the television series Esperanza, 1997-99, and reprised his role in its spin-off Esperanza: The Movie, 1999.

Rivero received Best Supporting Actor awards for Sa Dibdib ng Sierra Madre (In the Bosom of Sierra Madre), 1985, from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 1986; for Natutulog Ba ang Diyos (Is God Sleeping), 1988, from the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 1989; for Tuhog from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) in 2002; and for A Love Story from FAP in 2008. He earned FAMAS Best Actor nominations for Adriana in 1970, Wanted: Perfect Mother in 1971, Villa Miranda in 1973, Lumapit … Lumayo ang Umaga (Morning Comes and Goes) in 1976, and Azucena in 2001. His performance as Alejandro in 1st Ko si 3rd (Third Is My First), 2014, won him Best Actor in the 2014 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Erika Carreon

ROBLES, RUDY (Pastor Lluviosa Robles) b. Tacloban, Leyte 28 Apr 1908. d. 4 Jul 1970. Movie actor. His parents are Magdalena Lluviosa and Alfonso Robles. He attended school at Colegio de San Carlos in Cebu City and finished secondary education at Galileo High School in San Francisco, California. He enrolled in dramatics at the Pasadena Junior College, took courses in speech and drama at the Los Angeles City College, won medals in forensics and oratory, and was in the Pacific Coast Debating Championships of 1939. After he began acting, he trained further at Ben Bard’s Drama School and the Maria Ospikaya School in Los Angeles. He earned a bachelor’s degree in communications at the University of Southern California. During the war, he was an army captain. He returned to the Philippines after the war, married Leonarda Roxas of Bulacan, with whom he had a son, and settled down in Cebu as an entrepreneur.

Robles was working as a bellhop at the Beverly Hills Hotel in Hollywood when he was reported to have been “discovered” by Samuel Goldwyn himself, who gave him his screen name of Rudy Robles. He appeared in Hollywood films like The Real Glory, 1939, with Gary Cooper and David Niven; Adventures of Martin Eden, 1942, with Glenn Ford; Singapore, 1947, with Ava Gardner and Fred McMurray; and Okinawa, 1952, with Pat O’Brien and Richard Denning. He also appeared in television shows, among them Passport to Danger, Soldier of Fortune, and Alfred Hitchcock Presents. He was a member of the Screen Actors Guild of Hollywood and was listed in the International Film Almanac of New York.

After his return to the Philippines, Robles organized his own production company, Rudy Robles Productions. He produced, directed, and starred in films like Princesa sa Tawi-Tawi (Princess in Tawi-Tawi), Damgo ni Adan (Adam’s Dream), Ang Bahay sa Bundok (The House on the Mountain), Kanlaon, and Talahib (Wild Sugarcane). Written by Erlinda K. Alburo

ROCES, ROSANNA(Jennifer Cruz Adriano) b. Manila 25 May 1972. Movie and television actor. Roces, fondly nicknamed Osang, has German-Jewish ancestry. She has two children, Grace Adriano and Onyok Roces. Roces is also grandmother to Jose Gabriel Bautista, Grace’s son with Jolo Revilla (son of Ramon “Bong” Revilla Jr and Lani Mercado), and Maja Adriano Amir, Grace’s daughter with Arab national Filly Amir.

Roces was introduced by Seiko Films in 1994 as Ana Maceda in Celso Ad. Castillo’s Comfort Women: A Cry for Justice. In the same year, she also appeared in Mauro Gia Samonte’s Machete II. In 1995, she changed her screen name to Rosanna Roces and was launched as the lead in two movies: with Jestoni Alarcon in Di Mapigil ang Init (Can’t Stop the Heat), 1995, and with Gardo Versoza in Kandungan (Lap), 1995. She followed this up with Patikim ng Pinya (Let Me Taste the Pineapple), 1996, an adult comedy co-starring Leandro Baldemor. Patikim ng Pinya established Roces as Seiko Films’ most popular female sexy actor. After doing Mga Nagbabagang Labi (Fiery Lips), 1996, again with Jestoni Alarcon, Roces renegotiated her exclusive contract with Seiko into a non-exclusive contract that allowed her to work for other movie companies.

The year 1997 was a busy one for Roces as her career began to peak. First, she starred with Ramon “Bong” Revilla Jr and his wife Lani Mercado in Regal Films’ action-comedy Yes, Darling: Walang Matigas na Pulis 2 (Yes, Darling: There Is No Tough Cop 2), 1997. Then she co-starred with Cesar Montano in Pusakal (Hardened Criminal), 1997. She also did two more soft-core movies: with Emilio Garcia in Selosa (Jealous Woman), 1997, and with Anton Bernardo in Nang Mamulat si Eba Part 2 (Eve’s Awakening Part 2), 1997. But the highlight of her year is when she starred in esteemed director Carlos Siguion-Reyna’s Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin (They Call Me Joy), 1997, and Ang Lalaki sa Buhay ni Selya (The Man in Her Life), 1997. These two controversial yet critically acclaimed movies signalled Roces’s transformation into a serious dramatic actor.

The following year, Roces worked with other respected directors. She starred in Chito S. Roño’s Curacha: Ang Babaeng Walang Pahinga (Curacha: The Woman without Rest), 1998. Then she played the lead in Romy Suzara’s Cariño Brutal (Brutal Love), 1998, and Ginto’t Pilak (Gold and Silver), 1998. She also went back to her sexy roots in Mel Chionglo’s Mapusok (Passionate), 1998, with Emilio Garcia and Julio Diaz. Finally, Roces ended another busy year working again with Chito S. Roño in Babae sa Bintana (Woman by the Window), 1998.

After 1998, Roces appeared in several lackluster movies. She starred opposite Christopher de Leon in Abbo de la Cruz’s romance-thriller Katawan (Body), 1999. Then she went back to doing sexy comedies, first in Enrico S. Quizon’s Ms. Kristina Moran: Ang Babaeng Palaban (Ms Kristina Moran: Feisty Woman), 1999, with Albert Martinez, and then in Tony Y. Reyes’s Basta’t Ikaw … Nanginginig Pa! (Totally Yours … and Shivering!), 1999, with comedian Vic Sotto.

Roces returned with a vengeance in 2001 when she co-starred with Diether Ocampo in Chito S. Roño’s La Vida Rosa (The Life of Rosa). It won awards at the 2002 Gawad Urian for Screenplay, Editing, and Best Actress for Roces.

Roces also ventured into television. She first appeared in GMA Network’s sitcom Da Boy and Da Girl (The Boy and the Girl), 2002, opposite action star Rudy Fernandez. She also co-hosted Startalk, GMA’s popular showbiz-oriented program. This ended when she got into a very public feud with her co-host Lolit Solis (who is also her talent manager). She then transferred to rival network ABS-CBN and played supporting roles in soap operas such as Ysabella, 2007, May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), 2009, and Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009.

In recent years, Roces appeared in several indie productions, most notably in Ray Gibraltar’s Wanted: Border, 2009, for which she won a Best Actress award at the Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival; in Adolfo Alix Jr’s Haruo (Springtime Man), 2011, Mater Dolorosa (Sorrowful Mother), 2013, and Porno, 2013; and in Joel Lamangan’s Hustisya (Justice), 2014. Written by Elvin Valerio

ROCES, SUSAN(Jesusa Purificacion Levy Sonora) b. Pasay City 28 Jul 1941. Movie actor and producer. Her parents are Purificacion Levy and Dr Jesus Sonora. She studied at La Consolacion College in Bacolod City. In 1968 she married actor Fernando Poe Jr. They have a daughter, Mary Grace, a politician. Roces is sister to actor Rosemarie Sonora, sister-in-law to actor Ricky Belmonte, and aunt to actor Sheryl Cruz.

At age nine, Roces appeared in her first movie, Mga Bituin ng Kinabukasan (Stars of Tomorrow), 1952. She played the title role in Boksingera (Woman Boxer), 1956, sharing star billing with Luis Gonzales and Dolphy. She became known for her refreshing beauty and sweet personality in such films as Princesa Gusgusin (Shabby Princess), Sino ang Maysala? (Who Is Guilty?), and Mga Anak ng Diyos (Children of God), 1957; Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), 1958; and Debutante (Debutant), 1959. She became very popular as a lovable screwball in films like Torkwata, 1957; Susanang Daldal (Susan the Chatterbox), Susanang Twist (Susan the Twister), and Susan, Susay, Susy, 1962; and Amaliang Mali-Mali versus Susanang Daldal (Amalia the Blunderer versus Susan the Chatterbox), 1963. In most of her films she was paired with Romeo Vasquez.

When her contract with Sampaguita was over, she put up her own company, Rosas Productions. At the same time, she freelanced with FPJ, Lea, Regal, and other film companies. She appeared as the romantic partner of Fernando Poe Jr in Ang Daigdig Ko’y Ikaw (You Are My World), 1965; Zamboanga, 1966; Perlas ng Silangan (Pearl of the Orient), 1969; and Mahal … Saan Ka Nanggaling Kagabi (Honey … Where Were You Last Night?), 1979. She made horror films like Maruja, 1967, and Patayin Mo sa Sindak si Barbara (Kill Barbara with Fright), 1974. She was also active in industry affairs. The Experimental Cinema of the Philippines chose her to co-administer the Film Fund with Emilia Blas from 1984 to 1986.

Roces appeared in several TV series, including GMA Network’s Sana Ngayong Pasko (Hopefully This Christmas) and ABS-CBN’s John en Shirley (John and Shirley), 2006; Iisa Pa Lamang (Just One), 2008; 100 Days to Heaven, 2011; Walang Hanggan (My Eternal), 2012; Muling Buksan ang Puso (Open the Heart Once More), 2013; Sana Bukas Pa ang Kahapon (Hoping Yesterday Was Tomorrow), 2014; and FPJ’s Ang Probinsyano (FPJ’s The Country Boy), 2015.

Roces won Best Actress awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Maligno (Evil Spirit), 1977, and for Gumising Ka … Maruja (Wake Up … Maruja), 1978. She received the 1959 Dr Ciriaco Santiago Memorial Award for successfully promoting the Philippines as ambassador of goodwill at San Francisco Pacific Festival. The legacy of Roces as an actor in Philippine cinema was duly recognized in 2003 when the Film Academy of the Philippines conferred on her a Lifetime Achievement Award. In 2009 she received the Cinema One Legend Award from the Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival. Written by Galileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

ROCHA, EDUARDO (Eduardo Algredo Perez Rocha) aka E. A. Rocha. b. Manila 11 May 1951. Movie actor, scriptwriter, and producer. He is the son of Antonio Venancio Carlotta Rocha and Carmen Garchitorena Perez. He is married to Ana Maria Llamas Trillo. He finished high school at St. Mary’s College and later on graduated from Santa Clara University in California, 1973, with a bachelor of arts degree. His daughter Xandra is a television program host.

Rocha started his career in theater as actor and director, but he is better known for his work in film. His film career began with his performance as Padre Gil Corcuera in Eddie Romero’s Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?), 1976, for which he earned a Gawad Urian Best Supporting Actor nomination. He also had a role in Peque Gallaga’s Virgin Forest, 1985, and in the fantasy movie Once upon a Time, 1987, as Panginoong Bangurngor. He played the role of Padre Balaguer in Mike de Leon’s Bayaning 3rd World (Third World Hero).

Rocha produced award-winning films. He is the executive producer of K’na the Dreamweaver and English Only, Please, 2014; and the producer of Bonifacio: Ang Unang Pangulo (Bonifacio: The First President), 2014. He also wrote, with Henry Francia, Whirlwinds of Dust: The Fall of Antonio Luna, which won third place in the Film Development Council of the Philippines scriptwriting competition in 2010. Later, he also wrote with Francia and the film’s director Jerrold Tarog, as well as produced, the screen adaptation of Heneral Luna (General Luna), 2015.
