Rocha is the current vice president (since 2013) of the independent film company Artikulo Uno Productions and the president of Buchi Boy Films. Written byAnne Frances Sangil

ROCO, BEMBOL (Rafael Aranda Roco Jr) b. Manila 20 Nov 1953. Movie, stage, and television actor. His parents are Rafael Roco Sr and Thelma Aranda. He is married to Ana Maria Josefina Artadi with whom he has five children: Rafael III, Catherine, Louis, and the twins Dominic and Felix who are both actors.

One of LinoBrocka’s protégés, Roco was introduced in Tatlo,Dalawa,Isa (Three, Two, One), 1974. His debut appearance was followed by Brocka’s Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975, and Lunes, Martes, Miyerkules, Huwebes, Biyernes, Sabado, Linggo (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday), 1976; Behn Cervantes’s Sakada (Seasonal Cane Workers) and Mario O’Hara’s Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos (Three Godless Years), 1976; Boy Pana (Bow and Arrow Kid) and PagputingUwak,Pag-itimngTagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Hero Turns Black), 1978; Terror ng Tondo (Terror of Tondo), 1979; Ang Leon, ang Tigre at ang Alamid (The Lion, the Tiger, and the Wildcat), 1979; Kid Kaliwete (Left-Handed Kid), 1978; and Boy Kodyak, 1979. In the 1980s, his films include Peter Weir’s The Year of Living Dangerously, 1982; ’Merika (America), 1984; Orapronobis (Fight for Us) and Babangon Ako’t Dudurugin Kita (I Will Rise and Crush You), 1989. His later films include Gumapang Ka sa Lusak (Dirty Affair), 1990, and Wating (Street-smart), 1994. Roco has acted in notable independent films, like Auraeus Solito’s Tuli (Circumcision), 2005; Adolf Alix Jr’s Donsol, 2006, and Isda (Fable of the Fish), 2011; John Sayle’s Amigo (Friend), 2010; Brillante Mendoza’s Thy Womb, 2012; Ida del Mundo’s K’na the Dreamweaver, 2014; and John Paul Su’s Toto, 2015.

On stage, Roco performed for the Philippine Education Theater Association’s HanggangDitonaLamangatMaramingSalamat (This Is as Far as We Go, and Many Thanks), 1975; Lihis (Bent), 1976; Walang Kamatayang Buhay ni Juan de la Cruz Alyas … (The Eternal Life of Juan de la Cruz Alias …), 1976; MgaAma,MgaAnak (Three Generations), 1977. His later stage appearances include Titus Andronicus for Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas, 2011; and Noli at Fili Dekada 2000 (Noli and Fili in the Decade of the 2000s), 2008, and Arbol de Fuego (Cherry Orchard) for PETA, 2015.

On television, his work includes Raymond Red’s Kamada (State of Being), 1997; Beauty Queen, 2010; Sisid (Plunge), 2011; Ikaw ay Pag-ibig (You Are Love), 2011-12; One True Love, Wansapanataym (Once upon a Time), and Sa Ngalan ng Ina (In the Name of the Mother), 2012; May Isang Pangarap (There’s One Wish), Bayan Ko (My Country), Muling Buksan ang Puso (Open the Heart Once Again), Pyra: Ang Babaeng Apoy (Pyra: The Fire Lady), and Genesis, 2013; episodes in Magpakailanman (Forever), 2013-14, and Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 1995-2014; and Dyesebel, 2014.

Roco received the 1976 Filipino Academyof Movie ArtsandSciences Best Actor award for his performance in Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag. His laudable acting in Sa Piling ng mga Sugapa (In the Company of Addicts) won him the 1978 Gawad Urian Best Actor award. He also won Best Actor for Isda in the 2011 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. Written by Romulo P. Baquiran Jr, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

RODRIGO, RIC(Albert Paul Gozalvez Bregendahl) b. Manila 24 May 1924. Movie actor. His parents are Paul Albert Bregendahl of Copenhagen and Maria Luisa Gozalvez, a Spanish mestiza. He was married to movie actor Rita Gomez, with whom he had two children. Son Ronald Bregendahl was also a movie actor. He had another child by his second wife, Remedios Perez. He finished elementary and high school at Colegio de San Juan de Letran. He studied automotive mechanics in Santa Monica, California, USA, and managed a gasoline station, before he was drafted in the United States Army Engineering Corps. Coming back to the Philippines in 1950, he took up commerce at the Philippine College of Commerce and Business Administration for two years. He worked as production manager for American Biscuit Company before becoming an actor.

Rodrigo was discovered by Don Rafael Anton whose wife was a friend of his mother. He was cast in Lebran’s Song of Sto. Tomas, 1950, using the screen name Ricardo Montes, which was changed to Ricardo Rodrigo in his first picture under SampaguitaPictures, Reyna Bandida (Queen Bandit), 1953, opposite Gomez. He was introduced as RicRodrigo in Inspirasyon (Inspiration), 1953, with Carmen Rosales, and became a full-fledged star in Pilya (Naughty Girl), 1954, opposite Gloria Romero. Other films he made with GloriaRomero are Dalagang Ilocana (Ilocano Maiden), 1954; Kurdapya (Screwball) and Hindi Basta-Basta (Not an Ordinary Person), 1955; Miss Tilapia, 1956; and Beloved, 1958. His films with Rita Gomez include Señorita de Campanilla (Lady of the Manor), 1956, and Diosa (Goddess), 1957. With LolitaRodriguez he made Rosana, 1955; Emma, 1956; and Gabi at Araw (Night and Day), 1957. He was a mainstay in the TV program Padre de Familia (Head of the Family), which was made into a movie by Layno Productions in 1972. His later films include Gemma: Babaeng Kidlat (Gemma: Lightning Woman) and Kapitan Eddie Set: Mad Killer of Cavite (Captain Eddie Set), 1974; Iwasan: Alak, Babae at Sugal (Avoid: Alcohol, Women and Gambling), 1977; Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Mother, Sister, Daughter), 1979; Pag-ibig Ko, Hatiin Ninyo (Share My Love), 1980; Exploitation, Hula (Prediction), and Don’t Cry for Me, Papa, 1983; and Miguelito: Batang Rebelde (Miguelito: Young Rebel), 1985.

The National Press Club gave him the Box Office Popularity Award in 1965. He earned a Gawad Urian nomination for Best Supporting Actor for the LinoBrocka film Ina, Kapatid, Anak in 1980. He was named Asia’s Best Actor for his role in Nepomuceno Productions’ Igorota (Mountain Maiden), 1969, opposite CharitoSolis. He was accorded the Doña Narcisa Buencamino vda de Leon Memorial Award in 1969. Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Pamela Mathiel Lopez

RODRIGUEZ, CELIA(Cecilia Rodriguez) b. Sorsogon, Sorsogon 2 Jun 1939. Film and television actor. She worked in the late 1950s as a fashion model in Europe. Rodriguez appeared first in Shirley, My Darling, 1958, and was introduced in Student Canteen, 1958. Then, she played supporting roles in Pagsikat ng Araw (When the Sun Rises), 1959; Viuda de Oro (Widow of Gold), 1960; Konsiyerto ng Kamatayan (Concert of Death), 1961; Kung Bakit Dugo ang Kulay ng Gabi (Why Blood Is the Color of Night), 1963; and Passionate Strangers, 1965. She played the title role in Gerardo de Leon’s Lilet, 1970. She continued making more films, like Lipad, Darna, Lipad (Fly, Darna, Fly) and Si Popeye, Atbp. (Popeye and Others), 1973; La Paloma: Ang Kalapating Ligaw (La Paloma: The Lost Dove), Bawal: Asawa Mo, Asawa Ko (Forbidden: Your Spouse, My Spouse), Kampanerang Kuba (Hunchbacked Lady Bell Ringer), and Pito’ng Asawa Ko (I Have Seven Wives), 1974; Katorse (Fourteen) and Aguila, 1980; Kapitan Kidlat (Captain Lightning), 1981; Diary of Cristina Gaston, Palengke Queen (Queen of the Market), and Mother Dear, 1982; Bulaklak sa City Jail (Flower of the City Jail), 1984; Lihim ni Madonna (Madonna’s Secret), 1997; Kahit Saan … Kung Puwede (Anywhere … If Possible), 1998; Bullet, 1999; Magnifico, 2003; Naglalayag (Silent Passage), 2004; Ligalig (Anxiety), 2006; Fuchsia and Tarot, 2009; I’ll Be There, 2010; Shake, Rattle & Roll 13, 2011; and My Kontrabida Girl (My Villain Girl), 2012.

On television, she appeared in GMA Network’s Broken Vow and Coffee Prince, 2012; Genesis, Magkano Ba ang Pag-ibig? (How Much Does Love Cost?), and Anna Karenina, 2013; Ilustrado (Educated Native), Hiram na Alaala (Borrowed Memories), Ang Dalawang Mrs. Real (The Two Mrs Real), and Rhodora X, 2014. She also did shows for other TV networks, such as ABS-CBN’s Bituin (Star), 2002, and IBC’s May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow).

Rodriguez received Best Supporting Actress awards from the FilipinoAcademyof Movie Arts andSciences (FAMAS): in 1964 for Kung Bakit Dugo ang Kulay ng Gabi; in 1966 for Passionate Strangers; and in 2004 for Magnifico. In 1971, the FAMAS named her Best Actress for her role in Gerardo de Leon’s Lilet. At the 1984 Metro Manila Film Festival, she won the Best Supporting Actress award for Bulaklak sa City Jail. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mesandel Arguelles

RODRIGUEZ, EDDIE aka Luis Enriquez. b. Zamboanga City 23 Aug 1932. d. Pasig City 12 Oct 2001. Movie actor, director, writer, producer. Born to Dominic Enriquez and Ruperta Clemente, he studied law at the University of the East. He has a son, Paolo Romero, who also appeared in several movies in the 1970s.

He received several awards as actor, director, and producer. His movies include Luksang Tagumpay (Dark Victory), 1956; Malvarosa, 1958; Kundiman ng Lahi (Love Song of the Race), 1959; Emily, 1960; Tatlong Baraha (Three Playing Cards), 1961; Magtiis Ka, Darling (Endure It, Darling), 3 Mukha ni Pandora (Pandora’s Three Faces), Sapagkat Kami’y Tao Lamang (For We Are Only Human), and Tiger Unit, 1963; Salambao, Sa Kuko ng Lawin (In the Claws of an Eagle), and Scout Rangers, 1964; Mila Rosa, 1965; Ang Iniluluha Ko’y Dugo (My Tears Are Blood), 1966; O! Pagsintang Labis (Oh! Great Love) and Kapag Puso’y Sinugatan (When the Heart Is Wounded), 1967; Oh! My Papa, 1968; Ikaw (You), 1969; My Little Angel, 1970; Pag-ibig Mo, Buhay Ko (Your Love, My Life) and Hanggang sa Kabila ng Daigdig: The Tony Maiquez Story (Till the Other Side of the World: The Tony Maiquez Story), 1973; Ala-ala Mo, Daigdig Ko (Your Memories, My World), 1974; Halikan Mo at Magpaalam sa Kahapon (Kiss and Say Goodbye to Yesterday) and Pag-ibig Ko’y Awitin Mo (Sing My Love for You), 1977; High School circa ’65, 1979; Ang Babaing Hinugot sa Aking Tadyang (The Woman Who Was Pulled from My Rib), 1981; Bukas Luluhod ang mga Tala (Tomorrow the Stars Will Kneel), 1984; Hati Tayo sa Magdamag (Let Us Share the Night), 1988; Ang Lahat ng Ito Pati Na ang Langit (All These and Heaven, Too), 1989; Ayaw Matulog ng Gabi (The Night Refuses to Sleep), 1990; Bingbong: The Vincent Crisologo Story, 1991; Separada (Separated Woman), 1994; and Segurista (Dead Sure), 1996.

Rodriguez also wrote scripts for several films under the name Luis Enriquez, a number of which he starred in and directed, like Cobra, 1966; Mahalin Mo Sana Ako (Please Love Me), 1972; Pag-ibig Mo, Buhay Ko, 1973; and Halik sa Paa, Halik sa Kamay (A Kiss on the Feet, A Kiss on the Hand), 1979.

He won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Actor award for Sapagkat Kami’y Tao Lamang; the Best Actor and Best Director awards in Bacolod City Film Festival for Nakakahiya (Shameful), 1975; and the Best Actor and Best Director awards in the Quezon City Film Festival in 1973 for Hanggang sa Kabila ng Daigdig (Till the Other Side of the World). He was Manila Film Festival (MFF) Best Director for Kasalanan Kaya? (Is it a Sin?), 1968, and MFF Best Actor for Bakit Ako Pa? (Why Should It Be Me?), 1970. He reaped Best Director awards for Babae … Ikaw ang Dahilan! (Woman … You Are the Reason!), 1972, at the MFF and Iloilo Film Festival, as well as the Best Screenplay for the same movie in the FAMAS. In 1976 he received the Outstanding Actor in a Drama Series award from Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining for his performance in the TV drama Sanyugto (Episode).Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Pamela Mathiel Lopez

RODRIGUEZ, LOLITA (Lolita Marquez Clark) b. Majayjay, Laguna 25 Jan 1935. d. Hemet, California, USA 28 Nov 2016. Movie, television, and stage actor. Her parents are William Charles Clark and Carmen Marquez. She married actor Eddie Arenas, with whom she had three children

Rodriguez first appeared in Ang Ating Pag-ibig (Our Love), 1953, was introduced in Pilya (Naughty Girl), 1954, and became a star in Jack and Jill, 1955. She was a Sampaguita contract star for 12 years. She did action and dramatic films like Rosana, 1955; Emma, 1956; Tarhata and Taga sa Bato (Cut on a Stone), 1957; and Condenado (Condemned), 1958. Her other notable films are Kilabot sa Makiling (Terror of Makiling), 1959; Pitong Makasalanan (Seven Sinners), 1962; Iginuhit sa Buhangin (Written on the Sand), 1965; Tubog sa Ginto (Dipped in Gold), 1970; Tatlo, Dalawa Isa (Three, Two, One), 1974; Lunes, Martes, Miyerkules, Huwebes, Biyernes, Sabado, Linggo (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday), 1976; Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Mother, Sister, Daughter), 1979; and Paradise Inn, 1985. After moving to the United States and living there in relative anonymity, she returned for a short visit to the Philippines in 1991 and made the movie Lucia for BBC Television, which was directed by Mel Chionglo.

Rodriguez also performed on stage. For the Philippine Educational Theater Association, she played Candida and later Paula in the two productions of Nick Joaquin’s Larawan (A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino), directed by Lino Brocka, in 1969 and 1979, respectively. She played the wife of Vic Silayan in Bayaning Huwad (Straw Patriot), 1967.

She received Best Actress awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Gilda, 1956, and again for Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (You Were Weighed and Found Wanting), 1974. At the Manila Film Festival, she was chosen Best Actress for Kasalanan Kaya? (Is It a Sin?), 1968, and at the Catholic Mass Media Awards for Stardoom, 1971. In 1979, she won Best Actress (tied with Nora Aunor) at the Metro Manila Film Festival for her performance in Ina Ka ng Anak Mo (You Are the Mother of Your Daughter). Written byLena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

ROJAS, EMMANUEL ( Emmanuel Ignacio Rojas ) b. Manila 26 Dec 1912. d. Manila 4 Mar 1968. Cinematographer, movie director. His parents are Francisco Rojas and Cirila Ignacio. He married his classmate Gracia Carrillo, with whom he had four sons. He graduated with a bachelor of science in chemistry from the University of the Philippines in 1934.

After World War II, he became an assistant cinematographer. He worked with Manuel Conde in the first Juan Tamad movie, Si Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), 1947, then in Genghis Khan and Siete Infantes de Lara (Seven Devils), both in 1950. He also worked with Gerardo de Leon in such films as Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo (Python in the Old Dome) and Bagong Umaga (New Morning), 1952; Dyesebel, 1953; Ifugao, 1954; Sanda Wong, 1955; and Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1961, with Arsenio Baftu. Ifugao was shot in color.

In 1959, Rojas directed Anak ng Bulkan (Child of the Volcano), starring Edna Luna. He photographed some of the Hollywood films shot in the Philippines. These are The Steel Claw, 1961, and Warner Bros.’ Samar, 1962, both starring George Montgomery; Out of the Tiger’s Mouth, 1962; A Yank in Vietnam, 1964; United Artists’ Ambush Bay, 1966, and Kill a Dragon, 1967. He photographed and co-directed the award-winning short documentary film Soul of a Fortress, with Ferde Grofe Jr, in 1964.

Rojas earned a Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Photography award for Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo in 1953 and nominations for Ang Bagong Umaga and Dyesebel. Written byCesar Hernando and Teddie Co

ROMA, ARCADIO Active ca 1930-55. Stage and movie actor. He was with the Kababahay Troupe, the magician Nogalis Troupe, and the circus of Eli Torres. While on tour with the Antingan and Velez Troupes, he was recruited by playwright Emiliano Gabuya for minoros (“like the moro-moro”) performances. He wrote the play Langitnon Panimalas (Heaven Seen), 1939. By 1955, he had done more than 30 films, including Garbosa (Haughty Lady), Santilmo, Luha sa Kalipay (Tears of Joy), Dimakaling, Mga Anak Intawon (The Pitiful Children), and Gihigugma Ko Ikaw (I Love You). He thrice won in the comedy competitions of the Cebu Carnival. Written byErlinda K. Alburo

ROMERO, CHANDA b. Cagayan de Oro 16 Mar 1954. Movie and television actor. She is a niece of the late film director Eddie Romero and cousin to director Joey Romero. Romero has been active in the film industry since 1973, starring in more than 20 films in the 1970s. Such movies include Lipad, Darna, Lipad! (Fly, Darna, Fly!), 1973; No Medals for Heroes and Batul of Mactan, 1974; May Lalaki sa Ilalim ng Kama Ko (There’s a Man under My Bed), Fortress in the Sun, Mga Uhaw na Bulaklak (Thirsty Flowers), Obra Maestra (Masterpiece), Kahit ang Mundo’y Magunaw (Even If the World Ends), and Alat (Saltiness), 1975; Nasa Lupa ang Langit at Impyerno (Heaven and Hell Are on Earth) and Unos sa Dalampasigan (Downpour on the Shore), 1976; Mga Sariwang Bulaklak (Fresh Flowers), Beerhouse, and Banta ng Kahapon (Threat of Yesterday), 1977; Batang City Jail (City Jail Kid), 1978; and Basta Driver, Sweet Lover (Drivers Are Sweet Lovers), 1979; and Batch ’81, 1982. In 1984, Romero starred in the movie Dapat Ka Bang Mahalin? (Should You Be Loved?) with Sharon Cuneta and Gabby Concepcion. She also starred in Olongapo … The Great American Dream, 1987, Bocaue Pagoda Tragedy, 1995, Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin (They Call Me Joy), 1997, Naglalayag (Silent Passage), and Liberated 2, 2004.

Romero has starred in primetime television series, such as Vietnam Rose, 2005, Dyesebel, 2008, Dwarfina, 2011, My Husband’s Lover, 2013, and Kambal Sirena (Twin Mermaids), 2015.

Romero received Best Supporting Actress awards from the Gawad Urian for Boy Pana (Bow and Arrow Kid), 1978, and from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Karma, 1981. She was nominated Best Actress by the Gawad Urian and the FAMAS for her role in the film Bakit Manipis ang Ulap? (Why’s the Cloud So Thin?), 1985. She also received Best Supporting Actress nominations from the Gawad Urian for Inay (Mom), 1977, Ikaw … at ang Gabi (You … and the Night), 1979, and Kasal? (Marriage?), 1980. Written by Gregory del Carmen

ROMERO, EDDIE(Edgar Sinco Romero) aka Enrique Moreno. b. Dumaguete City 7 Jul 1924. d. 28 May 2013. National Artist for film and broadcast arts. Movie director, scriptwriter, producer. He is the son of Pilar Sinco, a schoolteacher, and Jose E. Romero, former congressman, education secretary, and Philippine ambassador to London. He married Carolina Gonzalez with whom he had three children. Son Joey Romero is also a movie director, and niece Chanda Romero is an actor. He studied at Dumaguete Elementary School, Ateneo de Manila, University of the Philippines (UP) High School, and Silliman University High School in Dumaguete City. He earned his bachelor of arts degree in UP, completed the associate in arts (prelaw) program at Silliman University, and was conferred the honorary degree Doctor of Humane Letters by the Foundation University in Dumaguete City. Romero was an acknowledged leader in the film industry. He also devoted time serving the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, the Cultural Center of the Philippines, the Film Development Foundation of the Philippines, the Film Academy of the Philippines, and the Movie Workers Welfare Foundation Inc (Mowelfund) and the Mowelfund Film Institute.

As a young high school student, Romero published short stories in the Philippines Free Press. His literary works interested director Gerardo de Leon and he was hired as the screenwriter of de Leon’s Ang Maestra (The Teacher), 1941. He also wrote de Leon’s Isumpa Mo, Giliw (Make a Vow, My Love), 1947, and eventually directed for Sampaguita Pictures.

Romero joined his family in London when his father was appointed ambassador to the Court of St. James. There he became acquainted with European directors David Lean, Karel Reisz, and Roberto Rossellini. In 1951, he came back to Manila to direct films for Sampaguita and Lebran.

Among his early films are Ang Kamay ng Diyos (The Hand of God), 1947; Hindi Kita Malimot (I Can’t Forget You) and Ang Selosa (The Jealous Woman), 1948; Apoy sa Langit (Fire in Heaven) and Abogada (Lady Lawyer), 1949; and Ang Asawa Kong Americana (My American Wife), 1953, the first Filipino movie to win an award in the Asian Film Festival. During this period, he was also known as the director of the Pancho Magalona–Tita Duran films: Always: Kay Ganda Mo (Always: You’re So Beautiful) and Sa Piling Mo (In Your Arms), 1949; Kasintahan sa Pangarap (Sweetheart in My Dreams), 1951; and Ang Ating Pag-ibig (Our Love Affair), 1953.

Romero became a producer-director with the film Buhay Alamang (Easy Come, Easy Go), 1952, which he adapted from a stage play by Gerardo de Leon. Under Hemisphere Productions, he produced films for international release, which he himself wrote and/or directed, like Day of the Trumpet, 1957; Man on the Run, 1958; Terror Is a Man, 1959; Lost Battalion, 1961; The Walls of Hell, 1964, co-directed with Gerardo de Leon; Passionate Strangers, 1966; Raiders of Leyte Gulf and Manila: Open City, 1967. His film Black Mama, White Mama, 1973, became a cult classic favorite.

In the mid-1970s, Romero returned to the local scene with Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?), 1976; Sino’ng Kapiling? Sino’ng Kasiping? (Housemates, Bedmates?) and Banta ng Kahapon (Threat of the Past), 1977; Durugin si Totoy Bato (Crush Totoy the Rock), 1979; Aguila, 1980; Kamakalawa (Day before Yesterday), 1981; Ang Padrino (The Godfather), 1984; and Hari sa Hari, Lahi sa Lahi (King and Emperor), 1987. In 1992 he scripted and directed the 13-episode TV version of Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) for the Cultural Center of the Philippines. He made over 70 films for international and local distribution. At 82, Romero explored digital movies by producing, directing, and co-writing Faces of Love, 2006,and Teach Me to Love, 2008.

In 1951, Romero won the Maria Clara Award for Best Director for Ang Prinsesa at ang Pulubi (The Princess and the Pauper). He received five Best Screenplay awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Buhay Alamang, Aguila, Passionate Strangers, Durugin si Totoy Bato, and Ang Padrino, which elevated him to the Hall of Fame. He was a recipient of the Dr Ciriaco Santiago Memorial Award for Outstanding Achievement in the Movie Industry for Day of the Trumpet. He won the Gawad Urian Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Screenplay for Ganito Kami Noon …, which also won in the Metro Manila Film Festival for Best Screenplay and Best Director. He received a Papal Award as Film Director of the Decade, 1971-80, from the Catholic Mass Media Awards. In 1994, the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) honored Romero with the Lamberto Avellana Memorial Award for Outstanding Achievement. He received the ASEAN Award for Outstanding Contributions to Regional Culture in Jakarta, Indonesia, in 1997. He also got Lifetime Achievement Awards from Gawad Urian, FAMAS, and FAP. In 2003, Romero was named National Artist for film and broadcast arts. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Rica Arevalo

ROMERO, GLORIA(Gloria Borrego Galla) b. Denver, Colorado 16 Dec 1933. Movie and television actor. Her parents are Pedro Galla of Pangasinan and Mary Borrego, an American. She finished grade school at Mabini Elementary School and graduated from Mabini Riverview High School in Mabini, Pangasinan. Her late brother, Tito Galla, was a movie actor. She married actor Juancho Gutierrez with whom she has a daughter, actor Maritess Gutierrez.

Romero started her movie career as an extra in Sampaguita Pictures before she was noticed in Kasintahan sa Pangarap (Dream Sweetheart), 1951, and starred with Cesar Ramirez in Palasig, 1952. Her first big break was the title role in Monghita (The Nun), 1952, opposite Oscar Moreno. In May Umaga Pang Darating (There Will Be Another Morning), 1953, she was cast as the daughter of prewar star Carmen Rosales. Her other important movies during this period are Apat na Taga (Four Slashes), 1953, with Ramon Revilla; Recuerdo (Memento), 1953, with Fred Montilla; Musikong Bumbong (Bamboo Music), 1954, with Pancho Magalona; Pilya (Naughty Girl), 1954, with Ric Rodrigo; and Dalagang Ilocana (Ilocano Maiden), 1954, with Dolphy.

She became extremely popular portraying komiks characters created by Mars Ravelo or Pablo Gomez, in such films as Kurdapya (Screwball), 1954; Mariposa (Butterfly), 1955; Mister Kasintahan (Mr Lover), 1953; and Miss Tilapia, 1956, where she played the original Pacifica Falayfay. Later, she settled for more sedate roles in Artista (Actress), 1955; Teresa, 1956; and Ikaw ang Aking Buhay (You Are My Life), 1959; and the remakes of prewar box-office romantic musicals, such as Pagdating ng Takip-silim (When Twilight Comes), 1956, Colegiala (Coed), 1957, and Paruparong Bukid (Country Butterfly), 1958.

Before her contract with Sampaguita expired, it was renewed for another eight years, making her Sampaguita’s longest exclusive star. She was paired with all the matinee idols of Sampaguita, especially Luis Gonzales and Ric Rodrigo. But she also made films for other movie companies, among them: Kaibigan Ko’ng Sto. Niño (The Holy Infant Is My Friend), 1967; Pitong Gabi sa Hongkong (Seven Nights in Hong Kong), 1966; Haydee, 1970, with Hilda Koronel; Lumuha Pati mga Anghel (Even the Angels Wept), 1971, with Eddie Garcia and Ronaldo Valdez; Sakada (Seasonal Cane Workers), 1976; and Bakit May Putik ang Bulaklak? (Why Is the Flower Muddy?), 1979, with Lorna Tolentino and Rosemarie Gil.

Other notable films where Romero appeared are Esmeralda at Ruby (Esmeralda and Ruby) and Kasal? (Marriage?), 1980; Mother Dear and Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan? (How Often Is Once?), 1982; To Mama with Love and Kickouts, 1983; Kung Mahawi Man ang Ulap (Should the Skies Clear), Sinner or Saint, Condemned, and Bulaklak sa City Jail (Flower of the City Jail), 1984; Miguelito: Batang Rebelde (Miguelito: Young Rebel), 1985; Payaso (Clown), 1986; Once Upon a Time, Alabok sa Ulap (Dust in the Cloud), and Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig? (Where Does Love Hide?), 1987; Nasaan Ka, Inay? (Where Are You, Mother?), Kapag Napagod ang Puso (When the Heart Tires), Nagbabagang Luha (Smoldering Tears), and Paano Tatakasan ang Bukas? (How Does One Escape from Tomorrow?), 1988; Impaktita (Young Female Monster), Kung Maibabalik Ko Lang (If I Can Only Bring It Back), Bilangin ang Bituin sa Langit (Count the Stars in the Sky), and Huwag Kang Hahalik sa Diablo (Do Not Kiss the Devil), 1989; Kapag Langit ang Humatol (Heaven’s Judgment) and Bakit Ikaw Pa Rin? (Why Still You?), 1990; Makiusap Ka sa Diyos (Plead with God), 1991; Alabang Girls and Bakit Labis Kitang Mahal (Why Do I Love You So), 1992; Ayaw Ko Nang Mangarap (I Do Not Want to Dream Anymore), 1993; Kadenang Bulaklak (Chain of Flowers) and Forever, 1994; Sana Dalawa ang Puso Ko (I Wish I Had Two Hearts), 1995; Do Re Mi and Rubberman, 1996; Takot Ako sa Darling Ko (I Am Scared of My Darling) and Laging Naroon Ka (You Were Always There), 1997; Dahil May Isang Ikaw (Because There Is You), 1999; Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000; American Adobo, 2001; and Magnifico, 2003.

On television, she starred in one of the longest-running sitcoms, Palibhasa Lalake (Because They Are Men), with Richard Gomez, Joey Marquez, Cynthia Patag, and Amy Perez. She also became one of the most celebrated character actors on television, playing the roles of the doting grandmother or the rich old lady in TV series such as May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), 2009; Kung Tayo’y Magkakalayo (If We Are Separated) and Kokey, 2010; and 100 Days to Heaven, 2011.

Romero has three acting awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS): Best Actress for Dalagang Ilocana in 1955, Best Supporting Actress for Nagbabagang Luha in 1989, and Best Actress for Tanging Yaman in 2001. From Gawad Urian, she also received a Best Actress award for Tanging Yaman and a Best Supporting Actress award years later for Magnifico, 2003. The Young Critics Circle also gave her a Best Performance award for Tanging Yaman. She won a Best Performance award from the Golden Screen Awards for Fuschia, 2009. Due to her stellar acting career, Romero received several Lifetime Achievement Awards: from the Cinemanila International Film Festival, 2001; Natatanging Gawad Urian, 2003; the FAMAS, 2004; the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board Awards, 2009; and the Star Awards for Television, 2012. Written byGalileo Zafra, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

ROÑO, CHITO(Jose Sarmiento Roño Jr) aka Sixto Kayko. b. Manila 28 Apr 1960. Movie director. The son of former congressman Jose Roño Sr and Carolina Sarmiento, he grew up in Calbayog, Samar, where he spent his elementary and high school years. He took up college courses in Manila, graduating from the University of the Philippines with a degree in mass communication. Afterward, he went abroad to study at the New York School for Social Research in New York City.

When he returned to the Philippines, he made his first film, Private Show, 1986, which made waves when it was chosen as the Philippine entry to the Chicago International Film Festival. His other films include Baleleng at ang Gintong Sirena (Baleleng and the Golden Mermaid) and Itanong Mo sa Buwan (Ask the Moon), 1988; Kasalanan Bang Sambahin Kita? (Is It a Sin to Worship You?) and Bakit Kay Tagal ng Sandali? (Why Is a Moment So Long?), 1990; Kailan Ka Magiging Akin (When Will You Be Mine), 1991; Narito ang Puso Ko (Here Is My Heart), 1992; Ikaw Lang (Only You), 1993; Separada (Separated Woman), 1994; Dahas (Rage), 1995; Nasaan ang Puso (Where Is the Heart), 1997; Curacha: Ang Babaeng Walang Pahinga (Curacha: The Woman without Rest) and Bata, Bata … Paano Ka Ginawa? (Lea’s Story), 1998; Laro sa Baga (Playing with Fire), 2000; La Vida Rosa (The Life of Rosa), 2001; Dekada ’70 (The 1970s), 2002; Feng Shui, 2004; Sukob (The Wedding Curse), 2006; Caregiver, 2008, Emir, 2010; The Healing, 2012; Badil (Dynamite Fishing) and Boy Golden, 2013; The Trial, 2014; and Etiquette for Mistresses, 2015.

Roño won numerous prestigious awards. His film Olongapo … The Great American Dream, 1987, was chosen Best Picture at the Metro Manila Film Festival. Itanong Mo sa Buwan won Best Picture awards at the Gawad Urian and Star Awards in 1989. Dekada ’70 won the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award in the 2002 Cinemanila International Film Festival. In 2011, he received Best Director awards for Emir from the Film Academy of the Philippines and the Golden Screen Awards. He won Indie Movie Director of the Year in the 2014 Star Awards for Movies for Badil. Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

ROSAL, ROSA(Florence Lansang Danon) b. Manila 16 Oct 1931. Movie and television actor. Her parents are Julio Danon and Gloria Lansang. Don Danon aka Armando Villa, an actor-director who was once a stand-in for Rudolph Valentino in Hollywood, is her half-brother. She attended grade school at Antonio Regidor Elementary School and finished high school at Cosmopolitan Colleges, where she took commerce courses. She married Walter Gayda, a commercial pilot, with whom she has one child, Toni Rose, a television host.

Rosal was working in the chest clinic of the Philippine General Hospital when Luis F. Nolasco spotted her and offered her a screen test in the movie Fort Santiago, 1946. She played a minor part in Kamagong, 1947, which starred Leopoldo Salcedo. Her first starring role was in the comedy film Biglang Yaman (Sudden Wealth), 1949, with Jaime de la Rosa and Pugo and Togo. The original “femme fatale” of the local cinema, she had no qualms about wearing bathing suits, doing kissing scenes, and playing villainess and vamp in films like Ang Lumang Simbahan (The Old Church), 1949; Mahal Mo Ba Ako? (Do You Love Me?), 1950; Bayan o Pag-ibig (Country or Love) and Amor Mio (My Love), 1951; Matador (Bullfighter), 1952; Mga Pusong May Lason (Poisoned Hearts), 1953; Dakilang Pagpapakasakit (Great Sacrifice), 1954; and Donato, 1954.

Rosal played a variety of roles in some of the finest movies produced in the industry. In Prinsipe Amante sa Rubitanya (Prince Amante in Rubitanya), 1951, she is stunning as the seductive princess who uses her beauty to win a kingdom. From a sword fighter in Dagohoy, 1953, she becomes a Tausug bride in Badjao, 1957. She is convincing as a nightclub hostess offering hope to an embittered war veteran in Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956. As the farmer’s widow who tries to build a future for her children by raising fragile lanzones trees in Biyaya ng Lupa (Blessings of the Land), 1959, she is both stirring and inspiring. In Sakada (Seasonal Cane Workers), 1976, she is militant as the exploited and oppressed sugar plantation worker.

In real life, her social conscience was reflected in her devotion to public service. In her TV programs Damayan (Helping One Another) and Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love My Fellowman), she gave help to countless Filipinos in need of assistance. She is actively involved with the Philippine National Red Cross and the Blood Bank.

Rosal received the Best Actress award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Sonny Boy, 1955, and the FAMAS International Prestige Award for Anak Dalita, which won Best Picture at the Asian Film Festival in Hong Kong. This merited her a presidential citation from then-president Ramon Magsaysay. She was nominated Best Actress by the FAMAS for Biyaya ng Lupa, Dagohoy, and Ang Lahat ng Ito Pati Na ang Langit (All These and Heaven, Too), 1989. From the Citizens’ Council for Mass Media (CCMM), she received in 1969 the Citizens’ Award for Television (CAT) as Best Actress for her appearance in the television series Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye). The Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino (MPP) honored her with the Natatanging Gawad Urian in 1987 for her lifetime achievement in Philippine cinema. Rosal was also awarded the Ading Fernando Lifetime Achievement Award at the 22nd PMPC Star Awards for Television in 2008.

Rosal’s unwavering humanitarian efforts and public service earned her on 30 Jun 1993 her second presidential citation from Pres Fidel V. Ramos for her outstanding work as governor of the Philippine National Red Cross. In 1999, Rosal was given the Ramon Magsaysay Award for Public Service. And in 2006, Pres Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo bestowed on Rosal the Order of the Golden Heart with the rank of Grand Cross. In 2012, she was the recipient of the Gawad Plaridel from the University of the Philippines College of Mass Communication. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

ROSALES, CARMEN(Januaria Constantino Keller) b. Bulacan 3 Mar 1917. d. Manila 11 Dec 1991. Movie actor. Her parents are Pantaleon Rosales Keller, a half-Swede, and Pilar Constantino. Her marriage to Ramon Navales produced a son, Rene; her second marriage to Jose Puyat Sr produced another son, Cesar.

Rosales began her movie career after she was proclaimed Radio Queen in 1937. Her first movie was Mahiwagang Binibini (Mysterious Woman), 1939, based on the sarsuwela Ang Kiri. In her second movie, Arimunding-Munding, 1939, she became a star. Sampaguita Pictures offered her an exclusive contract and successfully made her into one of its “hottest properties.” She was teamed up with Rogelio de la Rosa for the first time in Takip-silim (Twilight), 1939. Together they made some of the most memorable pre-World War II hits: Señorita (Young Mistress), Colegiala (Coed), and Lambingan (Romance), 1940; and Panambitan (Lament) and Tampuhan (Lovers’ Quarrel), 1941. During the war, she appeared for the Japanese Occupation film Tatlong Maria (Three Marys), 1944. By 1948, she had become the “Queen of Philippine Movies.”

After the war, she appeared in Premiere Productions’ first movie, Probinsiyana (Country Girl), 1946. LVN got her to appear in Kampanang Ginto (Golden Bell), Camelia, Sipag ay Yaman (Industry Is Wealth), Batalyon XIII (13th Battalion), all in 1949; and Ang Bombero (The Firefighter), 1950. She had turned freelancer, becoming the highest-paid actor in the local movie industry. Sampaguita Pictures got her back for a reunion with Rogelio de la Rosa in Maalaala Mo Kaya? (Will You Remember?), 1954; Ang Tangi Kong Pag-ibig (My Only Love), 1955; Iyung-Iyo (Yours Alone), 1955; and Lydia, 1956.

Rosales was also paired off with other stars. With Jose Padilla Jr she made Carmen, Princesita (Little Princess), and Lolita, 1941; Probinsiyana; Bombero; Walang Kapantay (No Equal), 1951; Rosa Villa, 1953; and Matandang Dalaga (Spinster), 1954. With Leopoldo Salcedo, she did Kaaway ng Bayan (The Country’s Enemy) and Ang Kamay ng Diyos (The Hand of God), 1947; Hindi Kita Malimot (I Can’t Forget You), 1948; and Sandra, 1959. With Oscar Moreno, she starred in Guerilyera (Lady Guerrilla Fighter), 1946; Si, Si Señorito (Yes, Yes, Young Gentleman), Mameng, Iniibig Kita (Mameng, I Love You), and Hele-Hele (Bago Quiere) (Pretending Not to Care), 1947; 24 na Pag-ibig (24 Loves), 1948; and MN, 1954. With Danilo Montes, she did Ang Magpapawid (Vendor of Palm Leaves), 1950, Nanay Ko! (Oh, Mother!), 1951, and Anak Ko! (Oh, My Child!), 1951. She also starred in Palikero (Playboy), 1941, with Ely Ramos; Carmencita Mia (My Little Carmen), 1949, with Fernando Poe Sr; Simpatika (Charming), 1949, with Pancho Magalona; Batalyon XIII, with Jaime de la Rosa; Luha ng Birhen (A Virgin’s Tears), 1954, with Van de Leon; Uhaw na Pag-ibig (Love Thirst), 1955, with Cesar Ramirez; and ROTC, 1955, with Ric Rodrigo. After resting for a few years, she came back in the early 1960s and appeared in Tatlong Magdalena (Three Magdalenes), 1960, with Mila del Sol and Rita Gomez; Octavia, 1961, with Lolita Rodriguez and Ric Rodrigo; Halik sa Lupa (Kiss the Earth), 1961, with Eddie Garcia and Lito Legaspi; Sugat sa Balikat (Wound on the Shoulder), 1962, with Jose Mari; Binibiro Lamang Kita (I Was Only Joking), 1964, with Oscar Moreno, Susan Roces, and Eddie Gutierrez; and The Dolly Sisters, 1964, with Susan Roces and Rosemarie Sonora.

Rosales received a Best Actress award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for her performance in Inspirasyon (Inspiration), 1953, which was based on a komiks novel by Pablo S. Gomez. In 2013, newspaper columnist Danny Dolor published the biography titled A Tribute to the Movie Queen: Carmen Rosales, Ang Tangi Kong Pag-ibig, written by Manny Fernandez. Written by Glecy Atienza and Joy Galvez, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

ROSALES, JERICHO(Jericho Vibar Rosales) b. Quezon City 22 Sep 1979. Movie and TV actor, host, singer, and model, Rosales is one of the five children of Rosario Vibar and Santiago Rosales. He last attended New Era University before he entered show business. He was part of the male group The Hunks. Jericho Rosales married Kim Jones in May 2014.

Rosales was discovered in Eat Bulaga! in 1996 after winning its “Mr. Pogi” (Mr Handsome) contest. After this, he moved to ABS-CBN and joined its Star Circle Batch 4. His first TV appearance was in Kaybol, Ang Bagong TV (Cable, The New TV), 1997-98, followed by roles in Esperanza, 1999; Oka Tokat! (I Am Afraid), 1998-2000; Richard Loves Lucy, 1998-2000; Ang Munting Paraiso (The Little Paradise), 1999-2002; Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000-2002; Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (I Wish This Were Forever), 2003-4; Carlo J. Caparas’ Ang Panday (The Blacksmith), 2005-6; Kahit Isang Saglit (Even for a Moment), 2008, opposite Malaysian actor Carmen Soo; I Love Betty La Fea, 2009; Green Rose, 2011; and The Legal Wife, 2014. He continued to host shows like I Dare You, 2011; It’s Showtime, 2013; and ASAP, since 1997.

Rosales appeared in films such as Biyudo si Daddy, Biyuda si Mommy (Daddy Is a Widower, Mommy Is a Widow) and Hanggang Kailan Kita Mamahalin (Until When Will I Love You), 1997; Magandang Hatinggabi (Good Midnight), 1998; Wanspanataym: The Movie (Once upon a Time: The Movie), 1999; Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000, Bagong Buwan (New Moon), 2001; Forevermore, 2002; Ngayong Nandito Ka (Now That You’re Here), 2003; I’ll Be There, 2010; Subject: I Love You, 2011; Yesterday Today Tomorrow, 2011; Alagwa (Breakaway), 2012; ABNKKBSNPLAko?!: The Movie (Wow I Can Actually Read Now?!: The Movie) and Bonifacio: Ang Unang Pangulo (Bonifacio: The First President), 2014.

Rosales received Best Actor awards from the Star Awards for Pacquiao: The Movie, 2006, and Baler, 2008. The 2011 New York Festival recognized Rosales for his role in Dahil May Isang Ikaw (Because There Is You), 2009. In 2013, he won the Gawad Urian Best Actor for Alagwa. A year later, for the same film, Rosales won the Outstanding Achievement in Acting award from the Newport Beach Film Festival and the Achievement in Acting award from Guam International Film Festival. Written by Christian Co, with notes from Mario Mendez Jr and Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

ROXAS, MEEK(Humilde Reyes Roxas) b. Kalibo, Aklan 26 Mar 1944. Movie scriptwriter. He is the son of sarsuwela writer Jose Roxas and Esperanza Reyes. He attended Makato Elementary School in San Juan and Florida College. At 18, he became a contributing writer for G. Miranda Publishing House, which published Tagalog komiks. He also wrote a radio soap opera, Medico Legal, while working as a messenger for an advertising agency. Later, he joined Sampaguita Pictures, where he helped write scripts. He did jobs like doing makeup, driving, and working as machine operator at a textile factory to support his wife, Rosemarie Pagsanjan, and two children.

In 1976, Roxas’s writing career took off. After doing the script for Kay Lupit Mo, Pag-ibig (How Cruel You Are, Love), 1973, with co-writers Renato del Prado and Jojo Lapus, he wrote Bitayin si Baby Ama (Execute Baby Ama), 1976, which starred Rudy Fernandez. His other notable films include Waywaya, 1982; Golden Buddha, 1987; Ipaglalaban Ko (I’ll Fight for It), Tatak ng Isang Api (Mark of the Oppressed), Joe Pring, and Ang Pumatay nang Dahil sa Iyo (To Kill for You), 1989; Kaaway ng Batas (Enemy of the Law) and Barumbado (Troublemaker), 1990; and Bingbong Crisologo, 1991. Roxas wrote mostly action and romance movies, including 21 films for Viva in 1991-92, like Bad Boy, Bad Boy II, Mandurugas (Swindler), and Pangako sa Iyo (The Promise). His other films include Masahol Pa sa Hayop (Worse Than an Animal), 1993; Bukas Bibitayin si Itay (Father Will Be Executed Tomorrow), 1995; Habang Nasasaktan, Lalong Tumatapang (More Pain, More Courage), 1997; Anakan Mo Ako (Make Me Pregnant), 1999; Kaaway Hanggang Hukay (Enemy until Death), 2001; and Ang Kapitbahay (The Neighbor), 2003.

Roxas won Best Screenplay for Andres Manambit, starring Eddie Garcia, at the 1992 Metro Manila Film Festival. Written by Raquel Hernandez, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

ROXLEE (Roque Federizon Lee) b. Naga City, Camarines Sur 16 Aug 1950. Filmmaker and cartoonist. His parents are Chit Lee and Fortuna Federizon. He finished his elementary and high school at Ateneo de Naga and took up architecture at National University. He started out as a cartoonist, first contributing cartoons to Jingle Magazine and, since 1981, doing the comic strip Cesar Asar for the Manila Bulletin in collaboration with his brother Monlee.

Roxlee studied filmmaking at a workshop sponsored by the Mowelfund Film Institute and Ateneo de Manila University in 1981. His early films were shot in Super 8mm and 16mm. Many were done with the assistance of artist-friends like Ludwig Ilio, Benjie Lontoc Jr, Wilfreda Calderon, At Maculangan, and his brother Ruben Lee. His works were exhibited in festivals in Berlin, Hamburg, New York, Hong Kong, and Japan. A retrospective of his films was featured at the Image Forum in Tokyo in 1991.

Roxlee’s films, lasting anywhere between 3 and 12 minutes, are freewheeling collages of animation, performance art, and “found” footage. Often crude in style and defiant of classical film aesthetics, they display raw energy, a morbid sense of humor, and flights of pure nonsense. His subjects are nature in the raw, primordial human urges, and environmental concerns. Among his works are Juan Gapang (Johnny Crawl), 1987, which has a naked semi-human creature crawling through the metropolis, commenting on its decay and congestion; Lizard, 1987, which shows a half-human, half-lizard, dancing to rock music; and The Great Smoke, 1984, an apocalyptic nuclear nightmare.

Roxlee’s films won numerous prizes in the short film competitions of the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines and the Cultural Center of the Philippines. He was one of the first recipients of the Best Experimental Film prize of the Gawad Urian for Juan Gapang and the Student Film Prize of the Film Academy of the Philippines. His Green Rocking Chair, 2008, was featured at the Rotterdam and Singapore International Film Festivals in 2009.

Roxlee served as executive committee member of the National Committee on Cinema of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. In 2006, he received the Daluyan (Vessel) Award as a progressive leader and pioneer in the independent film community in the Philippines. The Animation Council of the Philippines Inc gave Roxlee a Lifetime Achievement Award in 2010. Written by Teddie Co and Rosalinda Galang, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

ROYAL PRODUCTIONS Established 1946 by Fernando Poe, Bessie Kelley Poe, Jose R. Samson, and T.D. Agcaoili, it was originally known as Palaris Films. Later, it became Fernando Poe Productions.

Fernando Poe was a big star of pre-World War II Philippine cinema whose biggest hit was Filippine Films’ Zamboanga (Fury in Paradise), 1937. During World War II, he appeared in the Japanese-produced anti-American film Dawn of Freedom, 1944, which made him a controversial figure. To offset the stigma of “collaborator” hurled at those who worked with the Japanese, Poe directed and produced a movie where he played the role of a guerrilla soldier, Dugo ng Bayan (I Remember Bataan), 1946. Among his early postwar films were Intramuros: The Rape of a City, 1946; Hanggang Pier (Until the Pier), 1946; Kalbaryo ng Isang Ina (A Mother’s Calvary), 1946; Labis na Pagmamahal (Too Much Love), 1946; and Kanto Boy (Streetcorner Boy), 1947.

Royal Productions is known for the Darna movies that Poe produced, starring Rosa del Rosario in the title role. Darna, 1951, centered on a wonder woman and her nemesis, the snake-headed Valentina portrayed by Cristina Aragon, a Poe next-of-kin. Another Darna film, Darna at ang Babaing Lawin (Darna and the Hawkwoman), 1952, also starring del Rosario, was similarly well-received at the box office.

Poe’s sudden death from a dog bite on 23 Oct 1951 cut short any further plans of his company. His studio and film equipment were leased out to independent movie producers after his death. He produced a total of 33 films. Later, his son Ronald Allan Poe put up FPJ Productions, which was based on the lot that used to belong to Royal Productions. Written by Lena S. Pareja

RUBI, NATI(Natividad Basterrechea) b. 25 Apr 1911. Movie actor. While a student at La Concordia College, she met actor-director Salvador Tinsay. He convinced her to try the movies. Later, Jose Nepomuceno went to her house and urged her to report to Parlatone Studio.

Her first movie was Hampaslupa (Vagabond), 1937, with Angelito Nepomuceno, Rosario Moreno, and Carlos Padilla. This was followed by Anak ng Kadiliman (Child of Darkness), 1937, with Tita Duran, Angel Esmeralda, and Purita Santamaria. She appeared in most of the Sampaguita film dramas as the cruel stepmother or oppressive mother-in-law as in Paroparong Bukid (Country Butterfly), Alipin ng Palad (Slave of Fate), Madaling Araw (Break of Dawn), and Mapait na Lihim (Bitter Secret), all in 1938; and Dahong Lagas (Withered Leaf), Lagot na Kuwintas (Broken Necklace), Pasang Krus (Cross on the Shoulder), and Dalisay (Chaste), all in 1939.

After her stint with Sampaguita, she made movies with Excelsior Pictures, appearing in Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), 1939, with Rosario Moreno, Rudy Concepcion, and Tita Duran; Magpakailanman (Forever), 1940, with Rosario Moreno and Jose Padilla Jr; Mahal Pa Rin Kita (I Still Love You), 1940, with Rosario Moreno and Ernesto La Guardia; Ikaw Rin (You, Too), 1940, with Rudy Concepcion and Elsa Oria; and Kundiman (Love Song), 1941. She also made pictures for Filippine Films, among them Libingang Bakal (Iron Grave), 1940, Dalaga (Lady), 1940, and Binibiro Lamang Kita (I Was Only Joking), 1941. She also appeared in Waling-Waling’s Alitaptap (Firefly), 1940, starring Elsa Oria and Leopoldo Salcedo; Inday, 1940; and in LVN’s Ilang-Ilang, 1941, which reunited the love team of Leopoldo Salcedo and Rosa del Rosario.

After World War II, she appeared in LVN’s Romansa (Romance), Maling Akala (Mistaken Notion), and Bagong Manunubos (New Redeemer), all in 1947. Rubi epitomized the matronly kontrabida (villainess) of Filipino movies, which was popularized in later years by Etang Discher and Armida Siguion-Reyna. Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja

RUSTIA, RUBEN (Ruben Matias Cayari) b. Manila 25 Jul 1923. d. Manila 7 Apr 1994. Movie and television actor and scriptwriter. His parents are Petra Matias of San Miguel, Bulacan, and Jose Cayari of Polo, Bulacan. He and his wife Alejandra have six children. Rustia attended Legarda Elementary School and Mapa High School, where he appeared in plays. During the war, he was a member of the Young People’s Methodist Church and took part in stage dramas to raise funds for American prisoners of war. After the war, he worked as timekeeper for Drake Utah Grove Army Contractors based in Manila.

Rustia began his movie career in the late 1940s as an extra in Sampaguita Pictures’ Ang Kamay ng Diyos (The Hand of God), 1947. After several movies, he became a supporting actor in Consuelo Osorio’s Taga-Ilog (River Dwellers), 1951. He gained fame as a character actor in the films Sarswelista (Sarsuwela Player), 1952; Pitong Gatang (Seven Chupas), 1959; Konsiyerto ng Kamatayan (Concert of Death), Pitong Gabi sa Paris (Seven Nights in Paris), Mga Yapak na Walang Bakas (Footprints without a Trace), and The Flash Elorde Story, 1961; Kapag Buhay ang Inutang (When Life Is Taken), 1962; Dalawang Lahi, Isang Dugo (Two Races, One Blood), 1965; Hanapin si Leo Baron (Find Leo Baron), 1966; and Playpen, 1971. In the Cultural Center of the Philippines television series Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1993, he played Kapitan Tiago.

Rustia was nominated by the Maria Clara Awards as Best Supporting Actor for his performance in Gerardo de Leon’s Sisa, 1951. He was a five-time nominee of the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in various categories: as lead actor for Haring Tulisan (Bandit King), 1956; as scriptwriter and supporting actor for Alaala Kita (Thinking of You), 1961; as scriptwriter for Perlas ng Silangan (Pearl of the Orient), 1969; and as supporting actor for Psycho Sex Killer, 1970. He received the FAMAS Best Supporting Actor award for Pedro Penduko, 1954. He won Best Single Performance by an Actor in the Star Awards for Television for his performance in an episode of Lovingly Yours, Helen, 1992. He was honored with other tributes: from the Screenwriters’ Guild of the Philippines, a plaque of appreciation for his achievements as scriptwriter, 1983; from the Vic Silayan Foundation, the lifetime achievement award for acting in 1989; and from the Gintong Ina/Ama Foundation, the award for arts and culture in 1989. Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja

RUTA, ROLLY(Rolando Celestino Ruta) b. Naga City, Camarines Sur 29 May 1948. Sound engineer. His parents are Celestino and Juanita Ruta, who owned a farm in Bicol. He and his wife, Azucena, have two children. Ruta attended grade school at Libmanan Elementary School and finished high school at Colegio de Santisimo Rosario, Naga City. He is a graduate of electronics engineering from FEATI University. He handled various jobs as technician at Carlsound Electronics Corporation, Malacañan Palace Press Office, and National Media Production Center because of which he was able to travel abroad. In Japan, he trained under Aiko Recording Studio for three months and another three months in Seiko Recording Company. He also trained in sound recording during visits to London and the United States. He taught film production classes in New Era University from 1999 to 2004.

Ruta’s first commercial movie is Lea Productions’ Kapitan Kulas (Captain Kulas), 1975, directed by LambertoV.Avellana. After this film, he accepted the offer of Antonio Dulalia to head the sound studio of Magnatech Omni. Ruta expanded it from one to four studios, so that it could handle postproduction work on four films simultaneously.

Ruta is a multi-awarded sound director. He won two Best Sound awards from the Filipino AcademyofMovieArtsandSciences for Bukas Luluhod ang Mga Tala (Tomorrow the Stars Will Kneel), 1984, and Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig? (Where Does Love Hide?), 1987. He also won five awards for sound from the FilmAcademyof thePhilippines (FAP) for Bukas Luluhod ang Mga Tala; Paradise Inn, 1985; Lumuhod Ka sa Lupa (Kneel on the Ground), 1986, Balweg: The Rebel Priest, 1987; and Gawa Na ang Bala Na Papatay sa Iyo (The Bullet That Will Kill You Has Been Made), 1988. He won two Gawad Urian trophies for Best Sound for Bakit May Pag-ibig Pa (Wherefore Love), 1979, shared with Teddy Ramos and Vic Macamay; and for Ang Pumatay nang Dahil sa Iyo (To Kill for You), 1989. He won three awards for sound from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Himala (Miracle), 1982, Ano ang Kulay ng Mukha ng Diyos? (What Is the Color of God’s Face?), 1985, and Andres Manambit: Angkan ng Matatapang (Andres Manambit: Clan of the Brave), 1992. Ruta is in the FAP Hall of Fame with the distinction of being the only one to have won the awards for five consecutive years, 1984-88. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

SACDALAN, FELIPE(Felipe Jordan Sacdalan) aka Ka Ipe. b. Calumpit, Bulacan 30 Apr 1916. Cinematographer. He is the son of Jacinto Sacdalan and Antonina Jordan. Cinematographer Higino Fallorina is his cousin. He finished his elementary and secondary schooling in Malolos, Bulacan. He began working as a stillman at Filippine Films. From 1947 to 1948 he took up cinematography at the Motion Picture Institute in Birmingham, Michigan. He worked in more than 100 feature films and documentaries through the years—among them, The Day of the Trumpet, 1957, and Man on the Run, 1958.

Among his other films are Now and Forever, 1954; The Scavengers, 1959; Sa Mata ng Diyos (In God’s Eyes), 1960; Cry of the Battle, 1963; Moro Witch Doctor, 1964; Arizona Kid, 1970; Lollipops and Roses, 1971; Rio Tigre (Tiger River), 1972; Carnival Song, 1974; and Mababagsik na Anghel (Cruel Angels), 1975.

Sacdalan won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) awards for Best Cinematography for the following works: May Bakas ang Lumipas (Traces of the Past), 1954; Mga Yapak na Walang Bakas (Footprints without a Trace), 1961; Ito ang Pilipino (Behold the Filipino), 1966; Dalawang Mukha ng Tagumpay (Two Faces of Victory), 1973; and Krimen: Kayo ang Humatol (Crime: You Be the Judge), 1974. He was elevated to the FAMAS Hall of Fame in 1974. He also received the Best Photography award from the Manila Film Festival for Playpen, 1971, the Pioneer Award from the Film Academy of the Philippines in 1987, and a recognition award from the Filipino Society of Cinematographers in 1987. Written byLena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

SACRIS, LYLE (Lyle Edward Carmelo Nemenzo Sacris) b. Cebu City 15 Jul 1975. Cinematographer, director. He is the son of Eduardo M. Sacris and Carolina Nemenzo. He earned his bachelor’s degree in film and audiovisual communication at the University of the Philippines Diliman.

Early in his career, Sacris won awards for the music videos he directed for Slapshock, Teeth, Kyla, Chicosci, and Rivermaya. His first feature-length film as director was Akala Mo (Your Presumption), 2001. His second film, First Time, 2003, competed in the 2005 Singapore International Film Festival and was exhibited in the 2005 Puchon International Fantastic Film Festival. Both were produced by Viva Films.

As a director of photography, he collaborated with directors Erik Matti, Quark Henares, Ato Bautista, Joel Lamangan, and Keith Sicat. He photographed the segment by Henares in the omnibus Wag Kang Lilingon (Don’t Look Back), 2006, as well as Henares’s Super Noypi, 2006, and Rakenrol, 2011. He worked with Bautista on Blackout, 2007, and Carnivore, 2008. He was cinematographer of Lamangan’s Zsazsa Zaturnnah Ze Moveeh (Zsazsa Zaturnah: The Movie), 2006, and Desperadas 2 (All They Need Is More Love), 2008; Keith Sicat’s Room 213, 2008; and Matti’s The Arrival, 2010.

For his work in Exodus: Tales from the Enchanted Kingdom, 2005, directed by Matti, he won Best Cinematography in the 2005 Metro Manila Film Festival. For Blue Moon, 2005, he won Best Cinematography in the 2006 Maria Clara Awards. His work in the independent film Yanggaw, 2011, directed by Richard Somes, won Best Cinematography in the 2011 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival. Transit, 2013, directed by Hannah Espia, won for him Best Cinematography in the 2013 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival.

Sacris is also a television commercial director. Written by Patrick Campos

SALCEDO, LEOPOLDO(Leopoldo Ganal Salcedo) b. San Roque, Cavite 13 Mar 1912. d. Pasig City 11 Jun 1998. Movie actor. His parents are Juan Salcedo and Basilia Ganal. He enrolled to become a priest at San Vicente de Paul Seminary but quit after a year. He was married five times and sired 14 children.

Salcedo joined the bodabil troupe of Borromeo Lou at age 17. He was president of the Motion Picture Guild of the Philippines in 1952, which had Eddie Romero as secretary and Carmen Rosales as treasurer. Salcedo made over 200 pictures in a career that spanned more than five decades. In 1950, he set up his own Leopoldo Salcedo Productions, which made about 13 movies.

Salcedo first appeared in Jose Nepomuceno’s Sawing Palad (The Unfortunate), 1934. In 1937, he appeared with Rogelio de la Rosa and Alma Bella in Magkapatid (Brothers). He came out in Lamberto V. Avellana’s first directorial work, Sakay, 1939, and Cariñosa (Sweet), 1940, with Amparo Karagdag. In Huling Habilin (Last Will), 1940, he was paired with Rosa del Rosario. He made 10 films for LVN before World War II broke out, among them Ararong Ginto (Golden Plow), 1941, and Principe Teñoso, 1942. During the Japanese Occupation, Salcedo became a mainstay of the Philippine Artists League of Avellana and Sammy Rodriguez at the Avenue Theater. He continued appearing at the Apollo Theater after the war.

His other films include Dawn of Freedom, 1944, a Japanese war movie by Gerardo Leon; Death March, 1946, directed by Lamberto V. Avellana; Fort Santiago, 1946; Kamagong, 1947; Alias Sakim (Alias Greedy), 1947, a Ramon Estella movie, his first for Premiere Productions; Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), 1947, with Rosa del Rosario; Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), 1948, as one of the seven children of Rosa Aguirre; Puting Bantayog (White Monument), 1948, with Norma Blancaflor and Armando Goyena; Capas, 1949, about a Japanese concentration camp during World War II; Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1950; Tinig ng Tagumpay (Voice of Victory), 1953; Looban (Alley), 1953; Tampalasan (Bandit), 1953; Highway 54, 1953; Mister Dupung, 1954, a reference to his dark complexion, with Gloria Sevilla and Carol Varga; Parole, 1954; Divisoria, Quiapo, 1955; Zorina and Sumpa at Pangako (Vow and Promise), 1958; Sandra, 1959; Escape to Paradise, 1960; Lost Battalion, 1962; The Raiders of Leyte Gulf, 1963; Cry of Battle, 1963; Scout Rangers, 1964; Destination Vietnam, 1968; Kumander Dimas (Commander Dimas), 1968; Bimbo, 1969; Ako’y Tao, May Dugo at Laman (I Am a Man, with Blood and Flesh), 1970; Beast of the Yellow Night, 1971; One More Chance, 1972; Savage Sisters, 1974; Anino ng Araw (Shadow of the Sun), 1975; Burlesk Queen (Burlesque Queen), 1977; Anak sa Una, Kasal sa Ina (First Child, Married to Mother), 1978; Bihagin: Bilibid Boys (Capture: Bilibid Boys), 1981; The One-Armed Executioner, 1983; Pieta: Ikalawang Aklat (Pieta: Second Chapter), 1984; Private Show, 1985; Boy Negro, 1988; and Sakay, 1993.

He portrayed Elias in Gerardo de Leon’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1961. But his most notable role was for de Leon’s The Moises Padilla Story, 1961, which won for him the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Actor award. Fifteen years later he obtained his second FAMAS trophy as Best Supporting Actor for his performance in Eddie Romero’s Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were … What Happens to You Now?), 1976. He was honored with a tribute from the Movie Workers Welfare Foundation Inc in 1985 and received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Film Academy of the Philippines in 1989. In 1994, the Gawad Urian presented Salcedo with a Lifetime Achievement Award. Written byDanny Villanueva, updated by Pamela Mathiel Lopez

SALUMBIDES, VICENTE(Vicente Aranillo Salumbides) b. Lopez, Quezon 3 Aug 1893. d. 7 Aug 1979. Movie producer, director, actor. His parents are Pio Salumbides and Trinidad Aranillo. He married Rosario H. Panganiban by whom he had eight children. He left law school in Southern California, USA, to join the Allied Forces in France under Gen Pershing in World War I. He returned to the Philippines to finish law studies in 1922, working as company lawyer of the Philippine Trust Company.

Salumbides used to be an “extra” in the Famous Players Studio in Hollywood. Upon his return to the Philippines, he pioneered in the local movie industry, initially working with Jose Nepomuceno as cinematographer. His first movie was Miracles of Love, 1925, which he wrote, directed, edited, produced, and acted in. The cast included Elizabeth Cooper aka Dimples, Jose Carvajal, Hermogenes Ilagan, and Juanita Angeles. A box office hit, it was hailed by no less than Msgr Gregorio Aglipay and Felipe Buencamino. Miracles introduced many firsts in the local film industry. Makeup, as used by Hollywood actors, eliminated dark shadows on-screen. The close-up shot maximized the effectivity of the medium. The “cut back” scene emphasized suspense. To ward off prejudices against locally made films, Salumbides recruited the local elite and students of exclusive schools in Manila to appear in Fate or Consequence, 1926, and in his other films. His third movie, The Soul Saver, 1927, is the story of his life and romance and includes some footage of his actual wedding with Panganiban.

After working as a delegate to the 1935 Constitutional Convention, he returned to filmmaking in 1936. In 1938, he resigned as production manager of Parlatone Hispano-Filipino Inc and formed the Salumbides Film Co Ltd. In 1939, Salumbides formed a limited partnership with Aurora A. Quezon and other partners, producing Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), based on Francisco Baltazar’s awit (metrical romance). He made two other films for his own company—Anghel na Tukso (Tempting Angel), 1940, and Krisantemo (Chrysanthemum), 1941—and directed with Manuel Conde LVN Pictures’ trend-setting colorful spectacle Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941, before World War II broke out. He authored one of the first books on Philippine movies titled Motion Pictures in the Philippines, 1952. Written byGlecy Atienza

SALVADOR, AUGUSTO (Augusto Tagareta Salvador) b. Tondo, Manila 8 Aug 1940. Movie editor and director. His parents are Atilano Salvador, a Premiere Productions film editor, and Lucia Tagoreta.

Salvador was one of the country’s most sought after film editors. Among his notable films are Ang Daigdig Ko’y Ikaw (You Are My World), 1965; Divina Gracia (Divine Grace), 1970; Ang Leon at ang Daga (The Lion and the Mouse), 1975; City after Dark, 1980; Ano ang Kulay ng Mukha ng Diyos? (What Is the Color of the Face of God?), 1985; Sa Diyos Lang Ako Susuko (Only to God Will I Surrender), 1990; Hagedorn, 1996; Hostage, 2001; and Ang Panday (The Blacksmith), 2009.

Salvador was elevated to the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Hall of Fame for being a five-time winner of the Best Editing award for the following films: Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels without Heaven), 1970; Gumising Ka … Maruja (Wake Up … Maruja), 1978; Durugin si Totoy Bato (Crush Totoy the Rock), 1979; Partida (Margin), 1985; and Muslim Magnum .347, 1986. From the Film Academy of the Philippines, he received Best Editing awards for Batuigas II: Pasukuin si Waway (Batuigas II: Get Waway to Surrender), 1984; Lumuhod Ka sa Lupa (Kneel on the Ground), 1986, and Pinulot Ka Lang sa Lupa (You Were Merely Picked from the Ground), 1987. He received the Gawad Urian Best Editing award for Joe Pring, 1989. He also won editing awards for Dugo ng Bayan (Blood of the Nation), 1973, in the Olongapo Film Festival and for Mediavillo in the Iloilo Film Festival, 1974. Written byRamon Jocson, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

SALVADOR, LEROY(Joseph Leroy Ramirez Salvador) b. Hawaii, USA 8 Mar 1929. d. Makati 24 Sep 1991. Movie and television actor, director, producer. He was the eldest of 48 siblings sired by actor-director Lou Salvador Sr. His mother, Gloria Ramirez, was a bodabil star and dancing partner of Salvador Sr. He is half-brother to actors Phillip Salvador, Ross Rival, Lou Salvador Jr, Edward Gomez, Ding Salvador, Alona Alegre, Mina Aragon, and Chona Sandoval. Two of his children are also in the movies, Deborah Sun and Joebelle Salvador.

He began his career in show business as a chorus boy in his father’s stage productions, doubling as a courier for the underground during the Japanese Occupation. After World War II, he appeared as an extra in LVN’s Orasang Ginto (Golden Clock), 1946, followed by a bit role as the young Jaime de la Rosa in Aladin, 1946. His other early films are Dalawang Pag-ibig (Two Loves), 1953; Waray-Waray (Visayan Lass) and Doce Pares (Twelve Pairs), 1954; Karnabal (Carnival), Palasyong Pawid (Palm Palace), Darling Ko (My Darling), and Isa-Dalawa-Tatlo (One-Two-Three), 1955; and Charito, I Love You, 1956.

After his stint with LVN, Salvador turned to directing. Among the films that he directed are Puro Labis, Puro Kulang (All the More, All the Less), 1962; Gonzales, 1970; Pag-ibig, Magkano Ka? (Love, How Much Are You Worth?) and Baby Doll, 1978; Isang Araw, Isang Buhay (One Day, One Life) and Gising sa Magdamag (All Through the Night), 1979; Tinik sa Dibdib (Thorn in the Heart), 1985; Captain Barbell and Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (I Wish This Were Forever), 1986.

In 1980, he established Showbiz Productions. His first film as producer was Basag (Cracked), 1980. He also produced television shows like Showbiz with the Salvadors and Tang Tarangtang.

A staunch supporter of the Cebuano film industry, he is credited with having directed two of its finest films: Badlis sa Kinabuhi (Life Lines) 1969, and Matud Nila (They Say), 1991.

Salvador was hailed as Asia’s Best Supporting Actor at the 1960 Asian Film Festival held in Tokyo for his performance in Biyaya ng Lupa (Blessings of the Land), 1959. He won the Best Supporting Actor award twice from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), the first time for his portrayal of a deaf-mute in Huk sa Bagong Pamumuhay (Huk in a New Life), 1953, and again for Init (Heat), 1979. The FAMAS also nominated him as Best Supporting Actor for Pilipino Kostum, No Touch (Filipino Custom, No Touching), 1955, and as Best Director, twice, for Kayo ang Humatol (You Be the Judge), 1963, and Badlis sa Kinabuhi. He was nominated by the Gawad Urian as Best Supporting Actor for Mga Bilanggong Birhen (Caged Virgins), 1977.Written by Galileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja

SALVADOR, LOU SR(Lou Schultze Salvador) aka Van Ludor, Chipopoy. b. Tacloban, Leyte 7 Jul 1905. d. 1 Mar 1973. Movie and stage director, actor. His parents are Juan Salvador, a Spaniard, and Fermina Schultze, a German mestiza. He had his elementary education at Ateneo de Manila and Sampaloc Intermediate School. He finished high school at Manila North High School and two years of commerce at Jose Rizal College. He is reported to have sired 48 children, some of whom are in the movies: Leroy Salvador, Alona Alegre, Lou Salvador Jr, Chona Sandoval, Ross Rival, Mina Aragon, Phillip Salvador, and Ramon Salvador. Leroy’s mother was Lou’s dancing partner, Gloria Ramirez. The mother of Chona and Lou Jr is Jacinta. Alona’s mother is Inday Jalandoni, former LVN actor. Phillip, Mina, and Ramon’s mother is Corazon Reyes.

Salvador’s career in show business began when at age 15 he joined the troupe of Cebuano relative Lou Borromeo, as dancer. He was also a chorus boy for his sister, Miami, then a bodabil star. In 1925, he became known to the stage world as comedian “Chipopoy.”

After World War II, he became the most successful stage show impresario in the country. He established the first bodabil groups during the American occupation, which appeared in the Apollo, Alegria, Lotus, and Manila, as well as Cine Ideal in Avenida, Plaza Teatro in Echague, Heights Theater in Quezon City, and Inday Theater near Estero Cegado. He discovered and helped to make famous such names as Chiquito, Bentot, Cachupoy, and Pepe Pimentel, and singers like Diomedes Maturan and Eddie Peregrina.

From stage shows, he entered the movies as actor in films like Sa Tokyo Ikinasal (Married in Tokyo), 1948, and Genghis Khan, 1950, and as director of films like Doce Pares (Twelve Pairs), 1954; Tagapagmana (Heir), 1955; Bad Boy, 1957; and Barkada (Gang), 1958. He established his own production outfit, Master Films, and challenged the movies of the Big Four with such works as Krus na Daan (Crossroads), 1960; Alias Golden Boy, 1963; and Mestisang Bangus (Half-Breed), 1963. He also appeared in and directed for television the show Pamilya Kangkarot (Kangkarot Family), based on and featuring members of the Salvador family.

In 1991, the Film Academy of the Philippines paid a posthumous tribute to Lou Salvador Sr and the Salvador clan for their contributions to the Philippine movie and entertainment industry from 1920 to the present. Written byGalileo Zafra

SALVADOR, PHILLIP (Phillip Reyes Salvador) aka Ipe b. Manila 21 Aug 1953. Movie, television, and stage actor. His parents are Corazon Reyes and Lou Salvador Sr, who was also known as the “Master Showman” of bodabil. He studied at Jose Rizal College, where he pursued a course in commerce. He belongs to the famous clan of show business. Brother Ramon Salvador is a film production manager. Sister Mina Aragon is an actor and producer of Viva Films. Salvador is half-brother to the late actor-director Leroy Salvador, Chona Sandoval, actor-producer Alona Alegre of AA Productions, and actors Lou Salvador Jr, Ross Rival, Edward Gomez, and Ding Salvador. Actors Deborah Sun and Jobelle Salvador are his nieces. He has a child with actor and TV host Kris Aquino.

Salvador started his movie career in FPJ Productions’ Adios, Mi Amor (Goodbye, My Love), 1971, as the third person in a love triangle with Susan Roces and Eddie Gutierrez. In his next film, Basta’t Basketball (As Long as It’s Basketball), 1971, he shared star billing with Paquito Diaz, Romy Diaz, and other FPJ cagers. The years after were spent in virtual obscurity as he played minor and insignificant roles in films like Batya’t Palu-Palo (Laundry Tub and Wood Beater), 1974; Alupihang Dagat (Sea Centipede), 1975; Bato Sa Buhangin (Rock on the Sand), 1976; Sapagkat Kami’y mga Misis Lamang (Because We Are Only Wives), 1976; and Maligno (Evil Spirit), 1977.

One day he received a call from director Lino Brocka, asking him to audition for the role of a guardia civil (constable) in Lahing Pilipino (The Filipino Race), a National Media Production Center movie. The meeting with Brocka, who saw his potential as a dramatic star, led to the re-launching of his movie career, with choice parts in films like Mananayaw (Dancer), Rubia Servios, Ang Tatay Kong Nanay (My Father the Mother), and Gumising Ka … Maruja (Wake Up … Maruja), all in 1978; Init (Heat), 1979; Nakaw na Pag-ibig (Stolen Love) and Bona, 1980. But it was in Jaguar (Guard), 1979, that Salvador made his mark as a gifted dramatic actor. Orapronobis (Fight for Us), 1989, was the last film he did with Brocka. From this point on, Salvador became known as one of the most popular action stars in Philippine show business. His other films include Uubusin Ko ang Lahi Mo (I Will Exterminate Your Clan), 1991; Nandito Ako (I Am Here), 1993; Ka Hector (Comrade Hector), 1995; Hanggang May Hininga (While I Am Breathing), 1996; Berdugo (Executioner), 1998; Huwag Mo Akong Subukan (Do Not Test Me), 2000; Kaaway Hanggang Hukay (Enemy until Death), 2001; Baler, 2008; Rosario, 2010; Hitman, 2012; and 10,000 Hours, 2013.

Salvador also appeared in PETA stage productions: as Tony Javier in Larawan (Portrait), based on Nick Joaquin’s play, A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino; and as Stanley Kowalski in Flores para los Muertos (Flowers for the Dead), an adaptation of Tenessee Williams’s A Streetcar Named Desire.

Salvador got 11 Best Actor awards: for Cain at Abel (Cain and Abel), 1982, Gawad Urian and Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP); Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983, Gawad Urian; Bayan Ko: Kapit Sa Patalim (My Coutry: Gripping the Knife’s Edge), 1985, Gawad Urian, Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), FAP, and Catholic Mass Media Awards; Balweg: The Rebel Priest, 1987, FAP; Boy Negro, 1988, FAP; Ka Hector, 1994, FAP; and Bobby Barbers: Parak (Bobby Barbers: Police), 1997, FAMAS. Salvador also won Best Supporting Actor in the 2008 and 2009 Metro Manila Film Festival for the films Baler and Ang Panday (The Blacksmith). The Gawad Urian named Salvador as Actor of the Decade 1980-89. Written byGalileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

SAMPAGUITA PICTURES INC (SPI) A group of entrepreneurs headed by Representative Pedro Vera established Sampaguita Pictures Inc in 1937. The group included Judge (later senator) Jose O. Vera, Rep Jose Zulueta, Col Antonio Torres, Dr Catalino Gavino, Dr Pedro Abecilla, and Doña Apolonia vda de Vera. The person they chose to head movie production was Luis F. Nolasco.

Nolasco came to SPI with some of the big names in local movies at that time: Carlos Vander Tolosa, Elsa Oria, and Rogelio de la Rosa. With William “Billy” Smith as technical adviser, the Vera family built the studio on a four-hectare lot in the New Manila suburb where sound could more easily be controlled during shooting. On this property, the Sampaguita Studio was born.

The Silos brothers, each one an expert in his own field, took charge of the various production departments: Octavio and Manuel in screenplay and direction, Augusto in laboratory and film processing, and Cesar in cinematography. Their first movie was Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), a musical love story based on the immortal composition of the late Nicanor Abelardo. It starred the “Singing Sweetheart of the Philippines,” Elsa Oria, with matinee idol Rogelio de la Rosa. Directed by Carlos Vander Tolosa, it opened at the Grand Theater on 27 Dec 1937.

The success of their initial venture prompted SPI producers to follow it up immediately with other grand musical productions: Paroparong Bukid (Country Butterfly), 1938, starring Elsa Oria and new leading man Rudy Concepcion; Madaling Araw (Break of Dawn), 1938, with Elsa Oria, Ely Ramos, Yolanda Marquez, and Ernesto La Guardia; and Dalisay (Chaste), 1939, starring Fely Vallejo, Rogelio de la Rosa, and Corazon Noble. SPI also made melodramas with actors Tita Duran, Rosario Moreno, Carlos Padilla, Miguel Anzures, Pedro Faustino, Rosa Aguirre, Nanding Anzures, Flor de Jazmin, and Angel Esmeralda.

Toward the end of 1939, SPI “pirated” Carmen Rosales, the new contract star of its rival studio, Excelsior Pictures, to launch the biggest box-office love team of the next three decades, Carmen Rosales and Rogelio de la Rosa. Their initial movie, Takip-silim (Twilight), 1939, was followed by Señorita (Young Mistress), Lambingan (Romance), and Colegiala (Coed), all in 1940; Panambitan (Lament) and Tampuhan (Lovers’ Quarrel), 1941; Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 1954; and Ang Tangi Kong Pag-ibig (My Only Love), 1955.

The studio did not function from 1942 to 1945 because of World War II, but resumed operations in 1946 under Judge Jose O. Vera after its president Rep Pedro Vera died. It produced Gerardo de Leon’s So Long, America, 1946, and Isumpa Mo, Giliw (Make a Vow, My Love), 1947. In 1951, SPI suffered a setback when the studio was gutted by a big fire that destroyed all its master negatives. Using the ruins as a studio set, SPI made a low-budget movie, Roberta, starring an eight-year-old actor, Tessie Agana. The film broke box-office records and put SPI back into business, this time under the leadership of Dr Jose R. Perez, the husband of Judge Vera’s only daughter, Azucena, who would be known in the industry as the “Builder of Stars.” Perez was succeeded after his death by his eldest daughter, Marichu Vera Perez-Maceda.

For three decades up to his demise in 1975, Dr Perez gave the local movie industry some of its biggest names: Gloria Romero, Luis Gonzales, Ramon Revilla, Dolphy, Chichay, Lolita Rodriguez, Pancho Magalona, Rita Gomez, Susan Roces, Amalia Fuentes, Romeo Vasquez, Eddie Gutierrez, German Moreno, Rudy Fernandez, Vilma Santos, Tirso Cruz III, and Nora Aunor.

The roster of Sampaguita award-winning films include the following: Baguio Cadets, 1950, Maria Clara Best Cinematography (Higino Fallorina); Mapuputing Kamay (White Hands), 1950, Maria Clara Best Supporting Actress (Alicia Vergel); Prinsesa at Pulubi (The Princess and the Pauper), 1951, Maria Clara Best Director (Enrique Moreno aka Eddie Romero) and Best Child Actress (Tessie Agana); Roberta, 1951, Maria Clara Best Supporting Actress (Rosa Mia), Best Cinematography (Higino Fallorina), and Producer of the Year (Judge Jose O. Vera); Basahang Ginto (Rags of Gold), 1952, Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Actress (Alicia Vergel); Ang Asawa Kong Amerikana (My American Wife), 1953, Asian Film Festival Best Screenplay (Luciano B. Carlos); Inspirasyon (Inspiration), 1953, FAMAS Best Actress (Carmen Rosales) and Best Supporting Actress (Katy de la Cruz); Bondying, 1954, FAMAS Best Actor (Fred Montilla) and film editor (Jose H. Tarnate); Dalagang Ilocana (Ilocano Maiden), 1954, FAMAS Best Actress (Gloria Romero); Lupang Kayumanggi (Brown Land), 1955, FAMAS Best Supporting Actor (Panchito Alba); Gilda, 1956, FAMAS Best Actress (Lolita Rodriguez); Tumbando Caña (Bottoms Up), 1956, FAMAS Best Supporting Actress (Rosa Mia); Busabos (Slave), 1957, FAMAS Best Supporting Actress (Etang Discher); Sino ang Maysala? (Who Is Guilty?), 1957, FAMAS Best Actress (Paraluman) and Best Story (Fausto J.
