Galauran); Taga sa Bato (Cut on a Stone), 1957, FAMAS Best Actor (Van de Leon) and Best Supporting Actor (Eddie Garcia); Ako ang Maysala (I Am Guilty), 1958, Asian Film Festival Best Actor (Romeo Vasquez); Alaalang Banal (Sacred Memory), 1958, FAMAS Best Story (Susana de Guzman); Anino ni Bathala (Shadow of God), 1958, FAMAS Best Supporting Actress (Marlene Dauden); Condenado (Condemned), 1958, FAMAS Best Supporting Actor (Eddie Garcia); Talipandas (Wayward), 1958, FAMAS Best Actress (Rita Gomez); Kamandag (Venom), 1959, FAMAS Best Director (Jose Padilla Jr), Best Actor (Van de Leon), Best Supporting Actress (Marlene Dauden), Best Screenplay (Ding de Jesus), Best Cinematography (Felipe Santiago), Best Sound (Joseph Straight), and Best Editing (Jose H. Tarnate); Tanikalang Apoy (Chain of Fire), 1959, FAMAS Best Supporting Actor (Eddie Garcia); Pinagbuklod ng Langit (Joined by Heaven), 1969, FAMAS Best Director (Eddie Garcia), Best Screenplay (Emmanuel H. Borlaza), Best Cinematography (Felipe Santiago), Best Music (Restie Umali), and Best Editing (Jose H. Tarnate); Masikip Maluwang: Paraisong Parisukat (Narrow and Wide, Square Eden), 1977, FAMAS Best Music (Ryan Cayabyab); Masarap, Masakit ang Umibig (Joy and Pain of Loving), 1977, FAMAS Best Supporting Actor (Mat Ranillo III); and Pakawalan Mo Ako (Release Me), 1981, FAMAS Best Actress (Vilma Santos) and Best Music (Lutgardo Labad). Batch ’81 won the first Film Academy of the Philippines Best Picture award and the Gawad Urian for Best Screenplay (Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Raquel Villavicencio, and Mike de Leon). It was shown at the Directors’ Fortnight at the 1982 Cannes International Film Festival.

The Sampaguita collection of extant film materials is archived in the storage facility of the National Film Archive of the Film Development Council of the Philippines. However, copies have been acquired by the film archive of ABS-CBN, which continues to broadcast Sampaguita films on television. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

SANCHEZ, CARIDAD(Caridad Yuson Sanchez) b. Mandaue, Cebu 1 Aug 1936. Movie and television actor. The youngest of 15 children of Marcos Sanchez and Sofia Yuson, she attended Mandaue Elementary School and, after high school at the University of the Visayas, she took a secretarial course. She married Vicente Babao with whom she has two children. She and her classmate Gloria Sevilla were active in dramatics in the university. Sanchez started as a radio talent on DYRC in Cebu in the early 1950s.

She appeared in Cebuano movies, usually in kontrabida (antagonist) or character roles, such as in Dimakaling and Hukmanan sa Yuta (Court on Earth), 1956; Hain Ka Na Anak Ko? (Where Are You, My Child?), Politika (Politics), Remember Erlinda, and Garbosa (Haughty Woman), 1957; and Salingsing sa Kasakit (Pitiful Children), 1958. Around 1957, she began acting in Tagalog movies, appearing first in LVN pictures, like Hiwaga ng Pag-ibig (Mystery of Love), 1957; Malvarosa, Casa Grande (Mansion), and Austerity Love, 1958; Mucho Dinero (Plenty of Money), Linda Mora, Barrio Fiesta, Detective Maturan, Bayanihan (Community Spirit), and Tuko sa Madre Kakaw (Gecko at Madre Cacao), 1959; Navy Blues, Dahlia, and Awit ng mga Dukha (Song of the Poor), 1960; Blue Diamonds, Jikiri, Magnum, and Kilabot Maghiganti (Deadly Revenge), 1962; Maria Dolores, Limbo Rock, Mga Batong Hiyas (Precious Stones), Ang mga Lawin (The Hawks), and Asyang ng La Loma (Asyang of La Loma), 1963. Among her other films are The Untouchable Family, 1988; The Flor Contemplacion Story, 1995; Bagong Buwan (New Moon), 2001; Saan Nagtatago si Happiness? (Where Does Happiness Hide?), 2008; and Botelya (Bottle), 2008.

In 1992, she appeared as Doña Victorina in the TV series Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. She has also been a mainstay in a number of TV dramas and sitcoms such as Wala Kang Paki (None of Your Business), 1970-72; Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fortune), 1978-84; Buddy-Buddy, 1980; Family 3+1, 1988; Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1999-2001; Tabing Ilog (Riverside), 1999-2003; Marimar, 2007; Diva, 2010; Pahiram ng Sandali (Lend Me a Moment), 2013; and The Borrowed Wife, 2014.

She won several awards for her performances on the big screen and on television: Best Actress from the Citizens Council for Mass Media (CCMM) for Santiago, 1970; Best Supporting Actress from the Star Awards for Kapag Napagod ang Puso (When the Heart Tires), 1988; Best Supporting Actress in a TV comedy series from the CCMM for Wala Kang Paki, 1971; Best Actress for human development and value formation from the Catholic Mass Media Awards for the TV drama series Gulong ng Palad, 1979; and Best Actress in a comedy series from Star Awards for Television for Family 3+1, 1990 and 1993. Written byErlinda K. Alburo, updated by Mario Mendez Jr, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

SANCHEZ, SHERAD ANTHONY(Sherad Anthony Señoror Sanchez) b. Davao City 11 Aug 1984. Filmmaker. His parents are Dr Augustus Sanchez and Beverly Señoror. He received a bachelor of arts degree in communication from Ateneo de Manila University in 2008. He also participated in the Fusion Arts Program of the University of Southern California in 2007.

Sanchez started with films like Apple, Coming to Pass, Iyak ni Maria (Maria’s Cry), and Abstraction, 2005. Then in 2006, he directed Huling Balyan ng Buhi o Ang Sinalirap nga Asoy Nila (The Last Priestess of Buhi or The Woven Stories of the Other), winner of Cinema One Originals Film Festival Best Picture, Best Ensemble, Best Director, and Best Screenplay. In 2007, the film won the Prix du Premier at Fid-Marsielles, Marsielles, France; First Feature Prize at Osian Film Festival, New Delhi, India; One Future Prize at Munich Film Festival, Germany; and First Feature Competition Award at Cinefan Festival of Asian Arab Cinema.

His second feature, Imburnal (Sewer), 2008, won Best Picture, Best Screenplay, and Best Cinematography at Cinema One Originals Film Festival. It was awarded the Digital Lokal Grand Prize for Best Feature at the 10th Cinemanila International Film Festival. At Jeonju International Film Festival in South Korea, it won Best Picture and was presented the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema Award. In the Southeast Asian Competition of the 2009 Bangkok International Film Festival, it was given a Special Mention citation. The experimental coming-of-age film of two young boys set in the slums of Davao City was bestowed the Cinema of the Future Award–Special Mention at the 2010 Buenos Aires International Festival of Independent Cinema in Argentina.

His other films include Balangay (Balangay Boat), 2010, which won the Grand Jury Prize in the Digital Lokal section of the 2010 Cinemanila International Film Festival, and Jungle Love, 2012, which got a Special Mention citation at Berlin PronFest.

Sanchez served as a consultant and member of the selection committee for the Cinema One Originals Film Festival.Written byRica Arevalo

SANTIAGO, CIRIO H. (Cirio Hermoso Santiago) aka Leonard Hermes. b. Manila 18 Jan 1936. d. Makati City 26 Sep 2008. Movie producer, director, and writer. His parents are movie producers Dr Ciriaco Santiago and Doña Adela Hermoso-Santiago of Premiere Productions and People’s Pictures. He was educated at Cecilio Apostol Elementary School and Ateneo de Manila University where he took up business administration, major in management. He was married to Annabelle T. Raymond with whom he had five children: Christopher, Cathy, Claudine, Cirio Jr, and Cyril. As a child, Santiago appeared in movies produced by his parents, together with brother Danilo and sister Digna.

At 19, Santiago directed his first picture, Paltik (Homemade Gun), 1955, starring Jose Padilla Jr and Efren Reyes. He eyed the foreign market early on and became the first Filipino producer to make successful films for international release. In 1956, he put up his own outfit, the C. Santiago Film Organization, to make films for export as well as for the domestic audience, co-producing Kim with Vietnam’s United Artists Film Co, 1956. He brought in Japanese capital for Tokyo 1960, 1957, a big film tapping Filipino actors and technicians. Among his early ventures as executive producer was Day of the Trumpet, 1957, which featured Hollywood actors and local talents and technicians.

When Premiere Productions shut down in 1962, he convinced his mother to revive it and produce big color spectacles, including El Pinoy Matador (Filipino Bullfighter), starring Dolphy, which was shot in Spain; Arizona Kid, 1970, filmed in Arizona, USA, starring Chiquito and Mamie Van Doren; and Lollipops and Roses, 1971, shot on location in Hollywood, starring Nora Aunor.

Santiago was one of the trailblazers in the early 1970s of the “Blaxploitation” genre: American adventure films featuring strong action heroes depicted by African-American actors. The film TNT Jackson, 1974, eventually developed a cult following. From the 1980s onward, he directed and produced more than 20 movies with producer Roger Corman of Hollywood, and with young American directors Jonathan Demme, Joe Dante, and Carl Franklin.

Santiago won the Asian Film Festival awards for Best Story and Best Screenplay for Ifugao, 1954, which was directed by Gerardo de Leon. In 1960, he was chosen as an awardee for the arts of the The Outstanding Young Men. In 2008, he was given a Dekada Cinemanila award by then president Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo at Malacañan Palace. Up until 2008, he was one of only four Filipino directors in the list of active members of the US Film Directors’ Guild.

He was appointed by then president Corazon Aquino as officer-in-charge of the Task Force on All Film-Related Government Agencies in 1986. He was chair of the Film Development Foundation of the Philippines Inc (predecessor of the Film Development Council of the Philippines) from 1986 to 1999. Santiago was president of Premiere Film International until 1996, and became its chair when it became Premiere Entertainment Productions, a publicly listed company at the Philippine Stock Exchange. Until 2005, Santiago actively wrote, directed, and produced movies. Gerardo de Leon, Eddie Romero, and Santiago were recognized by American director Quentin Tarantino as the Filipino directors whose American B-movies influenced him. Written byLena S. Pareja, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

SANTOS, CHARO(Ma. Rosario Navarro Santos-Concio) b. Calapan City 27 Oct 1955. Movie and television actor, producer. Her parents are Winifredo Santos and Nora Navarro. She took up mass communication at St. Paul College. In 2007, she studied management at Harvard Business School. She is married to Cesar Concio Jr. They have two sons and two granddaughters. She was the president and chief executive officer of ABS-CBN Corporation, 2008-16. Currently, she is the chief content officer of ABS-CBN Corporation and president of ABS-CBN University.

Santos began her career in the film industry after she won the title Miss Baron Travel Girl. She was introduced in Itim (Rites of May), 1976, and subsequently appeared in movies like Tisoy (Mestizo), 1976; Sino’ng Pipigil sa Pagpatak ng Ulan? (Who Will Stop the Rain from Falling?), Durugin si Totoy Bato (Crush Totoy the Rock), and Ang Alamat ni Julian Makabayan (The Legend of Julian Makabayan), 1979; Brutal, Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (Will Your Heart Beat Faster?), and Aguila, 1980; Kontrobersyal (Controversial), 1981; Batas sa Aking Kamay (The Law in My Hands), 1987; and Gumapang Ka sa Lusak (Dirty Affair), 1990.

Santos was line producer for Bancom Audiovision. She became executive producer of Vanguard Films, which released critically acclaimed movies such as Brutal, 1980; Salome and Kisapmata (In the Blink of an Eye), 1981; Sangley Point, 1985; and The Victor Corpus Story, 1987. She became president of Vision Films, which produced Lino Brocka’s Kailan Mahuhugasan ang Kasalanan? (When Will Sin Be Washed Away?), 1989; Mel Chionglo’s Nagsimula sa Puso (Obsession), 1990; and Chito Roño’s Kailan Ka Magiging Akin? (When Will You Be Mine?), 1991. She moved to Regal Films and then to ABS-CBN in 1986 to become production manager. She helped create Star Cinema. She has been the host and producer of the TV drama anthology Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) since 1991. As executive producer, she has produced hundreds of movies for Star Cinema.

Santos received various awards, including Best Actress in the 1978 Asian Film Festival in Sydney, Australia, for Itim. Later, she received the Ading Fernando Lifetime Achievement Award from the Star Awards for Television in 2007; the Manuel de Leon Award from the Film Academy of the Philippines in 2007; the Woman Super Achiever Award by CMO (Chief Marketing Officer) Asia in 2011; the Golden Wheel Award for Corporate Media Management from the Quezon City government in 2013; the FitzGerald Belfry Lifetime Achievement Award from Las Familias Unidas in 2014; and the Woman of the Year by the Asia-Pacific Stevie Awards in 2014. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

SANTOS, JUDY ANN(Judy Anne Lumagui Santos-Agoncillo) aka Juday. b. Manila 11 May 1978. Movie and television actor and host. She is the daughter of Carolina Lumagui and Manuel Dayrit Santos, and sister of actor Jeffrey Santos. She is married to television host Ryan Agoncillo. They have two children and an adopted daughter. She studied at Assumption Convent and Our Lady of Peace, both in Antipolo, Rizal. She finished her secondary education at Mount Carmel in Quezon City.

She was only eight when Santos broke into the show business industry through GMA Network’s Kaming mga Ulila (We the Orphans), 1986. Shortly after, she got her first lead role in IBC 13’s Ula: Ang Batang Gubat (Ula: The Jungle Kid), 1988.

Santos then became a resident talent of Regal Films where she was given the lead role as Crisanta in the film Silang mga Sisiw sa Lansangan (The Waifs of the Streets), 1988. In the same year, she did Sa Akin Pa Rin ang Bukas (Tomorrow Still Belongs to Me), Nasaan Ka, Inay? (Where Are You, Mother?), and Sana Mahalin Mo Ako (Hoping You Love Me) together with Nora Aunor and Tirso Cruz III. She appeared in a number of movies in supporting roles, such as Kung Maibabalik Ko Lang (If Only I Could Take It Back), 1989, with Maricel Soriano; Dyesebel, 1990; Madonna … Babaeng Ahas (Madonna … Snake Woman) and Impaktita (Young Female Monster), 1991, with Nida Blanca and Jean Garcia; Manila Boy, 1992, with Robin Padilla; and Father en Son, 1994, her first film with Dolphy.

While being active in movies, Santos continued doing TV programs. She is best known for her role as Mara to Gladys Reyes’s Clara in ABS-CBN’s hit drama Mara Clara, which ran from 1992 to 1997. This TV drama was adapted into film, Mara Clara: The Movie, 1996, under Star Cinema, also starring Santos and Reyes. (The TV series was revived in 2010 starring teen actors Kathryn Bernardo and Julia Montes as Mara and Clara, respectively.)

Santos’s successful team-up with actor Wowie de Guzman, which was nurtured in Mara Clara and another ABS-CBN TV drama Esperanza, 1997, resulted in a number of films starring the two, such as Sana Naman (Hopefully), Kung Alam Mo Lang (If You Only Knew), and Nasaan Ka Nang Kailangan Kita? (Where Were You When I Needed You?), 1996; Paano ang Puso Ko? (How about My Heart?), 1997; Muling Ibalik ang Tamis ng Pag-ibig (Bring Love’s Sweetness Back), 1998; Dito sa Puso Ko (Here in My Heart) and My Pledge of Love, 1999, among others.

Later, she was paired with Mark Anthony Fernandez in Ako Ba ang Nasa Puso Mo? (Am I the One in Your Heart?), 1997; with Cesar Montano in Sanggano (Hoodlum), 1997; and with Bong Revilla in Minsan Ko Lang Sasabihin (I Will Tell You This Only Once), 2000. ABS-CBN soon introduced Santos and Piolo Pascual as a new love team. They starred in movies—like Kahit Isang Saglit (Even for a Moment), 2000; Bakit ’Di Totohanin (Why Don’t We Make This Real), 2001; and Till There Was You, 2003—and in a TV series, Sa Puso Ko Iingatan Ka (I Will Cherish You in My Heart), 2001-2. Santos was also paired with Ryan Agoncillo whom she dated and later married in 2009. Some of the projects they did together were the TV comedy-drama Ysabella, 2007; the TV sitcom George and Cecil, 2009-10; and movies Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo (Partner, Participant, Partaker), 2006, its sequel Sakal, Sakali, Saklolo (Strangle, Perchance, Help), 2007, and My House Husband, 2011.

From doing dramatic films like Lupita A. Kashiwahara’s Babae (Woman), 1997, to starring in youth-oriented shows like Gimik (Hang Out), 1996, and Gimik: The Reunion, 1999, to showcasing comic flexibility in Isusumbong Kita sa Tatay Ko (I’ll Tell on You to My Father), 1999, with Fernando Poe Jr, and then shifting to action as a heroine in the TV series Krystala, 2004, and Basta’t Kasama Kita (As Long as I’m with You), 2003, opposite action star Robin Padilla, to producing and starring in the celebrated indie film Ploning, 2008, to hosting the cooking reality show Master Chef Pinoy Edition, 2012, and the Philippine franchise of the game show for toddlers Bet on Your Baby, 2013, she is truly a versatile actor and performer.

Some of the accolades she has received include the Golden Screen Awards Best Supporting Actress for Mano Po 2: My Home, 2003; the Gawad Urian and Golden Screen Awards Best Actress for Sabel, 2004; the Metro Manila Film Festival, Film Academy of the Philippines, and Star Awards Best Actress for Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo; the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Actress for Sakal, Sakali, Saklolo; the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival Best Ensemble award (shared with Iza Calzado, Janice de Belen, and Agot Isidro) for Mga Mumunting Lihim (Those Little Secrets), 2012; and the Dekada Award from the Golden Screen Awards, 2013. Written by Lorelie Legisniana

SANTOS, TONY(Antonio P. Santos Sr) b. Tondo, Manila 10 Apr 1920. d. Manila 7 Feb 1988. Movie and television actor and director. He is the father of movie and television actor Tony Santos Jr. During the Japanese Occupation, he was a chorus boy and jitterbug dancer who came to be known as one of the “Four Hotshots” at the Life Theater.

His first movie was Gregorio Fernandez’s Garrison 13, 1946, which was LVN’s third picture after World War II. He was introduced in Lamberto V. Avellana’s Lukso ng Dugo (Blood Ties), 1948, and from then on became one of the busiest actors of LVN, appearing in such films as Krus na Bituin (Star Cross), 1948; Parola (Lighthouse), 1949; Kontrabando (Contraband), 1950; Bayan o Pag-ibig (Love or Country), 1951; Korea, 1952; Dagohoy and Tatlong Labuyo (Three Hotheads), 1953; and Prinsipe Teñoso (Prince Teñoso), 1954.

His first directorial work was for LVN’s Banda Uno (Band Number One), 1955, starring Armando Goyena and Nita Javier. This was followed by Chaperon, 1956, with Emma Alegre; Dama Juana Gang (Lady Juana Gang), 1956, with Leroy Salvador and Charito Solis; Troop 11, 1957, with Lou Salvador Jr and Chona Sandoval; Eddie, Junior Detective, 1958, with Manding Claro and Eddie Rodriguez; Teenage Crush, 1960, with Tessie Quintana; and Tres Muskiteros (Three Musketeers), 1961, with Pancho Magalona. When LVN stopped producing in 1961, he freelanced with other movie companies, either as actor or director. He directed several films for Dalisay Pictures like Alyas Palos (Alias Palos), 1961, based on a popular komiks novel starring Bernard Bonnin; its sequel Palos Contra Gagamba (Palos against Spider), 1963; Bakas ni Gagamba (Spider’s Footsteps), 1962; Ang Lihim ni Gagamba (The Secret of Spider), 1964; Magnum, 1962; and 7 Atsay (Seven Housemaids), 1962, with comedians Chichay, Aruray, Patsy, Menggay, Dely Atay-atayan, Metring David, and Elizabeth Ramsey. Toward the end of his colorful movie career, he played father roles to the top stars of local cinema. He depicted the controversial tatang (father) of the fastest woman in Asia, Asian Games champion Lydia de Vega, in Medalyong Ginto (Gold Medallion), 1982. He also played the role of a father to Phillip Salvador in Hot Property, 1983; Lito Lapid in Pedro Tunasan, 1983; Johnny Delgado in Misteryo sa Tuwa (Joyful Mystery), 1984; and Melanie Marquez in The Untold Story of Melanie Marquez, 1987.

On television, Santos directed and hosted many popular shows including Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour), D’Sensations, Mister Public Service, Paligsahan sa Awit (Singing Contest), The Best Show, Tony Santos Presents, and the long-running TV series Flordeluna.

Santos was the only actor who could lay claim to five Best Supporting Actor awards, one each from the different award-giving bodies of national stature. He won in the Maria Clara Awards for Hantik (Black Ant), 1950; the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), the Star Awards, and the Gawad Urian for Sister Stella L., 1984; and the Film Academy of the Philippines for Mabuhay Ka sa Baril (Live by the Gun), 1986. He was also the recipient of the Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining award as Most Outstanding Actor in a Single Performance in a Drama Series for his appearance in an episode of Katha (Fiction). He is best remembered, however, for his roles as a Korean war veteran in Anak Dalita (The Ruins), the Asian Film Festival Best Picture of 1956, which gave him a presidential citation and the FAMAS International Prestige Award in 1957; as a seafaring Badjao in Lamberto V. Avellana’s Badjao, 1957; and as the father in Biyaya ng Lupa (Blessings of the Land), 1959. Written byLena S. Pareja

SANTOS, VILMA(Rosa Vilma Tuazon Santos) b. Manila 3 Nov 1953. Movie and television actor and producer. Her parents are Milagros Tuazon and Amado C. Santos. She attended grade school and finished high school at St. Mary’s Academy. She was married twice: the first time to actor Edu Manzano, with whom she has a son, actor and TV host Luis Manzano; and the second time to politician Ralph Recto with whom she has a son, Ryan Christian. Santos entered Philippine politics in 1998 when she won the mayoralty of Lipa City, Batangas. In 2007, she proved her popularity in the province as she was declared governor of the province and remained in the position for three consecutive terms. She is now a congresswoman.

Santos started as a child actor. In an audition at Sampaguita Pictures attended by over a hundred children, she was chosen by Dr Jose R. Perez to play the role of Trudis, the Mars Ravelo komiks character, in Trudis Liit (Little Trudis), 1963. She portrayed Imee Marcos in Iginuhit ng Tadhana (Destined by Fate), 1965, and also in Pinagbuklod ng Langit (Joined by Heaven), 1969.

As a teenage star, she was paired with Edgar Mortiz in Sixteen and Young Love, 1970; with Tirso Cruz III in Ding Dong, 1970; and with Eddie Peregrina in I Do Love You, 1970. When her Sampaguita contract expired, she transferred to Tagalog Ilang-Ilang Productions (TIIP) and made Dyesebel, 1973, Darna and the Giants, 1973, Now and Forever, 1973, Kampanerang Kuba (Hunchbacked Lady Bell Ringer), 1974, and Biktima (Victim), 1974, among others.

After TIIP, she turned movie producer. Her film company, VS Films, produced Mga Rosas sa Putikan (Roses in the Mire), 1976, Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Heron Turns Black), 1978, and Halik sa Paa, Halik sa Kamay (A Kiss on the Foot, A Kiss on the Hand), 1979. Pagputi ng Uwak was chosen Best Picture by the FAMAS and the Gawad Urian, winning major awards in different categories, including direction, acting, story, screenplay, cinematography, sound, music, and production design. During this period she freelanced with other movie companies, one of which was Ian Films, producer of the controversial Burlesk Queen (Burlesque Queen), 1977. This movie swept the awards at the Metro Manila Film Festival only to be withdrawn later, causing a public outcry against the festival organizers. After Burlesk Queen, Santos became one of the most sought-after and durable actors in local movies.

Santos starred in memorable films such as Lipad, Darna, Lipad (Fly, Darna, Fly), 1973; Tag-ulan sa Tag-araw (Rainy Days in Summer), 1975; Dalawang Pugad, Isang Ibon (Two Nests, One Bird) and Masarap, Masakit ang Umibig (Joy and Pain of Loving), 1977; Ikaw ay Akin (You Are Mine) and Rubia Servios, 1978; Langis at Tubig (Oil and Water), 1980; T-Bird at Ako (Lesbian Love), Sinasamba Kita (I Worship You), Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan? (How Often Is Once?), and Haplos (Caress), 1982; Paano Ba ang Mangarap? (How Does One Dream?), 1983; Adultery (Aida Macaraeg) Case No. 7892 and Alyas Baby Tsina (Alias Baby Tsina), 1984; Palimos ng Pag-ibig (Begging for Love), 1986; Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig? (Where Does Love Hide?), 1987; Kapag Langit ang Humatol (Heaven’s Judgment) and Hahamakin Lahat (All Be Damned), 1990; Sinungaling Mong Puso (Your Lying Heart), 1992; Ikaw Lang (Only You), 1993; In My Life, 2009; and The Healing, 2012.

On television, she is credited with having produced some adaptations of American plays—among them, Lamat sa Kristal (Crack in the Glass), Katuparan (Fulfillment), and Once There Was a Love. She also hosted the TV variety show Vilma—formerly VIP (Vilma in Person)—which aired from 1986 to 1995.

Santos was elevated to the Hall of Fame of the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 1989. She won five FAMAS Best Actress awards: for Dama de Noche (Woman of the Night), 1972; Pakawalan Mo Ako (Release Me), 1981; Relasyon (An Affair), 1982; Tagos ng Dugo (Bloodstain), 1987; and Ibulong Mo sa Diyos (Whisper to God), 1988. For Relasyon, she was the first Best Actress winner of the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) and the first actor to score a “grand slam”—winning four Best Actress trophies from the Gawad Urian, FAMAS, FAP, and the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA). She received Gawad Urian Best Actress awards in three consecutive years: for Relasyon; Broken Marriage, 1983; and Sister Stella L., 1984. She won five other Gawad Urian Best Actress awards for Pahiram ng Isang Umaga (Lend Me One Morning), 1989; Ipagpatawad Mo (Forgive Me), 1991; Dahil Mahal Kita: The Dolzura Cortez Story (Because I Love You), 1993; Bata, Bata … Paano Ka Ginawa? (Lea’s Story), 1998; and Dekada ’70 (The 1970s). She holds four Best actress trophies from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) for Burlesk Queen (Burlesque Queen), 1977; Karma, 1981; Imortal (Immortal), 1989; and Mano Po 3: My Love, 2004. She was Best Actress at the 1988 CMMA for Tagos ng Dugo. She received Best Actress awards for Bata, Bata … Paano Ka Ginawa? from the FAP, Gawad Urian, Star Awards, and Young Critics Circle (YCC) Film Desk; for Anak (The Child), 2000, from the Star Awards; for Dekada ’70 from the FAP, Gawad Urian, Star Awards, and YCC Film Desk; for In My Life from the Star Awards for Movies; and for the independent film Ekstra (The Bit Player), 2013, from the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival and the Golden Screen Awards.

Santos won international Best Actress awards for Bata, Bata … Paano Ka Ginawa? in the 1999 Brussels International Independent Film Festival; for Dekada ’70 in the 2002 Cinemanila International Film Festival; and for Ekstra in the 2014 Dhaka International Film Festival.

Santos was Gawad Urian Best Actress of the Decades 1980-89 and 1990-99. The University of the Philippines honored her with the Gawad Plaridel of the College of Mass Communication in 2005 and the Diwata Award in 2006. She received Lifetime Achievement Awards from the FAP in 1998, from the FAMAS in 1999, from Cinemanila International Film Festival in 2002, and from the PMPC Star Awards in 2008. She was given the Cinema One Legend Award in 2009. The Golden Screen Awards presented her with the Gawad Lino Brocka for Lifetime Achievement in 2010.Written by Galileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

SARTE, SHAYNE (Suzanne Shayne Orbeta Sarte) b. Pasig City 4 Oct 1972. Cinematographer. She is the only daughter among five children of late lawyer Juan Sarte and retired businesswoman Sonia Orbeta. She finished grade school and high school at St. Theresa’s College in Quezon City. In 1992, she earned her bachelor’s degree in communication arts at De La Salle University. A year later, she took cinematography and sound workshop at Mowelfund Film Institute and apprenticed with Rody Lacap. In 2014, she took her master’s class under Karl Walter Lindenlauh, Paul Cameron, and Stephen Burum of the American Society of Cinematographers in Hollywood, California. The works of Lacap and Mexican cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki have the greatest artistic influence on her.

After college, Sarte worked as an account executive at Lightbox Inc, a television commercial production company. She worked as a production assistant and was promoted to production manager shortly afterward. At the early age of 25, Sarte did the cinematography for her first full-length film titled Pila Balde (Fetch a Pail of Water), 1998, under Regal Films. It was followed by Sa Paraiso ni Efren (In Efren’s Paradise), 1999, under the same production firm.

Sarte’s work on Pila Balde won the Young Critics Circle Film Desk’s Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design award in 1999. She was nominated for two consecutive years in the Gawad Urian for Pila Balde and Sa Paraiso ni Efren. In 2001, she claimed her first Gawad Urian trophy for Tuhog (Larger Than Life), 2001. The following year, she received Best Cinematography awards from the Gawad Urian and the Film Academy of the Philippines for the film Kailangan Kita (I Need You), 2002. She was nominated for achievement in cinematography in various award-giving bodies for the following films: Linlang (Deceit), 1999; Minsan, Minahal Kita (Once, I Loved You), 2000; Got2Believe (Got to Believe), 2002; I Think I’m in Love, 2002; Milan, 2004; For the First Time, 2008; and A Mother’s Story, 2011.

Currently, Sarte, works as executive producer for the film company Spring Films Inc, which produced the Kimmy Dora series, 2009-13, and Relaks, It’s Just Pag-ibig (Relax, It’s Just Love), 2014. Spring Films investors include director Joyce Bernal, actor Piolo Pascual, and talent manager Erickson Raymundo. Written byGregory del Carmen

SERNA, SNOOKY(Ma. Milagros Ocampo Serna) aka Kookie. b. Manila 4 Apr 1966. Movie and television actor. She belongs to a showbiz family: her parents are actors Von Serna and Mila Ocampo, while her grandaunt, on her mother’s side, is actor AnitaLinda. She finished elementary at St. Joseph’s College and high school at the Benedictine Abbey in Parañaque. She was married to actor Ricardo Cepeda with whom she has two daughters. Her second estranged husband, Niño Mendoza, was a vocalist for a local alternative rock band.

Snooky appeared as a child actor in films like Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star, Little Romeo and Juliet, and Snooky, 1970; Living Doll, I Love Mama, I Love Papa, The Golden Child, and The Wonderful World of Music, 1971. Later, in her teens, she became part of the crop of rising young stars in local cinema that came after VilmaSantos and NoraAunor. She was often cast in dramatic roles and established her box-office appeal as a solo star in Blusang Itim (Black Blouse), 1986.

Among the other films Serna appeared in are Strangers in Paradise, 1983; Paalam, Bukas ang Kasal Ko (Goodbye, Tomorrow I’m Getting Married) and Nasaan Ka Nang Kailangan Kita? (Where Were You When I Needed You?), 1986; Paano Kung Wala Ka Na (What If You Are Gone), 1987; Rosa Mistica (Mystical Rose), Bukas, Sisikat Din ang Araw (Tomorrow the Sun Shall Rise Again), and Kapag Napagod ang Puso (When the Heart Tires), 1988; Abot Hanggang Sukdulan (Reaching the Limits) and Mga Kuwento ng Pag-ibig (Stories of Love), 1989; Yakapin Mo Akong Muli (Embrace Me Once More) and Lacson: Batas ng Navotas (Lacson: The Law of Navotas), 1992; Mancao and Machete II, 1994; Captain Barbell, 2003; Bangkang Papel (Paper Boat), 2011; and Esoterika: Maynila (Esoterica: Manila), 2014.

Her recent involvement in television drama includes Elena Patron’s Blusang Itim (Black Blouse) and Angelito: Batang Ama (Angelito: Young Father), 2011; Kahit Konting Pagtingin (Just One Glance) and Genesis, 2013; and Once upon a Kiss, 2015, apart from several episodes for Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), Magpakailanman (Forever), and Wansapanataym (Once upon A Time) through the years.

Serna won three acting awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences: Best Child Actress for Mahalin Mo Sana Ako (Please Love Me), 1972; Best Actress for Koronang Itim (Black Crown), 1994; and Best Supporting Actress for Paupahan, 2008. From the Star Awards for Movies, she received two Movie Supporting Actress of the Year trophies: for Hahamakin Lahat (All Be Damned), 1991, and for Paupahan (Crossroads), 2008. She also won Best Actress in a Drama Series for Habang Kapiling Ka (While I’m with You), 2002, in the Star Awards for Television. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

SERVO, YUL(John Marvin Cruz Nieto) b. Manila 1977. Movie and television actor. Fondly known as Jon-Jon, Servo was the second eldest child of tailor and University of Santo Tomas’ architecture graduate Martin Nieto and interior design enthusiast Zenaida Cruz. He has seven siblings. He finished bachelor of science in criminology at the Philippine College of Criminology.

Servo was all set to become a policeman after college, but with the persistent help of his uncle Willy Cruz who saw Servo’s potential as an actor, director Maryo J. de los Reyes discovered him. De los Reyes gave him the screen name Yul Servo, a combination of the names of actor Yul Brynner and waiter Alex Servo III. Servo, who later on became a protégé of Tony Veloria, was first featured in Mario O’Hara’s final film, Pusang Gala (Stray Cat), 2001, alongside Janice de Belen and Gina Alajar, and Lav Diaz’s Batang West Side (West Side Avenue), 2001, for which he bagged the Cinemanila International Film Festival Best Actor award alongside Joel Torre, Arthur Acuña, and Ruben Tizon.

Servo starred in notable films like Laman (Flesh), 2002; Naglalayag (Silent Passage) and Pa-Siyam (Nine-Day Novena), 2004; Ilusyon (Illusion) and Sa Ilalim ng Kugon (Under the Cogon), 2005; Heremias: Unang Aklat (Heremias: Book One) and Kagat ng Dilim (Fangs of Darkness), 2006; Siquijor: Mystic Island, 2007; Brutus: Ang Paglalakbay (Brutus: The Journey), Torotot (Destierro), Dose (Twelve), and The Forgotten War, 2008; Kamoteng Kahoy (Cassava), 2009; Rosario, 2010; Manila Kingpin: The Asiong Salonga Story, 2011; El Presidente (The President), 2012; Hindi Tao, Hindi Hayop (Not Human, Not Animal), Porno, and Alamat ni China Doll (The Legend of China Doll), 2013; and Dementia, 2014.

For Naglalayag, Servo won Best Actor in the 2004 Manila Film Festival. For Brutus, he won the Balanghai trophy for Best Actor in the 2008 Cinemalaya Independent Film Festival. In 2011, he received a Best Supporting Actor award from the Film Academy of the Philippines for Rosario. Servo earned the distinction of receiving three Best Actor awards from Brussels International Independent Film Festival: for Batang West Side in 2002 (shared with Joel Torre, Art Acuña, and Ruben Tizon); for Naglalayag in 2004; and for Torotot in 2008. From 2006 to 2014, he received numerous nominations for his achievements in acting, either as lead or supporting actor, from the Gawad Urian (Ilusyon, Brutus, and Porno), Golden Screen Awards (Ilusyon, Brutus, and Torotot), Metro Manila Film Festival (Rosario), and PMPC Star Awards for Movies (Rosario). In 2014, alongside the cast of Porno, Servo was nominated for Best Performance by an Ensemble in the Young Critics Circle Film Desk Citations. Written by Gregory del Carmen

SEVILLA, GLORIA(Gloria Natividad Sevilla) b. Cebu City 24 Jan 1932. Movie and television actor. She is the daughter of Bonifacio Sevilla and Florida Natividad. She attended Cebu Normal School, Zapatera Elementary School, and University of Visayas (UV). She was a sophomore law student in UV when she was discovered for Azucena Pictures by Danilo Nuñez after she won the title “Princess of Camay” in 1950. She became the most popular Cebuano actor and was often paired in Visayan movies with Mat Ranillo Jr whom she married in 1954. They have six children, four of whom are in show business: Mat Ranillo III, Suzette, Lilibeth, and Dandin Ranillo. After Ranillo’s death, she married actor Amado Cortez, who served as consul at the Philippine Embassy in the USA until his death in 2003.

Sevilla’s early Tagalog films are Ifugao, with Efren Reyes, and May Bakas ang Lumipas (The Past Has Footprints), 1954, with Rogelio de la Rosa. More films followed, including Divisoria Quiapo, 1955; 3 Mukha ni Pandora (Pandora’s Three Faces) and Kami’y Kaawaan (Have Mercy on Us), 1963; Sapang Palay, 1965; and Ito ang Pilipino (Behold the Filipino), 1966. In the mid-1960s, she and Mat Ranillo tried to revive the dying Visayan film industry. Gloria accepted half the fee she would have received in Manila for the Cebuano film Gihandum Ko Ikaw sa Kanunay (I Think of You Always). The Mat-Gloria Productions produced Lungsod sa Buenavista (City in Buenavista), 1967; Palad Ta ang Nagbuot (Fate Dictates), 1968, starring Sevilla and boxer Gabriel Elorde; and the prizewinning Badlis sa Kinabuhi (Life Lines), 1969; the last two directed by Leroy Salvador. In the 1970s, her notable films include Dodong Ko, 1970; Gimingaw Ako (I Am Sad), 1973; Banaue, 1975; Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth), 1976; Mga Mata ni Angelita (The Eyes of Angelita), 1978; and Aliw-iw, 1979. Her later films include Guhit ng Palad (Line of Fate), 1988; Matud Nila (They Say), 1991; The Flor Contemplacion Story, 1995; Pacquiao: The Movie, 2006; El Presidente (The President), 2012; Boy Golden, Shoot to Kill: The Arturo Porcuna Story, 2013; and independent films, like M.: Mother’s Maiden Name and Children’s Show, 2014.

Her most recent involvement in television includes episodes for Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2010-15; Budoy, 2011; and Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14, under ABS-CBN.

From the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), Sevilla received a Best Supporting Actress award for Madugong Paghihiganti in 1963 and two Best Actress trophies for Badlis sa Kinabuhi in 1970 and for Gimingaw Ako in 1974. She was also given the Best Actress award for Badlis sa Kinabuhi in the 16th Asian Film Festival held in Jakarta in 1969. The movie was also showcased in the 1969 Berlin Film Festival. In 2007, she received the FAMAS Lifetime Achievement Award. She won Best Supporting Actress for M: Mother’s Maiden Name in the Indie New Wave section of the 2014 Metro Manila Film Festival. Written by Erlinda K. Alburo, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor
(See MUSIC volume.)

SIGUION-REYNA, CARLOS(Carlos Ponce Enrile Siguion-Reyna) aka Carlitos. b. Manila 4 Nov 1957. Director. Born to actor-singer-producer Armida Ponce-Enrile and corporate lawyer Leonardo Siguion-Reyna, he studied at Ateneo de Manila University from elementary to college, graduating with a bachelor of arts degree in interdisciplinary studies. He earned the degree of master of fine arts in film production at New York University with his thesis film Patas Lang (Evenly Matched). He is married to actor-scriptwriter Bibeth Orteza, with whom he has two children.

Siguion-Reyna directed his first movie, Misis Mo, Misis Ko (Your Wife, My Wife), 1989, for Viva Films when he was just fresh out of film school. Since then, he earned a name as one of the industry’s critically acclaimed directors. His other films are Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven), 1991; Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal (You’re the Only One I’ve Loved) and Kailangan Kita (I Need You), 1992; Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1993; Inagaw Mo ang Lahat sa Akin (Harvest Home), 1995; Abot-Kamay ang Pangarap (Elena’s Redemption), 1996; Ang Lalaki sa Buhay ni Selya (The Man in Her Life) and Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin (They Call Me Joy), 1997; Kahapon May Dalawang Bata (Yesterday Children), 1999; Azucena, 2000; and Kilig … Pintig … Yanig … (Thrill, Pulse, Tremor), 2004.

He received Best Director trophies for Misis Mo, Misis Ko, 1990 Star Awards; Hihintayin Kita sa Langit, 1992 Gawad Urian; and Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal, 1993 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards, Film Academy of the Philippines Awards, and Gawad Urian. In 1998, Ang Lalaki sa Buhay ni Selya won the Teddy Jury Award in Berlin International Film Festival. At the 2001 San Diego Asian Film Festival, his film Azucena won the Grand Jury Prize. Hari ng Tondo (Where I Am King), 2014, received the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival Special Jury Prize, Directors Showcase.

Siguion-Reyna represented the country in various international film festivals in Toronto, Berlin, Tokyo, Chicago, Seattle, Hawaii, Palm Springs, Paris, Valladolid, Shanghai, London, and Dublin. His films were screened at prestigious locations, such as the Lincoln Center’s Walter Reade Theater and the Directors Guild of America Theater.

He became a leader in the Philippine film industry, serving as president of the Directors’ Guild of the Philippines and vice president for external affairs of Nagkakaisang Manggagawa ng Pelikulang Pilipino (United Cinema Workers of the Philippines). Siguion-Reyna was also a key figure in the formation of the Film Development Council of the Philippines. Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

SILAYAN, VIC(Victor Payumo Silayan) b. Manila 31 Jan 1929. d. 30 Aug 1987. Movie, stage, and television actor. He is the son of Hilarion Silayan and Rosario Payumo. Actor-model Chat Silayan is a daughter. He got his bachelor of arts, 1951, and his master’s degree in speech and drama, 1961, from Ateneo de Manila University and attended a Harvard management course in 1962. He worked as radio producer-announcer at DZFM while teaching at the University of the East and San Beda College, then as a corporate secretary in a government agency, and vice-president of a firm engaged in executive development.

At Ateneo, Silayan developed as a stage actor, doing Shakespeare and Broadway plays. His famous role on stage was as Bitoy Camacho in the first production of Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1955. He was sought after as voice talent for radio and television commercials and movie trailers. He appeared in more than 300 films, including about 30 foreign productions. When war pictures were in vogue, he was the industry’s favorite Japanese officer, together with actor Vic Diaz. He appeared in supporting roles in Huk sa Bagong Pamumuhay (Huk in a New Life), 1953; Lapu-Lapu and Higit sa Lahat (Above All), 1955; Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956; Badjao and Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1957; Malvarosa, 1958; the film version of A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965; and Lilet, 1972.

He received a Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Supporting Actor award for Diligin Mo ng Hamog ang Uhaw na Lupa (Water the Parched Earth with Dew), 1975. From Gawad Urian, he received Best Actor awards for Ligaw na Bulaklak (Wildflower), 1976, and Kisapmata (In the Blink of an Eye), 1981; and a Best Supporting Actor award for Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983. Silayan is well-remembered as the psychologically imbalanced retired policeman in Kisapmata.

The Vic Silayan Memorial Awards for Trimedia Artists was established in 1989. Among its recipients were Ruben Rustia, Mary Walter, Pancho Magalona, and Robert Arevalo. Written by Danny Villanueva
(See MUSIC volume.)

SILOS, MANUEL(Manuel Santos Silos) aka Sano Tulia b. Manila 1 Jan 1906. d. 31 Mar 1988. Movie director and actor. His parents are Ana Santos and Jose Silos, photographer, music teacher, and conductor of the Philippine Constabulary Band. Silos belonged to a family of artists. Brother Cesar is a cinematographer; another brother, Augusto, is a laboratory man; two others, Luis and Octavio, are soundman and director, respectively. He married Rosalia Font, with whom he had seven children. His uncles, Rosalio and Juan Sr, and cousin Juan Jr, were all composers and bandleaders.

Trained early in bodabil, he first became famous as Sano in the comedy tandem Monang (Carvajal) and Sano. As an actor, he appeared in Sa Tokyo Ikinasal (Married in Tokyo), 1948, with Chipopoy (Lou Salvador Sr).

His creation of a silent film based on the comic strip Tres Sanganos, later expanded into The Three Tramps when he was 21, enabled him to become a director of Banahaw Pictures in 1930. His first film Mystery of the Convent was a box-office hit. With Carlos Vander Tolosa, he advanced film techniques from the simple use of static image to montage. He helped introduce modern film technology, especially in animation and trick photography. He developed an early form of the zoom lens called the Siloscope, a 90-degree wide angle camera lens.

He was at his best with musical films such as Ay! Kalisud (Oh, Misery), 1938, which made Fely Vallejo a star; Misteryoso (Mysterious), 1950; 1-2-3, 1955; Puppy Love, 1956; and Tuloy ang Ligaya (Let the Good Times Roll), 1958, where he used the technique of split screen for the first time. He also directed socially committed films such as Biyaya ng Lupa (Blessings of the Land), 1959, which brought Leroy Salvador and Joseph de Cordova to public attention. Movie outfits he worked for include Filippine Films, for whom he directed Mag-inang Mahirap (Destitute Mother and Child), 1934; Parlatone Hispano-Filipino under which he directed Lagablab ng Kabataan (The Raging Fire of Youth), 1936, and Hiram na Ligaya (Borrowed Happiness), 1937; Sampaguita Pictures, where he directed Dalisay (Chaste), 1939, and Tarhata, 1941; and LVN, for which he made the most number of movies, among them the first Filipino color movie, Batalyon XIII (13th Battalion), 1949, Edong Mapangarap (Edong the Dreamer), 1950, and Mucho Dinero (Plenty of Money), 1958.

Silos’s Biyaya ng Lupa won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Best Picture and Best Story (Celso Carunungan) awards in 1960. It also won Best Supporting Actor award for Leroy Salvador at the 1960 Asian Film Festival. He was a recipient of the Natatanging Gawad Urian in 1979. The Film Academy of the Philippines honored him with the Lifetime Achievement Award in 1985. Written byEmelie B. Capulong

SILOS, OCTAVIO(Octavio Santos Silos) b. Manila 15 Aug 1904. d. 11 Jan 1971. Movie director, scriptwriter, and news photographer. His parents are Ana Santos and Jose Silos, an orchestra conductor. He married Soledad Tapales, with whom he has four children. Son Raul is also a director. He belonged to the famous Silos show business clan. His grandfather was Leonardo Silos, the well-known composer and bandleader of the 1900s. His brother Manuel was Sano of bodabil fame who later became a multi-awarded movie director. His other brothers were also in movies: Cesar as cinematographer, Luis as soundman, and Augusto as laboratory man. His uncles Rosalio and Juan Sr, and cousin Juan Jr, were all composers and bandleaders.

Silos first worked as laboratory man on a silent short film directed by his brother Manuel and produced by Ramon Caro, Tres Sanganos (Three Tramps), 1927. When Banahaw Pictures was formed in the early 1930s, he joined the outfit as art director. He and his brothers worked as a team on the silent films Ang Gayuma (Love Potion), 1932, The Mystery of the Convent, 1932, and Ang Ilaw ng Kapitbahay (A Neighbor’s Lamp), 1932. With the advent of talking pictures, Silos and his brothers transferred to Filippine Films studio, where he initially worked as art director on two movies, Mag-inang Mahirap (Destitute Mother and Child), 1934, and Pag-iimbot (Avarice), 1934, before he got a chance to direct Hinagpis ng Magulang (A Parent’s Woes), 1934, based on his own story and screenplay. This was followed by Anak ng Bilanggo (The Convict’s Son), 1934, starring Rosa del Rosario and Jose Padilla Jr, and Kuwintas ng Himutok (Necklace of Resentments), 1935, with Mary Walter and Carlos Padilla. He transferred to Parlatone to direct Rosita Rivera and Rogelio de la Rosa in Kalupitan ng Tadhana (Fate’s Cruelty), 1936; child stars Tita Duran and Angelito Nepomuceno in Sa Paanan ng Krus (At the Foot of the Cross), 1937; and Teniente Rosario (Lieutenant Rosario), 1937. When Sampaguita Pictures opened, Silos joined the company and directed the musical Paroparong Bukid (Country Butterfly), 1938, starring Elsa Oria and Rudy Concepcion. Other films he directed for Sampaguita are Inang Mahal (Beloved Mother), 1938; Alipin ng Palad (Slave of Fate), 1938; Mapait na Lihim (Bitter Secret), 1938; Pasang Krus (Cross on the Shoulder), 1939; and Gabay ng Magulang (Parent’s Guidance), 1939. Silos directed some of the biggest productions of Excelsior Pictures in the prewar era: the Tita Duran–Rosario Moreno drama Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), 1939; Rudy Concepcion and Rosario Moreno’s romantic picture Pakiusap (Plea), 1940; Rudy Concepcion’s last picture before his sudden death, Ikaw Rin (You, Too), 1940; Jaime de la Rosa’s first starring movie, Ibong Sawi (Forlorn Bird), 1941; and the Arsenia Francisco–Rodolfo Ruiz–Patricia Mijares love triangle in Babalik Ka Rin (You Shall Return), 1941.

After World War II when Sampaguita Pictures resumed movie production, Silos came to be known as the “Dean of Movie Directors.” He directed the remakes of big prewar movies like Inang Mahal (Mother Dear), 1956; Pasang Krus, 1957; Mapait na Lihim (Bitter Secret), 1958; Pakiusap, 1959; and Alipin ng Palad, 1959. He continued making films up to the 1960s, co-directing the Mga Batang … series with Emmanuel H. Borlaza and scoring in the fantasy, comedy, and drama genres with Kerubin (Cherubim), 1952; Gorio at Tecla (Gorio and Tecla), 1953; Silveria, 1958; Wen Manang (Yes, Elder Sister), 1961; and Magnificent Bakya (Magnificent Wooden Slipper), 1965. Written byRamon Jocson and Lena S. Pareja

SMITH, WILLIAMaka Billy Smith. b. Echague, Isabela 12 Feb 1913. Movie sound engineer. Smith, considered the first Filipino sound recording engineer, was born of a Thomasite father and a Filipina. He married Lourdes Souza, and together they put up the Smith Sound System Laboratories in San Juan, Metro Manila.

While still in his teens, Smith was employed by Lyric Film Exchange to install sound equipment in theaters in the Philippines and Indonesia. His first movie was also Philippine cinema’s first talking picture, Ang Aswang (The Aswang), 1932, produced by George Musser. The knowledge that he gained from working with American technicians was immediately applied to local movies when he transferred to Filippine Films in 1933. He formed a “Four Plus One” team with the Silos brothers Manuel, Octavio, Cesar, and Augusto, in handling the technical aspects of film production for such movies as Mag-inang Mahirap (Destitute Mother and Child), X-R-X, and Anak ng Bilanggo (The Convict’s Son), all released in 1934. He then set up the sound department of Parlatone Hispano-Filipino, which made Diwata ng Karagatan (Goddess of the Sea), Awit ng mga Ulila (Song of the Orphans), and Sa Paanan ng Krus (At the Foot of the Cross), all in 1936. Together with Luis F. Nolasco, he chose the site for the studio of Sampaguita Pictures, a noise-free rolling terrain on Gilmore Avenue, New Manila, where he later set up the first Reeves black-and-white processing and optical sound laboratory. This assured the tonal quality of Sampaguita’s pioneering musicals, such as Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), 1937; Paroparong Bukid (Country Butterfly), and Madaling Araw (Break of Dawn), 1938; and other films. Shortly before the outbreak of World War II, he helped set up the sound studio of Excelsior Films, which produced Arimunding-Munding and Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), 1939.

During the war, Smith served in the United States Army corps of engineers but was captured by the enemy and detained in Fort Santiago. He was released in 1944 to work on the Japanese propaganda movie Tatlong Maria (Three Marys), directed by Abe Yutaka and Gerardo de Leon. After the war, he produced Si Malakas at si Maganda (The Strong and the Beautiful), 1947, starring Rosa del Rosario and Tony Benroy. He shot the film in Hollywood using 16mm Kodachrome (color reversal), which was later blown up to 35mm Ansco color for theatrical release. To do this, he had to maintain a balance of color temperature and exposure all throughout the filming so that the picture could be blown up effectively using only one light and one filter change. The success of his experiment won him recognition in the worldwide publication International Photographer, and it was said that Smith’s innovative technique was subsequently adapted by Walt Disney for his African wildlife series.

Smith worked on LVN’s Batalyon XIII (13th Battalion), 1949, the first Filipino movie in 35mm filmed entirely in color. He helped set up the LVN Color Laboratory, which had serviced the industry since 1951. He pioneered in the reduction of local films from 35mm to 16mm format for showing on TV and noncommercial venues through mobile projectors. Toward the early 1960s, he helped popularize magnetic film recording. Smith helped train many of the industry’s present crop of sound technicians, cinematographers, editors, and laboratory film technicians.

Smith was conferred the Natatanging Gawad Urian for his outstanding contribution to Philippine cinema by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino in 1985. In 1987 he received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Film Academy of the Philippines. Written byAgustin Sotto and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

article_title: Society of Filipino Archivists for Film (SOFIA)
text:
SOCIETY OF FILIPINO ARCHIVISTS FOR FILM (SOFIA) Also known as Samahan ng mga Filipinong Arkivista para sa Pelikula Inc, SOFIA is a nongovernment organization originally incorporated as the Society of Film Archivists in 1993 with eight founding members including the late film critic and historian Agustin Sotto. It was in 2008 when the organization was renamed as the Society of Filipino Archivists for Film.

SOFIA has been actively campaigning for the establishment of a national audiovisual archive since it joined a task force composed of the Philippine Information Agency, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 1998 to scout for a permanent film archive facility in the Philippines.

SOFIA works for the restoration of old landmark Filipino films. Among the films that were restored through the efforts of SOFIA are Giliw Ko (My Love), 1939, the first production of LVN Pictures; Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), 1939; Sanda Wong, 1955; Maalaala Mo Kaya? (Will You Remember?), 1954; Jack and Jill, 1954; MN, 1954; Dalagang Ilocana (Ilocano Maiden), 1954; Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1961; Banta ng Kahapon (Threat from the Past), 1977; and White Slavery, 1985.

In 2004, SOFIA marked its 11th founding anniversary with a festival of restored films dubbed “Ukay-Ukay: Where’s the Archive?” In 2010, the organization held a monthly film series at the CCP called “Overlooked Films, Underrated Filmmakers.” It was launched with Jun Raquiza’s Krimen: Kayo ang Humatol (Crime: You Be the Judge), 1974, which won Best Cinematography, Best Editing, and Best Production Design from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences. SOFIA also organized the “Ronwaldo Reyes Retrospective: A Tribute to National Artist Fernando Poe, Jr.,” 2011, which featured the works of the late actor who also directed films under the pseudonym Ronwaldo Reyes, and “Juan Tamad Goes Indie,” 2008, the retrospective of films by Manuel Conde, another National Artist, for the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival. Written by Kathrina Alvarez

SOLIS, CHARITO (Rosario Violeta Hernandez Solis) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 6 Oct 1935. d. Calamba City 9 Jan 1998. Movie, stage, and television actor. Her parents are Milagros Hernandez and Maximo Solis, a writer. She studied at San Pablo Elementary School in San Pablo, Batangas, and finished high school at the University of the East.

Director Felicing H. Constantino, uncle of Solis, brought his niece to LVN producer Doña Narcisa Buencamino vda de Leon when the studio was looking for a new face to appear opposite Jaime de la Rosa in Niña Bonita (Pretty Girl), 1955. The success of Niña Bonita called for a second team-up with de la Rosa in Dinayang Pagmamahal (Cheated Love), 1955. She next appeared with Leroy Salvador in Charito, I Love You and with Mario Montenegro in Ulilang Bituin (Lonely Star), 1956. In the same year, she was paired with Nestor de Villa in Big Shot, while Armando Goyena was her leading man in Sanga-Sangang Puso (Hearts Intertwined) and ?10,000 Pag-ibig (?10,000 Love), 1957. She also appeared opposite Eddie Rodriguez in Kundiman ng Lahi (Love Song of the Race), 1959. One of her most memorable films during this period is Malvarosa, 1958, an Asian Film Festival winner, where she plays Rosa to five brothers portrayed by Vic Silayan, Carlos Padilla Jr, Rey Ruiz, Vic Diaz, and Eddie Rodriguez. In 1960, she appeared opposite Pancho Magalona in Emily.

In 1961, LVN stopped producing movies and Solis became a freelancer, appearing in other movie companies. Among her films then are Angustia, 1963; Mga Pag-ibig ni Christine (The Loves of Christine), 1966; Manila: Open City, 1967; Pipo and Igorota (Mountain Maiden), 1968; Beerhouse, 1977; Babae, Ngayon at Kailanman (Woman, Now and Forever), 1977; Modelong Tanso (Fake Model) and Init (Heat), 1979; City after Dark, 1980; and Hinugot sa Langit (Wrenched from Heaven), 1985.

Her association with Brocka led to a stage performance in Larawan, the Filipino translation of Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino.

On television, she appeared regularly in the TV series Okay Ka, Fairy Ko (You’re Okay, My Fairy), which ran from 1987 to 1997, and Fifty Carats, O Di Ba? (Fifty Carats, Isn’t It So?) with Nida Blanca and Gloria Romero.

Solis received the Asian Film Festival Best Actress award for her performance in Dahil sa Isang Bulaklak (Because of a Flower), 1967. She was elevated to the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Hall of Fame for receiving five Best Actress awards: for Kundiman ng Lahi, 1959, Emily, 1960, Angustia, 1963, Igorota, 1968, and Don’t Cry for Me, Papa, 1983. She has three acting awards from Gawad Urian: Best Actress for Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Mother, Sister, Daughter), 1979, and Best Supporting Actress for Kisapmata (In the Blink of an Eye), 1981, and Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983. The Catholic Mass Media Awards cited her for Ina, Kapatid, Anak and Don’t Cry for Me, Papa. She also won two acting awards from the Metro Manila Film Festival: Best Actress for Araw-Araw, Gabi-Gabi (Every Day, Every Night), 1975, and Best Supporting Actress for Kisapmata. Her portrayal of the role of the spinster writer who recounts the tragedies of her mother’s family in Karnal also merited a Film Academy of the Philippines Best Supporting Actress award. She also appeared in international films, like the Japanese production of Buddha, 1962, where she portrayed the Buddha’s wife. Written byGalileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

SOLITO, AURAEUS aka Kanakan Balintagos.b. Manila 1969. Film director, writer, and producer. Solito hails from Palawan. He graduated from the Philippine Science High School in 1986 and received a bachelor of arts degree in theater arts from University of the Philippines in 1993.

Solito made his first short film titled Ang Maikling Buhay ng Apoy, Act 2–Scene 2: Suring at ang Kuk-ok (The Brief Lifespan of Fire, Act 2–Scene 2: Suring and the Kuk-ok), 1995, followed by Impeng Negro (Black Impe), 1998, an adaptation of Rogelio Sikat’s story. He also became popular for directing the music video of “Ang Huling El Bimbo,” a famous song by pop-rock band Eraserheads.

His first full-length film is Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros), 2005, one of the key films in the boom of Philippine independent cinema in the new millennium. It is a story of a gay boy torn between his family and his love for a young policeman. Also released in the same year was Tuli (Circumcision), which tackles a lesbian relationship in a small town. Pisay (Philippine Science High School), 2007, is an ode to his alma mater, while Boy, 2009, is a coming-of-age story of a young poet falling in love with a macho dancer. Solito explores Palawan culture in Busong (Palawan Fate), 2011, and Baybayin (The Palawan Script), 2012, both of which star Alessandra de Rossi. His first film as Kanakan Balintagos is Esprit de Corps, 2014, one of the finalists at the Cinema One Originals Film Festival, which shows the game of seduction and corruption in the military during the Marcos regime.

Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros won the Special Jury Prize at the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, Teddy Award for Best Feature Film at Berlin International Film Festival, the Golden Zenith Award at Montreal World Film Festival, and the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) Award at Rotterdam International Film Festival. It was also chosen as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 2000-09 by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino. Tuli won Best Picture and Best Director at Cinemanila International Film Festival, and was given the NETPAC Award at Berlin International Film Festival. Solito received Best Director awards for Pisay at Cinemalaya and Golden Screen Awards. Overseas, it won the Audience Award and the Grand Prize of the International Jury at Vesoul Asian Film Festival. After winning the Best Director award at Cinemalaya, Busong was shown in the Directors’ Fortnight at the 2011 Cannes Film Festival. It also won the International Federation of Film Critics Prize at Eurasia International Film Festival and the Tomorrow’s Cinema Award at Brussels International Festival of Independent Films, among its many honors. Esprit de Corps earned him another Best Director award, this time from the Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival. He also won a Palanca award for his full-length play Mga Buhay na Apoy (A Breath of Fire), 2015, and the Gawad Buhay award for original script in 2016. Written by Richard Bolisay, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

SOMES, RICHARD (Richard Villarosa Somes) b. Bacolod City 15 Nov 1977. Director, production designer, writer, producer. Among Somes’s directorial works are the “Lihim ng San Joaquin” (Secret of San Joaquin) segment of Shake, Rattle & Roll 2k5, 2005; Yanggaw (Affliction), 2008; Ishmael, 2010; 1942, a short film, 2011; Corazon: Ang Unang Aswang (Corazon: The First Aswang), Supremo, and Mariposa: Sa Hawla ng Gabi (Mariposa: In the Cage of the Night), 2012; and Liwanag sa Dilim (Light in the Darkness), 2015. He wrote the screenplay of most of these films.

Somes’s works as a production designer are also worthy of note. Among the films for which he did production design are Gagamboy (Spider Boy) and Pa-Siyam (Nine-Day Novena), 2004; Exodus: Tales from the Enchanted Kingdom, 2005; Ang Panday (The Blacksmith), 2009; Ang Panday 2 (The Blacksmith 2), 2011; The Healing, 2012; On the Job, 2013; Gemini and Violator, 2014; and Tragic Theater, 2015.

Somes has directed for television. Among his works are Imortal (Immortal), 2010-11; Maria la del Barrio (Maria of the Barrio), 2011-12; Bridges of Love, 2015; and The Story of Us, 2016.

Somes won Best Production Design in the 2005 Metro Manila Film Festival for Exodus: Tales from the Enchanted Kingdom. The same film won him Best Production Design from the Film Academy of the Philippines. He won Best Director and the Audience Award in the 2008 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival for Yanggaw. The same film won him a Star Award for Digital Movie Director of the Year in 2009. Also in 2009, Somes received the award for Best Production Design from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Ang Panday. The following year, the same film won him Movie Production Designer of the Year in the Star Awards and Best Production Design in the Golden Screen Awards. Written by Johann Vladimir Espiritu, with notes from Nicanor G. Tiongson

SORIANO, MARICEL (Maria Cecilia Martinez Soriano) aka Marya. b. Manila 25 Feb 1965. Movie and television actor. Her parents are Victor Soriano Sr and Linda Martinez. She attended grade school at St. Mary’s College, Pasay City, and high school at Centro Escolar University and Trinity College, Quezon City. Actor Meryl Soriano is her niece.

At a very young age, Soriano was a child performer on television and in the movies. She was already considered an outstanding child actor at the age of nine. Her regular appearance on the highly rated TV sitcom John en Marsha (John and Marsha), where she played Shirley, the daughter of Dolphy and Nida Blanca, did much to boost the comedy series. She appeared in the movie versions of the popular TV show: John en Marsha, 1974, John en Marsha sa Amerika (John and Marsha in America), 1975, and John en Marsha ’77, 1977.

Among her other movies are Underage, 1980; Summer Love, 1981; My Heart Belongs to Daddy, 1982; Hindi Kita Malimot (I Can’t Forget You), 1982; Pepe en Pilar (Pepe and Pilar), Minsan, May Isang Ina (Once There Was a Mother), and Saan Darating ang Umaga? (Where Will the Morning Come?), 1983; Kaya Kong Abutin ang Langit (I Can Reach the Sky), 1984; Hinugot sa Langit (Wrenched from Heaven), 1985; Inday Bote (Inday the Bottle Trader), 1985; Batang Quiapo (Quiapo Kid), 1986; Pinulot Ka Lang sa Lupa (You Were Merely Picked from the Ground), 1987; Taray at Teroy (Taray and Teroy), Babaeng Hampaslupa (Downtrodden Woman), and Super Inday and the Golden Bibe, 1988; Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal (You Are the Only One I’ve Loved), 1992; Minsan Lang Kitang Iibigin (I Will Love You Only Once), Vampira (Vampire), and Separada (Separated Woman), 1994; Dahas (Rage) and Inagaw Mo ang Lahat sa Akin (Harvest Home), 1995; Ama, Ina, Anak (Father, Mother, Child), 1996; Nasaan ang Puso (Where Is the Heart), 1997; Soltera (The Spinster), 1999; Mila, 2001; Mano Po (I Kiss Your Hand), 2002; Filipinas, 2003; I Will Survive, 2004; Inang Yaya (Mother Nanny), 2006; Bahay Kubo: A Pinoy Mano Po (Nipa Hut: A Filipino Mano Po), 2007.

Aside from John en Marsha, she also appeared in other television series, such as Kaya ni Mister, Kaya ni Misis (What the Husband Can Do, The Wife Can Too), 1999; Vietnam Rose, 2005; Genesis, 2013; and Ang Dalawang Mrs. Real (The Two Mrs Real), 2014.

Soriano began winning awards at the age of nine, when she was chosen Best Child Actress at the 9th Manila Film Festival for Virgo Films’ Alaala Mo, Daigdig Ko (Your Memory, My World), 1974. In 1988 and 1989, she received Best Actress awards from the Star Awards for Television for her weekly drama show, the Maricel Drama Special. In 1993, she won Best Performance from the Young Critics Circle (YCC) for Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal. She received the same award two years later for Vampira. More than a decade later, in 2007, she got her third award from the YCC for Inang Yaya. In 1995, she won Best Actress from the Star Awards for Movies for Separada. She got two Best Actress awards from the Metro Manila Film: for Yesterday Today Tomorrow in 2011, and Girl Boy Bakla Tomboy (Girl, Boy, Gay, Lesbian) in 2013. She won the Best Actress awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for the following films: Saan Darating ang Umaga, Dahas, and Nasaan ang Puso. She earned three Best Actress awards from the Film Academy of the Philippines for the following films: Nasaan ang Puso, Filipinas, and Bahay Kubo: A Pinoy Mano Po. She received two Best Performance by an Actress awards from the Golden Screen Awards for I Will Survive, 2004, and A Love Story, 2007. For her contributions to Philippine cinema, Soriano received the Cinema One Legend Award from the Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival in 2009. Written by Cristin Directo and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

SORIANO, MERYLL (Mary Rosalind Soriano Revillame) b. Manila 9 Dec 1982. Film and television actor. Her parents are comedian and TV host Willie Revillame and Bec Soriano, sister of movie and television actor Maricel Soriano. She has a son with estranged husband Bernard Palanca whom she married in 2006.

She started her career at age nine and appeared mostly in comedy movies, such as Rocky Plus V, 1991, with Vic Sotto and Aiza Seguerra; Buddy en Sol: Sine Ito (Buddy and Sol: This Is a Movie), 1992, with Eric Quizon and Redford White; and Da Best in da West 2: Da Western Pulis Istori (The Best in the West: The Western Police Story), 1996, with Dolphy, Lito Lapid, and Babalu. She also appeared in the movies Nasaan Ka Nang Kailangan Kita (Where Were You When I Needed You), 1996, starring Judy Ann Santos and Wowie de Guzman; Computer Kombat (Computer Combat), 1997, with Aiza Seguerra; and Kahit Minsan Lang (Even Just Once), 1997, with aunt Maricel Soriano and Tonton Gutierrez.

She also had a number of TV appearances, such as in ABS-CBN’s sitcoms Kaya ni Mister, Kaya ni Misis (What the Husband Can Do, The Wife Can Too), 1997-2001, and Mary D Potter (Mary The Potter), 2011. She also appeared in TV series, such as GMA Network’s Sana Ay Ikaw na Nga (I Hope You’re the One), 2001-3, and ABS-CBN’s Kampanerang Kuba (Hunchbacked Lady Bell Ringer), 2005; Super Inggo, 2006-7; I Love Betty La Fea, 2008; Noah, 2010; Honesto, 2013-14; and Ikaw Lamang (No Greater Love), 2014.

Active in the independent film scene in the country, she was recognized for her acting prowess. She appeared in Aloy Adlawan’s Room Boy, 2005, for which she won Best Actress in the 2005 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival; in Dado Lomibao’s In da Red Corner (In the Red Corner), 2006; in Ron Bryant’s Rotonda (Roundabout), 2006, for which she won Best Supporting Actress in the Gawad Urian in 2007; in Paolo Herras’s Rekados (Flavors), 2006; in Dante Nico Garcia’s Ploning, 2008; in Ellen Ongkeko-Marfil’s Boses (Voice), 2008; in Mark Meily’s Donor, 2010, for which she won Best Actress awards in the 2010 Brussels International Independent Film Festival and in the 2010 Cinemalaya.Written by Lorelie Legisniana

SOTTO, AGUSTIN L.(Agustin Laguda Sotto) aka Hammy Sotto b. Iloilo City 20 Apr 1950. d. Makati City 24 Apr 2001. Essayist, film archivist. Born to Plaridel Sotto and Aida Laguda, he graduated with a bachelor of arts in mass communications from the Ateneo de Manila University in 1971. He was film director of the National Media Production Center, 1973, and executive producer of Channel 4’s Sarilikha (Multicreations), 1974-75. He was a film lecturer at the De La Salle University, Assumption College, and College of Mass Communications in the University of the Philippines, Diliman. In the 1980s, he was a consultant to the Manila International Film Festival and the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines, and from 1986 to 1993, served as executive director of the Coordinating Center for Film of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. He was also the founding president of Society of Film Archivists (SOFIA).

Sotto became a member of the ManunuringPelikulang Pilipino in 1977 and served as its chairman in 1982-83, 1991-92, and 1999-2001. He was a juror at the Carthage Film Festival in Tunisia and the Phnom Penh Festival in Cambodia. He represented the Philippines in international film festivals in Cannes, Hong Kong, Venice, Tokyo, New York, San Francisco, Honolulu, Tashkent, and Moscow. He was also a member of the film committee of the NationalCommissionforCultureandtheArts.

Sotto was a correspondent for the International Film Guide and has written numerous essays and reviews on film for Philippine publications, such as Malaya, Newsday, Manila Standard, Sunday Inquirer Magazine, Daily Express, Weekend, Manila Paper, Panorama, and Timesweek, and for foreign journals like Positif, Cahiers du Cinema, L’Avant-Scene du Cinema, Larouse Encyclopedia, Far Eastern Economic Review, Asiaweek, International Film Guide, East-West Film Journal, and Manoa. Among his works which appeared in anthologies and collections or published separately are: “Genghis Khan at the Cinematheque Francaise” and “The Folk Philosopher in the Land of Juan Tamad” (an interview with Manuel Conde), in theUrianAnthology1970-1979, 1983; “The Celluloid Route of ‘Genghis Khan’,” in Readings in Philippine Cinema, 1983; “The Life and Art of Gerardo de Leon,” published by the Hong Kong Film Festival, 1983; “The Action Film,” in Unang Pagtingin sa Pelikulang Bakbakan (First Look at the Action Film), 1988; “War and Its Aftermath in Philippine Cinema,” in Panahon ng Hapon: Sining sa Digmaan, Digmaan sa Sining (The Japanese Occupation: Art in War, War in Art), 1992; and a series of articles on LinoBrocka, in Lino Brocka, The Artist and His Times, 1993.

Sotto has also done video documentaries, including The Woodcarvers of Paete, 1975; several documentaries on arts and crafts for Sarilikha, 1973-75; Philippine Cinema 1897-1944, 1983, produced by the Communication Foundation for Asia; and Pelikula (Film), 1989, and Pelikula II (1897-1960), 1993, produced by the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Sotto received a nomination from the Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining (PATAS) in 1974 for his work in Sarilikha. He has also won awards for The Woodcarvers of Paete and Pelikula (second prize, FilmAcademyofthePhilippines Awards, 1989).Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Elmer L. Gatchalian

STAR CINEMA/ABS-CBN FILM PRODUCTIONS INC Popularly known as Star Cinema, ABS-CBN Film Productions Inc is a Filipino entertainment company that seeks to deliver to its audiences quality films that are a contribution to Philippine cinema.

Star Cinema was established in 1993 to promote the film productions of ABS-CBN. Realizing the difficulty in permeating an industry already dominated by bigger and older film studios, such as Regal Films and Viva Films, the production outfit needed a hands-on type of management that could unite its growing staff. Under the leadership of Malou Santos, who worked with the company as a manager and executive producer, Star Cinema began to prosper. It now enjoys its status as the most financially successful film production outfit in the Philippines. This became possible through Santos’s efforts at building partnerships with other production companies, ensuring its productivity as a center of manpower, and producing films that not only promise income but elevate local filmmaking standards as well, thereby helping the country gain a spot in the international film arena. At present, the films released by Star Cinema are screened in Asia, North America, and Europe, forging the creation of new markets. Through this exposure, the company is also able to contribute to the continuing presence of the Philippines in the international scene.

Among the most memorable films that Star Cinema produced through the years are May Minamahal (Loving Someone), 1993; Minsan Lang Kitang Iibigan (I Will Love You Only Once), Separada (Separated Woman), and Maalaala Mo Kaya: The Movie (Will You Remember: The Movie), 1994; Patayin sa Sindak si Barbara (Kill Barbara with Fright) and Sarah … Ang Munting Prinsesa (Sarah … The Little Princess), 1995; Madrasta (Stepmother) and Cedie, 1996; Batang PX (Phil-American Boy), Ipaglaban Mo: The Movie II (Fight for It: The Movie 2), and Ang Lalaki sa Buhay ni Selya (The Man in Her Life), 1997; Bata, Bata … Paano Ka Ginawa? (Lea’s Story), 1998; Wansapanataym (Once upon a Time) and Esperanza: The Movie, 1999; Anak (The Child) and Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000; La Vida Rosa (The Life of Rosa) and Bagong Buwan (New Moon), 2001; Kailangan Kita (I Need You), American Adobo, and Dekada ’70 (The 1970s), 2002; Feng Shui and Milan, 2004; Dubai and Nasaan Ka Man (Wherever You Are), 2005; Sukob (The Wedding Curse) and Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo (Partner, Participant, Partaker), 2006; One More Chance and Sakal, Sakali, Saklolo (Strangle, Perchance, Help), 2007; Caregiver and A Very Special Love, 2008; I Love You, Goodbye and In My Life, 2009; Here Comes the Bride and RPG Metanoia, 2010; Bulong (Whisper) and No Other Woman, 2011; The Healing and The Mistress, 2012; and A Moment in Time and On the Job, 2013.

Many of the films made by Star Cinema have been recognized by award-giving bodies like the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, Gawad Urian, Film Academy of the Philippines, and Star Awards. Written by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu
(See MUSIC volume.)

SUNGA, ALEXb. ca 1925. Scriptwriter and movie director. One of Sunga’s earliest projects was the movie Tayug: Ang Bayang Api (Tayug: The Oppressed Town), 1947, the story line of which he wrote with Ricardo L. Brillantes and the screenplay with Jorge de Santos. He wrote the screenplay for Labi ng Bataan (Bataan Survivors), 1948, a Ramon Estella movie, and was scriptwriter and director of both Hindi Ako Susuko (I Will Not Surrender), 1949, which starred the love team Leila Morena and Efren Reyes, and Tigang na Lupa (Arid Earth), 1950, about the agrarian problem in Central Luzon, which starred Rogelio de la Rosa and Leila Morena. He directed, with Pedro S. Vera, Baril o Araro (Gun or Plow), 1955, also about agrarian problems, and Sisang Tabak (Sisa the Bolo Wielder), 1958, which starred Cesar Ramirez and Lilia Dizon. His other directorial works include Matira ang Matibay (The Strong Survives), 1958; Dead or Alive, 1962; Basang Sisiw (Pitiful Loser), 1970; and Nangyari sa Kagubatan (It Happened in the Wilderness), 1979.

Writing scripts for Fernando Poe Jr in the 1980s, he was nominated by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Muslim Magnum .347, 1986, and by the Film Academy of the Philippines for Ang Supremo (The Supreme Chief), 1988. Written byRamon Jocson and Ellen Bomasang, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

SUZARA, ROMY (Romeo Valmonte Suzara) b. Cabanatuan City 14 Jul 1940. Movie director. His parents are Ignacio Suzara and Lourdes Valmonte. He finished grade school at Caloocan Elementary School and high school at FEATI University. He took a course on television and movie directing at New York RCA Institute of Technology. While in New York, he worked in the sound recording unit of the United Nations Secretariat from 1966 to 1969.

Suzara directed his first movie Ang Kundoktora (The Conductress) in 1972. His other movies are Hello, Goodnight, Goodbye (1975); Laruang Apoy (Playing with Fire), Wanakosey (I Have Nothing to Say), and Mga Bilanggong Birhen (Caged Virgins), 1977; Salonga, Boy Pana (Bow and Arrow Kid), and Hamog (Dew), 1978; Hold-up, 1979; Pepeng Shotgun and Pag-ibig na Walang Dangal (Love without Honor), 1980; Sana Bukas Pa ang Kahapon (Hoping Yesterday Was Tomorrow), 1983; Idol, 1984; Deadly Target, 1986; Itakwil Man Ako ng Langit (Even If Heaven Disowns Me), 1991; Sarah … ang Munting Prinsesa (Sarah … the Little Princess), 1995; Hiram (Borrowed), 2003; and Sigaw sa Hatinggabi (Scream at Midnight), 2014.

Suzara holds two Best Director awards: for Mga Uod at Rosas (Worms and Roses), 1982, from the Film Academy of the Philippines; and for the TV show ’Yan ang Mrs. Ko (That’s My Wife), 1979, from the Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining. He was also named Movie Director of the Year 1981-82 by the Civic Foundation of the Philippines. Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

TAGALOG ILANG-ILANG PRODUCTIONS (TIIP)Originally a partnership by the brothers Espiridion and Antonio Laxa, Tagalog Ilang-Ilang Productions was expanded to a corporation in 1961 with Atty Espiridion Laxa as president and chairman of the board.
