TIIP is noted primarily for its action movies. Its first production in 1961 teamed up Fernando Poe Jr and Zaldy Zshornack in Kilabot sa Barilan (Gunfight Terror). This was followed by similar movies from 1961 to 1963: Ikaw o Ako (You or I), with Fernando Poe Jr and Romeo Vasquez; Baril sa Baril (Gun to Gun), with Fernando Poe Jr and Joseph Estrada; and a combination of action stars in Mga Tigreng Taga-Bukid (Tigers from the Countryside) and Ang Dakilang Siyam (The Great Nine). By 1964, TIIP had introduced new action stars in the persons of Jess Lapid and Tony Ferrer. Lapid made his mark in films like Kardong Kidlat (Lightning Kardo) and Suicide Commandos, while Ferrer rose to prominence in Sabotage and Dial 717. His role of superagent was derived from the popularity of the James Bond pictures of the period.

TIIP is likewise remembered for giving Vilma Santos her big break as teen star when it paired her with singer-actor Edgar Mortiz in My Pledge of Love, 1970. The love team rivaled the popularity of the Nora Aunor–Tirso Cruz III tandem during this period. TIIP also gave Santos her first successful solo movies with the revival of the popular Mars Ravelo superheroines in Dyesebel, 1973, and Lipad, Darna, Lipad (Fly, Darna, Fly), 1973.

In later years, TIIP slowed down on movie production, bowing to the competition of rival producers who owned theaters and had a ready circuit for their pictures. Nevertheless, it is credited with having assisted the major stars like Fernando Poe Jr, Joseph Estrada, and Vilma Santos in forming their own movie companies. TIIP president Laxa subsequently became director-general of the Film Academy of the Philippines.Written by Mauro Tumbocon Jr

TARNATE, JOSE H. (Jose Honrado Tarnate) b. Pasay City 11 Sep 1919. d. Manila 19 Dec 1989. Movie editor. His parents are Angeles Honrado and Jose A. Tarnate. He studied commerce at Far Eastern University, Manila. Tarnate is married to Adelina Arroyo with whom he had four children.

In 1937, he worked at various jobs with Sampaguita Pictures before becoming head of the studio’s editing department. He is the nephew of Dolores “Mommy” Vera of Sampaguita Pictures. Among his films are Jukebox Jamboree, 1964; Doon Po sa Amin (In Our Place), 1968; Young Girl and Bittersweet, 1969; Young Love, 1970; Life Everlasting, 1971; Tatlong Kasalanan (Three Sins) and Mrs. Eva Fonda, 16, 1976.

Tarnate received the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences award for Best Editing three times: for Bondying, 1954, Kamandag (Venom), 1959, and Pinagbuklod ng Langit (Joined by Heaven), 1969. He also received the Metro Manila Film Festival award for Best Editing for Rubia Servios, 1978.Written by Ramon Jocson

TAROG, JERROLD(Jerrold Viacrucis Tarog) aka Ramon Ukit, Pats R. Ranyo, Roger “TJ” Ladro, David Barril. b. 30 May 1977. Film director, screenwriter, editor, composer, actor, and producer. Tarog is the son of Jose Tarog and Aurora Viacrucis. He graduated from the University of the Philippines Rural High School in Los Baños, Laguna. He received a degree in music, major in music composition, from the University of the Philippines Diliman.

Among the films Tarog directed are Carpool, 2006; Confessional, 2007; Mangatyanan, 2009; Senior Year and the “Punerarya” (Funeral Parlor) episode of Shake, Rattle & Roll 12, 2010; Agusan Marsh Diaries, Aswang, and the “Parola” (Lighthouse) episode of Shake, Rattle & Roll 13, 2011; Sana Dati (If Only), 2013; the “Ulam” (Viand) episode of Shake, Rattle & Roll 15, 2014; and Heneral Luna (General Luna), 2015. He wrote, directed, and scored the short films Astig (Tough), 2007, and Faculty, 2010. Tarog wrote the screenplay of and edited most of these films. He appeared as the lead actor in Confessional. Being a formally trained musician, he also composed music for films.

Notable among the other films for which Tarog created the music score are Masahista (The Masseur), 2005; Kubrador (The Bet Collector), 2006; Foster Child, 2007; Ang Damgo ni Eleuteria (Eleuteria’s Dream), 2010; The Healing, 2012; and Mariquina, 2014.

In 2006, Tarog, together with his colleagues Rudy Gonzales and Nonoy Dadivas, received an award for Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration from the Young Critics Circle (YCC) Film Desk for Masahista. The following year, Tarog received a Balanghai trophy for Best Original Music Score from the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival for Kadin (The Goat), 2007. Also in 2007, he garnered awards for Best Picture, Best Director (shared with Ruel Antipuesto), Best Screenplay, Best Editing, and Best Sound from the Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival for Confessional. In 2008, Tarog won several more awards for Confessional, including Best Southeast Asian Film from Cinemanila International Film Festival and Best First Feature Film Award from Cinefan Festival of Asian and Arab Cinema. Tarog received Best Music awards from the 2010 Cinema One Originals and the 2011 Gawad Urian for Ang Damgo ni Eleuteria. Also in 2011, he won the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) award for Best Editing for Emir, 2010. Still in 2011, he received the Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration from the YCC for Shake, Rattle & Roll 12 (shared with Lamberto Casas Jr). In 2013, he won Balanghai trophies for Best Film, Best Director, Best Sound, Best Original Music Score, and Best Editing from the Cinemalaya for Sana Dati. He also won the Best Music award for Bendor (Vendor) at the 2013 Cinema One Originals. In 2014, he won the YCC Best Editing award for Pagpag: Siyam na Buhay (Shake-Off: Nine Lives), 2013, an award he shared with Aleks Castañeda, who also won for the film Porno. In that same year, Tarog received the Dekada Award for Best Director from the Star Awards for Movies for his work from 2003 to 2013. Tarog’s most critically celebrated work, Heneral Luna, won him the following awards in 2016: Best Editing, Best Music Score, Best Director, and Best Screenplay (shared with co-writers Henry Francia and E. A. Rocha) from the FAP; and Best Director, Best Cinematography, Best Sound, and Best Editing from the Gawad Urian. Written by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

TIONGSON, LITO (Angelito Guillermo Tiongson) b. Solano, Nueva Vizcaya 3 Mar 1953. d. 10 Oct 2004. Filmmaker and playwright. Born to Catalino Tiongson and Rosario Guillermo, he married Maria Luz Quesada. He finished elementary and high school at St. Louis School in Solano. He obtained his bachelor’s degree in humanities, major in art history, from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman in 1973.

Tiongson joined the Philippine Educational Theater Association in 1975. He became an apprentice under Lino Brocka, first as production assistant for Bona, 1980, and Kontrobersyal (Controversial), 1981, and eventually as assistant director for Burgis (Bourgeois), 1981, Caught in the Act, 1981, and other films. In 1982, he directed his first feature, Hubad na Gubat (Naked Forest), starring Phillip Salvador, Tetchie Agbayani, and Raul Aragon, produced by Topaz Films and written by Edgardo Maranan.

In the last quarter of 1982, Tiongson founded AsiaVisions Media Foundation (AVMF), originally Creative Audio-Visual Specialists, with Danilo Consumido and Jose Cuaresma. AVMF lasted until the late 1990s. It was a nonprofit foundation that aimed to develop the documentary film as a medium for the people’s struggle against all forms of exploitation and oppression. Tiongson served as AsiaVisions board secretary from 1985 to 1991.

Tiongson’s film work consists primarily of documentaries that were collectively authored under AsiaVisions. Among these are Arrogance of Power, 1983; Toil and Turmoil, 1984; No Time for Crying, 1986; Mendiola Massacre and Beyond the Walls of Prison, 1987; Migrante, 1988; DH and Lean, 1989; and Fragments, 1991.

Tiongson directed Musika (Music) and Sining-Biswal (Visual Arts), 1989, for the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). The CCP and AsiaVisions produced an adaptation of Rogelio Sikat’s “Tata Selo” titled Isang Munting Lupa (A Piece of Land), 1989, which Tiongson co-directed with Eulalio “Eli” Guieb III. In 2003, he directed Tunog Pinoy: A History of Philippine Radio of the CCP documentary series on broadcasting.

Tiongson also directed TV productions, such as “Panagpo sa Mactan/Lapu-Lapu,” an episode of the Alab ng Lahi (Fire of the Race) series, 1983; Ang Aming Daigdig (Our World), 1986; Bulilit (Tiny Tot), 1990; the public affairs series Pinoy Tok, 1990; the educational series Sine’skwela, 1994 (also as head writer); and Private Affairs, 1995. The CCP featured a retrospective of his works in the Independent Cinema and Video Artist Series, 1989.

Tiongson also wrote stage plays, short stories, and essays. His works for the stage include Cara y Cruz (Heads or Tails), 1974; Ang Sumpa (The Curse) and Ang Walang Kamatayang Buhay ni Juan de la Cruz Alyas … (The Never-Ending Life of Juan de la Cruz Alias …), 1975; Ang Hatol ng Guhit na Bilog (adaptation of The Caucasian Chalk Circle), 1977; Noong Unang Panahon: Tatlong Kuwentong Bayan (Once upon a Time: Three Folk Tales), 1978; Niño (Boy), 1979; Pari-Pari (Priest-Priest), later adapted for television, 1980; Dugo sa Tigang na Lupa (Blood on the Arid Land), 1981; A Prisoner’s Testament, 1984; and Testamento (Testament), 1993.

As a playwright, Tiongson received awards for Cara y Cruz from UP Timpalak Panitik; Ang Walang Kamatayang Buhay… from the Palihang Aurelio Tolentino Playwriting Contest, 1975; and Pari-Pari, second prize in the Palanca Awards, 1980. He also won at the annual CCP film and video festivals for No Time for Crying, first prize, 1987; Mendiola Massacre, second prize, 1987; Beyond the Walls of Prison, first prize, 1988; Lean, second prize, 1988; and Fragments, first prize, 1991. Fragments also won the award for the documentary from the Film Academy of the Philippines and the special jury prize in the 1992 TAM TAM International Festival in Italy; Batas Militar (Martial Law) won Best Documentary in the 1997 Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon and the 1997 Golden Dove Awards.

From 1993 until his death, Tiongson taught screenwriting and film-TV production. He became the chairperson of the Department of Mass Communication of St. Scholastica’s College, 1997-98. He was teaching in the Department of Broadcast of the College of Mass Communication, UP Diliman, when he was diagnosed with lymphoma and succumbed to pulmonary embolism that arose from his cancer in 2004. Written by Rosalinda Galang and Rosemarie Roque
Togo (See Pugo and Togo.)

TOLENTINO, LORNA(Victoria Lorna Perez Aluquin-Fernandez) aka LT. b. Concepcion, Tarlac 23 Dec 1961. Movie and television actor, producer. Her parents are Eloisa Perez and Amado Aluquin. She finished elementary and high school at St. Anthony School. She took up courses in fine arts at St. Paul College in Quezon City and mass communications at the University of Santo Tomas and Maryknoll (now Miriam) College, 1988. She is first cousin to actors Amy Perez and Zsa Zsa Padilla, and a niece to actor Jerry Pons. She was married to actor-producer RudyFernandez who died in 2008. They have two children, Rap and Renz Fernandez, who are both TV actors.

Tolentino first appeared in Prima Productions’ My Little One, 1970, using the screen name Giselle. Later, she changed this to LornaTolentino, after Siony Tolentino, who helped her enter FPJProductions. She played the young SusanRoces in Divina Gracia (Divine Grace), 1970. The following year, she was tapped by LinoBrocka to play one of the lead roles in Lea Productions’ Lumuha Pati mga Anghel (Even the Angels Wept). She was also cast in Pag-ibig Mo Buhay Ko (Your Love My Life), 1973, directed by Eddie Rodriguez for Virgo Films. Her first starring role was in Langit Ko ang Pag-ibig Mo (My Heaven Is Your Love), 1975, with Panchito and EddieGarcia. She appeared with Roberto Gonzales and Rodel Naval in Subok na Matatag (Proven Tough), 1975; then she was paired with TirsoCruzIII in Dalagita (Young Lady) and with Rudy Fernandez in Leap Year Ngayon, Lagot Ka, Pipikutin Kita (It’s Leap Year, Beware, I’ll Get You to Marry Me), 1976. Her other movies during this period are Baby Doll, Miss Dulce Amor, Ina (Miss Dulce Amor, Mother), and Katawang Alabok (Body of Dust), 1978; Iskandalo (Scandal), Stepsisters, Dalaga (Lady), and Bakit May Putik ang Bulaklak? (Why Is There Mud on the Flower?), 1979.

The 1980s proved a turning point in her career when film critics and audiences started to notice her talent. Her notable films of this period are Moral, 1982; Init sa Magdamag (Midnight Passion), 1983; Huwag Mo Kaming Isumpa (Do Not Curse Us) and Nakagapos na Puso (Shackled Heart), 1986; Maging Akin Ka Lamang (Anything to Have You), 1987; Natutulog Pa ang Diyos (God Is Still Sleeping) and Nagbabagang Luha (Smoldering Tears), 1988; and Kailan Mahuhugasan ang Kasalanan? (When Will Sin Be Washed Away?), 1989. More notable films followed, like Ayaw Matulog ng Gabi (The Night Is Restless), 1990; Kislap sa Dilim (Spark in the Dark), 1991; Patayin sa Sindak si Barbara (Kill Barbara with Fright), 1995; Pusong Mamon (Soft Hearts), 1998; Abakada … Ina (ABC … Mother), 2001; Magnifico, 2003; Mano Po 5: Gua Ai Di (I Kiss Your Hand 5: I Love You), 2006; Katas ng Saudi (Fruit of Labor in Saudi), 2007; Sa ’Yo Lamang (Only Yours), 2010; Ang Panday 2 (The Blacksmith 2), 2011; Burgos, 2013; and Felix Manalo, 2015.

Her involvement in television includes Dahil May Isang Ikaw (Because There Is You), 2009-10; Minsan Lang Kita Iibigin (I Will Love You Only Once), 2011; Glamorosa (Glamorous), 2011-12; Pidol’s Wonderland: Moomoo Mia, Valiente, Third Eye, Artista Academy, and Pahiram ng Sandali (Lend Me a Moment), 2012; Cassandra: Warrior Angel, Genesis, and Home Sweet Home, 2013; and My Destiny, 2014.

Tolentino won Best Child Performer from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels without Heaven), 1970. From the Film Academy of the Philippines, she won Best Actress for Maging Akin Ka Lamang, 1987. She earned the distinction of being a “grand slam” winner, receiving Best Actress awards from four major award-giving bodies—FAMAS, Gawad Urian, Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), and Star Awards—for her performance in Narito ang Puso Ko (Here Is My Heart), 1993. She continued receiving awards, including two more FAMAS Best Actress awards for Abakada … Ina and Katas ng Saudi; and two more FAP Best Actress awards for Abakada … Ina and Sa ’Yo Lamang.Written by Nenuca Jose and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

TOLOSA, CARLOS VANDER (Carlos Tolosa Vander Voort) b. Manila 6 Jul 1902. d. 1968. Movie director, actor, and scriptwriter. His parents are Henry Vander Voort, an American, and Francisca Tolosa, a Spaniard. He finished commerce at Ateneo de Manila.

Before he ventured into the movie industry, he was a classical dancer for a Spanish performing troupe at the Plaza Theater. His first movie was the silent picture Collegian Love, 1930, which he himself wrote and directed. Later, he directed the Filipino poet Jose Corazon de Jesus, aka Huseng Batute, in two silent movies, Oriental Blood, 1930, produced by Carmen Concha, and Ang Ilaw ng Kapitbahay (A Neighbor’s Lamp), 1932, a Banahaw picture. He also directed the silent movie Ang Gayuma (Love Potion), 1932, starring Mary Walter and Salvador Zaragoza. His first talking picture was Filippine Films’ X-R-X, 1934, starring Mary Walter, Rosa del Rosario, and the brothers Carlos and Jose Padilla Jr. Tolosa had the distinction of directing the opening films of the major important movie studios in the pre-World War II era: Parlatone’s Diwata ng Karagatan (Goddess of the Sea), 1936; Sampaguita’s Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), 1937; and LVN’s Giliw Ko (My Love), 1939.

His other prewar films include the musical productions Nasaan Ka Irog? (Where Are You, Beloved?), 1937, and Madaling Araw (Break of Dawn), 1938; the action-fantasy Tigre: Ang Taong Halimaw (Tiger: The Human Monster), 1938; and dramatic films like Milagro ng Nazareno sa Quiapo (Miracle of the Nazarene in Quiapo), 1937, starring Angel Esmeralda and Yolanda Marquez; and Dahong Lagas (Withered Leaf) and Mabangong Bulaklak (Fragrant Flower), 1939. He also directed LVN’s tropical saga Hali, 1940, before transferring to Filippine Films to direct Norma Blancaflor in three films: Dalaga, Isang Ngiti Mo Lamang (Lady, Just One Smile from You), Binibini ng Palengke (Muse of the Market), and Binibiro Lamang Kita (I Was Only Joking), all released in 1941. His last film for Philippine Films before World War II broke out was Serenata sa Nayon (Country Serenade), 1941, starring Rogelio de la Rosa, with 100 beautiful women singing the love songs of Mike Velarde Jr.
During the Japanese Occupation, Tolosa shifted to writing and directing stage shows.

He returned to directing movies after the war, among them, X’Otic Films’ Sunset over Corregidor, 1948, released worldwide by Universal International Pictures. He also directed Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), 1948, for Nolasco Bros Pictures and Darna at ang Babaing Lawin (Darna and the Hawkwoman), 1952, for Royal Productions. For Movietec, and later Lebran Inc, he directed Song of Sto. Tomas, 1950; Kalbaryo ni Hesus (The Calvary of Jesus) and Ang Pagsilang ng Mesiyas (The Birth of the Messiah), 1952; and Paniwalaan Dili (Believe It or Not), 1953. He returned to Sampaguita Pictures to do the remake of Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), 1957, and the films of Dolphy spoofing the Western jungle lord as Tanzan, the Mighty, 1962, and Tanzan vs Tarzan, 1963, among others. He did 20 other movies for Sampaguita from 1957 to 1966. His last picture was the Divina Valencia starrer Sexy Yata ’Yan (She’s the Sexy One), 1966. Written by Ramon Jocson and Lena S. Pareja

TORDESILLAS, JAKE (Joaquin Andueza Tordesillas) b. Quezon City 17 Oct 1952. d. Quezon City 30 Jun 2017. Movie and television scriptwriter. He was the son of Jesus Tordesillas and Felisa Andueza. He finished elementary at Don Bosco Technical Institute and high school at the University of San Agustin in Iloilo City. He obtained his degree in English at Adamson University.

Tordesillas wrote the scripts for such movies as High School circa ’65 and Annie Batungbakal, 1979; Ang Boyfriend Kong Kano (My American Boyfriend) and Minsan, May Isang Ina (Once There Was a Mother), 1983; Kaya Kong Abutin ang Langit (I Can Reach the Sky) and Bagets (Young Ones), 1984; Tagos ng Dugo (Bloodstain), 1987; Kapag Napagod ang Puso (When the Heart Tires), 1988; Sinungaling Mong Puso (Your Lying Heart) and Dinampot Ka Lang sa Putik (You’re Just Picked Up from the Mud), 1992; Sa ’Yo Lamang (Only Yours), 1995; Pahiram Kahit Sandali (Lend Even a Moment), 1998; and Nandito Ako … Nagmamahal sa ’Yo (I’m Here … Loving You), 2009. He also line-produced the last three movies, as well as Abel Morado: Ikaw ang Maysala (Abel Morado: You Are Guilty), 1993.

Tordesillas branched out to write for television, also serving as headwriter or script consultant. Some of his works on television are Ilumina, 2010; Amaya, 2011; Legacy, My Beloved, and One True Love, 2012; My Husband’s Lover, 2013; and Magpakailanman (Forever), 2013-15.

Tordesillas won in the Catholic Mass Media Awards for My Other Woman, 1990, co-written with Jose Javier Reyes. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

TORRE, JOEL(Jose Rizalino Torre) b. Bacolod City 19 Jun 1961. Movie and television actor. His parents are Alfonso and Luz Torre. He studied at De La Salle College in Bacolod from elementary to college. He is married to Christy Azcona, with whom he has two children.

At the age of seven, Torre began acting in school plays. After college, he worked as a production assistant for Peque Gallaga in the TV comedy show Champoy. Encouraged by Gallaga, he auditioned for and was given a major role in Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982, turning in a memorable performance under the guidance of his mentor.

Among his films are Init sa Magdamag (Midnight Passion), 1983; Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), 1985; Hindi Kita Malilimutan (I Cannot Forget You), 1986; Bilanggo sa Dilim (Prisoner in the Dark), 1987; Hiwaga sa Balete Drive (Mystery on Balete Drive) and Magkano ang Iyong Dangal (How Much Is Your Honor Worth), 1988; Mana sa Ina (Her Mother’s Child), 1990; Kasalanan ang Buhayin Ka (It’s a Sin to Keep You Alive), 1990; Comfort Women: A Cry for Justice, 1994; Eskapo: The Sergio Osmeña–Geny Lopez Story (Fugitive), 1995; Mumbaki (Shaman), 1996; Tirad Pass: The Story of Gen. Gregorio del Pilar, 1997; Jose Rizal, 1998; Bayaning 3rd World (Third World Hero), 1999; Tanging Yaman (A Change of Heart), 2000; Sanib (Possession), 2003; Evolution of a Filipino Family and Panaghoy sa Suba (The Call of the River), 2004; Ploning and Baler, 2008; Sabungero (The Cockfighter), 2009; Amigo (Friend), 2010; The Healing, 2012; and On the Job, 2013.

In 1993, he starred as Crisostomo Ibarra in the TV series Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. He appeared in numerous TV series, such as Esperanza, 1997; Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1999; Sa Puso Ko, Iingatan Ka (In My Heart, I Will Take Care of You), 2001; Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (I Wish This Were Forever), 2003; Marina, 2004; Zorro, 2009; 100 Days to Heaven, 2011; Walang Hanggan (My Eternal), 2012; Dahil sa Pag-ibig (Because of Love), 2012; My Little Juan, Honesto, and Juan dela Cruz, 2013; and On the Wings of Love, 2015.

Torre won Best Actor awards for the movie Unfaithful Wife, 1986, from the Catholic Mass Media Awards, and for the TV miniseries Boracay, 1991, from the Star Awards for Television. In 2000, he won Best Supporting Actor for Bayaning 3rd World from the Gawad Urian. He got two Best Actor awards also from the Gawad Urian for the films Batang West Side (West Side Avenue), 2001, and On the Job, 2013. He also won a Best Actor award from Cinemanila International Film Festival for Batang West Side. For On the Job, he received a Best Actor award from the 2013 Puchon International Fantastic Film Festival and Best Performance by an Actor in a Lead Role from the Golden Screen Awards. He received two acting awards from Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival: Best Supporting Actor for Yanggaw (Affliction), 2008, and Best Actor for Kabisera (Head of the Table), 2013. Written by Cristine Directo, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

TORRENTE, TOTOY(Alfonso Santos Torrente) b. Tondo, Manila 26 Jan 1914. d. Manila 3 Feb 1982. Movie and stage actor, special effects artist. His parents are Fernando Torrente and Juliana Santos. He was married to Concepcion Putian with whom he had 10 children. As a small boy, he ran away from home to join a circus troupe, where he performed for six years as a clown on the flying trapeze. In 1935, he graduated to the stage of the Cine Star on Azcarraga (now Claro M. Recto) Avenue, as a comedian. When the famous comedy team of Pugo and Togo transferred to another theater, the Star hired Torrente and his partner, Totong Rosales, to take their place.

His movie career began in 1939 with Lamberto V. Avellana’s Sakay. After World War II, Torrente was in demand for stereotype Japanese officer roles that he played to the hilt, complete with costume, props, makeup, and Japanese accent. He rose to become the country’s top special effects artist and made his mark in films such as Sunset over Corregidor, 1947; Isang Dakot na Bigas (A Handful of Rice), 1948; Kumander Sundang (Commander Bolo), 1949; Kulog sa Tag-Araw (Thunder in Summer), 1950; and Cry Freedom, 1959.

Though he was adept at creating special effects for fantasy films, his specialty was the creation of war effects for action pictures: exploding bombs and artillery shells, advancing tanks, ricocheting bullets, burning cities, explosions. He did the battle scenes and special effects of Hollywood films shot in the Philippines, such as Surrender Hell, Merrill’s Marauders, Huk, Blackburn’s Guerrillas, and Marco Polo. He also supplied various movie companies with costumes, sets, props, makeup artists, and stuntmen whom he personally trained and supervised. He founded the TNT Stuntmen.

Torrente received the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Film Academy of the Philippines in 1986 in recognition of his outstanding contribution to Philippine cinema. Written by Nenuca Jose

TORRES, JOHN (Jonathan Dalog Torres) b. Manila 24 Sep 1975. Director, screenwriter, editor. He is the son of Rodolfo Claro Torres and Nympha Dalog and is married to filmmaker Shireen Martinez Seno. He earned his bachelor of arts degree in communication from Ateneo de Manila University.

Torres’s emergence as a filmmaker coincides with the rise of independent filmmaking in the Philippines in the mid-2000s. He produced three short films in 2004: Kung Paano Kita Liligawan nang Di Kumakapit sa Iyo (How I Can Court You Without Depending on You), Salat (Wanting), and Tawidgutom (Bridging Hunger). All three were screened at Singapore International Film Festival. The second was also exhibited at Clermont-Ferrand Short Film Festival and the 2005 Cinemanila International Film Festival where it won the Ishmael Bernal Award for Young Cinema. The third competed in the 2005 Berlin Asia-Pacific Film Festival.

Using “video diary” footage of his travels and activities in the alternative art scene, Torres made Todo Todo Teros (All, All Is Terror), 2006, about an artist who wakes up one day as a terrorist. The film demonstrates Torres’s visual style as a filmmaker and introduces his predilection for experimentation, surreal narratives, bizarre characters, oblique configurations of theme, and multivalent symbolisms. It received the Dragons and Tigers Award for Young Cinema in the 25th Vancouver International Film Festival, the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) and International Federation of Film Critics awards in the 2006 Singapore International Film Festival, a Jury Special Mention in the Jogja-NETPAC Asian Film Festival, and the Best Editing award in the 2007 Gawad Urian.

In 2007, Torres received the Grand Jury Prize in Cinemanila International Film Festival for Voice, Tilted Screens, and Extended Scenes of Loneliness, 2007, a work-in-progress which eventually became his second feature, Taon Noong Ako’y Anak sa Labas (Years When I Was a Child Outside), 2008. This was given a Special Mention in the 2008 Southeast Asian Competition, Bangkok International Film Festival.

His third feature, Ang Ninanais (Refrains Happen like Revolutions in a Song), 2010, was premiered in Rotterdam International Film Festival and competed in Torino Film Festival, Era New Horizons Film Festival, and NETPAC Cinemalaya Independent Film Festival. His fourth feature, Lukas Niño (Lukas the Strange), 2013, also premiered in Rotterdam; it won Special Mention in Festival de Cine Lima Independiente.

In between his feature films, Torres continued to direct short films—namely, Hai, They Recycle Heartbreaks in Tokyo So Nothing’s Wasted, 2009; Very Specific Things at Night, 2009; We Don’t Care for Democracy, This Is What We Want: Love and Hope and Its Many Faces, 2010; Muse, 2011; Silent Film, 2011; and The Enchanting, 2012, all of which were exhibited in various international film festivals.

Torres had retrospective exhibitions of his films in the 2014 Festival Internacional de Cine Independiente de Cosquin, the 2013 Vienna International Film Festival, and the 2012 Seoul International New Media Festival. Written by Patrick Campos

TRILLO , DENNIS (Abelardo Dennis Florencio Ho) b. 12 May 1981. Movie and television actor, and singer. Trillo’s first TV exposure was as the Filipino voice of Steve Armstrong in the 1997 reissue of the 1977 classic robot cartoon Chôdenji Mashin Borutesu Faibu (or, in popular memory, Voltes V). Being a voice talent jumpstarted and led to Trillo’s engagement with the TV-viewing public as on-camera performer in the cast of Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001. The soap marked the start of a career as a mainstay of popular TV who appears daily in serials of various genres, weekly in feature anthologies and fixed format shows, and monthly in TV movies and specials.

Trillo’s image as a TV actor matured from teen romances like Twin Hearts, 2003; Mulawin and Love to Love, 2004; Darna, 2005; Mahiwagang Baul (Magic Chest) and Etheria: Ikalimang Kaharian ng Encantadia (Etheria: The Fifth Kingdom of Encantadia), 2005; Now and Forever, 2005-6; Majika, 2006; Super Twins and Zaido: Pulis Pangkalawakan (Zaido: Space Police), 2007; E.S.P. and Dear Friend, 2008; Adik sa ’Yo (Addicted to You) and Obra (Masterpiece), 2009; Darna, 2009-10; Gumapang Ka sa Lusak (Secret Affairs), Love Bug, and Endless Love, 2010; Dwarfina and Sinner or Saint, 2011; Legacy, 2012; to serious dramas, like the Filipino adaptation of the Koreanovela Temptation of Wife, 2012, and the critically acclaimed My Husband’s Lover, 2013.

On film and TV, Trillo took on a variety of roles, but he is remembered for three performances. First, he played Ignacio in the period drama Aishite Imasu 1941 (I Love You), 2004, for which he received a number of awards in 2005: Best Supporting Actor from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences, which also gave him the German Moreno Youth Achievement Award; Best Actor from the Film Academy of the Philippines; Breakthrough Performance by an Actor from the Golden Screen Awards; Best Supporting Actor from the Metro Manila Film Festival; New Movie Actor of the Year from the Star Awards for Movies; and Best Performance from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk. Second, he played the role of Daniel in Mano Po 6: A Mother’s Love (I Kiss Your Hand 6), 2009, for which he won Best Supporting Actor in the Golden Screen Awards. Third, Trillo came out as Eric del Mundo in GMA7’s My Husband’s Lover, 2013, a series that not only established him as a serious actor but also made Philippine TV history by introducing Filipino households to “bromance” and gendered TV viewing. For this role, he won Best Actor in a Drama Series in the 2014 Golden Screen Awards for Television.

Trillo is also known for Blue Moon, 2006, which got him four nominations; Yesterday Today Tomorrow, 2011, three nominations; Rosario, 2010, two nominations; Janitor, 2014, which earned him the Star Awards for Movie Actor of the Year in 2015; and Mulawin: The Movie, 2005, which got him the FAMAS for Best Supporting Actor in 2006. He received Dekada Awards from the Golden Screen Awards in 2013 and from Star Awards for Movies in 2014. Written by Camilo Villanueva, with notes from Clodualdo del Mundo Jr
(See BROADCAST ARTS volume.)

TROFEO, DIK (Ricardo Espiritu Trofeo) b. Manapla, Negros Occidental 11 Dec 1938. Cinematographer, producer, and director. He finished a bachelor of arts in journalism at Lyceum of the Philippines. His parents are Raymundo Trofeo and Melchorita Espiritu. He is married to Nita Rivas, who also produced films. They have four children: Ma. Patricia Trofeo-Ycasiano; Ma. Farah Trofeo-Ishizawa, a foreign film production coordinator; Ricardo Jose Trofeo, director and cinematographer; and Raymundo “Ari” Trofeo, sound recordist and videographer.

Trofeo trained in photography under Dick Baldovino and Brian Brake of Magnum, Time-Life, and National Geographic. He also trained under American cinematographer Louie Stein and director-editor Irving Lerner. He also studied laboratory systems under Tom Nurse of Colorfilm Laboratories, Australia.

Trofeo worked as assistant director to Gerardo de Leon in The Moises Padilla Story, 1961, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1962, El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1963, and Ang Daigdig ng mga Api (The World of the Oppressed), 1965. He shot the photography of several documentaries by Avellana.

Trofeo’s credits for cinematography include Ang Langit sa Lupa (Heaven on Earth), 1967; Igorota (Mountain Maiden), Luha sa Karimlan (Tears in the Dark), and Manila Open City, 1968, all for Nepomuceno Productions. He also did the cinematography for Kalabog en Bosyo Strike Again, 1986, and Narito ang Puso Ko (Here Is My Heart), 1992. He is better known for his documentaries that he photographed and directed like Samtoy, a film on the Ilocanos; Carlos P. Romulo: A Warrior for Peace, 1998, a chronicle about Romulo as a public servant; Moments with the Lord, 2006, a TV miniseries; Traslación (Displacement), 2008, on the 400th anniversary of the Black Nazarene of Quiapo; Sa Mata ng Balita: 50 Taong Pamamahayag sa Telebisyon (In the Eye of News: 50 Years of Television Journalism), 2013; Journey to God’s Heart, 2015, a Holy Week TV special on the Bohol earthquake and typhoon Yolanda; and Salamat sa Alaala (Thanks for the Memory), 2016, a tribute to National Artist Gerardo de Leon.

Trofeo is former president of the Filipino Society of Cinematographers. He is also a master photographer of the Camera Club of the Philippines. Written by Clodualdo del Mundo Jr

TRONQUED, MARIA (Maria Garcia Tronqued-Mañosa) b. Manila 27 Aug 1900. d. Manila 9 Dec 1984. Movie actor. Her parents are Ramon Tronqued, an impresario, and Rosa Garcia, an actor of Spanish zarzuelas. She married architect Manuel Mañosa with whom she had eight children, three of whom, Manuel Jr, Francisco, and Jose, are architects. Manuel Jr is married to choreographer dancer Inday Gaston. Maria’s siblings, Elisea, Matilde, and Ildefonso, were also connected with the stage.

She started her singing career at the age of nine when she appeared on stage with the Compañia Lyrica Infantil. In the 1910s, she was one of the Las Hermanas Tronqued (Elisea, Matilde, and Maria) who became famous on the local stage. She appeared in zarzuelas, such as La Viuda Alegre (The Merry Widow), Conde de Luxemburgo (Count of Luxemborg), and Los Tres Caballeros (Three Knights). The Tronqued sisters also provided entertainment numbers on stage during intermissions in between silent film screenings. It was during one such performance that Maria Tronqued was discovered by producer Dr Edward Gross who invited her to enter the movies.

Tronqued was one of the earliest Filipino film actresses. She played the title role in Nena la Boxeadora (Nena the Boxer), 1916, which was produced and directed by Dr Gross. She portrayed a poor farmer’s daughter who enters the prize ring to save herself from slavery after she was plunged into debt by her father’s illness. Her fight scenes were choreographed by her brother Alfonso Tronqued, who taught her how to pose as a boxer inside the ring. Written by Lena S. Pareja

TUELLS, LORENZO P. (Lorenzo Perez Tuells) b. Madrid, Spain 26 Dec 1899. d. Manila 7 Jul 1956. Movie director, writer. He married Consuelo Otazu, with whom he had three children. Tuells arrived in Manila at four years of age. He studied at Ateneo de Manila and finished a degree in accounting. He practiced as a certified public accountant for Hogar Filipino, Forbs, Munn and Co Ltd, Parsons Hardware, and Luneta Motor Corporation. As a young man, he took correspondence courses in scriptwriting. Later, he enrolled in directing courses at the renowned Palmer Institute of Motion Pictures and at Pennsylvania University, USA.

Tuells was the technical adviser of Excelsior Films in the 1930s. All the leading movie studios, including LVN and Sampaguita Pictures, engaged his services as a motion picture director. His first directorial assignment for LVN was Mabangong Bulaklak (Fragrant Flower), 1939, starring Elsa Oria and Fernando Poe. Among his films for Sampaguita Pictures are Magbalik Ka, Hirang (Come Back, My Love), 1940, starring Corazon Noble and Octavio Romero; Lambingan (Romance), starring Carmen Rosales and Rogelio de la Rosa; Panibugho (Jealousy), starring Corazon Noble and Jose Padilla Jr, and Balatkayo (Pretense), 1941, starring Corazon Noble and Ely Ramos. After the war, he directed Maynila (Manila), 1946; Hele-Hele (Bago Quiere) (Pretending Not to Care), 1947; Ang Kampeon (The Champion), 1949; and Huwag Ka Nang Magtampo (No Hard Feelings), 1950. He also directed the motion picture The Spell, 1950, for Lebran Inc, as well as other films for different production outfits. He also ventured into making documentary pictures for the United States Information Service.

Tuells’s greatest dream was to direct a movie on the life of former president Manuel L. Quezon, from whom he personally obtained the rights in 1941. But the project was aborted by World War II and the death of Quezon. Tuells was also known as a writer in Spanish. He became a member of the Academia Filipina in 1907. Written by Ramon Jocson and Ellen Bomasang, updated by Mario Mendez Jr

TUTANES, JOE (Jose Tujon Tutanes) b. Bicol 24 Sep 1923. Cinematographer. His parents are Eulalio Tutanes and Esperanza Tujon. He studied at Viga Elementary School.

In 1960, Tutanes apprenticed in Larry Santiago’s laboratory and also worked in the laboratory of Balatbat Productions. In 1964, he got a regular job as labman at Santiago’s outfit and, after some time, helped out in camerawork. In 1978 he was promoted to assistant cameraman. He later moved to Tower Productions. In 1979, his big break came when Gerald Productions hired him to be the cameraman in a Chiquito film, Goriong Maton (Gorio the Hoodlum). This was followed by another Chiquito starrer, Jack and the Magic Beans, where he did his first trick shot. His notable films include Private Show and Takaw Tukso (Flirting with Temptation), 1986; Macho Dancer and Ang Pumatay nang Dahil sa Iyo (To Kill for You), 1989; Shake, Rattle & Roll 3, 1991; Divine Mercy sa Buhay ni Sister Faustina (Divine Mercy in the Life of Sister Faustina), 1993; Batang-X (Kid-X) and Baby Love, 1995; Paano ang Puso Ko? (How about My Heart?), 1997; Mula sa Puso (From the Heart) and Esperanza: The Movie, 1999.

Tutanes eventually ventured into television, working in the following shows as lighting director or cameraman: Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2000; Ang Babaeng Hinugot sa Aking Tadyang (The Woman Plucked from My Ribs), 2009; Lumang Piso para sa Puso (An Old Peso for the Heart) and Inday Wanda, 2010; Amaya, 2011; Makapiling Kang Muli (To Be with You Again), 2012; and in the series Magpakailanman(Forever), 2012-15.

Tutanes won two Best Cinematography awards from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Alapaap (Clouds), 1984, and Magic Temple, 1996. He won the award for cinematography from the Film Academy of the Philippines for Ipaglaban Mo: The Movie II (Fight for It: The Movie 2) in 1998. Written by Raquel Hernandez, updated by Mario Mendez Jr
(See MUSIC volume.)

UNITEL PRODUCTIONS INC Established in July 1983, Unitel is a Filipino corporation engaged in the business of producing film and video commercials, documentaries, television shows, events, feature films, branded entertainment, and other original content.

The company evolved from being just a production arm to one that generates its own content. Since 2003, the company produced four award-winning feature films, all graded “A” by the Cinema Evaluation Board: Crying Ladies, 2003; Santa Santita (Magdalena), 2004; La Visa Loca (Crazy Visa), 2005; and I Do Bidoo Bidoo: Heto nAPO Sila! (I Do Bidoo Bidoo: The APO Is Here!), 2012. It worked on five seasons of a 14-episode breakthrough children’s television show for Jollibee called Jollitown and produced season one of the local franchise of Project Runway. In February and March of 2008, it staged national conventions for Coca Cola and Chowking under Saatchi & Saatchi and made for TV5.

In 2006, Unitel, through the leadership of Madonna Tarrayo, the Unitel’s client services head at that time and now its president, built a new production company called Straight Shooters Media Inc. Straight Shooters became one of the most successful and sought-after production companies in the country and region. As the company branches out into content, the business of producing television commercials is maintained. The company did work for all the major advertising agencies, such as McCann Worldwide Group, JWT, Jimenez Basic, Lowe, Y&R, and BBDO.Straight Shooters is also the go-to production house for regional productions as a line producer. It produced projects for various countries such as India, Malaysia, Thailand, United States, and United Kingdom.

Unitel and Straight Shooters are staffed with highly creative teams of producers and directors. The company facilities include production equipment—cameras for film, HD, the Epic, Phantom Camera, Motion Control, Virtual Set,and grip and lighting equipment. It is the only production house with its own editing facility called Engine Room, which has four Final Cut Pro Editing suites, a Quantel Pablo for color grading and online editing, an Imac on Smoke and graphics and visual effects capabilities.

Unitel was awarded six out of the ten Production House of the Year awards handed out by the advertising professional organization 4As. Written by Vincent Nebrida
Urian (See Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino.)
(See BROADCAST ARTS volume.)

VALDEZ , RONALDO (Ronald James Gibbs) b. Manila, 27 Nov 1947. Film and television actor. He is married to Maria Fe Ilagan, one of the daughters of director Gerardo de Leon (Gerardo de Leon Ilagan in real life), and by virtue of marriage became related to the Ilagan clan, such as actors Liberty Ilagan, Robert Arevalo, and Jay Ilagan, and musician Tito Arevalo. He is the father of singer Janno Gibbs.

His career began in 1966 as a teenager starring in the movies Pepe en Pilar (Pepe and Pilar), Mariang Kondesa (Countess Mary), and The Jukebox Queen. His showbiz breakthrough was made possible with the help of Dolphy pairing him up with Susan Roces in the movie Kaming Taga-Ilog (We from the River), 1968.

Valdez, known to be a glamour boy of the Philippine movies during his generation, was paired up with different leading ladies—namely, Chanda Romero, Hilda Koronel, and Gloria Diaz. Alongside Nora Aunor, Valdez portrayed Lucifer in the “Caridad” episode of Fe, Esperanza, Caridad, 1974, and an Ifugao native in Banaue, 1975, both directed by Gerardo de Leon. His other notable films are Hagkan Mo ang Dugo sa Kamay ni Venus (Kiss the Blood in the Hands of Venus) and Babae, Ngayon at Kailanman (Woman, Now and Forever), 1977; Ang Kabiyak (The Spouse) and Langis at Tubig (Oil and Water), 1980; Dear Heart, 1981; Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan? (How Often Is Once?), 1982; Palabra de Honor (Word of Honor), 1983; Kaya Kong Abutin and Langit (I Can Reach the Sky), 1984; Bomba Queen (Porn Queen), Heartache City, and Miguelito: Batang Rebelde (Miguelito: Young Rebel), 1985; Huwag Kang Hahalik sa Diablo (Never Kiss a Devil), 1989; Kolehiyala (College Girl) and Bad Boy, 1990; Joey Boy Munti: 15 Anyos Ka sa Muntinlupa (Joey Boy Munti: You Have 15 Years in Muntinlupa), 1991; Estribo Gang: The Jinggoy Sese Story, 1992; Padre Amante Guerrero (Father Amante Guerrero), 1993; Grepor Butch Belgica Story, 1994; I Love You, Sabado!!! (I Love You, Saturday!!!) and Campus Girls, 1995; Cedie, 1996; and Ikaw Pala ang Mahal Ko (I’m in Love with You All Along), 1997. Over the past decades, Valdez starred in some Star Cinema movies alongside young actors Kristine Hermosa, John Lloyd Cruz, and Bea Alonzo. Some of these films are Trip, 2001, Till There Was You, 2003, and The Mistress, 2012.

Valdez also starred in drama series such as Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001; Kamandag (Venom), 2007; I Love Betty La Fea, 2008; Full House, 2009; Minsan Lang Kita Iibigin (I Will Love You Only Once) and 100 Days to Heaven, 2011; Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Her Mother’s Daughter), 2013; and Ikaw Lamang (No Greater Love), 2014.

For his performance in May Minamahal (Loving Someone), 1993, Valdez won Best Supporting Actor recognitions from the Metro Manila Film Festival, Gawad Urian, Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), and Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences. He received FAP Best Supporting Actor awards for Nasaan ang Puso (Where Is the Heart) in 1998 and for The Mistress in 2013. Written by Gregory del Carmen

VALLEJO , FELY (Felisa Arriola Vallejo-Ilagan) b. Manila 27 Nov 1917. d. 21 Jul 2013. Movie actor and singer. Her parents are Jose Vallejo and Felisa Arriola. She was educated at San Andres Elementary School and Union High School and took voice lessons at the Conservatory of Music in the University of the Philippines. Her brother, Ernesto Vallejo, was a famous violinist. She married National Artist for film Gerardo Ilagan, better known as director Gerardo de Leon. Singer-actor Janno Gibbs is her grandson by daughter Maria Fe and actor Ronaldo Valdez.

Vallejo was dubbed by the press during prewar days as a “diminutive beauty with a golden voice,” rivaled only as a singing star by ElsaOria. She was a movie extra in Huling Awit (Last Song), 1937, before playing her first starring role in Dalisay (Chaste), 1939. Vallejo’s films, though not too many, were big hits. Among her other prewar movies are Ay! Kalisud (Oh, Misery), 1938, shown also in Hawaii and Malaysia; Bahay Kubo (Nipa Hut), 1938; and Kundiman (Love Song), 1941. She made a few more movies after the war, among them, Isumpa Mo, Giliw (Make a Vow, My Love), 1947, and So Long America, 1946, both directed by Gerardo de Leon; and Alaala Kita (Thinking of You), 1961, directed by Cesar Gallardo. Written by Danny Villanueva, updated by Erika Carreon

VARGA, CAROL (Carolina Trinidad) b. 6 Aug 1930. d. Las Vegas, Nevada 8 Mar 2008. Actor. Varga was a talent discovery of actor-producer LeopoldoSalcedo who cast her in his films Highway 54 and Kambal na Lihim (Twin Secrets) in the early 1950s. Previously, she had appeared in minor roles at X’Otic Films where actor Bimbo Danao took her for a screen test. Among her earlier films were Siyudad sa Ilalim ng Lupa (City beneath the Earth), 1949, and Sagur, 1949. One of her memorable roles during this period was that of Mary Magdalene in Carlos Vander Tolosa’s religious epic Kalbaryo ni Hesus (Calvary of Jesus), 1952, produced by LebranProductions. It established her as a screen vamp and set the pace for her succeeding performances in various films as a kontrabida (villainess).

Varga’s star began to shine brightly beginning wih Gerardo de Leon’s Dyesebel, 1953, where she portrayed a two-timing society girl who exposed Edna Luna’s mermaid fins in order to win back her lover, JaimedelaRosa. As a contract star of PremiereProductions she appeared in all its important productions, including Kapitan Berong (Captain Berong), 1953; Laging May Umaga (There’s Always Tomorrow) and Abenturera (Adventurous Woman), 1954; Pandora, 1955; Santa Lucia (Saint Lucia) and Lalo Kitang Mahal (I Love You All the More), 1956; Maskara (Mask) and Principe Alejandre at Don Luis (Prince Alejandre and Don Luis), 1957; Marta Soler, 1958; and Gitarang Ginto (Golden Guitar) and Pitong Gatang (Seven Chupas), 1959. Her other films include Akin ang Paghihiganti (Vengeance Is Mine) and Hongkong Honeymoon, 1960; I Believe, 1961; Apat na Agimat (Four Amulets) and Prinsesang Mandirigma (Warrior Princess), 1962; Sa Pagitan ng Dalawang Mata (Between the Eyes) and Aninong Bakal (Steel Shadow), 1963; Larawan ng Pag-ibig (A Picture of Love) and Anak ni Dyesebel (Dyesebel’s Daughter), 1964; Captain Barbell kontra Captain Bakal (Captain Barbell versus Captain Bakal) and 7 Mukha ni Dr. Evans (7 Faces of Dr Evans), 1965; Ang Iniluluha Ko’y Dugo (My Tears Are Blood), 1966; Hell of Borneo, 1967; and The Secret of the Sacred Forest, 1970. She later left the movies and resided with her family in Las Vegas, Nevada, USA.

Varga won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Supporting Actress award for Guwapo (Handsome), 1954, opposite ReynaldoDante. She earned Best Supporting Actress nominations in the FAMAS for Habang Buhay (For a Lifetime), 1953, where she acted with JosePadilla Jr and NenaCardenas; in Paltik, 1955; and in Akin ang Paghihiganti. Written by Cesar Hernando and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Erika Carreon

VARGAS, VIC (Jose Maria Marfort Asuncion) aka Pinggoy. b. 28 Mar 1934. d. Pasay 19 Jul 2003. Movie actor. He was a physical education instructor at the University of the East when he was offered a contract by Sampaguita-VP Pictures. Vargas is also famous for his proficiency in judo.

Vargas was not only an action star; he revealed a talent for sex-comedy roles in seriocomic dramas, which delighted both his mature and young audiences in films. His first movie was Diegong Tabak (Diego the Bolo Wielder), 1962, opposite LolitaRodriguez. This was followed by a comedy film spoofing the western jungle lord, Tansan vs Tarsan, 1963, where Vargas played the virile ape man Tarzan to Dolphy’s puny Tansan. The film was directed by CarlosVanderTolosa. Vargas’s other movies as a contract star of Sampaguita-VP include Walang Takot sa Patalim (Fearless); Kumander Judo (Commander Judo); From Tokyo with Love, a war drama; Mga Kanyon ng Corregidor (Cannons of Corregidor), a film about World War II; and Paratroop Squadron, all in 1964. When his contract expired, Vargas freelanced with other movie companies, appearing in Ang Tao Ay Makasalanan (Man Is Sinful), 1966; Perlas ng Silangan (Pearl of the Orient), 1969; Padre Valiente (Father Valiente), 1971; Ang Tigre at ang Diablo (The Tiger and the Devil), 1971; Huwag Tularan: Pito ang Asawa Ko (Do Not Imitate: I Have Seven Wives) and Bawal: Asawa Mo, Asawa Ko (Forbidden: Your Spouse, My Spouse), 1974; Daluyong at Habagat (Tall Waves and Wild Wind) and Babaing Hiwalay sa Asawa (Estranged Wife), 1976; BantangKahapon (Threat from the Past), Laruang Apoy (Playing with Fire), and Sino’ng Kapiling? Sino’ng Kasiping? (Housemates? Bedmates?), 1977; Cobra, Lawin, at Dragon (Cobra, Hawk, and Dragon), 1978; and Hold-up, 1979. His other films include Suicide Force, 1982; Hunt the Infiltrators!, 1984; Oscar Ramos: Hitman, 1987; Ang Pumatay nang Dahil sa Iyo (To Kill For You), 1989; Alejandro ‘Diablo’ Malbay, 1993; Relax Ka Lang, Sagot Kita (Relax, I Got You), 1994; The Secret of Katrina Salazar, 1997; and the historical film Lapu-Lapu, 2002. He also appeared in ABS-CBN’s Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000-2002, and GMA Network’s Kung Mawawala Ka (A World without You), 2002-3.

Vargas won Best Actor for El Vibora (The Viper), 1972, at the 7th Manila Film Festival. The film Pagdating saDulo (At the Top), 1971, in which he had a part, was chosen by the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino as one of the 10 Best Films of the Decade 1970-79. Written by Joy Galvez and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Erika Carreon

VASQUEZ, ROMEO (Ricardo Alandy Sumilang) b. Tayabas, Quezon 6 May 1942. d. Los Angeles, California, USA 2 May 2017. Movie actor. His parents are Salome Alandy and Dominador Sumilang. He was married to actor AmaliaFuentes with whom he had a child, actor Anna Lissa aka Liezl. He and Fuentes separated in 1969. He was a premed student at the San Beda College.

Vasquez, a popular matinee actor during the 1950s and 1960s, first appeared in Rosanna, 1955, and in Miss Tilapia, 1956. He played a lead role in Sino ang Maysala? (Who Is Guilty?) and in Pretty Boy, 1957. As a Sampaguita contract talent, he did song-and-dance roles. He and Fuentes made a popular love team in movies like Bobby, 1958; Bilanggong Birhen (Caged Virgins) and Isinakdal Ko ang Aking Ama (I Accused My Father), 1960; and Veinte Ocho de Mayo (The 28th of May), 1960. As a freelancer, he portrayed a variety of roles. His other films include Apat na Yugto ng Buhay (Four Chapters of Life), 1961; Pitong Kabanalan ng Isang Makasalanan (Seven Virtues of a Sinner), 1962; Ako’y Iyong-Iyo (I’m All Yours), 1963; Tatlong Siga sa Maynila (Three Toughies in Manila), 1964; Sapagkat Ikaw ay Akin (Because You Are Mine), 1965; Ikaw … Ang Gabi at ang Awit (Arrivederci Roma) and Pitong Pag-ibig ni Michaela (The Seven Loves of Michaela), 1966; Maruja, 1967; Kailanma’y Di Ka Mag-iisa (You’ll Never Be Alone), 1968; Rowena, 1969; Panginoon ng mga Kilabot (Lord of the Fearsome), 1970; Nagbalik na Lumipas (The Past Returning), 1973; Diego Rival, 1977; Dalawang Pugad, Isang Ibon (Two Nests, One Bird); Pinagbuklod ng Pag-ibig (Bound by Love), Bakit Kailangan Kita? (Why Do I Need You?), and Pag-ibig Ko sa Iyo Lang Ibibigay (I Will Give My Love Only to You), 1978; Bakit May Pag-ibig Pa (Wherefore Love), 1979; Ayaw Kong Maging Kerida (I Don’t Want to Be a Mistress), 1983; Nang Masugatan ang Gabi (When the Night Was Wounded), 1984; Hello Lover, Goodbye Friend, 1985; The Vizconde Massacre Story: God Help Us!, 1993; The Untold Story: Vizconde Massacre II; May the Lord Be with Us!, 1994; Urban Rangers, 1995; Reputasyon (Reputation), 1997. He also appeared in the GMA Network series Di Ba’t Ikaw (Wasn’t It You), 1999-2001.

He won the Golden Harvest award for Best Actor in the 5th Asian Film Festival for his performance as a juvenile delinquent in Ako ang Maysala (I Am Guilty), 1958. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Erika Carreon
(See MUSIC volume.)

VELEZ , VIVIAN (Vivian Zapata Rodriguez) aka VV. b. Cebu City 2 Dec 1956. Movie actor. She finished her secondary education at Venice High School in United States. After graduation she worked as a fashion model at the Manila Hilton. Velez was married to an Israeli and she has two sons with her estranged husband.

One of her earliest movies is Lea Productions’ Andalucia, 1975, where she shared star billing with FernandoPoe Jr and Gloria Diaz. In Ligaw Tingin, Halik Hangin (Flirty Looks, Harmless Kisses), 1976, she co-starred with Fred Montilla, GloriaRomero, and JayIlagan. This was followed by other light roles in Walang Bakas na Maiiwan (Leave No Traces), Diego Rival, Mariposang Dagat (Sea Butterfly), Valentin Labrador, and Beerhouse, all released in 1977. One of her more significant movies during this period is Babae, Ngayon at Kailanman (Woman, Now and Forever), 1977, a film based on three literary classics, scripted by AlbertoFlorentino, JoseF.Lacaba, and Wilfrido Nolledo. The role of the eternal female was interpreted on screen by CharitoSolis, Gloria Diaz, Chanda Romero, and Velez herself. Her other films include Ang Babaing Hinugot sa Aking Tadyang (The Woman Who Was Pulled from My Rib), 1981; Pieta, 1983; Pieta II, 1984; and Kasalanan Bang Sambahin Ka? (Is It a Sin to Worship You?), 1990. Her later films are Forever and a Day, 2011; On the Job, Badil (Dynamite Fishing), and Bendor (Vendor), 2013; and The Trial, 2014.

Her work on television includes Rio del Mar, 1999; Imortal (Immortal), 2010-11; Misibis Bay, 2013; and Maria Mercedes, 2013-14. She also starred in an episode of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2011, titled “Susi” (Key).

Velez received a Best Actress award from the Film Academy of the Philippines for her performance in Pieta, 1983. She also received Best Actress awards from the FilipinoAcademyofMovieArtsandSciences and the Metro Manila Film Festival for Paradise Inn, 1985. She won Best Actress in the 2003 Cinema One Originals Digital Film Festival for Bendor, which was shown in the ASEAN International Film Festival and Awards in 2015. Written by Nenuca Jose, Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor
(See THEATER volume.)

VERCHES, ANTONIO b. ca 1924. Movie editor, director. He finished his studies in Barcelona, Spain, after which he immediately worked for the Cinematografia Nacional Española of Barcelona as cameraman, laboratory man, assistant director, and finally, as a full-fledged director and film editor. Verches returned to the Philippines in 1940 to work for Apollo Pictures Inc. Under his supervision, the company dubbed the Argentine film La Rubia del Camino (Ruby of the Street) in Tagalog. Due to their success, X’Otic Films engaged his services to dub their film for international release titled Datu Talim, 1940, in English. This paved the way for his directorial break as the company gave him the task to direct the movie Palaris, starring Fernando Poe, in 1941.

After World War II, Verches joined Movietec and, later, Lebran Inc as chief editor and movie director. He directed His Darkest Hour, 1950, a war film, starring Erlinda Cortes, Fred Castro, and Cris de Vera.

Verches was the first film editor to receive the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences award, for May Isang Tsuper ng Taksi (There Was a Taxi Driver), 1953. Written by Lena S. Pareja

VERGEL , ACE (Ace York Caesar Asturias Aguilar) b. Manila 8 Nov 1954. d. 15 Dec 2007. Movie actor. His parents are actors CesarRamirez and AliciaVergel. Sister Beverly Vergel is also an actor. He finished a business management course at Ateneo de Manila.

In Taong Putik (Human Mud), 1959, young Ace got a role when the original child actor failed to show up. He was later cast in Anak ng Bulkan (Child of the Volcano), 1959, with FernandoPoe Jr and RonaldRemy. In one of the seven episodes of Viuda de Oro (Widow of Gold), 1960, titled “Kung Ano ang Puno” (Whatever the Tree Is), he appears as the grandson of Paquito Salcedo together with Lani Oteyza, Lauro Delgado, and Chiquito, under the direction of Nemesio Caravana.

He was reintroduced as a teenager in 9 Teeners, 1969, a musical directed by Mitos Villareal. His other films include Tatlong Kasalanan (Three Sins), 1976; Inay (Mother), 1977, with his real mother, Alicia Vergel, as co-star; Batang City Jail (City Jail Kid), 1978; and three films in 1979: Terror ng Tundo (Tondo Terror), with BembolRoco; Sugpuin, Holduppers (Stop the Holduppers), with TonyFerrer; and Teritoryo Ko Ito (This Is My Territory), with Bembol Roco and RudyFernandez. Among his films in the 1980s are Pieta, 1983, Basag ang Pula (The Yolk Is Broken), 1984, Bomba Arienda, 1985, and Anak ng Cabron (Son of a Thief), 1988.

His later films include Huling Sagupaan (Final Clash) and Seth Corteza, 1996; Utang Ko sa Iyo ang Buhay Ko (I Owe You My Life), Sarraza, and Jacob, 1997; Sige, Subukan Mo (Go Ahead and Try) and Ang Joker at ang Pistolero (The Joker and the Gunman), 1998; Abel Villarama: Armado (Abel Villarama: Armed), 1999; Carta Alas … Huwag Ka Nang Humirit (Card of Ace … Don’t Even Try), 2001; and Masamang Ugat (Bad Roots), 2003.

In 1986, Vergel received Best Actor awards from Gawad Urian and the Film Academy of the Philippines for Bomba Arienda, and another in 1989 from the Gawad Urian for Anak ng Cabron. Written by Glecy Atienza and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

VERGEL , ALICIA (Erlinda Gaerlan Asturias) b. Ermita, Manila 7 Jun 1927. d. Quezon City 21 May 1992. Movie actor. She married actor Cesar Ramirez. Their two children, actors Ace Vergel and Beverly Vergel, were also active in the movies. Actor Oscar Moreno is a cousin. In the 1980s, Vergel was active in local politics as barangay captain of her district, Matalahib, Quezon City.

Vergel started her movie career in Sampaguita Pictures with a brief appearance in the Tita Duran–Pancho Magalona film about a real-life happening in Lipa City, Milagro ng Birhen ng mga Rosas (Miracle of the Virgin of the Roses), 1949. She next appeared in a “dream sequence” production number of the musical Huwag Ka Nang Magtampo (Don’t Get Jealous), 1950, together with Paraluman, Linda Estrella, Lillian Leonardo, Maria Corazon, Lita Rio, Norma Vales, and Tessie Agana. She gained recognition as a full star in Huling Patak ng Dugo (Last Drop of Blood), 1950, as the leading lady of Pancho Magalona. Her other films during this period are Tenyente Ramirez (Lieutenant Ramirez), 1951, with Fred Montilla; Dugong Bughaw (Royal Blood), 1951, with Oscar Moreno; Balisong (Hunting Knife), 1955, with Ramon Revilla; and Mambo-Dyambo (Mambo Jumbo), 1955, with Dolphy.

She became the queen of action movies at Sampaguita, appearing opposite real and reel life romantic partner Cesar Ramirez in films like Bernardo Carpio, 1951; Espada (Sword), 1952; Diwani, 1953; Ukala, 1954; and Lupang Kayumanggi (Brown Land), 1955. As a dramatic star, she was well received in films like MN, 1954, and Madam X, 1952, where she played the leading role based on the life of a millionaire.

After her Sampaguita contract was over, she freelanced with other movie companies in films like Bicol Express, 1957; Day of the Trumpet, 1958; Kadenang Putik (Chain of Mud), 1960; NBI, 1961; and Viva Caballeras (Long Live Lady Cavaliers), 1961. For a while, she went into semiretirement but returned in the late 1970s to make films with director Lino Brocka, like Inay (Mother), 1977, where she again appeared with son Ace.

Vergel was the first Maria Clara awardee as Best Supporting Actress for her performance in Mapuputing Kamay (White Hands), 1950. She was also the first Best Actress awardee of the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for her role of a bus conductress in Basahang Ginto (Rags of Gold), 1952. In 1977, she was nominated in the Gawad Urian as Best Actress for Inay. Written by Glecy Atienza and Lena S. Pareja

VILLALUNA, PAOLO (Jose Paolo Lutz Villaluna) b. Davao City 18 Oct 1976. Editor and director. His parents are Larry S. Villaluna and Marilyn V. Lutz. A communication arts undergraduate of the University of the Philippines, Los Baños (1992-95), he attended the Mowelfund Film Institute Documentary Workshop in 2000.

Villaluna directed Palugid (Margin), 2001. He worked as assistant director to National Artist Eddie Romero in the romantic film Faces of Love, 2006. In 2005, he made his feature film debut with Ellen Ramos in Ilusyon (Illusion), 2005, and followed it up with Selda (The Inmate), 2007, and Walang Hanggang Paalam (Endless Farewell), 2009. These three feature-length films form a love trilogy that explores obscure romantic relationships. All three films received critical acclaim from local and international film festivals. Ilusyon was graded “A” by the Cinema Evaluation Board.

Palugid won Best Short Film at the 24th Gawad Urian, Best Documentary at the 2001 Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video, and the Audience Award at the 2001 eKsperimento International Film Festival. For Selda, actors Sid Lucero and Emilio Garcia won Best Actor awards at the 2008 Thessaloniki International Film Festival. For the same film, Lucero was chosen Best Actor in the Gawad Urian in 2008. Garcia won Best Supporting Actor in the Gawad Urian and the Star Awards for Movies in 2008. Walang Hanggang Paalam won the Best World Showcase Feature at the 2010 Soho International Film Festival, New York, USA.

In 2008, Villaluna made his television debut as director and editor of ABS-CBN News Channel documentary series Storyline, a Silver Medal winner at the 2011 New York Festivals Television & Film Awards. He also directs television commercials. Written by Rica Arevalo

VILLANO , TOR (Victoriano Ramos Villanueva) b. Manila 13 Jul 1908. Movie director. He is the son of Tomas Villanueva and Gregoria Ramos. He married Kalayaan Pineda with whom he had nine children. He studied at Sampaloc Intermediate School.

Villano started his movie career by writing stories for film directors Manuel Silos, Octavio Silos, and Cecilio Joaquin at Filippine Films studio. These were Anting-Anting (Amulet), where he also appeared as the villain, and Anak ng Bilanggo (The Convict’s Son), both in 1934, and Nang Magulo ang Maynila (When Manila Was in Chaos), 1937. His big break came when a rift developed between Joaquin and his producer George Harris, causing delays in the filming. Challenged to finish the picture when Joaquin walked out of the set, Villano came through with flying colors.

Following in the footsteps of his predecessor, Jose Nepomuceno, Villano started scouting around for new talents and new faces to light up the silver screen. He coached Rosa del Rosario in her Tagalog speaking lines so that she could effectively portray the role of the rape victim in an incestuous relationship, as the daughter of Gregorio Fernandez in Taong Demonyo (Demon Man), 1937. He cast a relatively unknown Carmen Rosales over the protests of his producers and made her a big star in Arimunding-Munding, 1939. He changed the name of Sigrid von Guiese to Paraluman and motivated her to render an unforgettable performance in the dying scene of La Paloma (The Dove), 1947. Among the screen luminaries whose careers he helped launch in his films are Rosita Rivera in Ilaw ng Langit (Light of Heaven), 1937; Arsenia Francisco in Azucena, 1939; Luningning in Ang Lihim ng Lumang Simbahan (The Secret of the Old Church), 1940; Serafin Garcia in Sa Duyan ng Pagmamahal (Love’s Hammock), 1940; Mona Lisa in Tinangay ng Apoy (Taken by Fire), 1940; and Tessie Quintana in Paraluman (Muse), 1941. It was also Tor Villano’s picture that first made audiences sit up and give notice to an outstanding love team, Tita Duran and Pancho Magalona in Dahil sa Iyo (Because of You), 1948.

Other important films directed by Villano that have left lasting imprints on the memories of his viewers are Cadena de Amor (Chain of Love), 1940; Kung Kita’y Kapiling (When We’re Together) and Halimaw (Monster), 1941; Simbahang Pawid (Nipa Church) and Amapola, 1948; and Damit Pangkasal (Wedding Gown), 1949. He also made two pre-World War II films at LVN Pictures like Patawad (Pardon), starring Purita Santamaria and Reynaldo Dante, and Nag-iisang Sangla (The Only Pawn), starring Mila del Sol and Leopoldo Salcedo, both in 1940.

In 1982 Villano received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Award from the city of Manila for his achievement in film, citing, among others, his contributions to the upliftment of Filipino moral values in his works. Ten years later, at the 1991 Metro Manila Film Festival, he received a Plaque of Recognition for his meritorious achievements in film. Written by Lena S. Pareja

VILLAVICENCIO, RAQUEL N. (Raquel David Nepomuceno-Villavicencio) aka Kelly b. Angeles City, Pampanga 16 Aug 1951. Screenwriter, actor, and production designer. Born to Armando Nepomuceno, a businessman, and Paciencia David, an English teacher, she attended grade school at Holy Family Academy in Angeles City. She finished high school at the College of the Holy Spirit and received her bachelor’s degree in communication arts from Maryknoll (now Miriam) College in 1972. She married Roberto Villavicencio, an insurance man, with whom she has three children.

In 1977 Villavicencio became interested in film and joined a workshop sponsored by LVN, which was organized by film directors Mike de Leon, Laurice Guillen, Pio de Castro III, and Mel Chionglo. After the workshop, de Leon asked her to write subtitles for Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (When You Dream and Wake Up), 1977, which led to their collaboration with Clodualdo del Mundo Jr in writing the comedy Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (Will Your Heart Beat Faster?), 1980, Kisapmata (In the Blink of an Eye), 1981, and Batch ’81, 1982. Villavicencio’s forte is drama; her particular interest, stories about women, family life, and coming of age. Among the many films she wrote are Init sa Magdamag (Midnight Passion), 1983, and Makiusap sa Diyos (Plead with God) and Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven), 1991.

As an actor, she also played supporting roles in Sister Stella L. and Alyas Baby Tsina (Alias Baby Tsina), 1984; Tagos ng Dugo (Bloodstain), 1987; Isang Araw Walang Diyos (One Day without God) and Orapronobis (Fight for Us), 1989; Dolora X, 1993; Separada (Separated Woman), 1994; Bayarang Puso (Heart for Hire), 1996; Gimik: The Reunion (Hang Out), 1999; Prosti (Prostitute), 2002; Sukob (The Wedding Curse), 2006; Niño (Boy), 2011; Aparisyon (Apparition), 2012; Dukit (Carving), 2013; The Gifted and Lorna, 2014.

Villavicencio won Best Screenplay awards for Kisapmata in the 1981 Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) and the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA); from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) and the Gawad Urian for Batch ’81, 1982, also co-written with de Leon and del Mundo; and from the FAP for Dapat Ka Bang Mahalin? (Should You Be Loved?), 1984, and Pinulot Ka Lang sa Lupa (You Were Merely Picked from the Ground), 1987.

She won Best Original Story and Best Screenplay at the 1985 Star Awards for Regal Films’ Teenage Marriage, 1984, and Best Screenplay Adaptation at the 1990 Star Awards for Mina Films’ Rosenda, 1989. For her screenplay of Reyna Films’ Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal (You’re the Only One I’ve Loved), 1993, Villavicencio received trophies from the Gawad Urian, Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), and FAP. In the 2003 MMFF, she was awarded Best Story and Best Screenplay for Viva Films’ Ang Huling Birhen sa Lupa (The Last Virgin), 2003.

As production designer she won Best Production Design in the MMFF for Lea Productions’ Kung Ako’y Iiwan Mo (Should You Abandon Me), 1980, and for the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines’ Himala (Miracle), 1982.

She won Best Actress in the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival, Directors Showcase, for Bisperas (Intruders), 2011, directed by Jeffrey Jeturian. Written by Raquel Hernandez, updated by Rica Arevalo

VINARAO, EDGARDO (Edgardo de Jesus Vinarao) aka Boy Vinarao.b. Caloocan City 7 Aug 1944. Film editor and director. His parents are Porfirio Vinarao, a lawyer, and Engracia de Jesus. He is married to Ester Valdez, with whom he has three children. He attended Caloocan Elementary School and Legarda Memorial High School in Echague, Isabela. He studied chemical engineering at Mapua Institute of Technology.

As editor, Vinarao received awards for Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth), 1976, from the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF), Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), and Gawad Urian; for Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), 1977, from the MMFF and FAMAS; for High School circa ’65, 1979, from the Gawad Urian and Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP); for Kadete (Cadet), 1979, from the MMFF and FAP; for Init o Lamig (Hot or Frigid) 1981, from the FAMAS and FAP; for Paradise Inn, 1985, from the MMFF and FAP; for Andrea, Paano Ba ang Maging Isang Ina? (Andrea, How Does One Become a Mother?) 1990, from the MMFF, FAMAS, and FAP; and for The Flor Contemplacion Story, 1995, and Birador (Hitman), 1999, from the FAP. Vinarao was elevated to the FAMAS Hall of Fame for receiving more than five awards for editing.

As director, his films include Tatak ng Kriminal (Mark of a Criminal) and Secret Love, 1993; Rubber Man, 1996; Epimaco Velasco Story: NBI, 1997; Kasal-Kasalan, Sakalan (Wedding Game, War Game), and Birador, for which he won Best Director at the 1999 FAP Awards; Diskarte (Personal Take), 2002; and Bacao, 2014.

Vinarao served as president of the Film Editors Guild for Motion Pictures–Philippines (FEGMP) and has been the director of the Mowelfund Film Institute since 2008. Written by Rica Arevalo

VITUG, ROMY (Romeo Reyes Vitug) b. Floridablanca, Pampanga 27 Jan 1937. Cinematographer. His father is Honesto Vitug, senior photographer of Manila Chronicle and Manila Times. His mother is Esperanza Reyes. Vitug quit prelaw on his second year college to work as a photographer for the Manila Chronicle from 1960 to 1965 and for the Manila Times from 1966 to 1968. During this period, he was also newsreel photographer for The Big News on Channel 5. He attended a film workshop in the United States (US), courtesy of the US Information Service.

Vitug’s entry into filmmaking began when director LinoBrocka asked him to be the publicity photographer for TinimbangKaNgunitKulang (You Were Weighed and Found Wanting) in 1974. In the same year, Brocka gave him his break as cinematographer in Tatlo,Dalawa,Isa (Three, Two, One). This was followed by Lunes, Martes, Miyerkules, Huwebes, Biyernes, Sabado, Linggo (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday), 1976, also by Brocka; Laruang Apoy (Playing with Fire), 1977, directed by RomySuzara; Ang Alamat ni Julian Makabayan (The Legend of Julian Makabayan), 1979, by CelsoAd.Castillo; Salome, 1981, by Laurice Guillen; Haplos (Caress), 1982, by Butch Perez; and other films.

Vitug reaped many awards. He is the first cinematographer who made it to the FilipinoAcademyofMovieArtsandSciences Hall of Fame for the following films: PagputingUwak,Pag-itimngTagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Heron Turns Black), 1978; Paano Ba ang Mangarap? (How Does One Dream?), 1983; Kung Mahawi Man ang Ulap (Should the Skies Clear), 1984; Paradise Inn, 1985; and Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig? (Where Does Love Hide?), 1987.

In addition, he received the Gawad Urian for Best Cinematography six times: for Mga Bilanggong Birhen (Caged Virgins), 1977; Kapag Langit ang Humatol (Heaven’s Judgment), 1990; Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven), 1991; Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal (You’re the Only One I’ve Loved), 1992; Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1993; and Bakit May Kahapon Pa? (Why Is There a Yesterday?), 1996.

He received nine trophies from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP): for Sinasamba Kita (I Worship You), 1982; Paano Ba ang Mangarap?; Isla (Island), 1984; Paradise Inn, 1985; Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig?; Kapag Langit ang Humatol; Maalaala Mo Kaya: The Movie (Will You Remember: The Movie), 1994; and Sana Maulit Muli (Second Chances), 1995. He was also awarded the FAP’s Manuel de Leon Award.

The Metro Manila Film Festival honored him eight times: for Mga Bilanggong Birhen; Atsay (Housemaid), 1978; Paradise Inn; Payaso (Clown), 1986; Magkano ang Iyong Dangal? (How Much Is Your Honor Worth?), 1988; Ang Bukas ay Akin (Tomorrow Is Mine), 1989; Kung Mawawala Ka Pa (If I Lose You), 1993; and Rizal sa Dapitan (Rizal in Dapitan), 1997. Moreover, he also won six times at the Star Awards for Movies: for Paradise Inn; Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig?; Hihintayin Kita sa Langit; Inagaw Mo ang Lahat sa Akin (Harvest Home), 1995; Rizal sa Dapitan; and Sa Pusod ng Dagat (In the Navel of the Sea), 1998. He won the Young Critics Circle’s Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design for The Flor Contemplacion Story, 1995. He also received a Lifetime Achievement Award from Cinemanila International Film Festival in 2000 and the Star Award for Ulirang Alagad ng Pelikula sa Likod ng Kamera (Exemplar Artist of the Cinema behind the Camera) in 2013. In 2016, Vitug received the Natatanging Gawad Urian. Written byDanny Villanueva and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

VIVA FILMS Established in 1981 by a group of businessmen in the music recording industry headed by Vic del Rosario of Vicor and his sister Teresita Cruz, Viva had its first offices at the Vicor Studio on Aurora Boulevard, Quezon City, before they moved to Scout Albano St.

Del Rosario keenly sensed the potential of combining music and film in a business enterprise. Many Vicor records were selling movies via their theme songs, and box-office titles of hit songs meant higher record sales. For Viva’s first movie project, he signed up Vicor’s biggest recording star, Sharon Cuneta, and young matinee idol Gabby Concepcion, and wove a romantic tale around the song P.S. I Love You, 1981. The experiment paid off in box-office revenues and it was followed immediately by My Only Love, 1983, and other Sharon-Gabby team-ups: Dapat Ka Bang Mahalin? (Should You Be Loved?) and Sa Hirap at Ginhawa (In Bad Times and Good Times), 1984; Pati Ba Pintig ng Puso? (And the Heartbeat, Too?), 1985; and Bakit Ikaw Pa Rin? (Why Still You?), 1990. Sharon also made films with other leading men: William Martinez in Forgive and Forget, 1982; Rowell Santiago in Cross My Heart, 1982; Miguel Rodriguez in To Love Again, 1983; Christopher de Leon in Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), 1985; Edu Manzano in Nakagapos na Puso (Shackled Heart), 1986; Herbert Bautista and Tonton Gutierrez in Jack & Jill sa America (Jack and Jill in America), 1988; Richard Gomez in Kahit Wala Ka Na (Even If You’re Gone), 1989; and Fernando Poe Jr in Kahit Konting Pagtingin (Just a Little Love), 1990.

Viva Films won Best Picture awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) and Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) for Gabi Na, Kumander (It’s Night, Commander), 1986; from FAMAS for Saan Nagtatago ang Pag-ibig? (Where Does Love Hide?), 1987; from the Metro Manila Film Festival for Imortal (Immortal), 1989; from the CMMA for Oras-Oras, Araw-Araw (Every Hour, Every Day), 1989; and from the Gawad Urian for Gumapang Ka sa Lusak (Dirty Affair), 1990. In five out of six consecutive years from 1986 to 1991, Viva won the Best Picture award from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) for the following movies: Gabi Na, Kumander, Saan Nagtatago and Pag-ibig?, Boy Negro, 1988, Gumapang Ka sa Lusak, and Ipagpatawad Mo (Forgive Me), 1991.

Other award-winning Viva films are Sinasamba Kita (I Worship You), 1982, FAP Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, and Best Song, and FAMAS Best Director; Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan? (How Often Is Once?), 1982, FAMAS Best Story, Best Screenplay, Best Editing, Best Song, and Best Musical Score, and FAP and FAMAS Best Sound; Paano Ba ang Mangarap? (How Does One Dream?), 1983, FAP Best Cinematography and FAMAS Best Screenplay, Best Cinematography, and Best Song; Minsan Pa Nating Hagkan ang Nakaraan (Let Us Kiss the Past Once More), 1983, FAMAS Best Actor (Eddie Garcia); Saan Darating ang Umaga? (Where Will the Morning Come?), 1983, FAMAS Best Supporting Actress (Maricel Soriano) and Best Child Actor (Jaypee de Guzman); Alyas Baby Tsina (Alias Baby Tsina), 1984, FAP Best Production Design and Best Musical Score; Sa Hirap at Ginhawa, FAP Best Actress (Sharon Cuneta); Dapat Ka Bang Mahalin?, FAMAS Best Song and Best Actress (Sharon Cuneta); Kung Mahawi Man ang Ulap (Should the Skies Clear), 1984, FAMAS Best Cinematography; Bukas, Luluhod ang mga Tala (Tomorrow the Stars Will Kneel), 1984, FAMAS Best Sound and Best Musical Score; Tinik sa Dibdib (Thorn in the Heart), 1985, FAP and FAMAS Best Supporting Actress (Dina Bonnevie) and Best Child Actor (Jaypee de Guzman); Bituing Walang Ningning, FAP Best Song and FAMAS Best Song and Best Musical Score; Magdusa Ka (Suffer), 1986, FAP Best Director, Best Actress (Dina Bonnevie), and Best Supporting Actress (Nida Blanca), and FAMAS Best Director, Best Screenplay, Best Actress, and Best Supporting Actress, and CMMA Best Actress and Best Supporting Actress; Palimos ng Pag-ibig (Begging for Love), 1986, FAMAS Best Musical Score; Sana’y Wala nang Wakas (I Wish This Were Forever), 1986, FAMAS Best Song; Maging Akin Ka Lamang (Anything to Have You), 1987, FAP Best Song and Best Actress (Lorna Tolentino), and FAP and FAMAS Best Supporting Actor (Jay Ilagan); Balweg, 1987, FAP Best Original Screenplay and Best Sound, and FAMAS Best Editing and Best Musical Score; Paano Tatakasan ang Bukas? (How Does One Escape from Tomorrow?), 1988, FAP Best Director and Best Musical Score; Oras-Oras, Araw-Araw, FAP Best Screenplay, Best Song, and Best Musical Score; Abot Hanggang Sukdulan (Reaching the Limits), 1989, FAMAS Best Supporting Actor (Ricky Davao); Aso’t Pusa (Cat and Dog), 1989, FAMAS Best Child Actress (Aiza Seguerra); Kahit Konting Pagtingin, FAP Best Supporting Actor (Dencio Padilla); Kasalanan Bang Sambahin Ka? (Is It a Sin to Worship You?), 1990, FAP Best Original Song and Urian Best Production Design; Biktima (Victim), 1990, FAP Best Sound and FAMAS and Gawad Urian Best Supporting Actress (Gina Alajar); and Una Kang Naging Akin (You Were Mine First), 1991, FAP and FAMAS Best Supporting Actress (Dawn Zulueta).

Viva Films also entered television production in the 1990s, partnering with the leading TV networks at the time.
