Viva’s partnership with GMA Network, for instance, produced hit programs like Ober da Bakod (Over the Fence), 1992, which starred the then-budding singer and comedy actor Janno Gibbs, Anjo Yllana, Gelli de Belen, and Donita Rose; Villa Quintana, 1993, which starred Keempee de Leon and Donna Cruz, and won the 1996 Star Awards for Television trophies for Best Drama Series, Best Drama Actor (Keempee de Leon), and Best Drama Actress (Isabel Rivas); and TGIS (Thank God It’s Sabado), a youth-oriented drama series that starred and popularized actors like Bobby Andrews, Angelu de Leon, Onemig Bondoc, Red Sternberg, Michael Flores, Raven Villanueva, Ciara Sotto, Dingdong Dantes, Polo Ravales, Sunshine Dizon, Anne Curtis, Antoinette Taus, Kim Delos Santos, Dino Guevarra, Chubi del Rosario, and others. Viva Films’ partnership with GMA later on provided Viva an avenue in which to showcase its latest movie releases. Dubbed Viva Sinerama, 1992, the GMA program showed Viva films every Thursday evening. Many other partnerships were formed between Viva Films and other TV networks, such as Star TV and Fox Philippines. Their tie-up resulted in Viva Cinema, an international Filipino film channel that showed Viva films daily. The channel came to a halt in 2003 when a new partnership between Viva Films and ABS-CBN enabled Viva Films to air its films through the ABS-CBN network. The resulting new Viva film channel was called Pinoy Box Office. In 2015, a new partnership emerged between Viva Films and TV5.

Viva Films later conquered the big screen once more by partnering with the leading film production companies. Among the films it created with Star Cinema, for instance, are Wag Kang Lilingon (Don’t Look Back), 2006, starring Kristine Hermosa and Anne Curtis; Ang Cute ng Ina Mo (Your Mother Is Cute), 2007, starring Ai-Ai delas Alas, Luis Manzano, Anne Curtis, and Eugene Domingo; Paano Kita Iibigin (How Will I Love You), also in 2007, starring Regine Velasquez and Piolo Pascual; When Love Begins, 2008, starring Aga Muhlach and Anne Curtis; A Very Special Love, also in 2008, starring John Lloyd Cruz and Sarah Geronimo, which was followed by its sequels You Changed My Life, 2009, and It Takes a Man and a Woman, 2013; The Unkabogable Praybeyt Benjamin (Can’t Be Upstaged Private Benjamin), 2011, starring Vice Ganda, Derek Ramsay, Jimmy Santos, and Eddie Garcia; Won’t Last a Day without You, 2011, starring Sarah Geronimo and Gerald Anderson; No Other Woman, 2011, starring Anne Curtis, Cristine Reyes, and Derek Ramsay; Girl Boy Bakla Tomboy (Girl, Boy, Gay, Lesbian), 2013, starring Vice Ganda, Maricel Soriano, Joey Marquez, and Ruffa Guttierez; and others. With GMA Films, Viva created Till I Met You, 2006, starring Robin Padilla and Regine Velasquez; a remake of the classic comedy film Working Girls, 2010, starring Eugene Domingo, Ruffa Guttierez, Jennylyn Mercado, Iza Calzado, Eula Valdez, Cristine Reyes, and Bianca King; Of All the Things, 2012, starring Aga Muhlach and Regine Velasquez, and others. One of Viva Films’ most successful films to date, as indicated by its record-breaking attendance on its premiere, is Felix Manalo, 2015, a biographical film that explores and dramatizes the life of the founder and first executive minister of the Iglesia ni Cristo. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

WALTER, MARY (Mary Ebio Walter) b. Bacon, Sorsogon 10 Sep 1912. d. Quezon City 25 Feb 1993. Movie, stage, and television actor. Her parents are Eugene Walter, a German, and Felisa Ebio. She studied at the Holy Ghost College. At 18 she married Alfonso Grimalt, a Spanish mestizo, with whom she had three children.

Walter was a 15-year-old student when producer director Jose Nepomuceno spotted her and asked her to dance the cariñosa in Sampaguita, 1927, a silent film. The following year, she starred opposite Gregorio Fernandez in Ang Lumang Simbahan (The Old Church), 1928. In the silent film Ang Gayuma (The Charm), 1932, she received her first screen kiss from leading man Fernandez. Her other silent films include Nanay Ko (My Mother), 1929; Maria Luisa and Prinsipe Teñoso (Prince Teñoso), 1930; Moro Pirates, Ang Lihim ni Bathala (God’s Secret), and Dalaga (Young Lady), 1931. When talking pictures came to the Philippines, she appeared in some of the earliest talkies of Philippine Films: Hinagpis ng Magulang (A Parent’s Woes), 1934; Ang Gulong ng Buhay (Wheel of Life) and Sumpa ng Aswang (Curse of the Aswang), 1935; Ang Buhok ni Ester (Ester’s Tresses), 1936; and Birheng Walang Dambana (The Virgin without a Shrine), 1937. After the war, she made several comebacks. She was the mother of Efren Reyes in Maliit Lamang ang Daigdig (It’s a Small World), 1948, and again in Mabilis Pa sa Lintik (Quicker Than Lightning), 1959. She also appeared in mother roles with Zaldy Zshornack in Krus na Daan (Crossroads), 1960; Fernando Poe Jr in Ikaw o Ako (You or I), 1961; and Lolita Rodriguez in Tatlo, Dalawa, Isa (Three, Two, One), 1974. In the 1970s, she appeared in mostly Lino Brocka films: Santiago, 1970; Lumuha Pati mga Anghel (Even the Angels Wept) and Cadena de Amor (Chain of Love), 1971; and Stardoom, 1972. She also appeared in Ishmael Bernal’s Dalawang Pugad, Isang Ibon (Two Nests, One Bird), 1977.

On stage, she played the mother of a missing activist in Desaparecido (The Disappeared), 1987. In 1990, she appeared as mother of Bernarda Alba in the Philippine Educational Theater Association production of La Casa de Bernarda Alba (The House of Bernarda Alba).

She was chosen Best Supporting Actress by the Manila Film Festival in 1974 for her performance in Alaala Mo, Daigdig Ko (Your Memories, My World). Among her many citations are the Tandang Sora Award in 1981, the Lifetime Achievement Award given by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences in 1982, the Natatanging Gawad Urian in 1992, and the Film Academy of the Philippines Lifetime Achievement Award in 1986. She also did outstanding work on television. The Citizens Council for Mass Media cited her in the series Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) as Best Supporting Female Performer in 1968. Also hailed by the Citizens’ Awards for Television in 1971 was her work in an episode of Panagimpan (Imagination) as Best Performance by an Actress in a Leading Role. She was conferred the Gawad CCP para sa Sining for film in 1993. Written by Glecy Atienza

YAMAMOTO, MICHIKO (Michiko Sy Yamamoto) b. Manila 2 Apr 1979. Screenwriter and producer. Her parents are Hiromi Yamamoto and Rosemary Sy. She grew up in Bulacan, Bulacan. She graduated with a bachelor of science in math, major in computer science, in 1999 from the University of Santo Tomas. She did postproduction work for Viva Films for two years and later worked for ABS-CBN, starting 2000 as a member of the concept development group.

Yamamoto attended the 1999 Film Development Council of the Philippines (FDCP) Scriptwriting Workshop under Nestor U. Torre. Her screenplay Magnifico Madyikero (Magnifico the Magician) won first place in the 2001 FDCP Scriptwriting Contest. It was produced by Violett Films Production and directed by Maryo J. de los Reyes. Magnifico, 2003, tells the story of a young boy who showers the people around him with love and hope. In the children’s category of the 2004 Berlin International Film Festival, it won the Crystal Bear and the Deutsches Kinderhilfswerk Grand Prix. In 2004, the same film won for Yamamoto the Best Story award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) and Best Screenplay awards from the Film Academy of the Philippines, the Gawad Urian, and the Golden Screen Awards. Magnifico was included in the “10 Best Films of the Decade 2000-2009” of the Gawad Urian.

Yamamoto also wrote the screenplay of Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros), 2005, and co-wrote the scripts of films such as Endo (Love on a Budget), 2007, and Zombadings: Patayin sa Shokot si Remington (Remington and the Curse of the Zombadings), 2011, with Jade Castro and Raymond Lee (aka Moira Lang); My Big Love, 2008, with Henry Quitain, Therese de Guzman, and Theodore Boborol; and On the Job, 2013, and Honor Thy Father, 2015, with Erik Matti.

Yamamoto was a contributing writer for the TV soap Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000. She also wrote for other television series such as SCQ Reload: OK Ako! (SCQ Reload: I’m OK!), 2004; Star Magic Presents: Abt Ur Luv, 2006; Nagsimula sa Puso (It Began from the Heart), 2009; Kasalanan Bang Ibigin Ka? (Is It a Sin to Love You?) and Magdalena: Anghel sa Putikan (Magdalena: Angel in the Mud), 2012; and Magkano Ba ang Pag-Ibig? (How Much Does Love Cost?), 2013.

In 2006, Yamamoto won the Gawad Urian for Best Screenplay for Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros. In 2008, she won Best Screenplay awards for Endo (shared with her co-writers) from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk and the Gawad Urian. In 2014, she was dubbed Movie Screenwriter of the Year, together with Erik Matti, by the Star Awards for Movies for On the Job. The same film won her and Matti the Best Screenplay award from FAMAS in the same year.

Yamamoto co-founded UFO Pictures with Raymond Lee, Jade Castro, Emman de la Cruz, and Ned Trespeces in 2004. After UFO folded up, she co-produced independent films with Origin8 Media, a company she founded with Raymond Lee, Emmanuel de la Cruz, Jade Castro, Katski Flores, Cholo Laurel, Tammy Bejerano-Dinopol, and Mari Lama. Written by Rica Arevalo, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu and Nicanor G. Tiongson
(See LITERATURE volume.)

YÑIGUEZ, BOY (Roberto Enriquez Yñiguez) b Malolos, Bulacan 13 May 1951. Cinematographer. He is the son of Marcos Yñiguez, an electrical engineer, and Julita Enriquez, a housewife. Marcos Yñiguez III, his brother, is an art director. Another brother, Gerardo Yñiguez, is a freelance animator. He finished bachelor of science in architecture in 1974 at University of the Philippines Diliman.

Yñiguez is most known for his work as a cinematographer. Examples of his work are the films Turumba, 1981; Balweg: The Rebel Priest, 1986; Memories of a Forgotten War and Tuhog (Larger Than Life), 2001; First Time, 2003; Kubrador (The Bet Collector), 2006; I Do, 2010; Bisperas (Intruders), 2011; Puti (White) and Independent Lens, 2013; Tragic Theater, Balikbayan #1: Memories of Overdevelopment Redux III, and Imbisibol (Invisible), 2015. His work as part of the camera and electrical department were seen in Jag Rodnar, 1981, and Boatman, 1985. He was also the assistant art director for Salome, 1981.

Yñiguez has also published photography books, among which are Sagada, Cañao for Boy, and Mesa’t Salumpuwit 1: A Collection of Chairs and Tables (Tables and Chairs 1: A Collection of Chairs and Tables), 2008; Mesa’t Salumpuwit 2: A Collection of Chairs and Tables, Inang Julita (Mother Julita), and Brent School 1909-2009: A Legacy of Learning, 2009; Pleasing the Spirits, 2010; Arawang Larawan: One Photo A Day / Year 2008 (Daily Photo: One Photo a Day / Year 2008), 2012; and South African, Black and White, 2013.

In 2001, Yñiguez won the Gawad Urian for Best Cinematography for Tuhog, which he shared with Shayne Sarte and Sherman So. In 2007, he received the same award for Kubrador. He won the Balanghai trophy for Best Cinematography at the 2011 Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival for Bisperas. In 2013, he received the Jury Prize for Best Cinematography from CineFilipino Film Festival for Puti. He won the Sinag Award for Best Cinematography at the 2015 Sinag Maynila Film Festival for Imbisibol. In 2016, he won Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design from the Young Critics Circle Film Desk for Balikbayan #1: Memories of Overdevelopment Redux III.Written by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu

YOUNG CRITICS CIRCLE FILM DESK In 1990, the Young Critics Circle (YCC) was founded by Joi Barrios, Jojo Buenconsejo, Eric Caruncho, Melissa Contreras, Jaime Daroy, Joel David, Gin de Mesa, Patrick D. Flores, Francine Y. Medina, Charlson Ong, Mozart A. T. Pastrano, Danilo Reyes, and Antonio Tinio, with Mike Feria as founding chair. The group aimed to evaluate works of art in various disciplines or “desks”—namely, film, theater, music, literature, visual arts, and broadcast arts. However, only the Film Desk was sustained.

In 1991, the first annual citations in film achievement were held by the YCC Film Desk. The six awards annually given are for Best Film, Best Performance, Best Screenplay, Best Editing, Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design, and Best Achievement in Sound and Aural Orchestration. In the first year of the “circle citations,” the awards for Best Film, Best Screenplay, and Best Performance were given to Gil Portes’s Andrea, Paano Ba ang Maging Isang Ina? (Andrea, How Does One Become a Mother?), 1990, written by Ricardo Lee and starring Nora Aunor.

The writings of the YCC Film Desk in its first decade were anthologized in Sampung Taong Sine: Philippine Cinema 1990-1999 (Ten Years of Film), 2002. The group, as the anthology states, “stakes its claims in advocating a strategic and interventive agenda for a transdisciplinary film criticism that is responsive to the needs of the moment and responsible for its future aspirations.” The group published another book, Sining ng Sineng Filipino (Art of Filipino Film), 2009.

The members of the YCC come from various academic disciplines, such as art studies, literary studies, communication, anthropology, history, and philosophy.The members at one time or another include Aristotle J. Atienza, Tessa Maria Guazon, Lisa Ito, J. Pilapil Jacobo, Skilty C. Labastilla, Nonoy L. Lauzon, JPaul S. Manzanilla, Jema M. Pamintuan, Choy Pangilinan, Jaime Oscar M. Salazar, and founding member Patrick Flores. Former members include Romulo P. Baquiran Jr, Flaudette May V. Datuin, Noel D. Ferrer, Eli R. Guieb III, Eloisa May P. Hernandez, Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez, Gerard Lico, James Rañeses, Jerry C. Respeto, Clare Salaveria, Neil Martial R. Santillan, Ariel N. Valerio, Ailyn A. Villamarin, and Galileo S. Zafra.Written by Patrick Campos

YOUNG, REMIGIO aka Migi Young. b. Calumpit, Bulacan 1 Oct 1909. d. 1977. Cinematographer. He began as a projectionist in a movie house where he was introduced to Don Jose Nepomuceno by his actors Luis Tuason, Salvador Tinsay, and Salvador Zaragosa during the showing of Ang Tatlong Hambog (The Three Braggarts) in 1926. Nepomuceno cast him as an extra in Hot Kisses in 1927, but he preferred to be a part of his production crew. Later, he became assistant cameraman to Nepomuceno, and then as a solo cameraman. He worked with various studios like Malayan Pictures, Filippine Films, Parlatone Hispano-Filipino, and Excelsior Pictures, and did almost all of the pre-World War II films of LVN Pictures. After the war, he studied color cinematography in Hollywood. When he returned in 1949, he was involved with Fernando Poe Productions and made color films for LVN from 1955 to 1961.

Having worked with director Carlos Vander Tolosa in Nasaan Ka, Irog? (Where Are You, Beloved?) in 1937, Tolosa got him for LVN’s first musical, Giliw Ko (My Love), 1939. Since then, he made a number of LVN films like Sawing Gantimpala (Lost Victory), 1940; Hali, 1940; Maginoong Takas (Gentleman Fugitive), 1940; Binatillo (Young Man), 1941; and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941, with Ray Lacap and Vicente Salumbides. He also did the cinematography for Gerardo de Leon’s Ang Bagong Maestra (The New Teacher), 1953, and Lamberto V. Avellana’s Lapu-Lapu, 1955. In an era of black-and-white movies, Young photographed in color the Nida Blanca–Nestor de Villa starrers—like Manuel Conde’s Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1955; Ikaw Kasi (You Are to Blame), 1955; and Tingnan Natin (Let Us See), 1957—as well as F.H. Constantino’s episodes in Medalyong Perlas (Pearl Medallion), 1956, and Casa Grande (Mansion), 1957. He also photographed in color Manuel Conde’s Juan Tamad Goes to Society (Lazy Juan Goes to Society), 1960; and Gregorio Fernandez’s Luksang Tagumpay (Dark Victory), 1956. He also did 30 more films for LVN until 1961, including several films of Susana C. de Guzman and Richard Abelardo.

Young was nominated by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Ang Bagong Maestra and won the FAMAS award in 1956 for Luksang Tagumpay. Written by Cesar Hernando

YVONNE (Yvonne Rosetti) b. Zamboanga City ca 1955. Movie actor. She was studying and working as a radio talent in Zamboanga City when lured to Manila by an illegal recruiter. She attracted attention when she doubled for CharitoSolis in a nude scene in Nepomuceno Productions’ Pipo, 1970. She went on to play an Ermita prostitute in Ishmael Bernal’s Scotch on the Rocks to Remember, Bitter Coffee to Forget, a film slated for international release and was not shown in the Philippines.

Yvonne gained a reputation as a bold star for her appearance in films called bomba, where the term connoted sex orientation, such as Climax of Love, 1970; Naked in the Dark, 1971; and Init sa Magdamag (Midnight Passion), 1971. Among her other films are Bawat Saglit, Kaligayahan (Every Second, Happiness), The Marijuana Kid, Sino? (Who?), Sinisi Ko ang Aking Ina (I Blamed My Mother), Sa Kamay ng Tatlong Takas (In the Hands of Three Fugitives), and Buhay na Manikin (Living Doll), all in 1971.

When the government restricted the bomba films, Yvonne was forced into semiretirement, stage performances, and a stint in Japan. In 1976, coming back on-screen with LigawnaBulaklak (Wildflower), she delivered a performance that won the Gawad Urian for Best Supporting Actress of the year. Ten years later, she was again nominated by the Gawad Urian for the same category for her role in Chito Roño’s Private Show, 1986.

ZABAT, FIEL (Fiel Corrales Zabat) b. Manila Jul 1950. Production designer. Her parents are Vicente Zabat and Nellie Corrales. She went to Far Eastern University for her primary and secondary schooling. She graduated from the University of the Philippines with a degree in fine arts in commercial design, major in advertising and editorial design.

Zabat first worked as an artist in an advertising agency, designing plastic signs, lamps, and other housewares. She supervised product shootings for catalogues. Then, she did television work for ABS-CBN as a graphics designer. Zabat also worked as a scenic designer and decorator for fashion shows, stage and TV productions.

Influenced by LinoBrocka and Marilou Diaz-Abaya, Zabat soon worked as a production designer for film. She worked for VivaFilms, Regal Films, Cine Suerte, and a few other film outfits. Zabat’s work as a production designer includes Insiang, 1976, which was shown in Cannes International Film Festival; Lunes, Martes, Miyerkules, Huwebes, Biyernes, Sabado, Linggo (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday), also in 1976; Inay (Mother), 1977; Boy Pana (Bow and Arrow Kid), 1978; and High School circa ’65, 1979. His films in the 1980s include Moral, 1982; Karnal (Of the Flesh), 1983; and Alyas Baby Tsina (Alias Baby Tsina), 1984. Aside from the local films she designed, she also worked in Final Mission, 1984, starring Richard Young and John Erickson, directed by Cirio Santiago, produced by G and R Productions for international release. While working in the film industry, Zabat taught production design for cinema at Ateneo de Manila University from 1982 to 1984. Then, she moved to New York, USA, where she became a sales associate for Bergdorf Goodman, Macy’s, and Georgiou, and a sales specialist for Bloomingdale’s.

While in the USA, Zabat designed shows staged in New York like Madama Butterfly, In My Father’s House, Sundang at Baril (Dagger and Gun), Mga Sugatang Perlas (Wounded Pearls), Kulintang, and Duyan ng Magiting (Cradle of the Brave). She also did the production design for Laurice Guillen’s American Adobo, 2001, which was shot in New York. In 2015, during a visit to the Philippines, she did the production design of an independent film, Sundalong Kanin (Toy Soldier), 2015, for the Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival.

The Citizen’s Council for Mass Media awarded her the Citizen Award for Television for That Young Image, 1970. She received the 1982 Gawad Urian for Best Production Design for HighSchoolcirca’65. For Karnal, she received the production design awards from the 1983 Metro Manila Film Festival, the 1984 Gawad Urian, and the 1984 FilmAcademyofthePhilippines (FAP) Awards. For Alyas Baby Tsina, she won Best Production Design in the 1985 FAP Awards. Written by Cristine Directo, updated by Sylvelyn Jo Almanzor

ZAMORA,RAMON(RamonArtiagaZamora) aka Monza. b.San Juan27 Jun 1935. d. Antipolo 26 Aug 2007.Actor,stage dancer, director, and producer.

Zamorastarted out as a stuntman and dancer for LVN Pictures in 1953. He performed at the Manila Grand Opera House and Clover Theater, and was a member of the Festival Dancers, a dance troupe that performed abroad.

Zamorais remembered primarily for his lead roles in local martial arts and action movies in the 1970s. Known as the “Bruce Lee of the Philippines,”Zamorawas once considered by international producers for a biopic of the late martial arts legend, but negotiations did not succeed.

In a span of a decade,Zamoradid 14 “dragon films,” with such titles as Landas ng Hari (Way of the Dragon)andShadow of the Dragon, 1973;The Dragon Fire,Return of the Dragon, Dread the Trail Dragon Fire,andThe Dragon Force Connection,1974;Mga Dragon sa Gubat(Dragons in the Forest) andRevenge of the Dragon, 1977;Kambal Dragon(Twin Dragons)andAng Dragon sa Maskarang Bakal(The Dragon in the Steel Mask),1978;Dragon at Harabas(Dragon and Harabas) andSnake Dragon Connection, 1979; and the last of them,Kato: Son of the Dragon, 1983.

He also did Bruce Lee-type, martial arts-themed action movies, such asCobra at Lawin(Cobra and Hawk),The Pig Boss,andThe King Plaster, 1973;Game of Death, 1974;The Interceptors, 1976; Golden ChakuandKarate Kung Fu Shaolin Masters, 1977; Crime Fighters,1978;Arnis, Karate, Kung Fu,The Experts, andThat Man from Shanghai,1979;Agent 00, 1981; andDalmacio Armas, 1983.

He was in the international filmsMeng Long Bi Hu Xiao Quan Wang(Dragon, Lizard, Boxer), 1977, and Hong Tian Mi Ling(Deadly Target), 1994.

He successfully depicted the folk character Pedro Penduko in Celso Ad. Castillo’s fantasy filmAng Mahiwagang Daigdig ni Pedro Penduko(The Mysterious World of Pedro Penduko), 1973.This was followed byBagsik at Kamandag ni Pedro Penduko(The Ferocity and Venom of Pedro Penduko), 1974; and much later,Pedro Penduko, Episode II: The Return of the Comeback, 2000;and Da Adventures of Pedro Penduko, Enteng Kabisote 3: Okay Ka Fairy Ko, The Legend Goes On and On(You’re Okay, My Fairy), 2006.

He teamed up with child actor Niño Muhlach inPeter Pandesal, 1976, andBruce Liit(Little Bruce), 1978.

Using his monicker “Monza,” he produced and directedKato and directed parts 1 and 2 ofMay Butas sa Dingding(There’s a Hole in the Wall), 1988. He was also in the TV seriesKomiks(Comics),Maging Sino Ka Man(Whoever You May Be), and the “Shades” episode ofMaalaala Mo Kaya(Will You Remember), 2006.

At the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences Awards, he was given the Lou Salvador Sr Memorial Award in 2001, and a posthumous award in 2007. He also received aBest Actoraward from theCitizens Award for Television for his performanceinSuper Laff-In.

His last movie,Ataul for Rent(Casket for Rent), 2007, had yet to be released when he died of a heart attack at age 72. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

ZIALCITA, DANNY (Danilo Lagdameo Zialcita) aka DLZ. b. Manila 24 Nov 1940. d. Manila 10 Mar 2013. Movie director, screenwriter, and producer. He was the son of Benigno Labog Zialcita and Pilar Lagdameo. He was married to actor Leonor Vergara; they had two children: Michael and Elizabeth.

Danny Zialcita’s work as a director evolved through the decades. His early films were influenced by the James Bond hits: Lady Killer, 1965; Target Domino and Cabonegro, 1966; the Palos series Palos Strikes Again!, 1968, and Palos Fights Back, 1969; andBart Salamanca, 1969. He forayed into bomba in the early 1970s, megging Gutom (Hunger), 1970, and Hidhid (Selfish), 1971. While Lino Brocka depicted squalor and poverty, Zialcita’s characters are well-off, and his leading ladies, impeccably dressed. He gained renown for “glossy melodramas” marked by long titles and witty dialogue (dictated on the set sans script): Hindi sa Iyo ang Mundo, Baby Porcuna (The World Is Not Yours, Baby Porcuna), 1978; Ikaw at ang Gabi (You and the Night), 1979;Langis at Tubig (Oil and Water), 1980; Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan? (How Often Is Once?), 1982; Palabra de Honor (Word of Honor) andNagalit ang Buwan sa Haba ng Gabi (The Moon Got Angry at the Long, Long Night), 1983; and May Daga sa Labas ng Lungga (There’s a Rat Outside the Burrow), 1984.

He did movies about bisexuals, transvestites, and gays: Si Malakas, si Maganda at si Mahinhin (The Strong, the Beautiful and the Demure), 1980; Mahinhin vs Mahinhin (Demure vs Demure), 1981; T-Bird at Ako (Lesbian Love), 1982; and Lalakwe (Not Quite a Man), 1985; and sex comedies like May Lamok sa Loob ng Kulambo (There’s a Mosquito in the Net), 1984.

He also directed the hottest love teams of the 1980s: Vilma Santos and Dindo Fernando in Langis at Tubig; Sharon Cuneta and Gabby Concepcion in Dear Heart, 1981; Aga Muhlach and Janice de Belen in Bakit Madalas ang Tibok ng Puso? (Why Does the Heart Beat Often?) and Martin Nievera and Pops Fernandez in Always and Forever, 1986. His last known movie is Bakit Iisa ang Pag-ibig (Why I Only Love One), 1987, which paired off Snooky Serna with Concepcion. He produced five of the films he directed.

Zialcita received the Best Screenplay award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for his collaboration with Tom Adrales on Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan?. He was cited by the Metro Manila Film Festival for Best Story for Langis at Tubig. He was nominated by the Gawad Urian twice for screenplay and direction of Hindi sa Iyo ang Mundo, Baby Porcuna and Ikaw at ang Gabi. The FAMAS nominated him four times as Best Director for Hindi sa Iyo ang Mundo, Baby Porcuna, Langis at Tubig, Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan?, and Bakit Manipis ang Ulap? (Why Are Clouds Transparent?), 1985, and once for Best Screenplay for Nang Masugatan ang Gabi (When Night Was Wounded), 1984. Written by Nenuca Jose, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani and Ramon Sixto Nocon

ZOBEL, MARITA (Mary Ann Respall Blanch-Roxas) b. Iloilo City 18 Jun 1941. Television and movie actor. She is the fourth child of Joseph Blanch and Remedios Respall. She finished her high school education at Philippine Christian Colleges (now Philippine Christian University) and her first year in AB English at Far Eastern University. She is married to Reynaldo Roxas, with whom she has six children: Reynaldo Jr, Raymund, Maricel, Robert, Marisa, and Raymar.

Zobel started her acting career in 1957 when she became a contract star of LVN Pictures, one of the “Big Three” studios during the 1950s. She first appeared in Bad Boy, 1957, with Lou Salvador Jr, the “James Dean of the Philippines.” She also starred in Casa Grande (Mansion) and Faithful, 1958; Limang Dalangin (Five Prayers), 1959; and Dahlia, 1960. She was nominated Best Supporting Actress by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for Biyaya ng Lupa (Blessings of the Land), 1959, which won Best Picture and was screened in the 10th Berlin International Film Festival. She topbilled LVN Pictures’ Si Marita at ang Pitong Duwende (Marita and the Seven Dwarves), 1960, and Botika sa Baryo (Drugstore in the Village), 1960. When LVN Pictures stopped producing films in 1961, Zobel transferred to its sister company, Dalisay Pictures, where she appeared in Sikat Na, Siga Pa (Famous and Tough), 1961, with Nida Blanca, Nestor de Villa, and Diomedes Maturan.

Zobel also appeared in the films Ama … Bakit Mo Ako Pinabayaan? (Father … Why Have You Forsaken Me?), 1990, directed by Lino Brocka; and Carlo J. Caparas’s The Maggie de la Riva Story, 1994. In the 2000s, she worked in several TV drama series, like GMA Network’s Sana ay Ikaw na Nga (I Hope You’re the One), 2001-3, ABS-CBN’s Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin (You Are Everything to Me), 2005-6, and TV5’s Babaeng Hampaslupa (The Hapless Woman), 2011. Written by Kathrina Alvarez

ZSHORNACK, ZALDY (Jose Rizaldy Zshornack) b. Manila 30 Dec1937. d. 18 Nov 2002.Movie actor, producer. He finished high school at Manila Central University. He marriedactorShirley Gorospe, who was his leading lady in many of his pictures. They had two children, Gino and Garizaldy/Coco.

Zshornack first appeared inSisa,1951, a film directed by Gerardo de Leon for Premiere Productions.He had major roles inMontalan Brothers, 1956, and Libre Comida (Free Meal), 1957, but it was in Larry Santiago Production’sLo’ Waist Gang, 1956,which he made with Fernando Poe Jr, that he gained recognition.The sequels to this box-office hit areBakasyon Grande (Grand Vacation) andLos Lacuacheros (The Truants), 1957.

Zshornack’s first starring role was inBarumbado(Troublemaker), 1957. His other films include Ukulele Boy,Kamay ni Cain(Hand of Cain), Bakya Mo, Neneng(Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), Pusakal(Hardened Criminal), andTokyo,1960, 1957; Batang Piyer(Waterfront Kid), Anak ng Lasengga(Child of a Drunkard Woman),Wanted: Husband,andAsintado(Marksman), 1958;Viuda de Oro(Widow of Gold), 1960; andFalcon,1962.

His reel and real-life romance with favorite leading lady Shirley Gorospe resulted in a string of musicals and dramas centering on their love life, such asSweethearts,1957; Shirley, My Darling, You’reMy Everythingand the “Hongkong Story” episode inObra Maestra(Masterpiece),1958;Ang Kanyang Kamahalan (Your Royal Highness) and Pitong Gatang (Seven Chupas), 1959; Basta Pinoy(You Can Count on the Pinoy),Hongkong Honeymoon,andOutside the Kulambo(Outside the Mosquito Net), 1960;Fil-American Girl,1963;Pitong Gabi sa Hongkong(Seven Nights in Hong Kong), 1966;andP.S. I Love You, 1967.

He also producedPasong Diablo(Devil’s Pass) in 1961. When his contract with Premiere expired, Zshornack set up his own ZZ Productions, which made Bangketa(Sidewalk), 1966.

He freelanced with other movie companies. Among the films that he made during this period areApat na Aguila(Four Eagles), 1964, for Lea Productions; Nueva Vizcaya,1973, for Rosal Films;Rio Tigre (Tiger River), 1972, for Roda Films; Sacramento,1974, for Film Productions; andKutong Lupa (Earth Lice), 1976, for Rootman Productions.

He did only four films after 1978 because his family migrated to the USA. For two decades, they shuttled back and forth between the Philippines and the USA, returning for good to the Philippines only in the 1990s. His last known film isLabanang Lalake (Manly War), 1997.

Zshornack was nominated for his performance in various films; it was for De la Cruz, 1971, that he won Best Actor at the 2nd Quezon City Film Festival. Written by Galileo Zafra and Lena S. Pareja, updated by Susan Claire Agbayani

ZULUETA, DAWN (Marie Rachel Taleon Lagdameo) b. Manila 4 Mar 1969. Movie and television actor. Her parents are Jose Fazil Taleon and Maria Cleofe Salman. She studied at Assumption College for her elementary education, Colegio de Santa Rosa for high school, and the Karilagan finishing school in Magallanes. She is married to businessman/politician Anton Lagdameo Jr. They have two children.

She first appeared on television as a model for a toothpaste commercial, then guested on various TV shows as a singer and dancer. Vic del Rosario and Mina Aragon of Viva Films encouraged her to join the movie industry.

When she was just starting out in the movies, Zulueta immediately gained attention in the films Pangarap na Ginto (Golden Dream), 1990; Robin Good, 1991; and Akin ang Pangarap Mo (Your Dram Is Mine) and Hanggang May Buhay (Till There Is Life), 1992. Her notable films include Apoy sa Puso (Fire in the Heart) and Iisa Pa Lamang (Only One), 1992; The Maggie de la Riva Story … God, Why Me?, 1994; Patayin sa Sindak si Barbara (Kill Barbara with Fright), 1995; Ikaw Naman ang Iiyak (It’s Your Turn to Cry) and Bakit May Kahapon Pa? (Why Is There a Yesterday?), 1996; Filipinas, 2003; Magkaibigan (Friends), 2008; Sigwa (Rage), 2010; and Ang Nawawala (What Isn’t There), 2012. She also appeared in several television series, including Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), 1995; Encantadia, 2004; Walang Hanggan (My Eternal), 2012; and Dyesebel, 2014.

After being nominated at the Gawad Urian in 1990 for a supporting role in Kasalanan Bang Sambahin Ka? (Is It a Sin to Worship You?), she won a series of acting trophies the following year: Best Supporting Actress from the Film Academy of the Philippines and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Una Kang Naging Akin (You Were Mine First), 1991, and Best Actress from the FAMAS for Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven), 1991. In 1993, she represented the Philippine entry, Hihintayin Kita sa Langit, in the 4th ASEANFilm Festival in Bangkok, Thailand. In the same year, she won the Best Actress award at the Metro Manila Film Festival for Kung Mawawala Ka Pa (If I Lose You). The following year, she won the FAMAS Best Actress award for the same film. In 1995, she received Best Actress award from the Star Awards for Movies for Buhay ng Buhay Ko (Life of My Life), 1994. Written by Cristine Directo, updated by Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu
